title: Rev. Wellman Warner, A Retired Educator, 93
description: The Rev. Dr. Wellman Joel Warner, a retired social psychologist and an educator, died on Thursday at Griffin Hospital in Derby, Conn. He was 93 years old and lived in Shelton, Conn.

title: Ms. Schub Weds Michael DeCarlo
description: Elizabeth Schub, the daughter of Stephanie Rose of New York and Michael A. Schub of Garrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Peter DeCarlo, a son of Sandra Bratti and Libero DeCarlo, both of Toronto. Judge Richard M. Palmer of Family Court in Brooklyn performed the ceremony at the Anthology Film Archives in New York.

title: Marinovich Leads U.S.C. in Classic
description: The carefully planned brilliance of Todd Marinovich is no surprise anymore. The varied gifts and surprising calm of Marvin Graves were kept on a practice field in Syracuse before tonight.

title: U.P.S. Awarded Japanese Route
description: The United States Transportation Department selected the United Parcel Service Company to operate a new all-cargo route to Japan. A U.P.S. spokesman, Ken Sternad, said the company had not yet placed a value on the route but said the award was ''significant.'' Emery Worldwide Airlines was awarded backup authority.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about threats against Arab-Americans referred incorrectly to the editor of an Arabic-language newspaper in Detroit. He is Osama Siblani.

title: About New York;   A Shrine Is Born In the Incubator Of the 'Wretched'
description: To the side of a blacktop city park at First Avenue and East First Street, a bronze plaque affixed to a fiberglass rock has been drawing a varied stream of pilgrims all summer.

title: Brazil-I.M.F. Accord Near
description: Brazil's Economy Minister, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, said today that she expected Brazil to reach a preliminary agreement with the International Monetary Fund on an economic adjustment program and standby loan within a week.

title: Deluge of Gulf Satellite Data
description: Intelligence analysts can barely handle the deluge of photographs pouring into the Central Intelligence Agency from spy satellites monitoring Iraqi forces in the Persian Gulf, Aviation Week and Space Technology magazine reported. The respected industry journal will report in its Monday edition that experts at the C.I.A.'s National Photo Interpretation Center said as many as five spacecraft are observing the Middle East crisis zone. Data from the satellites periodically backs up because there is too much to analyze. Copies of the report were provided to reporters in Cape Canaveral.

title: Nynex Discloses Settlement
description: The Nynex Corporation, the parent of the New York Telephone Company, released more documents yesterday about lewd parties in Florida each year from 1984 to 1988 that were attended by a dozen of Nynex's purchasing managers and some suppliers' employees.

title: Beliefs
description: For practical purposes the incident began on page 22B of the July 6 issue of The Jewish Press. There, under the headline ''Congressman Barney Frank Excommunicated,'' was a 173-word item. It reported that on June 27 the Beth Din Zedek, identified as a ''High Rabbinic Ecclesiastical Court,'' had formally excommunicated Mr. Frank, who has publicly acknowledged his homosexuality and was recently reprimanded by the House of Representatives for using his office to help a male prostitute.

title: Bigger or Stronger Europe?
description: The two Germanys have signed their treaty of unification, the last major act of the German Democratic Republic before it disappears into a single Germany on Oct. 3. The question of its role in Europe, indeed the role of nation-states in Europe, becomes increasingly urgent as the countries to the East move on from the euphoria of freedom to the agony of transformation.

title: U.S. Guidelines Address Meatpacking Injuries
description: The Labor Department is establishing a test program in the meatpacking industry to protect workers from painful and crippling injuries caused by repetitive motions.

title: Paris Film House Loses Its 58th Street Home
description: The Paris Theater, one of America's most venerable theaters for French and other foreign films, went out of existence yesterday after nearly 42 years at 58th Street near Fifth Avenue.

title: MEDICARE FEE PLAN SENT TO CONGRESS
description: In what health officials called a major step toward overhauling Medicare's chaotic reimbursement system, the Secretary of Health and Human Services yesterday gave Congress a model national fee schedule for 1,400 commonly performed medical procedures.

title: Rebels in Liberia Are Said To Have Killed 200 Civilians
description: Rebels have killed about 200 foreigners in Liberia whose governments contributed soldiers to a West African force sent to end the nation's civil war, the Ghana News Agency reported today.

title: Tyson Cut Badly in Training, and Bout Is Put Off
description: Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion, suffered a severe cut above his right eye yesterday when he and a sparring partner, Greg Page, struck heads in a workout at Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City. Tyson was taken directly to the Margate, N.J., office of Dr. Ira Trocki, who used 48 stitches to close the cut.

title: Israelis Say Jordanian Planes Fly Reconnaissance for Iraq
description: Israeli intelligence says American-made Jordanian warplanes, working on behalf of the Iraqi Government, are flying reconnaissance missions along the Saudi border and passing information on American troop deployments to Baghdad, officials here said today.

title: Dead Hostage in Iraq Identified as Banker From New York State
description: The American businessman who died, apparently of a heart attack, while being held hostage in Iraq was identified yesterday as James L. Worthington Jr. of Woodstock, N.Y.

title: Hope and Fear in South Africa
description: The spiraling violence in black townships around Johannesburg is a grievous setback to hopes for a peaceful transition to democratic rule in South Africa. More than 500 people have already been killed in battles between supporters of Nelson Mandela and the African National Congress and the Inkatha movement of Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi. Paramount responsibility for restoring order lies not with them but with President F. W. de Klerk.

title: Letter: On Garbage;   Let the Free Market Tackle Solid Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: Norway Oil Reserves
description: Norway may be able to maintain its current annual oil output for another 40 years, double previous estimates, the state-funded Petroleum Directorate said today. A directorate spokesman, Jan Hagland, disclosed the new projections but declined to give further details.

title: Cult Leader Convicted of 5 Killings in Ohio
description: The leader of a religious cult has been convicted of killing a family of five last year and burying them on a farm where his group lived.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-6

title: The Tubes Of War
description: Saddam Hussein challenged President Bush and Prime Minister Thatcher to a television debate. Mr. Bush said this would be ridiculous. Mrs. Thatcher said it would be a warm January in London before she stooped to debating such creatures as Mr. Hussein.

title: Stretching Food in Iraq: Rationing and Feed-Grain Bread
description: Iraq is beginning to take severe measures to stretch food supplies. They include issuing coupons and setting up food distribution centers in preparation for the imposition of rationing today and encouraging urban dwellers to join their relatives in the countryside.

title: Richard Greenebaum, Ex-Business Editor, 78
description: Richard W. Greenebaum, a former business editor who in the 1950's managed the Brazilian operations of IBEC, a Rockefeller Brothers housing venture in Latin America, died on Sunday at Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead, L.I. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Remsenburg, L.I.

title: E.M.S. Consents To End Jail Escorts
description: Barely two weeks after the Dinkins administration began requiring a police escort for Emergency Medical Service workers entering the Rikers Island jail, the city and the workers' union agreed yesterday to end the plan.

title: A Clink Heard Round the Valley
description: Normally the introduction of a new chardonnay by a Napa Valley winery causes no great interest here, especially at harvest time when winemakers are working seven days a week and keeping a wary eye on the weather. But when the winery is Sutter Home, which starts selling its first chardonnay today, vintners from Modesto to Mendocino have to take notice.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Acquired Larry Andersen, pitcher, from Houston for Jeff Bagwell, third baseman. Optioned Daryl Irvine, pitcher, to Pawtucket of the International League.

title: Chamber Group's Schedule
description: The New York Chamber Symphony will open its season at the 92d Street Y with a program on Oct. 6 and 9 at 8 P.M. and Oct. 7 at 3 P.M. Gerard Schwarz will conduct David Diamond's ''Music for Romeo and Juliet,'' Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, and the original 1924 arrangement of Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' with Misha Dichter as the piano soloist. Tickets are $25 and $30 at the box office, 1395 Lexington Avenue, and through Y-Charge, 996-1100.

title: Call Columbus the First American Immigrant;   Proud and Thankful
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside Rikers Island: A Bloody Struggle for Control
description: Busy smokestacks reach above the sprawling squat buildings of red brick and not-yet-rusty metal on Rikers Island, testament to a decade of frantic building that has more than doubled the size of the nation's largest penal colony. Except for street names like E-1 and the endless loops of razor wire lining every fence, some blocks look from the outside like any industrial swath of Queens.

title: Cablevision's TV Subscribers on L.I. Are Furious, That's Who
description: To the Editor:

title: Study of Three Mile Island Accident Finds Negligible Increase In Cancer
description: Scientists said yesterday that they had found no convincing evidence that the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania in 1979 had caused a rise in cancer rates.

title: CHRONICLE
description: B'nai B'rith has a new two-year term president. On Wednesday, KENT E. SCHINER of Baltimore defeated RICHARD HEIDEMAN of Washington in close balloting at the group's convention in Dallas.

title: Be Kind To Editors? No Way
description: LEAD: Most everybody knows that Sept. 3 is Labor Day, but not many are aware that Sept. 1 is Be Kind To Editors and Writers Day. Once again this year, I won't be celebrating this obscure holiday. As a writer, I don't want to appear ungrateful for having my own day; I simply would rather not share it with editors.

title: Genentech Tie To Roche Near
description: The previously announced merger between Genentech Inc. and Roche Holding Ltd. is on track to be completed by the end of next week, the companies said today.

title: For Elderly Just Hanging On, An Oasis of Jobs Is Shrinking
description: ''I'm what you call a displaced homemaker,'' said Doris Gibson, who is 66 years old and by any measure poor. She traces her poverty to the day 13 years ago when her husband walked out on her, and her survival to a Federal paycheck that will be harder and harder for future Doris Gibsons to get.

title: Retired Officer Sought in Death Of Ex-Senator
description: The police are searching for a retired correction officer and college classmate of Vander L. Beatty in connection with the fatal shooting of the former State Senator in his campaign headquarters in Brooklyn on Thursday.

title: Dr. John P. Hagen, 82, Director Of First Major U.S. Space Effort
description: Dr. John P. Hagen, a solar radio astronomer who in the late 1950's directed the United States' first major space effort, died last Sunday at a convalescent home in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 82 years old and lived in Las Vegas.

title: Richard Ekstract Is Wed To Eileen B. Jaffe on L.I.
description: Eileen B. Jaffe, a daughter of Mildred Goodman of Margate, N.J., and the late Morris Jaffe, was married yesterday to Richard Ekstract, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mack Ekstract of North Miami Beach, Fla. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at the bridegroom's home in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Beef Cattle Price Rises To Record
description: The price of beef cattle rose to a record high of $75.40 for a hundred pounds in August because of strong summer demand and a reduced number of cattle slaughtered, the Agriculture Department said today. The previous record price was $74.60 set in April, a department official said.

title: A Sharp McEnroe Overcomes Chesnokov
description: John McEnroe, a fallen but not forgotten star, played one of the best matches of his latest comeback attempt last night to gain the round of 16 of the United States Open, a tournament he has won four times but not since 1984.

title: Agassi Is Hit With a $3,000 Fine
description: Yesterday was a bad day for Andre Agassi, the men's fourth-seeded player, and he didn't even play.

title: Cambodia Gives Partial Backing To U.N. Plan for Ending the War
description: The Vietnamese-backed Cambodian Government today gave its qualified endorsement to a new United Nations peace plan under which it would share power with the three guerrilla groups it has been fighting for 11 years.

title: Judges Too Often Perpetuate Child Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Astros' Two-Out Rally Stuns Pirates
description: Glenn Wilson's single capped a three-run, two-out rally in the ninth inning tonight as the Houston Astros defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-2.

title: Iraq Sets New Limits On Freeing Captives And Relocates Some
description: The Iraqi Government put new conditions today on the departure of others in a group of 237 foreign women and children, including 14 Americans, that Iraq has said would be allowed to leave the country.

title: Special Phone Services Facing Curb
description: The Federal Communications Commission is proposing rules aimed at eliminating overcharges and other abuses by companies that connect callers at hotels, motels, hospitals and similar public places to long-distance carriers. Some consumer advocates say the rules do not go far enough.

title: Hawaii Has to Find Energy Where It Can
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents;   Improving Chip Making By X-Ray Lithography
description: Herbert A. Waggener, a researcher at Lepton Inc. in Murray Hill, N.J., has patented a new kind of mask that makes it easier to produce computer chips through the still-experimental process of X-ray lithography.

title: Gasoline Up As Supplies Stay Tight
description: Wholesale gasoline prices jumped again yesterday, but crude oil prices rose more modestly. Demand for gasoline remains strong, because of shortages of refinery capacity, traders said.

title: Review/Film;   Cat Lover With a Problem: Asthma
description: Between the time ''The Lemon Sisters'' was scheduled to open, a year ago, and its actual opening yesterday, a story surfaced that this much worked-over film would be renamed so no one would make cheap remarks like, ''It's a lemon.'' Relax; you won't hear any bad lemon jokes here. Just imagine Diane Keaton at her most hysterical, as an asthmatic cat lover who returns from a stay in the hospital to find that her two best friends have thrown her a cat-free welcome-home party. ''Those cats need me!'' she yells. ''Those cats love me!'' You can make up your own lemon jokes.

title: Federated Stores
description: The Federated and Allied department store chains said they intended to negotiate claims filed by the Internal Revenue Service for payment of more than $500 million in additional taxes. Federated Stores Inc., the retailers' parent company, said the claims were based on an I.R.S. audit of the company for 1984 to 1988. The audit was part of Federated's Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. The issues in dispute include the tax deductibility of merger and takeover expenses related to the Campeau Corporation's acquisitions of Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation.

title: Aid for Trapped Mideast Workers
description: One month after Iraq overran Kuwait, American companies are struggling to maintain increasingly tenuous communications links with employees trapped in the two countries and are reluctant to say much about their efforts for fear of endangering those workers.

title: Canadiens Sign Savard To Three-Year Contract
description: He spent 10 superb seasons with the Chicago Blackhawks, and when they traded him two months ago, Denis Savard looked forward to several more good ones with his next organization, the Montreal Canadiens. Yesterday, veteran player and new team took a step in that direction by agreeing on a three-year contract. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: U.S. Says Gulf Moves' Cost Will Far Exceed $25 Billion
description: The worldwide burden-sharing program for the Persian Gulf operation will require tens of billions of dollars in financial aid to third-world countries, repayment for trade lost in the embargo against Iraq, donations of fuel to American military forces and other contributions, Administration officials said today.

title: Call Columbus the First American Immigrant;   Don't Blame Discoverer
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Says Hospital Statistics Show Use of Cocaine May Have Peaked
description: In what Federal researchers called a strong indication that the nation's cocaine epidemic may have peaked, Government figures released today show that cocaine-related visits to hospital emergency rooms dropped 4 percent in the first quarter of the year.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about American acquisitions in Europe included an incorrect report from Translink's European Deal Review about a transaction between the GTE Corporation and Thorn Lighting in Britain. While GTE is discussing the acquisition of Thorn Lighting, no agreement has been reached.

title: Giants and Marshall Settle But Talks on Taylor Stall
description: Leonard Marshall, one of the two holdout Giants, signed a three-year contract extension today worth $2.6 million. The signing came only hours after negotiations broke off between the Giants and the other absent defensive star, Lawrence Taylor.

title: Patents;   Saving Fingernails On Flip-Top Cans
description: Two inventors in Southern California obtained a patent this week on a flip top for aluminum cans that they said is resealable and can be opened without damaging fingernails.

title: GERMANYS CODIFY DETAILS OF UNION
description: After weeks of intense political maneuvering, representatives of the two Germanys signed a treaty of almost 1,000 pages today detailing the mechanics of reunification, now only 33 days away.

title: Quebec Renews Effort To End Indian Protest
description: The work to remove the barricades set up by Mohawk Indians across the Mercier Bridge resumed today, after being halted on Thursday in the seven-week-old standoff between the Canadian Government and Mohawk Indians.

title: U S West Cable In Joint Venture
description: U S West Cable Communications and United International Holdings have committed $100 million to a joint venture to acquire and develop overseas cable television systems, the companies announced. The new venture, called United Communications International, will initially acquire an 86 percent interest in Norkabel, the second-largest cable television operator in Norway, and a 25 percent interest in Swedish Cable and Dish, the second largest operator in Sweden.

title: Key Witness Against Barry Gets Term of Probation
description: A Federal district judge has sentenced a key witness in the trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington to five years' probation on drug charges.

title: Space Shuttle Faces Up to Week's Delay Over Electrical Snag
description: Space agency officials said today that the launching of the space shuttle Columbia might be delayed up to a week so that a failed electrical device on the payload can be fixed.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday headed ''Filling the Void'' misstated the amount of oil that may be drawn by India and Malaysia from reserves to help offset world oil shortages. It is 600,000 barrels a day, not 400,000.

title: Tyson Bout Postponed
description: Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion, suffered a severe cut above his right eye when he and a sparring partner hit heads yesterday during a workout at Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City. Forty-eight stitches were required to close the cut. Because of his injury, Tyson's bout against Alex Stewart, which had been scheduled for Sept. 22, has been postponed. Page 42.

title: Dow Up 21.04 on Slowest Day of the Year
description: Stock trading slowed yesterday to the lowest point of the year, and the Dow Jones industrial average chalked up a modest advance, ending with its first weekly gain since mid-July.

title: Utility's Rates Tied to Saving Of Electricity
description: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

title: Samuel H. Mayes, 73; Was Principal Cellist
description: Samuel Houston Mayes, the principal cellist of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Philadelphia Orchestra for many years, died on Aug. 24 at his home in Mesa, Ariz. He was 73 years old.

title: Premed, Prelaw, Pretennis
description: Todd Martin sat in the players' lounge at the United States Open the other day, soaking up the glitz and glamour of a world in which he finished his debut about 45 minutes earlier. The 1990 Big Ten tennis player of the year had played the first match of his professional career and lost in straight sets, 7-6, 6-3, 7-6, to Jean-Philippe Fleurian.

title: Lawrence J. Kenney; Military Vicar Was 60
description: The Most Rev. Lawrence J. Kenney, Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese for the Military Services, died Thursday at the residence of John Cardinal O'Connor in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in Washington.

title: G.M. Unit Agrees To Buy Insurer
description: A unit of the General Motors Corporation agreed to buy the Navco Corporation insurance holding company from Crum & Forster, a unit of the Xerox Corporation, for an undisclosed price. The General Motors Acceptance Corporation subsidiary said Navco specializes in personal lines of insurance and has a record of strong growth and profitability.

title: No Need Seen to Tap Oil Reserve
description: Saying that oil supplies remained nearly in balance with demand despite the embargo against Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, the International Energy Agency, which represents 21 industrial nations, decided today not to recommend that members begin drawing down emergency reserves.

title: A Jazz Musician Turns Homeward
description: Abdullah Ibrahim, the South African pianist, tells a story about a man who collected birds, among them a rare bird from Africa. When the collector planned a trip to Africa, he asked the bird if there was anything he could bring back. ''The best thing to do is to let me out of this cage,'' the bird said, but the man refused. In Africa, members of the bird's family asked about their cousin; when he told them their relative was in a cage, one of the birds fell out of a tree, dead. Upon his return, the collector told the caged bird what had happened, and the bird collapsed, just as his relative had. The man took the bird out of the cage, and suddenly it revived, flying off. As it escaped, the bird said, ''Thank you for the information.''

title: De Klerk Asks Ruling Party To Open Rolls to All Races
description: President F. W. de Klerk urged today that people of all races be admitted to the governing National Party, which won power more than four decades ago as the racially exclusive guarantor of Afrikaner supremacy.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: Football;   Bears' Back Cleared
description: Johnny Bailey, a rookie running back with the Chicago Bears, rushed for 65 yards on 11 carries in a victory over Buffalo on Thursday night. Yesterday he found himself in the clear again when a judge in Houston released him from the final 10 months of a probation imposed on him in 1986.

title: Connecticut Governor Orders Spending Cut
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today ordered state agencies to cut spending by 5 percent to help offset a $379.4 million deficit that has accumulated in the budget year that began just two months ago.

title: New Zealand Bank Takeover
description: The high- profile merchant bank Fay, Richwhite & Company, founded by the backer of New Zealand's America's Cup yachting challenge, Sir Michael Fay, was taken over on Wednesday by Capital Markets for $140 million.

title: In Moscow, Gulf Crisis Ranks Second
description: Although Iraq is closer to the Soviet border than New York is to Boston, the gulf crisis that has fixated the rest of the world seems almost peripheral to residents of this capital of competing crises.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about Bargemusic Ltd. referred incorrectly to a flutist who appears there. He is Ransom Wilson.

title: Manila Delays Tariff Changes
description: President Corazon Aquino announced on Thursday that she would postpone for six months the imposition of significant changes in tariffs.

title: SOLDIER ACQUITTED IN PANAMA SLAYING
description: An Army paratrooper was acquitted today of charges that he murdered an unarmed Panamanian man at a roadblock during the United States invasion of Panama last year.

title: INSIDE
description: Soldier Acquitted in Killing

title: 2 Held in Slaying of a Bronx Prosecutor
description: A 21-year-old school janitor and his teen-age friend were charged yesterday in the fatal shooting of a Bronx prosecutor who accidentally stepped into what the police called a turf war over drugs a block from the county courthouse.

title: Edmund G. Love, an Author, 78; Wrote 'Subways Are for Sleeping'
description: Edmund G. Love, a writer whose book ''Subways Are for Sleeping'' was the basis for the Broadway musical of the same name, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Flint, Mich. He was 78 years old.

title: Prices of Long-Term Bonds Continue to Fall
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds continued to decline yesterday in an abbreviated pre-holiday session, largely on fears that rising oil prices would stimulate inflation. But prices of Treasury bills and short-term notes continued to rise on hopes that the Federal Reserve would have to lower interest rates soon to stimulate the economy.

title: No Decision on Jets Quarterback
description: With nine days to go before the football games in his rookie season as Jets head coach begin to count in the standing, Bruce Coslet still hasn't decided on a starting quarterback. Ken O'Brien? Tony Eason?

title: Patents;   A System To Keep Car From Rolling
description: Two Florida inventors have patented a ''creep control'' system to prevent cars with automatic transmissions that are stopped in traffic from rolling forward when the driver inadvertently eases pressure on the brake.

title: Johnson's Hit Beats Giants as Mets Get 3 in 9th
description: A couple of minor trades had left the dugout shaken up. One major comeback left it nearly torn apart.

title: Pearl Sacerdote Artist, 68
description: Pearl Sacerdote, an artist whose works in oils, acrylics, collage and mixed media were exhibited widely in the last two decades, died Wednesday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. She was 68 years old, and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx and in East Hampton, L.I. Her family said she died of an immune-system disorder. Mrs. Sacerdote, who was born in Brooklyn and grew up in Mount Vernon, N.Y., is survived by her husband, Dr. Paul Sacerdote; two sons, Dr. Alan Sacerdote of Brooklyn and Marc Sacerdote of Manhattan; two brothers, Nathan Quittell of North Lauderdale, Fla., and Jules Quittell of New Rochelle, N.Y., and four grandchildren.

title: Fuhr Used Cocaine, Paper Says
description: The Edmonton Oilers goaltender Grant Fuhr used cocaine for about seven years, but says he has been drug free since spending two weeks in a substance-abuse center last summer, according to a published report.

title: No Headline
description: The Teaching Revival ''I think there's a lot of anecdotal evidence that many of the brightest people are being turned away from teaching. . . . I've had superintendents tell me, 'I don't want those people in my school.' '' - C. Emily Feistritzer, director of the National Center for Education Information

title: Despite Complaints, Solicitation by Phone or Mail Is Growing
description: Your name, address and telephone number are no longer yours to give out only as you choose. Direct marketers all over the nation have them and are using them with increasing intensity to sell products and services.

title: Getting Your Money Faster
description: New Federal rules go into effect today that reduce the maximum time banks, savings and loan associations and credit unions can hold most deposited checks before crediting them to your account. Local checks cannot be held now for more than two business days, and nonlocal checks for more than five business days.

title: KEY RATES
Reds Acquire Doran
description: Bill Doran, after turning down a trade to the Mets, was sent by the Houston Astros to the Cincinnati Reds yesterday for three players to be named.

title: First Union Selling Bank Branches
description: The First Union Corporation said it would sell 100 bank branches to an affiliate of the Pitney Bowes Credit Corporation for $116 million and lease the branches back under a long-term lease agreement.

title: Inmate Penalties Called 'Draconian'
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union and the Legal Aid Society sent a letter yesterday to the Correction Commissioner, Allyn R. Sielaff, imploring him to stop ''unfair disciplinary proceedings'' against inmates stemming from the Aug. 14 disturbance at Rikers Island.

title: Books of The Times;   Christopher Columbus In Magical Realism
description: The Harp and the Shadow

title: Rivera Slam Sinks Yankees
description: There is only a month or so left, but there is no race for the Yankees in Fenway Park. Not this summer.

title: U.S. READY TO SEND ISRAELIS NEW ARMS AS SIGNAL TO IRAQ
description: The Bush Administration is preparing to transfer as much as $1 billion worth of advanced weapons to Israel to buttress the country's defenses against Iraq and address Israeli concerns about recent arms sales to Saudi Arabia, Administration officials said today.

title: Harry Starr, 71, Dies; A Trucking Executive
description: Harry A. Starr, an executive in New York's garment trucking industry, died on Aug. 17 at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 71 years old.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American International Group Inc., New York an insurance company, said it completed the acquisition of International Lease Finance Corp., Beverly Hills, Calif., a jet-aircraft leasing company. Each outstanding common share of International Lease was converted into the right to receive $32.50.

title: The Queen Who Sets Up the Curses
description: The rains of August had been taking their toll on ''Richard III,'' the New York Shakespeare Festival's production in Central Park, canceling or halting performances and making forecasts the topic of moment.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They're all in hiding because they know what the Iraqis are going to do to them. They're going to round them up in their houses. They knock on the door at midnight and take people away. We never hear from them again and they are interned.'' - Barbara Badine of the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, referring to Americans there. [1:4.]

title: State Senator James Donovan, 66, Leader on Education Policy, Dies
description: James H. Donovan, a longtime State Senator who played an important role in shaping state policy on education and transportation during the last 25 years, died today at his home in Chadwicks, near Utica. He was 66 years old.

title: Economic Cooperation for East Europe
description: Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland are now vigorously competing to be the first to throw off their remaining Communist shackles and free their markets. In time, these steps will benefit them economically. More immediately, they'll help attract Western capital and assistance.

title: Managua Journal;   Low-Tech Limbs for a Poor Land's War-Maimed
description: At a shady hilltop complex overlooking Lake Managua, Francisco Franco Espinoza went for a walk this week.

title: T.W.A. in 'Frequent Flier' Ruling
description: A Federal appeals court ruled on Thursday that Trans World Airlines could prohibit broker sales and other transfers of ''frequent flier'' discount coupons. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit at least temporarily set back T.W.A.'s attempt to enforce the ban through an injunction and lawsuit seeking damages against a company that buys unused coupons and sells them at cut rates.

title: Tisch Family Invests in 3 Banks
description: Laurence A. Tisch and members of his family have acquired sizable stakes in three bank holding companies whose stocks have fallen on hard times recently: Continental Bank, Baybanks and Equimark.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on the Health page on Aug. 2 about electroshock therapy referred incorrectly to the deputy chief of biological psychiatry at the New York State Psychiatric Institute. He is Dr. Harold Sackeim, a psychologist. c

title: Arizona Pact By Pacificorp
description: Pacificorp, the utility based in Portland, Ore., that last year bid $2.08 billion to acquire the Arizona Public Service Company, agreed today to several long-term transactions with the Arizona utility worth a total of $222 million.

title: No War Unless Iraq Strikes, U.S. Gulf Commander Says
description: The commander of American forces in Saudi Arabia said today that there would be no fighting here unless Iraq launched an attack.

title: 100 Years of the Starling
description: The year was 1890 when an eccentric drug manufacturer named Eugene Schieffelin entered New York City's Central Park and released some 60 European starlings he had imported from England. In 1891 he loosed 40 more. Schieffelin's motives were as romantic as they were ill fated: he hoped to introduce into North America every bird mentioned by Shakespeare.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD>

title: Disney Sues an Executive
description: The Walt Disney Company sued a former top movie executive on Thursday and accused him of trying to lure away other Disney employees and projects after the company released him from a contract.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It may not actually be the last weekend of summer, but for the vast majority of people Labor Day means the end of the season.

title: Recycling Juice Boxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush's Son Files Request
description: President Bush's son Neil has asked an administrative law judge to dismiss the Government's case against him, which charges him with conflict of interest as a director of a failed savings and loan, according to documents made available today.

title: McGee in N.L. Race
description: Willie McGee, with a .335 average set in statistical stone, could win the National League batting title while finishing the season with the Oakland Athletics.

title: Toyota Is Raising Prices On Lexus
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation's Lexus car division said prices of 1991 Lexus models would increase an average of 3.3 percent, or about $1,150 after adjusting for additional standard equipment on the LS400 model. Lexus, whose LS400 and ES250 models were introduced nearly a year ago, said the increase in price of 1991 models reflects the continuing growth of its operations and product development costs.

title: U.N. Secretary General Meets With Iraqi Official
description: A new diplomatic effort to persuade Iraq to pull out of Kuwait began here today with five hours of talks between Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations, and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq.

title: Comatose Woman's Lawyer Seeks to Reopen Death Issue
description: A lawyer for a comatose woman who was the central figure in a major Supreme Court ruling this summer has asked a state court to allow removal of her life-support system, citing new evidence that she would not want to continue living in her condition.

title: New Jersey's Wealthy School Districts Gird for Battle on Aid
description: Superintendents of New Jersey's wealthy suburban school districts are mounting a counterattack to the state's new school-financing formula, which by the mid-90's will strip their districts of the millions in state aid they now receive.

title: Japanese Finance Ministry In Actions Against 4 Firms
description: In another in a string of recent cases involving abuses in the stock market, the Ministry of Finance today ordered suspensions for four securities firms, including a unit of Citicorp, for aiding a speculator's manipulation of a stock last April.

title: Missouri Executes Man Convicted of Killing 5
description: A man convicted of five murders was put to death by injection early today for killing an elderly woman 11 years ago.

title: Gorbachev Says 6 Months Is Needed to Prepare for Market Economy
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that his country would need a six-month stabilization period to control inflation and resolve emergency consumer shortages before embarking on the transition to a market economy.

title: Bridge
description: The World Bridge Championships beginning here on Sunday will be by far the biggest ever staged, thanks to the efforts of Jimmy Ortiz-Patino, former president of the World Bridge Federation, Jose Damiani, president of the European Bridge League, and many others. For the first time, almost all players can compete regardless of experience.

title: Dr. Lot Page, 67, Dies; Led Program on Aging
description: Dr. Lot B. Page, a physician associated with the National Institute on Aging who also served as chief of medicine at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Manchester, N.H., died on Wednesday at his home in Lincoln, Mass. He was 67 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1990
description: Oil and the Mideast

title: William C. Schraft Jr., Pathologist, 69
description: William C. Schraft Jr., a pathologist and president of the Westchester County Board of Health, died on Thursday while vacationing with his family in Stonington, Conn. He was 69 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: Patents;   A 'Tea Bag' for Brewing Coffee in Microwave
description: Gideon P. Serbu, a retired astrophysicist for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, has invented what resembles a tea bag for brewing fresh coffee one cup at a time in a microwave oven.

title: Downturn in Canada
description: Canada's economy shrank at an annual rate of 1.6 percent from April to June, the Government said today. The gross domestic product, adjusted for inflation, showed the decline, after growing at a 2.2 percent rate in the first quarter, the Canadian statistics agency said. Housing construction and new-car sales were both sharply lower. Business spending on plant and equipment, which had kept the economy humming despite weak consumer demand, declined 2.9 percent.

title: Job Buyout At Chrysler
description: Hundreds of union workers at the Chrysler Corporation punched out today for the last time, after accepting buyouts from the auto maker intended to reduce the need for layoffs.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With the Choices in Headphones
description: Picking the right headphones isn't easy. You have to consider not just how they sound, but how they feel and how you're going to use them.

title: In the Saudi Desert: Heat, Sand and Restlessness
description: In the baking heat of eastern Saudi Arabia, Marine tank emplacements dot the desert sand. Four-man crews sit under camouflage nets with their M-60 tanks, which lie dug into the earth to make them less visible against the horizon.

title: Mideast Crisis Puts New Spotlight On an Idle Oil Plant in California
description: After standing unused and mothballed for nearly three years on a desolate bluff over the central coast of California, the Gaviota Oil and Gas Plant here is emerging as a key element in the American response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Endangered Bulbs
description: Spring flowers - next spring's - should be on the minds of gardeners now. It's time to make planting plans and to order bulbs. All bulbs, including the three showiest, trumpet daffodils, tulips and hyacinths, must be planted over the next two months. Although most small-flowered species are grown in nursery fields, some bulbs are being dug from the Mediterranean region, which threatens their survival. Conservationists, including the World Wildlife Fund, are asking gardeners who wish to avoid purchasing threatened-species bulbs to avoid packages marked ''Wild Origin.'' Here are some endangered bulbs. $ BULB DESCRIPTION Galanthus elwesii Giant snowdrop with emerald green blotches. Eranthis hymelis Winter aconite opens early with tiny buttercuplike flowers. Anemone blanda Grecian windflower propagated by many growers, but some are still being dug from the wild. Cyclamen species Dainty windswept flower grown domestically, though some are still dug from the wild.

title: Your Money;   Ways to Protect Disabled Heirs
description: Families who have disabled or impaired children need to take particular care in estate planning. Generally, this means putting assets in trust for those who cannot handle their own financial affairs, but coming to grips with the matter within the family, setting up the trust and choosing the right trustee can be nettlesome.

title: Life in Emptied Kuwait City: Diplomats Long for Comforts
description: The broad, sweeping boulevards of Kuwait's capital were all but deserted today except for clusters of Iraqi troops.

title: ECONOMISTS FAULT POPULATION FIGURE FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: Could a city that enjoyed its greatest economic boom since World War II, experienced a dizzying rise in housing prices, attracted the largest wave of immigration since the days of Ellis Island and seemed to grow more crowded in every conceivable way actually be smaller now than it was in 1980?

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Thursday misidentified the new position of Samuel A. Schulhof at the General Electric Research and Development Center. He is director of the center's new environmental research unit, not of the center itself.

title: Cardiac Trouble Tied To Pollution
description: Levels of carbon monoxide sometimes experienced by urban dwellers can induce potentially fatal disturbances of heart rhythms in cardiac patients during exercise, a new study has shown.

title: Sandinista Salon: Ortega Woos Publishers
description: Even for these post-Cold War days, it was an unlikely scene. Former Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the ideological enemy of the Reagan years, comfortably ensconced in an Upper East Side mansion, seated in an armchair upholstered in golden silk, talking to American corporate officers about a six-figure deal.

title: Seles Upset on Center Court in 1-6, 6-1, 7-6 Loss to Italian
description: The first time Linda Ferrando stood across the court from Monica Seles, in practice earlier this year in Chicago, she made so little impression that Seles failed to remember it ever happened.

title: Ford Shutdowns
description: The Ford Motor Company said it plans to close two assembly plants for one week beginning Sept. 10 because of a shortage of dealer orders for the Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz cars made at the plants. Sales of the Topaz are off 21.9 percent so far this year compared with 1989, while sales of the nearly identical Tempo have fallen 1.5 percent in 1990. The shutdown will idle about 4,200 hourly workers at Ford's assembly plants in Kansas City, Mo, and Louisville, Ky., the company said.

title: U.S. Is Said to Quietly Encourage A Kuwaiti Resistance Movement
description: A growing armed resistance to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, managed from an air base in the Saudi Arabian desert, has won American encouragement and advice, United States officials said this week. But the officials insisted that neither the Central Intelligence Agency nor the American military is directly supporting the movement.

title: Call Columbus the First American Immigrant
description: To the Editor:

title: Bikes Just Lack 'Curb Appeal'
description: The folks who run the World Trade Center stole my friend Jon's bicycle. They smashed the lock, then demanded $30 to give the bike back.

title: Shearson and 2 Ex-Workers Face Fraud Charges in Ohio
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and two former employees in Ohio have been accused of fraud in the sale of securities, Ohio officials said today.

title: Balancing Act Is Expected of Florio's New Chief of Staff
description: Faced with an angry outcry over tax increases, Gov. Jim Florio today appointed a new chief of staff and in doing so signaled a turn both toward more openness and a closer coordination of politics and government.

title: Bruins Sign Bourque
description: The All-Star defenseman Ray Bourque signed a new four-year contract with the Boston Bruins yesterday.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Monday is Labor Day. Here are holiday schedules:

title: CHRONICLE
description: While there is a plethora of people spending August's final weekend at their shoreside homes, SPIKE LEE, the movie producer, will have to wait a bit for his. Mr. Lee is having a retreat built near the Farm Neck Golf Club in Oak Bluffs on Martha's Vineyard.

title: Jews at U. of Wisconsin Are Victims of Bias Acts
description: Jewish students returning this week to the University of Wisconsin for the fall semester were the latest victims in a wave of anti-Semitic acts that began here in mid-July.

title: Colombian Guerrillas Forsake the Gun for Politics
description: It is Friday night, and the guerrillas have put down their AK-47's and gone dancing in the local saloons. Ten miles away, Government soldiers are playing cards by the soft wash of the Caribbean coast or standing a loose watch behind sandbagged gun positions.

title: Why Moscow Must Walk the Tightrope in Iraq;   Soldiers Exist to Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Ancient Burial Cave Is Found in Aleutian Islands
description: An ancient burial cave containing the mummified remains of more than 30 people has been found in the Aleutian Islands. The discovery is being called one of the most important in Alaska in years.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Gone Fishing, To Catch A Dream
description: LEAD: YOU can see their smiles in the rain as they scurry home to their mothers' kitchens. The dirty boys with dirty faces. The young adventurers clad in mud and worms and fishing hooks. The sportsmen, proud of their catch, the catch of the day: a 12-inch bass, a shiny rainbow, half a dozen blue gills and stories for a lifetime.

title: Settling Up
description: In the weeks, months and, finally, years after Michael Stewart died following his arrest by the transit police, the New York City Medical Examiner waffled on the question of whether foul play was involved and the police insisted that they had done no wrong. But the fact remained that after Mr. Stewart was arrested in 1983 for writing subway graffiti, he was delivered hogtied and bruised to Bellevue Hospital, where he died 13 days later. There followed heated allegations and denials of police brutality and racism - Mr. Stewart was black, the 11 officers involved in his arrest were white. The Stewart family sued, asking $40 million in damages. Last week, Millard and Carrie Stewart and their surviving children, Jon and Lisha Cole Stewart, settled out of court for a total of $1.7 million. Money changed hands and the Stewarts voiced vindication, but the police and city officials continued to insist they were blameless in the matter of Michael Stewart.

title: Beauty;   The Next Step
description: You'd think that after the last batch of high-concept fitness fads - the high- and low-impact aerobics, and their strange cousin , the multi-impact - there couldn't be much else for a body to do. But impact is out and verticality is the buzzword of the moment. This is not to say that rock climbing and hang gliding have hit the mainstream. Rather, it's the prosaic step that is providing all this excitement. Born in the stadium, where Montana wanna-be's have been loping up and down bleachers for years, the step workout is the latest answer to aerobic tedium and body-burnout. The step itself, which is just another term for the tried-and-true bench, is an inoffensive enough piece of equipment. Reebok, the most visible promoter of the new exercise, offers studios a 4-inch-high platform, made of polyethylene and covered with non-skid rubber, which can be raised to 12 inches with four sets of blocks.

title: A New Bergdorf's And a Yacht Party
description: Luminaries of the Women's International Tennis Association moved from the playing courts of Flushing Meadow to the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza hotel on Monday for their awards dinner to benefit the Greater New York March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation.

title: Gina H. Sockolow Is to Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Sockolow of Tenafly, N.J., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter GINA HENRIETTA SOCKOLOW and WILLIAM BRIAN BURGESS, a son of Gwendolyn Russell Burgess of Tampa, Fla., and Donald Eugene Burgess of Homewood, Ala.

title: Doreen A.C. Bottini and John H. Rivell Married
description: DOREEN A. C. BOTTINI, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Bottini of Colts Neck, N.J., was married yesterday to JOHN H. RIVELL, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Rivell of Oldwick, N.J. The Rev. Kevin Keelan performed the ceremony at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Marlboro, N.J.

title: Even for J. Crew, the Mail-Order Boom Days Are Over
description: Fourteen times a year it shows up, sandwiched between electric bills and sweepstakes come-ons, prompting a flash of recognition. There are more than 100 pages decorated with exultant models in rugby shirts, twill trousers and espadrilles, presented in meticulously shot photographs - the culmination of 8,000 rolls of film a year.

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from a visit to Mexico that included a round trip by train between Mexico City and San Miguel de Allende. The fare charged by the tour operator was $40 a person. The Mexican tickets listed the price as 33,300 pesos. At the rate of exchange at the time - 2,660 pesos to $1 - the actual price was $12.52; the markup was more than 200 percent.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Poet in Full Rig

title: Melissa Cleveland Weds Roy Salameh
description: At the Plaza hotel in New York yesterday, MELISSA CAROL CLEVELAND, a daughter of Dr. Richard J. Cleveland of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Marjorie Hanna Cleveland, was married to ROY JOSEPH SALAMEH, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Salameh of Beirut, Lebanon. Acting Justice Diane S. Lebedeff of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Works in Progress;   Going With the Flow
description: The volcano Kilauea, which has been erupting since 1983 on the island of Hawaii, is by now producing a continuous lava flow that has ravaged the coastal town of Kalapana, destroying more than 160 homes. Among the people still there is R. C. Leimana Pelton, a sculptor who has recently moved his workshop to Kalapana expressly to facilitate his art. In 1986, Pelton, who formerly worked in wood, turned his full-time attention to another medium - molten lava. ''The flow has completely inundated the community,'' says Pelton. ''One minute, I'm helping people move their lives out of the way of the flow. The next minute, I turn around and try to be creative with the same flow. That's produced a different feeling for me about the work I do.''

title: 5 Arts Awards Announced
description: Four academicians and a documentary film maker have each been awarded a $5,000 Charles Frankel Prize by the National Endowment for the Humanities, for ''bringing history, literature, philosophy and other humanities topics to the general public.''

title: Presto! Science Joins the Birthday Party
description: Welcome to a ''Mrs. Wizard'' science birthday party. If the idea seems a contradiction in terms - Science? Fun? Birthday? - Mrs. Krever's scientific sleight of hand soon dispels any idea that science has to be boring.

title: A 'Shirley Valentine' of Substance
description: During Willy Russell's crafty monodrama, ''Shirley Valentine,'' the summer season's final play at the Westport Country Playhouse, the audience is drawn into Shirley's release from intimidation.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q&A column on Aug. 19 about calling cruise ships misstated the telephone number for Comsat, a satellite communications company. It is (800) 627-4728.

title: AIDS Is Not the Only Political Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Tearfully, Romanians Recall a Wartime Partition
description: A village teacher spoke in a flat voice of ''savagery worthy of the Mongol invaders,'' and old peasant women in the large crowd wept copiously. Then a mixed choir sang a hymn to ''our heroic martyrs,'' and eight Orthodox priests intoned a prayer.

title: New Sunday Duty
description: HE spent 11 seasons playing football for the Cleveland Browns, but now Cody Riesien has found a more peaceful way to spend his Sunday afternoons.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing;   Off Urban Beaten Paths, Miniature Golf Beckons
description: Although New York City has never been known as a mecca for golfers, it has, in fact, 13 public golf courses. Rarer, however, are miniature golf courses, those toy-sized attractions that seem as much a part of suburbia as their larger, greener cousins.

title: AIDS Is Not the Only Political Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Mothers Are Taught Skills for Better Jobs
description: LEAD: GRACE MAYS, 26 years old, a single parent of two, wanted a better job but had neither the time nor the money to invest in courses to improve her skills. But today, just a year after graduating from a free program offered by Mutual of New York, she has a new job at the Englewood Health Department, closer to her home and offering better pay.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Filling In Those Bare Spots on the Family Tree
description: LEAD: EARLIER this year, my 6-year-old son had as homework the job of drawing a family tree, but the spaces he drew for his great-grandfathers, my grandfathers, were empty.

title: A Balanced Budget Would Finish Us Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week;   Why Are Baseball Brawls So Common?
description: The reason for all the brawls is quite simple. Baseball players are too sensitive. Any ball that hits a player regardless of how unintentional it may have been is taken as an assault for which there must be immediate retaliation.

title: Burt Hunton: Dress Form Designer
description: When Donna Karan, Bill Blass, Calvin Klein and other designers fit their clothes on pale linen-covered forms in the human shape, many of the forms are made by Wolf Forms, a Manhattan company in business since 1905.

title: Why Management Needs the Labor Movement
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: On July 29 you ran an interesting article on the Galicia region of Spain and the edible barnacles called percebes. But the caption about a ''Basque fisherman selling the shellfish'' must have been a guess. Maybe a fisherman; probably a merchant. The Gallegos are not Basques, who live hundreds of miles to the east. The man was not wearing a Basque boina but a French-Galician beret.

title: Why Moscow Must Walk the Tightrope in Iraq;   Earlier Invasions
description: To the Editor:

title: Seed-Grown Annuals for the Future
description: These seed-grown cultivars are planted in trial fields in spring and watched over carefully. The field trials are judged by horticultural professionals who observe the plants through the growing season and take special note of worthiness. If the cultivars exhibit improvements or unique qualities, they often end up as winners.

title: Above Southern France, a Ballet Against Fire
description: The cool wind stirred in the morning, and hit 60 miles an hour by midday. Comdr. Robert Bardo, the chief fire-control officer for the 15 departments in Provence, sensed smoke in the air.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ONE NATION UNDER TELEVISION: The Rise and Decline of Network TV. By J. Fred MacDonald. (Pantheon, $24.95.) In 1939, David Sarnoff of RCA, a pioneer in the development of the television industry, hailed the infant medium as ''a new art so important in its implications that it is bound to affect all society.'' As J. Fred MacDonald sees it, television has indeed affected American society in the intervening half-century, but not in the way its more idealistic proponents had foreseen. ''One Nation Under Television'' is largely the story of how a noble dream - the notion of network television as a tool for education and enlightenment - has been corrupted by corporate greed, Government indifference, programmers eager to pander to the lowest common denominator and viewers more interested in being tranquilized than in being challenged. Today, he notes, the networks' longstanding dominance of the airwaves is being dramatically eroded by the growth of cable and home video - and, perhaps, by the audience's growing indifference to what they have to offer. Mr. MacDonald, a professor of history at Northeastern Illinois University and the author of several previous books on broadcasting, has a fascinating story to tell, and he has amassed a prodigious amount of information. But he is more skillful as a researcher than as a storyteller; his prose tends to be dry and lackluster. And by attempting to recount the 50-year history of network television in 335 pages, Mr. MacDonald leaves himself little room for treating any aspect of his story in depth. He jumps so quickly from subject to subject that reading ''One Nation Under Television'' eventually becomes as unsatisfying as watching the tube in the company of a compulsive channel-changer.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Monday is Labor Day. Here are holiday schedules:

title: Pact for Bourque
description: HOCKEY'S $1 million a year club has added Ray Bourque, the Boston Bruins' All-Star defenseman. Bourque agreed to a new five-year contract that will pay him a base salary of $1.1 million per year, plus deferred payments of $140,000 a year for five years.

title: Citizens Are Starting to Shout Over Savings and Loan Costs
description: When a group of citizens held a raucous town meeting here on Wednesday as part of a campaign against the Federal bailout of the savings and loan industry, the only empty seats were those reserved for the state's Congressional delegation.

title: New Director Plans to Diversify At Harms Center
description: Now, Mr. Rawlins has to identify the collaborative possibilities between a 1,246-seat presenting house that has the Tokyo String Quartet, a Big Band Jamboree with the Jimmy Dorsey Orchestra and Ballet Hispanico, among other classical and contemporary bookings, lined up for the coming season, and a regional playhouse that is about to begin its fifth year producing primarily new plays in a 270 seat-theater on the campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

3 Styles of Housing-cum-Country Club
description: LEAD: Three developments in which houses will be clustered along golf course fairways are going up within a few miles of each other in western Suffolk. But the developers are taking different approaches to the way country club and golfing privileges are being made available to homebuyers.

title: California Lawmakers Defeat Plan for Early Presidential Primary
description: A plan to give California one of the nation's earliest Presidential primaries has been defeated, with lawmakers unable to agree whether to prohibit referendums from any Presidential ballot.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Why Moscow Must Walk the Tightrope in Iraq;   Jordan's Emergence
description: To the Editor:

title: Jillian B. Kurtz To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Kurtz of Englewood, N.J., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter, JILLIAN BETH KURTZ, and JEREMY HUGH TEMKIN, the son of Victor Temkin of Los Angeles and Susan Baer of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: For a Season And Beyond, Some Hopes
description: The Labor Day weekend signals the onset of a new season. What better time to muse idly about a few of our leading classical-music institutions and artists? And more than just muse: to offer, in the spirit of constructive criticism, a pre-Christmas wish list for an idiosyncratically selected assortment of individuals and organizations.

title: Northeast Notebook: Middlebury, Vt.;   Inns Facing Tougher Times
description: For Martin and Marcia Schuppert, buying the 180-year-old Waybury Inn last month - the one shown on the long-running Bob Newhart television show - was something of a dream come true.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Missouri;   Fraternity Party Turns Violent; Ban Is Adopted
description: The University of Missouri's Inter-Fraternity Council has voted to end the annual Bid Day Bash after at least 35 people were injured in violent incidents at the party last weekend.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Day The Dorm Stole My Older Brother
description: LEAD: ''YO, loser, the mailman's here,'' I bellowed from the bottom of the stairs. As I spoke the last word, a blur of color came charging down the hardwood stairs. He ran past me, past my parents and out our door. He met our mailman at the box and grabbed the stack of mail.

title: Mass of Misinformation About Parent Training
description: The frequency with which I hear the Maslow-Rogers theories of non-directive parenting and children's ''self-actualization'' expounded suggests that the public and many professionals are unaware that both of those gentlemen, before they died, realized that their theories were being misapplied and were causing much harm to children.

title: Theology Awaits The Vatican's Word on Evils Lesser and Greater
description: BECAUSE of the secrecy surrounding Vatican documents, predicting the contents of a major papal statement is like predicting the outcome of a Supreme Court decision - but without even knowing what case is on the docket.

title: Summer Vegetables for Tarts and Pizzas
description: The cooking teacher and author Anne Wallan gives an especially appealing recipe for the classic Nicois tart pissaladiere in her book ''French Regional Cooking'' (William Morrow $29.95). This tart is a French cousin of an Italian pizza and is made with a yeast dough. It is topped with onions and tomatoes in this version, along with anchovies and Nicois olives. I find it particularly good made with the young green onions now available at some farmstands. I also add a couple of crushed garlic cloves to the onions as they are cooking, but that is up to you.

title: Del Monte Recalls 843 Cases Of French-Style Green Beans
description: Del Monte Foods is recalling 843 cases of French-style green beans because about 50 of them contained cans of vegetables that had not been cooked.

title: Reds' Mahler Stops the cubs, 8-1
description: Rick Mahler gave Cincinnati's pitching staff a big lift today with a four-hitter as the Reds beat the Chicago Cubs, 8-1.

title: U.S.-Vietnam Search For Remains Winds Up
description: American-Vietnamese teams have finished their longest joint search ever for the remains of missing American servicemen, the official Vietnam News Agency said today.

title: Seaver Awaits Call
description: The talks never moved much beyond the exploratory stage, but Tom Seaver said his brush with the vacancy in the Yankee front office last month left him both intrigued and interested. If another team calls, he will listen.

title: Primaries in New York City Include Challenges to Incumbent Legislators
description: In an unusual departure from the power of incumbency, at least a half-dozen Democratic state legislators in New York City face stiff challenges in the Sept. 11 primary, which is usually tantamount to election in the predominantly Democratic city.

title: Athletes Build Strong Bodies 3 Ways
description: LEAD: LIKE an increasing number of athletes, Stanley E. Moraski Jr. begins his day with a run, a bicycle ride or a swim. By 6:30 A.M., he is on the road - running several miles or driving to the Y.M.C.A. in Winsted, where he swims 1,000 yards or more.

title: With Hugs and Sighs, Fresh Air Summer Ends
description: About 40 men and women were in line at Area X in the Port Authority bus terminal on Eighth Avenue in Manhattan. A black rope held them back from the door their eyes were locked on. They joked, smoked, traded small talk, but each time the door cracked open they were silent, expectant.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

title: Postings: Preservation-Plus;   A Forum On Issues Of Urgency
description: The landmarks preservation movement has profound implications for the maintenance of schools, churches and synagogues, libraries, fire houses, post offices, streets and roadways. It also bears a relation to environmental protection generally. So it seems appropriate that the New York Landmarks Preservation Foundation has organized a forum on Sept. 10 whose themes are ''Preservation and Public Structures'' and ''Preservation and Environmental Concerns.''

title: Voices of Promise Find Modest Fulfillment
description: It is all too true that ours is not an age of prevalent excellence in classical singing, but by combing carefully through cast lists and record releases, keeping track of promising young singers and bearing disappointments patiently, one can still find a good deal to enjoy in the work of artists not yet to be described as ''legendary,'' ''historical'' or ''veteran.''

title: Alicia M. Rioseco Engaged to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. George L. Rioseco of Purchase, N.Y., have announced December wedding plans for their daughter, ALICIA MARIE RIOSECO, and THOMAS ANTHONY COASH, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Coash of Rye, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: LEAD: The Streetscapes column on Aug. 12 about the boundaries of historic districts misstated the Landmarks Commission's legal powers to designate partial zoning lots. The commission prefers to designate full zoning lots but has the authority to designate partial lots.

title: Indonesia
description: To the Editor: In any future summary of tours, you might make note of the most enchanting tour I took during my visits to Indonesia:

title: Typhoon Kills 48 in China
description: Forty-eight people have been killed and 250 injured by a typhoon, the New China News Agency reported today. The typhoon, code-named Abe, was the sixth major storm to batter China's southeastern coast this summer. It struck Zhejiang Province on Friday morning, leaving more than 40,000 people homeless. The agency said 665,000 people were stranded by flooding caused by the storm.

title: England
description: To the Editor: ''A Walk Across England'' by Scott Burris (Travel, May 20) brought back memories of my own walk the length of Britain more than 60 years ago before the highways were infested by cars and ''England's green and pleasant land'' had been trampled flat by hordes of trippers.

title: Images From Southern Points
description: This is the script, but the reality is a cross section that could have been cut anywhere in New Jersey, or New York for that matter. And the point it makes is distressingly familiar: technique is more important than vision, but perhaps not as important as the interpretations of middlemen - curators or critics.

title: Why Moscow Must Walk the Tightrope in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: DRIVING THROUGH DETROIT
description: As a nearly lifelong resident of Detroit and a member of the ''black intelligentsia,'' I feel that Chafets ignores the positive aspects of the city. Unlike many other cities in the United States, Detroit has a real African-American middle class: doctors, lawyers and scholars (unconnected to the administration of Coleman A. Young) who find the quiet neighborhoods of tree-lined streets and large brick homes a safe place to live. People who have never been to a ''crack house,'' don't hang out with drug dealers, and possess the same values as white suburbanites: home, family, education.

title: India Air Pass: Waiting For Enlightenment
description: Twelve years ago, when we had last gone to India for an extended sabbatical, we had bought an Indian Airlines' special tourist air pass, obtainable only from outside the country. ''Discover the real India,'' the advertisements read. ''Unlimited air mileage for two weeks, just $99 per person!'' It sounded too good to be true. It was too good to be true. There should have been a small print addendum at the bottom of the ads:

title: The Age of 40 Seems Very Young
description: LEAD: Celeste Piano Wenzel sounds like a very nice person ("Birthdays Remind Me of What I Miss," Aug. 19), but 40 is much too early an age to be contemplating what she'll miss when gone. When she does attain old age, she might more gainfully consider what she won't miss: man's continuing inhumanity to man, sickness, accidents and natural disasters, to name only a few of many calamities in the modern world.

title:

>44 Years as the Town Clerk of Somers

Since then Presidents - as well as town supervisors and councilmen - have come and gone. But Ms. Gavaghan, a Republican, has remained as the keeper of the town's records, an elected position that required her to run for office 22 times, many times unopposed and sometimes with the endorsements of other parties.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OVERTAPPED OASIS: Reform or Revolution for Western Water. By Marc Reisner and Sarah Bates. (Island Press, Cloth, $31.95; Paper, $17.95.) Four years ago, in his book ''Cadillac Desert,'' Marc Reisner recounted with verve how the West was plumbed. In ''Overtapped Oasis,'' he wades into the morass of water policy. Mr. Reisner and his co-author, Sarah Bates, a lawyer with the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund, argue that it is time to revamp the way the Western United States' most precious resource is managed. The authors contend that outmoded state laws, and a system of Federal entitlements that funnels water to farmers at prices substantially below market value come monsoon or drought, breed waste and shortages. With fully three-quarters of Westerners living in urban areas, can the region afford to continue allowing 80 percent to 90 percent of its available water to go to agriculture, especially when it is used to irrigate pasturage and low-value crops like alfalfa? Joining a chorus of experts, the authors assert that the equation should be balanced by making water subject to market forces. Allowing water to rise to its highest economic use, they say, would benefit the environment as well as cities, since the value of rivers, lakes and wetlands, in terms of tourism and recreation dollars, would have to be factored in. Although ''Overtapped Oasis'' goes a long way toward simplifying byzantine material, it ultimately bogs down in legal intricacies. The analysis also occasionally operates at cross-purposes. Mr. Reisner and Ms. Bates advocate gradual reform of legal codes, yet, in their criticisms of the current system, they underscore the need for more radical change.

title: Aide Abets
description: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev dropped by the White House for a bit of summitry three months ago, he let it drop that he could use some help in organizing his own new Western-type presidency. Who gets a windowed corner office and who gets a basement cubby? Who gets to see the top man anytime and who has to write for an appointment? Well, said President Bush, who can handle such matters better than John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff? So there was Mr. Sununu in the Kremlin last week, ostensibly carrying out a scheduled visit to help Soviet leaders organize ''paper flow'' and the like. But when word of the Sept. 9 Bush-Gorbachev summit came yesterday, speculation was rife in Washington on what part Mr. Sununu played in setting it up. The White House was sketchy on his role, but one news report said that a trip that had been viewed as signaling ''a diminished role for Mr. Sununu'' now seemed to be ''a diplomatic success'' that would make him ''the toast of the town.''

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Vassar;   Freshmen Find First Campus Visit No Bed of Roses
description: The hard rubber floors of a gymnasium might seem like a strange place to spend the first night of college, but that's where more than half of Vassar College's freshmen class found themselves last weekend.

FORUM;

It was a memorable night for Seattle fans, and for the Griffeys, as Ken Sr.'s wife, Birdie, watched from the stands.

title: Within Regulations
description: Of the hundreds of Panamanians who were killed in the United States invasion, the Army contended that one was murdered and that Sgt. Roberto Bryan committed the crime. During Sergeant Bryan's trial last week in Fort Bragg, N.C., his lawyer maintained that the soldier had simply been doing his job when he shot a wounded Panamanian who had been part of a group from which a grenade was tossed, injuring 10 American soldiers. The military jury apparently agreed, finding him not guilty of ''unpremeditated murder.'' The charge had been based primarily on the testimony of Lieut. Brandon Thomas, who said that Sergeant Bryan killed the Panamanian to avenge the injured Americans. But others testified that the lieutenant bore a grudge against the sergeant and had not even seen the shooting. Suporters of Sergeant Bryan, whose 19-year service record is unblemished, said he was a scapegoat for other improper actions by American soldiers in Panama.

title: Belt Buckles, a k a Jewelry

Wide straps now have contoured edges to flatter curves. ''With dresses floating into the shift look, it's wonderful to embellish your waistline,'' said Terry Mayer, a jewelry designer. No cat suit will enter a room silently if adorned by Ms. Mayer's gently contoured black felt cummerbund, with 13 clusters of brass bells ($150). title: Aspiring Jazz Musicians May Soon Have an Alternative to Smoky Cabarets
description: Since its beginnings nearly a century ago, jazz has often been passed from one generation to the next through a chain of chord progressions, rhythmic patterns and melodic lines delivered in smoky clubs. Within a few years, aspiring young jazz musicians may be able to study their craft in a conservatory in Durham, N.C., devoted exclusively to jazz.

title: Typing Classes Decline
description: LEAD: THE sounds of clicking typewriters and a teacher reciting timed stenography exercises have been nuted in local high schools over the last decade with theincreased demand for computer-literate graduates.

title: Blake, Krystle and Alexis Settle In on Polish TV
description: ''Dynastia'' is Polish for ''dynasty.'' But nowadays it is more chic to say ''DIE-nas-tee,'' the American way. This new fashion started two months ago, when the initial installment of the United States-produced series was telecast on Poland's Channel 1. Since then, 10 times a week - twice daily from Monday to Friday - Poles are treated to the carryings-on of the enormously rich Carrington family of Colorado.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Clarkson University;   Computer Helps Professors Match Names and Faces
description: On the first day of class, a professor, perhaps seeking to drive away those who had gotten the impression that his course was a piece of cake, poses an almost ludicrously difficult hypothetical question.
