description: A FULL MOON OF WOMEN

title: What Happened to Guerrilla Bands?
description: Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces: 7,000 members; pro-Soviet from formation in 1964 until advent of perestroika. At war with Government; death on Aug. 10 of long-time leader Jacobo Arenas. May open group to peace talks; 6 of 43 fighting units have expressed interest in demobilization.

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a photograph with the Streetscapes column on Aug. 5 about the Central Park Loch contained an incorrect photo credit. The photo should have been credited to Herbert Mitchell.

title: SOVIET AGREEMENT REPORTED ON PLAN FOR FREE MARKETS
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin, whose rivalry has sometimes seemed to threaten the integrity of the Soviet Union, have agreed on a plan to dismantle central economic controls and move to free markets in 500 days, leaders of the Russian republic said today.

title: DRIVING THROUGH DETROIT
description: The people of Detroit are doing what the rest of us wish we could do: they're burning it down and starting over. Unfortunately, the burning down is always easier than the starting over.

title: Magazine in Uruguay Wins a Wide Audience
description: Cesar Aguiar, a prominent Uruguayan pollster and sociologist, considers it a sufficient measure of the virtues of Busqueda, a weekly news magazine, to note that Citibank and the Communist Party both advertise in its pages.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SOMEBODY SING. By Tom Leopold. (Dutton, $17.95.) Imagine being the star of a so-so cable television sitcom that's taped in the same studio where ''The Honeymooners'' was shot back in the 1950's. To Sandy Bayard, the narrator of Tom Leopold's second novel, ''that's like doing spin art in Picasso's house.'' Sandy can't help it if he's a jerk, but at least he'd like a little credit for being the first to admit it. Always quick to try for a laugh with his inexhaustible reservoir of pained sarcasm, he's a fast talker with a ''guilty, glass-jaw heart'' who's plagued by fear of monogamy (''Relationship jail!'') and the nagging suspicion that maybe he's not such a nice person after all. Unfortunately, before ''Somebody Sing'' has got very far, its readers will be inclined to agree with Sandy's darkest fears: his manic patter soon wears paper thin, exposing the needy, self-hating character behind the comic mask. Describing his long-suffering girlfriend and his childhood nanny, a poor black woman in need of open-heart surgery, Sandy reveals a distasteful penchant for sexual and racial stereotyping, all supposedly in the name of humor. While his backward attitudes may indeed reflect a troublesome strain in today's comedy, this does not make the sentiments he expresses any less offensive. No matter how many goofy turns the plot takes, it can't shake the phony ring of that faux-sensitive narrative voice. By the time Sandy reaches his personal epiphany at the novel's end, he has long since exhausted the patience of his audience.

title: Pope, in Tanzania to Start Africa Visit, Asks More Effort on AIDS
description: Pope John Paul II arrived today on his first trip to this East African nation, his seventh to the continent, and immediately tackled one of the most severe but least discussed problems afflicting Africa: AIDS.

title: Ethnic Groups in Jewish Arts Spotlight
description: LEAD: AT first glance, the oud and kanun, two ancient Middle Eastern musical instruments, would seem to have little in common with the klezmer clarinet.

title: Seen Any Warbleers Lately
description: Chandler S. Robbins, a senior U.S. Fish and Wildlife biologist at the Patuxent Wildlife Research Center, is rattling through the refuge in Laurel, Md., when he brakes his Chevy on a one-lane bridge spanning a creek that is swollen with spring rain. From a drooping branch hangs a nest, and in it sits an olive-brown mite of a bird he quickly identifies as an Acadian flycatcher.

title:
ART;

An Outpouring of Creativity in Neuberger's 'First Impressions'
description: LEAD: ASK a contemporary artist what he wants to be when he grows up, and he is likely to reply: a printmaker.

title: When Teachers Are Special People
description: For six-and-a-half hours a day, five days a week, for the next 40 weeks, the teacher has the power to control virtually every aspect of a child's life. Every basic decision - from when to go to the bathroom to when to talk (if ever), from when to eat to how to walk (one head lined up right behind the other), from what to read to what to write, may be determined by the teacher. And with daily homework assignments, the teacher's reach extends beyond school.

title: Venezuela Isn't Exactly Wild for Another Boom
description: A DECADE ago, Venezuela was often called South America's Saudi Arabia. Floating on the largest cushion of oil outside the Middle East, Venezuela's economy boomed, spawning superhighways, shopping sprees in Miami and a subway system linking the high-rises sprouting across this capital.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Cash Machine Users to Get More Outlets

title: A Plea to Help Villages With 'Special' Problems
description: Although he acknowledged that Westchester was facing serious budget problems, Mr. Feiner said, ''The county is in a better financial position to help these small villages than the villages are themselves.''

title: A Lively Menu Touches Many Bases
description: What was once Boodles is now Bretts, but the decor in the handsome old house in Greenwich is much as it was. The ground floor is broken into several cozy dining areas; the best by far is the glass-enclosed sun porch. It is positively dazzling on a sunny day, with window boxes full of yellow chrysanthemums and light streaming throgh the stained-glass panel in the rear. It is so pleasant, in fact, that one almost forgets how uncomfortable the bentwood chairs are, and how close together and small (for a group of four) the glass-topped tables are.

description: For one of summer's last flings, it's the romantic look.

An October wedding is planned.

THEATER;

''They work together, the tooth fairy and the line fairy,'' said Mr. Lane, who starred Off Broadway this past season in ''The Lisbon Traviata.

title: Question Of the Week;   Why Are Baseball Brawls So Common?
description: Baseball brawls are an outgrowth of the violence and masochism that pervade many American sports and our society as a whole. Champion boxers are among the richest men in sports; boxing and wrestling are aired on television virtually every day. Boxing, though artful, is inherently brutal, and mainstream wrestling is a charade of chaotic violence. That's what the people want.

title: Theft Abroad
description: To the Editor: I keep reading about tourists in France and Italy being robbed on the streets by immigrants from Eastern Europe. Indeed, in Paris, my wife was robbed of credit cards, money, and the like, by a woman and her children who had distracted her.

title: In Defense of Left-Handedness
description: To the Editor:

title: Bilingual Music Is Breaking Down Cultural Barriers
description: In a world tense with competing cultures, the product of conquests or immigration, distinct new ethnic identities can emerge. Lingering traditions - fragments of a language, a way of thinking - become integrated into the dominant culture. But the mainstream, which tends to be suspicious of such creolized cultures, defines them as foreign. In the United States, Spanish tradition and its descendant, Mexican culture - which existed decades before English colonists arrived - are still perceived as imports, not part of the American whole. The biographies of the Chicano artists behind three extremely different new albums show how inappropriate the label ''outsider'' can be.

title: Dateline Kuwait
description: Caryle Murphy was perhaps the only Westerner in Kuwait who considered herself to be in the right place at the right time when Iraqi tanks first rolled across the border. Ms. Murphy, a reporter for The Washington Post and the only American journalist known to have been in Kuwait from the start of Saddam Hussein's invasion, spent the next 25 days dodging Iraqi patrols and filing front-page stories for her newspaper. As tensions grew between Washington and Baghdad, the Post continued to run her articles but without her byline and Post editors asked other news organizations not to mention Ms. Murphy's presence in Kuwait City. Last week, with her ability to move around the city restricted and no significant new developments in sight, Ms. Murphy blithely convoyed across the Saudi border with a group of other refugees. ''I wanted to stay as long as I could,'' she said in an interview from Riyadh. ''But I was not about to become a heroine, because that would do my paper no good.''

title: A Needed Addition
description: To the Editor:

title: About Men;   When Father Doesn't Know Best
description: On Nov. 25, 1983, the prizefighter Marvis Frazier, 23 and inexperienced, was knocked out by the heavyweight champion of the world, Larry Holmes, after 2 minutes and 57 seconds of the first round. Frazier was sucker-punched. Holmes faked a left jab and Frazier went for it, leaving himself open for the decisive punch, a right. Frazier managed to stay on his feet while Holmes pummeled him with 19 consecutive punches. Finally, with three seconds left in the round, the referee stopped the fight. At that moment, Marvis Frazier's father and manager, the former heavyweight champion Joe Frazier, embraced his son and repeated over and over: ''It's all right. It's all right. I love you.''

title: TEACHING ON AIDS TO BE INCREASED
description: New York City school officials plan to increase their efforts to teach students about AIDS when the school year begins on Thursday.

title: 'Making of a Legend' Inspires Memories
description: I applied and got the job as a spear-bearer. Dressed as a ''real'' warrior, showing naked, knobby knees, I was given one memorable line. When time came for our entrance, all 10 of us marched on stage bearing our spears high and circled the stage. Finally, I gave the command - ''Spears down!'' However, I brought down the house, for I was recognized by some of my buddies sitting in the first few rows. I suppressed an urge to take a bow but I did smile. (Backstage they were yelling at me to drop that inane smile).

title: On Language;   Foreign Guests And Hostages

''Do you believe the Iraqis are using those Americans as a shield?'' was the way the question was put to Mr. Bush at a news conference.

title: Cruise Packages
description: To the Editor: Travelers should comparison shop for pre- and post-cruise hotel packages. My wife and I booked a three-day post-cruise package following a sailing out of Papeete. The package price was $320 a day. On arriving in Sydney we discovered that the hotel's rate for a direct booking was $219. Both prices included breakfast.

description: The Labor Department is establishing a test program in the meatpacking industry to protect workers from painful and crippling injuries caused by repetitive motions.

description: Suites of offices occupied by doctors or other professionals are regular features at the street level of hundreds of New York City cooperatives. Most are normally rented on long-term commercial leases from the co-op corporation.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SOME CAN WHISTLE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket Books, $5.95.) Late in life a rich, successful Danny Deck, the fictional novelist introduced in ''All My Friends Are Going to Be Strangers,'' gets a surprise visit from the 22-year-old daughter he has never seen. Last year our reviewer, Barbara Kingsolver, praised Larry McMurtry's ''extraordinary way with women. His heroines are the kind you want to love, listen to forever or at least have move in next door.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

When a Child Makes Friends You Wonder About
description: LEAD: PHEW! You've made it through eight weeks of summer togetherness. Eight weeks of putting up with the kids down the street who polish off an entire package of your cookies, who plunk down their bikes in your driveway just when you come roaring up and who have, to all appearances, moved in until they collect their first Social Security check.

description: Track and Field

title: Currency;   Three Havens That Weren't
description: Ouch. For those who fled to the British pound and the Australian and Canadian dollars as a safe harbor during the Persian Gulf crisis, the end of last week was rough. As some tension eased and as some traders began to take profits, the three curencies, especially the pound, fell sharply. The Australian dollar was off 1.6 percent for the week on Thursday but rebounded on Friday. The Canadian dollar dropped 1.9 percent by the end of the week. And the pound plunged 5 cents, or 2.6 percent. Meanwhile, the dollar rallied some against the German mark but no new trend is in sight. The Japanese yen managed to climb 1.9 percent against the dollar, helped by the expectation of a jump in Japan's official discount rate, which the Bank of Japan then announced on Thursday.

title: World Markets;   Ominous News From Japan
description: The Bank of Japan's increase of its discount rate to 6 percent from 5.25 percent has raised new questions about how much higher world interest rates will go and how many more investors will be drained from weak world equity markets.

description: Ossining, N.Y. $310,000

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: A Perfect Trail in Nova Scotia
description: On our second trip to Nova Scotia - the first was in July 1987 -we hoped to learn from our scattershot adventures during the first go. Our idea, insofar as we can be said to have had one, was to view to maximum advantage the astonishing landscape of the Cabot Trail, a circular tour, part of which goes through Cape Breton Highlands National Park. We wanted to intensify the virtues of the previous trip by rerunning its best moments. We intended - an elusive and quixotic ideal - to do this trip right.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: LEAD: LENS OF THE WORLD (Morrow, $18.95) by R. A. MacAvoy reads like a historical novel set in a time that could have been our own past but is not. Ms. MacAvoy is apparently familiar with the work of Gene Wolfe, Samuel R. Delany and Ursula K. Le Guin, and has built with great skill on their considerable achievements: this is fantasy with all the conceptual rigor of good science fiction.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Time out. Enjoy the three-day weekend.

title: Money Talks, Top 40 Listens
description: Amid its antic tales of malfeasance and egomania in the record business, Fredric Dannen's new book ''Hit Men'' (Times Books/Random House) details a sobering statistic: from the late 1970's through much of the 1980's, record companies laid out as much as $50 million to $80 million each year on independent promotion. An informal alliance of promotion men calling itself the Network controlled what was played - and what wasn't - on Top 40 radio stations across the United States. (One member of the Network, Joseph Isgro, has just gone on trial in Los Angeles for racketeering and payola.) What does it mean that for the last decade, cash has ruled the Top 40 as much as listeners' choice?

title: Trouble in 'Flatland,' or The War Against Confusion
description: Often the presentation of information obscures its meaning. To Edward R. Tufte, the correction of this scandal lies in design. He has made it his mission to turn statistical tables, scientific observations, schedules, maps, timetables and much more into ''bright and splendid visions'' reflecting the ''crystalline qualities of information display.'' If he has his way, a piece of paper, which he calls ''flatland,'' will reveal depths, contours and subtleties of reality we have never seen before.

title: Baseball Fights From Behind the Plate
description: In the late 1960's I umpired a game between the Mets and the Philadelphia Phillies at Shea Stadium. The Mets' pitcher - I forget who it was - hit one of the Phillie batters with a pitch. The next inning, the first batter for the Mets was hit. No fuss. No one charged the mound. I turned around and brushed off home plate, and as I did I told the catcher: 'Go out to the mound and tell your pitcher that's enough. You both had your shot; now it's over.' And that's what happened. These days, things aren't so simple.

description: While Poland's elite gathered this week in Gdansk to celebrate Solidarity's glorious past, the nation's drivers were treated to an uneasy glimpse of what may become this country's future: gas lines.

title: What S. & L.'s? What Contributions?

So last week, as a Government report showed that even the healthiest segment of the industry is growing weaker, the Resolution Trust Corporation announced that it would fight corruption in the bailout process by setting up a new department of, yes, S. & L. police.

description: Like countless other Americans, Carrie Fisher comes from a broken home, is divorced and has had problems with drug abuse. Nothing unusual.

However fortuitous, the scheduling implies a rationale: if you're going to exhibit the drawings of Julian Schnabel, that enfant terrible of the early 1980's and epitome of white male artistic success, equal time should go to work from a completely different part of the art realm.

description: The term, geometric abstraction, is simple, yet the art is anything but, and the complexity begins with the show's 232-page catalogue, which is handsome in appearance but confusing in layout, and lacks a checklist to boot.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

A Beach Junkie's Journey From Youth to Adulthood
description: LEAD: GROWING up on Long Island allowed me to become a beach junkie. Not that I was one of those ever-so-tan teens who spent their summers frolicking on Jones Beach knowing the world was looking at them. I was more the lobster type, moving from Day-Glo pink to tacky plaid, peeling away every ounce of potentially tanned skin.

title: A Month of Crisis in the Persian Gulf
description: Aug. 2 Iraq invades Kuwait hours after talks broke down between the two nations over oil production and debt repayment. Iraqi troops seize vast petroleum reserves and Kuwait's capital, plunging the Persian Gulf region into crisis. Witnesses report hundreds of casualties. The Kuwaiti ruler flees. President Bush calls the invasion ''naked aggression.'' The United Nations Security Council votes overwhelmingly to condemn it and demand the Iraqis' immediate and total withdrawal.

But in the wake of three separate proposals, some city officials and local merchants are raising questions about the impact these projects would have on existing retail areas and on traffic patterns.

But the hormone is meeting strong resistance, based in part on the stirring of unfounded fears. A recent study by the Food and Drug Administration confirms that the hormone presents no risk to human health.

title: Selling the Houses, but Leasing the Land

title: 60 Minutes, More or Less, Add Up to a Fine Time
description: Sidewalk tables, cascading fountains and sculpture parks lend a European air to the scene.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: Are fledgling photographers awash in a sea of film-speed confusion? That's the message Polaroid keeps sending out in its ads for its color-negative film called OneFilm. If you believe what you hear in these radio and television ads, snapshooters are as befuddled by ISO speeds as they used to be by f/stops.

title: New Free-Market Crime
description: If someone hadn't stolen his car radio last November, Reinhard Klunder might still be a security research assistant in a nuclear power plant instead of a founder of one of one of the most successful new businesses in East Berlin.

title:
LITTLE SILVER JOURNAL;

Restoration Campaign: Little Depot That Would

title:
All About/Replacement Auto Parts;

Times Are Tough In an Industry That Thrives on Breakdowns
description: LEAD: The peaks and valleys of the market for replacement automobile parts used to be predictable: First came a boom in auto sales, then a boom in breakdowns, and inevitably a boom in parts. But the companies that make and sell these parts are still waiting to benefit from the four-year surge in auto sales that ended in 1988.

title: Motor Homes
description: To the Editor: When my wife and I toured France and West Germany last year, we rented a 23-foot motor home that I would recommend to travelers thinking of renting a van or smaller motor home. During the low season, the rate was $1,097 a week, which included unlimited mileage and insurance. We have toured Europe four times by motor home and car with trailer and find the service provided by German Motorhome Travel to be one of the best. Pickup is in Frankfurt. We arranged everything through Bernd Hess, German Motorhome Travel, 1142 Manhattan Avenue, Suite 300, Manhattan Beach, Calif. 90266; 213-318-9995 or 800-468-3876.

title: Nancy Wallis to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. George R. Wallis of Portland, Me., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, NANCY EASTLAND WALLIS, and CHRISTOPHER JOHN KITTREDGE, the son of John Kittredge of Dalton, Mass., and the late Martha Jane Furey Kittredge. Miss Wallis, 26 years old, graduated from Dickinson College. She is a real-estate manager at Ivanhoe Inc., a commercial investment and development company in Boston. The prospective bridegroom, 28, a graduate of Denison University, is a geologist at Haley & Aldrich Inc., a Cambridge, Mass., geotechnical engineering firm.

title: Summit Meetings With Gorbachev
description: November 1985: President Ronald Reagan and Mikhail s. Gorbachev meet in Geneva for wide-ranging talks on arms controland other subjects. They agree to revive cultural exchanges and to increase air safety, but no arms-control agreements are achieved.

title: Can House Music Follow In Disco's Dance Steps?
description: For years, dance-club regulars have been expecting the boom-chucka-boom beat of house music to conquer pop. Meanwhile, outsiders have been waiting for songs that can hold up away from the dance floor.

title:
Focus: Retail Auctions;

Condo Residents Get New Neighbors

title: The Arts Catch Up With a Society in Disarray
description: The words come from the 19th century, and you have to wonder if they could be said today. Henrik Ibsen, the author of ''A Doll's House,'' was being honored for his contribution to women's rights. ''I thank you for the toast but must disclaim the honor of having consciously worked for the women's rights movement,'' the playwright said. ''My task has been the description of humanity.''

title: The Executive Life;   Where's the Barbarian? Where's the Gate?
description: Several months ago, one Harvard Business School student near the top of his class accepted a summer internship with a prominent Wall Street investment bank. Before arriving in New York, he devoured ''Barbarians at the Gate'' and ''Liar's Poker,'' the twin bibles of Wall Street's corporate culture. He braced himself for the industry's frantic pace and for the dizzying whirl of cocktail parties and recruiting dinners he expected to attend.

title: Contract Dispute
description: THE Phoenix Suns are burning mad and Jayson Williams, the former St. John's basketball star, is the reason.

title: When Your Home Videos Are Rated B (for Boring)
description: Professional film makers and editors are turning home movies and videotapes into modern mini-series of family life. Reels of Little League games or the family picnic are being chopped into short sequences and set to music like action shots on MTV.

title: Chinatown Leaders Are Indicted in Gambling Ring
description: Two former presidents of the Chinatown Merchants Association and the man who the authorities say was the leader of organized crime in Chinatown before he disappeared in 1984 were among 29 people indicted by a Federal grand jury last week on charges of operating a nationwide illegal gambling operation.

title: Berlin Wall Souvenir Is Lethal
description: A concrete slab of the Berlin wall tipped over and crushed a 14-year-old boy to death as he was trying to chip souvenir pieces from it, the police said today. ''The segment came loose and fell over on the boy like a guillotine,'' a West Berlin police spokesman said of the accident on Friday night. ''He was killed instantly.''

title: Editorial Notebook;   The Lost Spoils of Hitler's War
description: The inquisitive visitor to Quedlinburg in soon-to-vanish East Germany will be puzzled by what he doesn't find. Here occurred one of the century's great art thefts, yet Quedlinburgers profess disinterest. Their main concern is how unification will change a cobbled city abutting the frontier that has divided the Harz Mountains.

title: New Rules On Oil Tanks Intensify Fuel Battle
description: Targets of Gas Companies' Campaign

title: Nursing Home Memories
description: MISSING PIECES. By Stanislaw Benski. Translated by Walter Arndt. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) These spare, poetic stories were written during the 25 years that Stanislaw Benski was director of a Warsaw nursing home whose elderly residents included some of the last of Poland's Jews. Many of the 16 stories, deftly translated by Walter Arndt, are set in the nursing home; all tell of the anguish of surviving the Holocaust, of the struggle to recreate a life while tormented by memories. Benski (who died in 1988) reveals his characters' pain quietly. In ''The Tzaddik's Grandson,'' a woman named Rose, upon seeing a baby, says, ''I had three children. Three wonderful boys. By now I could have had grandchildren.'' In ''On the Corner,'' blind Abram visits the Warsaw district where he lived before the war, lovingly describing it as his friend Haskiel leads the way; Haskiel does not have the heart to tell him that his familiar landmarks have vanished, that nothing of the old neighborhood remains. In ''Missing Pieces,'' we also learn of a hunchback who saves a Jewish family by hiding them in a trench under his latrine; a widow who takes in a crippled Jewish girl who has jumped from a Treblinka-bound transport; a policeman who risks visiting a young Jewish woman sequestered in a windowless attic, making her realize that ''one could be glad of something after all, that one could miss another human being, that one could dream pleasurable dreams.'' Then there is the guilt-ridden Jewish couple in the title story, who spent the war outside Europe but decide to write new histories for themselves as if they, too, had known the horrors of the German occupation and the camps. I finished this book in one sitting, moved by the characters' tragic experiences, yet coming to know them as people with a full complement of human strengths and weaknesses.

title: The S.& L. Bailout Flouts the Tenets of Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: ''The knockout system put drama into the United States Championship,'' said the New York grandmaster Larry Christiansen, who was the runner-up to Lev Alburt in the Jacksonville, Fla., tournament, which ended Aug. 16. Joel Benjamin, a third New York grandmaster entrant, added: ''The old round-robins were producing too many draws and bored the players and spectators.''

title: The Rules of the Game: Inertia and Force
description: THE borders of the Arab countries of the Middle East were drawn largely by Britain and France after World War I when the League of Nations allowed them to carve up the Ottoman domains there. In Syria and Lebanon, France tried to establish republics; in Jordan and Iraq, Britain set up monarchies and installed members of the family that had led the Arab revolt against Turkey; in Egypt, central Arabia and Kuwait, London backed other traditional rulers with whom it had long friendships. All these countries are now fully independent, but force or conservative inertia, rather than the practice of democracy, have proved to be the decisive factors in how they are ruled; to one degree or another most remain authoritarian.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: DR. SUSAN G. WEINBERGER;

Mentors Help Students Stay in School
description: LEAD: THE United States Labor Secretary, Elizabeth Dole, recently called upon corporate leaders to release 10 percent of their employees to help local schools as mentors and tutors. While falling far short of that goal, such programs have begun in school systems all over the country, including Norwalk's, where 20 mentors started working at one elementary school in 1986.

title: Condos Pushing for Municipal Services

title: Question Of the Week;   Why Are Baseball Brawls So Common?
description: Obviously, the players are bored. Why else would they feel a need to create some ''action'' on the playing field?

title: Cutting Down On Trash
description: Logically, reducing the amount of garbage we generate should be primary, but legislation in this area is too often misguided because it is promulgated on a lack of knowledge, or disincentives. Two examples of this type of legislation are requiring the use of recycled newsprint with no understanding of the international market forces that drive the paper economy or the limited number of paper recycling mills, and higher taxation on single-use items, like disposable diapers or microwavable individual packaging, penalizing the consumer.

title: Garbo's Refuge
description: LEAD: ''You know, i've led a fabulous life,'' she said to my father last March, about a month before she died. It was a statement, not a reflection. We were having a vodka at sunset in her apartment, and she had just finished telling a story about touring the Cabinet War Rooms with Winston Churchill after World War II.

title: Gauging Next Move by Hussein: Uneasy Wait in a Tense Standoff
description: ''I can't predict what he's going to do,'' said President Bush about his current nemesis, President Saddam Hussein, at a news conference on Thursday. ''The unpredictable nature'' of the Iraqi leader, Mr. Bush argued, makes it impossible to say if war lies ahead.

title: Lauren E. Bober Weds Paul Young
description: LAUREN ELISE BOBER, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Bober of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday evening to PAUL BRETT YOUNG, a son of Brian P. Young of Johannesburg and Joan Young of Paris. Rabbi David Levy officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: To the Rescue
description: To the Editor: While in Glacier National Park in Montana in July, my daughter lost her thyroid medication. It was late Friday afternoon and we were to hike to Sperry Chalet on Sunday. To get to the chalet, we would have to climb 3,400 feet, with some of the terrain covered by snow.

title: Kuwait Exiles Rallying To Back Royal Rulers
description: Before the Iraqi invasion, Kuwait was not a nation in turmoil, but there were festering divisions over its halting steps toward full democracy.

title: Ann C. Neilan Marries
description: ANN CORNELIA NEILAN, an investment adviser for State Street Bank and Trust in Quincy, Mass., was married yesterday in Milford, Mass., to First Lieut. JAMES LEONARD ROTH, an Army lawyer. The Rev. Michael Roy officiated at St. Mary of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Roth, the daughter of Cornelia Neilan of Milford and the late Robert E. Neilan, graduated from Wheaton College. Lieutenant Roth, the son of Mrs. Claude Foulkes of Hartsdale, N.Y., is a member of the Judge Advocate General Corps in Norfolk, Va. He graduated from Boston University and received a law degree from Southern Methodist University.

title: Yachting;   2 World Regattas Set for U.S. Waters
description: It is only now and then that world championship events in yachting touch base in the United States. But this season, two of the sport's most competitive Olympic classes, the Star and the Flying Dutchman, are organizing world regattas in waters off Newport, R.I., and Cleveland.

title: DRIVING THROUGH DETROIT
description: When I read Ze'ev Chafets's article ''The Tragedy of Detroit'' (July 29) and saw the photographs, I was reminded of how in the 1960's The Detroit News published maps of the Detroit freeways, identifying ''safe'' routes into and out of the city for suburbanites. As a former resident of Detroit who is black, I find it difficult to discount thoughts of deliberate intent by the news media to destroy a city with negative publicity of this kind.

title: Specialty Magazines Covering New Jersey
description: Bride to Be, Greater New Jersey's own bridal magazine, was the original full-color glossy magazine specifically written and edited for the New Jersey market. The charter issue of Bride to Be, New Jersey, appeared in May 1986. The magazine has published, and will continue to publish, on its regular schedule without interruption.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 29 about the Berkshires misstated the price of lawn tickets at Tanglewood. They are $7 to $12. The concert season ends today.

description: ANIMAL DREAMS

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL

title: Married to the Beats
description: OFF THE ROAD: My Years With Cassady, Kerouac, and Ginsberg. By Carolyn Cassady. (Morrow, $22.95.) In August 1947, 24-year-old Carolyn Robinson found her boyfriend, Neal Cassady, naked in bed with his estranged wife and his friend Allen Ginsberg. The next year - on April Fool's Day - she married Cassady, and she spent the next 20 years amid the neurotic heroes of the Beat Generation. In ''Off the Road,'' Ms. Cassady confessionally chronicles their weird and wild escapades, which involved promiscuity, jail sentences and haphazard careers, as well as experimentation with marijuana, hashish, LSD and peyote. In 1952, Jack Kerouac moved into the Cassadys' New York City apartment. While still married to Neal, Ms. Cassady had an affair with Kerouac and became, in the words of Allen Ginsberg, Jack's ''Ideal Mother Image, Madwoman, chick and ignu.'' (''The last word,'' the poet explained, ''means a special honorary type post-hip intellectual. Its main root is ignoramus.'') While living with the Cassadys, Kerouac finished writing ''On the Road,'' which immortalized Cassady in the character of Dean Moriarty. The Cassadys eventually divorced, and Neal Cassady died in 1968, at the age of 43. Nearly two years later, at the age of 47, Kerouac died. This sometimes pathetic story culminates with one of Cassady's other wives calling Carolyn for Neal's ashes, then deciding to bury them in Kerouac's grave. Ms. Cassady, passive to the end, agrees to the odd request. Unfortunately, the author offers very little insight into her masochism and self-destructive tendencies. It's hard to swallow her portrayal of herself as a victimized good girl among the bad-boy beatniks and their harem. Still, ''Off the Road'' is rich with gossip, historically significant photographs, intimate memories, unpublished letters and - alas - bad poetry from the Beats.

title: PASTIMES: Gardening;   Tulips: A History of Success
description: There was a time when three tulip bulbs could be sold to pay for a house. That was in the Netherlands in 1636 at the height of Tulipmania, a wacky period in European history when a frenzy for greed held sway.

title: Crist Falls On Steeplechase
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'Shirley Valentine' At Westport Playhouse
description: During Willy Russell's crafty monodrama, ''Shirley Valentine,'' the summer season's final play at the Westport Country Playhouse, the audience is drawn into Shirley's release from intimidation. There is palpable delight at seeing her in Greece. And the playwright has given anecdotal color to more than a good half-dozen unseen characters, besides Joe: Shirley's liberating Greek lover, Costas, her rebellious son and bossy daughter, her obsessive father, an insensitive teacher, and a condescending, then unexpectedly compassionate neighbor.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Manchester, N.H.;

20-Story Tower For Downtown
description: LEAD: A 20-storY, 284,000-square-foot office tower has gone into construction in the heart of downtown.

title: Why Moscow Must Walk the Tightrope in Iraq;   The Long Way There
description: To the Editor:

title: Alarms Are Sounding About Rabid Raccoons
description: Rabies Now in the State

title: Wine Country
description: As Californians know, when seeking out lush fall foliage in their state one must look not to the trees but to the grape vines as they turn from green to gold and russet in late September and early October. The beauty of the vineyards in fall adds to the excitement of the season in Napa and Sonoma counties as rounds of private parties and public celebrations mark another grape harvest. The searing heat of summer gives way to a temperate climate, allowing visitors to sit outdoors and sip a glass of wine while watching the sun set over the miles of glowing vines, making this one of the best times to visit.

title: Data Bank/September 2, 1990
The Arena Theater in Washington Gets Ready for a Change of Cast
description: Arena Stage, the prestigious resident theater that was born in a 247-seat converted movie house on skid row, is about to celebrate its 40th year and its last season under the artistic direction of its founder and producing director. The transition comes at a time when Arena is embarking on a concentrated effort to build a multiracial company and reach out to a multicultural audience.

title:
DINING OUT;

Italy Is Updated With Theatricality in Rye Brook
description: LEAD: NO need to leave teen-agers, or anyone else for that matter, at home when dining at Provare. This witty, theatrical, exuberant trattoria will appeal to almost everyone. And it must be seen to be believed.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu;   A Quick Sauce for The Pasta
description: Now is the time for the coolness of a fresh uncooked tomato sauce, flavored with basil, atop a steaming mound of pasta. The meal is especially inviting with some ears of corn, just picked if possible. It can be a quick, undemanding supper.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: ACRONYM POWER
description: As an English teacher and sometime acronym enthusiast, I agree with Jack Rosenthal that ''the most obvious reason to coin an acronym is mnemonic, to make a term easy to remember.'' My students and I decided last year that our favorite acronym is IACOCCA. Lee Iacocca should have no trouble remembering his position, because he can say with certainty, ''I Am Chairman of Chrysler Corporation of America.''

title: Recession: Are the Questions How Deep and How Long?
description: The economic news was gloomy even before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait: half a year of lackluster growth, rising inflation and a softening employment picture. Now, as oil prices rise and consumer confidence tumbles to its lowest level in seven years, the battered economy is sure to take another beating. But does it mean recession or just more of the same - the softest of soft landings? And if it does mean recession, how long and how deep?

title: Edwin Reischauer, Diplomat and Scholar, Dies at 79
description: Edwin O. Reischauer, a scholar who specialized in East Asian affairs and who served as United States Ambassador to Japan from 1961 to 1966, died yesterday at Green Hospital of the Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation La Jolla, Calif. He was 79 years old and lived in Belmont, Mass., and La Jolla.

title: Madelaine Lynch Plans to Marry
description: Late September wedding plans for MADELAINE CHAUNCEY LYNCH and RICHARD JOHN MAKIN JR., a son of Mrs. Richard J. Makin of Gloucester, Mass., and the late Mr. Makin, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George P. Lynch Jr. of West Hartford, Conn.

title: Korean Divers Search for 20
description: Police divers searched today for at least 20 passengers reported missing after a bus slid off a highway bridge into a river, a South Korean news agency, Yonhap, reported. Four people managed to escape through windows after the bus plunged about 60 feet into the river near Yochon, about 35 miles southeast of Seoul. The rescued passengers told the agency that about 20 others were missing.

title: Ms. McDonnell Weds J. F. McAuliff Jr.
description: MARY BYRNE McDONNELL, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Chilton H. McDonnell of Warrenton, Va., was married yesterday to JOHN FRANCIS McAULIFF JR., a son of Mrs. McAuliff of Indianapolis and the late Mr. McAuliff. Stephanie Nichols, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the home of William and Catherine Rieser in Perkasie, Pa.

title: Tap Germany's Expertise With Synfuels
description: To the Editor:

title:
FILM;

Preston Sturges: The Film Maker Seen Whole
description: LEAD: ''California is all right for the Californians. The people who rave about it are the people who came from somewhere worse,'' wrote Preston Sturges to a friend after his first month as a screenwriter in Hollywood. It was 1932, and the restless cosmopolitan from New York was at the beginning of a two-decade Hollywood career as a screenwriter and screenwriter-director.

title: Film Series Returns To College
description: LEAD: THE fall Friday night film series at Westchester Community College returns on Sept. 14, opening with ''Cinema Paradiso,'' the 1989 Academy Award winner for best foreign film.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Do the Mets Have What It Takes to Win It All?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: The Executive Computer;   Unsure What Program to Buy? Sample Some
description: ''Shareware'' has become increasingly popular with businesses, government agencies and educational institutions. Shareware is commercial software that differs from the more conventional programs primarily in the way it is distributed and priced. The underlying philosophies of shareware are that good software need not be expensive and that users should be able to try software before buying it.

title: Belinda Hughes: Coat Designer
description: It happens every year: parents frantically seek the right coat for children. Casual or dressy or for all occasions? How much should they spend when the child will outgrow the coat in a year?

title: Some Portents of Trends in Autumn Fashions
description: Retailers admit that business is not good, what with the high price of clothing and the anxiety over the Middle East. But even in the worst of times, some women take comfort in shopping.

title: Will You Listen for a Minute?
description: IN THE ROOM WE SHARE

title: AIDS Is Not the Only Political Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: After Years Of Declines, School Rolls Stabilize
description: Overall enrollment throughout the Island is declining slightly on the secondary level and beginning to rise on the elementary level. Nassau County has shown a slight overall decline, but there are some growing areas in Suffolk that are showing increasing enrollment. Schools across Long Island are also seeing an influx of immigrant populations, which have helped to keep the school enrollments steady. The fastest-growing population on the Island are Asians, who seem to be attracted to school districts with the better reputations, said Edward Murphy, district superintendent of BOCES III. There is also a growing Hispanic population on the Island, he said.

title: 49ers Heading for a Third Straight Supper Bowl Title ... but Broncos Hope to Find Way to Win Their First
description: The following American Conference preview was prepared and written by Gerald Eskenazi. Teams are listed in the predicted order of finish, with Denver picked to go to the Super Bowl.

title: SALVADOR JESUITS CLAIM ARMY FIRING
description: Two Jesuit priests said they were pinned down here for two hours and nearly killed by an army sniper in what church officials are denouncing as the most recent in a series of attacks on rural civilians.

title: Dorian R. Deglin To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Deglin of New York have announced October wedding plans for their daughter DORIAN REED DEGLIN and JAMES HOWK SCAMMON, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Scammon Jr. of Hopkinton, N.H.

title: A Fall Wedding For Jill Marans
description: Mr. and Mrs. Victor Marans of New York have announced October wedding plans for their daughter JILL MARANS and MITCHELL ROBERT LUBIN, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen H. Lubin of Rochester.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch;   From Bustling Deli to Elegant Cafe
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

title: Miss Lindenbaum To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Lindenbaum of New York have announced November wedding plans for their daughter LAURIE ELLEN LINDENBAUM and ROBERT ALAN HORNE, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred M. Horne of Wheeling, W.Va.

title: Dr. Tobin Weds Dr. David Ritterband
description: DR. CORINNE TOBIN, a resident in radiology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, and DR. DAVID CARL RITTERBAND, an intern at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan, were married last evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue. Rabbi Philip Graubart performed the ceremony. Dr. Tobin, 26 years old, is keeping her name. A daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Tobin of Seaford, L.I., she graduated from Yale University and received her M.D. degree from New York Medical College. Her father is a physician and her mother is a retired elementary-school teacher.

title: Tom Herr Adjusts to Playing for 'Them'
description: Tom Herr had no time to think about it. He had to react.

title: BUSH WILL MEET GORBACHEV ON SUNDAY, GULF ON AGENDA; IRAQIS LET SOME HOSTAGES GO
description: President Bush announced today that he and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet in Helsinki on Sept. 9. Administration officials said the meeting was intended to display superpower solidarity at a time when Washington is eager to hold together the alliance against Iraq.

title: Dodge City Believed in Strict Gun Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Jane E. Frieder To Wed in Fall
description: The engagement of JANE ELIZABETH FRIEDER to MARK WILF, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wilf of Hillside, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Philip R. Frieder of Rydal, Pa. An October wedding is planned.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: San Francisco State;   Canceling Classes Prompts Lines To Alter Schedules
description: The sudden cancellation of 200 classes at San Francisco State University on Tuesday forced students to wait in registration lines for as long as eight hours for a chance to rearrange their schedules.

title: Praise for Ending Kindergarten Screening
description: A child who is nervous and overwhelmed by a new situation (and who may, if screened in the spring, be as young as 4 1/2) is not going to give an accurate picture of current capability or potential. A much better way to learn about children's abilities is in school. Kindergarten, a transition year between preschool and grade school, is the ideal time for a school system to get to know its children.

title: What America Did After the War: A Tale Told by the Census
description: THOUGH foggy as a steamed-up bathroom mirror, the early 1990 census figures released last week offered the country its first look at itself as it emerged from the 1980's: the sagging cities, spreading suburbs, and the southern coasts and the Southwestern states bulging with economic and political muscle.

title: Blacks Return To Homeland Pretoria Took
description: The blue-gum trees are the same, and so is the wind that kneads them. And some people are the same, too, seeking shade and shadow below the trees in the first stirrings of an African summer.

title: Valerie Artzt Wed To Mark P. Coles
description: VALERIE JAN ARTZT, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Artzt of Stroudsburg, Pa., was married last evening to MARK PETER COLES, a son of Patricia Coles of Canberra, Australia, and the late Noel Coles. Rabbi Charles Davidson and the Rev. Louis Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Judy Kreston and David Fields Lahm Are Married
description: JUDY KRESTON, the daughter of the late Gitta Gradova and the late Dr. Maurice H. Cottle of Chicago, was married yesterday to DAVID FIELDS LAHM, the son of the late Dorothy Fields, the lyricist, and the late Eli Lahm of New York. Rabbi Charles Davidson officiated at the couple's home in Chelsea.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Aug. 18

title: Accepting the Risk in Forecasting
description: Tens of billions of dollars were wasted in the 1980's by investing in the wrong future. More will be lost in the decades to come. One of the costliest examples was the collapse of the synthetic fuels industry. Energy companies and the United States Government first spent billions of dollars on the false assumption that oil prices would endlessly rise only to cancel their efforts when prices fell. They failed to understand the oil roller coaster. Now that Saddam Hussein has set off another price rise, we wish we had the option of producing synthetic fuel. There have been other recent forecasting disasters as well.

title:
ART;

Links to Ecological Themes
description: LEAD: INSTALLATION pieces are a rapidly growing interest among artists all over the world. For example, they figure prominently in the current Venice Biennale, the oldest and best known international showcase.

title: More Oil from more PLaces Could Loosen Gulf's Grip
description: TO many Americans, it's clear enough why Saddam Hussein must be stopped: Such a man cannot be permitted to control the oil lifeline to the world's industrialized nations. But even if Mr. Hussein were to retire to Switzerland tomorrow, the West's dependence on the Persian Gulf - and thus its vulnerability to conflict in the Middle East - would continue to grow.

title:
Your Own Account;

Out on Your Own? Watch Your Step
description: LEAD: Many people who decide to leave their jobs and set up their own business make amistake when analyzing how much money they must earn: They underestimate the real value of their current salary and benefits package and ignore the tax implications of self-employment.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. PETER HALL;

Keeping Race Horses in the Running
description: LEAD: KEEPING patients in good overall condition is a physician's continuing goal, and Dr. Peter Hall is no exception. He is a veterinarian at three of the state's five race tracks - Monmouth Park, Garden State Park and the Meadowlands (the others are the Atlantic City Racetrack and the Freehold Raceway).

title: Who Did It? And What Does It All Mean?
description: A BED BY THE WINDOW

title: In the Region: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
A Procrustean Bed For Our Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Data Update
Pretoria Condemns Shootings of Protesters
description: Amid a fierce dispute over police behavior in South Africa's segregated black townships, an official report released today castigated officers for opening fire on protesters in March without justification or orders to do so.

title: Dominican 'Toll'
description: To the Editor: The toll at the Santo Domingo entrance to the autopista linking the capital city of the Dominican Republic with Puerto Plata and the famed beaches of the north is 50 centavos, about 8 cents. Some 22 miles farther along that road, however, is an unofficial ''toll'' so exorbitant that ''highway robbery'' would be a more appropriate term.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 6 of the Arts and Leisure section today about a Balinese dancer misstates the performance date for a troupe of Balinese children at Montclair (N.J.) State College. It is Friday, Sept. 14, not this Friday.

title: Tax Those Big Gas Guzzlers by Engine Size
description: To the Editor:

title: A Summer's Day, A Mower's Roar
description: If you haven't bought that neighbor's house, or moved, you probably will after discovering what autumn holds in cacophonous contributions: leaf blowers.

title: Cola Parker Is a Bride
description: COLA GODDEN PARKER and HAROLD WILLIAM ANDERSON 3D were married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sumner Parker of Easton, Md. Miss Parker, 27 years old, is a graduate of Dartmouth College and is studying for a master's degree in architecture at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Mr. Anderson, 36, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anderson Jr. of Ludlow, Vt. He graduated from Trinity College in Hartford and teaches Spanish at the Groton (Mass.) School.

title: Ireland
description: To the Editor: I could not resist writing in regard to Nancy Sharkey's article (''By Horse Through Ireland's West,'' Travel, July 15). She wrote about a stone hunting lodge, Screebe Lodge, where she spent two nights, and mentioned that the owner spun tales of Lady Dudley's ghost.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;

Michigan's Cherries, Berries and Pies
description: LEAD: By 7 o'clock every morning Bill Fraser is rolling out pie dough - sometimes enough for up to 90 double crusts - at Jesperson's Restaurant in Petoskey, Mich. They serve breakfast there, but most customers will be coming in for the cherry-berry pie (the berries are red raspberries) - and the customers come in from all over.

title: 'I Have Never Been Able to Tell a Story'
description: Denis Donoghue, the literary critic and scholar, grew up in the small town of Warrenpoint in Northern Ireland, at the end of an inlet of the Irish Sea called Carlingford Lough. In his new book, named for the town, he combines a memoir of coming of age with meditations on literary and religious influences that helped shape his life and thought.

title: Miss Fredd Plans To Marry in Fall
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Fredd of Potomac, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, NATALIE HEATHER FREDD, to SCOTT BALIAN KULDELL, a son of Mrs. Philip D. Kuldell of Potomac and the late Mr. Kuldell. A November wedding is planned.

title: Joy Amid the Pain
description: CARNAL ACTS

title: The Peacock Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Feminist on a Woman's Errand
description: To the Editor:

title: Coping With Dull Cutting Tools
description: During use, the stone must be kept saturated with lightweight cutting oil or mineral oil. This captures the metal particles scraped from the blade and prevents them from clogging the stone and ruining it.

title: See How They Run and Shoot
description: ''They were so-ooo bad,'' said Mouse Davis, as he frowned, tugged at his cap, bent it and then squashed it onto his head. Davis was reflecting on the Detroit Lions offense he inherited 13 games into the 1988 season, a plodding and groping offense in an ugly 4-12 year.

title: Jets' Quarterback Decision Goes to Wire
description: Besides the fact that he has still not named a clear-cut winner in the battle between Kenny O'Brien and Tony Eason for the Jets' starting quarterback job, Coach Bruce Coslet has some other thorny decisions to make just one week before his regular-season debut.

title: Does Top Dollar Buy Top Audio?
description: The cooled-off economy has predictably dampened the audio trade. Dealers grumble about the slump but add smilingly that the really expensive stuff is selling as well as ever.

title: We, the Rich
description: THE BORDERLESS WORLD

title: Below the Surface On Fathers' Rights
description: We are discovering millions of walking wounded as adult survivors of child abuse speak out about the horror of their childhoods. As children, most of them told an adult of the abuse but weren't believed. Sadly enough, nothing has changed. Children are still being abused by trusted adults in epidemic proportions, and no one is listening as they ask for help. While studies have shown that 98 percent of children who tell about abuse are telling the truth, child-protective services validate only about 40 percent of the alleged child-abuse reports made to them. Less than 5 percent of child sexual abusers ever admit to being abusive.

title: The Body As Provocateur And Victim
description: ''Figuring the Body,'' at The Museum of Fine Arts, through Oct. 28, is an important and timely exhibition, although in no sense is it the last word on the subject of contemporary art and the human form. It is, finally, diffuse and preachy, as if the museum's curators - Kathy Halbreich (appointed this week as the new director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis) and Trevor Fairbrother - had wanted above all to insure that their display touched on as many points of political interest as possible.

title: Joan D. O'Grady Is Engaged
description: Mrs. John P. O'Grady of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter JOAN DEIRDRE O'GRADY to ANDREW HENRY BARADA, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew S. Barada 3d of New Canaan, Conn. An October wedding is planned. The prospective bride, also a daughter of the late Mr. O'Grady, graduated from Georgetown University and is a nurse epidemiologist at New York Hospital. Mr. Barada, a cum laude graduate of Lehigh University, is a senior project engineer at the Material Research Corporation, a semiconductor manufacturer in Orangeburg, N.Y.

title: Turning Humble Materials Into Salable Arts and Crafts
description: ''I don't have a passion for handicrafts,'' admitted the organization's president, Clare Brett Smith, ''but I like what these handicrafts represent.''

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER For Students, the Grand Tour at Budget Prices
description: Where did the young people travel this summer? Mostly to Europe, as always, according to those who deal in wholesale student and youth tickets. Where in Europe? Wherever it's cheap, said the owner of a courier-booking service.

title: This Courtroom Is a Long Way From 'L.A. Law'
description: It took only a brief stint as a juror in Manhattan to convince Andy Wolk that when it came to criminal justice in New York, reality is the best story of all. But as Mr. Wolk or any other writer can attest, reality is never easy to simulate, particularly the reality of a system under siege, and particularly in a made-for-TV drama.

title: U.S. and Britain, 'Mixed Up Together' for 50 Years
description: LEAD: The Anglo-American alliance that has flourished in the Persian Gulf in recent weeks celebrates its 50th birthday today.

title: Mercedes Gets Smoother by the Mile
description: AT first glance, the car in the driveway looks like a new Mercedes. At second glance, it still looks that way. But this silver sedan has been a real nomad since it rolled out of a Florida dealer's showroom back in October 1984.

title: To Cut School Costs, Try Regionalization
description: If school financing is to be so regionalized, then it's time for the schools themselves to be regionalized. The escalating and ruinous costs to the present smaller school districts make regionalization an absolute imperative, even without the State Supreme Court decision.

title: Susan Kendrick Wed to B.P. Kaufman
description: SUSAN C. KENDRICK, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. E. Kendrick of Columbus, Ind., was married there yesterday to BENJAMIN P. KAUFMAN, a son of Mrs. Robert C. Rosenberg of New York and Harold Kaufman of San Francisco. The Rev. Allan Wilson performed the interfaith ceremony at the First United Methodist Church.

title: Muslims in Sri Lanka Flee Violence of Civil War
description: Barely 7 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people are Muslims, the descendants of Arab traders who sailed here centuries ago. They have lived largely undisturbed on this abundant island, through Portuguese, Dutch and British colonization and 42 years of Sri Lankan independence, running businesses, farms and fishing boats.

title: R. A. Martinelli Weds Miss Gorski
description: Christ the King Church in Snyder, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriageof CATHERINE CURREY GORSKI, a daughter of Justice and Mrs. Jerome C. Gorski of Williamsville, N.Y., to RAYMOND ANTHONY MARTINELLI, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Martinelli of South Windsor, Conn. The Rev. Donald W. Trautman, the Roman Catholic Bishop of Erie, Pa., performed the ceremony.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A refreshment stand is on the site but visitors can also take picnics. Admission is free except for a $1 parking charge. To reach the site take I-684 to Exit 4, go right on 172, and take Route 22 north to Route 121. Turn onto Route 137 and the farm is on the right. Call 234-3954 for more information.

title: Just Stop the Arguing Between Parents
description: Dr. Lipow asks why he can't continue to enjoy joint custody despite getting a divorce. The answer is: you can't have it all. Don't get married if you can't handle the responsibilities. Divorce always has a price; if you don't want to pay, work things out with your spouse and stay married.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

When Gum Balls Cost a Penny
description: LEAD: ONE rainy evening not long ago I found myself at the glassed-in entrance/exit area of the local grocery store, balancing a bag of groceries on my hip while attempting to slip into my overcoat and find my car keys without poking an eye out with my umbrella. Then I noticed the only other person there - a little boy about 5, standing in front of a two-tiered bank of gum-ball machines.

title: A 'World of Miracles' Copes With New Realities
description: Down the hall, Sherry Miller, of New Haven, had gone into labor with her sixth child. With her husband, Paul, by her side, Mrs. Miller, 39, said she had delivered each of her other five children within two hours and without medication. ''I walk a lot,'' she said.

title: At College Stores, Colors Are Cooler, But Sales ($5.5 Billion) Remain Hot
description: ''We're getting a back-to-basics group this year,'' said Deborah Rizzo-Puccio, who runs the campus bookstore at the State University of New York at New Paltz. ''They'll be more traditional in dress and more serious about issues.''

title: Jews, Blacks and Trouble in Hollywood
description: Perhaps it was one of those unspoken issues that keep smoldering until something finally ignites it. For years, blacks had rightfully complained about their unconscionably small numbers in positions of power in Hollywood, but in July during a panel discussion on blacks in the entertainment industry at the convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in Los Angeles, the debate took a strange and disquieting new turn.

title: U.S. Mistakenly Sold a Prosecutor's Secret Data
description: A United States Attorney's secret computer files, including electronic copies of sealed indictments and information about pending F.B.I. inquiries, were mistakenly sold by the Government a month ago to a businessman who paid $45 for what he thought was only broken computer equipment.

title: Mentally Ill Residents of Group Home Coach Actors for Play
description: LEAD: THE other day, a half-dozen actors packed into a blue mini-van and made a midday journey from their Manhattan rehearsal studio to an unassuming brick and shingled house on a peaceful residential street in Westbury.

title: Gorbachev Steps Into the Gulf Lineup
description: In the briefest possible announcement, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev informed the Soviet nation tonight that he had elected to become a far more visible world player in the critical standoff over Iraq's invasion and seizure of Kuwait.

title: DRIVING THROUGH DETROIT
description: I happen to live in a very solid house in a very safe, stable, racially mixed neighborhood on Detroit's East Side. It isn't an affluent neighborhood, and it isn't a slum. It is just one of many middle- or working-class neighborhoods found throughout the city, and it's certainly not the exception.

title: Phantom Breeze Wins Manhattan
description: Phantom Breeze, who had made a summer of getting caught by better horses, snapped an 11-race losing streak with a front-running six-length victory yesterday in the $86,850 Manhattan Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: In Hussein, the Palestinians Have an Ally and a Curse
description: THE veteran Israeli politician Abba Eban is widely credited with coining an aphorism about Palestinian diplomacy that has stuck for many years: The Palestinians never miss an opportunity to miss an opportunity. Now some Israelis might modify that: The Palestinians never give up a chance to hurt their chances.

title: Hawaii
description: To the Editor: Oh! No! Not Lanai! (Travel, June 3). Returning from a two-month around-the-world-on-our-own tour in 1983, my husband and I spent four delicious, relaxing, noncommercial days on Lanai. The small and only hotel with its Spartan accommodations, the town simplicity (latest postcard 1921), jeep drives over barren moonlike territory, secluded beaches, narrow mountain ridge drives with breathtaking views of the island, sea and distant Maui, the endless pineapple fields and all that penetrating red dust - the last quiet, uncrowded uncluttered spot. And now it's gone!

title: Q and A
description: Finding a Travel Partner

title: POLICE TAKING AIM AT SLOT MACHINES
description: The days when the police in New York City wielded sledgehammers against slot machines have returned.

title: In Rush to Save What's Left, Historic Districts Spread
description: The rate of approval is also increasing. From 1961 to last year, local property owners voted for about half the proposed districts. Last year, 9 of 10 proposed districts were approved. ''The western part of the state has had the greatest success rate in getting historic districts passed,'' said John W. Shannahan, director of the Connecticut Historical Society, which reviews all proposals. ''But more and more people are realizing that this is the only law that can really protect a historic community.

title: A Summer's Day, A Mower's Roar
description: LEAD: In response to Irving Kamil's article, "Will You Turn That Mower Off?" (Opinion page, July 15):

title: A Reconfigured Times Sq. Station Has a Blueprint
description: The Times Square subway station, congested, often forbidding and one of the most dangerous stations in the city, will be transformed under renovation plans completed recently after six years of study.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT'S likely that few have noticed, but since the last days of July, New Jersey has been slowly infiltrated by a gathering host of birds. They are small. They are stealthy. Many are cryptically colored; more bland, by far, than beautiful. What's more, they are silent. This feathered fifth column is composed of warblers.

title: Who Decides Who Works At Jobs Imperiling Fetuses?
description: The unobtrusive factory, tucked behind a hillside shopping center in this little college town, runs all day and all night seven days a week. The 280 production workers make lead automobile batteries for Sears, Goodyear and other big customers. Only 12 workers are women, and none of them can have children. The company won't hire any who can.

title: Question Of the Week;   Why Are Baseball Brawls So Common?
description: When someone throws a hard ball at you at 90-plus miles per hour it tends to make you quite angry.

title: Canada's Atlantic Side
description: Windswept Signal Hill, which overlooks the mile-long placid oval of the St. John's harbor in Newfoundland, was the perfect place for Guglielmo Marconi to await, in 1901, the first wireless signal from Europe. Its green and red sandstone cliffs, containing no iron to interfere with an electromagnetic current, drop dauntingly enough to induce vertigo in the most stalwart of souls. If electric waves were to travel from 1,250 miles away, surely the first place they would strike would be this high promontory holding fast against the North Atlantic gales.

title: U.N.-Iraq Talks Break Off
description: Talks between the Secretary General of the United Nations and Iraq's Foreign Minister, aimed at persuading Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, broke off inconclusively. Page 19.

''Pretty soon,'' wrote the wannabe trend-buster, ''the California littoral will be littered with these guys, stroked out on the beach like beached white whales, and girls, too, who can't give up the mystique, the mysterioso mystique. . . .''

title: In Quest of That Singular Quality Known as Style

She praised the New York City Ballet for having a style of its own. And when asked how a young choreographer could develop a personal style, she replied that this necessarily involves ''spending thousands of hours in a studio by yourself.''

title: New Stamp on a New Season

title: Students Learn to Conserve Wildlife
description: LEAD: BIRD'S nest surveys, a fish census and correcting erosion problems on wilderness trails are not the typical summer activities of most middle-school-aged students. But for eight weeks this summer, 15 youths, members of the Union County Trailside Nature Center's Rangers, learned firsthand about such wildlife conservation methods.

title: Halpin Adamant on 1991 Property-Tax Pledge

title: Bus Schedules and School Bells End Motherhood's First Leg

(Not that I'll mourn the passing of hot weather - after two babies and a steady diet of Twinkies, the words ''bathing suit'' have left my vocabulary.) No, I'm wincing as the weeks pass because fall means September. September means school reopens.

Since the 1960's the Showboat has been known for its reproduction of a Mississippi riverboat docked next to its property, which runs down to the shore of Greenwich Harbor just off Exit 3 of the New England Thruway.

description: Despite a national education movement intended partly to give teachers more control over their classrooms and curriculums, teachers are increasingly unhappy with their lack of authority, with their working conditions and with the movement for better schools itself, according to a sweeping survey by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.

title: A Village Among the Vineyards
description: A sign hanging in the Williams Selyem Winery outside Healdsburg, Calif., reads, ''Wine is God's proof that He loves us and likes to see us happy.'' As Bert Williams, one of the owners, poured his pinot noir for my friends and me to taste, it was a slogan easy for us to believe. Bert's partner, Ed Selyem, joined us and we took our glasses outside and sat on a low wall overlooking the vineyard. The sun was hot. Where grapes are grown and how wine is made is good talk. No one was in a hurry. The owners at this winery will welcome you if you call, even if they may not have cases to sell to you. Production is limited and is spoken for quickly, although the White House did manage to get a 1985 pinot noir to serve at a recent dinner. Many of the wine maps don't mention Williams Selyem. It's one of many, many open secrets in this area that you can come upon for yourself, then wonder why you never heard of it, since so many others have.

title: Tech Notes;   Making Lightning Like Nature's Own
description: Lightning flashes are a significant threat to aircraft, missiles and nuclear weapons. Designing devices to withstand such blows has always been compromised by the inability of man-made tools to mimic natural electric fields, which have as much as 100 million volts. Now the Sandia National Laboratory in Albuquerque, N.M., has developed a lightning simulator that can simulate an extremely severe cloud-to-ground direct strike. It can deliver current to a large test object with peak power and speed very close to the most extreme levels found in natural lightning. The Sandia lightning simulator relies on a proprietary ''crowbar'' switch, which evolved from the lab's fusion power program. The switch is filled with sulphur hexafluoride gas to hold off the high voltage and is triggered by a laser pulse.

title: Imbalances in Trade

title: Review/Dance;   Alan Good Explores Space And Time
description: A slight tension between solitariness and group activity persisted through the piece. Solos reflected essential elements of each dancer's presence. Mischa Van Dullemen's springy bounce and charged stillness provided a nice counterpart to Calla Jo's look of teasing gravity and alertness and Jeannie Steele's quick, light leg and foot work. A stubby little trio near the end, with arms crooking into right-angled frames, was interesting but seemed somehow out of place. But ''Repeater'' is an engaging, satisfying piece. It is dedicated to the memory of Philip Salvatori, a charming and witty Martha Graham dancer who died in 1987. It is clear that Mr. Good has been influenced by Mr. Cunningham's style of dance. But he uses that style as a springboard rather than a crutch in ''Repeater'' and in ''Spry Dave,'' a trio performed in silence. There is a look of arbitrariness to the way the two dances are plotted. There is a tinge of comedy to the ''Spry Dave'' trio, whose dancers assume some quietly eccentric shapes. The three dancers seem to exist in a magnetic field in which bodies fall into and out of motion for no apparent reason.

title: New I.B.M. Mainframes Due

Where I.B.M's Profits Are While I.B.M. has also introduced powerful computers that use microprocessors, this market is far more competitive and less profitable than the mainframe market, where I.B.M. still holds almost 90 percent of the American market and therefore has been able to dictate prices. Including software and peripherals, mainframes account for more than half of the Armonk, N.Y., company's annual profits, analysts estimate.

title: Books of The Times Encounters Odd and Normal at Once
description: As readers of Mr. Baxter's earlier books (''Through the Safety Net,'' ''First Light,'' ''Harmony of the World'') are aware, such events are not merely isolated epiphanies. Rather, they underscore a view of the world as a highly precarious place, where the arc of a life may be suddenly and irrevocably altered by a random occurrence, where happiness and domestic calm are highly provisional - subject to accidents, bad luck, unexpected passions and unforeseen twists of fate. An idealistic man befriends a crazed, homeless man, then realizes that his act of good will has awakened fears and resentments in his wife and son (''Shelter''). A 12-year-old boy accompanies his older brother and his girlfriend to a lake where a car has fallen through the ice, and he has a glimpse of the perils and uncertainties of the grown-up world that awaits him (''Snow''). A woman who realizes that she loves her husband's best friend develops an irrational fear of prowlers that keeps her awake at night.

The merger will make Subaru of America a wholly owned subsidiary of Fuji, the Japanese manufacturer that builds Subaru cars.

title: Battle Scene on Egyptian Temple May Be Earliest View of Israelites
description: The result is a growing consensus among Egyptologists, Biblical scholars and archeologists that most of the early Israelites were Canaanites. Into their midst may have filtered some nomadic shepherds from east of the Jordan and others who had fled Egypt, assuming the story of Exodus has a historical basis. But they were mainly Canaanites who settled along the ridge running north from Hebron through Jerusalem far from the fortified city-states to the west.

title: Beijing Journal;   A Mystical Art, but Can It Make the Lame Walk?
description: Craze Sweeps the Country

title: Presto! They Vanish
description: When things reach this stage people need something to chase their troubles away. This is why the latest military expedition has been so refreshing. It has given us some new news.

title: INSIDE
description: Page B1.

title: Talking Business; with Weinberg of Hartmarx;   Merging of Roles Seen in Retailing
description: Q. Is dual distribution still valid in these turbulent times for retailing?
