description: 'Indefinite Time Frame'

title: Florida St. to A.C.C.?
description: But he cautioned that the eight members aren't sure if they want to add No. 9.

title: Growing Fiscal Problems Put Squeeze on Social Programs in Many States
description: ''We probably have over 35 states who are in what I would say are degrees of fiscal difficulty, and I believe that human services, social programs, are clearly feeling the pinch in most of those states,'' said Gerald Miller, executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers. ''There's no question the next couple of years will be much tougher, and the outlook is that those with the least ability to lobby the legislature will be hurt the most.''

title: A Major Studio Plans to Test the Rating System
description: The director of ''Henry and June,'' Philip Kaufman, whose other films include ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being'' and ''The Right Stuff,'' says he plans to appeal the X rating. The case seems certain to rally critics who have called for a change in the system to allow seriously intended adult films to be given a rating that does not connote pornography.

title: Chided for Pushing Research, Colleges Reaffirm Education
description: LEAD: American higher education has become the envy of much of the rest of the world but, increasingly, a disappointment at home.

title: Immigrants Look Outside New York for Better Life
description: ''There is fear,'' said Clarence Davis, whose said his business, Clarence Davis Realty in the East Flatbush area of Brooklyn, has increased 60 percent in the last three years as a result of the migration. ''I'm talking within the community. There are a certain number of youngsters who make their living selling drugs. They frighten the hard-working people. They don't want to be with that element. That is the reason many people decide to migrate.''

title: Tennis;   Graf Gives Capriati a Quick Lesson on Playing at the Top
description: ''She seems,'' her coach would say later, ''a little tied up. But maybe it's not so much Capriati as it is a big match in the U.S. Open, and that 20,000 people will be probably rooting for Jennifer. And you have to remember, too, that she was not herself in her last match.'' A Comeback at 21? In that match, she had lost a set to Elna Reinach, a name hardly ever uttered in the same breath with Graf, the No. 1-ranked woman in the world.

title: Kansas City Journal;   Coyotes Don't Know It, But Airport Isn't Prairie
description: Airport crews began trying to trap and dispose of the the animals. For one trapped coyote, a blow to the back of the head was enough to kill it. But the result was explosive.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   How a Vacation Helps Even a Crisis President
description: Whatever the reason, the President's demeanor was noticeably sunnier last week. Some traced the change to last Monday morning, when he went fishing at 5 A.M. He floated around the Kennebunk River for an hour or two, catching nothing but grinning broadly when he spied a group of bleary-eyed reporters on the bank swatting frantically at early-morning hordes of moquitoes.

title: Queries First, Aid Later For a County's Homeless
description: In three gleaming white trailers here on the grounds of the Westchester County Airport, doctors, mental-health professionals and social workers spend three days evaluating and examining each person applying for shelter. The applicants stay in an adjacent shelter. A similar program is being developed for homeless families, which for now are still sent directly to motels.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising - ADDENDA;   Miscellany
description: For their winning entry, a billboard for Oil of Olay, an art director, Ralph Yznaga, and a copywriter, Alison Grant, will receive trips to London.

title: Parading Into Fall to the Tempo of the Day
description: Marching Into Autumn

title: Virginia Beach a Year Later: Roadblocks and Calm
description: Peace, But at a Price

title: Congress Returning to Its Tasks With No Sign of Budget Accord
description: Hundreds of thousands of furlough notices have been sent to employees of Federal agencies planning for automatic cuts if Congress does not meet its mandated deficit targets, and many members predict that Congress will have to return for its first post-election session since 1982.

title: Bird Songs Offer Clues To Habitats
description: ''If an area is unsuitable for a particular species it can relatively easily fly away in hopes of finding a more suitable habitat,'' said Ms. Croonquist, who worked on the project with Dr. Robert P. Brooks, an associate professor of wildlife ecology.

title: Nancy Sutton, 67, Dies; Retired Ad Executive
description: Ms. Sutton, who spent 30 years in advertising, became a vice president in 1962 at Grey Advertising Inc. in Manhattan. Canada Dry, Timex, Revlon and B. F. Goodrich were among her accounts. She retired in 1987.

title: Sweetwater: The Nobility Of Simplicity
description: ''The last time I saw him, I noticed he'd gained a lot of weight; you know, sitting in a cab, not getting any exercise,'' recalled Jim Watkins, a boyhood friend of Clifton's. ''I said, 'Sweets, man, you gotta lose some weight.' He just laughed and said, 'I'm living good, Nuggie.' That was Sweets. Sweets was happy with himself; that's something very few people can say.''

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   WIDE AIR DEPLOYMENT BY U.S. IS REPORTED IN GULF NATIONS; IRAQ BARS 3 HOSTAGE FLIGHTS
description: Only a handful of the aircraft deployments had been publicly disclosed because of the gulf nations' sensitivities about inviting the Americans. The arrangements, discussed by American and Saudi officials in interviews in recent days, were worked out by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney during his recent visit to Saudi Arabia and the four gulf nations.

title: Powerful Light Beam
description: The device consists of the mirror of a conventional 16-inch telescope, which bounces sunlight to a spot 0.39 of an inch in diameter about a yard away. The spot is aligned with a kind of sapphire cone, which then bends and squeezes the light to a beam less than 0.004 of an inch in diameter.

title: Armed Mohawks Dig In and Vow to Resist Troops
description: The dispute began on July 11 when several dozen armed Mohawks belonging to a militant group known as the Warrior Society fought a gun battle with the Quebec Provincial Police in the Indian community of Kanesatake, in the town of Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal. A police officer was killed in the encounter.

title: Iran-Contra Trial of Former C.I.A. Official to Begin
description: Mr. Clines is the eighth person to be prosecuted in the three-and-a-half-year investigation into the Iran-contra affair, which centers on the sale of arms to Iran and efforts to supply weapons to rebels in Nicaragua after Congress barred direct military assistance to them. Prosecutors have said Mr. Clines's failure to disclose his income was part of a broad effort by people in the affair to conceal their activities.

title: Football;   Coslet Chooses O'Brien To Start as Jet Quarterback
description: Congratulations From Eason

title: Review/Television;   A System With Criminals But Not Much Justice
description: Two cases take up most of the hour. Viewers see a young man being approached on a bus by a sharp-eyed Port Authority detective. The suspect turns out to be one of the ''mules'' who are paid to transport drugs from New York to other cities, just one of the tens of thousands of such inner-city youths who are picked up every year.

title: Umpires and a Lawsuit On Vincent's Daybook
description: Among other arguments, the lawyer said, the suit will contend that Vincent is biased and that Kleinman would not be able to get a fair hearing before him.

title: Patterns
description: Customers have already canceled orders for the Paris haute couture, which depends on rich Arabs for its business. Some houses like Jean-Louis Scherrer and Guy Laroche, which sell up to 30 percent of their clothes to Arab clients, have lost a small number of orders from Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, Women's Wear Daily reported last week.

title: Tourist Slain In a Subway In Manhattan
description: The victim, Brian Watkins of Provo, stepped in when a group of young men slashed his father's pants pocket and buttocks and hit his mother in the station at 53d Street and Seventh Avenue. The family was going to dinner at the Tavern on the Green in Central Park.

title: Countdown Begins for Long-Delayed Shuttle
description: The launching is scheduled for 1:20 A.M. on Thursday. The countdown clock started ticking early today.

title: Chile Cool to Argentina's Plan on Economic Ties
description: A Cooler Reception

title: A Plague on Tennis
description: LEAD: The U.S. Open, America's premier tennis event, is under way and at the end of its two hectic weeks of fierce competition, new champions will be crowned in the men's and women's fields. But one of the hottest controversies on the professional tennis circuit will remain unresolved: the threat to the integrity of the game posed by the new breed of power rackets.

title: 4 Companies Order $13.45 Billion in Aircraft
description: In a dispatch from Seoul, The Associated Press reported today that the South Korean carrier Asiana Airlines had ordered 27 airliners from the Boeing Company and had taken options on 24 more aircraft, in a deal that could be worth as much as $6 billion.

title: BRIEFS
description: LEAD: Common Stock

title: Markets Closed For Holiday
description: LEAD: The nation's stock, bond and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of the Labor Day holiday. Government offices and most banks were also closed.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. Jet Crashes; No Injuries
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 - LEAD: An Air Force F-16 involved in the American buildup in the Gulf crashed today in the southern Arabian peninsula during a training mission, the Pentagon said. A spokesman said the pilot ejected and was unhurt in the accident.

title: Hugh Owens, 80, Dies; Ex-Member of S.E.C.
description: A family spokesman said Mr. Owens died of a heart attack after suffering a stroke.

title: U.S. to Sell Bills Today
description: No corporate issues are scheduled this week, according to McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei Inc., a financial research and rating service.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: Freed American hostages are in satisfactory health A8

title: BAR GROUP GIVES SOUTER TOP RATING
description: Although the bar association has played a critical role in evaluating Federal court nominees for nearly 40 years, its relationship with the Reagan Administration and the Bush Administration has been largely strained since the group evaluated Robert H. Bork, Ronald Reagan's nominee, in 1987.

title: Doubts Voiced on Congress's Ability To Act on Big Domestic Policy Bills
description: Doubts on Work Load

title: Obituary;   Robert F. Joyce, Catholic Bishop, 93
description: He was 93 years old.

title: New York Says Census Missed Housing Units
description: New York City and local governments across the country have until Sept. 19 to review census figures for housing units by blocks and challenge those blocks where the bureau counted at least five fewer units than the city.

title: New Valid Logic President Wants More Market Share
description: ''Running a $200 million company amid the rapidly evolving electronic design automation market demands a balance between long-range and day-to-day management activities that is best achieved through the traditional C.E.O. and C.O.O. structure,'' said W. Douglas Hajjar, Valid's chairman and chief executive officer.

description: The firm plans to call itself

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   A President Is Named at W. B. Doner
description: Doner, which has billings of about $350 million, was founded in Detroit 53 years ago by Wilfred B. Doner, who died in January. The Detroit office creates ads for Campbell's, Vlasic pickles and Ballpark Franks. In 1955 the agency opened its Baltimore office, which has created well-known campaigns for Arby's Restaurants and Yoplait Frozen Yogurt.

title: Saudis Widen Military Recruiting And Encourage Women to Work
description: In his edict on women in the workplace, the official Saudi press agency said that the King ordered ''all specialized Government authorities to accept those women volunteers who present themselves to carry on duties in the areas of human services and medical services within the context of fully preserving Islamic and social values.''

title: Fighting Mobocracy in Bulgaria
description: More than 40 years of Communist dictatorship helped produce the dangerous passions now being unleashed. The details of that tyranny are just coming to light. But there's no doubt that thousands of innocent Bulgarians were arrested, tortured and murdered. Under the long tenure of Todor Zhivkov, corruption and nepotism sealed the economy's ruin, while cynical manipulation of ethnic issues set citizens against each other.

title: Regan, in a Split With Leaders, Opposes Environmental Bond Act
description: Part of the Job

title: 2 Contenders at Hartford Debate Claim an Edge in Ability
description: The hourlong debate, which was taped here for broadcast on Connecticut Public Television, marked one of the few moments of complete even-handedness in what has been through the spring and summer a wildly out-of-balance race. Until today, Mr. Morrison, a far better-financed and better-known candidate who also has the backing of the party, had displayed an almost complete disregard for Mr. Cibes as a threat.

title: Books of The Times;   Making the Civil War Real With Pictures and Essays
description: ''At what point shall we expect the approach of danger? By what means shall we fortify against it? Shall we expect some trans-Atlantic military giant, to step the Ocean, and crush us at a blow? Never! All the armies of Europe, Asia and Africa combined, with all the treasure of the earth . . . could not by force, take a drink from the Ohio, or make a track on the Blue Ridge, in a trial of a thousand years . . . If destruction be our lot, we must ourselves be its author and finisher. As a nation of freemen, we must live through all time, or die by suicide.''

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Soviets Suggest Conference Combining Issues of Mideast
description: Longtime Source of Contention

title: Mideast Humpty Dumpty
description: One sentence ended the whole campaign. The P.L.O. news agency WAFA, reporting his latest message to the occupied territories, quoted Mr. Arafat: ''We can only be in the camp hostile to Israel and its imperialist allies, who have mobilized all their sophisticated war machine not to come to anybody's aid but to protect their own interests.'' So much for the peace initiative, the desire for negotiations, the recognition of Israel.

title: Oil Prices Up Again, Rising 6.6%
description: ''This market is still searching for an equilibrium price,'' said Andrew Lebow, a futures trader at E.D.&F. Man International. ''In getting there, it has been subject to these wide emotional swings.''

title: Dallas Fed's President
description: DALLAS, Sept. 4 - LEAD: Robert D. McTeer Jr. has been named president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Dallas effective in February. Mr. McTeer, who is 47 years old, replaces Robert H. Boykin, who is retiring after 37 years with the Dallas reserve bank. Mr. McTeer is senior vice president of the Baltimore branch of the Federal Reserve Bank in Richmond.

title: Market Place;   Continuing Slump Dogs Lands' End
description: In last year's second quarter, Lands' End also startled analysts when it reported profits of just $2.2 million, less than half of what it earned the previous year.

title: Penny-Stock Guilty Plea
description: The schemes netted Mr. Tucker and others more than $67 million in profits, Mr. Chertoff said.

title: Wine Talk
description: And that seems to be the whole problem: a bureaucratic fumble. Had Sumitomo registered the substance at some point in the past, the testing would have been completed by now, tolerance levels determined, and presumably Sumisclex, the substance's trade name, would have been approved.

title: Attempt by Philips To Slow Downturn
description: In 1989, Philips' components division had sales of about $6.2 billion and employed a total of 75,000 people. Of those, 35,000 worked in Europe.

title: Penny Collender Weds Ross Kapilian
description: Mrs. Kapilian, 23 years old, graduated from Stuyvesant High School, as did her husband, and from New York University, magna cum laude. She is a paralegal at the Manhattan law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan. Her father is the president of the American Federation of Government Employees Local 1760. Her mother, Susan Collender, is an administrator at the Lower Manhattan Outreach Center.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Chain letter indeed! It's a joke that in 1990 people still fall for them. And a stellar cast had fallen for this one. Leafing through the stack of letters, I was amazed by the eclectic assortment of correspondence. Barry Slotnick, the lawyer, sent along a slightly risque poem about Mary and how she ended up with a little lamb. The comedian Jackie Mason, not wanting a jinx two weeks before his show opened in Los Angeles, responded: ''Oy vey! I am so nauseous that I got this &*a&%N chain letter, but I am not taking any chances.''

title: In Shift, Nunn Backs Right To Abortion in Most Cases
description: In the past, the Senator was a supporter of proposed constitutional amendments to overturn the Supreme Court's 1973 decision that legalized abortion.

title: Customs Service Fines K Mart
description: Analysts estimate that as much as one-quarter of K Mart's revenue, which last year totaled nearly $30 billion, comes from apparel, some of which is imported from Asia.

title: Higher Fares On Foreign Flights Due
description: Some Sample Fare Rises

title: At the Nation's Table
description: The signature dish at Skyline, which cooks its chili at a central commissary and trucks it to its 60-plus restaurants in the Cincinnatti area two or three times a week, is a thin, auburn-colored broth with beef ground to a mush and simmered in mild spices that are said to include cinnamon and cumin. (Some detect a faint taste of chocolate.) This is ladled over spaghetti, then topped with chopped onions and cheddar cheese grated to resemble a hillock of orange confetti.

title: Chiles Wins Democrats' Vote for Florida Governor
description: In Florida with 98 percent of the precincts reporting in the Democratic primary, Mr. Chiles had 723,339 votes, or 70 percent, as against Mr. Nelson's 316,258 votes, or 30 percent.

title: Righetti Agent Sees Lengthy Talks Ahead
description: No-Trade Clause Sought

title: Memories to Be Scaled Back by Diamandis
description: Peter Diamandis, president and chief executive, issued a brief statement saying that ''the current softness in the advertising marketplace makes it imprudent to continue'' as a bimonthly. Mr. Diamandis' office said he would not be available for further comment.

title: Business Digest
description: Most of the world's airlines will seek to increase fares on international routes by about 7 percent to 8 percent by Oct. 1 to help cope with a rapid rise in fuel costs. [D1.]

title: Tilt-Rotor Osprey Can Save Lives
description: The second point is open to debate. Should a vertical assault, particularly one from amphibious warships, become necessary, the Osprey can play a vitally important role. The advantages of this tilt-rotor aircraft over existing helicopters, such as being able to carry the same payload at twice the speed, can mean the difference between success and failure.

title: Rishiri Journal;   In the Fished-Out Sea, a Little Island Founders
description: Rishiri juts up as the tip of a submarine volcano in the Sea of Japan about 50 miles from territorial waters of the Soviet Union, a rugged speck of land with a population of about 5,500 people and breathtaking alpine panoramas of the windswept ocean from the forested ridges of its central peak.

title: Corrections
description: LEAD: A report yesterday about the marriage of Penny Collender and Ross Kapilian appeared with sections scrambled in some copies. A corrected version appears today on page B4.

title: Losses Posted at Federated
description: Campeau's holding company for the two units, Federated Stores Inc., Cincinnati, said the losses were less than it had expected.

title: Confrontation in the Gulf;   For Asians, Gulf Is Fickle Godmother
description: Many in Kuwait and Iraq, especially ordinary workers, are returning virtually destitute to their homes, unable to draw on savings that are locked in Kuwaiti banks. Their new unemployment is likely to create major social and economic problems in South Asia because their earnings often supported large families.

title: Review/Television;   Jackson on Assignment in Iraq: The Reporter Becomes the Story
description: Audiences may be tuning in this week more to get a line on the interviewer than on the interviewee, particularly if they caught Mr. Jackson's return to the United States on Sunday with a planeful of the people whom the Iraqi Government had apparently let out at his behest. CNN covered the homecoming, which began with Mr. Jackson's telling of his exertions and dropping in a plug for his syndicated shows. After a hostage from Texas made some remarks critical of Iraq, Mr. Jackson whispered something to him, and he returned to the microphone to say that he was free ''by the grace of God and Jesse Jackson,'' adding that the State Department had not lifted a hand in his behalf.

title: New Chief Is Named In Shift at First Boston
description: Some at First Boston said that the change was Mr. Hennessy's idea, but other executives viewed it as an effort by executives at Credit Suisse, the Swiss banking concern whose parent owns about 45 percent of CS First Boston, to assert more control over the First Boston Corporation. Mr. Cox is a longtime friend of Rainer E. Gut, the chairman of both Credit Suisse and CS First Boston.

title: New Jersey Taxpayers Don't Want an Explanation, but Relief;   Tradition of Resistance
description: New Jersey went on to depend on property taxes for decades. Well into the 1960's, it was one of the last states - along with New Hampshire - to have neither sales tax nor income tax. The winds of revolt that have blown across the country since California's Proposition 13 have only inflamed New Jersey's simmering tax resistance. Whatever the merit of Gov. Jim Florio's tax plan, it should be no surprise that it has found hard going.

title: The Joy of Garlic
description: True, garlic is said to keep vampires away, and some say it will keep lovers away. But will it inhibit cancer cells, atherosclerosis, heart attacks and strokes? The participants in the ''First World Congress on the Health Significance of Garlic and Garlic Constituents,'' held in Washington last week, say maybe. And maybe not.

title: Stocks in Tokyo Plunge
description: Brokers bemoaned a complete absence of buying interest because of concern over future developments in the Middle East, which is being viewed in an increasingly pessimistic light. ''The market is basically discounting itself now for a war,'' one trader said. He said that if fighting breaks out, an initial drop would be followed by a rebound. The Nikkei index of 225 shares was down 829.30 points, or 3.33 percent, to 24,078.34, after dropping more than 500 points on Tuesday.

title: North-South Korea Talks Begin Today
description: Talks Start Amiably

title: White-Umpire Dispute Is Defused by Vincent
description: A one baseball person familiar with the dispute and its resolution des cribed White as being ''very unhappy'' and said a problem could still remain as far as White's status is concerned.

title: Genetic Link Suggested In One Form of Arthritis
description: The researchers, from Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland and Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia, studied members of an Ohio family prone to severe arthritis that develops early in life. The researchers found that those affected had a genetic defect that resulted in an abnormal collagen, the principal building block of cartilage, the tough material that covers and protects the bony surfaces in joints. In osteoarthritis, the normally smooth cartilage surface is torn and frayed.

title: Times Executive Named Carnegie Adviser
description: Mr. Hechinger has been associated with The Times since 1959. He served as education editor for 10 years, then became a member of the editorial board. He became president of the Times Foundation in 1977. Since 1978, he has written a column, ''About Education,'' in The Times.

title: Conservation, Not Nuclear, Will Stop Oil Binge;   Try Co-generation
description: Co-generation has cut total energy bills for factories, hospitals, offices and even apartment buildings by as much as 45 percent.

title: Review/Film;   Loyalties Scalded by Humiliation
description: Mr. Sembene's latest work (co-written and co-directed by Thierno Faty Sow), has a far different setting: a French army camp in Dakar in 1944, where African soldiers who have fought for France in World War II are kept before returning to their various countries.

title: Old-Timer (All of 27) Visits Open
description: That was 1977. Tracy Austin is now 27, and quite glad to be strolling the grounds of the United States Open, preaching the value of car seat belts that saved her life in a wreck a year ago. The common wisdom is that Austin suffered from ''burnout'' from playing too much tennis before she was old enough to vote, but Austin looks at the new breed and decides she was positively sheltered.

title: Pirates Rally and Retake First
description: Darrel Akerfelds (5-2) replaced Carman in the sixth and immediately got into a jam when a pinch-hitter, Wally Backman, doubled. King grounded out and Jay Bell was hit by a pitch. Backman scored the go-ahead when the Philadelphia shortstop, Dickie Thon, couldn't hold John Kruk's throw on Van Slyke's apparent double-play grounder.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: Asian refugees from Kuwait and Iraq continue to pour into Jordan's desert refugee camps at the rate of 10,000 every 24 hours, relief officials said.

title: After Parcells Follows a Lead, Giants Acquire Duerson
description: The probability remained that the Giants might add a third quarterback, a veteran like Pat Ryan, the former Jet cut by Cleveland on Monday, or Matt Cavanaugh, let go by the Eagles. But no such announcement was expected before Wednesday.

title: Rates Fall Sharply At Citicorp's Sale
description: It also sold $50 million in 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.875 percent, down from 8.011 percent.

title: Soviet Rebuff on Oil Cited
description: East European countries depend almost completely on imported crude oil and rely heavily on supplies from the Soviet Union, the world's biggest oil producer.

title: Baltimore Bancorp Is Put on Notice
description: In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, T. Rowe Price said it should no longer be considered a strictly passive investor in Baltimore Bancorp.

title: Conservation, Not Nuclear, Will Stop Oil Binge
description: Also, in the 45-year history of atomic energy, nobody has found a way to dispose of nuclear waste safely. About 20,000 metric tons of nuclear waste sits today in heavily guarded spent-fuel pools around the country awaiting a national repository site. In the same Aug. 19 edition (Week in Review), you report that New York State couldn't find a place to dispose of the low-level nuclear waste it produces, ''enough low-level waste,'' you say, ''to fill an Olympic-sized swimming pool every year.''

title: Program Buying Trims Dow's Loss to 0.99
description: Volume on the exchange slumped to 92.9 million shares, the slowest since Dec. 26, 1989, when it was 76.7 million shares. The year's slowest day until yesterday had been Friday's 96.5 million.

title: Dallas Holdout Signs
description: LEAD: No terms were disclosed, but after holding out for 48 days, Emmitt Smith, the former Florida running back, has signed a contract with the Dallas Cowboys. Smith, the 17th draft pick, set 58 school records before giving up a year of collegiate eligibility to enter the 1990 draft. (AP) SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL

title: Mets Lose To Cards And Fall From First
description: ''It was kind of glaring, watching the scoreboard,'' said Bud Harrelson, the manager of the Mets. ''But let's get on to Pittsburgh. Let's get it over with.'' The Mets will play eight games against the Pirates in the next four weeks, six of them in Pittsburgh, starting with a doubleheader. They even sent Frank Viola and Bob Ojeda to Pittsburgh today to get extra rest for pitching the doubleheader. They set the stage with care, and then went out and scored no runs against a team of juniors, rookies and irregulars.

title: KEY RATES
After Risking McNeil, Jets Get to Keep Him
description: Besides McNeil, the Jets also recalled three other players: Chris Dressel, a tight end, and John Galvin and Don Murray, linebackers. They also claimed two players off the waiver wire: Troy Johnson, a third-year linebacker from the Chicago Bears, and Doug Wellsandt, a tight end from Cincinnati familiar to Bruce Coslet, the Jets' coach, who was the Bengals' offensive coordinator last year.

title: MUSCOVITES VIEW BREAD AS SYMBOL

The committee was empowered to focus fast on a range of urban ills beyond the bread shortage, from growing public concern about street crime to the shortage of cigarettes that has caused edgy smokers to venture into traffic to stage protests.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: Skirt steak is ideal for grilling, broiling or sauteeing. Whatever method used, the heat must be intense. This cut of meat has a very high moisture content, so if you do not sear it quickly the interior will begin to steam and tighten, leaving you with a steak that could frustrate a German shepherd. Skirt steak is delicious braised, too, but it must be cooked a very long time.

description: He died of pancreatic cancer, a spokesman for the family said.

description: A professor of Asian studies at Harvard, he was named Ambassador to Tokyo in 1961 by President Kennedy. During a five-year tour he did much to change the chemistry of U.S.-Japanese relations.

title: Prosecutor Seeks Rehearing On Appeals from North Case

Poindexter, the former national security adviser who was convicted on April 7 of five criminal charges arising from efforts to conceal from Congress the sale of arms to Iran and the diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: For Assembly: Queens and Brooklyn
description: QUEENS. 29th District: The incumbent, Cynthia Jenkins, has cultivated an outspoken manner during eight years representing her district, which includes Springfield Gardens, Rosedale and St. Albans, but has accomplished little of note. Her opponent, Anna Thompson, is making her second try at replacing Ms. Jenkins and, for the second time, warrants support. Ms. Thompson, a civic leader and head of a home care agency, seems in touch with the problems facing the district and could provide more effective leadership. 32d District: Vivian Cook's knowledgeable views about child care and adoption could make a difference in Albany. The outcome might turn on race. The 18-year veteran Assemblyman, Edward Abramson, is white, and some oppose him because his district, which stretches from Howard Beach to Rochdale Village, is now overwhelmingly black. That's a shame; Mr. Abramson genuinely cares about his district and provides good constituent services. However, he has failed to use his considerable seniority effectively in Albany and we endorse Ms. Cook for the promise she represents.

title: Fantasy and Taste in a New Bridal Salon

The elevated level of taste she exhibited at both jobs permeates her own salon on two floors of 991 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street. A curved staircase of French limestone, white oak paneling, beige draperies, plump sofas, crystal chandeliers and copious arrangements of fresh flowers make the shop a grand town house. Each selling area is like a living room.

title: Critic's Notebook;   World of Hollywood Is Finding Its Way Into Many Novels
description: Using show business as a backdrop also makes commercial sense, since audiences and readers display such an insatiable interest in any aspect of movie-making lore. If the writer has been in a good position to observe the process at close range, or has even come close enough to want to flee, so much the better. The protagonist of Mr. McMurtry's ''Some Can Whistle'' has made it so big in television that he can afford to retire back to Texas. In any case, the appeal of Hollywood as a lively backdrop and a prime source of raw material has never been greater. And we've obviously come a long way since F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Last Tycoon.'' Ms. Rossner, whose novel ''His Little Women'' has a narrator whose father was once the head of a movie studio, refers to ''the romance that has made Hollywood America's Buckingham Palace, those stars our kings and queens.'' But show business looks a lot less rosy when seen through the eyes of a tough guy like Spenser, Mr. Parker's Boston-based private eye. In ''Stardust,'' Spenser is hired to protect a television star named Jill Joyce, and if Mr. Parker's portrait of Jill as a feisty, wine-guzzling nymphomaniac lacks any verisimilitude, his feeling for on-the-set ambiance during location shooting is dead-on.

title: Conservation, Not Nuclear, Will Stop Oil Binge;   Deregulation and Prices

All real energy prices are below their levels of 1981, when President Reagan deregulated oil, and of 1985, when natural gas controls expired. Price controls never really reduce prices. At best, they can hold down dollar prices, for those who can get supplies, while raising the price, through shortages, inconvenience, substitution and waiting time for everyone.

title: Australian Company Net

Gorbachev announced a major shift in Soviet policy on the United Nations. In urging that the United Nations be given a bigger role in finding political solutions to regional conflicts, Mr. Gorbachev urged that the moribund Military Staff Committee be revived and given the job of coordinating United Nations peacekeeping operations.

title: Close to Home
description: I doubt it, but who knows? After all I was thrilled by ''Ziegfeld Girl'' this week. ''Ziegfeld Girl'' stars Lana Turner at her perkiest, Judy Garland at her most girlish and Hedy Lamarr at her most glamorous. James Stewart plays a truck driver turned bootlegger; Rosario and Antonio dance a heated flamenco; and Charles Winninger is half of a vaudeville team named Gallagher and Shean. The Ziegfeld Girls are dressed in spangles and toss balloons, and Hedy is a vision in stars that encircle her head. Tony Martin sings ''You Stepped Out of A Dream'' while she swans down an endless staircase, and, truly, she looks as if she had.

title: If a Fledgling's New Nest Is Empty, Too

College freshmen are happily settling into dormitory rooms with enough newly acquired or permanently borrowed belongings to move away from home forever. Ozone is destroyed by chlorofluorocarbons, common industrial chemicals widely used in refrigerants, air-conditioners, fire extinguishers and solvents.

title: Forget About Gulfo
description: Here are four graphs on burden-sharing from a two-decade supporter of the Mansfield Amendment: 1. Money: The $8-a-barrel rise in oil prices since the invasion, combined with the two-million-barrel-a-day increase in production by the emirates and the Saudis, means added profit to them of $3 billion a month, a third of that from the U.S. alone. That windfall should be for protection, not profiteering; all money generated by the blockade of Iraqi-Kuwaiti oil should be escrowed in the Overthrow-Saddam Fund. 2. Arab participation: The states to benefit most from the realignment of the Arab world are Egypt, our ally, and Syria, our bedfellow. Cairo should put 50,000 soldiers in Saudi Arabia soon if it wants to assume Arab leadership; Damascus should mass its 4,000 tanks on its Iraqi border to force Mr. Hussein to split his forces. 3. European troops: Turkey, a NATO member, has a long border with Iraq. NATO forces should be moved quickly from facing the Soviets to NATO's southern flank to face its new military-economic threat. Ships, planes and French tokenism are not enough; unless NATO nations are willing to put soldiers on the new front line, the U.S. will speed its NATO drawdown. 4. Soviet double-gaming: Mr. Bush should tell Mr. Gorbachev to choose sides. A thousand Russians are even now teaching Iraqi troops how to use the most modern Soviet equipment to kill Americans; not only should they be withdrawn forthwith, but the largest army in the world should participate actively in the world police action.

title: Books of The Times;   Kitty Dukakis's Life Of Sad Uncertainties And Self-Made Mists
description: Some may read Kitty Dukakis's harrowing new memoir about her own journey into a drug-crazed fog as a cautionary tale about the self-abnegation required of political wives. But really, politics seems almost beside the point in this intensely personal diary of a beautiful, intelligent woman with a devoted family who tries, again and again and again, right up until the final dizzying pages, to destroy herself because she feels like a worthless fraud. Her father once told Kitty she had a talent for making a career out of catastrophe. And, indeed, just as Madonna is an icon of America's obsession with fitness, Kitty Dukakis has become an icon of America's addiction to addictions, flashing her electric smile for Newsweek's ''Addictive Personalities'' cover, beaming again from the cover of ''Now You Know'' about a struggle with alcohol, pills and depression that is far from over.

Such a campaign would also seek to overcome fears of bias and the dread of a positive result on the test.

title: Computers That Mimic Desks
description: I am not alone. The most advanced desktop computers now have screens that look like desktops. The text that used to glow with amber or green letters can now appear on the screen as if it has just been typeset; a spreadsheet can appear the same way, as if printed on white bond. These electronic ''papers'' can be piled up on the screen, shuffled about, cut and pasted, filed or destroyed. A calculator can be pulled forward, or a calendar, and the information easily inserted in another document. My screen can even simulate a messy desktop - and usually does. The heralded paperless office hasn't arrived; instead, paper has expanded its territory to the electronic screen. The desktop screen design was made commercially successful by Apple's Macintosh computers beginning in 1984. The screen promised to be easy to use and folksily familiar. Apple advertised itself as the countercultural answer to Big Brother I.B.M.: the homey image of the ordinary desktop was its answer to the image of the computer's intimidating technology.

title: China Faces Its Longest March
description: Will China shift abruptly again? Beijing's economic reforms may look more successful than Moscow's and Eastern Europe's, but China still needs a national version of glasnost to make reform work in the long run. And in China, that's the difficult part. The culture of China is ingrained in its government. China's leaders still cling to elitist traditions that bind them to an era long before the revolution, and the Communist party perpetuates cherished old values of power. Indeed most of the political leaders in power in China today were born during the last ruling Manchu dynasty, which fell in 1911. And although they ended the inequities of imperialism when they came to power, they continued the political tradition of hierarchical elitism from past ages.

title: Review/Theater;   Dancing in the Footsteps Of Ludlam's 'Camille'
description: In the revived ''Camille,'' now at the Charles Ludlam Theater, Everett Quinton, Ludlam's partner and successor, has dared to step into a role that it has been difficult to imagine anybody else carrying off with the same bravura grandeur. That Mr. Quinton, in his own way, creates a memorable Marguerite is good news, not only for the revival, but for the Ridiculous Theatrical Company's future. Though not perfect, the production proves once and for all that Ludlam created a style that was not ultimately dependent on his flamboyant, brilliant presence both on the stage and behind the scenes - a style that, for all its extravagance, seems both enduring and surprisingly malleable. As much as Mr. Quinton has learned from Ludlam, the kind of energy he gives off when performing is quite different. Where Ludlam invented an insouciant camp style of physical caricature that crackled with a maniacal spontaneity, Mr. Quinton, using the same vocabulary, imparts an air of considered, classical precision. Mr. Quinton's air of underlying austerity - the sense that his every gesture, right down to the twitch of an eyebrow and the curl of a cherry-red lip, is not wasted - lends a very different tone to this production.

True, the story's evil temptress (Cynthia Bond), who picks up all her victims at the same singles' bar, manages to dispatch each man with considerable gusto. But the killings are staged with very un-Tromalike tact. And the film's elements of parody, while apparent, remain mostly underused. The only Troma touch is the near complete absence of extras, even to fill out the singles' bar scenes.

title: Books of The Times;   A Samurai in the South And a Joke on America
description: ''East Is East,'' Mr. Boyle's latest novel, also sends up contemporary America, turning a Japanese visitor's adventures in the Deep South into a hilarious black farce about racial stereotypes, selfish dreams and ambitions run hopelessly amok. Less self-consciously literary than his previous works, ''East Is East'' uses its author's hyperkinetic language and gift for wild invention to create a rollicking, old-fashioned tale full of cartoony heroes and villains and deliciously satiric incidents. It's a pastoral version of ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' peopled with dumb rednecks, scheming litterateurs, dotty Southern aristocrats and one Mishima-obsessed sailor from Japan. That sailor, Hiro Tanaka by name, has fled Japan in search of his American father - a bearded, long-haired hippie who had a brief fling with Hiro's Japanese mother before heading back to the States. Mocked as a half-breed in Japan, Hiro dreams of joining America's melting pot. He feels that ''he had to blend in with the masses, find himself a job, an apartment with Western furniture and Japanese appliances, with toaster ovens and end tables and deep, thick woolly carpets that climbed up the walls like a surging tide. Then he'd be safe, then he could play miniature golf and eat cheeseburgers or stroll down the street with an armload of groceries and no one would blink twice.''

title: At Ellis Island, Embracing the Past and the Future

Designed in the Beaux-Arts style by the New York firm of Boring & Tilton (which won the commission over the celebrated firm of McKim, Mead & White) to replace a simpler building destroyed by fire, the structure of limestone and red brick was finished in 1900. Its three arched portals and four copper-domed towers, as sumptuous a symbol of the public grandeur that awaited immigrants as any American courthouse or train station, received immigrants until 1924, when the island's function as a gateway ended.

title: Review/Art;   De Kooning: Masterworks From a Master Painter
description: The one major chapter of de Kooning's career missing from the show is the celebrated series of black-and-white paintings from the late 1940's, perhaps the grittiest and most metaphysical works de Kooning has done. William O'Reilly, a co-director of the gallery, said he wanted paintings from this series but could not borrow them (many are fragile). Without them, de Kooning appears more pastoral than urban, with a voluptuousness, a feeling for the lewd, unexpected (and sometimes unwanted) presence and for the improbable juxtaposition that is commonplace in the pastoral tradition. For Salander O'Reilly, which has never before done a de Kooning show, this selective mini-retrospective serves several purposes. This is primarily a painting gallery, and de Kooning is a very good argument for the unceasing necessity of painting. In addition, the show will help the gallery, which represents contemporary abstract painters for whom the medium of painting is the message, to present contemporary figurative work: few artists have explored and tested the language of painting more exhaustively than de Kooning, whose figurative inspiration has remained intact.

title: Review/Art;   In Praise of a Neglected Painter of His Time
description: More than a year in Italy strengthened his connections with the tradition of Italian landscape painting and with the art of Joseph Vernet. His works betray the influence of artists like Gerrit van Honthorst, although it is an accomplishment of this exhibition to make clear that the relationship between Wright and the Northern Caravaggist painters has been overemphasized. Links can also be forged between Wright's sharply outlined figures and those in the works of Jacques Louis David. ''Widow of an Indian Chief,'' for instance, suggests that he was familiar with David's ''Oath of the Horatii.'' Perhaps most distinctively, during a century in which painters were largely defined by their work in a single genre, like portraiture or landscape, Wright seemed to move easily among a variety of genres. The same artist whose ''Arkwright's Cotton Mills at Night'' has been interpreted - perhaps optimistically - as a celebration of modernity and the Industrial Revolution also painted the Gothic adaptation of an Aesop fable, ''The Old Man and Death.''

title: Review/Theater;   'Money Talks,' a Comedy Starring Dolores Gray
description: What passes for a plot in this homage to Philistinism revolves around five members of the Wealthy Widows Investment Club, whose only concern, between rubbers of bridge and canasta tournaments, is their stock portfolios. These women go through brokers the way more adventuresome rich widows might go through gigolos. As a subplot, two of the cattiest members of the club try to palm off their daughters on a couple of Wall Street dealers. Widows, wealthy or poor, deserve better than this. The level of humor ranges from the insults these vain women toss at one another to their disparagement of domestics. The director's idea of hilarity seems to be having a stageful of fatuous females, panicked when a burglar alarm trips and the lights go out, waving their arms and shouting ''Is everything all right?'' In fact, the shrill tone that permeates the whole exercise tempts one to rename the play ''Money Shrieks.''

title: In Memoirs and Novels, Literary Testimony to How It Was
description: Among the immigrants in that year was a 10-year-old boy, Edward Corsi, whose future distinguished public career included the office of United States Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, the boss of the Ellis Island that had greeted him as a child. In a 1935 memoir, ''In the Shadow of Liberty: The Chronicle of Ellis Island,'' he recalled the trip from ship to the island: ''During this ride across the bay, as I watched the faces of the people milling about me, I realized that Ellis Island could inspire both hope and fear. Some of the passengers were afraid and obviously dreading the events of the next few hours; others were impatient, anxious to get through the inspection and be off to their destinations. I have never forgotten the scene.'' Fiorello H. La Guardia, American-born of Italian parents, was an interpreter at Ellis Island in 1907, at the beginning of an adult life that was to see him become Mayor of New York City. In his autobiography, ''The Making of an Insurgent,'' he describes the process from a different perspective: ''The work on the island was difficult and strenuous. For two years we worked seven days a week, for immigration was very heavy at this time. All of us were glad, however, to have the jobs, despite the long hours and tiring tasks. Immigrants were pouring in at the average rate of 5,000 a day, and it was a constant grind from the moment we got into our uniforms early in the morning until the last minute before we left on the 5:30 boat in the evening . . . The immigration laws were rigidly enforced, and there were many heartbreaking scenes on Ellis Island. I never managed during the three years I worked there to become callous to the mental anguish, the disappointment and the despair I witnessed almost daily. Some of the employees did become callous to the suffering after a while, but on the whole they were a hardworking lot, conscientious and loyal.'' In 1923, Henry H. Curran, a literate New York political figure, became Commissioner of Immigration for the Port of New York. In his autobiography, ''From Pillar to Post,'' he describes the duties he undertook just as the first general restrictive immigration laws were taking effect.

title: Manhattan Perspectives

But, for the tourist, who will be in and out before glamour fades, Manhattan, on that first glimpse, intoxicates, with its hint that whatever one wants is to be found within it. Notice that Manhattan and New York are interchangeable here, in the lexicon of the tourist. Surrounding boroughs and regions also offer unique attractions, but those will be for the graduate student in New York exploration; for the tourist on limited duty, the little island of ''downtown'' holds more than enough for a first visit.

title: Guide for Home Buyers, Sellers and Renters;   Co-ops and Condominiums: What's the Difference?
description: Residents of a co-op pay monthly maintenance charges, which represent their proportionate share of the building's expenses for carrying the underlying mortgage, real-estate taxes, labor, heating and hot water, electricity and gas, repairs and maintenance, insurance premiums and management fees. In addition, in co-ops that allow buyers to finance their purchases, shareholders may have mortgages on their own units. As in other forms of housing, the real estate taxes and the mortgage interest paid to the building are fully deductible from taxable income, and so, too, are the interest payments on an individual mortgage.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: The stated goal of these essays - to replace the received wisdom, or lack thereof, about the human mind with new metaphors - is a noble one. Too often, however, the thinking is fuzzy and confined by the myopic vision of the author's particular discipline. Few of the ideas are illuminating or original, although some have the virtue of being bizarre. The neurophysiologist William H. Calvin suggests the brain is a ''Darwin Machine'' that is ''mimicking biological evolution on a greatly accelerated time scale, creating new thoughts rather than new species.'' It is not clear whether he thinks this proposition constitutes a useful scientific theory. The philosopher Daniel C. Dennett recognizes the need for testable hypotheses. He offers a number of them having to do with the genesis, function and mechanism of the mind. What is missing is the hard task of translating hypotheses into experimental agendas. Indeed, what is lacking throughout this volume is a serious effort to lay down ground rules for what a useful new metaphor of the brain must accomplish. Let me suggest a few of the more obvious: a successful metaphor must reconcile all observed brain processes, from the biological to the psychological; it must pose testable hypotheses for currently unexplainable phenomena; and it must frame a research program by which one can probe the metaphor's validity. These are not trivial demands. Any attempt to invent a new scientific metaphor for the brain must satisfy them. Otherwise, it is not iconoclasm but merely mysticism.

title: Currency;   The Yen's Turn to Shine

The yen is now just midway between its weakest point of the year - 160 to the dollar - and its record high, 120.90, which was reached in November 1988. This round of strengthening was prompted by the Bank of Japan's decision to raise its official discount rate to 6 percent on Aug. 30.

title: Technology;   The Internationalization of the Cash Machine
description: The globalization of automated teller machines, or ATM's, represents the newest expansion of the ever-widening networks that have evolved within the United States in recent years. The upshot is that routine bank transactions can increasingly be executed from around the world about as quickly as if they were around the corner.

How America's savings and loans were looted of billions of dollars. 13 * 10 33 MEGATRENDS 2000, by John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene. (Morrow, $21.95.)
