(Prentice Hall/Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988.

title: Whose Law Is It?
description: Jurisprudence has always been a wild card in the legal deck. While the dictionary allows it may be the ''science or philosophy of law,'' no two commentators agree on its meaning, still less its relationship with what lawyers think of as real law. Even so, a distinctive form of jurisprudence has gradually emerged in this country. Its most conspicuous attribute has been an obsessive concern with judges and the judiciary.

title: Clothes Help Immigrants Come Alive on Ellis Island
description: A Minimal Cleaning

title: Charge and Rebuttal: California Campaign Ads
description: California's candidates for governor have used television to trade allegations about each other's association with the savings and loan crisis. Here are scripts and photographs from two 30-second commercials. The general election will be Nov. 6.

title: Miss Bone Wed To M.A. Bolinger
description: She is a senior assistant buyer at Strawbridge & Clothier in Philadelphia. Her father is a partner in Rouse Associates, a real-estate development company in Baltimore. Her mother, Lee Bone, is a senior research associate at the Johns Hopkins University School of Hygiene and Public Health.

title: Cruising by Moonlight Along the Tiber
description: The Tiber's abandonment over the last few decades is a relatively recent event in Rome's nearly 3,000-year existence. As legend tells it, the twins Romulus and Remus founded the settlement that would grow into Rome on the spot on the left bank where they were rescued from their drifting in a basket down the Tiber. In reality, the hills of what was to become Rome probably attracted various tribes because nearby Tiber Island made it easy to cross the river.

title: Three Johnsons Depict Fantasy
description: An opponent of abstraction, Mr. Rodman included Ben Johnson with Rico Lebrun, James Kearns and other artists of conscience in a book called ''The Insiders.'' Mr. Kramer, more attuned to the appearance of art, perceived in Mr. Johnson an affinity to Milton Avery and hence to Matisse, while simultaneously taking note of his color's ''cosmetic garishness'' and his draftsmanship bordering on ''illustration and cartoon.'' Nevertheless, Mr. Johnson's obsession with buxom female beauty placed him, in Mr. Kramer's estimation, closer to Gaston Lachaise than any Pop artist.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: From the beginning of the 19th century until 1861 when the United States Government took responsiblity, all bank notes were printed privately and the number of banks was astronomical. There were banks for farmers, for whalers, for machinists and for chemical manufacturers. Most towns had their own banks, each with a uniquely designed bank note.

title: Guide for Home Buyers, Sellers and Renters;   Rent Rules Cover More Than a Million Apartments
description: Rent regulation today includes the remnants of wartime rent control and a later, parallel system called rent stabilization. Critics charge that its firm grip has created a gridlock in the marketplace, provided unneeded benefits for the wealthy, penalized the poor, discouraged the development of affordable housing and served as a catalyst for decay in some neighborhoods.

title: Catherine van Straalen And V.K. Marshall Wed
description: LEAD: Catherine Elizabeth van Straalen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Johannes van Straalen of Madison, Conn., was married yesterday to VanKeuren Marshall, a son of Chovine Van Keuren Johnson and J. Quitman Marshall Jr., both of Columbia, S.C. The Rev. Ross Wright officiated at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Charleston, S

title: When It's Time To Take a Stand, Every Player Has His Own
description: The subject is the batting stance, a baseball player's definitive body language, as individualistic as his signature on an autographed ball.

title: Style Makers;   Ed Antczak and Peter Shea, Map Designers
description: The new product is Mapwrap, a line of gift wrap and note cards with images of Earth printed on recycled paper and packaged in biodegradable wood-based cellophane.

title: Neutral States of Europe Start Shedding Their Postwar Shell
description: Asked if he could foresee any circumstances that might lead Finland to abandon its military neutrality and join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Mr. Suominen shook his head, laughed and said, ''We certainly wouldn't want to be an adversary if the Soviet Union joined NATO.''

title: S. T. Limpe Weds Tracy Lynn Tang
description: Mrs. Limpe, 28 years old, is the associate director of children's book clubs at the Book-of-the-Month Club in New York. A graduate of Duke University, she received an M.B.A. from New York University. Her father is the president and chief executive of the Reich & Tang investment management firm in New York. Her mother, Frances Tang, is a real-estate developer in Vail.

title: Group Fosters Hope On Missing Soldiers
description: LEAD: AT the Bridgewater Fair last month, Kathleen and William Shemeley were sitting in their boothwhen a young man stopped to look at the stainless-steel and aluminium bracelets they sell. As he examined the bracelets, each engraved with the name and casualty date of a New England serviceman missing in the Vietnam or Korean War, the young man asked the Shemeleys whether they might one day carry similar bracelets for the Americans held hostage in Kuwait and

title: PARENT AND CHILD
description: LEAD:

title: Ms. Kaplan Wed To A. R. Peikon
description: Mrs. Peikon, a graduate of Lehigh University with a master's degree in journalism from American University, is the director of corporate communications at Lang Communications, publisher of Working Woman and Ms. magazines in New York. Her father is a lawyer in New York.

title: Playing the Post-Iraqi Markets
description: Gerald R. Jordan, founding partner of the Hellman-Jordan Management Company, which invests $1.3 billion for pension funds, sold almost $300 million of stocks when the Dow Jones industrial average hit 3,000 in July. Out were holdings in companies like General Electric, Wal-Mart, Pepsi and Eli Lilly. Just one month later, noting that a list of the stocks making new lows on Aug. 23 was almost as long as the list on Aug. 20, 1987, he bought back many of the same securities. Both lists now hang in his Boston office. This year, his clients' accounts are up about 1 percent.

title: THE ANNOTATED CALENDAR: TELEVISION
description: ''EVENING SHADE.'' Burt Reynolds stars in a comedy, written by Linda Bloodworth-Thomason (''Designing Women''), about a pro football player who returns home to Evening Shade, Ark., to coach the high school team. With a strong supporting cast, including Elizabeth Ashley, Ossie Davis, Charles Durning, Marilu Henner, Hal Holbrook and Michael Jeter. Fridays at 8, CBS.

title:
ART;

Repetition as a Theme
description: LEAD: WHEN an essay accompanying an exhibition begins, ''A response to global issues invests these stylistically diverse works with an integrity directly related to our social conditions,'' you hang on tight, expecting a bumpy ride. But, thankfully, ''A Force of Repetition'' at the New Jersey State Museum is much more enjoyable, and has a much more straightforward impact, than the windy prose that accompanies it.

title: Rutgers Wins in Coach's Debut
description: Tom Tarver, the senior quarterback for Rutgers, threw for 172 yards and two touchdowns, and the Scarlet Knights' defense produced a third touchdown when Willie Wilkes intercepted a Freddie Maggard pass and raced 19 yards for the score. It was the first time in five years that a Rutgers defensive player had returned an intercepted pass for a touchdown.

title: Charles E. Hertan Is Wed To Jayme A. Shorin
description: Both have master of social work degrees from Smith College and both are social workers, she at Cambridge (Mass.) Hospital and he at Elder Services in Boston.

title: Mets Explode Out of Their Losing Streak
description: They staged two three-run innings and an even rarer four-run inning. And they did all the things they hadn't been doing during those five dry days when they managed only 20 hits and three runs in 45 innings and understandably lost all five games.

title: Data Update
NEWS SUMMARY
description: LEAD:

title: A Long-Shot Victory for Carson City
description: Carson City fought off an early challenge from For Really, pulled clear in midstretch under Jerry Bailey and then withstood Sewickley's late rush up the rail to by half a length. For Really held third another 1 3/4 lengths back, with Traskwood half a length back in fourth. Joy Maker was fifth, beating only Timebank.

title: Streetscapes: 249 Central Park West;   An Accidental Restoration in a New Historic District
description: In 1887, the block front on Central Park West between 84th and 85th Streets came into the hands of William Noble, a builder, and in accordance with restrictions on the site, he erected a row of nine brick and brownstone single-family houses numbered 241-249.

title: 3 Women Plead Guilty In Bombing of Capitol
description: Ms. Evans, 43 years old, told United States District Judge Harold H. Greene that the bomb was exploded to protest the American invasion of Grenada. Five paintings were damaged and an office door was blown off its hinges.

title: Residential Resales
description: TriBeCa $217,000

title: Guide for Home Buyers, Sellers and Renters;   Most Buyers Are Choosing Fixed-Rate Mortgages
description: For a while, this was a good deal when the mortgages were written with a low initial ''teaser'' rate - say 7 percent for the first year for a 9 percent commitment rate that rises or falls with the market after a year or so. The argument for teaser rates and a subsequent short-term low commitment was that they allowed buyers of limited means to buy as much house as they could someday reasonably expect to be able to afford with a rising income. The reality often proved quite different.

title: Men, Women and Golf: More Views
description: The game of golf is a four-hour game. Yet many of the men permitted to play earlier than I on weekend mornings score no better and take much longer to play. But they are allowed premium time slots (tee off times) just because they are men.

title: Choosing a Lawn Mower: Push or Ride?
description: Those who have to mow large swathes of grass can opt for still another choice, the riding mower-tractor, which is the only practical solution for many homeowners. If the lawn is more than 20,000 square feet, then it is almost mandatory. Besides, routine maintenance becomes kind of fun with this machine.

title: THE ANNOTATED CALENDAR: ANTIQUES
description: ''FIVE STAR FOLK ART.'' Some of the finest paintings, sculpture, furniture and textiles produced between 1730 and 1970 from New England to the Southwest have been culled from public and private collections by Jean Lipman, called the ''first lady of Americana'' by the Times art critic John Russell. Thursday-Dec. 2, Museum of American Folk Art.

title: Headliners;   Stringing Along
description: The judges then reviewed her audition tape and decided that it was the work of either Yehudi Menuhin or Fritz Kreisler, ''There were doubts from the beginning,'' said Thomas J. Beckiewicz, the director of the contest, which carries a prize of $20,000 and a Carnegie Hall debut. After the judges called Ms. Singer a fraud, Mr. Beckiewicz said, she offered ''no admission, no regrets, no penitence.''

title: Politics and the Gulf
description: On his recent campaign swing, Mr. Bush sensibly and properly refrained from openly seeking Republican votes as a reward for his military response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. That, nonetheless, was the net effect of his remarks.

title: Lowell Kern Wed To Jill Rothleder
description: He will become an associate in the New York law firm of Milgrim Thomajan & Lee next month. His mother is a travel consultant in Great Neck, L.I. His father is a dentist in New York.

title: In First Class
description: After caviar, lobster, foie gras, crab claws and Japanese hors d'oeuvres, J.A.L. offers a choice of soups and a list of entrees, which includes filet mignon, roast beef, a seafood special and skewered chicken teriyaki, served with potatoes, asparagus and carrots. Salad, cheeses, dessert and fruit follow.

title: Class Act
description: Which means that the only people who know much about Irene Dunne, apart from those old enough to have seen her when her films were first-run, are the kind of people who believe that the 30's and the 40's marked Hollywood's Golden Age. And few of its ornaments shone brighter than Irene Dunne.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ''A Window on Provence'' describes how she joined her parents, who had rented a house in Provence, in a hamlet of about a dozen dwellings near the hilltop village of Gordes (which has been called one of France's most beautiful villages). She wanted a sabbatical from her job and family responsibilities - time to look, think, feel, keep a journal, draw, make collages and enjoy time with her mother, a painter, and her father, a composer. She explored the countryside, went to local markets, visited a Cistercian abbey, attended a wine festival, a circus and various fetes. She met interesting people, among them Lizzie Napoli, a book illustrator from Paris who owned and summered in a tiny roulotte, or gypsy cart, decorated in bright colors with a curtain of beads and pale-pink scalloped awnings. She was invited to the art historian John Rewald's house, The Citadel, where sketches by some of his favorite Impressionists hung on the walls. Ms. Niles gives snippets of the area's history and describes local customs and characters. Her book, illustrated with the author's amusing line drawings, is charming and intelligent; she can make you taste an oily olive and a sun-dried tomato, smell the rosemary and picture sunflowers and a rugged, stony terrain. If it is not possible to go to Provence, this book will transport you there and give you a taste of the region. One wishes for more and thanks Ms. Niles for a fascinating journey.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

The Years Can Bring Siblings Together
description: LEAD: OH, BROTHER! My daughter and son are engaged in one of their frequent bickering sessions. He wants to borrow a tape, and although she's not listening to it at the moment, she says he can't. The verbal combat begins, and I finally move away in search of some peace.

title: Question Of the Week;   Do the Mets Have What It Takes to Win It All?
description: LEAD: Win it all? No way. Tom Herr, the only fielder on the team, four good starters, and only one relief pitcher may be enough to beat the Pirates, but no way does this team beat Cincinnati. And if they did, there would still be Boston or Oakland left. F'gedabodit!

title: 'Waiting for Armageddon'
description: Just as they muse out loud, toward the end of their essay, about how C. S. Lewis might feel about being appropriated by fundamentalists as one of their own, I wonder how Mr. Westberg feels about the willingness of Mr. Lifton and Mr. Strozier to do the same thing to him. Let me be clear: I know Granger Westberg, having worked with him on a television program. Mr. Westberg was then, and still is, very much involved in holistic health centers, which combine medical staffs and clergy as teams to deal with the totality of a person who is ill. He is about as far from a fundamentalist as one can be - especially given the definition of fundamentalism the authors seem to use.

title: The Executive Computer;   Can Invaders Be Stopped but Civil Liberties Upheld?
description: For example, is a company vulnerable to legal action, or the seizure of its computer equipment and data, if a single employee is accused of using a home computer to capture or store unauthorized data? Do private messages sent on an electronic mail system have the same protection as messages sent through the Postal Service? Is the concept of property valid in a world where data can be copied and replicated without limits and without disturbing the original data?

title: As One Grocery Boycott Ends, One Drags On
description: Mayor Dinkins said at the rally that his office was continuing to work toward a settlement in Flatbush, but added that details of that boycott, and of the negotiations, were ''too complicated'' to discuss. ''We're confident we will achieve a resolution,'' he said.

title: 'Waiting for Armageddon'
description: LEAD: To the Editor:

title: A Single Shining Muscle of a Girl
description: Don't let your daughter near the gym, Mrs. Worthington, or, like Shereel Dupont, the heroine of Mr. Crews's electric new novel, ''Body,'' she won't come back. Or if she does, it won't be as the sweet, plump young thing you know and love but, as the book puts it, and puts it so well, ''a single shining muscle of a girl.'' See? There goes your daughter, off already! Pumping iron like Shereel to make the sleek dream of androgyny come true. Too skinny for menstrual periods. Narcissa triumphant! Anorexia jubilant! And not for a moment, such is this male writer's skill, the throttled-back energy of his writing, do I doubt Mr. Crews's right to be as intimate as he is with his female characters.

title: Special Hasidic Ballot Leads to Brooklyn Suit
description: In a lawsuit filed last week in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn against the Board of Elections, Mr. Norman charged that a statute that allows individuals to vote by special ballot rather that at a polling site because of ''religious scruples'' is unconstitutionally vague. One of his lawyers, Mitchell Alter, said the law gives the board ''arbitrary discretion as to who to give these ballots to.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: DANCERS & THE DANCE. By Summer Brenner. (Coffee House Press, Paper, $9.95.) All writers have obsessions that run through their works like threads of the same color in clothes of very different design. For Summer Brenner, a dancer and poet as well as a writer of short fiction, it is dance - from ballet to flamenco, from ballroom to African style.

title: Bonnie A. Blake Wed To John Kubick on L.I.
description: LEAD: Bonnie A. Blake, the daughter of Donald M. Blake of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late Aileen M. Blake, was married yesterday to John J. Kubick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kubick Jr. of Tenafly, N.J. The Rev. Charles A. Ribaudo, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Dominic Church in Oyster Bay.

title: Trading Safety for Better Car Mileage
description: The GEO Metro gets 53 miles per gallon, but it is a ''niche'' car, not something that could be the ''average'' in the United States, Europe or Japan. Prototypes that do 70 miles per gallon have no heater or radio; the windows do not open, and the streamlining would be very costly for production cars. The developers make it clear that these cars are for research, and will never be mass-produced.

title: Portuguese Food Plus European Service
description: The lone waiter is a marvel to observe. One evening, when every one of the dozen tables was filled, he handled the room spectacularly: promptly delivering food, knowing who ordered what and even taking time for a friendly word at each table. His was a solo performance, with only a busboy in attendance.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: IN SOUTHERN LIGHT: Trekking Through Zaire and the Amazon, by Alex Shoumatoff. (Vintage, $9.95.) After traveling up the Amazon in search of its namesake, the legendary tribe of giant women, Alex Shoumatoff headed to Zaire to look for pygmies. ''Mr. Shoumatoff achieves the difficult task of getting beyond that sector of the country that faces West and into the lives of the 95 percent or so of its residents who ordinarily live out of the sight of visitors,'' Edward Zuckerman said here in 1986. Vintage has recently reissued two other Shoumatoff books. Published in 1985, THE MOUNTAIN OF NAMES: A History of the Human Family ($10.95) explores the genealogical impulse, describing among other things an old Sumatran who can chant 70 generations' worth of his family tree and the Mormon Church's 1.5 billion-name data base, which it keeps in a bombproof vault inside a mountain. In RUSSIAN BLOOD ($12.95), published in 1982, Mr. Shoumatoff traces his own ancestry back to 15th-century Russia.

title: Poem of My Time
description: LEAD: Hebrew writing and Arabic writing go from east to west,

title: Reportage Is Out and Opinions Are In As the Camera Redefines Itself
description: Pictures that address social issues are one trend, and they are as likely to be overtly opinionated as they are reportorial. Examples range from Sebastiao Salgado's photojournalism, coming to the International Center of Photography in March, to the bright and oddly cheery color images of a new group of documentary British photographers, opening Feb. 15 at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Katherine Royes Is Wed
description: LEAD: Katherine Downey Royes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Royes Jr. of Scotch Plains, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Shepherd Boyd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen R. Boyd of West Falmouth, Mass. The Rev. Blaine Taylor, assisted by the Rev. William Harvey, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the United Methodist Church in Osterville, Mass.

title: Miss Kagan Wed To M.J. Diserio
description: Mrs. Diserio graduated from the Chapin School and Columbia University. She is the managing director of Erica Wilson Needleworks in New York and Nantucket. Her mother, a designer and author known professionally as Erica Wilson, owns the company. The bride's father, a New York designer of furniture and interiors, is president of the New York Metropolitan Chapter of the American Society of Interior Designers.

title: Postings: $650,000 Plus;   Church Repairs
description: As a result of an engineering report by the Manhattan firm of Walter Melvin, the church at 85th Street is now embarked on a program to rebuild the wall and replace or repair gutters, downspouts, roof tiles and the deteriorated Manhattan schist of the facade. Eventually, the work will also embrace the stained glass, including the main window by Louis Comfort Tiffany.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;

1860's Houses Being Updated
description: LEAD: Two local developers are transforming 26 Civil War-era row houses built for millworkers into a European-style village in the city's Manayunk section, about 20 minutes northwest of Center City.

title: Ohio State Beats Texas Tech, 17-10
description: During an 82-yard drive near the end of the third quarter, Smith caught one pass for 24 yards and had three carries for 49 more yards. He ended the drive with a 2-yard run to tie the score at 10-10. Ohio State threatened on its first possession of the final quarter after an 11-yard punt by Tech gave the Buckeyes the ball at the Red Raiders' 34. But a 21-yard field-goal attempt by Tim Williams was wide.

title:
DINING OUT;

Tuscan Food, Casually Stylish Setting
description: LEAD: FOR all its gentrifying in the last few years, Jersey City has been disappointingly slow to come up with some first-rate restaurants, and so word of a casually stylish new eating place specializing in Tuscan cuisine was welcome.

title: Videodisks Make a Push For a Larger Audience
description: The increasing use of videodisks also affects other segments of the video market. In particular, there has been a mini-boom in the sale of large-screen projection sets, because the large screen shows off the videodisk to the best advtange. That's why an unusual number of projection sets are making their debut this fall.

title: Yvette Teofan and Randy Hazelton Are Married
description: The Rev. Jack Deeves officiated at St. Rita Roman Catholic Church in Dallas. The bride, who is 27 years old and is keeping her name, and her husband, also 27, graduated from Stanford University in 1985. She received a law degree from Yale University and is an associate with Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton in New York. The bridegroom is an associate at the First Boston Corporation in New York.

title: Yet Again, Some Once-in-a-Lifetime Exhibitions, This Time Of Titian and Van Dyck. Plus, the Unseen Malevich
description: ''Titian'' is, simply put, a once-in-a-lifetime event. The first big retrospective of the Venetian Renaissance master to be held in this country, these 60 paintings, many of them newly cleaned and restored, will give body to one of the greatest names in art and trace a career of astounding historical sweep.

title: William Silent Hughes, 84 Stock Exchange Governor
description: He died of degenerative heart disease, a family spokesman said.

title: Campus Life: Lehigh;   When a College Drops Required Languages
description: A majority of the 500 students who were required to study languages were enrolling for basic French and Spanish for just the required two semesters, the chairman of the department of modern and foreign languages and literature, David W. Pankenier, said. ''Are we really achieving our goal this way?'' he asked. ''Pedagogically it doesn't make sense.''

title: New Taint on East German Pollution
description: But now, senior officials at the complex - which produces basic chemicals, aluminum, pesticides, dyes, plastics and hundreds of other products -are saying the region was poisoned willfully in a scheme to raise money for the state.

title: PARENT AND CHILD
description: LEAD:

title: Of Parenthood And Adulthood
description: Before the author knows it, his last child will be grown up and out of the house, leaving him another three or four decades to once again join the express line at the supermarket, visit sports-car dealerships, stay up all night to watch old movies or enjoy three-day weekends.

title: Question Of the Week;   Do the Mets Have What It Takes to Win It All?
description: A more legitimate question would be: Can the Mets play better than the Pirates for the rest of the season and capture their division?

title: THE ANNOTATED CALENDAR: FILM
description: ''WHITE HUNTER, BLACK HEART.'' Shot in Africa, based on Peter Viertel's bitter yet adoring 1955 novel about a film director suspiciously like John Huston making ''The African Queen.'' Clint Eastwood directs and stars, with Marisa Berenson as the fictionalized Katharine Hepburn and Jeff Fahey as the Viertel stand-in. Got mixed reviews at Cannes. Friday. ''GOODFELLAS.'' No director is better than Martin Scorsese, and few are as good. ''Goodfellas'' is his mature return to the ''Mean Streets'' material that made him famous, and should be one of the season's best. Ray Liotta, as Henry Hill, fulfills a boyhood dream and becomes a mobster, with Robert De Niro, Joe Pesci and Paul Sorvino as part of his crime family. Watch for delightful small acting roles by Catherine and Charles Scorsese, the director's parents, the stars of his documentary ''Italianamerican.'' Based on Nicholas Pileggi's nonfiction book ''Wiseguy.'' Sept. 19.

title: THE ANNOTATED CALENDAR: THEATER
description: ''IVANOV.'' William Hurt plays the title role in the Chekhov play. The staging is by Oleg Yefreymov, the artistic director of the Moscow Art Theater, making his American debut. Sept. 21, Yale Repertory Theater. ''MACHINAL.'' Put Franz Xaver Kroetz in a time machine and out comes this 1928 Sophie Treadwell play. In her Expressionist view, women are savaged by an industrialized society. Staged by Michael Greif, one of three young directors in residence this year at the New York Shakespeare Festival. Sept. 25, Public Theater.

title: Nancy E. Breslow To Wed in Fall
description: Her father recently retired as the vice president of taxes at ANR Pipeline Company in Detroit. Her stepfather, Peter Claman, is a partner in the New York architectural firm of Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron.

title: THE ANNOTATED CALENDAR: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: ''THE WOMEN OF JUCHITAN.'' Graciela Iturbide is one of Mexico's finest contemporary photographers. These haunting, mysterious images describe the matriarchal culture of a small town on the Pacific coast. Thursday-Oct. 19, Camera Club of New York, 853 B'way at 14th St., N.Y., 260-7077.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: A. Commercial sources? Unknown. This is a protected species of club moss (Lycopodium), an evergreen, and it is rarely, if ever, propagated, but grows naturally where conditions suit it. Because princess pine (ground pine) can often be found in abundance in some locales, it is often gathered carelessly for Christmas decorations. This indiscriminate pulling up of the club mosses is threatening the species' survival.

title: Symphony Is Offering 'Music in Gothic Space'
description: Still later comes a Christmas concert ''in the Currier and Ives spirit'' by the Waterbury Chorale. And the May finale is what Ms. West calls ''a classical blockbuster'' with the pianist Ruth Laredo and the Shanghai String Quartet (567-4162).

title:
TELEVISION;

It's the Year of the (Sort of Strange) Family
description: LEAD: Television families seem to lurch - like drunken sailors - from the bland to the bizarre. As a kid, I watched ''Ozzie and Harriet,'' all-American vanilla except when Ricky sang a little rock-and-roll. My children grew up with daily reruns of ''The Brady Bunch,'' who were so disgustingly perky I wanted to pull their fingernails out.

title: CRIME
description: Mr. Block has a fine nose for the pungencies of New York's after-dark street life, and he gives his hero wonderful opportunities to swap syllables with the city's most articulate riffraff. This is primo stuff, and Scudder doesn't get any sharper than when he's interviewing transvestite hookers, desk clerks in fleabag hotels and bouncers in gay leather bars. He does waste too much time, though, gabbing with a supposedly high-class hooker who talks pure tripe. ''We've been under a strain, both of us,'' states this bore. ''I think it's made us more vulnerable than we realized.'' And a mite duller, too.

title: Guide for Home Buyers, Sellers and Renters;   Sifting Through the Boilerplate For Essentials in a Prospectus
description: Beyond the prospectus and its amendments, there are other important documents to examine. In the case of an already established co-op or condominium, it is wise to read the minutes of the co-op or condominium board meetings, which may disclose major problems in a building. In the case of a conversion, the tenants' engineering report is essential reading since it will indicate what must be done to make the building sound.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: JOAN L. MESCHI;

'Making a Lot of Noise' to Fight AIDS
description: LEAD: THE call to action for Joan L. Meschi were the deaths of many friends from AIDS. Convinced that more had to be done to teach both the public and the government, the 23-year-old Port Chester resident got together with a fellow student at the State University of New York at Purchase, Roger Newton of Mount Kisco, and founded a Westchester chapter of Act-Up - or the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power.

title: In Home Video, a Lot to Rent and Even More to Buy
description: Though the hits keep coming, video enters autumn with other concerns. Still a very popular way to spend an evening, movies on cassette are no longer the rage they were in the 80's. These days the industry must work harder to hold the public's interest. In most video specialty stores, the priority is nourishing the rental trade. At the big studios, the plan is to supply the market with scores of titles, new and old, to sell to consumers at prices that in some cases have gone below $15 and might be headed still lower. (Both ''Pretty Woman'' and ''Total Recall'' should rent well, of course, but at $19.99 and $24.99 respectively, they will enter stores priced to sell.) On another front, the industry, like other arts-related enterprises, warily eyes would-be censors in states and localities where restrictive regulations are contemplated. (One forthcoming release may have nothing to do with censorship per se, but perhaps it's symbolic of new sensibilities. While video commonly restores X-rated material cut from movies for their theater runs, Vidmark has cut a sizable chunk from the previously unrated film ''The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover,'' due Oct. 17, so that the film could be given an R rating for its video release. Vidmark will also bring out an unrated version.) Whatever the issues, a video season comes down to titles. Here is a partial sampling of what will be released in the next few months, beginning with ''name'' movies, which, if not necessarily works of art or blockbusters at the box office, are the titles that most often bring people to the video store.

title: Bush and Gorbachev, in Helsinki, Face the Gulf Crisis
description: ''Here in Helsinki, President Gorbachev and I meet, hopefully to strengthen our common approach to this unjustifiable act of aggression,'' he said after alighting from his new Presidential jumbo jet at the Helsinki Airport this morning, The two leaders were meeting for the third time as heads of state; they met in Malta in December and in Washington at the end of May.

title: Campus Life: Rutgers;   Fraternity Chapter Starts With Focus On Helping Others
description: ''A bunch of us did rush other fraternities and didn't like what we saw,'' said the chapter president, Steven Craig, a senior from Randolph majoring in biology and psychology. ''So we said this isn't what we want. We want to get together and start something to suit us.''

title: Suzan Onel, an Attorney, Marries in Mamaroneck
description: Mrs. Bickel and her husband are both 25 years old and 1986 graduates of the University of Pennsylvania. She received a law degree from the University of Virginia in May and is to become an associate at the Washington law firm of Arent, Fox, Kintner, Plotkin & Kahn next month. The bridegroom has a master's degree in international relations from Johns Hopkins University and is to begin doctoral studies there next month in American foreign policy.

title: The World;   Increasingly Isolated, North Korea Starts Talking
description: A significant opening occurred last week when, after a year of sputtering delays, Prime Minister Yon Hyung Muk of North Korea led the highest-level delegation to South Korea since the end of World War II. The two sides failed to narrow their differences but agreed to continue efforts to reduce tensions, meeting next in North Korea. More important was the fact that a dialogue had begun. Clearly part of what compelled the North to visit the South was the changing global environment brought about by the collapse of the cold war. But there were also signs of extraordinary internal and external pressures on the ossified regime of the 78-year-old self-proclaimed Great Leader, Mr. Kim.

title: Pastimes: Gardening;   Restoration of Old-Fashioned Plants Is the Goal
description: After instituting guided tours through Monticello's gardens in 1983, he noticed that many of the visitors were involved in garden restoration work. The visitors had no idea, however, how to find the plants that had been grown in this country a century and more ago.

title: Browsing by Screen: Libraries Make Some Overdue Changes
description: LEAD: LAST summer a woman walked into the Library of the Chathams and exclaimed in surprise at the sight of the card catalogue. There was nothing at all unusual about the tidy arrangement of wooden drawers, each filled with the familiar well-worn title and author cards.

title: In the 'Jungle' Of Another Language
description: It has been said that the devil is in the details, and the devil for English speakers learning a European language is likely to be grammatical gender. In German, for example, a man is masculine and a woman is feminine, and that's as it should be. But why is a young girl neuter? Why does the sturdy masculine article ''der'' undergo a sex change in the possessive case? And why, if it comes to that, is a pencil masculine and a pen feminine? Mine not to reason why, mine just to memorize.

title: As Defaults Keep Rising, A Market Dies
description: Announcing the death of a market is always risky. There are still Wall Streeters who talk, with malicious glee, about Business Week's ''Death of Equities'' cover more than a decade ago. But while there will always be a stock market, the need for a junk bond market is far less obvious.

The institution is Carnegie Hall, which celebrates its 100th birthday all season, culminating in a 10-day centennial festival and an all-star centennial gala on May 5. Isaac Stern, Carnegie's president, will also be celebrating his own 70th birthday throughout much of the season.

title: The Scandal Is the Lack of Funding for Medical Research
description: For example, infection-control procedures proposed by the Occupational Safey and Health Administration may cost dentists and therefore patients up to $1 billion a year, supposedly to reduce transmission of AIDS and hepatitis in the dental office. But there is scant evidence that AIDS can be transmitted in the dental office, and there is a good vaccine for hepatitis B. But the far bigger scandal is that simple addition of $1.7 billion, $1.6 billion and $1.1 billion equals $4.4 billion total for AIDS, cancer, and heart disease research in 1990. Is this a bad joke? Pick something to compare it to, anything - the $180 billion-a-year illicit narcotics industry in the United States; $400 billion to $500 billion for the savings and loan crisis.

title: Giants Possess What the Jets Need

But as cautious as he and most N.F.L. coaches are, he acknowledged being ''generally happy'' with the atmosphere surrounding the Giants while awaiting tonight's opener against the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Headliners;   Short Reign
description: The enraged Governor postponed his trip and set his aides on Ms. Murphy. One accused her of an ''attempted bloodless coup.'' Another said she was ''dangerously flirting with the economic health'' of Massachusetts. Ms. Murphy, who has a Ph.D. in economics, insisted she was within her rights. ''Frankly, I find the Governor's response weird,'' she said. The very day he left, she did indeed issue orders for cutbacks, but Mr. Dukakis can rescind them upon his return this week, before they take effect, and he said he saw no reson to cut his trip short.

title: Laos
description: The author's ''glimpses at traditional [that is to say, authentic] Asia'' are marred with what he considers to be inconsistent images: ''Men wear Western clothes, and wear them rather casually.'' Invited to share a family feast, Mr. Kristof only depicts his host's inadequate hygiene: ''A few toasts with local wine left us reeling, only partly at the realization that the dozen revelers were all sharing the same glasses and nobody was bothering to wash them between rounds.'' (If I am not mistaken, there are many comparable Western practices.) The author generalizes on the basis of limited knowledge of Laotian culture. After a single picnic he says of Laotian cuisine, ''The food, unfortunately, was authentic Lao, which is to say, not very good.'' He adds, ''Lao food is built around tasteless gobs of sticky rice, and it is even less appetizing after it has been shaped by other people's unwashed hands.''

title: JUNK MAIL'S TOP DOGS

I find it hard to believe that a journalist who has so often been a proponent of direct marketing's effectiveness in today's fragmented marketplace could perpetuate the disparaging term "junk mail.

As an active-duty army officer, the Spanish King cultivated close personal links with the military while steadily guiding Spain away from authoritarianism.

title: Reducing Stress to Increase Productivity
description: A. It depends on whether it's positive or negative stress. Positive stress, for example, might occur when there is a meeting where you have to make a presentation. Your body gears up, your palms get sweaty and your heartbeat speeds up and your respiration increases. Then the adrenaline kicks in to help you cope with the situation. After you make the presentation, you should go back to a relaxation response, where things become normal and the body calms down. Positive stress helps us cope with situations.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

The Mulberry Trees Evoke a Simpler Time
description: LEAD: WHEN I was a boy, the hills near Peekskill were still ''the country.'' A short walk from our house, along a still-undeveloped road and then through a stand of tall pine trees, was the lake where it seemed all the ''sunnys'' in the world lived. Just down the hill a bit was an apple orchard where we played ball, or sometimes, entrenched beneath the scraggly trees, a game of mock war, hurling rotten apples at each other like so many grenades.

title: PARENT AND CHILD
description: Despite its commendable intentions, ''Endangered Minds'' suffers from a diffusion, both overall and specific, that severely limits its impact and usefulness. There is diffusion of purpose. Is the point to enlist the reader in some fierce culture bashing? Is it to establish the thesis that our brains are atrophying? To identify and obliterate the enemies? To reform schools? The author takes on all.

title: The Executive Life;   Puckish Humor, Pranksters and Pratfalls
description: The prank at the diminutive consultant's expense illustrates what a delicate matter practical jokes can be in corporate settings. When they works - and the butt of the joke is good-natured like Ms. Spanier - humor can build rapport, reduce stress and smooth communications, according to consultants, psychologists and comedians who profit from teaching organizations how to inject levity into staid corporate cultures. But humor in the office is a risky business. A practical joke that flops can be hurtful and divisive.

title: Fear in the Subway: Riders Adopt Tactics To Ward Off Danger

She frowns constantly and carries a six-inch switchblade knife in her purse for protection. ''I don't like carrying a knife and hope to never use it,'' she said, ''but I have no other choice.''

title: Tech Notes;   Giving Good Weight to Plastic

Some early products will be faucets, packaging for cosmetics, piano keys and housings for small appliances. G.E. adds weight to its valox plastics by mixing in 65 percent by weight of mineral filler. ''It amounts to blending rocks with cookie batter,'' said Blair Anthony, the product manager. ''The difficult part is to manufacture the material without having the rocks settle out.'' The material can be treated to resemble metal components.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

At Penn Station, Commuters See The Ugly Truth
description: LEAD: AS a commuter frequently using Pennsylvania Station, I was both relieved and disturbed by the station management's decision to evict the homeless living there. Relieved because, like most commuters, I have been harassed by the homeless who reside there, and yet not quite comfortable with the move because the removal of the homeless from the station represents yet another attempt to keep us all from seeing this population, from witnessing the state in which thousands live.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: ''Heaven and Hell'' seems to have half the population of the Bronx between its covers. In fact a cast list at the beginning of the book will probably be helpful to the reader from time to time. The book is not hard to follow. It is simply crowded with people and action.

title: He Died to Tell the Tale
description: Mr. Nooteboom's narrators - the writers who speak to us in such novels as ''In the Dutch Mountains'' and ''A Song of Truth and Semblance'' - worry over their role as creators of fictions. They urge readers to remember that the book itself is an odd object, floating in the complicated context of a writer's thoughts and feelings. A book reflects idiosyncratic decisions: what to exclude, how to interpret and translate reality. These questions affect not only the writer of fiction but of nonfiction as well. This is particularly true of biography, in which the writer must use all his wiles and strategies to apprehend his subject's life, to locate the boundaries between that life and his own.

title: Vikings Pick Kicker
description: LEAD: The Minnesota Vikings have decided to let an expensive insurance policy lapse rather than keep two place-kickers on the squad. The team, which has decided to go with Donald Igwebuike as its kicker, said it had given its previous kicker, Rick Karlis, permission to seek offers from other teams. SPORTS PEOPLE

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A private ferry for residents and their guests is ''a tremendous asset for the village,'' said the Mayor, Frank C. Trotta. Bellport has operated a ferry to its Fire Island beach for many years. ''We leased one,'' Mr. Trotta said. A few years ago, the village decided to buy one. ''We had this ferry built in Patchogue to our specifications,'' the mayor said. ''It seats 45. This is the third summer we've had it.''

title: Austria's Clandestine Workers
description: The street-corner black market for workers here is another sign of the economic upheaval in Eastern Europe and its spillover effects on the region's Western neighbors. Tens of thousands of East Europeans have streamed into Austria recently to work illegally, according to police statistics, Government officials and economists. Most are temporary employees, who work in Austria for a few months for the comparatively high wages and then return home, much as illegal Mexican workers in the United States do. At home, even low-paying jobs are dwindling as Eastern nations making the rocky transition to market-driven systems experience higher unemployment and more business failures.

title: Review/Dance;   Program of Recent Works Opens Out-of-Towners Festival
description: Set to music by Winston Damon, ''The Crotch to the World Phrase'' started out with an interesting duet for Mr. Eisen and Joanne Barrett in which the two grappled, fiercely and playfully, but seldom seemed related otherwise. And the duet went on at the same level of energy and focus a very long time.

This would be more efficient and there would be no chance of moisture going from one bathroom to the other. A long, narrow vent opening will work, but its cross-section area should be equal to the inside area of the duct that connects to it. Insulating the duct is not is not necessary.

description: Many apparel companies operate today about the way they did at the turn of the century. Rows of workers apply the same stitches, piece after piece, to bundles of partially finished garments. Then they pass the bundles on to others for the next step.

description: ''It's a very tough, negative campaign and I don't think anybody's being very nice,'' said Bob Slagle, the Texas Democratic chairman.

title:
DANCE;

Reflecting the Cultures Of a Wider World
description: LEAD: THE island of Bali's youngest artist-ambassadors will offer a program of music and dance on Friday when 22 Balinese children cap their cultural residency in Montclair with a public performance at Montclair State College. Their performance, along with many others throughout the state in the coming season, reflects the expansion of multicultural offerings in the national performing arts scene.

title: The Blue and the Gray, in Color
description: Thus we have the familiar but still moving sights of Walt Whitman turning in despair from the carnage in a Union hospital; of Abraham Lincoln all but prodding Gen. George B. McClellan with a pitchfork toward the battleground; of Mary Chestnut documenting the South's cultural collapse in her private diary; of Henry Adams in London, exulting over the Union victory at Vicksburg: ''I want to fight some small man and lick him.'' We also have less familiar voices: a freed Louisiana slave who encounters his captured former owner and declares, ''Hello, Massa, bottom rail on top dis time''; a wounded Union soldier who badly burns his hands rescuing fallen Confederates from the burning underbrush, ''but me and them rebs tried to shake hands''; a Southern soldier describing the terrifying, exhilarating noise at Shiloh: ''a ripping, roaring, boom bang!'' The narrative is amplified by separate essays by the historians C. Vann Woodward, James M. McPherson, Don E. Fehrenbacher and Barbara J. Fields, and by a fascinating interview with Shelby Foote; these authorities, who have made the subject of the Civil War their lives, probe the causes and issues of the war and provide interesting personal viewpoints. A companion to a nine-part Public Broadcasting System documentary, this superbly designed book easily stands on its own.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: McBee Ahead by a Shot: The defending champion, Rives McBee, finished with an eagle to shoot a five-under-par 67 yesterday and hold a two-stroke lead in the Bank One Seniors Classic in Lexington, Ky. McBee, who won his first Seniors event in the 1989 tournament, birdied No. 17 before the eagle on the 531-yard final hole on the Kearney Hill Golf Links. He had a 36-hole total of 133, 11 under par. Quinton Gray shot a 67 to stay two strokes behind McBee heading into the final round today. Gray is at nine-under 135. McBee birdied the 14th to break a tie with Gray. Lee Trevino, a six-time winner and the Senior Tour's leading money winner, pulled into contention with a 66, and was four strokes behind McBee at 137. (AP)

title: Putting the Focus On Beauty That's Skin Deep
description: The exhibit's emphasis on surface decoration over form is part of a trend that can be seen today in museum and gallery presentations of decorative arts from antiquity onward. Increasingly, these shows reveal a taste for bold graphics, compositional complexity and offbeat combinations of textures. Embellishment is also the subject of several exhibits at New York galleries this season.

title: Sihanouk Makes Concession on Cambodian Talks
description: In a statement, issued in Beijing, Prince Sihanouk announced that he would make a concession of his own and agree to an even division of the interim body, called the Supreme National Council, between the rival claimants in Cambodia, as Mr. Hun Sen has demanded. The council is intended to embody Cambodian sovereignty until elections.

The sulfurous stench of brimstone bubbled up from the volcano's steaming crater. A blue-white bolt of lightning shattered the air no more than 50 yards away.

title: The World;   Shocks From Kuwait Hit the Third World
description: More than a million Arab workers are on the run from Kuwait and Iraq, and the loss of the wages they sent home or saved for a new life will particularly affect Egypt, Jordan and the scattered Palestinians. In Kuwait, much of the bureaucracy was made up of Palestinians, while Egyptians were represented as teachers and doctors. Jordan, with few resources of its own, became an exporter of people, building an educational system that sent skilled engineers and other workers to the Gulf.

title: What's Best for the Nation - Not the Oil Industry
description: Did it occur to anyone that what's best for ''oil'' is not necessarily best for the country? What is urgently needed is an overall energy policy that would insure that we are not, and will never become, dependent on a foreign country for energy. The plan should include all components of energy production and use. And for once, let's remember that the purpose of a government subsidy should be to solve the energy problem, not improve corporate profits.

title: Still Asking the Embarassing Questions
description: Like many of Mr. Vonnegut's novels, ''Hocus Pocus'' is a retrospective first-person narrative in which several time and story lines gradually converge. It is told by one Eugene Debs Hartke and purportedly written in prison on scraps of paper, each scrap a thought, story or digression unto itself - a form ideally suited to Mr. Vonnegut's thumbnail essayistic bent and his high-speed forward- and reverse-narrative time travel.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: ASK Americans today to identify the name Garfield, and most would probably think of the cat from the comic strips. But at one time the name meant the martyred President whose slow, agonizing death at the Jersey Shore 109 years ago this month transfixed the nation in horror and pity.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Beowulf, Get Off the Sofa
description: LEAD: ONE morning at breakfast, we were watching the news while my 9-year-old son waited for his school bus. The commentator was discussing the refurbishing of the Sistine Chapel at the Vatican. There were wonderful shots of the famous frescos on the ceiling and walls, as the video voice-over discussed Michelangelo.

title: Adrift in Sex
description: Mr. Michaels's second collection of stories, ''I Would Have Saved Them if I Could,'' came out in 1975 and, surprisingly, they were more promising than the earlier ones. In fact, they were good in his special way, if you forgave them their sins. These stories were leaner, more truly quirky, full of almost danceable rhythms. They were New York City stories in the best sense, proud of their sophistication. They were less strained. Mr. Michaels was putting more of his energy into persuading us that his characters exist in the world, or at least in some world. He had discovered that, if you intensify a fault, it may turn into a style.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Sending the Market a Message
description: LEAD: IT started with a phone call close to suppertime.

title: Letter Omits Critique Of Museum Mission
description: The tenfold increase in attendance claimed by Mr. Black seems to be wishful thinking (he should speak to some of the docents) and the donation cookie jar near the reception desk seldom appears to be overflowing. I believe that Black qualifies for the first annual ''Emperor's New Clothing Award'' and I wish him well in obtaining accreditation similar to the Heckscher and the Parrish, and neighboring art galleries at C.W. Post, Hofstra, Adelphi, New York Tech. etc.

title: U.S. Cases Rise in New York Circuit as Drug Trials Dominate

title: Q and A
description: The association holds two weekend seminars a year in Santa Barbara for $375 a person and $650 a couple; the cost includes food but not rooms. On Thursday, JoAnn Bell of the association will be at Macy's in New York along with other innkeepers to talk about starting an inn.

title: Hers;   A Second Time Around
description: I later found out that what he really meant was that he wanted to take part in a growing tradition. A second bar mitzvah is a relatively modern custom celebrating old age - the fact that a person has lived out his biblical allotment of 70 years (Psalms 90:10). After 70 that person begins counting over. Upon reaching the year when he is again 13, actually 83, he may elect to go through a ceremony that echoes his bar mitzvah. Many of these elderly people choose to read the same portion from the Torah - in my father's case, a passage from Exodus - that was read all those years before. No need, it seems, to learn a new one. A true blessing.

title: The Underside of the Stones
description: The Jones murder scenario makes a slender foundation for a book with the vast pretensions of ''Blown Away.'' Mr. Hotchner, the author of the memoir ''Papa Hemingway'' and biographies of Doris Day and Sophia Loren, professes to map the course of the 1960's against the ascent of the Rolling Stones. Jones, the son of an aeronautical engineer from Cheltenham, England, put an ad in a musicians' magazine that brought together some working-class kids who loved rhythm-and-blues; he named the group the Rolling Stones, and it worked its way from the back rooms of pubs to arenas full of screaming fans. The arc ends, for the book's purposes, with Jones's drowning in July 1969 and the Altamont, Calif., concert that December, at which three people died and many more were beaten by Hell's Angels who had been hired as a security force.

title: Small Civic Groups Unite in Causes
description: LEAD: TOWNS and villages across Long Island that have long waged lonely battles to safeguard their quality of life, which others see as the not-in-my-backyard syndrome, are beginning to find strength in numbers.

title: When This Umpire Takes the Field, Fans Cheer
description: LEAD: NICK KOULES is a walking refutation of the adage that the best umpires and referees are the ones who go unnoticed. After 50 years of officiating in thousands of amateur games in three sports, Mr. Koules is instantly recognizable to coaches, players and fans throughout southern Connecticut.

title: L. Frank Frehill Weds Miss Hohn
description: The Rev. Frederick D. Hoesli officiated.

title: Reischauer's Band Hastened Japan's Downfall
description: Reischauer, just beginning his lustrous career at Harvard, went to Washington shortly after Pearl Harbor. His confidential mission was to take under his wing at Arlington Hall Station in Virginia 50 or so specially recruited enlistees, I among them, who had been studying Japanese, mostly at Columbia, Harvard and Yale. He would instruct us in translating Japanese military and diplomatic telegrams that had been transliterated into the Roman alphabet.

title: Europeans Splurge on Vacations in Mauritius
description: But now German families are strolling along the pale, fine beaches, happy to spend $15,000 for a two-week package deal vacation. At the top of the line Royal Palm Hotel, English families attest to the power of the pound, paying $850 a night for a suite, water skiing, wind surfing and sailing included.

title: Traffic Alert
description: LEAD: The streets bordering Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village will be closed today from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. for the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit.

title:
ART;

What's High, What's Low - and Who Cares?
description: LEAD: There's something about categorizing things, about putting things in their place. Maybe it's a kind of comfort. Maybe it's setting things straight, putting first things first. Whatever it is, it surely has a hold on us. We seem intent on labeling and ordering. It's how we get on with our lives, all in a day's work, from the maintenance of homes and offices to the supposedly loftier pursuits of arranging history and conducting diplomacy.

title: Employees Take Leaves to Try New Paths
description: LEAD: FOR those who work to support families and make mortgage payments, life is often too short, and the work day too long, to allow for the pursuit of dreams. Now a few companies are offering their employees time off to follow those dreams, encouraging them to take sabbatical leaves, sometimes at full salary, to explore other interests.

title: Arbour Says Islanders' Future Is Now
description: Arbour Is Pleased

title: Air Fares
description: One bought a round-trip ''economy'' ticket in the spring for $464. The other purchased a round-trip ticket in July within hours of flight time for $138. They sat in adjacent seats.

title: Postings: Affordability Exhibition;   Bronx Designs
description: Called ''Visions of Home'' and scheduled to run from Sept. 27 through Jan. 27 at the museum at 1040 Grand Concourse, it comprises 50 of the 120 architectural renderings of affordable-housing designs submitted as part of a nationwide design competition. Ten of these, including the first-place winner by the Armonk, N.Y., architectural team of Christopher and Timothy Morris, were also awarded $10,000 in prizes by the museum. Besides the renderings and scale models, the exhibit will include lectures and housing tours of the South Bronx, an area that recently has seen a revival of interest in investment and homeownership. Admission is $2 (children under 12 free). Closed Fridays.

title: Drop Shots Vs. Education
description: Unfortunately, there are other institutions in the shadow of La Guardia Airport that have never received similar solicitude. One of them is Queens College. Teaching classes at Queens is a little like trying to lecture during the London blitz. Up to 500 planes a day blast off from La Guardia, and on bad days roar over the campus every couple of minutes. The noise shatters concentration in the classroom, destroys the mood and continuity of lectures, makes students even more restless, and frustrates everybody. But in the 50-year history of the college, not one plane has ever been diverted from the campus area.

title: Above It All
description: When the building opened during the depths of the Depression, its office-vacancy rate was so high that the owners relied on income from the observation deck to pay their taxes. The observatory was conceived as a temporary gimmick, with the deck eventually to become a hub for what was thought to be the transportation wave of the future - dirigibles. The 102d floor was designed as a dirigible waiting room, according to Laura Fries, the observatory's director, although only two of the unwieldy airships were ever moored atop the building. Instead the small, enclosed area on the 102d floor and a larger indoor-and-outdoor viewing deck on the 86th floor have become permanent and immensely popular attractions.

title: Something's Gone Terribly Wrong in New York
description: With allowance for the hyperbole of a bedazzled visitor, this was the city of my youth, the enchanted island in which I grew up and to which I later returned on vacations from college, on furlough from the Army or simply because, in those heady years, it was the center of my universe.

title: Autumn, It's No Garden Party
description: The harvest moon sometimes ushers in such a frost, always one of nature's heartbreakers, since typically it is followed by a few weeks of fine growing weather. When the tomatoes have succumbed to a September frost, and hang like black crepe from their cages, those weeks can seem cruel - the tease and rebuke of missed opportunities. So on those evenings when a full moon dominates a cloudless sky, and the air has a faint metallic tang to it, implying it will give up its heat without a struggle, we make a last-ditch stand on behalf of the annuals. To hold close some remnant of the earth's warmth, we dress the tomatoes and squashes and cucumbers in old bed sheets and tarps. On silvery nights like these the vegetable garden looks like a congregation of ghosts, and the earth feels as if it has lost its blanket; nothing stands between it and outer space. Bed sheets, a tender annual's spacesuit.

title: SMALL-FRY SWEARING
description: I feel that it simply expresses anxieties - in this case, about sex in general. Further, girls in a ''pack,'' like boys in a pack, exhibit extreme and ridiculous behaviors.

title: Data Bank/September 9, 1990
The Life of Barnum Gets Another Look
description: LEAD: A NEW image of P. T. Barnum, one of Connecticut's most celebrated personages, emerges from a recently published biography of the showman, written by A. H. Saxon, of Fairfield.

title: Headliners;   Old Story
description: Ever since Mr. Blanchard said a few weeks ago that the 78-year-old Mrs. Griffiths would be dropped from his re-election ticket because of her age and increasing frailty, he has been under a steady hail of criticism from two of his most loyal constituencies, the women and the elderly whose votes helped him win his first term in office. Mrs. Griffiths, a former 10-term Congresswoman and an icon in Michigan Democratic politics, was initially furious. ''The biggest problem in politics,'' she said, ''is that you help some S.O.B. get what he wants and then he throws you off the train.'' But Mr. Blanchard seemed to have Mrs. Griffiths' supporters in mind last week when he named his new running mate -Olivia Maynard, the 54-year-old director of the state Office of Aging.

title: Carolyn J. Hirschhorn Weds Curtis Schenker
description: Mrs. Schenker, 24 years old, graduated from Tufts University. Her father is the president of the Eastern Container Companies in Springfield, Mass. Her mother, Marjorie E. Hirschhorn, heads her own interior-design company in Longmeadow.

title: Attaching Paneling to Walls
description: Masonry nails to be driven into concrete should be long enough to penetrate about three-quarters of an inch. No increased holding power is achieved by driving nails deeper than an inch.

title: President of Turkey Advises Preparing for Military Role
description: ''You cannot have peace unless you are determined to reach out for it and be ready to make self-sacrifices for it, or to fight for it if necessary,'' the semi-official Anatolian News Agency quoted him as saying. ''You cannot get anywhere with fear. Therefore it is of great importance to solve the issue which has put the whole world into distress.

title: Nome or Bust
description: The story did not faze Mr. Scott, who was going to mush 800 miles from Manley Hot Springs, in the center of Alaska, to Nome, on its western edge. Mr. Scott, the author of ''Scot Free,'' ''A Scot Goes South'' and ''A Scot Returns,'' knew that rewards come to innocent adventurers - and to those who repeat the journey with them on the wings of a superb book.

title: Why Mozart Has Become an Icon for Today
description: Mozart is so familiar that some performers have been going out of their way to defamiliarize him, whether by updating him or by embalming him in ''historical'' timbres. Those supremely provocative opera productions of Peter Sellars try to have it both ways. The works are updated on the stage, embalmed in the pit - a perfect paradigm of post-modernism, perhaps, and yet another unmasking of the pseudohistoricism of ''Early Music.''

title: Air Force One Journal;   200,000 Miles Later, the President Gets His Wings
description: Now he has an airplane that can fly 6,200 miles on one tank of fuel and can be refueled in midair. Will George Bush beat his vice presidential record of 1,330,239 miles on the road?

title: SMALL-FRY SWEARING
description: Swearing by small fry was a common, daily occurrence. We allowed our son to swear at home but discouraged him from cursing in public. That took the shock value out of those words. If he banged his finger with a hammer, we would hear some well-chosen expletives.

title: Arab-Americans and Ugly Americans
description: To hold a diverse Arab world collectively responsible for a single leader's misdeeds traduces an entire people.

title: Guide for Home Buyers, Sellers and Renters;   Choices Rise, Rents Fall As Free Market Adds Units
description: Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, one of the city's largest rental agencies, put the rents for units in full-service, doorman buildings at about 10 percent below what they were last year. Her agency's listings show studios renting for between $900 to $1,000 a month, one-bedrooms going for $1,300 to $1,400, two-bedrooms renting for $2,000 to $2,2000 and apartments with three or more bedrooms going for $3,200 to $3,500. ''Rents are more negotiable than earlier this year,'' she said. Nevertheless, as her figures and those of other agents show, there are few bargains available. Rockrose Rental Division, a subsidiary of Rockrose Development Corporation of Manhattan, a real estate company that owns rental buildings and develops co-ops and condominiums, reported that the average rent for a 600-square-foot studio apartment in Battery Park City is now about $1,125. In Greenwich Village, the company found that rents for 450- to 500-square-foot studios range from $1,095 to $1,175.

title: Disabled Boy's Dog Provokes School Dispute
description: Michael's parents, Jane and Michael Gaudiello Sr., say their son is legally entitled to use a support dog and are planning to sue the special education unit of the Rose Tree Media School District. Upper Chichester, a Philadelphia suburb where the Gaudiellos live, is outside the school district, and state education officials want Michael to attend a school in his own district.

title: World Markets;   Taking the Country-Fund Plunge
description: Country funds are part of a special breed of mutual fund that can be buffeted by two variables. But the price also moves with the direction of the underlying foreign stock market.

Three years ago, it divested itself of these interests, retaining its divisions dealing with gas and oil transportation, farm and construction equipment and shipbuilding, among others.

title: Travel Advisory
description: But Ron Bitting, president of the National Association of Cruise-Only Agencies, believes cruise operators brought market troubles on themselves. Last year the Bermuda Government limited the number of cruise lines authorized to call there to four, a move that many thought would bolster prices. Instead, said Mr. Bitting, the high prices that resulted scared price-conscious customers away. ''We've been approaching it from the perspective that customers would have to pay full price,'' he said. ''But in times of economic stress you can't sell value. You have to sell price.''

title: Academy of Engineers Says U.S. Should Welcome Foreign Investors
description: The report comes at a time of uncertainty about what the Bush Administration will do to help American companies compete. Officials have said they want to avoid having the Government set industrial policy, through measures like incentives to encourage production of certain products. But President Bush recently suggested that he would offer Federal support for work on ''generic technologies'' that industries may use in their own way. The report calls for much stronger Federal action.

Night face, or after-hours contact, counts double; weekend face counts quadruple.

Instead, the 27-year-old center fielder has proven all doubters wrong, weaving his burgeoning abilities, the welcomed opportunity given by the Phillies and an unrelenting drive to excel into a season of widespread achievement.

description: Now along comes Maggie Schultz, the third-grade heroine of Beverly Cleary's ''Muggie Maggie.'' In a primary school version of ''The Chocolate War,'' Robert Cormier's classic young-adult novel, Maggie decides not to learn cursive. Why should she bother? She can read, she can print and she can use a computer. Maggie does not write grocery lists or memos or checks - the only things that cursive seems useful for - and besides, who would want to master a system of writing that is ''all wrinkled and stuck together''?

title: Das Kapital;   From Moscow, A Plan to Junk Communism in 500 Days
description: ''Our sad experience demonstrates how dangerous for society and for normal life is the man who has nothing to lose,'' declared the 250-page reform plan in indicting 72 years of Bolshevism for offering the common citizen a personal share in little more than despair. Under the plan, the central economic dictatorship would be dismantled and the nation's 15 sovereignty-hungry republics turned loose to build the free-market economy - all in 500 days. ''Property in the hands of each individual is a guarantee of the stability of society and a principal factor for preventing social and national cataclysm,'' proclaimed the panel, dialectic alchemists turning old heresy to gleaming dogma.

title: Why We Love the Mafia in the Movies
description: Then, whatever success ''The Valachi Papers'' enjoyed was immediately dwarfed by Mario Puzo's novel ''The Godfather'' and Francis Ford Coppola's two epic movie presentations in 1972 and 1974, the first based on the book and the second a totally cinematic extension of it.

title: Samurai on the Run
description: But Mr. Boyle, with his consummate artistry, has shaped this story into an absorbing tragedy. That we find ourselves laughing all the way to the increasingly inevitable catastrophe does not in any way blur the book's impact, for ours is the laughter of recognition and revelation, rueful and cleansing. All of us who have ever weighed the desperate desire to belong against the coexisting need for self-respect will recognize ourselves in Mr. Boyle's lowly Japanese sailor as well as in his counterprotagonist, the frantically ambitious young writer Ruth Dershowitz, who becomes Hiro Tanaka's protector and, ultimately, his nemesis. That Hiro - the hero - at last does the honorable, albeit doomed, thing, according to his code, and that Ruth, in marked contrast, joyfully sells out after a brief pang of conscience, results in a double catharsis. When it comes to an ending, the reader gets to have it both ways.

title: Question Of the Week;   Do the Mets Have What It Takes to Win It All?

I keep asking myself, how in the world are they over .500?

title: Review/Pop;   Marc Ribot Homogenizes Opposites
description: Mr. Ribot set up full-band riffs that sometimes sounded like rock and other times like funk, only to dissolve them quickly into crystalline trios or duos, with his guitar and Mr. Byron's clarinet running through a composed line. Though there was a fair amount of soloing - Mr. Ribot is a decent guitarist who breaks his lines up with big intervallic jumps - the improvisations were always less important than the group interplay, and the overall texture of the music blurred the distinction between the foreground of the soloist and the background of the rhythm section. Occasionally Mr. Ribot sang or talked - he talked through an ironic, jokey version of Jimi Hendrix's ''Wind Cried Mary'' - and like the sampled noises coming from Mr. Coleman's keyboards, or the toy xylophone and whistles Mr. Byron played, his voice was just another sound added to the thick mix of the group. By the end of the set, ideas that had seemed contradictory had made peace with each other.

title: A Festival Celebrating Poetry
description: Ms. Oates is a professor of humanities at Princeton University, and Ms. Clifton is a professor of literature and creative writing at the University of California in Santa Cruz. Both are award-winning authors of prose as well as poetic works.

title: Goodbye Again, Dark Love
description: This precarious contingency is at the heart of ''Amongst Women,'' John McGahern's fictional study of a patriarch and his children on the family farm in the Irish countryside. Autocratic, embittered and volatile, Michael Moran inspires both reverence and dread in his family. His five children gauge his mood as if it were the weather, scattering for cover when he storms, emerging gratefully when he subsides and all the while plotting how to wriggle free - through work, love or scholarship - from his smothering embrace. The novel, which surveys two decades in the life of the Morans, takes up the effect of their escapes on a man who thinks of his family as a ''larger version of himself.''

title: Review/Opera;   'Street Scene,' Kurt Weill's Personal American Dream
description: The New York City Opera first staged the work in 1959. The production, last seen in 1979, was revived on Friday evening at the New York State Theater, and despite its age it looked remarkably fresh. Paul Sylbert's single set, a run-down-building facade, suits the work well, as do the period costumes by Marjorie McCown. Jay Lesenger, the stage director, moved the singers around the stage naturally. More crucially, the company has assembled a consistently strong group of singers, and Chris Nance conducted a performance that was lively, polished and flexible. Flexibility is an important requirement for ''Street Scene,'' which is as eclectic a work as Weill composed.

title: The Best-Laid Plans of Architects Are Often Best Seen on Paper

The Cooper-Hewitt is also a participant in an ambitious six-institution series of exhibitions and public programs entitled ''Home: a Place in the World,'' running through this fall. The Bronx Museum of the Arts, the Brooklyn Children's Museum, the Jewish Museum and the Studio Museum in Harlem will all mount exhibitions; the New School and the Cooper-Hewitt will sponsor symposiums.

In an age of sound bites, melodies take too long to develop, while a snappy beat and a brash texture can register instantly. Hits are emerging from the dance floor (or through ''Club MTV,'' the channel's answer to ''American Bandstand''), in part because radio stations are so reluctant to take a chance on a new song. More specifically, each is directed toward expanding, correcting, elaborating and illustrating the thesis Mr. Bailyn first advanced in his extremely influential 1967 book, ''The Ideological Origins of the American Revolution.''

''Our guys have got this under control,'' says Dilenschneider in his deep, rich voice. He is a big man, over six feet tall, with a firm handshake and a little extra muscle around the midsection. His office is rather small and crowded, with wood-paneled walls and not much of a view. The moment he sits down, the phone rings. For Dilenschneider, the phone is his lifeline. He is on it constantly - at airports, in airplanes, in the car. Dilenschneider loves his job - the drama, the intrigue, the power.

But one might not necessarily know any of those things from a visit to the suburb, some 15 miles from London. On another, says the playwright, it's ''about people who fill themselves with the trash of modern life and try to retain a measure of dignity and integrity.'' The play is Mr. Baitz's first New York production since the 1988 ''Film Society,'' which critics remembered for its wit and literacy. ''I tend to write about well-intentioned people whose stances are slowly made unavailable to them,'' says Mr. Baitz, 28, who was born in Los Angeles and spent six years in South Africa. ''We discover our beliefs when tested. A lot of times our passions are so very comfortable. Liberalism is so pleasant and removed. Conservatism is so rigid and removed.''
