description: The idea that Brian Watkins's death had resonated across the country, stirring souls in little towns and great cities, seemed a comfort to those who remembered him today.

title: Marcia Cleveland Weds M.T. Green
description: The bride, who is keeping her name, is a daughter of Carolyn W. Cleveland of Greenwich and Robert W. Cleveland Jr. of Rye, N.Y. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Green of St. Paul and New York.

title: The Great Sturges
description: The tragic element is supplied by the film maker's later life, after he had churned out his best movies and the studios had no more use for him. But even in these passages, as we loiter perilously long on Sturges the broken man and Sturges the broke man, this is still a man who can quip, ''The Nietzschean theory of living dangerously is splendid, but should possibly be modified to 'live dangerously with a small income.' '' The sheer ebullience of the prose provides the happy ending: Sturges, previously the victim of two plodding biographies, finally gets the summing-up he deserves, a masterpiece of wit and dazzling proof of his ability to spin a yarn with one hand while unraveling it with the other.

title: Crisis in Gulf Prompts Red Cross to Issue Call
description: LEAD: THE Westchester chapter of the American Red Cross is responding to the Middle East crisis with a call for additional volunteers to assist military personnel and their families. It will start a support group for the families if there are enough requests.

title: Machine See, Machine Do
description: In ''The Age of Intelligent Machines,'' Mr. Kurzweil valiantly attempts to provide an overview of artificial intelligence - the field devoted to the theory, design and construction of computing machines that think, or at least appear to. He discusses its philosophical, mathematical, psychological and technical roots; the outstanding problems in contemporary research on artificial intelligence; the history and current state of the industry; the impact of artificial intelligence on the arts, and the future of the discipline. The volume is an innovative blend of monograph and anthology, for it includes not only Mr. Kurzweil's own writing but a number of essays by philosophers and researchers in artificial intelligence. This structure would have been more successful, however, if the author had included views divergent from his own alongside those that buttress his position.

title: Nebraska
description: It is well worth a stop. A hospitality office will supply information about a variety of B & B's and tours of the Cather Home.

title: Postings: Advice for Owners;   A Seminar on Defaults
description: Accordingly, the council will hold a seminar Tuesday on what apartment owners can do to minimize the consequences of sponsor defaults.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Baltimore;

Housing Loses to Shopping
description: LEAD: A 19-month struggle between a developer who wants to convert an abandoned dairy complex into a shopping center and nearby residents who want more moderate-income housing in their neighborhood has been decided in the developer's favor by the Baltimore City Council.

title: Queens and Nassau Vie For New F.A.A. Base
description: But once Queens politicians and business leaders learned that the F.A.A., which has 600 employees and an annual payroll of $30 million, was planning to move to Nassau in this time of lagging economy, the turf battle began in earnest.

title: Miss Dillon Weds William Bird Jr.
description: Mrs. Bird, 33 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Gordon Dillon of Gladstone, N.J. A graduate of Vassar College, she is an exhibit designer at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, where her husband is a museum specialist at the National Museum of American History. Her father is of counsel with the law firm of Dillon, Bitar & Luther in Morristown, N.J. Her mother, Dorothy H. Dillon, retired as head of the Kent Place School in Summit, N.J.

title: Sharkey Sparks St. John's Victory
description: Sharkey's first intercollegiate pass was complete for 71 yards and led to one touchdown. His third pass went 22 yards to the same receiver, Anthony Iadevaio, three minutes later for the winning points and St. John's went on to defeat Iona, 21-14, for its 10th straight victory over the Gaels.

title: THE ANNOTATED CALENDAR: CLASSICAL RECORDINGS
description: LEAD: Opera and Vocal BACH. Mass in B minor - The venerable Robert Shaw conducts the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and Chorus and soloists. Telarc, Oct.

title: Scare Tactics
description: Mr. Leavitt deplores the new N.E.A. ''loyalty oath,'' which requires that recipients promise not to produce work that includes ''sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children, or individuals engaged in sex acts . . .''

title: 'Waiting for Armageddon'
description: Many evangelicals and most orthodox Christians have little use for the charts and timetables of end time and do not ''wait'' for Armageddon.

title: Campus Life: Michigan;   Student President Charges an Effort To Stifle Dissent
description: Ms. Van Valey, a junior, criticized the administration for instead inviting a former Michigan student, now enrolled at another university, to address the convocation last Tuesday. The student body president ''has the right to address incoming students,'' she said.

title: Tara Sherman Wed to Anthony Weiss
description: Dr. Sherman, 29 years old, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David H. Sherman of New York. Her husband, 29, is a son of Dr. Elizabeth Weiss of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Dr. Marshall F. Weiss of New York. The bride and bridegroom received their medical degrees from the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, where her father is an assistant clinical professor of obstetrics and gynecology and his father is an assistant professor of surgery.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

New Interest (and New Ideas) in Rentals
description: LEAD: The rental market in Suffolk County is strong, according to some observers, and weak according to others; the latter say there are widespread vacancies with many landlords offering concessions.

title: Lauren Singer and Mason Salit Are Married on L.I.
description: LEAD: Lauren Singer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Singer of Dix Hills, L.I., was married last evening to Mason Salit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Salit of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Mordechai Waxman officiated at the Huntington (L.I.) Hilton. Mrs. Salit, 26 years old, is an associate at the New York law firm of Finkelstein Borah Schwartz Altschuler & Goldstein.

title: Why Is America Failing Its Children
description: LEAD: Frightened children crowd the chaotic, steamy hall outside a Los Angeles courtroom. Some are crying. Others can only muster the energy to whimper. Most are dirty, with sallow skin and dull expressions, and they cling to their mothers' skirts.

title: The Nation;   Opponents Find Judge Souter Is a Hard Choice to Oppose
description: No senators have declared opposition to David H. Souter, whom President Bush picked seven weeks ago to succeed Justice William J. Brennan Jr. The 50-year-old Federal judge from New Hampshire goes before the Judiciary Committee Thursday.

title: Seoul Searching
description: What the author calls ''a revolution of rising expectations'' in the spring of 1987 led within nine months to South Korea's first presidential election. Here Mr. Shapiro reports on the Korea and the Koreans that he found during one socially and politically tumultuous year - from the winter of 1988 through the Olympics in Seoul the following autumn. In a postscript, written just before publication, he confirms what most of us know: South Korea's economy continues to boom, yet a return to totalitarianism now seems likely. But we know little of the South Korean people, whose fate has been shaped by the country's political and social exigencies. It is this information that is the real contribution of Mr. Shapiro's book.

title: Dayna C. Klein Is Wed
description: LEAD: Dayna C. Klein and Andrew Kaplan were married last evening at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y., by Rabbi Jeffrey Summit. Mrs. Kaplan, 27 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Klein of Little Neck, Queens. A cum laude graduate of Tufts University, she is an account executive at Liz Claiborne in New York.

title: PAINFUL DECISIONS
description: What is morally troublesome is not that the life of this individual was prolonged, but that the relevant decisions were made as if, because of illness, an individual's claim on community resources were undebatable. No one who was mentioned in your article seemed to realize that these are community resources and that there are rights and obligations going far beyond the wishes of the patient or her physicians.

title: Fashion;   Casual, for the Car Pool (or Whatever)
description: The clothes are part of Mr. Kors's new lower-priced line, called simply Kors, which is being unveiled in a video directed by David Cameron, a former designer, on Tuesday night at Sticky Mike's Frog Bar in the East Village. The clothes will be available in stores next spring.

title: The Book on Giants-Eagles
description: * Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants on Coach Buddy Ryan of the Eagles:

title: To Our Readers
description: LEAD: Starting next week, the suggested Sunday newsstand price of The Times in New York City, within 75 miles and on all of Long Island will be increased to $1.50 from $1.25. The weekday price, and the Sunday price outside the New York area, will be unchanged.

title: A Modest Proposal: Kill County Government
description: New York has more layers of government than many other states and probably more duplication, too. Connecticut doesn't have county government, it doesn't have an income tax and its residents don't pay the high taxes we do. At the present time, New York State often provides the policy directives but the county has to pay for the programs and the county has to implement state directives. It doesn't make sense.

title: ROMANIA: THE DREAMS CAN COME TRUE AGAIN
description: I left Brasov for the big city of Bucharest, and met a shy, skinny kid named Ilie Nastase. While Nastase was blessed with a talent that God distributes only once every few generations, I was blessed with a decent pair of legs, and a will to work and win. We won our fair share and became national heroes, putting Romania on the map of international tennis in the process.

title: Other Animals Don't Strive to Be Like Us
description: How can there be ''cheating,'' ''infidelity,'' ''philandering,'' ''betrayal,'' and ''cuckolding'' (a term itself transferred from bird behavior to humans) if there is no contract for exclusivity in the first place?

title: Guide for Home Buyers, Sellers and Renters;   Some Caveats on Buying a Town House
description: The drawback is isolation. Some occupants feel unsafe with only a single door between themselves and the street. ''It's a vulnerable situation,'' said David Gross, owner of North American Security on Staten Island.

title: S. K. Vogel Weds Susan Sherrerd
description: The bride, who is keeping her name, is 26 years old and a cum laude graduate of Princeton University. She is an associate in the venture capital firm of Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco. Her father is a founding partner in Miller, Anderson & Sherrerd, investment counselors in Philadelphia.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   Some Familiar Places With Unfamiliar Faces
description: Among starters on the Sunday menu are duck and pistachio terrine with pickled vegetables and lettuce; barbecued shrimp salad with a citrus vinaigrette and a corn-poblano-tomatillo relish; and a salad of pan-roasted quail, asparagus and roasted new potatoes with aioli.

title: Rich in Japan
description: Mr. Hamabata disconcerts people. His efforts at Japanese do not win him praise, as they would any foreigner with a non-Japanese face. The executives he hopes to interview - and even cabdrivers, for that matter - find his solecisms irritating, his ignorance of both spoken and physical decorum embarrassing. Mr. Hamabata, a sociologist and the dean of Haverford College in Pennsylvania, soon learns that the easiest way to get ''inside'' Japan is to exaggerate his status as an outsider - to speak English even after he has mastered Japanese and to pretend a boyish sexual innocence so as to pose no imagined threat to the wives and daughters of his potential informants.

title: Goodbye, You Rotten Place
description: Because Mr. Klitgaard is so likable, it is easy to excuse him, I suppose, for so often being the hero of his own stories - he appears to be the only foreign expert in the capital city of Malabo who is not disillusioned, lazy or ineffective - and to forgive him for repeating the praise lavished on him by various Equatorial Guineans. ''You are the first adviser who wants to teach us,'' says one. ''This is very rare here,'' says the President. ''Many advisers are happy just to sit back and relax. But you are trying to help us. . . . This makes me very pleased.'' Remember, however, this is a small country, so Mr. Klitgaard probably was the best white man in Malabo. There certainly appears to have been little competition for the title.

title: INSIDE
description: Several tell their stories. Page 36.

title: Texas Surges Past Penn State
description: The Longhorns scored 10 points in the third quarter and then squelched a last-second pass in the end zone to emerge with a 17-13 victory today before 85,973.

title: Guide for Home Buyers, Sellers and Renters;   An American Verity: Long-Term Ownership Pays
description: In the go-go years of the 80's, however, it was the speculative motive that drove many purchasers. They were willing to pay high prices because they were gambling with their own shelter.

title: JUNK MAIL'S TOP DOGS
description: LEAD: Junk mail's top dogs have the right to send me anything they want to, just as I have the right to throw it away. But every time I toss out unopened, unsolicited junk mail, it angers me that direct-mail advertisers are not required to print their ads on recycled paper. How many landfills do "62.78 billion pieces of third-class mail" fill up every year?

title: Drinking in the View
description: Using elevator logic, begin low and ascend gradually. Top of the Tower, in the Beekman Hotel, just east of First Avenue at 49th Street, sits 26 stories above the sidewalk, a middling height by Manhattan standards, but just about right for this 1920's neighborhood. The window seating runs almost all the way around the building, so you can look east over the posh old apartment buildings of Sutton Place, across the East River and Roosevelt Island, to the new blue-green Citicorp tower in Queens. To the west lies midtown's tight phalanx of glossy office towers, dominated by the oxblood ovoid of Philip Johnson's ''lipstick'' building. The view south is boring - First Avenue running straight as an arrow downtown - but the north view includes the Queensboro Bridge, beloved of F. Scott Fitzgerald, the direct route to tea dances at the Plaza Hotel during the Jazz Age.

title: The Hospital Is Full - the Doctor Is Alone
description: The miracle of ''Other Women's Children'' is that, given all her apparent perfection, Amelia Stern is a first-class fictional creation, complex and three-dimensional. As readers, we take seriously her dissatisfactions and doubts; we care about the outcome of her psychological struggles. And struggle she surely does, for at the core of this book is a profound question of integration: how does an individual who is expected to play more than one role balance the clashes and inconsistencies of those roles, their paradoxes, and still remain intact?

title: John W. O'Beirne, Former F.B.I. Official, 72
description: He was 72 years old and lived in Silver Spring, Md. His family said he died after a heart attack.

title: S. Mississippi Tops Alabama
description: Tennessee 40, Miss. State 7

title: Lifestyle;   Nowadays, Man's (Yes, Man's) Best Friend Is Likely to Be a Cat (or a Houseful of Cats)
description: Man's Best Friend

title: Hong Kong Increases Emigration Estimate
description: Mr. Rowse said he expected emigration figures to level off at about 60,000 a year for the next two years, but would not project beyond that period. A business consultant who tracks trends here said that if the numbers level off, it would be because the number of people qualified to emigrate had dwindled or because other countries had tightened their quotas. ''Basically, everyone here who can go, will go,'' he said.

title: Opening Night: Fashion;   MY FAIR LADIES
description: And for some folks, any kind of dressing up makes them downright cranky. Kyra Sedgwick sees the whole thing as a big nightmare. ''Maybe for the next premiere I'll wear nothing at all,'' she says. Sedgwick, whose new movie, ''Mr. and Mrs. Bridge,'' opens this fall, concedes that opening night is the ''most glamorous part of making a movie - but it's also the most false. Everyone has a great time until about 11, which is when they begin to doubt the hoopla and slink home to a couple of Valiums.''

title: With Guns Blazing, the Movies Get Ready For a Fresh Season of Crime
description: Two criminal works will show up in the New York Film Festival this month shortly before starting their commercial runs: Joel and Ethan Coen's ''Miller's Crossing,'' a 1929 gangster story starring Gabriel Byrne and Albert Finney as rivals for one woman; and ''King of New York,'' with Christopher Walken as a crime boss just released from prison who spreads his drug money among the poor.

title: To Tour Rome For 60 Cents, Take the Bus
description: But for tourists arriving in Rome, traveling by city bus is surely the most economic and comprehensive way to view the city. For a fraction of what a tour bus, private limousine or taxi would cost, a person can travel from one end of a bus line to the other. Besides, Rome is not really a taxi city yet: cabs are few and far between, overly expensive and can't be flagged down on just any street corner, but only at designated taxi stands.

title: JUNK MAIL'S TOP DOGS
description: The letter was far too engaging and literate to deserve the epithet ''junk mail.'' My congratulatory note to the group's president on the quality of his mailing was forwarded to its creator - who turned out to be Bill Jayme. It was a nice tribute to my hypercritical judgment to learn that the rare letter I admired so much had been written by none other than the best in the business.

title: Dana E. Buckley Married on L.I.
description: The bride, a commercial photographer, was presented at the Thanksgiving Eve Ball of the Junior League of New York and at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball in New York. She is a graduate of Tufts University and has a diploma from the Museum School of Fine Arts in Boston. Her first marriage ended in divorce. Her father was an owner and operator of radio stations and head of the Buckley Broadcasting Corporation in New York.The bridegroom is an art dealer. His father, the author of ''Living Well Is the Best Revenge,'' is a staff writer at The New Yorker.

title: PRETTY WOMAN
description: LEAD: "Pretty Woman II" really should be "An Unmarried Woman II." She divorces him for being too patronizing, for promoting the idea of marriage as glorified prostitution - and she takes him for all he's worth.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: However, Alburt's nerves brought on errors in the late stages of the game that would have given his opponent a way to avoid defeat, had it not been for De Firmian's counterbalancing blunders under time pressure.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Gee, Mom, What Were the 60's Like?
description: There were lots of tie-dyed clothing, peace signs, platform shoes and crazy sunglasses. (On the whole, this was a group not all that accustomed to broad daylight.) Bewigged residents of the neighborhood came out in full regalia to watch bewigged nightclub performers in full regalia spoof the 60's. The karma was dynamite. In addition to the hippie-style outfits, there were also in evidence Pucci prints and flowery baby-doll dresses. Both are hits from the 60's that are enjoying an early 90's revival.

description: The wrong way is for the sellers to take the price a neighbor got for a similar home two or three years ago and then rachet it up to reflect their sense of the more attractive qualities of their own home. The market has turned decisively in the Northeast, prompting Edwin Haflich, an appraiser in Trumbull, Conn., who works principally for lenders, to offer this advice:

title: Nouveau Right Winger
description: The way Mr. Leavitt uses labels and language implies that he believes that such usage makes them truth. In short, his article reminds one of Jesse Helms. I have no way of knowing whether my notions of sexual behavior are ''correct,'' but apparently if they are not open and receptive to the likes of Robert Mapplethorpe or Holly Hughes's challenges to sexual behavior, I am a ''right winger.'' From Mr. Leavitt's tone, I assume this is not a good thing to be.

title: ALEPPO'S ALLURE
description: Turmoil in nearby Lebanon and a reputation as an 'outlaw state' have effectively kept Americans away. But I found Syria to be a safe and fascinating country . . . with numerous, dazzling sights.'' The implication is that Syria has been unjustly criticized and that we should visit the country, particularly Aleppo.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Camera makers began to elaborate on the basic point-and-shoot, adding first telephoto lenses and then zoom lenses. Little buttons began appearing on the sides and tops of the cameras, and the bodies began to bulk up, so that they no longer fit in anyone's pocket. Features like fill-in flash, sequential shooting and auto zooming for portraits were like icing on the cake.

title: Susan Kaiser Wed To Seth Greenland
description: She is a graduate of Kalamazoo College and Brooklyn Law School. Her father is a consulting engineer. Her mother, Bette Kaiser, is a retired teacher.

title: Corrections
description: LEAD: A map accompanying an article on Aug. 26 about radioactive waste included an incorrectly placed symbol for the Tatum Dome atomic test site.

title: PRETTY WOMAN
description: LEAD: Daphne Merkin is entitled, I suppose, to her retro fantasy about the prostitute and her rich john in the film "Pretty Woman" (Hers: "Prince Charming Comes Back," July 15). I prefer one about a neurosurgeon who graduates at the top of her class and defies conventional wisdom to pursue research that earns her a Nobel Prize and saves the lives of thousands, all the while finding sexual fulfillment with a contented Czech body builder.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: BIG TIME. By Marcel Montecino. (Morrow, $19.95.) As Marcel Montecino's second novel begins, Sal D'Amore, 38-year-old barroom crooner and gambler-not-so-anonymous, is imagining the slow, gruesome death that awaits him. After all, he has crossed the bullies of the New Orleans mob, to whom he owes almost $200,000.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: The archives offer an extraordinarily detailed look at how a stamp is made, from initial artist's sketch, through models and color tests, to the production of master engravings and finished proofs. There are also original letters between American Bank Note and postal officials regarding designs and printing techniques.

title: 'Sloop John B' Joins Forces With French Challenger
description: First Boat in Water

description: Mr. Watkins and his wife, Patti, paid ''in the mid-200's'' for his family's new home, a four-bedroom colonial in Northport. It has a large yard and a bedroom for each of their three children.

title: Old Gold and Even Older Antiquities Shed Light on Ancient Cultures
description: ''Gold of Greece: Jewelry and Ornaments From the Benaki Museum'' (at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, Tuesday to Jan. 13, 1991) will show the evolution of the goldsmith's skills in 200 objects from Mycenae to post-Byzantine Greece.

title: Hussein's Summit Message: Gulf Crisis Is an Arab Issue
description: Instead, he demanded that the Persian Gulf crisis be settled along lines he put forward on Aug. 12.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

Long Islander in the Bay of Bengal
description: LEAD: THE JOURNEY. By Indira Ganesan. (Knopf, $18.95.) Indira Ganesan's first novel is a symphony for the senses. Its pages teem with unforgettable images, rendered in clean, economical prose: Kali-worshipers with unkempt hair and necklaces of skulls; white teeth biting into purple sugar cane; the ghost of a madwoman who had ''seen the horror of life and couldn't stop screaming.

title: Joys of a New Team
description: All the Mount St. Joseph graduates are women. The former all-women's school, which admitted men for the first time three years ago, is fielding its first football team this season and the 62-year-old Pont is relishing his role in a new element.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Changing Our Driving Habits
description: LEAD: WE love our cars, care for them, dream about them, spend money on them. But this vehicular love affair is clogging our roads, smogging our air and driving us headlong into the tragedy of global warming. The time has come, in fact is long overdue, for us to start thinking about the way we drive.

title: ONE TRIAL SOUGHT FOR 12 DEFENDANTS

description: At Dollar Rent-a-Car, a subcompact for one week begining next Wednesday at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago was $129 with 21-day advance booking, but $140 with a 7-day advance booking.

Dr. Vasa, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Vasa of New York, graduated from Columbia University and its School of Optometry. He was a widower. He retired as chief of the optometry section in the Office of the Navy Surgeon General in Washington.

title: Sectarian Schools Gain Most From Choice Plan;   Direction Is Needed
description: Giving principals, teachers and parents greater involvement in local decision making is a key to any effective school. That involvement for parents should include choice. Choice should stimulate competition, encourage and foster interest, provide quality education and not cause schools to be viewed as inferior. In Yonkers, choice stimulates competition to provide the best education programs for children in 30 magnet schools.

A desperate Carr grabbed a blank Boston Celtic contract and signed Siverson for $1,000,000. On the bottom of the document he inserted a heartbreaking stipulation: Not Valid Under Law.

title: INSIDE

title: Books Star on TV, but Only in France
description: The extraordinary success of the show, one of the most watched on French television, was based on an extremely simple formula: Mr. Pivot, a genial journalist with a love of books and Beaujolais, is host of a 90-minute discussion with a handful of authors about their books.

title: Miss Jones Is Wed To P.J. MacGuire

title: Chronicle

title: 'Stay Intense but Not Overdo It'
description: But as the Giants-Eagles game began, even Lawrence Taylor was wondering if he could escape the usual curse of a long pro football holdout: vulnerability to certain injuries, notably a pulled hamstring muscle, in trying to do too much too soon. And others were wondering why George Young, the Giants' general manager, has developed a dangerous tradition of letting contract disputes linger, often to the detriment of the players involved. Two years ago, Carl Banks, the Giants' other outside linebacker, finally signed the Wednesday before the opener.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Sindelar Prevails in Playoff: Joey Sindelar parred the first playoff hole Sunday to defeat Willie Wood at the Hardee's Golf Classic in Coal Valley, Ill. After both golfers hit their second shots into the rough on the par-4 16th, Sindelar chipped within a foot of the cup while Wood's shot flew six feet past. Wood missed his attempt for par before Sindelar holed the short putt for the victory.

title: Reports of Hartford's Death Are Exaggerated
description: There is no question that Hartford, like most of urban America, faces serious problems. These are exacerbated by economic downturn in the nation and New England in particular. Long-term trends are at work, such as the suburban mall phenomenon, but also near-term cyclical forces and revivifying dynamics help us. For example, although six downtown restaurants closed in the last year, eight new restaurants opened. And Hartford's renowned cultural life, ranging from jazz to art and theater, is as inviting as ever.

title: Shoulder to Shoulder Against Iraq
description: Some may be tempted to make too much of the differences that remain between Washington and Moscow. But they pale in significance against the remarkable common ground the two leaders have now reached. Not since 1945 have the United States and Soviet Union stood so close in a regional dispute. And not since the early days of the cold war has a U.S. President indicated readiness to provide economic aid to the Soviet Union.

title: Tokyo Stocks Up; Dollar Off
description: But despite mild bullishness on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, investors remain cautious, the brokers said. ''I don't think anybody really believes the market is posting lasting gains,' said Philip Gordon-Lennox, the fund manager at the Nippon Credit Bank.

title: Islanders Spilling Their Own Blood

Coach Al Arbour also said the high stick was accidental. Dalgarno disagreed today. ''It was a pretty brutal swing; it was totally ridiculous,'' he said, the words hissing slightly through his clinched jaw. ''It was on purpose. It wasn't an accident.''

title: Candidate Owing Back Taxes Won't Quit Race

title: To Chinese These Days, 'Comrade' Is Gauche
description: The decline of ''comrade'' and the return of ''Miss'' is but one of the ways that ordinary Chinese are shedding the revolutionary trappings of the last four decades. While the airwaves mount a propaganda blitz for Communist values, people are each day moving more in the other direction: wearing more cosmetics and shorter skirts, studying more English, trying ever more frantically to go to the West -and, perhaps most basic of all, reverting to pre-Communist era ways of speaking and writing the Chinese language.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST

title: Review/Music;   Japanese Tale of Longing
description: All of this has been turned into prose by Makoto Ooka, a poet, and set to music by Maki Ishii. The entire project was inspired by Michiko Akao, who is a virtuoso on the varied forms of the yokobue, or Japanese transverse flute, and was recited by Kayoko Shiraishi, a well-known actress. Yasunori Yamaguchi played elaborate onstage percussion; Akio Jissoji was the director, and the lavish lighting, sets and costumes were by Sumio Yoshii, Hiroshi Tomi and Takayuki Mori, respectively. The trouble for a Western viewer was that Mr. Ooka provided lots of text, and apart from projected synopses before each scene (which duplicated material in the program), there was no semi-simultaneous translation by supertitles. Thus despite Miss Shiraishi's seemingly powerful oratory, what she was saying remained mostly stylized vocal grimaces in the traditional Japanese manner, devoid of denotative meaning.

title: 5 Digits Were Not the Rule at First

title: New York Joins Mobil Schedule

The 1991 Grand Prix schedule, with 19 meets, was approved over the weekend at Athens with a meet in Monte Carlo being added as well as New York. Lebow said the New York Games would probably be switched from Columbia's Wien Stadium to Randalls Island, where the 1991 national championships would also be held, later in the summer.

UPSA, whose value has not been disclosed, employs 1,500 people and had 1989 sales of 1.25 billion francs (about $238 million). It owns distribution companies in Italy, Spain and Portugal. UPSA stands for Union Pharmacologique Scientifique Appliquee.

title: Review/Television;   How the Iraqis Built Their Arsenal
description: The details, in the unpolished version of the program that was available for previewing, are not as clear and direct as the best ''Frontline'' reports, and the hour has its awkward spots. The evidence about shadowy companies getting around export restrictions is suggestive, but it is easy to lose track of who was producing what. No doubt the finished work will be smoother. Even if some of the details remain fuzzy, however, it is plain enough that millions of dollars have been made by Western businessmen willing not to inquire too closely into the uses to which their products were being put and that their Governments did not discourage them. Much of the second half of the program is given to the operations of an arms dealer who is now under indictment in the United States for his services as middleman between the Iraqi military and American suppliers of helicopters, uniforms and other items. He maintains that his operations were ''cleared 100 percent'' by the State Department and the White House. Associated with him in one deal, according to documents cited here, were Richard M. Nixon, Spiro T. Agnew and John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, after they left office. They apparently helped obtain Romanian-made uniforms for the Iraqis, who had expected American-made uniforms. You can't trust anybody.

title: A Printer Sidesteps A Choice
description: Hewlett-Packard, the leading maker of laser printers, is counting on the HP Deskjet 500 to win the hearts of PC users who want laser-like print quality on a dot-matrix budget. It cannot match a laser on overall print quality, speed or flexibility, but it is certainly an attractive alternative to dot-matrix printers.

title: In 10 State Primaries, Candidates Scurry Not to Look Like Politicians
description: Primaries in 10 States

title: People
description: LEAD: * Robert G. Kirkpatrick, a media director at the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, has been named senior vice president.

title: Corrections
description: LEAD: A news analysis article on Saturday about Mayor David N. Dinkins's responses to recent crimes misstated his margin of victory over Edward I. Koch in the Democratic primary last year. It was 9 percentage points, not 12.

title: The 1990 U.S. Open Provided Everything but a Predicted Outcome
description: Unassuming Teen-Ager

title: Baumgartner Re-signed
description: Terms were not announced. Baumgartner, 24, joined the Islanders, along with Hubie McDonough, from the Los Angeles Kings in exchange for Mikko Makela last November. He appeared in 53 games for the Islanders with no goals, 5 assists and 194 penalty minutes.

title: Junior Partner No More, Gorbachev Raises Role to Major Player in Crisis
description: By all indications, his desire was to tie the Soviets more tightly into the international consensus, to send to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq the picture of a solid front, not to open a new one.

title: Review/Television;   An Unlikely Friendship In an Unfriendly South
description: Set in rural Georgia, where it was filmed, ''Sudie and Simpson'' is based on a 1986 novel, loosely autobiographical, by Sara Flanigan. The teleplay was written by Ms. Flanigan and Ken Koser. The time is 1943. Most of the young men in a town called Linlow are off fighting in World War II. Public signs warn: ''Nigger, don't let the sun set on you.'' Sudie Harrigan (Sara Gilbert) never did pay any attention to the signs. Sudie, a feisty 12-year-old, has never even seen a black person. Then she meets Simpson (Louis Gossett Jr.).

title: Pension Shift by McDonnell
description: By buying the contract with Metropolitan, McDonnell was able to realize a portion of the plan's market value beyond its pension obligations, a McDonnell spokeswoman, Barbara Anderson, said. McDonnell did not have to terminate the plan, and benefits to retirees will continue unchanged, she said.

title: English Military Site Bombed
description: No one was seriously wounded in the explosion, the police said. A woman was taken to a hospital suffering from shock. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but suspicion fell on the Irish Republican Army, which has attacked at least seven military establishments in England this year.

title: Eiland's Effort Is Wasted
description: Eiland, one of nine rookies called up Sunday from the Yankees' Columbus affiliate, pitched eight and one-third shutout innings but left without getting a decision. It was decided in the 11th inning when Rafael Palmeiro singled off Lee Guetterman to give the Texas Rangers a 1-0 victory that sent the Yankees to their fifth consecutive loss and 10th in 11 games.

title: Swiss Set Bank Curbs
description: There was no immediate reaction from the banks, although the industry had previously said it would appeal such a decision to the supreme court.

title: To Lure Better Teachers, New York City Must Offer Better Pay;   How About Dignity?
description: I am entering my third year of teaching. Last year, four days into the teaching year, I was informed that I no longer had a job because of a union policy that a more senior teacher could bump me out of a position. And never mind that both my supervisor and the principal wanted me to stay; the union rules appear to be written in stone.

title: Constable's 'Lock' to Be Auctioned
description: Morrison bought the painting on the first day it was exhibited in 1824 at the Royal Academy for about $740. Sotheby's estimates that it will sell for $18 million to $28 million.

title: Metro Datelines;   No Foul Play Seen In Death of Student
description: An autopsy was performed yesterday at the state medical examiner's office in Farmington. The office could not immediately establish a cause of death, saying it would have to await the results of laboratory tests.

title: Fernandez Urges Higher Teacher Salaries
description: ''We're almost down at the bottom,'' he said while visiting almost a dozen classes yesterday at three schools -two in Queens and one in Brooklyn. ''In terms of a contract, if we want to attract the best teachers, we have to be competitive with these other districts.''

title: Award Granted In Film Suit
description: Oliver Heard Jr., a lawyer representing Pheasantry Films Inc., said the court had granted the default judgment because Virgin Vision violated disclosure rules by refusing to allow its books to be examined.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Crews Continue Work on Shuttle
description: A module containing three recirculation pumps was removed from the Columbia's aft compartment on Sunday. Tests on the new set are expected to begin early Tuesday.

title: Shakespeare in Tongues He Surely Never Heard
description: Behind this production of ''Romeo and Juliet,'' which includes music and dance, there is a story of the company itself and the 72 men and women who have come from rural Mexico to perform it. The two leads, in fact, are a Maya-Mayo intermarriage that has not run into the family snags encountered by their role models from Verona.

title: Deals
description: Houston assigned LaRose to Tucson of the Pacific Coast League and Davis to Asheville of the South Atlantic League.

title: Revitalized Chiquita Seeks Growth
description: The company earned $67.7 million, or $1.67 a share, on sales of $3.8 billion in 1989. In the process, it sold 13 billion bananas, about a third of the world's supply of the fruit. Bananas are by far the world's most popular fruit.

title: Corrections
description: LEAD: A report on Sunday about the wedding of Dawn E. Kesselman and Barry S. Wisset referred to the couple incorrectly. They are known as Mr. and Mrs. Wisset.

title: Chronicle
description: LEAD: "Tune in Tomorrow. . . .," starring PETER FALK and ELIZABETH McGOVERN, was picked as the favorite movie at the 16th annual Festival du Film Americain in Deauville, France. The film, directed by JON AMIEL and based on the novel "Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter" by MARIO VARGAS LLOSA, has not opened in commercial theaters.

title: Heinz Net Rises 13.1%
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 - LEAD: The H. J. Heinz Company's first-quarter earnings increased 13.1 percent because of higher food prices and favorable exchange rates for foreign currency, the food maker said today. Heinz posted earnings of $143.2 million, or 54 cents a share, in the quarter ended Aug. 1, up from $126.6 million, or 48 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1989.

title: Souter No Cardozo
description: When Cardozo, a liberal Democrat, was appointed in 1932 to replace Oliver Wendell Holmes by President Herbert Hoover, a conservative Republican, he was viewed by Democrat and Republican to have the finest legal mind in America. Cardozo had as a judge in New York written four brilliant books on legal and judicial philosophy and scores of opinions that were models for all America. Judge Souter's supporters should eschew hyperbole.

title: Metro Datelines;   Trial Set for Oct. 11 For 2 in Jogger Case
description: Because they were all under the age of 16 when they attacked the woman on the night of April 19, 1989, they will be sentenced as juveniles and thus face a maximum of 5 to 10 years in prison, becoming eligible for parole after five years.

title: FIGHTING BY NIGHT IS ARMY WAR PLAN
description: As General McCaffrey spoke, units under his command prepared for their regular 2 A.M. to 10 A.M. training. They carry out maneuvers using infrared night-vision equipment mounted on M-1 tanks and Bradley fighting vehicles, which are essentially armored personnel carriers equipped with antitank missiles and 25-millimeter guns.

title: Bernard Nadel, 81, An Ex-New York Judge
description: He died of complications of Parkinson's disease, said his son, S. Michael Nadel.

title: Consumer Credit Rose 7.4% in July
description: The July advance was the largest since a 7.8 percent jump in November and approximated the $4.42 billion monthly average of 1988 and 1989.

title: Can Mets Come From Behind?
description: In the crucible of the 162-game season, these Mets won twice as front-runners. But they have never won coming from behind.

title: Corrections
description: LEAD: An art review in the Westchester Weekly on Sept. 2 about the "First Impressions" show at the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, N.Y., misstated the closing date. The show continues through Sept. 23; it does not close this Sunday.

title: Ending Talks, All Cambodia Parties Commit Themselves to U.N. Peace Plan
description: Mr. Alatas, who has been instrumental in over two years of difficult negotiations, beamed as the heads of the four factions held hands for the cameras at the end of a news conference tonight.

title: Don't Put Income Ceiling on Child Care
description: The proposal to phase out dependent-care tax benefits, contained in the House of Representatives version of the child-care bill, would create the only income ceiling on work-related tax benefits. So next April taxpayers at all income levels could deduct exclusive club memberships, luxury business cars and lavish office furnishings, but not the child care that enables them to work.

title: Cuomo Attacks U.S. Priorities
description: Mr. Cuomo contended that the Bush and Reagan Administrations had forced state and local governments to raise taxes by slashing Federal aid to programs aimed at attacking national social problems, like drugs, education and homelessness.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dow Jones & Company, New York, announced several executive appointments. Bernard T. Flanagan was named to the new position of vice president of marketing of Dow Jones; Paul Atkinson to vice president of advertising for The Wall Street Journal; Robert D. Higgins to director of advertising administration for The Wall Street Journal, and James Friedlich to director of international sales and marketing for Dow Jones Publications.

title: Business and Health;   Hospitals Increase Use of Computers
description: ''It is not unusual for a hospital to have 1,000 terminals,'' said Dr. Clement J. McDonald, a professor of medicine at Indiana University and head of medical information science at the Regenstrief Institute, a research foundation in Indianapolis. He added: ''There is already a treasure trove of information sitting around in the hospital. Where it is easy to get at, it is used lovingly.''

title: Rhone-Poulenc Sets Divestitures
description: PARIS, Sept. 10 - LEAD: The French chemicals and pharmaceuticals company Rhone-Poulenc S.A. will continue to divest itself of peripheral assets to help defray the cost of its $2 billion acquisition of Rorer Inc., the company said. Assets sales for all of 1990 could bring between 1 billion and 1.5 billion francs, or about $192 million to $288 million, Rhone-Poulenc's chairman, Jean-Rene Fourtou, said.

title: Judge Souter Has a Record . . .
description: LEAD: David H. Souter, the man nominated by President Bush to replace Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. on the U.S. Supreme Court, has been treated so far as if he just landed from Mars. We have been told he is an ''enigma,'' a ''blank slate,'' a ''pig in a poke'' and the ''Nowhere Man.'' Nonsense.

title: Lockheed Unit Has Japan Air Contract
description: The tentative agreement between Lockheed and the Japanese airline also calls for J.A.L. to invest in Lockheed's newly formed aircraft maintenance operation, Lockheed Commercial Aircraft Center Inc.

title: Johnson Sets a January Date For His Return to Competition
description: Inquiries and Reforms

title: Parole Hearing for Ex-Judge
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 10 - LEAD: Federal parole officers recommended today that Walter L. Nixon, who was stripped of his Federal judgeship last year, be sent back to prison for breaking parole by carrying firearms on a turkey hunt. The recommendation came after Chester Diaz, a state wildlife investigator testified about Mr. Nixon's arrest April 25 on hunting violations.

title: BUSH, REVERSING U.S. POLICY, WON'T OPPOSE A SOVIET ROLE IN MIDDLE EAST PEACE TALKS
description: The first sign of this change was given at the Gorbachev-Bush news conference in Helsinki on Sunday when Mr. Gorbachev said he had a ''secret'' to reveal - that Mr. Bush had confessed that in the past the United States had tried to keep the Soviet Union out of the Middle East but that now he felt that it was important to cooperate. Was Israel Consulted? The officials today called this aspect of the meeting, which was reflected in comments by Mr. Gorbachev and in the two leaders' joint statement, a development that was overshadowed by the two leaders' vow to oppose Baghdad in the immediate crisis and by their apparent divisions over the use of military force.

title: Price of Oil Surges 6% In Minutes
description: Other Markets Affected

title: Brown Chief Has National Ambitions
description: In addition, by merging the office with a well-known agency, Mr. Brown would instantly acquire a bigger reputation for his New York office -a must in New York, which has more than a dozen widely admired small agencies.

title: A Foe to Be Feared: Prince Yormie Johnson
description: Rebel Leaders Split

title: Population Decline in Rural America: A Product of Advances in Technology
description: ''It looks like a ghost town,'' said Bill Gibson, a 74-year-old farmer, whose grandfather broke ground on the family's land with a team of oxen in the middle of the 19th century. ''I sure miss the people.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: The committee meets after this tournament. Muster, the seventh-ranked player in the world, was fined $25,000 and could be suspended for 10 weeks for an incident at a tournament in Prague in August. If Muster is suspended, he will miss the Davis Cup semifinal against the United States at Vienna, Sept. 21-23. In other matches yesterday, Jerome Potier of France was eliminated by Jose-Francisco Altur of Spain, 7-6, 6-2, and Carlos Costa of Spain defeated Jens Wohmann of West Germany, 6-3, 7-5. (AP)

title: 115 Nations Consider A Water Supply Crisis
description: With continuing environmental degradation and pollution, the situation compounds health problems. Water-borne diseases are a major threat to life, especially of children, in many poor lands. These diseases include cholera, gastroenteritis, malaria and other ailments as well as infections carried by insects or other organisms that breed in stagnant ponds.

title: Attack Crime at Root, Dinkins Urges
description: Mr. Dinkins took every opportunity to repair the city's and his own battered images. Both have taken a beating in recent weeks, the city for a rash of high-profile crimes, including the subway death of a Provo, Utah, man in town with his family for the U.S. Open, and Mr. Dinkins for what some say is a slow and overly cautious response.

title: Cuomo's Crime Remedy: 'Produce the Police, Period'
description: But Mr. Cuomo did not address the question of how to pay for more police, a question that has occupied Mayor David N. Dinkins and the New York City Council for weeks. The Governor said he would discuss the issue further in a speech on Tuesday before the Citizens Crime Commission in Manhattan.

title: Round-the-Clock Talks Planned To Avert Closing of New York Post
description: George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, an umbrella group that includes the newspaper's 10 unions, called a news conference to announce that union leaders were essentially satisfied that The Post was hemorrhaging money, though he declined to cite specific figures.

title: Coslet Lauds Jet Effort Despite Loss in Opener
description: O'Brien's offensive statistics, 27 completions in 49 attempts for 300 yards and a pair of touchdown to Al Toon - the third best performance of opening day in terms of yardage - tells how well the Jets' line was clicking in the first three quarters. The four sacks (safety included) and the lone interception of O'Brien all came in the fourth quarter when the line broke down.

title: Howard Beach: The Third Trial Opens Quietly
description: This is the second trial in this case for the three defendants, who are accused of being part of a group of whites that set upon three black men who had entered the mostly white community in southern Queens, severely beating one and chasing another, who ran out onto a highway where he was killed.

title: Ms. O'Keefe Wed To Brian O'Neill
description: The bride, 22 years old, is keeping her name. She was presented at the Thanksgiving Eve Ball of the Junior League of New York. A graduate of the New School for Social Research, she is studying for a master's degree in education at New York University. Her stepfather is the Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Canadian Affairs. Her mother, Pia Pines, is an early-childhood teacher in the New York City school system.

title: Seeq Technology
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 - LEAD: Seeq Technology Inc., a semiconductor company, said it would stop manufacturing its own computer chips and would instead have them manufactured by other companies. The move will mean the dismissal of about 95 workers, about a fifth of the company's work force, and a one-time charge of $8 million to $10 million in the fourth quarter, which ends this month.

title: Jane Mapes, 73, Dies; A Marketing Executive
description: A spokesman for the family said that the death was listed as a suicide. She had been ill for some time with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease.

title: Shift at Ford Jersey Plant
description: EDISON, N.J., Sept. 10 - LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had begun making trucks at its Edison, N.J., plant, where cars were assembled for more than 40 years. The plant began producing a light truck, the Ranger, after a three-month retooling, which cost nearly $300 million. The factory is the ninth Ford plant in North America that is building light trucks.

title: Gene for Key Brain Protein Isolated
description: Isolation of Receptor

title: School Opens And Teacher And Students Find Rapport
description: A Time for Ribbons

title: New York Can Be Made to Work
description: The workforce has grown by more than 50,000 people in the last 10 years. In the same period, labor contracts have grown generously, both in compensation and benefits. This is not the profile of a city without means, even though the needs to be met are also considerable.

title: Liberian Insurgents Kill President, Diplomats and Broadcasts Report
description: It is unclear whether the President died from gunshot wounds suffered during his capture or whether he was killed after arriving at rebel headquarters. President Doe was reportedly seen being interrogated by Mr. Johnson shortly before his death.

title: TV News: Children's Scary Window on New York
description: Disquieting Questions

title: New York Says Konnichi Wa to a Hit Salsa Band
description: ''I learned how to sing off records by Celia Cruz or El Gran Combo or Willie Colon,'' said the group's lead singer, who goes by the name Nora. ''Our producer helped me with pronunciation. When I write songs, they're at a kindergarten level. I don't understand most of the words, but I'm getting better. Now we have a Japanese translation on the C.D. of our first record, but before that, nobody in the band knew the words!''

title:
MEDICAL SCIENCE;

Studies Find a Link Between Aggressiveness and Cholesterol Levels
description: LEAD: SCIENTISTS have found in recent animal and human studies that lowering cholesterol may be associated with higher levels of aggressiveness and an increased risk of mortality from accidents and suicide.

title: Grandmother, 77, Is Imprisoned In Rhode Island Custody Dispute
description: Judge Pfeiffer, who had given Mrs. Pigeon until today to tell him where her daughter, Elaine Yates, and the girls were hiding, said Mrs. Pigeon would remain in prison until she gave him the information.

title: Trade Violations Are Called Too Small to Prop Up Iraq
description: ''The first point is that we've shut off the ocean routes,'' said a Bush Administration official who is following the crisis. ''That's the key to the embargo's overall effectiveness. And one reason we've been so effective is that people know what will happen to their ships if they go into that area.''

title: Careers;   Measuring The Quality Of a Company
description: Although created by Congress, the program is financed primarily by the private sector, said Dr. Curt W. Reimann, who manages the program for the National Institute of Standards and Technology in Gaithersburg, Md. Large companies pay $2,500 to apply; small companies with fewer than 500 employees pay $1,000.

title: Romania Seeks Lines of Credit
description: Although Romania became the first Eastern European member of the I.M.F. in 1972, its former ruler, Nicolae Ceausescu, had wanted to take the country out of the agency in the last years of his rule.

title: G.E. Capital Prices $250 Million Issue
description: The three-year notes were won by Bear, Stearns & Company and have an 8.45 percent coupon. Reoffered to the publc at a price of 99.922, the notes yield 8.48 percent, or about 32 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one one-hundredth of a percentage point.

title: G.M. in New Moves To Halt Slide of Olds
description: Division Needs a 'Rationale'

title: 68% in Poll See Drop In the Quality of Life
description: Twenty-three percent said they believed living in the city had not changed.

title: Mickey Mouse Program
description: This first drawing is done in cel 1, named after the sheets of celluloid on which the frames of the classic movie animated cartoons were drawn.

title: Amendment Ratified
description: LEAD: Representatives of the National Basketball Association's players' union yesterday ratified an amendment to the collective bargaining agreement that may limit free agency by lowering the salary cap.

title: Treasury Issues Fall in Slow Day
description: ''I don't think oil is the most germane issue at the moment,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. ''The budget is the key to what the Fed will or won't do. And if we don't get a budget agreement in the next 24 hours, my feeling is they won't have one until the end of the month, when sequestration will push them into it.''

title: Hearns to Fight Benn
description: LEAD: Nigel Benn of Britain, the World Boxing Organization middleweight champion, will fight Thomas Hearns, the W.B.O. super-middleweight title holder, in Atlantic City on Jan. 4, Benn's agent, Ambrose Mendy, said yesterday. It has yet to be decided which title will be at stake. (Reuters) SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING

title: Privatization In Hungary
description: As much as 90 percent of production now comes from state-owned enterprises.

title: Books of The Times;   The Human Behind the Heroic Pose
description: With his last book, ''Love in the Time of Cholera,'' Mr. Garcia Marquez took a step away from the hallucinatory methods of those previous books to tell an old-fashioned love story grounded in the day-to-day facts of domestic life. It was a move toward the ordinary and the realistic that is taken even further in his latest novel, ''The General in His Labyrinth,'' an improvisation on the life and times of the Latin American revolutionary Simon Bolivar that turns a mythic hero into a fallible human being.

title: Texas Instruments Is Sued by Tandy
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 - LEAD: The Tandy Corporation and its subsidiary, Grid Systems Corporation, have filed an antitrust lawsuit against Texas Instruments Inc. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in San Francisco, accuses Texas Instruments of forcing personal computer manufacturers like Tandy and Grid to make excessive license payments for invalid patents.

title: 3 Ways to See Housebuster Run
description: Now, though, the colt's career is at a crossroads. Most of his victories have been in Grade II and Grade III sprints restricted to 3-year-olds, and it is time for him to take on the nation's best horses.

title: Visitors' Stories Flow on Ellis Island
description: Family-History Day

title: The U.N.'s Biggest Deadbeat
description: The figures are an embarrassment. The United States currently owes $520 million in regular assessments plus $150 million for special peacekeeping costs. Other members in default on regular dues are South Africa ($40 million), Brazil ($17 million), Iran ($12 million), Argentina ($10 million) and Libya ($5 million).

title: I.B.M. Outlook On Revenues
description: I.B.M. introduced a line of mainframe computers last week, and analysts said the success of the new line was crucial to the future of I.B.M., which has long maintained a stranglehold on the high end of the computer market.

title: Coach Recommended
description: LEAD: Theresa Grentz, who has coached the Rutgers women's team for the past 14 seasons, was recommended yesterday by the Women's Games Committee to serve as coach of the United States women's basketball team at the 1992 Olympic Games in Barcelona, Spain.

title: Roger (Doc) Cramer; Baseball Player, 85
description: An outfielder who played from 1929 to 1948, Mr. Cramer had a .296 career batting average. He was a standout defensive player with the Philadelphia Athletics, the Boston Red Sox, the Washington Senators and the Detroit Tigers. In 1940, he led the American League in hits with 200 while playing for the Red Sox.

title: ECONOMIC REFORM: A KREMLIN INTRIGUE
description: Calls for Ryzhkov's Ouster

title: Patterns
description: ''I couldn't believe how sweet he was and how much he knows about clothing,'' said Mr. Versace, who pointed out that Mr. Tyson knows a thing or two about Versace women's wear from all the models he has dated. Mr. Tyson, a fan, had suggested lunch. ''It's nice to know men who like and understand fashion,'' Mr. Versace added.

title: Cities Begin Taking Action on Environment
description: With a loan from the Interamerican Development Bank, Mayor Camacho reported, Mexico will be able to reduce its foreign debt by $150 million and use the money to plant trees on some 150,000 acres of now barren Federal lands around the city.

title: Hearst Reported to Seek Nabisco's 20% of ESPN
description: ESPN has been one of Capital Cities/ABC's most profitable holdings.

title: Pirates Win, 3-2, on Sacrifice Fly in 9th
description: Bonilla then hit his sacrifice fly to Von Hayes in left field and Backman easily beat the throw to the plate.

title: U.S. Regulators Assert Right to Curb Neil Bush
description: The Office of Thrift Supervision, which oversees savings and loan institutions, said today that to justify a cease and desist order, ''all that is necessary is that he was a director of an insured institution at the time he committed his wrongful acts.''

title: Bush & Gorbachev Inc.
description: Conveying to Saddam Hussein the message that Moscow was standing with Washington and the rest of the world was meaningful in itself, of course; the chances of persuading him to pull out of Kuwait depend to a considerable degree on penetrating the Iraqi dictator's tough psychological carapace and making him feel increasingly shunned, cornered, friendless.

title: Corrections
description: LEAD: A listing of candidates yesterday for the local primary elections today omitted one of three Democrats running for Civil Court judge in the Ninth District in Manhattan. He is Eugene F. Prosnitz; his opponents are Anthony J. Fiorella Jr. and Dianne Shapiro Gasworth.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: Trade violations are called too small to prop up Iraq A17

title: Saudis Gave U.S. Help In Mozambique War
description: King Fahd, at the behest of William Casey at the Central Intelligence Agency, sponsored the guerrillas of the Mozambican National Resistance (Renamo). Besides financial support, supplies have been flown from Saudi Arabia to the Comoro Islands, to be transshipped and funneled into northern Mozambique.

title: HOCKEY: Reporters' Notebook;   Rangers Look at Acquiring Brown
description: Maybe not entirely, however. The Rangers, looking to add toughness to their lineup, have inquired about acquiring Brown, who since the attack has been vilified by the Garden crowd at his every appearance. Brown, a member of the Flyers when he leveled Sandstrom, is unhappy in Edmonton wants to be traded.

title: Investor Increases Stake in Henley
description: He has received clearance from Federal antitrust regulators to increase his holdings in the Hampton, N.H., manufacturing concern to more than 15 percent.

title: Probing School Success Of Asian-Americans
description: Part of that success, the new research suggests, is explained by the fact that Asian-American students, far more than members of other minorities, see earning advanced degrees as the only sure-fire way to overcome discrimination. That perception operates hand in hand with strong family bonds to make Asian-American students work harder at their studies, doing almost 50 percent more homework than their peers from grammar school on.

title: Lawsuits Can Chill Drug Research
description: When I was 3, I was given penicillin - then the new wonder drug - for an infection. I had a severe allergic reaction to the penicillin and almost died. I suppose my family and others whom penicillin killed or almost killed could have sued the manufacturer, and with any luck, this dangerous drug would have been taken off the market. The result would have been a small number of lives saved, the end of antibiotic research and the return of deaths from scarlet fever, pneumonia and rheumatic fever.

title: Cuts Planned At Nordstrom
description: ''The company is looking to decrease expenses across the board nationwide, but it will be up to each individual store manager where the percentage of cuts comes from,'' he said. ''In some cases, some employees will be affected, then again they may not.''

title: Giants Emphasize Backs' Quickness
description: On Sunday night, in the season opener, Hampton and Meggett scored on big plays to help the Giants beat their nemesis, the Philadelphia Eagles, 27-20. After the Giants' offense had sputtered in the first half, Hampton, with shifty running, turned a short pass from Phil Simms into a 12-yard touchdown play. Less than two minutes later, Meggett twisted and cut and raced 68 yards on a punt return for the second touchdown. Less than 11 minutes later, Simms hit Mark Ingram on a 41-yard touchdown play.

title: For U.S., Disturbing Mideast Options
description: LEAD: Notwithstanding the formidable U.S. force sent to the Persian Gulf, there seems to be no early end of the crisis in sight. Moreover, we speak of the crisis as though it is obvious what the crisis is and what its resolution might be.

description: The debt-laden Aussat satellite group would be sold, probably to foreign interests, to form the basis of a competitor to the combined Telecom-OTC.

title: New Plan Wing Design Greatly Cuts Drag To Save Fuel
description: The secret of reducing skin-friction drag in aircraft, boats or any vehicle passing through a fluid is to maintain a condition called laminar flow, in which air or water slides smoothly over the surfaces of wings, hulls or other components of the vehicle. The air in laminar flow behaves as if it were a sandwich (a ''boundary layer'') of many sheets, each one sliding smoothly against its neighbor.

title: Out of Oil's Frying Pan Into Wood-Based Fire
description: I mean your obvious bias in favor of wood-derived alcohols.

title: A Walker in This City
description: She was doing, of course, the Manhattan Zig-Zag, that dazzling progression of quick steps to the left and sudden feints to the right that keeps pedestrian traffic moving swiftly. But at 44th Street and Sixth Avenue she stopped. A young man with an acoustic guitar was playing music as haunting as the soundtrack for ''Twin Peaks.'' His diverse audience, crowding the corner, applauded as courteously as concertgoers at Carnegie Hall.

title: William Bales, Dancer, Is Dead; Choreographer and Educator, 80
description: The cause of death was Alzheimer's disease and bladder cancer, his son, Michael, said.

title: Stock Rally Is Cut Short; Dow Off by 3.96
description: He said optimism over the solidarity shown between the United States and the Soviet Union at summit talks in Helsinki over the weekend had caused oil prices to fall early yesterday. This, he said, lifted most stocks except oil shares.

title: U.S. Blocks Columbia 'Junk' Sale
description: Under the Gordon America proposal, Columbia would have accepted a 10-year note for 90 percent of the $3 billion purchase price. Regulators said the feature might not comply with the Federal bailout legislation adopted in August of last year, which requires all savings institutions to sell non-investment-grade securities by the end of 1994.

title: Tokyo Stocks Close Lower
description: Brokers here said the market was influenced by weak bond futures prices, Wall Street's small losses on Monday and higher oil prices.

title: Hillock Named to Post

title: Books of The Times;   Benedict Arnold, the Great American Traitor
description: During the American Revolution, General Arnold served with distinction at Ticonderoga, Quebec City and Saratoga. He was wounded while leading the assault on Quebec, the strongest fortress on the continent. Although his forces withdrew and Canada remained British, the attack so alarmed the British Government that it took the largest force of regulars dispatched across the Atlantic and sent almost half of them to Quebec. By draining off the British soldiery, the ultimate result would be the most decisive American victory of the war, at Saratoga. But before the war was over, Arnold changed sides and sold out to the British. After his treason, his effigy was paraded through the streets of Philadelphia. ''Benedict Arnold: Patriot and Traitor'' is a why-done-it. The hero turns out to be a little worse as a man, and a little better as a soldier, than his reputation. In the course of the story, the reader learns a good deal about the Revolutionary War and how close the ragtag American army came to defeat. For Benedict Arnold was not the only traitor, deserter or summer soldier under General Washington's command. Despair was a part of the rations carried in almost every soldier's knapsack.

title: Love Conquers All in Hollywood Summer Season

Despite increases that pushed the price of admission to $7 or more in major cities, movie grosses were down about 9 percent from the record summer of 1989 and production costs were up, with several large action-adventure movies costing more than $50 million each because of big names and expensive special effects.

title: Not the Only Crisis
description: Not at all. West Germany and the Soviet Union, for instance, now have agreed on how to share the costs of Soviet troop withdrawals from East Germany; so German reunification actually will take place on Oct. 3, barely three weeks from now. In the long run, this might be the most important event of 1990, or the coming decade; but it's taking place in a vacuum of public and perhaps official discussion, owing to the Middle East frenzy created by a dedicated Administration and a headline-happy press.

Somebody has to do the ironing, he said, and ''more and more men are doing these chores,'' he said.

title: Mercedes Sales
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11 - LEAD: Mercedes-Benz said it expects to sell about 75,000 cars in the United States in 1990, down slightly from last year's 75,714. United States sales for Daimler-Benz A.G., the West German company that builds the Mercedes, have fallen gradually each year from a peak of 99,000 cars in 1986. "We seem to be on target for sales of 75,000 cars for calendar year 1990," said Albert Weiss, general manager of marketing communications for Mercedes-Benz of North America, Montvale, N.J.

title: Topics of The Times;   Trying to Change Seasons
description: These are scattered but welcome signs announcing ''good riddance'' to a wet and miserable summer. The crickets are already becoming a chorus. Purple and white asters will soon dapple whole fields, and swallows collect in twittering congregations, expectantly waiting to head south.

title: The Bloom Is Off Organic Produce Sales
description: ''Initially consumers seemed interested and were buying organic produce, but sales have now declined,'' said Steve D'Agostino, vice president for marketing. ''But we will continue to carry it because we believe our customers should have a selection.'' He said organic produce sometimes does not look as good as regular produce. He said prices, at least 30 percent higher, represent higher production and handling costs, and denied that there is a bigger retail markup on organic produce.

title: Let Us Remember Also Dorothea Dix
description: In the mid-19th century, she learned that psychotic and mentally deficient people were housed (often chained) in sheds and subjected to abominable conditions in jails and almshouses. From then on, she spent many years visiting state after state, publicizing such conditions until legislatures committed themselves to building mental hospitals, to be administered by the best standards known. Her remarkable story is told, among other places, as a chapter of ''The Lame, the Halt and the Blind'' by Dr. Howard Haggard (1932).

title: Thomas J. Davis, 77, Investment Executive
description: Thomas J. Davis, a founder of the Mayfield Fund, a venture-capital investment firm on the West Coast, died Tuesday at the University Convalescent Hospital in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 77 years old.

title: Reviews/Music;   A Choir of Men and Boys Evoking the Renaissance
description: George Guest, a Welsh chorus master and organist, has enjoyed a notable career that has extended beyond Britain with his many recordings. description: The paradox is that in other ways, the Yugoslav press has undergone the same transformation that has revolutionized the press in other parts of Eastern Europe.

description: The number of rigs exploring for oil in the United States soared by 27 last week, to a total of 1,039, Baker Hughes Inc. reported on Monday. ''It's the highest since Jan. 2, when the count was 1,042,'' said Ike Kerridge, who keeps track of the count for Baker.

description: ''It's like buying a used car,'' said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip. But nobody has yet said, 'Here is the real car, and here is the real price.' ''

title: Savings Units for Sale
description: Federal regulators put 65 more failed savings and loan associations up for sale today as part of the bailout of the troubled industry. The Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency supervising the bailout, said the institutions have a total of about $9.7 billion in deposits. Of the institutions put up for sale, 22 are in the Midwest; 18 are in the East, including Florida and Georgia; 17 are in the Southwest, and 8 are in the West.

description: The Brazilian Government said today that it would open its computer market to imports, ending a policy adopted in 1984 to protect its fledgling computer industry.

description: The agency tested all the generic and brand-name versions of 24 drugs that can be harmful or ineffective if they do not deliver the labeled amount of active ingredients within very narrow limits.

description: ''I'm guilty,'' he once said. ''I can accept my punishment. I'm sorry I done it, yeah, but it's done.''

title: Chronicle
description: In an election year awash in political fund-raising events comes a new angle - a politician lending his own supporters to raise money for an arts institution. The National Arts Club in Manhattan is giving its Citation of Merit to ROY M. GOODMAN, who is up for re-election, at a dinner on Tuesday. Some 300 of the Republican State Senator's friends will each pay $100 to attend.

title: Kitty Litter Maker Selling Operations
description: Edward Lowe Industries, the maker of Kitty Litter cat box filler, agreed to sell its marketing and manufacturing operations to an investment group. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The buyer is a group led by the Good Capital Company of New York and Knightsbridge Inc. of Chicago.

title: AIDS-ONLY CENTERS CALLED A BAD IDEA
description: The committee, the New York City Task Force on Single-Disease Hospitals, is a private group created and financed by the United Hospital Fund and the New York Community Trust. Its conclusions were published today in the New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Ex-Lord & Taylor Head To Run Texas Retailer
description: Frank C. Watson, who resigned in 1988 as president and chief operating officer of Lord & Taylor, has joined Scarbroughs, an Austin, Tex., fashion specialty chain, as its president, chief operating officer and principal.

title: New Jersey's Death Penalty: Fair or Fake?
description: Twenty days after New Jersey enacted its death penalty law in 1982, Richard F. Biegenwald shot a teen-age girl to death in Asbury Park. Soon after, he became one of the first people sentenced under the law to die by lethal injection.

title: An Autumn Fandango at Bloomingdale's
description: TO the design lexicons of American country, English country and French country, consider adding Spanish country furniture, which is among the objects featured in ''Spain: Europe's Rising Star,'' the storewide promotional celebration at Bloomingdale's this fall.

title: Energy Proposals Proliferate as Oil Prices Rise
description: Rising oil prices have injected new life into a host of programs that members of Congress from energy-producing states have tried to push for years.

title: Accounts
description: * Procter & Gamble Co., Cincinnati, to Font & Vaamonde Inc., New York, for all Hispanic network television media placement.

title: Mariners Close in on a Modest Goal
description: The Mets and the Toronto Blue Jays, the best Eastern Division teams paper can produce, are desperately clinging to their hopes of producing where division championships are decided: on the field.

title: Aviation Security Force Called Too Small by Half
description: The document is being drafted in response to recommendations made in May by the Presidential Commission on Aviation Security and Terrorism, which investigated the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988, when 270 people were killed, including 11 on the ground. The commission found major flaws in Federal aviation security programs, including insufficient security staffing at domestic as well as foreign airports.

title: Architect's Inspiration: Forest Folly
description: SOMETIMES good design can be found in the smallest building. In 1987, Charles Warren, a Manhattan architect, was engaged to renovate a client's guest house in Carmel, N.Y. ''As part of the job, there was a fireplace in the guest house, and it occurred to me it would be fun to make a garden folly out of the woodshed,'' Mr. Warren said. The architect turned the woodshed into a miniature house that he calls ''an allegory for the forest.''

title: Article 804590 -- No Title
description: ARCO said today that it had settled a 13-year dispute with Alaska by agreeing to pay $287 million in royalties on the production of oil from the North Slope.

title: Japan's Surplus Rises
description: Japan's trade surplus edged up 3.7 percent in August, to $3.49 billion, from $3.37 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry announced today. It was the third time this year that the surplus had widened compared with a year earlier. The surplus had declined for 11 consecutive months until March. Imports in August rose 2.4 percent from a year earlier, to $18.9 billion, but exports climbed 2.6 percent, to $22.39 billion. The surplus with the United States, Japan's largest trading partner, shrank 6 percent, to $2.83 billion.

title: Review/Architecture;   For San Francisco, a New Art Museum With Its Own Signature
description: Outflanked and outclassed in the last decade by the explosive growth of museums in Los Angeles, San Francisco on Tuesday had its first look at a bold design for a museum building that will serve as the centerpiece for a new downtown cultural district that public officials and arts executives hope will once again energize the city's cultural scene.

title: Hesitation on Soviet Economy
description: The plan in question is a 500-day recipe for free markets originally designed by economists loyal to Boris N. Yeltsin. It has been massaged into final form, and given a broader trademark, by a committee of economists under Stanislav S. Shatalin, one of Mr. Gorbachev's top advisers.

title: Dr. Vivian A. Tenney; Internist, 77
description: Dr. Vivian Allison Tenney, an internist and a gynecologist in Manhattan for 45 years, died on Monday at Rockingham Memorial Hospital in Harrisonburg, Va. She was 77 years old and lived in Bridgewater, Va.

title: Lawyers in Landmark Estimate Board Suit Ask $1 Million
description: Three lawyers in the suit that led to a United States Supreme Court decision that ultimately abolished the New York City Board of Estimate and altered the structure of the city government are claiming a total of more than $1 million from the city for legal work in the landmark case.

title: U.S. Doesn't Have to Go to War With Iraq on Hussein's Terms
description: It was wise to send troops to Saudi Arabia to permit it to increase oil production without threat of Iraqi military action, to freeze Kuwaiti and Iraqi assets, to embargo the sale of oil from them and to convince other countries to cut off financial aid and military sales to Iraq. It was dangerously foolish to impose a blockade on all imports to Iraq or to commit ourselves to military action should diplomatic efforts fail.

title: In Fall, It's Spring To Bulb-Planters
