description: GOOD gardeners know that spring begins in fall. The autumnal equinox is a week away, so it is time to stop procrastinating, decide which hardy flower bulbs to buy, and then plant the species that will brighten the scene when winter begins to fade.

title: West German Named Director of the Philadelphia
description: The West German conductor Wolfgang Sawallisch has been appointed music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, beginning in the 1993-94 season, the orchestra announced yesterday. He will succeed Riccardo Muti, who said in March that he would give up the directorship to spend more time in Europe when his current contract ends, in August 1992. Mr. Muti will become laureate conductor of the orchestra.

title: Corrections
description: LEAD: A report in the Business People column yesterday about the appointment of a chief executive officer at the Lear Siegler Seymour Corporation misstated the number of ironing boards the company plans to sell this year in North America. It is 4 million, not 400 million.

title: INSIDE
description: Senators expect to vote for him, but not to learn his views on crucial issues. Page A18.

title: U.S. Doesn't Have to Go to War With Iraq on Hussein's Terms; Credit to Vegetius
description: To the Editor:

title: Setback for President's Son
description: An administrative law judge in Denver has denied Neil Bush's motion to dismiss charges that he violated conflict-of-interest laws as a director of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver.

title: A Dog Has His Day, Again
description: THE RCA dog is back.

title: Gulf States Loses Round
description: Gulf States Utilities will not get a second chance to convince state regulators that its customers should pay an additional $1.4 billion in nuclear plant construction costs, the Texas Supreme Court ruled today.

title: A Chill of Death Lingers As College Life Goes On
description: ''We've all been affected, and we are all on our guard more,'' said Miss Taube, who once would have thought nothing of walking to the library by herself. ''But at least we aren't just staying home and locked up like we were two weeks ago.''

title: Judge Halts Publication of Book By Ex-Israeli Intelligence Agent
description: ''The idea of prior restraint on a book is odious to me, and we will fight very hard to get this book published,'' said Thomas J. McCormack, the chairman and chief executive of St. Martin's Press.

title: Newsday Buys a Business That Distributes 'Shoppers'
description: Newsday, the Long Island daily newspaper, bought a newspaper distribution business yesterday that delivers several local ''shoppers'' newspapers. The papers, which are filled with advertisements, are given out free to more than 1.15 million homes.

title: Man Shot Trying to Stop Holdup
description: A man who was trying to stop the holdup of a neighbor's newsstand in Richmond Hill, Queens, was shot and seriously wounded yesterday by one of the robbers, the police said.

title:
Talking Deals;

2 Utilities Decide To Share Power
description: LEAD: IF he were a more impetuous leader, A. M. Gleason, the chairman of Pacificorp, would have made a hostile takeover bid last month for the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation. Mr. Gleason coveted Pinnacle West's crown jewel, the Arizona Public Service Company, the state's largest electric utility, and there appeared to be no other way to get it.

title: Cone Stops Pirates and Gives Mets New Life
description: One week after they were swept out of Pittsburgh, the Mets rose up out of the debris of their pennant race last night and made a run for it as David Cone pitched them past the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2-1, and they drew within two and a half games of the top with only 20 left to play.

title: Reagan Reconquers Berlin but Fallen Wall Has the Last Laugh
description: A Visit to the Reichstag

title: Girl Killed and Mother Hurt In a Hit-and-Run Accident
description: A 3-year-old girl was killed and her mother was seriously injured in a hit-and-run accident last night on Atlantic Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Giants' Walls Getting Ready to Face Old Teammates
description: For nine years, Everson Walls was a backbone of the Dallas Cowboys' defense, a free-agent cornerback who led the National Football League three years in interceptions. He was a team leader, a straight arrow, a hometown hero.

title: World Bank's 5-Year Bonds Are Priced to Yield 8.74%
description: The World Bank yesterday priced $2 billion in five-year global bonds through a group of 15 international dealers jointly managed by Deutsche Bank Capital Markets and Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Merger Is Set With Smart
description: Smart magazine and a new men's magazine that was set for publication early next year by Norris Publishing will merge into Smart: For Men, Owen Lipstein, chairman of the New American Magazine Company, said yesterday.

title: California Justices Block AIDS Testing In Prostitution Cases
description: The court could take up to three months to decide whether to take the case.

title: Corrections
description: LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a report on hospital care provided to people who lack health insurance or are covered by the Government's Medicaid program referred incorrectly to comments by James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association. They were made in an interview, not in his editorial for the A.M.A.

title: Ogrodnick Accord Near
description: The Rangers and John Ogrodnick said tonight they were on the verge of a deal that could have the free agent left wing practicing with the team by as early as Friday.

title: Chronicle
description: The DALAI LAMA expressed optimism yesterday that the Chinese Government would soften its line on Tibet. The spiritual and political leader of the region that is ruled by China began a three-week visit to the United States and Canada yesterday with a one-day stop in New York. While in the city, he announced the International Year of Tibet, in which Tibetan performances and art exhibitions will visit the United States and 27 other countries in 1991. The event is sponsored by Tibet House, a group headed by the actor RICHARD GERE.

title: Some Tough Situations but a Successful Evening for Cone
description: David Cone didn't need road signs to figure out which way to the trouble spots in the Pirates' lineup en route to a 2-1 victory. Bobby Bonilla and Barry Bonds reside there, No. 4 and No. 5 in the batting order, 207 runs batted in, 58 home runs and counting at the start of the game against the Mets last night.

title: Review/Dance;   A Gentle Portrayal Of Alienation By Otteco
description: The tone was pleasant and soothing when Otteco presented an evening of modern dance on Saturday night at the 14th Street Dance Center. But that may not have been what Gerald Otte, a former member of the Nikolais Dance Theater, had in mind since ''The Offering,'' a new work that was the program's centerpiece, seemed to be about loss of identity in the modern world.

title: Zoltan Rozsnyai, 64, Founder of Orchestra
description: Zoltan Rozsnyai, the founder and conductor of the United States International University Orchestra and the former conductor of the San Diego Symphony, was found dead, apparently of a heart attack, at his home on Monday. He was 64 years old.

title: Dallas Police Chief Is Fired After Indictment
description: Prosecutors had urged felony charges against Mr. Vines for statements he made in August to a panel investigating the firing of a Dallas police officer, Patrick LeMaire.

title: Mathematical Error Is Seen Behind Flaw In Hubble Telescope
description: The error was made in transposing the design of the intrument, a reflective null corrector, from the drawing board to the assembly room, said Robin Laurance, an official with the European Space Agency and an observer on the committee investigating the flaw for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Glimpses of How Other Half Lived
description: Baltimore will gain an important new museum Sept. 17 when the lavishly appointed Evergreen House officially opens to the public after a three-year restoration costing $4.3 million.

title: New York Fails to Deter Vans Used As Buses
description: For years, thousands of private vans have cruised city bus routes in Brooklyn and Queens and on Staten Island, poaching passengers and fares from the Transit Authority and other bus companies licensed to operate in New York City.

title: Swissair and Aoki Cancel Hotel Sale
description: Swissair, Switzerland's national airline, said the planned sale of its Swissotel hotel interests to the Aoki Corporation of Japan had been canceled. The airline cited the uncertainty in world financial markets and the recent strength of the Swiss franc for the joint decision. The sale price, which has not been disclosed, had been in Swiss francs.

title: Nederlander Gets Owners' Approval
description: The upheaval in the Yankees' hierarchy moved one step closer to resolution today with Robert Nederlander apparently receiving recommendation as successor to George Steinbrenner as the club's managing partner, Following Nederlander's 20-minute appearance before baseball's eight-man ownership committee, Commissioner Fay Vincent said, ''My understanding is the committee will come forward with a recommendation tomorrow to approve him and I would expect he would be approved.''

title: Congress and the Crisis: To Intervene or Not?
description: ''It not only will give a sense of shared responsibility, but it will give a sense of unity in this country on a major decision,'' said Representative Dante B. Fascell, a Florida Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.

title: Bridge
description: Players from the United States and Europe dominated the play in the semifinal stages of the world championships here today with an American partnership and a French partnership at the head of the standings.

title: Elenore Lester, 69, Writer and Editor
description: Elenore Lester, a writer, editor and teacher, died Sunday at New York Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: American Plans A Fare Increase
description: American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, plans to raise its fares again because of higher fuel costs, Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of the AMR Corporation, the airline's parent company, said yesterday.

title: Accountants' Move Favors Airlines
description: After years of debate, an accounting group yesterday abandoned its plan to propose a new way for airlines to treat frequent-flier miles when calculating their profits. The move is likely to please airline executives, who can report higher earnings using current accounting methods.

title: Lawmakers Rushing to Lift Caps on F.D.I.C. Premiums
description: As dire predictions about the future of the Federal fund that insures deposits at banks continued to mount, lawmakers moved quickly today to propose regulatory reforms in an apparent effort to escape the political taint of another taxpayer bailout.

title: Ames Posts Deeper Loss
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. today reported a second-quarter loss of $152.5 million, but store officials said the loss before nonrecurring charges was significantly smaller than expected.

title: Houston Raises $75 Million
description: A $75 million issue of prior lien revenue bonds from the Houston water and sewer system was priced in competitive bidding yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday misidentified the company to be acquired by Tyco Toys Inc. It is Playtime Products Inc.

title: Corrections
description: LEAD: A picture caption with the Gardener's World column of The Home Section on Aug. 23 misidentified a plant.

title: Pipeline Project Is Endorsed
description: A Federal hearing officer recommended on Tuesday that construction proceed on a long-delayed pipeline that would carry natural gas from Canada to the United States.

title: Bush Tapes a Message for Iraqi TV
description: Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq denounced the speech Mr. Bush delivered to Congress on Tuesday night. The official Iraqi press agency quoted Mr. Aziz as saying: ''The U.S. President's address is a model speech by an imperialist ruler who wants to impose his power on the world. Most of the globe's peoples, the Arabs in the forefront, reject that and insist on preserving their independence and free will.'' A Simulated Debate? In making his tape for broadcast in Iraq, officials acknowledged that Mr. Bush was running the risk that it would be edited, although they were taking steps to make that harder technically. It could also be preceded or followed by a rebuttal from President Saddam Hussein himself, creating the appearance of just the kind of debate that Mr. Bush has rejected.

title: Review/Television;   New Series Has 2 Tiers, The Chase and the Trial
description: Tonight and next Thursday, NBC is using the slot it normally reserved for ''L.A. Law'' to preview its new series called ''Law and Order.'' Created by Dick Wolf, who is also one of the executive producers, ''Law and Order'' lays claim to a new concept, describing itself as a ''two-tiered crime drama.'' The first half of each episode follows a police team as it apprehends the ''alleged perps''; the second follows the case into the criminal courts through the work of two assistant district attorneys.

title: China Is Said to Execute 500 to Reduce Crime
description: The Chinese Government does not report how many people have been sentenced to death and the real figure is believed to be much higher, the organization said.

title: Japan's One-Way Lobbying
description: These activities are entirely legal, Mr. Choate acknowledges, but also ''deeply corrosive of the U.S. political and economic system.'' One-third of the principal officials in the White House Trade Office since 1973 have left to become foreign agents, mostly for Japan. Japanese-led PAC's contribute heavily to political campaigns. Most university programs in Japanese studies rely on Japanese money, sapping academic independence, Mr. Choate says.

title: Calendar: Race to Save Treasures of Past
description: A Fragile Past, Metropolitan Life Gallery, 24 East 24 Street; (212) 578-2723.

title: Books of The Times;   Astream, Seeking Trout and Wisdom
description: What the River Knows

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: WHEN he was 13 years old, Laurence Steinberg felt cursed by his 20/20 vision. ''It seemed like everyone who was popular wore glasses,'' said Dr. Steinberg, a professor of psychology at Temple University in Philadelphia and the author of ''You and Your Adolescent'' (Harper & Row, 1990, $19.95).

title: Debt Plan for Morocco
description: Morocco's creditor governments have agreed to allow the North African country to spread repayments on part of its official development aid loans over 20 years and reschedule debt service payments on other credits over a 15-year period, the French Finance Ministry said today. The ministry gave no indication of the amount of rescheduled debt. It is the first time lenders had offered such favorable terms to a highly indebted middle-income country. Previous recipients of such concessions have been much poorer.

title: Reviews/Music;   Into Juju's Ecstatic Heart
description: In the eight years since the Nigerian juju-music band leader King Sunny Ade released his first album here, starting the World Beat movement in the United States, juju music's prominence has faded. It has been replaced in the minds of agents, record companies and the audience looking for something different by Zairian and Parisian soukous music. Shina Peters, a 32-year-old Nigerian band leader, brought his 17-piece juju orchestra to Kilimanjaro on Saturday night, and it was obvious he hadn't heard the news. Mr. Peters and his orchestra shook the house, and had the audience transfixed.

title: Cram in Fifth Ave. Race
description: Steve Cram, the British middle-distance runner who holds the world record for the mile, has joined an impressive field planning to compete in the 10th Mercedes Mile on Fifth Avenue on Sept. 22. In addition to Cram, whose record of 3 minutes 46.32, was set five years, the field includes Said Aouita of Morocco, the second-fastest miler ever with a time of 3:46.76; Peter Elliott of England, the defending champion, and Steve Scott, one of the United States's premier middle-distance runners. Neither Cram nor Aouita has competed in the Mercedes Miles before.

title: A Good Gulf Pep Rally
description: The President has thus earned the confidence to say that Iraqi aggression will be defeated. ''And that's not a threat, not a boast,'' he said. ''It's just the way it's going to be.''

title: Macho? Yes. Violent? Sure. Hockey? Of Course.
description: In the 1969 film ''Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid,'' the character Butch, played by Paul Newman, is challenged to fight by a big man with a big knife. His name is Harvey and he is contesting Butch for the leadership of an outlaw gang.

title: Tiffany's Celebrates Manhattan
description: TO celebrate its 50th anniversary at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, Tiffany & Company is exhibiting four table settings that depict imaginary moments in a Manhattan where big bands played and the Empire State Building was still the tallest building in the world.

title: U.S. Wants to Aid 2 Cambodia Factions
description: Testifying before the House subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs, Under Secretary of State Robert M. Kimmitt noted ''a dramatic upswing in the prospects for a peaceful settlement'' between the guerrilla coalition and the Cambodian Government.

title: Leo Mirkovic, 86, Dies; A Cantor in New York
description: Leo Mirkovic, an opera singer in Europe before World War II, who became a well-known cantor in New York and Washington, died on Friday in Miami. He was 86 years old and had moved to Miami in 1974.

title: Aquino Orders Halt to Offensives In Provinces Damaged by Quakes
description: Military Offensives Stopped

title: Souter Hearings On Public TV
description: In addition to WETA, and WNET in New York, public television stations in Los Angeles, Chicago, Houston and New Hampshire have agreed to carry the PBS coverage. The hearings will also be covered by the Cable News Network. ABC, CBS and NBC will report on the hearings in their regular news programs but will not carry live coverage unless there is unexpected news.

title: The Rugged Land Helps Shape G.I.'s
description: Almost all soldiers interviewed said they thought they were here for a year at least, whether war was waged or not.

title: Chronicle
description: Preparing to defend his title in New York Oct. 7, the World Chess Champion, GARY KASPAROV, has renounced Moscow for an isolated house overlooking the ocean on Martha's Vineyard. He is there with his wife, his mother and four trainers.

title: NEW F.D.A. CHIEF REPORTED CHOSEN
description: The 39-year-old Dr. Kessler, would replace Dr. James S. Benson, the acting Commissioner. Dr. Benson replaced Dr. Frank E. Young, who resigned under pressure last year.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ambase Corp., an insurance concern, ended talks to sell its United States International Reinsurance Co.

title: People
description: * Wendy Lapidus-Saltz has joined DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago, as an associate creative director.

title: HEALTH: Personal Health;   Food poisoning called shigellosis is on the rise, prompting efforts to fight it.
description: As child care and food handling become more centralized, food-borne diseases that spread easily in communal settings can flourish unless a concerted effort is made to prevent them.

title: In Surrogate Race, a Well-Solicited 13% Voted
description: Only 13 percent of the 500,000 Democrats in Manhattan voted in their party's primary for surrogate on Tuesday, but rarely has such a small audience been so bombarded by mailings, television, radio and print advertising, telephone calls and palm cards.

title: Weavings of Navajo Belief
description: Beginning in 1954, Edwin and Ruth Kennedy amassed a wide assortment of 19th- and 20th-century blankets, rugs and wall hangings representing the various types of Navajo weavings. They also acquired Navajo and Zuni Pueblo silver and turquoise jewelry: bracelets, pins, necklaces, earrings, crosses, bolo ties and belts.

title: Primary Results: Setting the Stage for November
description: Primaries held Sept. 11. Percentages are not final.

title: New Focus on Sperm Brings Fertility Successes
description: Doctors who treat infertile couples are increasingly looking at men, not just women, as potential sources of the problem, and this is resulting in more pregnancies for the childless, specialists report.

title: Kits Ease Task of Building a Succah
description: THE Jewish holiday of Succoth, a feast of thanksgiving lasting eight days, begins the evening of Oct. 3 this year. Those who observe Succoth, which celebrates the Jewish people's travels in the desert after their escape from slavery in Egypt, eat all their meals in succahs, specially constructed outdoor booths with roofs of naturally grown materials that allow the sky to show through. The succahs symbolize the huts the Jewish people built in the desert, as described in Leviticus in the Old Testament.

title: New Orchestra for Dutoit
description: Charles Dutoit, the music director of the Montreal Symphony Orchestra, has been named music director of the Orchestre National de France. His responsibility for the musical programming begins immediately, and starting in September 1992 he is to make 12 appearances a year with the French orchestra. He is to continue to conduct the Montreal Symphony Orchestra and to manage its touring and recording schedules. Mr. Dutoit and the Montreal ensemble are to give concerts at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 3 and 4.

title: Investor Is Given Bally Directorship
description: The New Jersey investor Arthur M. Goldberg has acquired a 5.39 percent stake in the Bally Manufacturing Corporation and will receive a seat on the board of the Chicago-based game machine and casino company. In return, Mr. Goldberg has agreed not to raise his stake beyond 15 percent, seek control of Bally or solicit proxies for three years.

title: Investor's Claim Has Marital Twist
description: Like many investors, Stephen L. Lane, the president and chief executive of the Emerson Radio Corporation, lost millions in the market crash of 1987 and has filed a claim against his brokerage firm, the defunct Drexel Burnham Lambert, to recover his money.

title: A Historic Moment Slips By, Overtaken by Other Events
description: And yet the ''Treaty on the Final Settlement With Respect to Germany,'' to give it its full title, arguably had a significance akin to agreements familiar from every high school history text -the Versailles Treaty of 1871, from which a united Germany first emerged; and the Potsdam conference of 1945, from which the Germans emerged severed in two.

title: Summer's Soldiers
description: At the county fair the armored personnel carrier stood between the pony rides and the dart game. Boys passed through it all afternoon, poring over the controls, running their hands along its camouflage-colored body. ''It is not a tank,'' said a soldier sternly each time a boy raised on G.I. Joe mislabeled the thing. It seemed to fall somewhere between a Trans Am and the Tilt-A-Whirl in the minds of the kids, to have as much to do with death as the John Deere tractor exhibit.

title: Nissan Motor
description: The Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation introduced a redesigned 1991 Sentra that will be aimed at more affluent buyers. The base cost will be $7,999, up from $7,399. The introduction of the model at Nissan's Smyrna, Tenn., plant rounds out a new generation of cars and trucks offered by the Japanese manufacturer since 1988. The company predicts sales of 160,000 Sentras for 1991.

title: Wild Debut For a Yank
description: Steve Adkins flirted with history last night when he stepped onto a major league mound for the first time. By the time he left, he had not given a hit. The problem was, it only was the second inning, he had walked eight batters, including five in a row, and the Yankees were trailing the Texas Rangers.

title: Review/Television;   Street Crime as Seen in the Living Room
description: Can't get enough on local news? Stay tuned. Tonight brings two hours of prime-time crime. ''Murder U.S.A.,'' the season premiere of ''48 Hours'' at 8 P.M. on CBS, serves up bodies on stretchers, bodies in bags and bodies in coffins. There are drug raids, gun-running and a case of sexual assault. There are innocent victims and grieving parents. (''What they share is their pain and their anguish,'' intones the ''48 Hours'' reporter.) There is uplift in a visit to an inner-city camp for teen-agers to keep them off the streets; and there is show biz in an interview with a rap singer and glimpses of the trial of a television actor charged with shooting a drug seller. And more.

title: Four Allies Give Up Rights in Germany
description: End of an Era

title: Philip Donham, 82, Consultant and Author
description: Philip Donham, a management consultant who was the co-author of a book on the inner workings of Congress, died Monday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 82 years old and lived in North Weymouth, Mass.

title: Norwalk Show to Display 800 Boats
description: Nearly 800 craft valued at more than $100 million will be on display at the Norwalk (Conn.) In-water Power Boat Show, which opens today and runs through Sunday.

title: RESIST U.S. IN GULF, TOP IRANIAN CLERIC URGES ALL MUSLIMS
description: ''We will never permit the United States to make a foothold or turn the region into its zone of influence wherever we are present and have influence and anywhere our words, as the voice of Islam, are heard by Muslims,'' Ayatollah Khamenei told a group that included leaders of Iranian veterans organizations.

title: Mills Aims for N.B.A.
description: Terry Mills, the first-round draft choice the Denver Nuggets thought they were getting for Danny Schayes, has left the Greek pro team he signed with and will be returning this weekend to negotiate with the Nuggets, his attorney, Bob Woolf, said yesterday.

title: Buildup of U.S. Forces in the Gulf Is a Temporary Move, Assad Says
description: ''The problem of Kuwait should be solved between the Arabs,'' he said. ''When it is over I am sure that all foreign troops will withdraw. But first all Arab countries should stand together against the invasion of one Arab brother by another.''

title: A 2d Suitor Makes Offer For Corroon
description: The Corroon & Black Corporation, the giant New York-based insurance concern that recently agreed to merge with a big British insurance brokerage, said today that it had received another, larger offer.

title: Clean Air Bills Are Likely to Cost More Than Anyone Expected;   The Price of Breathing
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ROOF gutters protect against drainage problems that can seriously damage foundations. But to do their job, they need to be clean and free of leaks. Gutters should be cleaned twice a year, in spring and in late fall after leaves have dropped. But if the gutters leak or drain poorly even when clean, repair them promptly.

title: The Brady Bill and New York Guns
description: The Brady bill, introduced by Representative Edward Feighan of Ohio, would require a customer to wait seven days between purchase and delivery of a handgun, permitting local police to check the customer's background. It is named for President Reagan's press secretary James Brady, injured by a handgun bullet intended for the President.

title: Bringing Janacek's 'House of the Dead' to Life
description: Leos Janacek's ninth and final opera, ''From the House of the Dead,'' does not have a plot, in the conventional sense. Based on the Dostoyevsky novel ''Notes From the House of the Dead,'' its dramatic boundaries are the arrival and departure of Aleksandr Petrovich Goryanchikov, a political prisoner. But Goryanchikov quickly fades into the mass of interned men, a few of whom emerge to tell their stories in arias or dialogues. Only a pantomime, staged by the prisoners in the second act, breaks the grimness of the work's atmosphere.

title: Seoul Is Firm on Rice
description: South Korea will not budge from its refusal to open its market to foreign rice and will keep price controls on rice to protect its farmers, an Agriculture Ministry official said today. He said that Seoul was forced by political pressures to ask for special concessions to keep its rice market closed. Farmers staged protests last week against Seoul's taking part in the current GATT multilateral trade talks and last month threw bottles at the agriculture minister, forcing him to halt a speech.

title: As U.S. Warms to U.N., It Finds Unpaid Debts Embarrassing
description: The United States does not recognize the validity of about $70 million of its United Nations debt. Over more than a decade, Washington has consistently withheld what are known as ''legislative and policy withholdings'' arising out of such disputes as the tax liabilities of American citizens working for the United Nations and support for activities related to the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Soweto Journal;   Terror and Death Replace Hope in Squatter Camp
description: Victim of Factional Battles

title: On Wood, Fantasies In Finishing
description: WOOD, whether on a chair, bureau or fan, has been turned into fake ivory, marble or ebony at an exhibition of student work at the Isabel O'Neil Foundation's Studio Workshop, which opens tomorrow at 177 East 87th Street in Manhattan.

title: Senate Panel Backs Extension of Arts Agency
description: The Senate committee that oversees the National Endowment for the Arts today approved a bill calling for a five-year extension of the endowment without restrictions on the kind of art the agency may support.

title: Corrections
description: LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages on Tuesday about Ben Johnson's return to track and field competition gave an incorrect time for the 100-meter world record set by the Canadian sprinter at the 1988 Seoul Olympics. The time, later disallowed because Johnson failed a drug test, was 9.79 seconds.

title: Top Legislator Attacks Boycott Of Korean Store
description: As the boycott of a Korean-owned market in Brooklyn dragged bitterly toward its ninth month yesterday, Assembly Speaker Mel Miller told a City Council committee that the boycott ''should be condemned universally.''

title: Drug-Testing Kit for Parents Spurs Stormy Debate
description: Some drug treatment experts say any tool that spurs parents to act quickly in identifying drug problems is helpful. ''A lot of parents block out the reality of their kids' using drugs because it's the worst reality there is,'' said Joseph P. Cleary, director of the Renaissance Project, a Westchester County treatment program. ''If this test works, and if parents use it for investigation, not for conclusions or discipline, it could be very useful.'' Mr. Cleary has not tried the testing kit.

title: Volvo Said to Join Bidding for Skoda
description: The French auto maker Renault said the Swedish auto maker Volvo A.B. had joined its bid for a stake in the Czechoslovak state-run car company, Skoda.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Network Group Inc., Nashville, named Larry D. Sensing vice president and chief financial officer. He succeeds Al Dupere, who was chief financial officer on a interim basis.

title: Northwest Seeks Australian Route
description: Northwest Airlines has applied to the United States Transportation Department for special authority to enter the Australian market.

title: Diabetes Enzyme Found Identical to One in Brain
description: Diabetes researchers had had difficulty studying the enzyme because only small amounts of it could be found in the pancreas, which does not function properly in diabetics. But brain researchers have been able to obtain larger amounts of the enzyme. The discovery that the two are the same will be a boon to diabetes research, experts said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Acheson's Co-signer
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidate Calls A Victory Party Ahead of Count
description: State Senator Serphin R. Maltese of Queens held a victory party for 600 campaign workers Tuesday evening even though the votes in his write-in campaign for the Republican nomination for the State Senate will not be counted until tomorrow.

title: Asset Sale Sought By Georgia-Pacific
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, in need of cash to help finance its $5 billion takeover of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, is negotiating to sell about $740 million worth of mills and timberlands. The prospective buyers are the Packaging Corporation of America, a subsidiary of Tenneco Inc., and the General Electric Capital Corporation.

title: Top Currency Trader Joins Capital Holdings
description: Andrew J. Krieger, who earned a formidable reputation as a currency options trader by making $300 million for the Bankers Trust Company in 1987, is re-entering the market after a few years of doing mostly advisory work.

title: In Philadelphia, Rebirth of a Hotel
description: IN 1976, after Legionnaires' disease broke out at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel in Philadelphia, the hotel closed. It reopened in 1979 and closed again in 1986 for renovation. Last year, as Hotel Atop the Bellevue, it reopened and this August, won an award from the American Society of Interior Designers. It was one of 439 commercial and residential design entries, nearly double last year's. And this year, non-members entered the competition.

title: Israel Welcomes Expansion of Soviet Role in Gulf
description: At a news conference on his return from the United States, Mr. Levy said that if Soviet ''involvement means a halt in supplying weapons to the Arab countries, and preaching, directing and pressuring them to make peace with Israel, then the Soviet Union would be welcome partners.''

title: Poll Says Young Watch Less TV Than Thought
description: Some young Americans watch far less television than advertisers might hope, according to a survey conducted for Archie Comic Publications Inc. by Mark Clements Inc., an independent research company.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 2 Efforts For Simpler VCR Use
description: Fifteen years after the videocassette recorder began transforming the nation's television viewing habits, inventors are still trying to figure out how to make it easier to program the darned machines.

title: Rubin R. Dobin; Rabbi, 74
description: Rabbi Rubin R. Dobin, an Orthodox rabbi who was active in congregations in Queens and in Miami Beach, Fla., died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach. He was 74 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: Red Sox Beat Brewers On Boddicker's 7-Hitter
description: The Boston Red Sox ended a long home stand with a 6-1 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers tonight as Mike Boddicker pitched a seven-hitter. Boston extended its lead in the American League East to four games over the Toronto Blue Jays, who lost to Kansas City.

title: Savings Bond Sales Up
description: Sales of United States savings bonds rose 5 percent last month for their best August performance in four years, the Treasury Department reported today. It said sales totaled $653 million last month, up from $622 million a year earlier and the largest for the month since $1.1 billion was posted in 1986. Sales in July totaled $629 million. Savings bonds currently earn interest of 7.01 percent when held five years or longer.

title: Treasuries Mixed in a Quiet Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in lackluster trading yesterday, and interest rates on the longer maturities rose slightly.

title: Stake in Henley Raised to 14.89%
description: Libra Investment Ltd., a Swiss firm controlled by the Lebanese investor Toufic Aboukhater, has raised its stake in Henley Group Inc., a Hampton, N.H., holding company, to 14.89 percent, from 12.8 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Aboukhater reiterated that his Henley shares were purchased as an investment.

title: Lowly Royals Rehire Wathan as Manager
description: The Kansas City Royals have rehired embattled Manager John Wathan for 1991, General Manager John Schuerholz announced yesterday.

title: Bonn and Tokyo Are Criticized For Not Bearing More of Gulf Cost
description: On the floor, in television and newspaper interviews and in speeches to their constituents, the legislators are using startlingly abrasive language. To a considerable degree, that reflects the views of newspaper editorialists and of the general public, as reflected in recent opinion surveys.

title: Bertelsmann Net Up 26.9%
description: Bertelsmann A.G. said today that its profit rose 26.9 percent in the year that ended on June 30.

title: Acid Leak Forces Evacuation
description: The leak in a plastic pipe at the Midwest Ralumac plant was reported about 1:45 A.M. and plugged about 4 A.M., fire officials said. No serious injuries were reported, and a cloud caused by the spill dissipated late in the morning. The cause of the leak is being investigated.

title: 'NATO' in the Gulf: A Certain Disaster
description: An entangling alliance in the Persian Gulf, as outlined by Secretary of State James Baker in testimony before the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Sept. 5, is not in the national interest of the United States.

title: After Criticism, U.N. Selects New Chief For Relief Efforts
description: But Cuba and Yemen are pressing the Security Council to permit India to send a shipload of food to the roughly 150,000 Indians still believed to be in Iraq and Kuwait, a move the United States sees as an attempt to punch a hole in the trade embargo.

title: At Home, as at School, Child Beating Must Stop
description: There is a long history of unacceptable violence against children. In ancient Babylonia, Greece and Rome, children were the property of their fathers and could be beaten, sold or even killed. Even in the 18th century, according to one historian, more than 200 statements of advice on child rearing approved beating children severely, and the beatings described were generally serious, involving bruising and bloodying of the body, which began early and was a regular part of the child's life.

title: Fujitsu Computer
description: Fujitsu Ltd. said it would enter the market for fault-tolerant computers, which contain backup features to insure constant operation. Such machines are essential for banking, air traffic control and other fields where failures could cause severe financial or safety problems.

title: Dow Up 13.12, to 2,625.74; Trading Sluggish
description: Stocks seesawed wildly most of the morning yesterday but then advanced steadily for the rest of the day, ending slightly higher.

title: New York City Will Prevail
description: New York City is at war with its criminals, and the city needs help from every quarter.

title: Maxwell Holds Talks on Deals
description: The Maxwell Communication Corporation is in talks to sell some of its nonstrategic businesses, the British publishing company's chairman, Robert Maxwell, said today.

title: A Tough Coach Is a Tough Act to Follow
description: Gary Moeller's line of work must be one of the very few in which a person can be intensely examined for first impressions at a place where he has spent 18 of his previous 21 years. But the still brand-new coach at the University of Michigan - he will remain brand-new up to the kickoff of the Wolverine season at South Bend, Ind., on Saturday night - can expect to be scrutinized in areas from the approach to his passing game to whether he has the good sense to keep kickoffs out of the hands of Notre Dame's Raghib Ismail.

title: SENATORS EXPECT ASSENT ON SOUTER
description: Senator Dennis J. DeConcini, an Arizona Democrat who is considered a swing vote on the 14-member committee, said ''my inclination now'' is to vote for Judge Souter's confirmation. ''I always operate on the presumption that the President sends up qualified people,'' he said, ''and I have not found anything that's shaken that presumption.''

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: MY younger daughter has announced her engagement. She announced it with tears, laughter, a bottle of German champagne and an extended left hand. Her ring, she says, is the most beautiful ring in the world.

title: Drabek No Drysdale, But He May be a 'Cy'
description: Doug Drabek never pretended to be a prototypical right-hander, the sort whose personality as well as his pitches are pure hardball, who needed only one name to strike fear into the hearts of the heart of any lineup:

title: Lead Paint: New Guide On Safety
description: LEAD: To help guard against lead poisoning, a new guide on how to remove the danger of lead paint has been issued by the Massachusetts Historical Commission.

title: Maryland Coach Fined
description: Gary Williams, the men's basketball coach at the University of Maryland, has been fined $250 and sentenced in Silver Spring, Md., to one year's unsupervised probation after pleading guilty to driving while under the influence of alcohol. The 45-year-old Williams was arrested on May 13 on the inner loop of Capital Beltway after returning from a late dinner. A test after his arrest showed Williams had a blood alcohol level of .11. He was also charged with driving in more than one lane of traffic. Williams was given probation before judgment, which means his record will be wiped clean after he completes an alcohol-education program.

title: Information Is Offered On Private Schools
description: The Parents League of New York is sponsoring several programs to help families learn more about private schools in the area, known for their distinct personalities, liberal learning styles and smaller classes.

title: Preventing Genocide in Liberia
description: Until the 1980's, Liberia's main divide was between indigenous people and the Americo-Liberians, descended from freed U.S. slaves. Mr. Doe's bloody coup ended the old elite's dominance. Power and patronage flowed instead to the Krahn. That favoritism, along with the regime's brutality and incompetence, sparked opposition from other ethnic groups, like the Gio and the Mano. One rebel leader, Prince Johnson, is from the Gio. His rival, Charles Taylor, is an Americo-Liberian.

title: Review/Music;   Black Repertory Group in Debut
description: Seven years ago, Columbia College Chicago established a Center for Black Music Research, with the goal of promoting music by black composers in all musical genres. The center publishes journals, bulletins and monographs, maintains a data base and holds conferences. It also sponsors the Black Music Repertory Ensemble, which made its New York debut on Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Country House Regains Glory
description: LEAD: The roof was a 7,500-square-foot colander, the 28 rooms were gray with mildew, 80 percent of the Italianate facade was either crumbling or missing, the kitchen was minus a ceiling, and the pipes made noises sinister even for country plumbing.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: The signing of the final settlement between the Germans and their World War II victors seemed almost lost in the tumult of more immediate concerns. A1

title: Q&A
description: Bleaching a Floor

title: 4 U.S. Guards Indicted as Part Of Holdup Ring
description: Four Federal detention officers have been indicted as members of a gang that posed as police and narcotics detectives and stole hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash and jewelry from dozens of victims in the last year, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said yesterday.

title: Cuban Defector Tells of Soviet Cuts
description: ''The honeymoon has ended and now Cuba has no opportunity for re-exporting oil,'' Mr. Gonzalez said at a conference sponsored by the University of Miami's Research Institute of Cuban Studies. ''Even if they wanted to, the Soviets have no capability to maintain the kind of financial aid they have maintained during the last 30 years.''

title: Market Place;   Chase Faces Many Doubts on Wall Street
description: Just how bad off are the large New York banks? Investors are acting as if many of them are in very poor shape.

title: Barry Backlash: Capital Turned Upside Down
description: ''If I were Marion Barry I would get out of the Council race right now because the same big vote that Sharon Pratt Dixon got Tuesday is going to be solidly against him in the fall election,'' said Joslyn Williams, the chairman of the city's Democratic Party.

title: Jet Denies Tipping Off Former Club
description: According to Doug Wellsandt, it was not his loose lip that sank the Jets' ship on that third-down-and-goal end-around play at the Cincinnati Bengals' 1-yard line on Sunday. The former Bengal tight end was backed up by the Jets' coach, Bruce Coslet, and his new teammates despite the 25-20 season-opening defeat, Coslet's regular-season debut.

title: Lasting Visions of the Home
description: POWERFUL contemporary images, arcane artifacts, down-to-earth housing solutions, touching tableaux of a bygone era and programs that could keep the most energetic New Yorker going at a fast clip for months are all part of ''Home: A Place in the World.'' This ambitious multicultural event is a collaboration of five New York City museums and the New School for Social Research.

title: Daniel M. Feins, 73, Ex-Principal in Bronx
description: Daniel M. Feins, a teacher and an administrator in the New York City public schools for almost 40 years and the former principal of Walton High School in the Bronx, died on Monday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 73 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Event Shifted Over Bias Rule
description: The Western Open, one of the oldest events on the PGA Tour, will move to Cog Hill Golf and Country Club next year in compliance with anti-discrimination guidelines, according to a published report.

title: The Mets' Desperate Hours
description: Over 162 games, a baseball season has a slow, smooth pulse. If your team loses, there's always tomorrow. Or the day after. But in a pennant race the pulse quickens and throbs, as it did for the Mets on Tuesday night. Up on the Shea Stadium scoreboard, the Pirates had won in Philadelphia. In the Mets' dugout John Franco was yelling: ''I stink! I stink!'' after having allowed the Cardinals to create an 8-8 tie with two runs in the top of the ninth inning.

title: Grants Given to Address Campus Race Issues
description: Under the Ford Foundation's program, the 19 colleges and universities received grants from $25,000 to $100,000 to create new courses and to integrate more information about different cultures into existing courses. The program also seeks to address the growing ethnic diversity on campuses. ''Ignorance about other cultures breeds insensitivity and intolerance in young and old alike,'' said Franklin A. Thomas, president of the foundation, which is based in New York.

title: Connecticut Victory Shows Tax Fears, Morrison Says
description: United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison said today that his overwhelming victory on Tuesday in the Democratic primary for governor sent an unmistakable message: Residents want cuts in state spending, not new taxes, and woe to any politician who doesn't understand that.

title: Christopher Cox; Editor, 41
description: Christopher Cox, an author and a senior editor with Ballantine Books, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan at the age of 41. A spokesman for the publisher said he died of complications from an HIV infection.

title: Jury Backs Chip Patents
description: In a case that breaks legal ground, the Advanced Micro Devices Inc. has lost a patent infringement suit brought by the Brooktree Corporation, a computer chip company in San Diego.

title: Primary Results Across U.S. Reflect Wide Outcry Against Politics as Usual
description: A public outcry against business-as-usual politics welled up among voters in primary voting around the country on Tuesday, illustrating a mood of anxiety about growth, the economy, the quality of life and the quality of politics.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: LEAD: "We have drawn a line under World War II and we have started keeping the time of a new age."

title: Critic's Notebook;   TV Sitcoms Do Little for the Education Crisis
description: When it comes to dealing with education, prime-time television transmits a decidedly ambiguous message: Forget what I say and just watch what I do.

title: Free The Baltics II
description: A little over a year ago, an incendiary headline appeared in this space: ''Free the Baltics.'' A dispatch from a Baltic capital appeared here later with a provocative dateline: ''RIGA, Soviet-occupied Latvia.''

title: Black Business Ownership Up
description: The number of businesses owned by black Americans rose modestly from 1982 to 1987, but revenues for the same period more than doubled, according to a new Census Bureau survey released on Tuesday.

title: CURB ON ABORTION VOTED IN MICHIGAN
description: The requirement will go into effect next spring, 90 days after the last legislative session in December.

title: Metro Matters;   Cuomo's Seizing Of the Moment On Police Hiring
description: During last year's New York City mayoral campaign, David N. Dinkins bristled every time his restrained, equivocal style was measured against the Rev. Jesse Jackson's, just because both are black. Why not, Mr. Dinkins argued persuasively, compare any of his white opponents to New York's glib Governor, Mario M. Cuomo?

title: Church's Landmark Status Is Upheld
description: The landmark designation of St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue was upheld unanimously yesterday by the Federal Court of Appeals against a constitutional challenge by the Episcopal parish, which argued that landmark status interfered with its freedom of religion and its property rights.

title: New President At Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that James R. Mellor had been named president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 1.

title: Dark Side to New York's Neon Clubs
description: The four-man police car cruised slowly down a block filled with young men and women laughing, smoking languidly or perfecting their stylized aerobic prancing to the beat of ''house music'' from a nearby nightclub. The car crept by. No one broke rhythm.

title: I.M.F. Loans Rose in 1989
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that it had pledged loans to developing countries of $15.6 billion last year, more than twice the amount promised in 1988 and the highest level in seven years.

title: Flow of Asians Fleeing Iraq Has Eased, Jordan Reports
description: Anxieties among the Jordanians and the international relief agencies assisting them, including at least six United Nations agencies, have begun to turn to a new factor, the onset of chillier autumn weather. At a meeting in Amman today presided over by Crown Prince Hassan, brother of King Hussein, the official who is overseeing the relief effort for Jordan, Salame Hamad, said that 300,000 blankets were needed since the Asians needed two or three blankets each to shelter from the colder nights, along with additional tents.

title: United Bests American In O'Hare Scheduling
description: United Airlines won a critical round yesterday in its battle with American Airlines over schedule changes at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago when the Federal Aviation Administration approved United's fall schedule of flights.

title: Ecolab and Henkel In European Venture
description: In a bid to establish a sizable presence in the European cleaning business, Ecolab Inc. of St. Paul has agreed to swap 19 percent of its equity and pay $74 million to Henkel, a West German manufacturer of detergents and cosmetics based in Dusseldorf.

title: KEY RATES
Corrections
description: Sheik Ali al-Khalifa al-Sabah, Kuwait's Finance Minister, was at the left, with glasses, and Ibrahim S. Dabdoub, the bank's chief executive, was at the right. A caption under the bank symbol mistranslated the Arabic script.

title: Post at the Brink Again as Owner Seeks Wage Cuts
description: The New York Post, which has lost money for decades, is at death's door for the second time in two and a half years, and union leaders met all day yesterday with representatives of the paper's owner in an effort to hammer out an agreement that would keep it alive.

title: Yields Mixed Amid Worry
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: Miscellany
description: * Saatchi & Saatchi has decided not to sell Siegel & Gale, a corporate-identify firm, back to its management, according to Alan Siegel, chairman and chief executive of Siegel & Gale. Saatchi acquired the firm in 1985 and was expected to resell the New York-based company last summer.

title: Pakistan Files More Charges Of Corruption Under Bhutto
description: The charges were filed in the provincial capital of Punjab, before a special single-judge court set up by the caretaker Government to try graft cases and disqualify candidates from the scheduled Oct. 24 election.

title: Trial Begins for 10 Accused of Running Drug Ring
description: At the opening of a Federal narcotics trial yesterday, the prosecutor portrayed the 10 defendants as the operators of ''one of the largest, one of the most effective and one of the most violent drug organizations ever to invade the streets of Brooklyn.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title: Flatley Signs Contract
description: Patrick Flatley, who overcame knee surgery to become the Islanders' highest-scoring forward last season, has re-signed with the club.

title: Paul Magriel, 84, Collector of Art And Tour Guide at the Met, Dies
description: Paul Magriel, an art collector, connoisseur and former tour guide at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84 years old. He died of a heart attack, a spokesman for the family said. Mr. Magriel was educated at Columbia University, and in his early years became involved with the dance world. He was librarian at the American School of Ballet and was later curator of the dance archives at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Federal Courts Moving to Permit Trial Coverage by Radio and TV
description: Burger Opposed Cameras

title: Clean Air Bills Are Likely to Cost More Than Anyone Expected
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Lamplit Whimsies (Mind the Dogs)
description: AT Judyth van Amringe's new store in SoHo, lamps wear hats, standard black poodles lounge on a floor that is stenciled with yet more poodles and goldfish swim in ornate wrought-iron bowls. The pets are not for sale, but everything else is.

title: Zeckendorf Feels Pinch On 2 Projects
description: William Zeckendorf Jr., who is considered to be one of the most conservative of the city's large developers, is being pinched by New York's troubled real estate market.

title: Troops' Message to Powell: When Can We Go Home?
description: Wherever Gen. Colin L. Powell went today on his tour of American forces here, he was confronted with one question: When can we go home?

title: Review/Film;   Love and Pain Among the Gentry in Ireland
description: Pat O'Connor's ''Fools of Fortune,'' which opens today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, wears a solemn expression that is appropriate for a sad romantic melodrama set against the background of Ireland's fight for independence. The approach is serious, the performances are sincere and the physical production is impressive. Yet ''Fools of Fortune'' quite often seems desperate to the point of being unhinged.

title: Francis A. Goodhue Jr., Lawyer, 74
description: Francis A. Goodhue Jr., a Manhattan tax lawyer for 50 years, died yesterday at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Mount Kisco.

title: Ban on Mossad Book Is Overturned
description: The Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court, overturning a ruling made Wednesday by a State Supreme Court justice, lifted a ban on the United States publication of a book by a former member of Mossad, an Israeli intelligence service.

title: Review/Film;   Bach in Hell's Kitchen, and the Gang's all There
description: Every gangster story needs its loose cannon, the individual scary and erratic enough to take the possibility of danger way beyond the theoretical. Better still if that character, like Sonny Corleone of ''The Godfather'' or Robert De Niro's Johnny Boy in ''Mean Streets,'' is also vastly sympathetic, despite his own least enlightened or charitable instincts.

title: Accounts
description: * Beech-Nut Nutrition Corp., Fort Washington, Pa., a subsidiary of the Ralston Purina Co., to DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago, for its baby food products. Billings were not disclosed. DDB Needham handles several other Ralston Purina accounts.

title: Florida St. Invited To Join A.C.C.
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference voted today to invite Florida State to join the eight-team league.

title: Post for Bob Boone
description: A National League expansion franchise is still just a dream in Orlando, Fla., but the team's manager became a reality yesterday. Orlando Pro Baseball Inc. named the 43-year-old Kansas City Royal catcher, Bob Boone, a 19-year major league veteran, to run its team, if the group is awarded one. The group also named a former major league infielder, Denny Doyle, as director of baseball operations and his brother, Brian, as director of development.(AP)

title: Guard Hurt Saving Student
description: A 74-year-old school crossing guard was seriously injured Wednesday when he tried to shield a student from a car, the police said today. The guard, Michael De Marco, was in an intersection six blocks from Leonard V. Moore School when he unsuccessfully tried to keep Henry Manesis, 12, from being hit. The boy suffered a broken arm. The driver, Marilyn Samuel, 37, of Roselle, told the police she did not see Mr. De Marco. She was cited for careless driving.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: CHRONICLE
description: TOMMY TUNE has won the Jean Cocteau International Style Award. ''For his elegant presence, an unparalleled style and innovative force in the theater,'' said TONY CLARK, executive director of the Severin Wunderman Museum in Irvine, Calif., which says it has the largest collection of Cocteau works.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Anglo American, Johannesburg, will go ahead with its mining project in the Moab area, 100 miles southwest of Johannesburg.

title: Nets' Talks With Coleman Are Yielding Little Progress
description: Derrick Coleman will not be signing a contract with the Nets this week. He may not sign next week. And with each week that passes, the possibility increases that Coleman will be unsigned when training camp opens next month.

title: Excerpts From First Senate Session on the Souter Nomination
description: Following are excerpts from today's opening session of Senate Judiciary Committee hearings on the nomination of David H. Souter to the Supreme Court, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: Dow Drops by 43.07, To 2,582.67
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in repeated waves of computerized program selling, with the Dow Jones industrial average sliding 43.07, or 1.64 percent, to 2,582.67.

title: Bessie Awards and Politics
description: The New York Dance and Performance Awards, also known as the Bessies, honor performers, choreographers, composers and designers with cash prizes in a yearly event that also includes performances and a good deal of amusing onstage repartee. But the Seventh Annual Bessies, held on Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, took on a new and urgent political tone after the recent resignations of this year's co-hosts, Karen Finley and Danitra Vance.

title: Navy Finds No Wrongdoing By I.B.M. in Procurements
description: The Navy Department said in a report released today that it had found no evidence that the International Business Machines Corporation violated Federal contracting laws in procuring Navy contracts.

title: Kohl Vows to Widen Role in Gulf Effort
description: Apparently trying to curb Congressional anger that Bonn is not pulling its weight in the Persian Gulf, Chancellor Helmut Kohl pledged more help today, but was meager with details.

title: 2 Nations May Leave Liberian Peace Force
description: West African troops evacuated 1,000 people today from the mansion of the country's slain President, but two members of the five-nation peacekeeping force said they were reconsidering their role.

title: Printer System From Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced a printing system today that will let personal computer users hook up with high-speed printers previously reserved for mainframes.

title: Guitar-Piano Duets
description: The Schanzer-Speach Duo - Jeffrey Schanzer, guitarist, and Bernadette Speach, pianist - will perform new collaborative compositions and improvisations at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street, tomorrow evening at 8. Thomas Buckner, a baritone, and Barbara Held, a flutist, will perform with the ensemble. Tickets are $5. Information: 219-8242.

title: Greenspan Urges Cautious Moves To Shore Up the Banking System
description: Warning Congress to move cautiously in trying to cure the ailing banking system, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that increasing the premiums that institutions pay to the declining fund that insures bank deposits could be more harmful than helpful, threatening some banks with insolvency.

title: Hamilton to Drill For North Sea Gas
description: The Hamilton Oil Company and four partners plan to tap a giant natural gas reserve off the coast of Scotland, in a $2.85 billion deal that could create the largest gas project in the British North Sea. The British Department of Energy agreed to allow Denver-based Hamilton and its partners to drill a series of wells in the Bruce field, 240 miles northeast of Aberdeen, Scotland.

title: Illuminating Man Ray As Fashion Photographer
description: Man Ray came out of an era when photographers painted with light. There is a stillness about his fashion photography: stark, static studio images of models in black lace, organdy silk and embroidered crepe, their arms stretched skyward, their faces lighted from above. His women never look into the camera. They seem to be in no particular space or place. They look chipped out of marble.

title: Rights-Group Report Asserts Syria Tortures and Kills Political Foes
description: Middle East Watch, an independent human-rights group, has issued a report asserting that Syria systematically kills and tortures political opponents and persecutes ethnic and religious minorities.

title: Crisis Spurs Campaign To Save Oil
description: IN response to the crisis in the Middle East, the Federal Government began a yearlong public service campaign yesterday that urges Americans to ''Do Your Part, Drive Smart.''

title: Dinkins Assails Bashing of New York
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins lashed out at the ''bashing and trashing'' of cities, and encouraged people to visit New York City in a speech today that was meant to counter the idea that crime in the city has grown out of control.

title: Souter Tacks Over Shoals;   Bork's Defeat Echoes as Questioning Starts
description: Even as he refused to give his views on the Supreme Court's abortion precedents, David H. Souter used the opening day of his confirmation hearing to assure senators that they could trust him as a judge of moderate instincts, able to understand and sympathize with the dilemmas of modern life and ordinary people.

title: Review/Film;   Ghost Tales in Cowboy Lands
description: What is an actor of the stature of James Earl Jones doing in a film like ''Grim Prairie Tales,'' a quartet of limp ghost stories set in the Wild West?

title: Review/Film;   Eastwood Follows The Trail Of the Elusive, Essential Huston
description: In 1951, while in central Africa to prepare for the filming of ''The African Queen,'' John Huston embarked upon a brief safari with his sound man. ''How often have you been elephant hunting, John?'' the sound man asked during the course of the trip.

title: Texas A&M Fined
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has fined Texas A&M $1,000 and publicly reprimanded the school for not reporting the ineligibility of an athlete before the 1990 track championships.

title: Multimedia President Departs for Classroom
description: James T. Lynagh has resigned as president and chief operating officer of Multimedia Inc., which owns newspapers, broadcast stations, cable franchies and television programming, including the Phil Donahue show.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Airgas Inc., Radnor, Pa., appointed Britton H. Murdoch vice president of finance, chief financial officer and treasurer. John P. McNiff was named vice president of corporate development.

title: John E. Reeves, Executive, 77
description: John E. Reeves, former chairman of Reeves Brothers, Inc., a Manhattan textile manufacturer, died on Tuesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Summit.

title: Yankees Overcome Blunders And Tigers
description: On a warmish evening in this cozy old downtown ball yard, the Yankees played about the way a last-place team is expected to play in the last month of a lost season.

title: Top Research Partner To Quit Goldman, Sachs
description: Michael Armellino, partner in charge of research at Goldman, Sachs and a top-ranked airline analyst, plans to step down Dec. 1, he said yesterday.

title: Fannie Gelb, Dress Designer, 94
description: Fannie Gelb, a children's dress designer, died on Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 94 years old and was a resident of the Jewish Home and Hospital in the Bronx.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Sentimental Lizards

title: Split, Catholic Bishops Defer Proposals on Women's Issues
description: A final decision on a seven-year effort by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops to set church policy on issues of concern to women, from abortion to sexual discrimination to ordination, was postponed indefinitely yesterday under the weight of criticism from both liberals and conservatives in the church.

title:
Connecticut Projects;

No Car Needed at This Suburban Condo
description: LEAD: Dependence on the automobile is usually unavoidable in new suburban developments, but a builder has tried to make car ownership optional for residents of a 167-unit condominium being built on Forest Avenue in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: SUNY and CUNY: Taxpayer Frauds
description: LEAD: The fiscal problems of the State University of New York and the City University of New York have grabbed the attention of the news media. But the troubles that plague the university system today are rooted deeply in a variety of circumstances that have a long history.

title: Mexican Free Trade Pact Pushed
description: President Bush, acting more swiftly than expected, will ask Congress next week for authority to negotiate a comprehensive free trade agreement with Mexico, Administration officials said today. Though not the only reason, the Persian Gulf crisis was a factor in the decision, they said.

title: Congress to Take New Look at Racketeering Law
description: Congress is poised to consider a measure that critics contend would protect many individuals and businesses charged with white-collar crime - including those involved in the savings and loan scandal - from civil suits.

title: Review/Film;   A Search for a Fictive Father
description: It is a sad indication of the insularity of American cinema that Theo Angelopoulos, a Greek director with international stature, is virtually unknown in the United States. The 53-year-old Athens-born film maker, whose 1988 epic ''Landscape in the Mist'' opens today at the Public Theater, belongs to a stately modernist tradition that embraces figures as divergent as Michelangelo Antonioni, Robert Bresson and Wim Wenders.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 522 money market mutual funds increased $474.2 million, to $407.01 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 162 institutional funds decreased by $252 million, to $97.64 billion. The assets of the 255 general-purpose funds were up by $118 million, to $143.8 billion. The 105 broker-dealer funds increased by $608.2 million, to $165.57 billion, the institute said.

title: Review/Film;   New Life for an Iranian Boy Seeking Refuge From War
description: Airborne danger hovers over the 10-year-old title character of the Iranian film ''Bashu, the Little Stranger,'' but it changes as radically as the young boy's surroundings do. He is at the Persian Gulf as the film begins, experiencing the terrors of an Iraqi air raid (the film has silhouetted warplanes flying behind its opening titles) and watching in anguish as the bombing kills his parents and destroys his home. After this, Bashu stows away on a northbound truck and winds up in a greener, more peaceful part of his native land, where the greatest danger comes from birds of prey.

title: Bid for Allegheny Close to Approval
description: A bankruptcy judge said today that he expected to sign an order clearing the way for Japonica Partners, an investment group, to take control of Allegheny International Inc., an appliance manufacturer. Judge Joseph Cosetti said he planned to sign the order by Friday.

title: John Bowlby, Psychiatric Pioneer On Mother-Child Bond, Dies at 83
description: Dr. John Bowlby, the British psychiatrist whose work on the bond between mother and child profoundly influenced psychotherapy and child psychology, died Sept. 2 at his vacation home on the Isle of Skye. He was 83 years old.

title: You Can't Take the Politics Out of the Court;   Griswold v. Connecticut
description: To the Editor:

title: Frank David Kitchin, Doctor, 66
description: Frank David Kitchin, the director of the department of Occupational Health at New York Hospital, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 66 years old.

title: Pop/Jazz;   With Words and Music, A Union is Forged
description: Rock-and-roll, jazz and poetry will come a little closer together tonight at Tramps when the guitarist Marc Ribot performs with his group Rootless Cosmopolitans on a bill with the poet Allen Ginsberg. Both are celebrating album releases: Mr. Ribot's autonomous debut album with the Rootless Cosmopolitans is just out on the Antilles label, while Island Records is rereleasing Mr. Ginsberg's 1989 spoken-word-and-avant-garde-jazz recording ''The Lion for Real.''

title: A Top Official At Newsday Is Promoted
description: The associate publisher of Newsday, Steven L. Isenberg, who played a key role in developing New York Newsday, has been appointed executive vice president for marketing for The Los Angeles Times.

title: A World of Good Reading Comes to Fifth Avenue
description: The longest bookshelf in town, maybe in the world, will be installed along nine blocks of Fifth Avenue on Sunday. Not only will the 12th annual New York Is Book Country street fair speak volumes, as it usually does; this year it will revel in the gift of tongues.

title: Samuel S. Stratton, 73, Former Congressman, Dies
description: Samuel S. Stratton, a former Congressman who represented the Albany and Schenectady area for 30 years and was a longtime member of the House Armed Services Committee, died yesterday at Shady Grove Hospital in Gaithersburg, Md. He was 73 years old and had lived for the last year in the Manor Care nursing home in Potomac, Md.

title: You Can't Take the Politics Out of the Court;   The Ninth Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounting Panel Postpones Vote on Bank Write-Downs
description: Bowing to pressure from the banking community, a leading rule-making body yesterday postponed voting on a plan to require banks to write down certain losing investments on a quarterly basis. Instead, the group voted unanimously to require the banks to describe their holdings more fully in the footnotes to their financial statements.

title: Moscow and Bonn in a 'Good Neighbor' Pact
description: The Soviet Union and West Germany today initialed a broad ''treaty on good-neighborliness, partnership and cooperation'' setting a framework for relations between Moscow and a united Germany.

title: U.N. Council Votes Strict Limits On Food Aid to Iraq and Kuwait
description: The Security Council voted overwhelmingly tonight to adopt a plan setting tight limits on humanitarian food supplies sent to Iraq and occupied Kuwait.

title: Her Car Towed, a Woman Learns New York's Lessons
description: Stephanie Gorski of Wyckoff, N.J., drove into midtown Manhattan yesterday on what she thought would be a simple errand. Instead, the 23-year-old woman became the center of attention on West 45th Street -and learned something about New Yorkers that she had never dreamed possible.

title: Kuwait Urges Exiled Citizens To Register in Armed Forces
description: The Kuwaiti Government today urged its nationals who have fled to other Persian Gulf countries to join the armed forces so they could help drive out the Iraqis occupying their country.

title: Michael Cooke, 56, Literature Professor At Yale and Author
description: Michael G. Cooke, a professor of English at Yale University and an authority on the English Romantic Movement and African and Caribbean literature, died on Tuesday at St. Raphael's Hospital in New Haven. He had turned 56 years old on Tuesday and lived in Bethany, Conn.

title: Foes of Mubarak Question U.S. Aims and Are Barred From Peace Journey
description: As the magnitude of American military involvement in the Persian Gulf becomes increasingly clear to them, opposition politicians in Egypt have begun to question Washington's long-term intentions in the region and Cairo's close association with them.

title: An $800 Million Windfall
description: LEAD: With differences between Congressional budget negotiators narrowing, an extra billion a year in found money could be the grease that makes the wheels spin. We know a place where that sort of money can be found -$800 million a year for the next eight years, with no new taxes and no strings attached.

title: Critic's Choice
description: The World Music Institute presents traditional, classical and folk music from every part of the world, and in this reviewer's experience, the organization's instincts are as sure as they are broad. Most weekends from September through June - and sometimes during the week - the organization offers two or three concerts featuring performers who are renowned in their own cultures, and in many cases have been heard about (if not actually heard) in the United States.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Feast of San Gennaro, which began yesterday and runs through Sept. 23, Mulberry Street between Canal and Prince Streets will be closed from 11 A.M. to 11:30 P.M. daily.

title: E. Ralph Lacey, 78; Designed Submarines
description: E. Ralph Lacey, a naval architect and marine engineer who in a 41-year career with the Navy specialized in the preliminary design of submarines, died on Friday at the Saybrook Convalescent Home in Old Saybrook, Conn. He was 78 years old and lived in Lyme, Conn.

title: Islanders' Roster Poses Unanswered Questions
description: As their nine-game preseason schedule begins Friday night against the Boston Bruins in the Nassau Coliseum, the Islanders have enough question marks on their club to fill a punctuation guide.

title: Cuomo Says 'No New Taxes' Is Not an 'Absolute' Promise
description: Issuing one of the more elastic versions of a ''no new taxes'' pledge, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he planned to hold the line on tax increases next year but could not make an ''absolute'' promise because of uncertainty over the state's economy and the Federal budget.

title: Restaurants
description: A French bistro reopens with a more international menu and without its Surrealist gallery.

title: Forgive Them Not
description: ''There are only two groups that are beating the drums for war in the Middle East - the Israeli Defense Ministry and its amen corner in the United States.''

title: Without Money or Choices, Philadelphia Plans Big Cuts
description: The city's financial problems assumed grim reality today as a plan for obtaining temporary financing on Wall Street collapsed and officials began discussing drastic cuts in city services.

title: Let Donor Interests Prevail in Transplant
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Report Killing 2 Gunmen In Street Incidents in 2 Boroughs
description: Two men with guns were shot and killed by New York City police officers in separate incidents Wednesday night and yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Review/Film;   Mauled, Even Eaten, By Junk
description: ''Hardware'' is a sci-fi-horror film of such dopiness that it seems certain to become a cult classic somewhere. Movies that are so insistently silly often have the effect of seeming to expand the mind after midnight, which may have something to do with metabolism if not with controlled substances.

title: Milacron Selling Robotics Division
description: ABB Robotics Inc. has signed a letter of intent to buy the industrial robot business of Cincinnati Milacron Inc. The division includes a plant in Greenwood, S.C., and its 200 employees. The companies declined to disclose the sale price.

title: Red Sox Maintain 4-Game Lead
description: Ivan Calderon, batting leadoff for the first time in his career, doubled to start a tie-breaking three-run third inning and broke the game open with a three-run homer in the fourth tonight, leading the Chicago White Sox to a 9-6 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: You Can't Take the Politics Out of the Court;   George Bush's Lawyer
description: To the Editor:

title: Mehta, Rostropovich And a Study in Synergy
description: One of Zubin Mehta's strengths as a conductor is his ability to take fire from a soloist whose playing throws off inspirational sparks. The New York Philharmonic's music director had just such a congenial partner on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, where he and the cellist Mstislav Rostropovich made an incendiary combination. The concert, a benefit for the orchestra's pension fund that was Mr. Mehta's 1,000th appearance with the Philharmonic, was essentially a showcase for Mr. Rostropovich's irresistible brand of music making. However, there proved to be enough honor to be shared by everyone concerned.

title: Mehta and Mahler's 3d
description: Zubin Mehta will conduct the New York Philharmonic, the Westminster Symphonic Choir and the American Boychoir in the Mahler Symphony No. 3 at Avery Fisher Hall tonight at 8. The mezzo-soprano Florence Quivar is to be the soloist. The program will be repeated tomorrow evening at 8. Tickets are $10 to $43. Information: 580-8700.

title: Review/Film;   Gleaning a Killing Ground
