He was 63 years old. He died of intestinal cancer, said his brother, Dr. Sherwin B. Nuland of Hamden, Conn.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Good News Takes Care
description: It's all done but the parades. D-day, ''Deutschland-day'' in Eurojargon, is Oct. 3. United Germany will elect its first postwar government Dec. 2. There will be no more occupation rights but certain obligations.

title: Seattle Tunnel to Open
description: A $459 million bus tunnel is scheduled to open Saturday after four years of ripped-up streets and traffic nightmares, offering to speed commuters through congested downtown in about one-third the time it takes on the surface. The two-lane tunnel is expected to reduce downtown bus traffic 25 percent by next fall and 40 percent by the end of the decade.

title: U.S. to Sell Saudis $20 Billion in Arms; Weapons Deal Is Largest in History
description: In the single largest arms sale ever, the United States has agreed to sell Saudi Arabia about $20 billion in advanced weapons and technical support over several years, the Pentagon said today.

title: Iran Frees U.S. Prisoner Amid Conciliation Signs
description: The State Department announced today that Iran had released an American citizen who had been held in an Iranian prison since October 1984.

title: Jason Honigman, 85, Ex-Michigan Lawyer
description: Jason L. Honigman, a corporate lawyer and the founder of one of Michigan's most powerful law firms, died Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Mich. He was 85 years old.

title: Queens Senate Write-In Primary Aids the G.O.P.
description: The odds that the Democrats will take control of the State Senate were downgraded today when Senator Serphin R. Maltese was declared the winner of an unusual write-in primary for the Republican nomination in his Queens district.

title: '60 Minutes,' a Success Story and Still Counting
description: The CBS newsmagazine program, ''60 Minutes,'' is not only the longest-running prime-time program on television, it is also, says Don Hewitt, the program's creator and executive producer, the most successful television program of any kind in the medium's history.

title: Officers Wound Three Men In Drug Raid in Manhattan
description: Three men were shot by police officers in an apartment on 135th Street after one of them fired at the officers during a drug raid, the police said.

title: Cost of S.&L. Deals In '88 Put at Double The Initial Estimate
description: A Congressional review has found that the Government's sale of nearly 100 failing savings institutions in 1988 to private investors will cost taxpayers $71 billion, almost double the amount originally projected by regulators two years ago.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor: The article about Italian gelato ''Ice Cream for La Dolce Vita'' (Travel, Aug. 19) brought back fond memories. I wonder if you can still buy gelato on the roof of the Duomo in Milan. Or even if you can still go up and walk around on the roof. It was wonderful to sit at the peak admiring the view, dripping ice cream and thinking with awe of that huge open area under us.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ORIGINS: The Lives and Worlds of Modern Cosmologists. By Alan Lightman and Roberta Brawer. (Harvard University, $29.95). Of all the sciences, cosmology cuts closest to the emotional bone, daring a scientific answer to the kinds of questions children wonder about: How far does the world go? Does time have a beginning or an end? ''Cosmic questions start inside,'' say Alan Lightman, a professor of science and writing at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Roberta Brawer, a graduate student there. Armed with a tape recorder, they sought out 27 cosmologists and asked them about their childhoods, philosophical preferences and personal reactions to recent developments in their field. There is a lot to talk about. Emboldened by the discovery of faint radio waves lingering from the putative big bang with which the universe began, astronomers and particle physicists have joined forces in the last few years and succeeded in unraveling a plausible history of the universe back to the first fiery picosecond of recorded time. Yet so much remains unexplained, the voices in this book remind us over and over, that the entire edifice often seems to teeter one datum point from disgrace. The subjects, who include astronomers, physicists, observers, theorists and even one nonbeliever in the big bang - Fred Hoyle - come across as a friendly, if driven, bunch (most had settled on science before adolescence and have never looked back) and disarmingly frank about the uncertainties and pitfalls in the cosmic quest. Margaret Geller, whose maps of the universe have helped subvert several cherished theories, says: ''I think it's hard in this field to really have the courage of your convictions. You have to have a sense of humor about it because the likelihood of ever being right is so low.'' General readers may struggle with a crisp scientific summary that is as unrelenting as it is lucid, and they may be exasperated when the authors, who are physicists, cut off juicy reminiscences to return to the drier parts of their agenda. However, ''Origins'' should prove invaluable to scholars, journalists and perhaps novelists who want to launch their own investigations of how we came to think of the world as we do.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have dark paneling that I would like to paint over in a light color. Over the years, I have used various spray-on furniture waxes and polishes on this paneling, and I am wondering how to prepare the surface for painting. Can I use a chemical de-glossing liquid, or do I have to sand the panels?

title: Doing the Right Thing With Compost
description: RECYCLING is the right thing to do. With so much focus, and rightly so, on overstuffed landfills, gardeners are learning that they can do their part if they compost.

title: Question of the Week;   Are Umpires Getting Too Aggressive?
description: The question is not whether umpires are getting too aggressive, but whether they are responding inappropriately to the lack of respect they receive. In football, basketball and hockey, officials are authority figures who are given very little ''lip'' by the coaches and athletes. In baseball, throughout its history, umpires have been verbally abused by managers and players to the delight of the fans. The umpires' current aggressiveness is a response that I sympathize with.

title: Susan Malamed, Lawyer, Marries
description: Susan Jane Malamed and Eric Rieder were married last evening at the Hotel Westbury in New York by Rabbi Thomas Weiner. The bride, who is keeping her name, is a daughter of Seymour H. Malamed of New York and the late Doris Malamed. Her husband is a son of Dolly Rieder of Philadelphia and the late Fredric N. Rieder.

title: Q and A
description: Sponsor-Management Tie

title: Initiative Amendment: Dissenting Views
description: The arguments against initiative and referendum to counteract Governor Florio's big pocket lightener are antiquated and confused. At the end of Mr. Hochbaum's article he calls voting a more effective way to express dissatisfaction. Well, what else is a referendum - is it not the most democratic form of a vote? Its direct action returns that power to those to whom it really belongs.

title: Briton Who Leaked Army Report Wins Fight
description: A former civilian employee of the British Army who has said he helped wage campaigns of disinformation about the Irish Republican Army and politicians in the 1970's has won compensation for being unfairly dismissed from his job.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Weill Sampler Offers Fine Singing
description: ONE song contains the lyric ''For once do something bad and you'll survive.'' Another sings of ''faith and trust in mankind.''

title: Cara Silverman Is Married
description: Cara Beth Silverman and Anthony Adam Faske were married last evening at the Ridgeway Country Club in White Plains by Rabbi Norton Shargel. Mrs. Faske, 27 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Silverman of Mount Kisco, N.Y. Mr. Faske, 28, is a son of Phyllis Faske of Long Beach, L.I., and Leonard Faske of Hewlett, L.I. Both are graduates of Syracuse University. She is a vice president at Chavin Lambert Advertising in New York. He is a co-publisher of The Manhattan Pennysaver, a retail advertising weekly.

title: Tokyo
description: Tokyo shines in the fall. Enamel-blue skies polished bright by cool breezes replace the soggy haze hanging over this sprawling, concrete-coated metropolis during the summer. Usually scowling Japanese business executives ply the city's myriad alleys, neon-lit streets, parks, bars and homey restaurants in happy clusters.

title: Jenifer A. Smith Weds Francis Bacon Gilbert 3d
description: Jenifer Ann Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel J. Smith of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Francis Bacon Gilbert 3d, the son of Mr. Gilbert Jr. of Wilton, Conn., and the late Sandra Still Gilbert. The Rev. Robert F. Grippo performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: Correction
description: An article on Aug. 19 about career counseling for dancers misidentified a Canadian organization that works with retired dancers and characterized it incorrectly. The group is the Dancer Transition Center; it is independent and financed by the Canada Employment and Immigration Commission. The article also referred incorrectly to the center's founder, Joysanne Sidimus. She was a member of the New York City Ballet and a principal dancer of the National Ballet of Canada and the Pennsylvan

title: Wreck-Diving Beneath Truk's Blue Lagoon
description: LEAD: Viewed from a palm-studded Micronesian beach, Truk Lagoon looks peaceful. Children splash and giggle in the shallows. The waters go from turquoise green to sapphire blue, and in the distance, the jungles and peaks of other islands send clouds towering into the sky.

title: Love, Myth and Cold Winters
description: WONDERMONGER

title: The X-Factor Delivers a Championship
description: A young tennis player stares at her coach with empty eyes. Her passionless face tells it all: Why am I here? Where am I going? Is there a future for me?

title: The Peep Show As an Art Form
description: To the Editor:

title: Lifestyle;   Campus Cafes Attract 'Neo-Beatniks'
description: All the superficial signs of beatnik redux are there: the long hair or bob, the goatee and clothes that run from tie-dye T-shirts and salvaged Salvation Army pieces to Guatemalan ethnic and basic black.

title: U.S. Builds Up Power to Attack In a Gulf Clash
description: Five weeks after the first American forces arrived here, the United States is building up its offensive capability against Iraq, according to American officials.

title: 3 Teen-Agers Held in Shooting of Toddler
description: Three teen-age boys were arrested Friday in the wounding of a 2-year-old boy, but the shooting, which prompted outrage here, is not considered deliberate, the authorities said.

title: Miss Charyk Wed To C. R. Norris 3d
description: Diane Elizabeth Charyk, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph V. Charyk of Delray Beach, Fla., and Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday in Falmouth to Charles Rutter Norris 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norris Jr. of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Perry Haines officiated at the First Congregational Church.

title: Men, Women and Armageddon
description: To the Editor:

title: To Endangered List in Gulf, Add Archeology
description: Saddam Hussein, successor to the rulers of ancient Mesopotamia, the likes of Gilgamesh and Hammurabi, has clouded the prospects for explorations into the civilizations that produced the first writing and earliest experiments in agriculture and urban living.

title: Ohio St. Stops Boston College
description: Bobby Olive caught two scoring passes today and Ohio State's improved defense kept Boston College without an offensive touchdown this season in a 31-10 victory.

title: Michele Monagas Wed to T. J. Turner
description: Michele L. Monagas, the daughter of Lionel J. Monagas of Willow Grove, Pa., and the late Natalie L. Hinderas, was married yesterday to Timothy J. Turner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Turner of Sioux City, Iowa. The Rev. Edward Barry performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Judith Jackson Weds B. D. Haims
description: Judith Jackson and Bruce D. Haims were married yesterday at the bridegroom's weekend home in Pawling, N.Y. The Rev. M. Fletcher Davis, an Episcopal priest, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Roaming Australia On a Bus Pass
description: Outside the cities, roads in Australia narrow to two lanes: one for coming and one for going. Traffic and towns are scarce. Dust is abundant. Occasionally the multitrailer rigs called road trains lumber onto the horizon, then they roar into the past. At night, the great round moon, the stars and headlights show the way. The roads seem anomalous, strange black strips in the landscape. The two lanes run straight on, hypnotically straight on until morning.

title: Question of the Week;   Are Umpires Getting Too Aggressive?
description: Now Joe West and the baseball umpires are on trial. What an outrage. Anyone who saw the disgraceful display by the Mets and Phillies that dreadful evening can testify to the total breakdown of order. Had the umpires done nothing, it is certain that they would have been criticized for not taking action.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Souter Anecdote: Off the Cuff or From the Script?
description: While David H. Souter seemed to satisfy the Senate Judiciary Committee this week that he was no longer what one Senator called ''the Stealth nominee'' to the Supreme Court, he has not convinced everyone.

title: Teufel a Man For All Positions
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
MUSIC;

Research on Chopin Leads to a Prized Pupil
description: LEAD: THE musicologist Ferdinand Gajewski, whose recent book was cited for its scholarly commentary on the sketches of Chopin's last published work, has turned his attention to the life and music of a Chopin pupil who won acclaim but died at the age of 15.

title: Currency;   A Little Rally That Went Poof
description: The dollar put on a little rally last week against the German mark, inching up above 1.59 marks. But Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, ended the rally quickly on Thursday. He told the House Banking Committee that the Fed would ease interest rates if the White House and Congress came up with a credible agreement to cut the budget deficit. Although Mr. Greenspan had said such things before, it was enough to send the dollar reeling against all major currencies. With a boost from Mideast jitters on Friday, the dollar managed to finish a little up for the week against the mark. As for the yen, it continued its rally against the dollar and other major currencies. On Friday, the yen was at its highest level since August 1989.

title: Michigan Upstages Yanks-Tigers
description: The crisp evening temperatures, falling from the low 60's to the high 50's, weren't the only element that lent an air of football to the baseball game here at Tiger Stadium tonight.

title: Human Differences
description: To the Editor:

title: Prokofiev's 'Nevsky' For Music Video Fans
description: THE Hartford Symphony is offering the ultimate music video next weekend with its New England premiere of the recently restored 1938 Russian film ''Alexander Nevsky.'' Sergei Prokofiev's original score will be performed by a 94-piece orchestra with the Yale Russian Chorus and the Hartford Chorale.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

A Converter Tries a New Condo Project
description: LEAD: The realities have been enough to daunt most of the state's residential builders: an uncertain economic climate, tight financing, slow sales and an oversupply of new and resale houses.

title: Museum Researcher And His Wife Die In a Crash in France
description: Dr. Leonid Tarassuk, an expert on arms and armor at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and his wife, the former Nina Rostovzova, died in an automobile accident on Tuesday in the village of Quimper in the Brittany section of France, officials of the museum reported.

title: Ms. McAllister Weds C.C. Platt
description: Maureen Jean McAllister and Charles Collier Platt were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee.

title:
DINING OUT;

Where the Unusual Becomes a Standard
description: LEAD: THE inspiration for Richard Tozzi's newest restaurant in Madison is the Humphrey Bogart-Ingrid Bergman movie ''Casablanca.'' Although the name is Richard's Cafe Americain instead of Rick's, and there is very little inside reminiscent of Morocco, Mr. Tozzi has nonetheless managed to make the tiny restaurant into a romantic gem that the two erstwhile lovers would have found appealing.

title: Stoppard's Film Wins Top Award in Venice
description: The British playwright Tom Stoppard won the Venice film festival's top award, the Golden Lion, today for his first film, ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead.''

title: 'I'm Kitty Dukakis and I'm ...'
description: NOW YOU KNOW

title: Kate J. Weiner Is Married to Robert J. Webber
description: Kate J. Weiner and Robert J. Webber were married yesterday in Schenectady, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Davis Jr., a Congregational minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the First Reformed Church.

title: Redskins Receivers Eager to Meet 49ers
description: When the Washington Redskins round up their posse this afternoon in a marquee clash against the San Francisco 49ers at Candlestick Park, featuring the two teams that won the most games in the last decade, peace and order will be far from the Redskins' minds.

title: Gertrude Was Not a Dope
description: HAMLET'S MOTHER

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: Traci Reed Wed To William Dippy
description: Traci Reed, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Reed of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to William Bradner Dippy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Dippy 3d of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Philip E. Perkins officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: Upper-Class Artists?
description: To the Editor:

title: She Wants to Be a Human
description: LEAD:

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: That old pro Clive Egleton is at it again with IN THE RED (St. Martin's, $17.95). For about 20 years this British author has been writing espionage novels of the highest category. Himself a former intelligence officer who served in various countries, he knows the setup as only one who worked in it can. More important, he is a fine stylist, writing with a certain amount of British reserve but never letting it interfere with hectic action and a straight, coherent story line.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: MYRA M. OLIVER;

Institute Turns Refugees Into Americans
description: LEAD: EACH year, the International Institute of Connecticut assists 5,000 to 6,000 foreign-born people and their families with immigration and resettlement services. In 1989, people from 99 countries received assistance, said Myra M. Oliver, executive director of the agency. The institute also helped 350 people become American citizens and 180 refugees become permanent residents of the United

title: Kyoto's Fragrant Green Teas
description: The inner surface of the small, blush glazed cup is netted with dark cracks, their pattern visible through the nearly transparent, jade green liquid that fills the cup, warm but not hot to the touch. A fresh green fragrance escapes from the cup. The first sip is astringent, yet has a sweetness that is not that of sugar but of the scent of green things. That special sweetness is characteristic of tea from Uji, southeast of central Kyoto and the major tea-growing area for Kyoto - the home of the tea ceremony - and for western Japan.

title: All Shakespeare's Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: Green Acres Steps Up Drive Against Crime
description: LEAD: FACED with a history of security problems and a persistent negative image, the Green Acres Mall has joined the 5th Police Precinct in an anti-crime program that, the shopping center says, is producing results. But some nearby residents are not sure about the effects. The second-largest mall on Long Island and a highly profitable shopping center, Green Acres has the size and location on Sunrise Highway in Valley Stream at the Nassau County-Queens line that help account for its profitability and its problems.

title: Initiative Amendment: Dissenting Views
description: The initiative and referendum article prompts these thoughts.

title: Smithsonian's Road Show Rolls into Greenwich
description: LEAD: THE Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington will be reunited with its Connecticut roots when the Smithsonian Institution opens the fall cultural season in Greenwich with lectures, seminars and a concert. Topics will range from art to the American Indians, music to historic preservation, in seven diverse events condensed into a three-day weekend beginning on

title: Campus Life: SUNY, Albany;   Faculty Seeking A Stronger Voice On Sports Issue
description: Despite a desire in many quarters for the State University of New York at Albany to move into big-time athletics, a large number of faculty members served notice last week that they may not be willing to let it happen without a fight.

title: Front and Center for the Blue and Gray
description: ''War is hell'' ranks among our most familiar sayings. All but unknown, however, is the rest of that quotation, which goes in part: ''I am sick and tired of war. . . . It is only those who have neither fired a shot nor heard the shrieks and groans of the wounded who cry aloud for blood, more vengeance, more desolation.''

title:
The View From: The Music and Art Center for the Handicapped;

'We Now Serve Anyone Who Can Benefit'
description: LEAD: AFTER a dozen years, the organization in Bridgeport that was known as the Music Foundation for the Visually Handicapped and later as the Music Foundation for the Handicapped has yet another name and a wider scope. But its mission remains enriching the lives of people with disabilities.

title: Love Canal Video Criticized as Misleading
description: The state agency trying to sell homes at Love Canal could face a lawsuit if it does not change a ''misleading and incorrect'' videotape, the State Attorney General's office said.

title: Florio and the Need to Raise Taxes
description: We always hear about the lack of vision by our political officials, yet we are experiencing a resurgence of leadership in New Jersey.

title: A Dream Turned Deadly
description: On Thursday July 26, a dark-green garbage bag washed up onto a beach in Long Branch, N.J.

title: Jill Kaplin Is Bride Of Andrew L. Herz
description: Jill M. Kaplin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maury I. Kaplin of Toledo, Ohio, was married last evening to Andrew L. Herz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Herz of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Richard Chapin officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Days of Murder Dim the Hopes of South Africa
description: Anyone scheming to scuttle the hopes of those South Africans working to dismantle apartheid could hardly have devised a more destructive scenario than the seemingly random violence that spilled more black blood in and around Johannesburg last week. The killings, including a gang attack inside a commuter train to Soweto that left at least 26 people dead and well over 100 injured, have become so predictable in their senselessness that it is not hard to understand why some South Africans see malicious method to the madness erupting around them.

title: Glas(s)nost on 67th St.
description: The Soviet Mission to the United Nations is a squarish, white-brick building that looks like just another squarish, white-brick apartment house on Manhattan's Upper East Side, except for police standing watch at its door day and night. Until last week, the door at 136 East 67th Street was shrouded by curtains - not iron, but they might as well have been. No prying eyes penetrated Moscow's New York nest.

title: Pitt Is Smothered By Oklahoma, 52-10
description: Kenyon Rasheed, Ike Lewis and Dewell Brewer all ran for more than 100 yards today as Oklahoma flattened Pitt, 52-10, for the Sooners' second consecutive impressive victory.

title: STORE STYLE
description: MACY'S

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;

A Call for Saw Mill Parkway Proposals
description: LEAD: The New York State Department of Transportation is looking for proposals to redevelop two vacant service stations on the Saw Mill River Parkway in Hastings on Hudson for ''transportation-related'' uses, which could include gasoline stations, restaurants or tourism centers.

title: Ms. Woolf Is Wed To J.L. Feinberg
description: Stacey Lee Woolf, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Woolf of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married last evening in Boston to Jeffrey Louis Feinberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Feinberg of Bergenfield, N.J. Rabbi Alan Turetz officiated at the ceremony at the Copley Plaza hotel.

title: Campus Life: Brandeis-Holy Cross;   A Joint Program One Could Call Judeo-Catholic
description: Brandeis University, which has a large Jewish enrollment, and the College of the Holy Cross, a Roman Catholic institution in Worcester, are teaming up in a comparative-religion study program that officials hope will promote understanding between students of the two faiths.

title: 'Goodfellas' Looks at the Banality of Mob Life
description: Forget family ties. Forget the much-vaunted code of honor. Forget the tragic, eloquent grace of Francis Ford Coppola's ''Godfather'' movies and the cheerful inanity of Jonathan Demme's ''Married to the Mob.'' Martin Scorsese's blood-splattered new film, ''Goodfellas,'' is a splash of ice-cold water in the face of a public grown drunk on romantic myths about the mob.

title: Campus Life: Oberlin;   Six Housemates Bridge the Gap Of Generations
description: The day may come when all the residents of the Jeanne Beattie Butts House will get together to play a board game on the living-room floor. But the two elderly residents, ages 77 and 79, three college students and one recent graduate who are sharing a ground-breaking intergenerational house at Oberlin College have not come that far yet.

title: 'Moses und Aron' And Its Problems Finally Arrive
description: Arnold Schoenberg's ''Moses und Aron'' may well be the most important opera never given a New York staged production. But that neglect hasn't been for lack of trying. Christopher Keene, the New York City Opera's general director, who will finally bring the masterpiece to Lincoln Center Saturday night, first proposed that the company mount it eight years ago. In fact, Mr. Keene, on whose stark black desk Schoenberg's large yellow-bound score glows like a Holy Grail, says he can get so carried away by the opera ''that sometimes I just want to dwell over it like an old medievalist looking over his mystical books.''

title: It's Countdown Time for Macao
description: Knowing that both are doomed to extinction - at least in their present form - tiny Portuguese Macao is making a determined bid to take over Hong Kong's luster as a tourist mecca, particularly after the last two remaining foreign-ruled territories in China return to Beijing's rule, before the end of this century. There is a chance, albeit a remote chance, that Macao may succeed.

title: Ramapo Defeats Wagner by 31-14
description: Jim Grant, a junior quarterback, threw three touchdown passes and ran for a fourth as undefeated Ramapo overtook Wagner, 31-14, yesterday afternoon at Fisher Field in Grymes Hill, Staten Island.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

After the Hectic Hamptons, a Beachgoer Comes Home
description: LEAD: NINETEEN years ago, when I met my Long Island-born husband, he introduced me to the Long Island shoreline. For a young girl who had spent summers on the Sound in New London, that first encounter at Jones Beach let me know what a real beach was. Miles of white sand and a pounding surf made up for the tiresome schlep from the overwhelming parking lot.

title: Managing;   A Constructive Criticism Primer
description: An engineer presented a plan for developing new software to the vice president of his high-technology company. With his team, the engineer waited expectantly, hoping for praise and encouragement; the plan was the result of months of work.

title: Ms. Harshman Weds Ralph Johnston
description: Cecily Cooper Harshman and Ralph Thomas Johnston were married yesterday at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Harshman, in Neversink, N.Y. The Rev. Carla V. Berkedal, an Episcopal priest, officiated. Her husband is a son of Ralph T. Johnston of Myrtle Beach, S.C., and the late Norma C. F. Johnston.

title: Twice-a-Week Ferry Service Links South Korea and China
description: South Korea began regular ferry service with China today for the first time since the Korean peninsula was divided in 1945.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

Born of Frustration, a Fantasy Is Made Real
description: LEAD: AS the sap runs in the maple trees, the juices run in the middle-school child. The sun is warm, the end of the year is in sight and spirits are high. What comes out of book bags, in the form of ''Forbidden Fruit,'' matches this mood.

title: Headliners;   Reagan Hailed for Taking the Evil Out Of The Empire?
description: Historians may continue to debate exactly why Communism fell, but Eastern European leaders last week rained gratitude on Ronald Reagan for giving it a push.

title: Was Warhol Great?
description: To the Editor:

title: Parents Vow to Protest AIDS Student
description: Parents of about a dozen students at a Brooklyn junior high school are threatening to keep their children out of class tomorrow to protest the presence of an 11-year-old boy who recently revealed that he is infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Miss Berenson Weds M.D. Bernstein
description: Cindy E. Berenson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Berenson of Kings Point, L.I., was married last evening to Mitchell D. Bernstein, the son of Richard B. Bernstein of New City, N.Y., and the late Karen Bernstein. Rabbi David E. Fass officiated at the Pierre in New York.

description: LEAD:

title:
Beauty/Fashion: Los Angeles;

Face to Face With Four Cities
description: LEAD: On Los Angeles, where the resort climate and the entertainment industry dominate, the influence of appearance is profound. Even if you don't earn your living based on how you look, you probably work out next to or dine across from someone who does. Temperate weather means that parts of the body, from the toes up, are exposed practically year round.

title: California Faces Test On the Environment
description: The economic and political realities of protecting the environment are being tested in California.

title: A Fair Shake At Cooperstown
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Howell A. Inghram, 94; Professor at Columbia
description: Howell Arthur Inghram, professor emeritus of accounting at Columbia University, died on Thursday at Walton County Hospital in Monroe, Ga. He was 94 years old and lived in Monroe.

title: Ms. Rutherfurd Weds in Boston
description: Linda Elizabeth Rutherfurd, a daughter of Mrs. Winthrop Rutherfurd of New York and the late Mr. Rutherfurd, was married yesterday to Mark Gideon Borden, a son of Arthur M. Borden of New York and the late Florence Smiley Borden. The Rev. Robert VerEecke, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Somerset Club in Boston.

title: Beyond the Red Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Where the Apples Are (Yours for the Picking)
description: As the harvest season begins, the mid-Hudson Valley is filling up with ripe, red apples, waiting to be picked. Favorable weather in eastern New York during the growing season has left trees laden with fruit in orchards on both sides of the Hudson River.

title: Gorbachev Presses Israel to Join Forum on Mideast
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, after the first meeting in 20 years between a Kremlin leader and Israeli ministers, was reported today to have restated his insistence that the Soviet Union would recognize Israel only if it dropped its opposition to an international conference on the Middle East.

title: A Slave to His Own Liberation
description: THE GENERAL IN HIS LABYRINTH

title: How the Bible Serves As a Garden's Guide
description: LEAD: ''I CANNOT imagine life without a garden,'' said Butzi Moffitt, who has spent more than 20 years tending an herb garden at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church, in Fairfield. The garden, in the center of the church's front lawn, is composed entirely of herbs that are mentioned in the Bible. The garden, which Mrs.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Have Elite Yacht Races Become Too Dangerous?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Ms. Vermilye Wed To Morgan May
description: Dana Ritchie Vermilye, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Vermilye of Manchester, Mass., was married at their home yesterday to Morgan May, the son of Mollie May of New York and the late Merrill R. May, by Lois Ann Lehn, town justice of Manchester, and Rabbi Allan Press.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

THE ART OF CONFRONTATION
description: LEAD: Although many art critics and historians have pigeonholed Robert Morris as an apolitical minimalist sculptor, Maurice Berger points out that the artist's work of the 1960's and early 70's addresses social and political themes. In LABYRINTHS: Robert Morris, Minimalism, and the 1960s (HarperCollins, Paper, $14.95), Mr.

title: Shakespeare On the Potomac: A Reappearing Act
description: His eyeglasses balanced delicately on his balding forehead and a bottle of diet soda gripped firmly in his right hand, Michael Kahn leans forward, focusing intently on the words and actions of the villainous Richard III as the misshapen murderer takes Lord Stanley's son hostage to his sovereign wishes. Standing a breath away from the face of his Machiavellian anti-hero, who is played by Stacy Keach, Mr. Kahn moves his hips rhythmically to the beat of Richard's syllables, dancing his very own Shakespearean rumba.

title: Headliners;   Finding Fault
description: Stephen L. Lane claims the defunct brokerage firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert is responsible for his $12 million loss in the 1987 market crash because his Drexel broker lacked experience and supervision. He should know; she was, and is, his wife, Trina Lane. In a complaint that was filed with the American Arbitration Association two years ago and came to light last week, Mr. Lane said that his wife had an ''almost total lack of meaningful experience in managing a commodities account.'' Mr. Lane, who is president of the Emerson Radio Corporation, also said that when his wife joined Drexel, the only jobs listed on her resume were a 20-month stint as a stockbroker and two years as a ''model and Playboy bunny in the New York Playboy Club.'' He said an illness kept him from keeping track of how his wife was managing his account. Lawyers for Drexel have maintained that Mr. Lane made his claims only to avoid having to pay the brokerage $5 million in trading losses he accrued.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Sept. 1

title: Style Makers;   Michael Mott, Fashion Designer
description: Like practically every fashion retailer, designer or wearer of clothes, Michael Mott begins with a jacket these days. For fall, the jackets tend to be longer and softer than they used to be. What sets off Mr. Mott's styles from a lot of others is that they are realistically priced, at $150 to $300 - and they are made to order. For new customers, he offers one fitting. Women he has worked with in the past usually can pick up their clothes about two weeks after placing an order.

title: M. J. O'Connor Weds Kristine Hatzenbuhler
description: Kristine Smith Hatzenbuhler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Hatzenbuhler of Verona, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael John O'Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. O'Connor, also of Verona. The Rev. Nicholas T. Cooke 3d officiated at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Montclair, N.J.

title: Can Cellular Phone Companies Agree On a New Standard for Transmission?
description: Cellular industry executives now find themselves in a quandary. They agreed last year on a technique to transmit calls that offers a desperately needed threefold increase in the number that can be handled simultaneously in one city. Japan and many European countries have already adopted this technique as their standard.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have dark paneling that I would like to paint over in a light color. Over the years, I have used various spray-on furniture waxes and polishes on this paneling, and I am wondering how to prepare the surface for painting. Can I use a chemical de-glossing liquid, or do I have to sand the panels?

title: Preservation's Supreme Authority
description: Mention the name William J. Brennan Jr. to a legal scholar, and you are likely to hear encomiums for the retiring Supreme Court Justice's reputation as one of the century's great defenders of individual liberties. Justice Brennan was the intellectual anchor of the Warren Court, the activist who merged an idealistic outlook with a rigorous respect for the Constitution.

title: The Region;   New York Voices: Are 5,000 Officers the Best Antidote to Rising Crime?
description: As Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins struggled last week to one-up each other on whether and how New York City should hire 5,000 more police officers, crime once again showed that it could talk tougher than either of them.

title:
Food;

Pasta's Past
description: LEAD: There is almost nothing that can't be ruined by bad taste and poor execution, and baked pasta, a jewel of the Renaissance, is no exception. In 20th-century America, baked pasta has come to mean the flaccid baked ziti displayed at salad bars, gloppy lasagnas served at church suppers and, weirdest of all, tuna-noodle casseroles chock full of Velveeta, potato chips, cashews and

title: Who Killed Christopher Marlowe?
description: ENTERED FROM THE SUN

title: Love for the Proper Outlaw
description: THE WOMAN LIT BY FIREFLIES

title: Initiative Amendment: Dissenting Views
description: In his article, ''Initiative and Referendum? Say No'' (Opinion page, Aug. 19), Martin Hochbaum opposes an initiative and referendum amendment in New Jersey. He suggests that the visibility of the New Jersey Legislature's deliberative process, together with newspaper commentary, freedom-of-information laws, open public meetings and open-to-the-public legislative committee hearings provide ample opportunity for public testimony.

title: Headliners;   Baton Poised
description: First prize for Wolfgang Sawallisch turned out to be 15 weeks with the Philadelphia. The West German conductor is to succeed Riccardo Muti as the music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra in 1993, and his contract requires him to spend at least that much time each season directing the orchestra whose lush string sound was made famous by Leopold Stokowski and Eugene Ormandy. Mr. Sawallisch (pronounced suh-VAHL-ish), who is 67 years old, first appeared with the orchestra as a guest conductor in 1966. He said he plans to continue living in his native Munich, where he is the general director of the Bavarian State Opera, although he will give up that post. In appearances in the United States, he has often conducted works by recent West German composers. He said he also would like to explore American ones, but described his tastes as very conservative, warning, ''I am not a friend of extremely contemporary music, with electronic sounds and so on.''

title: Data Update
Campus Life: Pennsylvania;   Fraternities Lose Grip On Prime Housing Site
description: For at least 20 years, the housing along Locust Walk, the main artery for pedestrians on the University of Pennsylvania campus, has been the exclusive domain of fraternities. Now it is the focus of a debate as the administration has moved to end the exclusivity.

title: NICARAGUA USING A NEW CURRENCY
description: In the bitterest days of the conflict between this country's former Sandinista leaders and American-backed rebels, all Nicaraguans shared one crucial piece of common ground: their reliance on the American dollar.

title: Inside The Arsenals
description: For weeks, an endless military caravan has disgorged metal and explosives onto the sands of Saudi Arabia. No sooner did the American buildup begin than Pentagon commanders started to draw up the so-called order of battle - an ever-shifting account of the forces arrayed on each side. They calibrated the speed, reach, accuracy and deadliness of weapons, and worked on a strategy to take advantage of their strengths and Iraq's presumed weaknesses.

title: Threats and Party Backlash for El Salvador Chief
description: In the 15 months since his inauguration at the head of a rightist Government, President Alfredo Cristiani has moved moved toward the center of the Salvadoran political spectrum, provoking a backlash from the core of his party that threatens his administration, Western diplomats and Salvadoran politicians say.

title: The Truth of Feeling Joins the Truth of Fact
description: Once or twice in every hundred years there is a draftsman who can do just about anything with graphite, watercolor, gouache and stump. One such was Adolph Menzel (1815-1905), the long-lived Berliner whose drawings are having their first-ever major exhibition in the United States at the Frick Collection through Nov. 18.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDY: Business inventories for July.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin;   Students Accuse A University Of Housing Bias
description: The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development is investigating a discrimination complaint filed by students against the University of Wisconsin's housing division.

title: David Eaglesfield Weds Dr. Anne Butler
description: Dr. Anne Butler, the daughter of Mrs. James C. Thomson Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., and David Butler of Denver was married yesterday in Brookline, Mass., to David Eaglesfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carrol Eaglesfield of Burlington, Wash. The Rev. Robert McAfee Brown, a Presbyterian minister and an uncle of the bride, officiated at the home of Dr. and Mrs. James H. Sowles.

title: Turcotte Regaining Form
description: The therapy is required almost every other day. The trainer's fingers are dug deep into the left foot, reorganizing bones and releasing muscles. They touch what are officially called ''trigger points,'' but by the end of the standard half-hour of work what they have triggered as well are tears at the corners of Darren Turcotte's eyes.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

My Last Child Is Starting Kindergarten
description: LEAD: MY daughter has started kindergarten. She's thrilled, and I'm apprehensive.

title: Melissa Pruzan Is a Bride
description: Melissa B. Pruzan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Pruzan of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeffrey Fishman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Fishman of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Mark Weiner performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents. Mrs. Fishman, a graduate of Wellesley College, is the projects director for the American Marketing Network, a promotion concern in New York. Her husband, a graduate of the State University of New Yorkat Oneonta and St. John's University Law School, is the president of Horizon Investments, a real-estate investment concern in New York.

title: Dispersal Surprises in Woodward
description: Confusion in the handicap ranks and a new leader of the 2-year-olds emerged from a pair of upsets yesterday at Belmont Park, after Dispersal won the $590,000 Woodward Handicap and Eastern Echo took the $115,600 Futurity Stakes.

title:
Beauty/Fashion: Prague;

Face to Face With Four Cities
description: LEAD: At first glance, there is nothing in the faces of Prague to distinguish them. The city is located at Europe's geographic center, and in its people you see an amalgam of ethnic origins - Russian, Latin, Nordic. These are the eminently reasonable faces of the Velvet Revolution, peaceful yet determined.

title: Headliners;   Too Thrilling
description: Bungee jumping, something of a passion in Australia, lost a lot of its appeal last week. The sport, which involves jumping from great heights while attached to elastic cords, was banned in Sydney when one cord broke for a beauty queen, who plunged 130 feet and fractured her collarbone. Natalie McCurry, whose reign as Miss Australia ended Monday, had successfully executed a solo and then jumped in tandem with a member of the Bungee Bats, a group that arranged public jumps. Both jumpers were treated for neck and back injuries. The ban will remain until a report can be completed on the accident. Theoretically, the jumpers were to leap from a cage secured to a crane suspended over water, the cords attached to their ankles stopping them a couple of yards short of the water. Safety checks had included a weigh-in and a match of the cords' tensile strength to the couple's combined weight. The public jumps were approved by the local authorities only last month after standards were tightened.

title: Wall Street;   New York Gets a Break in the Bond Market
description: Despite the crime and gunfire that have dominated the New York City headlines, the Big Apple got a better deal from the bond market last week than it did back in June.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's very worrying. They've been educated, and they have something they can give back to the country. But just when they reach that point, they depart this life.''

title: AIDS in Africa: A Killer Rages On
description: The AIDS epidemic continues to course through Africa, outracing the prevention campaigns that have now been started by every government.

title: U.S. TO POSTPONE DEBATE ON ZIONISM
description: The Bush Administration is postponing plans to seek repeal of a United Nations resolution equating Zionism with racism at this year's General Assembly so as not to imperil Arab support for trade sanctions against Iraq and for America's military buildup in the Persian Gulf, United Nations and American officials say.

title: Fitting a New Sink Into a Counter Top
description: FITTING a new kitchen sink into a counter top - professional installers call it cutting in - is mostly a case of planning and careful workmanship. Planning begins by making sure that the sink will fit the counter top and base cabinet supporting it. In most cases, the horizontal framing spanning the rear of any base cabinet can be cut away to make room for the sink without much loss of support. Likewise, the framing across the front can be cut away slightly or notched along its rear edge. The front framing must not be cut through completely, else a gap will be visible beneath the counter top.

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting today, the suggested Sunday newsstand price of The Times in New York City, within 75 miles and on all of Long Island is increased to $1.50 from $1.25. The weekday price is unchanged, as is the Sunday price outside the New York area.

title: Bill Would Again End Benefits to Census Workers
description: About $40 million in unemployment benefits that were stripped from temporary census workers in May and restored in August are threatened again by legislation approved this week by a Senate subcommittee.

title: Liane Pei and William F. Kracklauer, Lawyers in New York, Are Married
description: Liane Pei, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. M. Pei of New York, was married yesterday to William Frederick Kracklauer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Kracklauer of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Damian Myett officiated at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: No Clear Favorite for 1996
description: One of the most intense bidding campaigns in recent years will end Tuesday evening in Tokyo when the International Olympic Committee votes to select the site for the 1996 Summer Olympics.

title: Man Charged in Towing Fracas Is Released After 2 Days in Jail
description: A man arrested on Thursday when a crowd intervened as a woman's car was being towed in midtown Manhattan was released early yesterday, after being arraigned on a number of charges, including second-degree assault on a uniformed officer.

title: THE SPORTSCASTERS
description: In this age of global stress, American men have lost a vital component of their leisure time. ''The guy you hang out with'' is a vanishing commodity in our lives. The sportscaster can fill this void (albeit artificially). He should no more restrict his comments to on-field events than you and your pal would when attending a live game.

title: Seeing Far-Off Hong Kong for Rates Within Reach
description: If you have ever considered a quick visit to Hong Kong, now is the time. There are one-week package trips available of round-trip flights from the West Coast and five nights in a hotel for the price of the air fare - $1,055, or even $899, depending on the tour operator, the airline and the hotel.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Reflecting Reggae And Rap
description: An exotic mix of fabrics, chunky beaded necklaces, distinctive hairstyles and clunky-soled shoes are making a fashion statement that reflects the influences of Reggae and Rap music. Many young American blacks and youths from the Caribbean are wearing combinations that generally involve a mix of oversized clothes and jackets and a big fabric cap. The shirts are often in prints that contain four to six patterns in a single design. Print duffle bags are tossed over the shoulder.

In the Region: Long Island;

Tenants Reap Benefits of High Vacancies
description: LEAD: With the lease on his 2,000 square feet of office space in a converted store in East Meadow about to expire last February, Baldur Peter, president of Spiegel, Peter & Liu, Architects, went searching for more modern offices in a larger building.

title: Ms. Auchincloss Weds S. B. Reynolds
description: Elizabeth Buck Auchincloss, a daughter of Eva Seed Auchincloss of San Francisco and the late J. Stuart Auchincloss, was married yesterday to Stephen Bradley Reynolds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Clinton Reynolds Jr. of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Mary Moore Gaines officiated at St. Joseph's Episcopal Chapel in Kent, Conn.

description: Peter Pan

title: Cheap Tapes May Be Costly
description: Videophiles have long been aware of the dangers posed by off-brand cassettes, sold under unfamiliar names, which may damage a VCR in the process of playing or recording. Unhappily, some of these cassettes are now being passed off with the regular VHS logo.

title: No Way to Choose a Judge
description: What qualities count most in choosing judges? Integrity and independence? Legal philosophy and judicial temperament? Not under New York's system of judicial elections. It puts a premium on fund-raising, slick advertisements and chumminess with clubhouse pols. Last week's Democratic primary for Manhattan Surrogate underscores the case for reform.

title: Ad Hominem
description: To the Editor:

title: Amsterdam
description: To the Editor: Is it really appropriate to describe Amsterdam (Travel, Aug. 19) without mentioning the Anne Frank House?

title: Kimberly Tompkins Is Wed
description: Kimberly A. Tompkins, the daughter of Sophia P. Tompkins of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Joseph G. Tompkins Jr. of Tokyo, was married yesterday in Bedford, N.Y., to Ian M. Bickley, a son of Mrs. Walter L. Bickley of Warwick, Bermuda, and the late Mr. Bickley. The Rev. James T. McGuire officiated at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Bickley, 25 years old, graduated from Skidmore College and is an interior design consultant in Munich, West Germany, where her husband, 26, is a management consultant with a clothing manufacturer and retailer. He is a graduate of Harvard University.

title: Walter J. Petry Sr., Y.M.C.A. Director
description: Walter J. Petry Sr., a member of the board of the Harlem Y.M.C.A. for 50 years, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Political Memo;   3 Familiar Faces Vie for the Title Of Mr. Outsider (And Governor)
description: NOW that United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison, of Hamden, has secured the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, several economic concerns remain the major issues for November's election: the state's yawning budget deficit, the possibility of a state income tax and a sluggish economy that is forcing the layoffs of thousands of workers, particularly in the military industry.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Two Strangers Share An Accident
description: LEAD: I HAD driven to Katonah to do a few errands and I decided just past noon to stop and have a sandwich and coffee at a local restaurant.

title: VIETNAM AND THE GULF CRISIS
description: Members of the House and Senate whose lives were touched by the Vietnam War see lessons for the Persian Gulf crisis. Page 18.

title:
SCOTCH PLAINS JOURNAL;

Town Rallies to Save a Family Zoo
description: LEAD: REGULAR Sunday morning patrons of the Sip and Dunk Donut Shop are no longer surprised to see Frank Terry and his 5-year-old chimp, Holly, seated at the counter munching on glazed doughnuts. After all, Mr. Terry and his wife, Louise, have owned and operated the nearby Terry Lou Zoo, on Terrill and Raritan

title: Finding Perfect Privacy on Phuket
description: Intrepid backpacking travelers of the 60's and early 70's deserve credit for discovering the beauties of Phuket, in the Andaman Sea off Thailand's southern coast. The best beaches were isolated at the time by formidable limestone mountains and required determination as well as stamina to reach; once there, the only accommodations on most were a few ramshackle bungalows of bamboo and thatch with primitive sanitary facilities. The water, though, was crystal clear, the sand was pure white, the costs were minimal, and, best of all, the privacy was practically absolute.

title: Arts Foundation Awards $35,000 to 6 Authors
description: Three Americans are among the six authors who were awarded $35,000 each by the Lannan Foundation, a private arts organization based in Los Angeles.

title: Union and G.M. Extend Pact And Continue Negotiations
description: The United Auto Workers union and the General Motors Corporation agreed to extend their current contract Friday night, then negotiated through today on a new agreement affecting about 300,000 workers nationwide.

title: BUSINESS DIARY/SEPTEMBER 9-14
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Teacher Strikes End With New Contracts In 2 School Districts
description: The teacher strikes in the South Orange-Maplewood and Deptford school districts are over.

title: Nature and Design in Subtle Harmonies
description: THREE immense bronze bells are suspended in wooden supports on one side of Toshiko Takaezu's yard. Silhouetted against an ashen sky, they resemble austere ancient torii shrines.
