description: Armonk, N.Y. $407,000

title: Review/Stage;   Skelton's 1-Man Band Of Comical Characters
description: A fellow named Lou went into a synagogue one day and asked the Lord to make him a lottery winner.

title: Always on Stage
description: LEAD:

title: Alfred Hollender, 87, A New York Executive
description: Alfred L. Hollender, a retired New York businessman and advertising executive and a former producer of popular game shows in the 1950's and early 60's, died on Thursday at his home in Water Mill, L.I. He was 87 years old and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Jane Elizabeth Krug Weds Jerry Farmer Stone 3d
description: Jane Elizabeth Krug, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Thatcher Krug of Old Bethpage, L.I., was married yesterday to Jerry Farmer Stone 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stone Jr. of Summit, N.J. The Revs. Robert Bruschi and Kenneth Swanson officiated at St. Simon-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Mantoloking, N.J.

title: New Jersey Judge Bars Referendums on Taxes
description: A Superior Court judge today denied a bid by more than 30 county and local governments to hold nonbinding referendums advocating the repeal of Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax program. Judge Burrell Ives Humphreys said those governments could not use the referendum process to poll popular sentiment because the issues of state taxes and school aid are not within their purview.

title: Birmingham Marker Honors Girls Killed at Church in '63
description: Twenty-seven years after four black girls attending church died in a racist bombing here, several dozen people gathered at a cemetery where three of the girls are buried to remember them as martyrs for social change.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Water all newly planted material, especially divisions of perennials, new evergreens such as rhododendrons, azaleas, pieris, laurels, and if bulbs have been set out, be sure that the soil is moist for proper root growth. Mow the new lawn if the grass is about three inches tall; keep mowing established lawns and set the mowers to cut at two inches. Start raking when leaves begin to accumulate on the lawn.

title: THE SPORTSCASTERS
description: A comic-strip cover - what a delightful idea. I imagine if Charlie Chaplin had drawn cartoons instead of making movies, they might look not unlike these.

title: A Bond Strategy for Foreigners
description: With the economy slowing down, or possibly in a recession, and with a steadily weakening dollar, there is little to attract foreign investors to the American stock and bond markets From January through May, foreigners were net sellers of $6.7 billion in American stocks and $5.9 billion in Government securities, according to the most recent data from the Securities Industry Association. Analysts say the trend is likely to continue - especially if the dollar falls further, which would cut deeper into profits or widen losses for foreign investors who must convert assets back into their home currencies.

title: Once Considered a Sure Thing, California's Environmental Package Falters
description: When first proposed, a sweeping California ballot measure that promised a ''bold and comprehensive'' plan to protect the environment seemed a sure winner that could deliver a powerful national message about the public's determination to fight pollution.

title: In the Region: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Fort Salonga $319,000

title: Jets Planning to Show New Look Today
description: When the Jets show up in Giants Stadium today for Bruce Coslet's regular-season home debut, against the Cleveland Browns, they will be wearing their new-look green jerseys and white pants. It will be the first time since 1984 that the team has worn dark jerseys at home. The previous regime stayed with white tops because it thought players looked bigger in them.

title: In Mohegan Lake, a Lubavitch Couple Reach Out
description: WHEN Loretta Ciner, a Reform Jew with little education in her religion, decided to study Judaism at the Chabad of Northern Westchester - also known as the Lakeland Synagogue in Mohegan Lake - her family was horrified.

title: Not Bad for a Dog
description: MILLIE'S BOOK

title: Festival Completes A Mission
description: AS if in summation of an era, the second and third productions of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's 28th summer and Paul Barry's last as artistic director reflect what has come to pass for the company's best work (''Measure for Measure'') and its lamentable worst (''King John'').

title: Poignant Drama With a Light Touch
description: THE acronym Nimby, for Not in My Backyard, has become a catchword. Garbage dumps, prisons, hospices and other projects perceived to be socially unclean or unpleasant are often passed along with the fervent hope that some other person or community will deal with the problem.

title: A Pyrrhic Triumph In Katmandu
description: My last night in Katmandu, a city that does not count cosmopolitan night life among its many charms. Having spent the daylight hours canvassing Nepal's capital for an article I was researching, a relaxing evening free of open sewers and wandering cows seemed the perfect nepenthe for an American unaccustomed to the unspeakable squalor the average Nepalese confronts every day of his life.

title: Fed Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Gabriel Byrne, Bound for 'Miller's Crossing'
description: Since 1980, a tide of films featuring, even starring Gabriel Byrne has washed ashore here. Playing opposite Jill Clayburgh in Costa Gavras's ''Hanna K.,'' he was an Israeli prosecutor with an accent appropriate to the venue; for ''Gothic,'' a Ken Russell surreal frenzy, he was Lord Byron, with bouffant hair and upper-class inflections; his speech emerged slightly and romantically Italianate in ''Julia and Julia,'' a Kathleen Turner vehicle, and a touch Hispanic in ''Siesta,'' an overnight failure redeemed by the presence of Ellen Barkin, whom he subsequently married. In all, there have been nearly a dozen features, some of which have actually lasted on local marquees longer than 10 minutes. But mention his name to any reasonably attentive moviegoer . . . ''and,'' he obligingly rescues an embarrassed visitor, ''they say, 'Who?' ''

title: When Going Too Far Is Not Far Enough
description: In these days when demolition is usually a matter of cold-blooded expediency or worse, Charles Ludlam's ''Camille'' qualifies as an act of loving sabotage.

title: Beset in Mount Vernon
description: To the Editor:

title: Style Makers;   David Urso, Spice-Jewelry Designer
description: David Urso adds a dash of rosemary to his garlic potatoes, some oregano to his ratatouille, a pinch of thyme to his favorite chicken dish and lots of basil tohis pesto. He also sprinkles herbs from his garden on the jewelry that he designs.

title: SAVING FACE
description: The red and white stripes on the old-fashioned barber's pole stood for blood and bandages, representing a time when a barber was just as likely to remove molars as hair. Although those days are over, the association of shaving with blood and pain is still all too apt for many men. To those with sensitive skin, trimming the daily growth of 15-thousandths of an inch of whiskers might just as well be pulling teeth. And while avoiding it may seem ideal, not all men can get away with a beard, or the famous sexy stubble of Mel Gibson or Don Johnson.

title: Campus Life: Notre Dame;   Back to School: Books, Exams And Now Sponges
description: Students at the University of Notre Dame found something new in their dorm rooms when they returned to campus this month: two spray bottles and a sponge.

title: Missy Putman, Manager, Wed
description: Jennifer Ritchie Putman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Fenn Putman of Mendham, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Fink, a son of Barbara J. Cooper of North Massapequa, L.I., and Eugene P. Fink of Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. Alfred Niese officiated at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: The Recycling of 'Dump'
description: A city man back from a small-town summer reports that recycling is creating an endangered species. For years the town dump was called just that, the dump. Or, whimsically, the Exchange: he would go there to discard a wobbly kitchen table and come home with a gimpy rocking chair. A few years ago the dump officially became the ''landfill'' - a Nice Nellyism, as if its purpose were to improve land, not get rid of trash. Anyway, everybody still called it the dump.

title: Taking Aim At Fear
description: The politics of crime is simple and cynical: only respond to the public's fear of crime. It costs too much, politically and financially, to do anything about crime itself; at least it probably would cost too much if anyone actually knew what should be done about crime.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Brunch;   A Relaxing Ambiance Helps Start the Week
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

title: Uncounted New Yorker Wants to Know Why
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Company Eluding Assault Rifle Import Ban
description: Assault-style AK-47 rifles are being made for the first time by an American company that is getting around the Government's ban on imports of the weapon by producing some new parts in the United States.

title: Beauty/Fashion: New York;   Face to Face With Four Cities
description: Manhattan is a total crap shoot when it comes to looks. What with the lunching ladies uptown, the SoHo-TriBeCa downtown contingent and the harried midtown business crowd, it's not easy to coalesce the visual shticks into one city image. Or into clear-cut buying patterns. While market research shows that women in the Midwest, for example, purchase more blue eye shadow than any other makeup, the New York City group falls into that hazy territory known as ''Metropolitan America,'' for which statistics are wildly variable, deeply general.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: A Boy Who Knows His Forks
description: ARAMINTA'S PAINT BOX

title: Dr. Beverly Granger, Dentist, Is Wed To Dr. Aloysius Cuyjet, Physician
description: Dr. Beverly M. Granger, the daughter of Dr. Dorothy Reed Granger of Sag Harbor, L.I., and the late Dr. Richard A. Granger, was married yesterday to Dr. Aloysius Baxter Cuyjet, a son of Barbara L. Cuyjet of Bayonne, N.J., and Dr. Aloysius Bishop Cuyjet of Lake Huntington, N.Y. Justice Robert J. Mangum, a retired justice of the State Court of Claims, officiated in the ceremony at the bride's home in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: Dar-ryl, Dar-ryl, Dar-ryl, Dar-ryl, Dar-ryl
description: Some people put off going to the dentist. Some people put off term papers. Some people put off income taxes. The Mets put off Darryl. Now it's going to cost them. For those who have just tuned in to this melodrama, the tall man in right field with the rather improbable name of Darryl Strawberry went through a month in a rehabilitation center last winter and is probably going to have the best season of his career.

title: Kathleen Robinson Is Bride
description: Kathleen M. Robinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Robinson of Middletown, N.J., was married yesterday to David S. French 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel R. French of Oakwood, Ohio. The Rev. Michael J. Corona officiated at St. James Roman Catholic Church in Red Bank, N.J. Miss Robinson graduated from Kean College, and her husband from Union College in Schenectady, N.Y. She is a marketing representative for Guilford of Maine Textiles, and he is a trader at Oppenheimer & Company, both in New York.

title: Slashed Tires
description: To the Editor: Over the years I recall reading about the racket of gas station attendants slashing tires when gas is being bought, for the purpose of building tire sales at the station. As I recall, the favorite states for this outdoor sport were South Carolina, Georgia and Florida.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Duty-Free Limit Is Increased For Caribbean

title: Japan, Not Knowing How to Act, Isn't Sure It Wants To
description: The Middle East crisis has plunged Japan into something resembling a full-scale identity crisis.

title: Trying to Bring Order to Busy Schedules
description: IF it's Friday, it must be Ad Club. If it's Thursday, it's Sales and Marketing. In the normal course of business life, most people belong to at least one professional organization. And if they're in sales, marketing, advertising or communications, they're likely to belong to several.

title: 100 Years Ago, the Father of Movies Disappeared
description: Who invented motion pictures? The Lumiere Brothers in 1895? Thomas Edison in 1896? Try again. A hundred years ago today a French inventor named Augustin Le Prince was scheduled to project his motion pictures at the Jumel Mansion in upper Manhattan and would have, had not an unfortunate incident occurred.

title: Speakers With Hidden Charms
description: Loudspeakers sometimes clash with the decor. Anyone seeking visual as well as musical harmony for Queen Anne or Chippendale in the living room would have a hard time finding something suitable in a hi-fi store.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in the Real Estate section on June 17 about California wineries that are moving operations southward to Santa Barbara County quoted the operations director for the Kendall-Jackson Winery as saying the primary reason for the move was that ''land values are so much lower.'' In editing, The Times omitted a further comment from the director, Randall Clifton: ''The quality of Chardonnay grapes in Santa Barbara County is superior to those grown in Napa and Sonoma Counties.''

title: When Life is Toxic
description: The advance instructions for the interview were explicit: Wear well-washed old clothing, no synthetics, nothing recently dry-cleaned, no cologne or after-shave lotion, and bring nothing likely to emit chemicals, like a fresh newspaper.

title: All About/Gambling Equipment;   Hardware Makers Cash In On America's Betting Mania
description: The blackjack tables, the roulette wheels and the dice are still there. But the companies that make gambling equipment have turned the casinos into high-technology arcades. Rows of electronically linked slot machines monitor wagering, accept hundred-dollar bets or deliver million-dollar, lottery-style jackpots. Customers play poker and blackjack on video screens.

title: In the Region: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Chatham $187,500

title: Wall Street;   Rules for Government Securities?
description: There's something about the term ''government securities'' that resonates with safety and solidity. In an age of ''junk bonds'' and penny stocks, what could be more conservative and prudent than buying things like Treasury bonds or the securities of federally chartered agencies such as the Federal National Mortgage Association?

title: The French Collection
description: CONFESSIONS OF A LITERARY ARCHAEOLOGIST. By Carlton Lake. (New Directions, $21.95.) The sight of rich, green leather bindings and gold-lettered type scrolled across the spine of a book makes Carlton Lake ecstatic. He positively gushes if the book also happens to be a first edition of Baudelaire's prose work ''Les Paradis Artificiels,'' which, in one instance, it was. Mr. Lake, a private collector and the executive curator of the Humanities Research Center at the University of Texas, dived into his avocation while living in Paris in the 1950's. From then on, he focused his collecting energies on French literature and art. ''Confessions of a Literary Archaeologist'' is well stocked with intriguing anecdotes of his searches high and low for special and rare books, letters and manuscripts. In the course of relating his discoveries, Mr. Lake not only opens up the relatively closed door of the French rare-book trade, but also discloses both gossipy and scholarly information about many French cultural heroes, including Paul Valery, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec and Jean Cocteau. Writing with a sure and eloquent hand, Mr. Lake provides, often by quoting from actual documents, character-revealing information otherwise unknown to the general public. For example, in letters written by Toulouse-Lautrec's mother, one sees a leaden maternal hand that, Mr. Lake opines, may not have been obvious in biographies of the artist. Cocteau, ever the controversial cult figure, grows more outrageous as Mr. Lake describes the sword - custom-made from Cartier, with a profile of Oedipus's head - Cocteau carried during his induction ceremony into the French Academy. Readers will be lured by such amusing and plentiful details throughout this charming book.

title: Jordan and Palestine Remain Separate Entities
description: To the Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND Q & A: STEVEN B. GREENBERG;

What Makes Certain Stores Prosper and Others Falter
description: LEAD: AS president of the Greenberg Group, a real-estate site-selection business, Steven B. Greenberg advised many retailers.

title: Downtown Malls
description: To the Editor:

title: Kings Sign Mays
description: He's already been credited with helping rebuild one sagging basketball program, and now Travis Mays is set to begin working his magic on another. Mays, a former Texas Longhorn who is the leading scorer in Southwest Conference history, signed a multiyear contract with the Sacramento Kings on Friday.

title: Stanley R. Kay, 44, Schizophrenia Expert
description: Stanley R. Kay, an authority on schizophrenia, died on Monday in Kyoto, Japan where he was attending a medical conference. He was 44 years old and lived in Mahopac, N.Y.

title: Pragmatism Guides Political Gifts, a Study Shows
description: Political action committees base their contributions less on ideological or geographic factors than on whether the recipient sits on a Congressional committee that can help them, a study has found.

title: Tailor-Made Yachts: Floating Individuality
description: AS a young man growing up on the North Carolina coast, N. Denis Crowther followed the local tradition of building wooden fishing boats. Today he is president of a boat-building business in Mystic, a town once known for building wooden clipper ships.

title: Deadlock Threatens Future of Nuclear Treaty
description: A dispute between the United States and a group of nonaligned nations has threatened the future of the 20-year-old treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons, diplomats said today after a monthlong review of progress toward nuclear disarmament ended here in deadlock.

title: Orchestra Gambles To Win The Young
description: WHEN a summer downpour forced the Philharmonia Virtuosi to move its popular free outdoor performance of Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons'' from Kensico Plaza to the cavernous County Center one Tuesday, gloomy orchestra officials predicted that few members of the audience would follow inside.

title: Polish Rail Car to Israelis
description: A freight car once used to transport Nazi prisoners to the Auschwitz death camp has been presented by Polish railroad workers to Israel's Holocaust museum. Aleksander Janiszewski, director general of the Polish State Railways, presented the rail car to the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial in a ceremony at a Warsaw locomotive shed on Friday. Zvi Rav-Ner, the Israeli charge d'affaires in Warsaw, accepted the gift.

title: Question of the Week;   Are Umpires Getting Too Aggressive?
description: After Bob Gibson's microscopic 1.12 earned run average in 1968, rule changes (lowering the mound from 15 to 10 inches) were instituted to put some offense back into the game. Since 1968 the inside part of the plate has changed ownership. What once belonged to Gibson and others able to control the inside corner, has become (apparently) the batters' real estate. A pitcher and a batter both wanting the inside part of the plate, at the same time, has been the issue in several brawls this year.

title: Under Blue Skies, Global Race Begins
description: A storm front gave way to blue skies and fair winds today as 24 solo sailors crossed the starting line in the BOC Challenge, the 27,000-mile yacht race around the world.

title: Clint Eastwood Directs Himself Portraying a Director
description: Moving through the green and sepia tones of the savannah, kicking up dust and stones, an open Land-Rover suddenly pulls to a halt and several intent white men, clad in khaki hunting gear, leap out, rifles in hand. One of them, tall and lean, his face shaded by the wide awning of his bush hat, has a particular urgency. ''On to a big one?'' he asks the young African boy waiting for him.

title: N.F.L. Planning Drug Advice Line
description: The National Football League is planning to offer a toll-free telephone line so players can talk confidentially with a drug adviser.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: Most bridge players go through life without ever having the good fortune of picking up a ''hand of a lifetime.'' This sort of hand offers fair prospects of making 13 tricks opposite a yarborough.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article Sept. 2 about school budget cuts misidentified Paul Hinckley, an official of the regional school district in Woodbury and Bethlehem. He is chairman of the school board.

title: Kimberly Grillo Weds David Bernstein
description: Kimberly Ann Grillo, a daughter of Fred E. Grillo of Stonington, Conn., was married yesterday to David Hal Bernstein, the son of Diane Bernstein and Paul Bernstein, both of New York. Federal District Judge Robert E. Keeton of Boston, for whom the bridegroom recently completed a clerkship, and Assistant Town Judge Ethel Brosnahan of Newfane, Vt., officiated at the Windham County Courthouse in Newfane.

title: It's Back to School for Adults, Too
description: DO British crossword puzzles intimidate you? Perhaps you have secretly harbored a desire to learn the art of belly dancing. Or maybe the thought of faraway places stirs a latent wanderlust. Open the cover of an adult education catalogue and a world of course offerings, seminars and special events awaits you.

title: Foreigners Finding Long Delays at U.S. Airports
description: Short of inspectors, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has been unable to keep pace with the explosive increase of foreign visitors to this country.

title: Review/Concert;   A New-Music Ensemble Celebrates Its 10 Years
description: Music Today has been one of New York's most admirable new-music series, and it was hard to believe at first that Wednesday's program at Merkin Concert Hall marked the beginning of its 10th-anniversary season. For the occasion, the ensemble engaged Rhonda Kess, a Los Angeles-trained conductor who lives in London but who has appeared in New York on a couple of auspicious occasions in recent years. Ms. Kess put together an ambitious program devoted to music theater, and conducted it surely. Too bad the evening suffered a terminal case of the cutes.

title: V. P. Moravec Jr. Wed to Ms. Lamb
description: Wendy Lamb, the daughter of Carolyn Buchanan Lamb of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church to Vincent Paul Moravec Jr., a son of Janis Howe Moravec of Beaver, Pa., and the late Mr. Moravec. The Rev. Roland M. Jones performed the ceremony, assisted by the Very Rev. J. Edwin Bacon Jr. The bride, who is keeping her name, is also the daughter of the late Thomas Lamb, an inventor, children's book illustrator and industrial designer. The bride, who graduated from Brown University, is a consulting editor in the children's books division of Delacorte Press in New York. Her mother is a medical writer and editor.

title: Commercial Property: 10 Years of False Starts;   Of Britons, Bahrainis and a Block of Brownstones
description: Although American creativity is at the core of the office tower and museum planned on Manhattan's West 53d Street, it took a development team whose roots are in Bahrain and Britain to put the deal together.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have dark paneling that I would like to paint over in a light color. Over the years, I have used various spray-on furniture waxes and polishes on this paneling, and I am wondering how to prepare the surface for painting. Can I use a chemical de-glossing liquid, or do I have to sand the panels?

title: Trailing By 29-7, B.Y.U. Wins
description: Ty Detmer threw three of his five touchdown passes during a 36-point final quarter today as Brigham Young came from far back to beat Washington State, 50-36.

title: 17 'Lost' Elaine de Kooning Works
description: LEAD: WHEN Elaine and Willem de Kooning took up a summer-term residency at Black Mountain College near Asheville, N.C., in 1948, their careers were poised for stylistic breakthroughs.

title: Man Is Convicted of Trying to Kill Girlfriend
description: An Old Saybrook clothing store owner has been convicted of trying to hire someone to kill his girlfriend so he could use money from her estate to save his business.

title: Sculpture Show in the Open
description: INAUGURATED last June, the open season for sculpture continues in the form of the Snug Harbor Sculpture Festival. A visit to this annual event, however, is more akin to bird watching than blood sports.

title: Putting Burden On Capriati
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Aid Group Musters Resources for Jordan Airlift
description: LEAD: WHEN news of the looming refugee crisis in Jordan reached Robert Macauley at his home in New Canaan, he got on the phone with his friends. Mr. Macauley, who is on a first-name basis with Ronald Reagan and calls his former schoolmate George Bush ''Poppy,'' started appealing to airline executives.

title: Iona's Neighbors Report Friction
description: LEAD: WHILE Iona College brings educational, cultural and economic benefits to New Rochelle, the school's neighbors say it also brings problems. Chief among them is a strip of bars on North Avenue just south of the campus that attracts hundreds of students and other young people. Neighbors complain of noise, litter and other disturbances.

title: Shortage Grows in Affordable Rentals
description: LEAD: A SAGGING economy and state budget restraints are worsening an already critical shortage of inexpensive rental apartments in New Jersey, despite scattered but earnest efforts by nonprofit groups to create decent housing for low-income families.

title: Easing Interest for Called Up Reservists
description: Armed Forces reservists who are called to trade their split level in suburbia for a tent in Saudi Arabia can take some comfort, at least, from a World War II law that reduces their mortgage interest rate to 6 percent and protects them and their families from mortgage foreclosure while they are on active duty.

title: WHAT'S SO FUNNY ABOUT WASHINGTON?
description: I have long been an admirer of cartoonist Pat Oliphant's insightful observations (''What's So Funny About Washington?'' by Wayne King, Aug. 5). It was, however, disheartening to learn that this obviously intelligent artist - described as ''the soul of tolerance in private matters'' - is offended by ''small things'' such as the use of the term ''gay'' to identify homosexuals (''Why can't we have 'gay' back, and they can keep 'poofter?' '').

title: Looking at the Big Picture in a Small Way, and Vice Versa
description: Arrangements for piano come in two types - those that risk doing too much and those that risk doing too little. Using Bela Bartok as his theme, the pianist Gyorgy Sandor will bring specimens of both to Carnegie Hall next Sunday afternoon.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: RICHARD C. LEONE;

Looking Ahead for the Port Authority
description: LEAD: RICHARD C. LEONE jogs where Einstein walked.

title: A Good Season for Grilled Eggplant
description: GRILLED eggplant, according to the late Waverley Root, became a fad in France in the late 18th century when people wolfed down slices ''in their disorderly gathering place, the gardens of the Palais Royal.'' Louis XIV had introduced the vegetable to France when he grew it in the royal kitchen gardens and served it to surprised guests (not all of whom were exactly thrilled, since it was rumored at the time to cause epilepsy).

title: Postings: Preservation Awards;   A Broader Connecticut Contest
description: Connecticut residents who have spruced up their old homes, sheds, barns or commercial buildings, and who feel the work deserves praise, may have their chance. For the second year, the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation will be presenting preservation awards.

title: Miss Rittenhouse to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest J. Rittenhouse of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter Cynthia Ann Rittenhouse and Daniel E. McIntyre, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel E. McIntyre of Short Hills, N.J. Miss Rittenhouse graduated from the University of Virginia and until recently was an advertising copy director for Bloomingdale's in New York. The prospective bridegroom graduated from Lafayette College and Seton Hall University Law School. He is an assistant general counsel to the Alex Brown & Sons investment bank in Baltimore.

title: Poor Nations Get Unspecified Pledge of More Aid
description: Rich industrial nations agreed to increase their aid to the world's poorest nations at a United Nations conference that ended here today, but their agreement fell short of the third world's goal of having the industrialized world double its aid.

title:
The Executive Life;

Only the Best For the Bergdorf Man?
description: LEAD: For Ira Neimark, chairman of Bergdorf Goodman, it was a delicious moment. Striding through the crowded main floor of the tony new Bergdorf Goodman Men store, Mr. Neimark was suddenly pulled up short as he spotted the familiar face of a competitor checking out the scene. For a moment, it looked as though William Roberti, president of Brooks Brothers, might make a quick getaway through Tailored Clothing.

title: THE SPORTSCASTERS
description: I read with delight Charles Siebert's article ''The Sportscasters'' (Aug. 19). I was a major-league pitcher (of limited success and longevity) and a broadcaster with the Pittsburgh Pirates from 1967 to 1975, where I had the pleasure of working with longtime Pirates broadcaster Bob Prince. He knew how to play a dramatic moment. He'd give his home-run call, ''You can kiss it good-bye,'' and then let the crowd tell the radio audience how exciting it was. He had a rule that you mentioned your name and your fellow announcers only at the start and finish of each game: ''If you're good, you don't have to tell them who you are. If you're bad, you don't want them to know.''

title:
Style Makers;

Robert Le Heros, Textile Designers
description: LEAD: Robert Le Heros is a curious designer signature, considering that the four art school graduates who founded this home furnishings textile company in 1987 are all women. Young - they are all 28 years old - and unorthodox, Blandine Lelong, Isabelle Rodier, Corinne Hellein and Christelle Le Dean believed that the name was symbolic of their design mission.

title: Pre-Civil War Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   The Creamy Flavor of Pesto But Without All That Fat
description: There is no way to put pesto in the low-fat, low-calorie column. But it is possible to obtain that rich creamy basil and pine nut flavor, using plenty of fresh basil, low-fat ricotta and yogurt and a little blue cheese.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: The Nation;   In Politics, Will 1990 Be a New Beginning?
description: The gulf crisis has become a lens through which Americans are focusing their ideas about a host of issues, foreign and domestic, military and economic, political and cultural. As the campaigns blah, blah, It has created oportunites for Republicans to revive themes and issues that had flagged, so to speak, but it also is bringing to vivid life the economic nationalism that some Democrats see as the last best hope for their party.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Portsmouth, N.H.;

Redeveloping Pease A.F.B.
description: LEAD: A $650-million proposal by the Bechtel Corporation to redevelop a military base scheduled to be shut down next June is now under review by the Pease Air Force Base Redevelopment Authority. It recently completed a series of public hearings on the proposal, which covers land in the communities of Portsmouth and Newington.

title: Blue Jays' Late Rally Beats Orioles Again
description: The Toronto Blue Jays, getting a three-run homer from Kelly Gruber, overcame a two-run deficit in the ninth inning for the second successive game, beating the Baltimore Orioles, 4-3, today to help themselves in the American League East.

title: Center Aids Teachers of the Disabled
description: LEAD: AS a special-education teacher re-entering the work force, Linda J. Rogen seeks the latest instructional manuals and research on teaching learning-disabled children. And as the mother of an adopted daughter who was born addicted to heroin and is now starting kindergarten, Ms. Rogen said she wants to be familiar with the research that may affect how her child is educated.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

In Search Of Just The Right House
description: LEAD: FORGET the latest hit movie. This summer's best entertainment was my search for a house in New Jersey. Besides, who can afford to waste money on a movie with a new mortgage to attend to? No way will I jeopardize my finances. No way.

title: Penelope Scott Weds Philip Moss
description: Penelope Ann Scott, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Scott Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Philip Alexander Moss, a son of Mrs. Roland C. Sherrer Jr. of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Salzburg, Austria, and Peter Bayard Moss of Chestertown, Md. The Rev. Dr. David St. George officiated at Christ Episocpal Church in Short Hills.

title: More Early Retirement Plans Offered by Large Companies
description: LEAD: AGING work forces at the high ends of salary scales and a sluggish economy that is squeezing profits are forcing Long Island employers to look for ways to cut costs.

title: From 93 Students to 7,000: Iona Celebrates Its 50th Year
description: LEAD: FIFTY years ago, Iona College was founded on the grounds of Iona Prep School here with an enrollment of 93 male students. Most were drafted to fight in World War II, and only four students graduated in 1944. No one graduated in 1945.

title: Was van Gogh Dizzy?
description: To the Editor:

title:
DANCE;

New Recognition for Denishawn Troupe
description: LEAD: THE Somerville-based Denishawn Repertory Dancers will perform 11 pieces from their repertory of early modern-dance works in Lyon, France, on Wednesday as part of the 1990 Lyon Biennale de la Danse. As specialists in the preservation and performance of works by the modern-dance pioneers Ruth St. Denis, Ted Shawn and Doris Humphrey, the eight-dancer ensemble will carry to the festival living examples of

title: Lucinda Florio Steps Gently Into a Spotlight of Her Own
description: LEAD: LUCINDA FLORIO was a little misty-eyed. It was school time again, Mrs. Florio's second year away from her third-grade classroom, where she had taught for 11 years. Earlier that morning a former student had visited her at Drumthwacket, the elegant mansion where she and the Governor live, toting scrapbooks and news of a life that seemed so far away.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

Architecture of Expectations
description: LEAD:

title:
ART;

Sculpture Garden Yields Bumper Crop
description: LEAD: AMID the welter of sculpture at the Kouros Gallery Sculpture Center, in Ridgefield, is a genuine scarecrow, a reminder that the place is essentially a garden. Besides noting what the crows might be after, one might also be distracted by the abundance of unopened orchids. But what this garden grows most visibly is contemporary sculpture, and it is a bumper crop.

title: Expos Trip Up Pirates
description: Manager Jim Leyland suggested, after a late-inning loss by the Pirates to the Expos on Friday night that perhaps his young team, in the severe heat of a pennant race, was scared.

title: Mutual Funds;   Here Comes the S.E.C. on Fees
description: In late August, Richard C. Breeden, head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and members of his staff shared a birthday cake with members of the Investment Company Institute, the mutual fund industry trade group. The occasion: the golden anniversary of the Investment Company Act of 1940, the law that regulates mutual funds.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have dark paneling that I would like to paint over in a light color. Over the years, I have used various spray-on furniture waxes and polishes on this paneling, and I am wondering how to prepare the surface for painting. Can I use a chemical de-glossing liquid, or do I have to sand the panels?

title: Review/Dance;   Jo Lechay's Reflections On Her Art
description: When Jo Lechay stared intently out at the audience on Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, she could have been gazing far into space deep into her own heart. ''Affamee'' (''Starved''),'' the hourlong solo she offered, was an excursion into both private and public realms.

title: Social Events
description: A Broadway Tribute

title: Reverse Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: Belize
description: To the Editor: The letter by Julian Janowitz (Travel, Feb. 11) concerning Belize and the drive to Tikal, which recently came to my attention, reminded me of a trip in December. My son and I rented a jeep and explored Belize. As part of the trip we drove to Tikal, approximately 60 miles from the border. Aside from a slight hassle at the Guatemalan side concerning vehicle papers, we found the trip absolutely delightful.

title: France's Industrial Shogun
description: Alain Gomez is an unlikely candidate to be the savior of America's consumer electronics industry.

title: A Tradition of Intrusion Collides With Western Rules
description: In the Damascus office of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria is a mural depicting the Battle of Hittin: in 1187, near Tiberias in the Holy Land, Saladin won a crucial victory over the Crusaders. Seven years ago, while standing in front of that painting, I commented to the Syrian President that this battle was where the Muslims soundly defeated the Christians. ''No,'' he said with a teasing smile. ''This was where the Arabs defeated the West.''

title: Initiative Amendment: Dissenting Views
description: Mr. Hochbaum argues that because our Legislature in recent years has become more ''open,'' and because it has spawned a growing bureaucracy of specialized committees with larger and larger staffs, it is well equipped to make good decisions for us. He says that the public's use of referendums would amount to amateur meddling, and that we should patiently wait for the next election if our representatives outrage us.

title: THEY'RE SO VAIN
description: The White House is ordinarily a place where vanity grows wild. But each Administration takes its cue from the boss, and George Bush has had it baked into his psyche from the time he was a lad in Greenwich, Conn., that it was unseemly to brag, preen or primp.

title: When the Two Germanys Unite, What Happens to the Bavarian Yodeler?
description: Dec. 17, 1989, Was the day i lost confidence in my television's remote-control device. It was just after the evening news broadcast on West Germany's ARD network, and Alois Moig, a 200-pounder attired in Alpine dress, appeared on the screen surrounded by a group of Bavarian yodelers and promising 90 minutes of folk music.

title: New Gardener
description: The new owner of the famed Pebble Beach Golf Links in California may be a Tokyo businessman, but at least Minoru Isutani has the Japanese savy to know the best remedy for an infestation of the dreaded kikuyugrass: some good old American know-how.

title: Japanese Cars Aren't More Fuel Efficient
description: To the Editor:

title:
Beauty/Fashion: Paris;

Face to Face With Four Cities
description: LEAD: French women have a secret weapon, it's water, hands down. No self-respecting Parisian is without her liter bottle of designer drinking water. Sales figures for Evian and Vittel, the two best-selling brands, more than prove the point: last year, Evian sold 805 million liters in metropolitan France alone.

title: Mother Teresa Hopes Nuns In Order Will Go to Albania
description: Mother Teresa said today that she hoped to send her order's nuns to care for the poor and destitute in Albania, Europe's last bastion of old-style Communism.

title: On the 2 P.M. From Adelaide To Alice
description: With a camel painted on its face, the sleek green and yellow engine of the Ghan train blasts its horn and slides out of Adelaide's Keswick Station every Thursday at 2 P.M. Bound for Alice Springs in the red desert heartlands of central Australia, the Ghan heads north, up through South Australia and into the Northern Territory.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine today about Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan refers incorrectly to Senator Bob Dole's position on the Senate Finance Committee. He is a member; Senator Lloyd Bentsen is chairman.

title: California, Land of Freeways, Plans to Build Toll Highways
description: California's first planned toll roads were announced Friday, marking the first time that motorists will face fees on anything but bridges.

title: Works in Progress;   Body of Work
description: ''He's reacting to a vulture flying overhead,'' says Stephen Brois, explaining the startled amazement on the face in the foreground above. Brois (above right, holding the skull) is one of three exhibit preparators at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City making the mannequins for the museum's new Hall of Human Biology and Evolution, scheduled to open in the fall of 1992. The face in question belongs to a test model, an imperfect draft (note the crack along the bridge of the nose) of a figure representing male Homo erectus, a human ancestor of about 1.7 million years ago.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: NO MORE MR. NICE GUY: A Life of Hardball. By Dick Williams and Bill Plaschke. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) Dick Williams managed six teams for a total of 21 years in the major leagues, winning 1,571 games (13th on the all-time list), taking three different franchises to the World Series and winning the baseball writers' Manager of the Year award three times. Four times he took over teams with losing histories and performed dramatic turnarounds. He fought, screamed, heckled umpires and opponents and probably, if such things could be determined, would be found to have kicked more dirt and made more lasting enemies than any other manager. Compared with Dick Williams, Billy Martin was a mere brat and Earl Weaver was Gandhi. Not the least of the charms of Mr. Williams's memoir, ''No More Mr. Nice Guy,'' is his refreshing refusal to rewrite history. Mr. Williams, now retired, is quite willing to acknowledge that he was, in the words of a former player, ''arrogant, brash and a pain.'' In his reply, Mr. Williams says, ''I always defend the truth.'' Being so candid about himself, he feels free to savage just about every baseball legend he has met. Speaking of his celebrated former teammates on the Brooklyn Dodgers, Mr. Williams writes, ''Many of those Boys of Summer weren't really boys but mean-spirited men filled with conceit.'' Mr. Williams even managed to fight with mascots, once threatening to assault the Philly Phanatic. Curiously, the one man you might expect Mr. Williams to blast - the irascible Charlie Finley, former owner of the Oakland A's - comes off comparatively well: ''While Charlie may have been a demon, he was a champion.'' Perhaps Mr. Williams saw a front-office version of himself. Not surprisingly, ''No More Mr. Nice Guy,'' written with the Los Angeles Times sportswriter Bill Plaschke, is great baseball reading; the 1967 pennant year of the Boston Red Sox and the string of championships in the early 70's with the A's are recalled in vivid detail. But the real kick of the book is the nearly constant fussin' and feudin'. ''When a fight is over,'' Mr. Williams says, ''it's over. I'll forgive. I just don't forget.'' His book demonstrates that he hasn't forgotten much that is worth remembering.

title: The Nation;   Behind the Census Numbers, Swirling Tides Of Movement
description: As demographers study the preliminary results of the 1990 census, they are discovering that not everything is as it seems. There were great internal population shifts, but they did not always reflect Americans' preferences for one part of the country over another. And places where growth had seemed to be stagnant were actually alive with counterbalancing migrations.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Amnesia and the Beach
description: LEAD: ''ONCE more unto the beach, dear friends, once more,'' we hum to ourselves on our way to the seaside. The trouble is we gloss over summer and retouch it with kinder hues during the winter months, softening the harsh light and smoothing the sand.

title: Gulf Crisis Slows Decline at Military Plants
description: THE crisis in the Persian Gulf could soon affect Connecticut's economy, injecting new life into the state's hard-hit military-equipment industry but possibly dealing a blow to the flourishing commercial aerospace business, military and industry analysts say.

title: To Lower Gas Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Will Face Improved Cowboys
description: It is tempting for Giants fans to dismiss today's game against the Dallas Cowboys in Irving, Tex., as a cakewalk.

title: Leaving Welfare Behind by Degrees
description: Every day, Esther Fuller wakes up in a Yonkers housing project crawling with crack dealers, plastered with graffiti and reeking of urine, and every night, she tucks her two children into bed there. But in between, on the rolling campus of Westchester Community College here, her life is undergoing a great, if gradual, change.

title: Tamsy Smith Wed In Rhode Island
description: Tamsy Rowena Smith, the daughter of Col. Allen D. Smith, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Smith, of Paige, Tex., was married yesterday to George Wild Markham, a son of Susan M. Kirkpatrick of Del Ray Beach, Fla., and Watch Hill, R.I., and the late Dean F. Markham. The Rev. Joseph Besse performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Watch Hill Chapel.

title: Former Dallas Police Chief Pleads Not Guilty to Perjury
description: The former Dallas police chief, Mack Vines, pleaded not guilty on Friday to a perjury charge that resulted in his dismissal earlier in the week.

title: Cities Get the Conductors They Deserve
description: And so it has begun, Zubin Mehta's 13th and final season as music director of the New York Philharmonic. Not by tradition the luckiest of numbers, but a record-breaker nonetheless; 13 represents the longest incumbency of any chief conductor in the orchestra's history. Inevitably, attention will center as this season unfolds on Mr. Mehta's stewardship and his place in Philharmonic history. What is likely to be overlooked, I think, is the role that New York itself has played in his long tenure and his limited artistic success. Music does not happen in a vacuum.

title: In Mississippi, They're Counted Out
description: The words are repeated, almost verbatim, from one front stoop to the next, as the residents of the Unita Blackwell housing project come out to answer a question from their Mayor, Unita Blackwell: ''No, ma'am, the census didn't come here.'' ''No, nobody talked to me.''

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

My Tiny Garden Has a Mind of Its Own
description: LEAD: MY handkerchief-size garden is not at its best this year and I don't know why. I harvested my first bit of produce - a perfectly formed, fairly large tomato. We shall have it for dinnercarefully sliced and arranged on its own plate at our candle-lit table.

title: About Men;   Vasectomy Vets
description: Shortly after our second daughter was born, I found a urologist in the Yellow Pages and made an appointment for a ''pre-vasectomy conference.'' To prevent children, my wife, Shoshana, had undergone eight years of diaphragms, jellies and foams. To create them, she had undergone four years of episiotomies, palpations, probes and sonograms. A vasectomy seemed the least I could do. In the waiting room, we filled out our reproductive short form. ''How many pregnancies have you had?'' ''How many children do you have?'' Besides our two daughters, there had been the cry of pain from the upstairs bathroom six weeks into my wife's second pregnancy. I had sprinted into the room and joined Shoshana, who was more upset than injured. We stood together at the toilet, staring down at a small, discrete pool of blood. Worse still was a pregnancy a year later that ended when a routine sonogram showed a great plume of matter spilling out of a gap in the fetal skull. At last, at 42, I was a man with a reasonable possibility of passing his genes into the next generation.

title: Data Bank/September 16, 1990
Postings: Celebration;   Hovels To Homes
description: When Maria Soto first laid eyes on the West 105th Street building she now calls home, it was dank and dirty and smelled of rain-soaked linoleum, discarded furniture and garbage.

title: Japan
description: To the Editor: In ''A View Too Close for Comfort'' (Travel, Aug. 19), Allen R. Myerson writes that the driver of a bus in Japan ''was curiously positioned on the right side of the bus, even though Japanese drivers are usually on the left.''

title: What the Handicapped Learn in School
description: I'd appreciate an opportunity to comment on Linda Saslow's article ''After Years of Declines, School Rolls Stabilize'' [Sept. 2] .

title: Flying High
description: The National Hockey League has two more potential million-dollar men, Ron Hextall, the Philadelphia Flyer goalie, and his teammate Rick Tocchet, a right wing. The two high-flying Flyers signed new long-term contracts Friday with incentive clauses that could bring them each $1 million this season.

title: Jail Plan Intensifies Battle For Harlem's Historic Sites
description: For nearly 20 years a row of century-old brownstones facing Mount Morris Park have stood abandoned, their interiors gutted and their facades crumbling while nearby town houses have painstakingly been restored in this central Harlem neighborhood.

title: Realty Doctorates
description: To the Editor:

title: In Insiders' City, Dixon Clings to Outsider Image
description: Among other things, Sharon Pratt Dixon had been the least known of the candidates in last Tuesday's Democratic mayoral primary.

title: Juli-Ann Dritz Marries
description: Juli-Ann Dritz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Dritz of Armonk, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Paul R. Cialone, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Tiberio Cialone of New Rochelle, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Cantor Raymond Smolover and the Rev. Sal Humana, a Roman Catholic priest, at the home of the bride's parents. Mrs. Cialone graduated summa cum laude from Cornell University.Her husband graduated magna cum laude from Colgate University and received his M.D. from the University of Rochester. He is a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester.

title: Lisa H. Steiman Marries
description: Lisa H. Steiman, the daughter of Esther Steiman of Black Rock, Conn., and the late Wolf Steiman, was married last evening to John B. Alters, the son of Maxine Alters and Gerald Alters, both of New York. Rabbi Robert J. Orkand officiated at Waveny House in New Haven. Mrs. Alters, 29, who graduated from New York University, is a producer of television commercials at BBDO advertising in New York. Her husband, 30, who is a graduate of Syracuse University, is a music producer at McCann-Erickson in New York.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Fire Island Obstacle

title: A Resort on the Edge of the Wild
description: The Tanjung Aru Beach Hotel is a luxury seaside resort in the Malaysian state of Sabah, on the northern tip of the grand, green island of Borneo. The hotel sits on 23 landscaped acres at the edge of the South China Sea, near the base of Mount Kinabalu, 13,455 feet tall. And while this is a deluxe resort with all the amenities - from a free-form swimming pool to tennis courts and a palm-shaded playground for children - it is surrounded by land and waters that are wild and exotic.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: THE FAB FOUR

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Jayme A. Shorin to Charles E. Hertan referred to the bride incorrectly and omitted her parents' names. She is the daughter of Philip P. Shorin of New York and Caryl J. Shorin of Great Neck, L.I., and is keeping her name.

title: If Lots of People Feel pain, Is That a Recession?
description: Whatever the statistics say, millions of Americans have concluded in recent weeks that the United States is in a recession. They are probably overstating the case. But if the word recession is heard more and more, it certainly reflects the hardship, both actual and anticipated, that is spreading across the country.

title: A Breathless 'Tenor' Races Into New Haven
description: THEATERGOERS who have a habit of darting up the aisles at the final drop of the curtain, just before the actors take their bows, hear this. At the end of ''Lend Me a Tenor,'' don't.

title: Internal Medicine as a Specialty Is Said to Be Losing Favor
description: LEAD: WHILE crises plaguing medicine such as skyrocketing costs, unavailable health insurance, and soaring malpractice awards have been highly publicized, within the medical world another problem is quietly festering. The specialty of internal medicine is ailing.

title: Who's Laughing Now? Women
description: Men who frequent the Improv, beware: next time could be your turn to be serenaded by Katsy Schappell. Ms. Schappell, a waiting-to-be-discovered comic, likes to pick a new man from the audience each night, then beckon him to join her onstage. There he will be seated on a chair while Ms. Schappell sings to him the haunting hit from ''Dreamgirls.'' Just when he's been lulled into a defenseless state, BAM! Ms. Schappell jumps him. She hurls him over her shoulder and spins him round and round, spanking this token of male oppression soundly on his patriarchal behind.

title: Big Matchup Turns Into Rout
description: The 1990 New York high school football season kicked off Friday night with a game between Union-Endicott High of Endicott, the state's top team last year in a poll of New York State sportswriters, and Bellport of Long Island, which finished 10th in that poll. The game was believed by the coaches to be the first between a powerhouse from Long Island and one from upstate.

title: Review/Music;   Martha Thigpen, As Tosca, Leads New City Opera Cast
description: New singers took up the principal roles in Puccini's ''Tosca'' at the New York City Opera on Tuesday evening. In terms of consistency and power, the performance was a considerable improvement over the one that opened this season's run last month. And some of the staging problems that afflicted the opener - in particular, the unfortunate tendency to have the singers overplay frailty by flopping around the stage - have been remedied as well.

title: No Thanks
description: It looked like the opportunity of a league lifetime, the chance to get a ready-made expansion team virtually guaranteed to be a contender the first season. But after reviewing a Soviet proposal to establish a team in Milwaukee as a National Hockey League club, John Ziegler, the N.H.L., president, said nyet.

title: Tenderhearted Men: Lonesome, Sad and Blue
description: There's a certain kind of American story that is characterized by a laconic surface and a tight-lipped speaking voice. The narrator in this story has been made inarticulate by modern life. Vulnerable to his own loneliness, he is forced into hard-boiled self-protection. His inexpressiveness is eloquent: the poetry of strong emotion trapped in confused and disintegrating times. Yet he longs for things to be other than they are. He yearns, in fact, for tender connection. Just behind the leanness and coolness of the prose lies the open - but doomed - expectation that romantic love saves. Settings vary and regional idioms intrude, but almost always it is men and women together that is being written about.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE FINAL CLUB

title: Choosing Sides
description: To the Editor:

title: Postings: Central Park Guide;   A Book of Bridges and Arches
description: Among Central Park's abundant esthetic surprises, some of the most charming and evocative are the bridges and arches. These compositions in cast iron, brick, wood and stone, each one different, span the landscape with delicacy and grace. Even their names conjure 19th-century romanticism: Denesmouth, Eaglevale, Greyshot, Huddlestone, Mountcliff, Pine Bank, Trefoil, Willowdell.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Shot to Death
description: A 50-year-old Brooklyn man was shot and killed Friday night as he walked down a dark street on his way to a video store to return some tapes, according to the police, who said that the fatal bullet apparently was intended for someone else.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Rockland, Mass.;

Prices Hold Near the Cape
description: LEAD: New houses are selling well in this growing area halfway between Boston and Cape Cod, where single-family houses priced at $163,000 to $197,000 are being marketed at French's Crossing, a development named for a creek on the property.

title: Gottschalk Wed in Illinois
description: Kirsten E. Gottschalk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Gottschalk of Lake Forest, Ill., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Brian C. Allaire, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Allaire of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. John F. Costello, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Yankees Are in Critical Condition as Their New Era Begins
description: They will finish in last place for the first time since 1966, the second time since 1912 and only the fourth time in the 88-year history of the franchise. They will very likely finish with their worst record since 1913. They have already suffered the first season-series shutout (to Oakland) in their history. They also failed to win a game at Fenway Park for the first time ever.

title: Miss Chen Weds George Murnaghan
description: Elizabeth Chen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald T. Chen of Boston, was married yesterday to George Andrews Murnaghan, the son of Jane Hughes Murnaghan of Glyndon, Md., and Judge Francis D. Murnaghan Jr. of Baltimore. The Rev. Douglas Fox officiated at the Old Otterbein United Methodist Church in Baltimore.

title: Question of the Week;   Are Umpires Getting Too Aggressive?
description: I do not like aggressive umpires, but I also do not like artificial turf, the designated hitter, domed stadiums, arrogant and egocentric team owners and pampered and immature players.

title: Always Off Balance and Always Secure

title: Show Fairness To Taiwanese

title: Car Injury Suits Are Declining
description: A CHANGE in the automobile insurance law in 1989 is resulting in a drop in personal injury lawsuits, which state officials applaud as a step toward lowering premiums.

title: In Budget Talks, Philosophy Is the Sticking Point
description: In eight days of bargaining sessions - some fiery, many tedious, most lasting until late at night - the White House officials and Congressional leaders working on a plan to reduce the Federal budget deficit have resolved the issues that could be settled by splitting the difference.

title: Duck Season Split; Bag Limit Is Three
description: Although there was a slight increase in the breeding populations of North American ducks this spring, New York State's waterfowl seasons and bag limits will remain much the same as last year.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SAILING FOR GOOD WILL

title: Streetscapes: The Old Grolier Club;   Recycling an 1890's Survivor
description: It has been a midtown puzzle, a curious, neo-Romanesque gem out of place in its surroundings of tall lofts and offices. Now the building, built for and occupied by the Grolier Club from 1889 to 1917, has reopened as the Grolier, a membership supper club.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT was one of those peaceful suburban afternoons. I was chained to my computer meeting some deadline or other, and the sound of Linda and her lawn mower hummed through my subconscious. And then the music stopped. ''Must have run out of gas,'' I mused, grasping the long straw. ''Open the door!'' my quick-thinking, quick-moving and arm-flailing wife shouted from halfway across the yard.

title: Lee Caswell Is Married To Melissa Cary Baten
description: Melissa C. Baten, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Baten of White Plains, was married last evening to Hollis L. Caswell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hollis Caswell of New Canaan, Conn. Rabbi Bruce Goldman officiated, assisted by the Rev. Eric Markman, a Presbyterian minister, at the Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Mrs. Caswell, 25 years old, and her husband, who is 31 and known as Lee, have M.B.A. degrees from Dartmouth College. She is a senior market specialist at Sun Micro Systems in Palo Alto, Calif., and he is the director of marketing at Kodiak Technology in San Jose, Calif.

title: Question of the Week;   Are Umpires Getting Too Aggressive?
description: Umpires are not aggressive enough. They take too much abuse, which demeans them and diminishes their authority. Why should they have to accept verbal and physical abuse by managers, coaches and players screaming in their faces?

title: Diana Simonds Is Married
description: Diana Simonds, an elementary and high school teacher in Caracas, Venezuela, and Gorki Mesones, an architect in Caracas, were married yesterday at the Little White Church in Eaton, N.H., by the Rev. Ronald P. Prinn, an Episcopal priest. Mrs. Mesones is a daughter of Joan P. Simonds of Yarmouth, Me., and the late James G. Simonds. The bridegroom, whose first marriage ended in divorce, is a son of Hilda Varvas of Chiclayo, Peru, and the late Alvaro Mesones de la Piedra of Lima, Peru.

title: Massachusetts Journal;   State Borrows Trouble With New Library Law
description: The frantic call to the Plymouth Public Library came from a woman who had several overdue books and was frightened that she might be arrested.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Margarine News: Polyunsaturated Anger
description: LEAD: SKIP the virtue and pass the hot-fudge sundae. I'm going to wring the neck of the next researcher who changes the ground rules about how to stay healthy.

title: Error-Filled Loss for the Lions
description: Three years ago, theirs had been the most promising freshman football class at Columbia in recent memory. This year was to be their year, with expectations high for these seniors to finally live up to the potential they had shown as undefeated freshmen in 1987.

title: Hoping for A Friendly Recession
description: American consumers, the bastion of strength in years past, reacted to the Mideast crisis by putting away their wallets. Now the question is whether those wallets can be pried open.

title: Germany Pledges $1.87 Billion to Aid Gulf Effort
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that his country would fulfill its responsibilities in the multinational effort to confront Iraq by providing military equipment and economic assistance worth $1.87 billion.

title: Question of the Week;   Are Umpires Getting Too Aggressive?
description: Today's game involves big bucks, so with bad rules and bad calls you get big bad fights. The commissioner's office should change the rules and bring in the replay. With one exception: don't use the replay on the call for balls and strikes.

title: Ex-Sergeant's Release Ordered in Stun-Gun Case
description: Overruling parole officials, a judge has ordered the release of a former New York City police sergeant imprisoned after being convicted for torturing suspects with a stun gun at a Queens station house.

title: F.A.A. Orders Secrecy on New Bomb Detectors
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration has classified as secret all new details about the performance of costly bomb detection devices whose capabilities have been widely questioned during a year of tests at several airports.

title: Parents Hellbent on Pleasure
description: THE LIGHT YEARS

title: Church Prods Kenya to Issue Report on Death
description: Stepping up its pressure for political change in Kenya, the Anglican Church called on the Government today to release a highly sensitive British investigative report on the slaying earlier this year of a former Foreign Minister.

title: George Michael on Fame and 'Freedom'
description: George Michael's hit single, ''Praying for Time,'' evokes a 1970's anthem by an ex-Beatle but turned emotionally upside down. Against a funereal beat of the sort George Harrison used to favor in his devotional ballads, the 27-year-old English pop star sermonizes in a voice that deliberately seems to echo the fuzzed vocal texture of John Lennon's ''Imagine.'' But instead of exhorting religious mysticism or utopian dreams, Mr. Michael emits an extended yelp of despair: ''It's hard to love when there's so much to hate/ Hanging on to hope when there is no hope to speak of.''

title: THE SPORTSCASTERS
description: You can keep your Vin Scully, Bob Costas and Tim McCarver. To me, the boys of summer are the New York Mets, minus sound, with a stack of Jimmy Buffett compact disks to accompany the action. Ain't life grand!

title: >Westport Blessed With Hong Kong Fare
description: Westport should count its blessings - two new Chinese restaurants have opened in recent months featuring Hong Kong cuisine, and both of them are very good.

title: Artistic Bonds In Southhampton
description: As a serious practicing artist, I wish to convey the following: the article ''Greek Artists Share a Shinnecock Bond'' [July 29] had some reservations on my part.

title: Vietnam Is Not the Enemy
description: You thought it was 1990, and the enemy was Iraq. No. For some policy makers in the Bush Administration it remains 1975, and the enemy remains Vietnam. There's no other plausible explanation for the Administration's self-defeating decision to extend the U.S. economic embargo against Vietnam for one more year under the Trading With the Enemy Act of 1917.

title: Article 212290 -- No Title
description: BLANK CHECK

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Peddlers, The Goatherds And the Gnus
description: LEAD: ONCE upon a time, not long ago, in a land not too far off, there resided a group of trusting and peaceful mortals. Happy and content in their Cape Cod wickiups, they lived serenely, in tiny villages, on the wooded hills surrounding the grassy plains of Gnu Valley.

title: FEARING BACKLASH, BIG OIL COMPANIES WILL TRIM PROFITS
description: Fearful of public and Congressional outcry over the large profits that many oil companies are likely to report for the fiscal quarter that ends in two weeks, industry executives are trying to find ways to hold down those profits.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing on page 52 of the Arts and Leisure section today for the Wretched Refuse String Band gives an outdated performance location, supplied by the band's publicity agent. The performance is at Brady's Tavern, 67 Murray Street, in Manhattan.

title: Headliners;   On the Shelves
description: Top Israeli intelligence officials may be having a word or two with whoever suggested that the best way to stop publication of a book in the United States was to go to court. To be sure, one New York judge did buy the Israeli Government's argument that the book, ''By Way of Deception: The Making and Unmaking of a Mossad Officer,'' would endanger Israeli agents. He ordered its distribution halted early last week. But top legal experts dismissed the ruling out of hand and a state appellate court overthrew it the next day. The author, Victor Ostrovsky, a former Mossad agent, said the Israelis were only in danger of being embarrassed. He says, for example, that Israel had advance knowledge of the bombing that killed 241 Marines in Lebanon in 1983 and failed to warn Washington. All in all, the Israelis' legal action accomplished the opposite of what they sought. The publisher, St. Martin's Press, said that with all the publicity, it had to double the first printing to 100,000 copies.

title: What's Iraq's Best Case?
description: Iraq's brutal invasion and pillage of Kuwait cannot be justified. Its violation of several Western embassies in Kuwait last week is inexcusable. But for the sake of any possible negotiated settlement, it's important at least to understand Iraq's grievances. If Saddam Hussein were disposed to solve problems peacefully, here are the arguments he might raise - and their answers.

title: Bradford Verter Weds Sarah Gardner
description: Sarah Sturges Gardner, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Gardner Jr., of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Bradford J. Michael Verter, a son of Scott J. Schwartz and Mona C. Verter of Brookline, Mass. Judge Aram H. Tellalian, a retired judge of the Connecticut Probate Court, officiated at the Fairfield Beach Club.

title: Lights, Camera, Sex
description: HARD CORE

title: Hints on Hats
description: A hat on a man can do something for him - or to him. Knowing the distinction has become even more important this season, when men's-wear styles from Armani to Brooks Brothers have featured the soft, slouchy silhouette that looks best with a hat. Men of the hour, from Dick Tracy to Gorbachev, have also helped put this accessory back in the news and on the heads of those who might not have considered it before.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the history of relations between the Soviet Union and Iraq misstated the signing date of a friendship treaty between the nations. It was 1972, not 1982.

title: For Visitors, a Make-Believe Bali
description: LEAD: In 1932 Colin McPhee, an American composer tired of Paris and depressed by news of Hitler's political success, sailed to Bali, Indonesia, intent on building a house where he could study the island's music. For days he drove around the hills, as he wrote in ''A House In Bali,'' ''looking for the perfect village, off the beaten track, far from the sight of tourists, yet near enough to some center of music and dancing.

title: Revised Wishbone Helps Power Army
description: Mike Mayweather, the left halfback who holds all the Army rushing records, ran for more than 100 yards today, and that is always a good sign for the Black Knights.

title: Another Approach to Managing a Pension Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools Draw Up Plans For 47 Emergencies
description: WITH all schools in the state preparing to meet an Oct. 1 deadline for having emergency plans in effect, the director of the county's Office of Disaster and Emergency Services, Edward J. Nullet, said Westchester's schools ''are as well prepared as any county in the state, if not better prepared.''

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Premier Vows Fight

title: Provincial Pottery From Thai Kilns
description: When they go north to the province of Chiangmai, the people of Thailand say they are going ''upcountry.'' The mountains extend down from Myanmar (formerly Burma) and Laos, forming a natural barrier to the rest of the land. Remarkable temples attest to the splendor of what was once the seat of Thai culture and the capital of the separate kingdom of Lanna. The hill tribes people come into Chiangmai's Night Bazaar to sell their handicrafts. And here celadon - the pottery of Thailand's Golden Age and called siladol in Thai - originated.

title: Soul Searching
description: To the Editor:

title: CHUNNELVISION
description: When the evening is clear in Folkestone, the lights of France throb gently just across the English Channel, as though Europe were creeping westward under cover of darkness. With a strong throw, a good flat rock, it seems, could skip all the way to Calais. Among the bright pinpoints strung along the coast, one radiates like a fuzzy headlight. It is the construction site for the Channel Tunnel, at Sangatte, floodlighted throughout the night as hundreds of workers carry on with the largest construction project Europe has seen this century.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There is at least one person in New York who never, well almost never, buys potatoes. This person has nothing against potatoes, in point of fact she considers that potatoes have everything going for them including, unfortunately, her appetite. This appetite is apparently insatiable when confronted with mashed, fried, scalloped, baked or roasted spuds and although these and other more esoteric versions are ordered when dining out, she knows that potatoes in her kitchen are an open invitation to disaster.

title: What Builders Really Want
description: If builders had anything worthwhile to say on the subject of the pine barrens, they'd be saying it.

title: AHEAD OF THE CROWD
description: There was a time when men were judged by their devotion to a subtlety called form. ''One had only to look at him,'' wrote Edith Wharton of one of her nattiest characters, to sense that ''form must be congenital in any one who knew how to wear . . . good clothes so carelessly . . . .''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table last Sunday listing the performance of world stock markets was out of date. The data, supplied by Goldman, Sachs & Company, were for the week ended Aug. 31. The table for the week ended Sept. 7 appears today on page 20.

title: The Budget, From Comedy to Tragedy
description: Our annual budget comedy is beginning to resemble a Greek tragedy, with well-meaning politicians terrified of doing the right thing and with our children as the hapless victims. Before the last act - which we hope is not yet written - it is time to rethink just why budget deficits matter and why we must do better than the ''summit'' package nearing completion in Washington.

title: Revised Plan for RAceway May Retain Sports Role
description: LEAD: BACKING away from plans for a large commercial and housing development on the 172-acre Roosevelt Raceway property in the commercial center of Nassau County, the owners of the property are cooperating with Town of Hempstead officials, who not only want the proposed project scaled down, but also seek to continue to use at least half the property for sports.

title: Votes in Congress;   Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: House

title: Officer's Last Words Recalled at Murder Trial
description: Six New York City police officers were killed in the line of duty last year, and in a quiet Manhattan courtroom on Friday the agonizing final moments of one of them were recalled without much emotion, or the usual courtroom tears, at the trial of one of the defendants charged with the officer's murder.

title: Changing Malaysian Isle
description: The sleepy island of Langkawi had its last and only moment on the world stage at the turn of the century when it became an unwitting pawn in the rivalry between the British and German empires, a struggle that would ultimately explode into the First World War. To the officers of the imperial German navy, Langkawi's sheltered bays and its location less than 50 miles off the west coast of the Malay peninsula made it an ideal base. With a secure port on the island, the Kaiser's ships could dominate the Strait of Malacca and the swelling stream of merchant shipping that passed through the strait ferrying goods between Europe and Asia.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: THE SPORTSCASTERS
description: I liked Charles Siebert's article, but his use of the past tense to describe radio's baseball announcers incorrectly assigns a premature death to a quite lively medium. I'm 24, and I grew up listening to Tiger baseball broadcasters Paul Carey and Ernie Harwell on my crystal radio late at night - Paul with his trained baritone; Ernie with that crackling drawl, saying, ''He stood there like the house by the side of the road and watched that one go by.'' Neither one was afraid to let you hear the noise of the crowd.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Manhattan Beach
description: May link recalls her first trolley rides to Manhattan Beach with her mother in 1912. For five cents, they took hour-long trips from working-class Williamsburg to the Brooklyn enclave of millionaires' mansions.

title:
Pastimes;

After a Frost, Harvest Begins
description: LEAD: Autumn's arrival, which will be official in one week, is a rewarding time for growers of parsnips, Brussels sprouts, Oriental cabbages, kale, carrots and many greens. These vegetables laugh at frost and reach their flavorful best in the nippy fall nights that zap their tender brethren. Cold acts on these hardy vegetables like

title: THE WORLD: Powers That Be;   It's a New World, Much Like That Of 50 Years Ago
description: Nine months into 1990, the world as Americans have known it for most of the last half-century has changed utterly. But in one major respect - the reliance of the free world on American power - it hasn't changed at all.

title: Florio and the Need To Raise Taxes
description: Re: ''Florio's Response to Tax Critics Is Questioned,'' Aug. 5:

title: A Change of Course by an Old Standby

Andre Guillet and Jean-Claude Denner are still running the show, with Andre in the dining room and Jean-Claude in the kitchen. But new menus and additional chefs (Giamba Pasquali and Alain Krauss) reflect a change in course by this traditional French restaurant.

title: Mining the Greeks' Gold Standard
