title: Those 'Sexy' Issues on Capitol Hill . . .
description: This summer, I left Capitol Hill after four years, grateful for the opportunity to have worked there, but afraid that good, conscientious government may have become too boring to be popular. While Washington's establishment - its politicians, reporters and administrators - is whipped into motion by the mere whiff of an emotional issue or scandal, there is no reward in today's Capitol for fixing the broken mechanics of govern ment or solving the huge problems that haunt us.

title: Shelley Huber Weds James Annarella
description: Shelley Goss Huber was married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Rumson, N.J., to James Vincent Annarella, the son of Mr. and Mrs. R. James Annarella of Locust, N.J. The Rev. Foster C. Wilson performed the ceremony.

title: Time of Decision: The LP Collector In the CD Age
description: I suppose i became a certifiable record collector the day I covered up one of my apartment windows with a second CD cabinet. Fellow collectors understood. But the others! You'd have thought I was an ax murderer. ''Can't you get rid of some LP's?'' they'd ask. Six years later, I have the answer: It all depends. When digital recording and the compact disk came along, consumers were expected to change buying habits of three decades, throw out their ''obsolete'' LP's and completely rebuild their collections. It's amazing how quickly that happened. But serious collectors find themselves in a quandary: which if any LP should be discarded when a duplicate CD is released?

title: What Makes The 2 Sexes So Vulnerable To Epidemic
description: A host of medical, cultural and economic factors make Africa especially vulnerable to the heterosexual spread of AIDS, which is believed to account for more than 80 percent of adult cases there.

title: Embracing Life in a Maelstrom
description: BEIRUT FRAGMENTS

title: Views on the Gulf: Lawmakers Versed in Vietnam
description: Their lives were touched by the long, hard, painful war in Vietnam.

description: Katherine Eastwick Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace E. Jones of Philadelphia, was married yesterday in Padanaram, Mass. to Richard Newcomb Stillwell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Stillwell of Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Walter A. Sullivan officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Chuch.

title: Ms. Cowgill Wed To D. S. DeCrane
description: Linda Jeanne Cowgill, a daughter of Mildred E. Cowgill of Rosarito Beach, Baja California, Mexico, and the late Lieut. Col. Wayne J. Cowgill, U.S.A.F., was married yesterday to David S. DeCrane, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. DeCrane Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Jonathan Young, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Crotona Institute in Ojai, Calif.

description: OUT OF BEDLAM

title: Tranquil Calverton Area May Undergo Changes
description: LEAD: ON a recent visit to the intersection of Routes 24 and 25, where the heart of Calverton beats under the hamlet's sole traffic light, the once-sleepy crossroads was awash with activity. Presaging the near future, an auction of 1,000 pieces of mostly farm equipment were being prepared for sale.

title: Just Give Me $10 Million, Baby
description: In their disappointment and disgust, some Oakland people burned their Raider jackets and T-shirts. And in nearby San Leandro, Calif., at Ricky's sports bar and restaurant, where Raider jerseys once worn by Ken Stabler and George Blanda are shrines, the huge white banner announcing ''Welcome Home, Oakland Raiders'' in silver-and-black lettering was taken down.

title: GOING, GOING, GONE
description: For a teen-age boy going bald, ''the first time'' has two meanings. My first ''first time'' came when I was 17, at midmorning, in the brightly lighted basement of a Massachusetts boys' boarding school. I was sitting in Mr. Sambito's barber's chair, receiving his customary five-minute bowl haircut, when he said, ''I got bad news for you, Clarke. It's going.'' ''What's going?'' ''Your hair, buddy.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Forum page last Sunday about corporate support for museum exhibitions misstated the year in which Daimler-Benz A.G. commissioned art from Andy Warhol. The work was commissioned in 1986 and exhibited at the Guggenheim Museum in 1988.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of construction, one of the three Lincoln Tunnel tubes will be closed until 6 A.M. tomorrow.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: FAST FORWARD
description: Attitudes are changing at the video store. Julia Roberts is partly to blame and so is Arnold Schwarzenegger. With the release of ''Pretty Woman'' (Touchstone) next month at $19.99 and ''Total Recall'' (LIVE) on Nov. 1 at $24.99, one of video's most strongly drawn lines of demarcation - that between renting or selling big hits when they first come out - has begun to fade somewhat.

title: For Single Men, a Place to Share Feelings and Shed a Tear
description: ALL the misconceptions about what ''real men'' don't do get left outside the door three Mondays a month when members of a support group called For Men Only get together to let their hair down, share feelings and sometimes even cry.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE BANANA WARS: A History of United States Military Intervention in Latin America From the Spanish-American War to the Invasion of Panama. By Ivan Musicant. (Macmillan, $24.95.) Ivan Musicant's military history of selected United States interventions in Central and South America is awkwardly written but painstakingly researched. Mr. Musicant, a former Marine whose previous books include ''Battleship at War'' and ''U.S. Armored Cruisers,'' is particularly thorough in describing ships, surf conditions and military tactics. Too thorough, in fact. He buries us in detail; the replacement of a provincial military chief in the occupation of Cuba, for example, receives almost as much weight in his story as Theodore Roosevelt's decision to reinvade the island. A lack of analysis weakens ''The Banana Wars'' even as military history. The chapter on the 1983 Grenada invasion reads like the script of ''H.M.S. Pinafore,'' with invading ships forced to count on the B.B.C. World Service for intelligence and maps too small to be read - no whitewash here - but Mr. Musicant never shows why such mistakes occurred. More important, the book treats invasions as problems in naval engineering or military logistics. Mr. Musicant says in his introduction that he will make no sweeping condemnation or approvals of policy, and then goes on to do exactly that with a checklist of ''good'' invasions (Panama in 1885, Cuba in 1899, Haiti) and ''bad'' (Cuba in 1912 and Nicaragua in 1927). But after spending two paragraphs of the introduction discussing what makes a justified or successful intervention, he does not offer any insights on the topic in the rest of the book. The material is there - the disastrous occupations to ''bring democracy'' to Cuba and Haiti foreshadow current attempts to do the same in Panama and El Salvador - but Mr. Musicant does not try to explain why the invasions failed. He draws no conclusions from his history, no lessons or insights to prevent fiascos in the future.

title: Fashion;   Designer Clothes at a Lower Price
description: Gordon Henderson doesn't like his nose. But it didn't seem to bother the admiring women who turned up at Saks Fifth Avenue on Thursday to meet the designer and see his fall clothes.

title: Miss Billingsley Weds Journalist
description: Ann Barker Billingsley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Billingsley of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Aldo Geracioti, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Geracioti of Toledo, Ohio.

title:
DINING OUT;

Dishes of Northern Italy in Tarrytown
description: LEAD: WHATEVER the reality, most Italian restaurants claim to offer northern Italian fare. They play to a dining audience that, for the most part, associates the north with light, refined, somewhat Francofied food and the south with heavy, oily, sharply spiced dishes. The truth is, a kitchen will usually prepare the dishes it makes best, paying little heed to these cliches of

description: Catherine Ann Sullivan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Galvin of Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. John J. Lynch officiated.

Both series are designed to appeal to audiences that up to now have not made either center part of their cultural lives.

title: Pastimes;   Camera

title: Who's Afraid of Industrial Policy?
description: It is not news that the United States and Japan are on a collision course. In fact, a book entitled ''Nichi-bei Shototsu e no Michi,'' which is roughly translated as ''The Japanese-American Collision Course,'' is a best seller in Tokyo. What is news is that intellectual vested interests stand in the way of clearly recognizing the differences between the two countries and prevent either side from taking appropriate measures to change course.

description: For more than a century ''three hots and a cot'' has been the Salvation Army's traditional reimbursement to the people it has sheltered and given a chance to work through their problems. But now the Federal Government says the organization should pay their workers the minimum wage as well.

Bass Jr. and Jacek von Henneberg, both of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to David Archibald Gillies, a son of Joy Gillies of Northport, L.I., and Archibald L. Gillies of New York. The Rev. Brendan Griswold performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Ferry House in South Dartmouth, Mass.

Your Own Account;

The Many Faces of a Pension Plan

Since then, the premises have metamorphosed into the Hudson River Museum and the association has changed its name to Hudson River Contemporary Artists, but the relationship has continued more or less uninterrupted.

On the verbal battlefield, the goal is not wealth or territory but the shaping of public opinion. But winning the hearts and minds of the Middle East is not easy, and in the war of words between Washington and Baghdad, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has a natural advantage.

title: New & Noteworthy

''A novel of obsession is moving - is successful - in direct proportion to its ability to implicate the reader in its own warped and passionate view of the world,'' Elizabeth Tallent said here last year. ''This wintry novel, breathing cold from every page, brimming with that violence, is magnificently convincing.''

title: Initiative Amendment: Dissenting Views

title: Ideas & Trends;   Why Gene Therapy Is Considered Scary But Cell Therapy Isn't
description: It took three years, three months, one week and one hour, but researchers at the National Institutes of Health finally got permission to try gene therapy. At 10:15 A.M. on Sept. 7, the director of the N.I.H. approved a proposal by Dr. W. French Anderson of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute and his colleagues to try to correct a rare but deadly immune system disorder in children. The researchers wanted to insert a gene taken from a healthy person into the victims' blood cells so they could make an enzyme they lack.

title: The Court, in Lectures and Cartoons
description: LEAD: THE Supreme Court from 1789 to the present - and its role in the lives of the American public - will be the focus of an exhibition of 24 political cartoons at the gallery of Marymount College in Tarrytown from Oct. 1 through Nov. 6. A series of lectures, one by Federal Judge Charles L. Brieant, chief judge of the Southern District of New York, will complement the exhibit.

title: Talking: Failed Plans;   The Rights Of Interim Tenants
description: One result of the downturn in the home market has been an increase in failed co-op conversion plans in the New York City area. Although no exact figures are available, ''we are definitely detecting an increasing number of failed plans,'' said Frederick K. Mehlman, assistant attorney general in charge of the state's Real Estate Financing Bureau, which regulates conversions.

title: As It Must to All, Death Comes To Post-Modernism
description: Ten years after it created a sensation in the art world, the tendentious, media-conscious movement known as post-modernism has lost its momentum. Having gained notoriety by announcing the death of the ideals and practices of modernist art, and having made household words out of such arcane terms as appropriation and deconstruction, post-modernism now shows the very same signs of fatigue that its adherents saw in the art world of the 1970's.

title: Airport Proposal Is Going to Voters
description: A DECADE-OLD struggle over the appropriate size of a new terminal at the Westchester County Airport, the keystone of a modernization program, entered what may be its final stretch last week, when the County Board of Legislators made its choice and asked for voter approval in an Election Day bond referendum. The legislators approved a 41,000-square-foot terminal at the airport, which abuts Greenwich. The new building would be four times the size of the existing terminal, a World War II Quonset hut.

title: German Expertise Not Needed to Develop Synfuels
description: To the Editor:

title: Chamber Recitals Plus Talks
description: THIRTY-FOUR years ago, Friends of Music began presenting chamber concerts in Connecticut and attempting to break down the barriers between performers and listeners. Named for the Viennese society founded by Beethoven and his pupil-patron Archduke Rudolph, the group also emulates its forebears by having pre-concert lectures or discussions in private homes as well as post-concert receptions with the performers for the entire audience.

title: Chilled by Violence, New Yorkers Are Questioning Life in Their City
description: New York City is looking in the mirror these days and does not like what it is seeing.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

The Early Wimp Gets to Work
description: LEAD: CALL me a wimp. That's what I feel like, or at least felt like, when I started getting up an hour earlier to beat the morning traffic crush on the Merritt Parkway. Like Peter Finch in ''Network,'' I, too, was mad as hell and wasn't going to take it anymore. But I didn't have the guts to scream it from a window until the whole world joined in.

title: PARIS ADDING 84,000 TO FORCE IN GULF; BONN'S AID TO RISE
description: Responding to Baghdad's moves against French and other foreign diplomats in Kuwait on Friday, President Francois Mitterrand today ordered 4,000 soldiers and dozens of planes, helicopters and tanks to Saudi Arabia.

title: Fashion;   From Paris, a la lingerie
description: Forget about mimicking Madonna - that's the vulgar approach. If, however, you harbor a longing to flutter out in public in your nightie, slip, bustier or petticoat, this is the way to do it.

title: Caroline L. Herter, Saleswoman, Wed To Benjamin W. Winship, a Musician
description: Caroline Lee Herter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Miles Herter of Manchester, Mass., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Benjamin Wistar Winship, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Winship of Lincoln, Mass. The Rev. Cynthia Kittredge, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Tentative Accord Reached to Keep Post Publishing
description: Peter S. Kalikow, owner of The New York Post, reached a tentative agreement with the paper's nine unions late Friday on concessions that would keep the paper open. But leadership of the Newspaper Guild was divided on whether to accept Mr. Kalikow's demands, and the union's members will settle the issue in a vote tomorrow.

title: Airport Compromise Awaits Verdict of Voters
description: A DECADE-OLD struggle over the appropriate size of a new terminal at the Westchester County Airport, the keystone of a modernization program, entered what may be its final stretch last week, when the County Board of Legislators made its choice and asked for voter approval in an Election Day bond referendum.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Portland, Me.;

First Venture By Japanese
description: LEAD: Tenants have begun moving into a 15-story apartment building here that is believed to be the first Japanese joint venture in a Maine real estate development.

title: Diana Lands and Michael Nathanson Are Wed
description: Diana Victoria Lands, the daughter of Mona M. Lands of Tarzana, Calif., and Dr. Victor G. Lands of Beverly Hills, Calif., was married yesterday in Rutherford, Calif., to Michael G. Nathanson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Nathanson of New York. Judge Donald R. Fretz of Superior Court in Napa, Calif., officiated at the Beaulieu Vineyards.

title: Lori Janice Shyer and Steven Ray Glick Marry
description: Lori Janice Shyer and Steven Ray Glick were married last evening at Windows on the World in New York, with Rabbi Arthur Schwartz officiating. Mrs. Glick is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Shyer of New York. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton Glick of Boca Raton, Fla.

title: On Language;   Right On, Dead-On
description: For a bravura example of deadline reporting,'' reads the citation to Linda Greenhouse, ''and dead-on analysis as the Supreme Court ended its session. . . .'' That's the wording of one of the coveted publisher's awards posted on the bulletin board in the New York Times Washington bureau.

title: Fashion;   Chenille: From Household to Wardrobe
description: If you think chenille means bedspreads, bathrobes and bathmats, you're in for a surprise this fall.

title: Correction
description: An article on July 29 about canoeing in Zimbabwe misstated the telephone number of Safariworld. The tour operator has recently written to point out that the number is (800) 366-0505.

title: Reliving the War Between Brothers
description: LEAD: For more than five years, the film maker Ken Burns has, in a sense, been refighting the Civil War. In preparation for his 11-hour documentary on the conflict, which begins next Sunday on the Public Broadcasting Service, the 37-year-old Mr. Burns immersed himself in written and visual documents relating to the war, in an effort to trace its causes, re-create its battles and analyze the potent reverberations of what he calls ''our near suicide.

title: Medical Research Must Show Results
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Straddle a Line in Policy Statement
description: The Democratic National Committee tried to accomplish a difficult task here today: express full support for the American troops in the Persian Gulf while criticizing the Republican Administration that put them there.

title: Missing The Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Boris Yeltsin: At Least He Has a Plan
description: Given his problems at home, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev undoubtedly regarded last week's summit meeting with George Bush as a welcome relief. By contrast, it was his Aug. 30 ''summit'' with Boris N. Yeltsin that was the ordeal. Mr. Yeltsin used his post as President of the Russian Republic to issue a 500-day plan for economic reform. In so doing, he took the political and economic initiative away from Mr. Gorbachev and forced him to sign onto his plan at the last minute. Finally there is someone in the Soviet Union who seems to know what he wants to do - and when.

title: Miss Paglia Wed To A. J. Curtin
description: Anne Marie Paglia, a daughter of Dr. Michael A. Paglia and Dr. Albina Claps of Grimes Hill, S.I., was married yesterday to Andrew J. Curtin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Curtin of Orchard Park, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph A. Jordan performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church in Grimes Hill.

title: Tougher Rules Backed on Pollutants in Smog
description: House and Senate negotiators gave formal approval Friday to a provision of the clean air bill that would require factories and businesses to tighten controls on pollutants that cause smog.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Overrated
description: To the Editor:

title: Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Liberal? Conservative? Or Just Pat?
description: Few people relish being right quite so fiercely as Daniel Patrick Moynihan; and just now, New York's senior Senator is taking particular delight in being right at the right time. He has specialized, in years past, in unseasonable, unpalatable truths - about the breakdown of the black family, about the paralysis of the United Nations - and he has publicly reveled in his martyrdom. This time, however, history has caught up with him. In recent months, Moynihan has insisted that the collapse of the system built on the cold war permits - in fact demands - a return to old American political principles, above all a respect for international law. Late last month, Harvard University Press published Moynihan's 15th book, ''On the Law of Nations.'' And at virtually the same moment, the United States, acting through the United Nations, orchestrated a worldwide response to Iraq's aggression against Kuwait. For once, everybody was riding Moynihan's hobbyhorse.

title: Be Quiet, Father Is Writing
description: LEAD:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE ISLAMIC CULTURAL CENTER;

Where Moslems Gather to Worship, Study and Socialize
description: LEAD: THE mosque is in a white frame ranch house; a crescent, symbol of the Moslem faith, adorns the roof. The offices are in a rambling white frame mansion, the kind often associated with American country estates, but in the living room there is a small tiled pool for guests who wish to bathe their feet, in the Middle

title: Fine Singing in a Weill Sampler
description: ONE song contains the lyric ''For once do something bad and you'll survive.'' Another sings of ''good beyond such ill,'' of ''faith and trust in mankind.''

title: Rock vs. Disco: Who Really Won the War?
description: Electrified popular music of the last 35 years has suffered its share of attacks from without, the opponents being mainly parents or religious extremists. But it has also been riven by internal polemics, and few of those battles grew fiercer and meaner than the rock-versus-disco wars of the late 1970's.

Morehouse of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Matthew Alden Kenney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Kenney of Searsport, Me. The Rev. Fred Bender officiated at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn.

title: Q and A
description: Car 'Purchase' in Europe

title: Evening Hours;   Sweaters, Flowers And Man Ray's Art
description: A party in honor of the exhibition ''Man Ray/Bazaar Years: A Fashion Retrospective'' drew guests on Monday to the midtown gallery of the International Center of Photography. The sponsors were the Chase Manhattan Corporation and Hearst Magazines.

title: Miss Jones Wed To R.N. Stillwell
description: Katherine Eastwick Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace C. Jones of Philadelphia, was married yesterday in Padanaram, Mass., to Richard Newcomb Stillwell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Stillwell of Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Walter A. Sullivan officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: John B. Evans Weds Miss Kim
description: Deborah Yong Kim, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Y. Kim of Butler, Pa., was married yesterday to John Berwyn Evans, the son of Emma Evans of Cheshire, England, and the late E. A. B. Evans. The Rev. Ann Holt officiated at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Sky Manor, N.J.

title: Leaving Chicago
description: The Chicago White Sox, surprising contenders in the American League West this season, announced yesterday that by mutual agreement their general manager, Larry Himes, would not return for the 1991 season.

title: Review/Pop;   Ice Cube's Hip-Hop Warms up the Apollo
description: The most enlightened discussions about violence and sexism in hip-hop have focused on how the audience receives it. Ice Cube, a rap artist from Los Angeles whose undeniably violent and sexist record, ''Amerikkka's Most Wanted,'' has become a hit with virtually no airplay, headlined a hip-hop show at the Apollo Theater on Sept. 8.

title: Miss Crow Weds P.H. Flanagan
description: Leslie Kirven Crow, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Crow of Asheville, N.C., was married there yesterday to Patrick Houghton Flanagan, the son of Mrs. James L. Emery of Washington and Thomas J. Flanagan of Rochester. The Rev. William M. Todd performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Miss Adkins Wed To David Ernst
description: Jennifer Brooks Adkins and David Ernst were married yesterday at the Siasconset (Mass.) Union Chapel by the Revs. Edward B. Anderson, a Unitarian minister, and Dr. Leslie John Adkins, a Congregational minister and a grandfather of the bride.

title: Focus: The Midwest Market;   Demand is Strong and Prices Are Rising
description: In marked contrast to the housing picture in the rest of the country, the demand for homes throughout the Middle West remains robust, with brisk sales and rising prices signaling the region's emergence as the strongest market in the country.

title: Colleen Hughes and Tony Scherman, Editors, Wed
description: Colleen E. Hughes and Tony Scherman, magazine editors in New York, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David E. Scherman, in Stony Point, N.Y. The Rev. Clarke Campbell-Evans, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: In Brooklyn, Dinkins Asks for Help in Crime Fight
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, who has asked New Yorkers to get involved in the fight against crime, carried his request to the streets of East New York yesterday, a section of Brooklyn with one of the highest crime rates in the city.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: 2 New Yorkers Win 2d World Bridge Titles
description: Four bridge experts, two from Brazil and two from New York City, won their second world titles in a year this afternoon.

title: WHEN PARENTHESES ARE TRANSGRESSIVE
description: Richard Bernstein's On Language column ''When Parentheses Are Transgressive'' (July 29) is a good update of George Orwell's essay, ''Politics and the English Language.''

title: South Africa Cracks Down in Townships
description: The South African police announced a severe crackdown on township violence today, a day after Nelson Mandela said that the Government believed sinister outsiders were manipulating the fighting between rival black factions.

title: Meg Laidlaw Is Wed to John Nebens
description: Margaret Elizabeth Laidlaw, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Laidlaw of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Mitchell Nebens, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Nebens of Millwood, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Larry L. Bethune officiated at the Bedford (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

Twente, both of Brooklyn, N.Y. The Rev P. C. Enniss performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church in Bronxville.

title: Ms. Eckman Wed In Westchester
description: Heidi Kim Eckman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Eckman of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Barry Philip Silverstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Silverstein of West Newton, Mass. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at the Baldwin Estate in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Harold S. Carlson, 87, A Psychology Educator
description: Harold S. Carlson, an educator, former chairman of the American Association of State Psychology Boards and former president of the New Jersey Psychology Association, died yesterday in Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 87 years and lived in Amenia, N.Y.

title: Jury Award In Hughes Case
description: A jury has awarded a discharged Hughes Aircraft worker $1.9 million after finding the company retaliated against him for uncovering overcharges on Government military contract work.

title: Experts Tally the Cost Of Rebuilding Kuwait
description: With Iraqi soldiers crushing roads under the weight of their tanks and reportedly mining public utilities and oilfields, how quickly would Kuwait be able to rebuild its economy if it is liberated?

title: Lawmakers Hopeful on a Budget Deal
description: Congressional leaders from both parties said today that they thought negotiators working on a new Federal budget could resolve differences over tax policy and reach a compromise as early as Monday night to reduce the deficit.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

American Bikers Are on Top
description: LEAD: American racers won four of five events at the world mountain-bike cross-country championships here today, with each champion besting the efforts of athletes from 26 countries.

title: Calling To Account
description: Here are three officials who ought to be looking for new jobs: 1. The Chief Legal Counsel in the Mossad has just made an oxymoron out of ''Israeli intelligence'' and deserves to be fired.

title: The Myth of Iraq's Oil Stranglehold
description: LEAD: One of the major justifications for America's intervention in the Persian Gulf is oil, both its price and its strategic value. Iraq, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia collectively possess half the world's proven petroleum reserves, the argument goes. How could we allow Saddam Hussein to control half the world's oil resources?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Magazines;   For Former Staff of 7 Days Eighth Day Dawns Quickly
description: IN the magazine industry, the surest ticket to success is often failure.

description: Could the most impressive 2-year-old in the country this year be a filly?

title: S.& L. Failures Benefit Seller of Troubled Assets
description: The misfortune of the savings and loan industry has brought good fortune to Joseph E. Robert Jr. Mr. Robert is chairman of the J. E. Robert Companies, an organization that was in the right place at the right time when the Government needed to contract for managers to dispose of the assets of failed institutions.

title: Post or No Post, Dailies Face Flux
description: The fate of The New York Post, be it life or death, raises the curtain on a period of tremendous flux in the city's already tense and economically distressed newspaper market -particularly for The Daily News, which is embroiled in its own showdown with unions.

Stolwijk, the Susan Dwight Bliss Professor of Epidemiology and Public Health at Yale University. Rabbi Emily Korzenik officiated at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick P. Rose of Rye, N.Y.

description: Oil and the Mideast

description: French farmers have stepped up their violent attacks on trucks hauling imported livestock in a protest that has divided France's Government and renewed tensions with Britain.

title: Can Life After Tennis Be Free of Plane Noise?
description: To the Editor:

title: Within South Africa, The 'Lost Generation'
description: For many young South African blacks, liberation could yield little without the education they gave up for revolution.

description: TO say that Dorothy (Dodo) Cheney comes from a tennis-playing family is like saying there is water in the ocean.

title: Prostitute Quits But Too Late
description: Ann Kanini, 30 years old, still lives in the same Nairobi slum where she worked for five years as a prostitute. She quit a year ago, knowing it was too late. ''I was already getting sick,'' she said. Quitting, she knew, would at least stop the steady exposure to other sexually transmitted diseases that might hasten her death.

title: Alas, Judge Souter Won't Read This
description: LEAD: The media portrayal of Judge David Souter as a recluse from the back woods of New Hampshire raises a serious question about his fitness for the Supreme Court.

title: Outdoors: The Feast That Follows the Catch
description: ALTHOUGH there are some anglers, most notably those who fly-fish for trout in no-kill areas, to whom hooking and playing the fish are everything, most of us who angle find pleasure in consuming our prey. Indeed, to this fisherman at least, the ritual is incomplete unless the feast follows the catch.

title: Review/Art;   Malevich's Search for a New Reality
description: The Kasimir Malevich retrospective that opened Sunday at the National Gallery of Art is more than a landmark exhibition. It is an exceptionally moving event. For the first time the American public is being given a thorough look at the greatest 20th-century Soviet painter, one of the select few who helped shape the modernist imagination.

title: U.N. Seeks Wider Embargo In Vote Assailing Iraqi Acts
description: The Security Council unanimously condemned Baghdad early today for acts of violence against foreign embassies and their personnel in occupied Kuwait and promised new, unspecified steps to tighten the mandatory trade embargo against Iraq.

title: Business and the Law;   An Old Weapon Against Buyouts
description: THE bondholders of Allied Stores said last week that they expected to file a lawsuit next month seeking at least $700 million from the Campeau Corporation, Allied's parent, and a group of banks and investment houses.

title: Man Shoots Himself After Estranged Wife Is Slain
description: A Manhattan woman was shot and killed Saturday night by a man the police said was her estranged husband. The man then shot himself in the chest. The woman, Patrice David, 20 years old, who lived at 1963 Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard, near 118th Street, died after being struck by four bullets fired from a .380-caliber automatic pistol outside 988 Lincoln Place in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, a police spokesman, Officer Scott Bloch, said.

title: Review/Opera;   Chicago Season Opens With Gluck's 'Alceste'
description: Christoph Willibald Gluck's ''Alceste,'' with which Lyric Opera of Chicago opened its 1990 season on Friday evening, is known to the musical public for two principal reasons: the aria ''Divinites du Styx'' and the reformist manifesto that the composer published in connection with the first performance in Vienna on Dec. 26, 1767. Though the opera is periodically revived, its respectable credentials have never been enough to keep it in the international repertory for long. However, the work holds so much historical interest that almost any new staging can arouse the serious operagoer's curiosity.

title: Shanahan Gaining With Every Move
description: Brendan Shanahan is one of five invaluable members of the Devils entering their option years, but contracts are the last thing on any of their minds, especially Shanahan's.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf

title: 3 Plead Guilty In Stock Fraud
description: Three former officials of F. D. Roberts Securities Inc. pleaded guilty on Friday to Federal felony charges in one of the largest cases of penny-stock frauds.

description: For thousands of Asians fleeing Kuwait, misery has pitched a tent at this Turkish outpost on the border with Iraq.

Kefauver Jr. of Washington. The Rev. Sheldon Reese, a Methodist minister, officiated at the Strong Mansion at Sugarloaf Mountain in Dickerson, Md.

Dinkins and his aides have groped for two weeks to say and do what they think is right on crime in ways that others think is right, too.

description: For 30 minutes, as much time as it takes to place a patient inside the metal doughnut of a CAT scanner and make a cross-sectioned study of his cancerous throat, the fate of Buster hung in the balance.

description: Israeli officials expressed alarm today over American plans to sell more than $20 billion in advanced weapons to Saudi Arabia, and they began making efforts to get more military aid for themselves.

title: Giants Breeze Past Cowboys
description: The heat was oppressive today - 96 degrees in the stands, 104 on the Astroturf field of Texas Stadium. As far as the Dallas Cowboys were concerned, the Giants were oppressive, too.

title: Pebble Beach Glee Is Hard to Hide
description: It would be hard to find a company more ambivalent about the biggest deal in its history than the private Japanese concern that just bought the Pebble Beach Company, making one of America's best-known golf resorts into another prestigious Japanese holding.

title: Jane Simon Is Wed to Stephen Poss
description: Jane Fitz Simon, a daughter of Jane F. Huston of San Diego and Maurice C. Fitzsimons of Salem, Ore., was married yesterday to Stephen Daniel Poss, a son of the late Bernice and Gilbert Poss of Buffalo. Rabbi Cathy L. Felix performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's sister, Dr. Ellen Poss, and brother-in-law, Mitchell Kapor, in Brookline, Mass.

title: Use Head and Feet For This Hiking
description: IN the sport of orienteering, the two most important elements are the feet and the head. The feet will get you there. But you must decide where there is. So this is an athletic and cerebral sport with little left to chance.

title: Politics Of Hate
description: Edwin O'Connor drew the classic picture of Massachusetts politics in ''The Last Hurrah.'' It was a world of hacks and scoundrels, of lovable rogues and rented dogs. O'Connor modeled his tainted hero on James Michael Curley, the Mayor, Governor and Congressman who served a term in Federal prison.

title: Sure We Need Beauticians...
description: LEAD: I had a miserable summer. As a college president I should have been happy. A lot of students wanted to enter DePauw this fall. Yet in spite of the institution's largest financial aid program ever, these freshmen insisted they needed more money. I believed them, but what could we do? We were dangerously close to deficit budgeting for the first time in decades, and the fastest-growing expenditure was financial aid.

title: Chronicle
description: Six-year-old SAM LeBLOND, a grandson of GEORGE and BARBARA BUSH, has begun first grade at a public school in the Washington area, accompanied by two friends wearing dark suits and earphones. Secret Service agents stay with both Sam and his 3-year-old sister NANCY ELLIS LEBLOND, who attends a private kindergarten.

title: Kroger Picks President And Chief Adds Title
description: The Kroger Company, a major supermarket chain, has named a president and chief operating officer, and its new chief executive has added the title of chairman.

title: Dinah Martin and Stephen Lefkowitz Are Wed
description: Dinah Martin and Stephen Lefkowitz were married yesterday at the home of the bride's father, Samuel N. Friedman, in New York by Rabbi Amy Ehrlich.

title: Steve Condos, 71, a Tap Dancer, Dies After Performance in France
description: Steve Condos, who won widespread acclaim as a tap-dance virtuoso in recent years after a lifelong career in films and vaudeville, died shortly after performing at the Lyons International Dance Biennial in France tonight. Mr. Condos was 71 years old and lived in Hollywood, Fla.

title: A Surge of Anti-Semitic Crimes Jars Madison's Pride as a Liberal Haven
description: As always around the holidays, Jewish children will be asking their parents many questions this week about the meaning of Rosh ha-Shanah.

title: In South Africa, a 'Lost Generation'
description: While still in his teens, Lulamile Jojiyasi walked out of school as part of a boycott. That was in February 1984. He never went back.

title: Lead for Red Sox Shrinks to 1 Game
description: The Chicago White Sox completed a four-game sweep of Boston today, beating the stumbling Red Sox by 4-2 as Bobby Thigpen got his 51st save.

title: Soviet Violinist, 20, Wins Competition
description: Pavel Berman, a 20-year-old Soviet violinist, won the top prize in the 1990 International Violin Competition of Indianapolis yesterday, contest officials announced.

title: More on the Gulf
description: FASTER LOAN RELIEF Big global lending agencies plan to make loans more quickly and provide other help to countries suffering the consequences of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Business Day, page D1.

title: The 'Not Bork' Test;   Senators Know What Judge Souter Isn't, But a Question Remains: Is That Enough?
description: While the cameras and the questions focused on David H. Souter in the opening days of his Supreme Court confirmation hearings last week, the confirmation process itself was also on display.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Saddam Hussein tells you that this crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world.''

title: Robin P. Levine Is Married
description: Robin Phyllis Levine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Harvey Levine of Sands Point, L.I., was married yesterday to David Aron Sigman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Sigman of Roslyn Heights, L.I. Rabbis Lee Friedlander and Joy Levitt officiated at Harrison House in Glen Cove, L.I. Mrs. Sigman, 29 years old, graduated from Trinity College in Hartford and is the marketing manager at Parenting magazine in New York. Her husband, 29, graduated from Princeton University. He is a project manager with the Zeckendorf real-estate development company in New York.

title: AIDS Tears Lives of the African Family
description: Sanford Mweupe now looks back wistfully on the uncomplicated days when he had only two wives to worry about. So do the two wives. Domestic life has been strained ever since the events delicately referred to in the household as ''the confusion.''

title: Egypt Raises Its Guard Against Iraqi Terrorism
description: The Egyptian authorities have begun to register concern that the Persian Gulf conflict could spill over here in the form of Iraqi-sponsored terrorism, Western diplomats said today.

title: Why Not a Hero?
description: LEAD: DENNIS CONNER, who opened America's eyes to sailing in 1987, changing forever the tradition of the America's Cup, smiled when he heard the sport's ''in'' crowd thinks he will be hard pressed to win the right to defend the cup in 1992.

title: Roberta Tulman Is Married
description: Roberta Naomi Tulman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Tulman of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Randy Samuels, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Samuels of Bridgewater, N.J. Rabbi Barry Friedman, assisted by Cantor Bruce Benson, officiated at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J.

title: 49ers Triumph; Mark for Montana
description: Joe Montana, who became San Francisco's career leader in passing yardage, threw for touchdowns to John Taylor and Jerry Rice as the 49ers beat the Washington Redskins, 26-13, today.

title: Superpowers Seeking an Angola Agreement
description: In another sign of growing superpower cooperation, the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to work jointly as mediators to revive Angola's stalled peace talks and end civil strife there, American and Soviet officials say.

title: Leftist Journal Concludes Allende Killed Himself
description: Saying that the ''historic truth'' should be known, a Chilean news magazine identified with the left has published a special report concluding that former President Salvador Allende committed suicide 17 years ago.

title: New School Aid in '91? Toms River Isn't Cheering
description: Come September 1991, and the public school district here will get its first installment of a five-year, $53 million increase in state education aid. But that first installment, nearly $28 million, has generated little sense of ecstasy in the district.

title: Writers in China Are Asked to Write, But Not Subversively
description: Literature is like groceries, says Ma Feng, the earthy ''old revolutionary'' who is China's new literary czar: in both cases the government should encourage what is nutritious and ban what is poisonous.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, followed on Thursday by an auction of one-year bills.

title: INSIDE
description: Fighting in Liberia

title: Money Is the Word to Cruciverbalists
description: After two years of preparation, a group of leading crossword-puzzle writers and editors met in New York on Saturday to seek 1 across: what Aretha Franklin wanted the most (r-e-s-p-e-c-t).

title: Soviet Trading In Commodities
description: A newly created Moscow Commodity Exchange is selling seats for about $162,000 and plans to begin trading next week, a Soviet news agency reported Friday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   How Ayer Views Talks With Dentsu
description: JERRY J. SIANO, the chairman and chief executive of Ayer, wants to set the record straight.

title: Dolphins Dazzling in Victory
description: Coach Don Shula said the Miami Dolphins approached perfection today, and as a result they have the only perfect record in the American Football Conference East.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Cruising in the Wind
description: Jim Drake, a designer of the windsurfer in 1967, has developed a cruising version of the sailboard. But instead of one hull, his new craft has three, a configuration that makes capsizing less likely. The spindly craft has two compartments in the hull for stowing gear like a tent, sleeping bag, food and water, goods that might be needed for long-distance trips.

title: White Says He's No Diplomat And He Makes No Apologies
description: BILL WHITE has long prided himself on being a person who cannot be easily fitted into any mold. In the early 1960's, when it was safer for one's career as well as health to acquiesce quietly to the nation's Jim Crow laws, White was among a vocal minority of black players who spoke out vociferously against inadequacies at Florida spring-training sites and in minor league cities throughout the South.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article in some copies yesterday about French steps in the Persian Gulf crisis misstated the procedure that would be permissible if the United Nations expanded the embargo against Iraq to air traffic.

title: State Farm Limits Role in Pennsylvania
description: The State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company has told its agents to stop writing new policies in Pennsylvania.

title: Weicker's Lead Is Narrowing In Governor Race, Poll Finds
description: Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the independent gubernatorial candidate, has lost a sizable portion of his support but still holds a commanding lead over the Democratic and Republican candidates in the race, according to a poll released this weekend by Quinnipiac College in Hamden.

title: Nancy Lewson Is Married
description: Nancy Beth Lewson, the chief of staff at the New York City Department of Environmental Protection, was married yesterday to Howard Alan Kurz, a managing director of the Continental Grain Company in New York. Rabbi David Greenberg, assisted by Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson, officiated at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Crew Is Injured in Tanker Blast in Michigan
description: A fuel tanker exploded and burned today in the Saginaw River, injuring most of the 18 people aboard and spilling gasoline into the water, the authorities said.

title: Op-Ed Columnists
description: The days on which Op-Ed columnists appear are rotated periodically.

title: Bridge
description: When the two World Pairs Championships ended here Saturday it was clear that 12 time periods had magic properties.

title: Ms. Steiker Weds Paul V. Holtzman
description: Carol Susan Steiker and Paul Victor Holtzman, lawyers in Washington, were married yesterday at the Andalusia estate in Andalusia, Pa., by Rabbi Myron Fenster. The bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Steiker of Elkins Park, Pa. Her husband is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles M. Holtzman of Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: Mets Fall Again to DeJesus
description: For a fleeting moment yesterday afternoon, the Mets were tied for first place with the Pirates. It was about as fleeting as a moment can get.

title: Egypt Will Send More Soldiers to the Gulf
description: Responding to United States urging, Egypt is to expand its troop strength in the Persian Gulf with a mechanized division of up to 15,000 soldiers backed by tanks and armored personnel carriers to confront Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, military officials said today.

title: Spain's Leader Feels the Heat From Scandal
description: For most of the time since he became Spain's Prime Minister in 1982, Felipe Gonzalez has been able to concentrate on the affairs of state in the confident knowledge that his chief deputy, Alfonso Guerra, was serving as his political bodyguard.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;

Allen Panned For Video Act
description: LEAD: MAYBE it was because he had been away from the college football scene so long he had forgot the niceties of the gentlemen's agreements whereby rival coaches routinely exchange videotapes of their most recent games.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 16:

title: Chronicle
description: These are among the recipients of various honors in recent days:

title: Claudia Gropper Marries Jay Gayner
description: Claudia M. Gropper, the daughter of Ursula M. Gropper of Sausalito, Calif., and Dr. Marc N. Gropper of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Jay D. Gayner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving C. Gayner of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Mark Schiftan officated at Lyford House in Tiburon, Calif.

title: Easing Local Phone Rules: Fight on Profit
description: A year ago the Government granted the American Telephone and Telegraph Company greater freedom to raise or lower prices while eliminating most controls on its rate of return. The idea was to encourage better services, cut costs and create savings for consumers and shareholders.

title: Editorial Notebook;   The 'Tyranny' of 911
description: In New York City's ongoing debate over crime, ''community policing'' often sounds like a buzzword -an impressive label for vague ideas. In fact, however, ''community policing'' refers to a well developed theory of law enforcement that has been the subject of experiment and research in a number of cities for much of the past decade.

title: Irate Voters in Gabon Attack Poll Aides and Ballot Boxes
description: Voters in this West African nation attacked election officials and smashed ballot boxes today, asserting that the country's first multiparty elections in 22 years were rigged in favor of President Omar Bongo.

title: Ms. Sorokin Wed To Michael James
description: Sharon Linda Sorokin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton S. Sorokin of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Theodore James, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton R. James of Lincoln, Mass. Rabbi Charles Davidson and the Rev. Dwight Juliani, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at St. Clement's Estate in Portland, Conn.

title: Text of Bush's Television Message to Iraqi People
description: Following is the text of President Bush's address to the people of Iraq, as issued by the White House. The address, videotaped in Washington and broadcast on Iraqi television, was accompanied by Arabic subtitles and by a voice-over translation into Arabic, both provided by Voice of America.

title: Andrea J. Davidson, a Store Buyer, Marries Jay Evan Scharf, a Lawyer
description: Andrea Jane Davidson, the daughter of Sara G. Stone of New York and Louis A. Davidson of Tulsa, Okla., was married yesterday to Jay Evan Scharf, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel R. Scharf of Old Westbury, L.I. Rabbi David Lincoln officiated at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Spaniards Are Divided On Why Boom Is Over
description: Spain has chosen the Persian Gulf crisis as the occasion to acknowledge the end of a four-year economic boom, but many business executives and labor leaders say recent Government policy is more to blame than the sudden jump in oil prices.

title: 'Fresh Prince of Bel Air' Puts Rap in Mainstream
description: It took less than a decade for rap music to push its way off the streets of the South Bronx and become a dominant force in the Top 40. Now, in a programming gamble being watched in network and advertising offices, NBC is about to find out whether the rap, or hip-hop, style can dent the Nielsen ratings.

title: American Jesuit in Sri Lanka Is Missing and Feared Dead
description: An American Jesuit missionary who spent 41 years in Sri Lanka building up a well-known vocational school for boys has been missing since Aug. 15, and may have been killed in fighting between rival ethnic factions in a renewed civil war.

title: 6 Florida Winners to Split $105 Million Prize
description: Owners of six winning tickets will split a record Florida Lotto jackpot of about $105 million, lottery officials said today.

title: Postal Bus System Has Worked in West
description: To the Editor:

title: Ghana Is Said to Strike Liberian Rebels
description: In a move that could signal a new offensive role for the West African peacekeeing force in Liberia, Ghanaian planes reportedly attacked rebel positions in Monrovia.

title: Miss Domershick Wed to K. G. Golub
description: Alyssa Fern Domershick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Domershick of Malverne, L.I., was married yesterday to Kenneth Gray Golub, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Golub of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Chaim Stern officiated at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

title: New York's Water Rules Worry Catskills
description: Little by little, from Woodstock to Delhi, the reality is sinking in: If New York City is to avoid spending $4 billion to filter the drinking water it draws from these parts, life in the Catskills will never be the same again.

title: Hungary Privatizations
description: Hungary said Friday that it would sell 20 state-owned companies with total assets worth $1.1 billion and 1989 profits of $92 million. The Government expects $385 million to $614 million from the sale. The biggest of the companies to be sold will be Centrum Stores, which had sales of $300 million and pretax profits of $6.5 million last year. Richter Gideon Chemicals, with pretax profits of $15 million, will also be offered.

title: Tokyo Stocks Down by 2.14%
description: Stock prices fell in very thin trading today, with the 225-share Nikkei index closing off 2.14 percent.

title: Fishing Off Queens as Tide Rises, 6 Get Fished to Safety by a Copter
description: Six weekend fishermen were plucked from a breaker-swamped jetty in the Atlantic Ocean off Queens Saturday night in an unusual helicopter rescue by the New York City police.

title: Glaser-Engelberg Ceremony Is Held
description: An interfaith wedding ceremony was held yesterday for Gabrielle Christina Glaser, a freelance journalist in Warsaw, and Stephen Paul Engelberg, the Warsaw bureau chief of The New York Times. Rabbi Harold White and the Rev. Joseph Russell, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Athenaeum Art Gallery in Alexandria, Va. The couple were married in a civil ceremony in March at the municipal courthouse in St. Thomas, V.I.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Centel Corp., Chicago, a provider of telephone service and electric power, named Patricia E. Simmons vice president of Federal legislative affairs.

title: People
description: * Keith Evans has been named vice president and art director at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, New York. Ron Henderson has joined the agency as vice president and copywriter.

title: Deficit Threat and Tax Ire Greet Trenton's Fall Session
description: State legislators returned to the capital this week facing the sobering possibility that the slowing economy would create yet another budget deficit, despite their approval of the biggest tax increase in state history in June.

title: Karen Legon Is Married
description: Karen Elisabeth Legon, a daughter of Ruth O. Legon of New York and Allan R. Legon of Tiburon, Calif., was married yesterday to Adam Carl Berkowitz, a son of Lenore Berkowitz of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Norman Berkowitz. Rabbi Jerome Davidson officiated at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club. Mrs. Berkowitz, 27 years old, a Tulane University graduate, is a development executive at Savoy Pictures Entertainment in New York. Her husband, 29, is a television agent at the William Morris Agency in New York. He is a graduate of the State University of New Yorkat Albany and the Fordham University School of Law.

title: Julie R. Goldblatt Weds F. R. Kern
description: Julie Ruth Goldblatt, a daughter of David Goldblatt of New York and Mary S. Goldblatt of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Franklin Reid Kern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Kern of Scarsdale. Rabbi Jack Stern officiated at the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale. He was assisted by Cantor Peter Merkel.

title: First Signs of Fall: Pig Races, Festivals and Literature
description: Contrary to popular belief and scientific evidence, fall does not always begin with the annual autumnal equinox, that precise moment in mid-to-late September when the sun slides across the equator and delivers a day of equal parts.

title: Chronicle
description: GEORGE SELDES celebrated his 100th birthday yesterday, with about 10 relatives who traveled to his home in Hartland Four Corners, Vt. His last book, ''Witness to a Century,'' was a best seller and was written when he was 97.

title: For William Hurt, the Art of the Role, Chekhov and Fortune Cookies
description: William Hurt, currently playing a drama student better than a drama student could, says he ''jumped at the chance'' to act the title role in Chekhov's ''Ivanov'' at the Yale Repertory Theater. The bait was Oleg Yefremov, the director of the Moscow Art Theater, who in Mr. Hurt's eyes may be just a step below Stanislavsky - or God.

title: Souter Gives Little Comfort to Wary Conservatives
description: In his testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee last week, Judge David H. Souter said he had an open mind on abortion, spoke admiringly of Justice William J. Brennan Jr. and emphasized the need for some affirmative action to redress racial discrimination. He even resisted an obvious invitation by a conservative member of the committee to inveigh against judicial activism.

title: Poland's Jewish Uproar, And With So Few Jews
description: As Poland nears its first fully free election in a generation, this country virtually without Jews finds itself once again grappling with issues about Jews and anti-Semitism.

title: U.S. LAGS ON RULES MANDATED IN 1987 FOR NURSING CARE
description: Three years after Congress passed a landmark law to protect patients' rights and improve the quality of care in nursing homes, the Federal Government has not issued regulations needed to carry out the law.

title: Bank Insurance: Proceed With Care
description: Yes, the Federal insurance fund for bank deposits needs fixing. No, despite some dire talk in Washington, it is not on the verge of collapse. Members of Congress, badly burned by the savings and loan crisis, now itch to ''do something'' before the banks' problems become even more costly. Haste could do more harm than good.

title: Sports of The Times;   For the Jets, Proof of Progress
description: DURING last Thursday's practice, Bruce Coslet blew his whistle. ''That's not how we run that play,'' he said. Quickly but firmly, the Jets' new head coach reminded his players of the blocking assignments on that particular play. Moments later, the Jets ran it the way it's supposed to be run. The way Bruce Coslet demands it be run. The way every play should be run if the Jets are again to be a winning team, as they were yesterday in holding on for a 24-21 victory over the Cleveland Browns.

title: No Double Standard on Primary School Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Text of the Resolution Condemning Action by Iraq
description: Following is the text of a resolution adopted unanimously by the Security Council early today to condemn Iraq's violation of diplomatic premises in Kuwait:

title: Books of The Times;   Playing Games and Naming Names
description: What Happened Was This

title: Marta Osnos, 83, Dies; Researcher on Cancer
description: Marta Osnos, a retired research associate at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died on Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Use Oil Reserves? When, if Not Now?
description: The U.S. has spent billions of dollars creating the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, 600 million barrels of oil stored in salt domes along the U.S. Gulf Coast, to protect the economy during emergencies. Yet the Bush Administration has refused to tap the reserve in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the immediate loss of four million barrels of oil exports each day from the region.

title: After a Dry Spell of Six Years, It's Raining Encyclopedias
description: No new comprehensive, one-volume encyclopedia has been published for about six years, but editions of two such books are now on their way to the nation's bookstores and at least two others are waiting in the wings.

title: Ms. Bernhardt Weds Tony Giovannetti
description: Elise Bernhardt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Bernhardt of Freeport, L.I., was married yesterday to Tony J. Giovannetti, the son of Eleanor R. Giovannetti of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Anthony J. Giovannetti. Justice Aaron D. Bernstein of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn officiated aboard the yacht Amberjack V in New York Harbor.

title: Review/Theater;   'Falsettoland,' a William Finn Sequel, Reopens
description: ''Falsettoland,'' initially produced by Playwrights Horizons, has reopened at the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street. Following are excerpts from Frank Rich's review, which appeared in The New York Times on June 29. Lonny Price has succeeded Chip Zien in the role of Mendel.

title: In Moscow, a City of Bare Shelves, Consumer Rage Turns on Cabinet
description: Dispirited Muscovites took time out today from their latest consumer trial, a citywide shortage of meat, and rallied by the tens of thousands outside the Kremlin demanding the resignation of the Soviet Cabinet.

title: Washington Talk;   Shuffling Of Cabinet May Be At Hand
description: As off-year elections approach, so, usually, do rumors of musical chairs in the Cabinet. This week's entries for this year's shuffles involve the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, the Attorney General and the United States trade representative.

title: Israeli Exchange Closed
description: The Tel Aviv stock exchange stayed shut today while nervous investors deciphered a Government plan imposing new taxes on corporate profits from trading stocks. The exchange was scheduled to reopen Monday. The plan, approved by the Government on Thursday, is intended to help pay for settling the one million Soviet Jews expected to move to Israel during the next five years. After the stock market closed for the weekend on Thursday, the Government said it would impose a 20 percent tax on corporation profits from share dealings. A similar tax would be imposed on interest earned in personal savings plans that include stock and bond investments.

title: Review/Television; John Cage On His Way With Sound
description: Perhaps the most striking thing about John Cage is his ability to reduce just about anyone in his vicinity to a gentle smile. For more than 50 years, the distinguished, influential and often provocative composer has been challenging audiences with his work and his ideas. All the while, his primary goal has been disarmingly simple. Mr. Cage is interested, as he puts it, in ''increasing one's enjoyment of life, to become more open.''

title: Border Opened, Kuwaitis Flee Their Country
description: Several thousand Kuwaitis streamed into Saudi Arabia today after Iraqi troops opened a border crossing that had been closed since shortly after the Iraqi invasion last month.

title: Kelly Heller Is Married
description: Kelly Ann Heller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin G. Heller of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to David Michael Shelsky, a son of Edith Joseph of Bayside, Queens, and Seymour Shelsky of New York. Cantor Ted Aronson officiated at the Grand Summit in Summit, N.J. Mrs. Shelsky, 24 years old and a University of Michigan graduate, is an account executive at 525 Made in America, a sweater manufacturer in New York. The bridegroom, 28, graduated from the State University of New York at Oneonta and is the national sales manager of Kikit, a New York sportswear company.

title: Benefits Expected for Japan As the Yen Bounces Back
description: After weakening most of this year while the German mark and the Swiss franc reached record highs against the dollar, the yen is bounciing back.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-14

title: Jane Seaberry Wed to C. F. Foote Jr.
description: Jane Anita Seaberry, a reporter for The Washington Post, and Cornelius Francis Foote Jr., the minority-affairs director for the American Society of Newspaper Editors in Reston, Va., were married yesterday at the South Shore Cultural Center in Chicago. The Rev. Kenneth B. Smith, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Injured Gwynn Back in San Diego
description: Tony Gwynn, the San Diego Padres' right fielder, returned to San Diego today after suffering a fracture in the tip of his right index finger.

title: Paine Webber Lays Off 34 Employees
description: Responding to the downturn on Wall Street, Paine Webber Inc. dismissed about 9 percent of its investment banking staff last week.

title: Bremen Journal;   Why the Kaisers' Heir Is a Very Happy Prussian
description: When he recalls the day the Berlin wall broke open, Prince Louis Ferdinand of Prussia, the man who would be Kaiser if Germany still had a throne, assumes an almost reverential tone.

title: On General Mills Agenda, Stock Options as Merit Pay
description: Stockholders of General Mills Inc. will be asked at their annual meeting today to approve a plan that gives top managers the choice of taking merit raises and other pay increases in the form of stock options.

title: Irene Daria Wed To Cary Wiener
description: Irene Daria, a writer, and Cary Robert Wiener, a lawyer, were married yesterday at their home in Amagansett, L.I. The Rev. Gaylord Shimnoski, a Roman Catholic priest, and Cantor David Benedict officiated.

title: Question Box
description: Pitchers Left Out

title: Nonresidents' Rights Backed in Plebiscite
description: The Governor of Puerto Rico joined Puerto Rican politicians from New York and Philadelphia yesterday in urging Congress to guarantee Puerto Ricans who live in the United States a right to vote in the island's upcoming plebiscite on its sovereignty.

title: Miscellany
description: * Grey Advertising's British agency, Grey Communications Group, London, is acquiring a minority stake in Davies Ireland-Smith, a London-based medical and health-care agency. The new company, which will be called Davies Ireland-Smith Grey, is the seventh health-care agency in the Grey network.

title: Careful, but Undeterred, Visitors Take New York
description: Within hours of arriving in New York last week, Joe Lucia, a 25-year-old tourist from Sydney, Australia, had to wrest his luggage away from a man in the Port Authority Bus Terminal who had promised to hail a taxi for him, but instead headed down a dingy alley with it.

title: British Aid Figured in Roosevelt Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Emmys for Falk, Wettig And 'Murphy Brown'
description: Patricia Wettig, who plays the cancer-stricken young mother on ABC's ''Thirtysomething'' won the award for best actress in a drama series in the 42d Annual Emmy Awards tonight. Peter Falk won the Emmy for outstanding dramatic actor as ''Columbo.''

title: Union Announces Tentative Pact With G.M.
description: The United Auto Workers announced a tentative agreement early today with the General Motors Corporation on a new contract covering 300,000 American workers.

title: Bond Markets Worried by Fall of Dollar
description: The recent decline in the dollar, which has received at least tacit approval from the Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury Department, is a source of growing concern to credit market participants.

title: South African Rally For Township Amity Stirs Hard Feelings
description: A Zulu traditional leader, addressing migrant workers at rallies called to promote tribal peace in South Africa's black townships, said today that ''the killing talk'' must stop between his people and supporters of the African National Congress.

title: Carter Urges Arab Mediator
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that military action against Iraq by American forces may be inevitable, but should be undertaken only if no Arab mediator can be found. ''We need to let Saddam know, and let the Arab community know, that we are willing to have a respected mediator explore every possibility for a peaceful settlement,'' Mr. Carter said, referring to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. He said the superpowers or the United Nations should ask the Arab countries to designate a mediator to explore options for a solution with Iraq.

title: New Airline In Korea Irks Flag Carrier
description: A plan by a fledgling South Korean carrier, Asiana Airlines, to buy billions of dollars worth of Boeing jets to cash in on an expected Asian travel boom has irritated the long-established flag carrier, Korean Air Lines.

title: Kimberly Richey-Rankin Marries Matthew Rapf
description: Kimberly D. Richey-Rankin, the daughter of Vel Richey-Rankin of New York and Jack R. Rankin of Las Vegas, Nev., was married yesterday to Matthew William Rapf, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew W. Rapf of Malibu, Calif. Rabbi Benjamin performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Linda Novak Is Wed To Robert Greenberg
description: Linda Novak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Novak of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Michael Greenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Greenberg of Hillsdale, N.J. Rabbi Andre Ungar performed the ceremony at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: D'Amato Joins In Proposals To Add Police
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato joined the field of politicians offering plans for solving New York City's crime problems, announcing yesterday that he would introduce legislation that would allow the city to use Federal transit funds to hire 4,400 police officers.

title: Jury Selection in Murder Trial
description: Lawyers are expected to begin Monday questioning some of the more than 3,000 potential jurors called for the trial of a paroled killer accused in the serial slayings of 11 women over the last two years. Arthur J. Shawcross, 45 years old, has been jailed since his arrest in early January, at which time the police said he confessed to the 11 slayings. The victims, mostly prostitutes, were found dead between March 1988 and January 1990. Most had been strangled or suffocated.

title: Jets Hold Off Browns
description: With the Jets ahead by 10 points in the fourth quarter for the second straight week, their home opener against Cleveland at Giants Stadium today looked like something Yogi Berra might call ''deja vu all over again.'' But this time New York held on to give Bruce Coslet his first victory as a head coach.

title: Gulf Crisis Activates Loan Plans
description: The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund plan to make loans more quickly and provide other help to countries jolted by trade losses, higher oil prices, lower remittances from workers overseas and other consequences of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, officials of the lending agencies say.

title: Althea Simmons, 66, N.A.A.C.P. Lobbyist
description: Althea T. L. Simmons, head of the Washington branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People since 1979 and the organization's chief lobbyist in the capital, died Thursday at Howard University Hospital in Washington. She was 66 years old.

title: 10.6% Inflation In Britain
description: Britain said Friday that its annual inflation rate broke through the psychologically important 10 percent level in August for the first time in eight years.

title: Pirates Flee Canada
description: How do you say ''good riddance'' in French?

title: Tobacco Industry Sees Boon in Sales to Soviets
description: The recently announced sale of American cigarettes to the Soviet Union will fatten the already rich profits of the tobacco industry in the United States to a larger extent than the numbers involved suggest, Wall Street analysts say.

title: Taiwan to Open Investing
description: Taiwan will open its stock market to foreign institutional investors in a bid to curb speculation by local investors, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Friday.

title: Critic's Notebook;   The Iraq Conflict on American TV
description: For the television audience, the confrontation with Iraq has become a war of the innocents. The screen is dominated not by warriors but by wives, not men but boys, not armor but infants. Such images are hardly bugle calls to battle; they remind us night after night of the costs of conflict, as counted in the pains of ordinary people.

title: Amy M. Gelman,An Editor, Weds
description: Amy Miriam Gelman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Gelman of New York, was married yesterday to Eric Darth Haugesag, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dentley M. Haugesag of Minneapolis. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony at the Parker Meridien in New York.

title: Metro Matters;   Fight City Hall? Nope, Not Even Mother Teresa
description: Mother Teresa, the 80-year-old nun and Nobel Peace Prize winner whose name is synonymous with selflessness, has finally learned for herself what many New Yorkers consider axiomatic: You can't fight City Hall.

title: N.B.A.'s New Foul Plan
description: The National Basketball Association announced plans today to impose stronger penalties against players who commit overly aggressive fouls.

title: Methodical Bears Roll, 31-13
description: There were few gadget plays and little gimmickry in the Chicago Bears' 31-13 victory over the Green Bay Packers here today before a Lambeau Field record crowd of 58,938 fans. The Bears scored three touchdowns directly following Packer turnovers. Their defense, primarily riding a rejuvenated pass rush, pinned the Packers back all afternoon, forcing three fumbles and intercepting Anthony Dilweg and Dan Majkowski once each.

title: Market Place;   Finding a Buyer For Dole Food
description: SINCE July, when Castle & Cooke Inc. announced that several companies were interested in acquiring its Dole Food Company, the prospect of a high-stakes auction for Dole has generated growing interest on Wall Street.

title: I.B.M. Reported in Dispute With Microsoft on Software
description: Executives of the International Business Machines Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation met this weekend to try to clarify the relationship of the companies in developing basic software for personal computers, according to industry officials and a trade publication.

title: By the Books
description: WITH the end of the baseball season just around the corner, fans may be wondering what they can do to satisfy their baseball appetite. How about going to school? The New School for Social Research in Manhattan is offering two baseball-related courses this fall. The History of Baseball in America, which begins Sept. 25 and the Mystique of Baseball, which starts Nov. 6, will be offered for six Tuesday sessions from 7:45 to 9:30 P.M. for $130 per course.

title: Immigration Bill Invests in America's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Talks of Reducing Troops in Philippines
description: United States and Philippine officials opened talks today on the future of American military bases, and the chief negotiator for the United States said the days of its large military presence here ''are coming to an end.''

title: Review/Television;   Man vs. Man vs. Nature in the Amazon Rain Forest
description: Adrian Cowell must have had a premonition. Two years ago, Mr. Cowell, a British movie maker who had done BBC documentaries on the Amazon, traveled the new highway into the Brazilian rain forest to begin chronicling the effects of the invasion of homesteaders and others. By now, the damage has been extensively reported and deplored, yet Mr. Cowell's dramatic five-hour documentary, ''The Decade of Destruction,'' brings home the reality with fresh force and compassion. Channels 13 and 49 are carrying the work in four parts, beginning with a two-hour episode at 9 tonight.

title: Jets Back on the Track With Same Old O'Neil
description: Although he is seventh in career receptions and is in the top 10 in yards gained receiving for the Jets, Freeman McNeil is usually thought of as a runner. He is the team career leader in that category and the only man in club history to rush for more than 1,000 yards twice in a season.

title: Review/Theater;   Linda Lavin Takes Her Turn as Mama Rose
description: Tyne Daly, a television cop with scant musical-theater experience, sounded like a terrible idea for the role of Rose in ''Gypsy.'' Linda Lavin, who has succeeded Ms. Daly in the revival of the landmark 1959 musical at the St. James, sounds like a natural. Early in her career, Ms. Lavin belted out sprightly numbers in brash New York musicals - ''The Mad Show,'' the Harold Prince ''Superman'' - and only a few seasons ago she gave a memorable serious performance as another resolute, Depression-forged mama of starry-eyed children in Neil Simon's ''Broadway Bound.''

title: Osprey Raise Fledglings in New York Refuge
description: FOR the first time in more than 30 years, nesting osprey have produced fledglings in New York City.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Contel Cellular Inc., a partly owned subsidiary of the Contel Corp., Atlanta, appointed Charles M. Parrish senior vice president of operations.

title: New Kodak System for Showing Photos on TV
description: In a bid to combine traditional picture-taking with electronics, the Eastman Kodak Company plans to sell a system for storing photographs on compact disks and displaying them on television sets and computer screens.

title: Craft Sends Views of Venus
description: WITH communications fully restored after two mysterious silences, the Magellan spacecraft has begun mapping the surface of Venus with radar - a month late, but flawlessly. Researchers hope it will provide the most complete and detailed imaging ever of the cloud-enveloped planet.

title: China's Use of Forced Labor Questioned by Import Study
description: There is ''circumstantial evidence'' that products made under forced-labor conditions in China have been exported to the United States in violation of American trade law, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Head of Equity Department Resigns From First Boston
description: In the First Boston Corporation's first management change since it hired a new chief executive, the New York investment firm announced yesterday that Curtis R. Welling, the head of its equity department, was resigning.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Here in New York, if you defend yourself you're in trouble.

title: Gorbachev Proposes Referendum On Legalizing Land Ownership
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev compounded the confusion over economic changes today by unexpectedly proposing a national referendum on the question of whether the private ownership of land should be legalized.

title: A Mother's Plea to Hussein Frees Her Son
description: Never underestimate a mother's influence.

title: New Choctaw Bid To Acquire Justin
description: Choctaw Securities L.P., an investment group led by the Kansas City executive Perry H. Sutherland and the New York investor Barry S. Rosenstein, has offered to acquire Justin Industries for $18 a share, or $153 million. An earlier bid by Choctaw of $18.50 a share was rejected by the Fort Worth-based company in March.

title: Technical Failures Bedevil Star Wars
