description: In ''Interrogation,'' a wildly extroverted blond nightclub singer named Tonia (Krystyna Janda) is imprisoned by the Polish security police and grilled relentlessly about the kinds of crimes that under less charged circumstances might have landed her on a talk show. In the Stalinist climate of the early 1950's, Tonia is accused of having slept with highly placed, politically dangerous men.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: CORNISH hens are ideal for quick dinners, as they roast in 45 minutes or less. They are also convenient for families whose members come home at different times. The hens, each a single serving, can easily be kept warm and served later. Most commercially raised Cornish hens weigh about a pound. They have firmer, slightly moister flesh than chickens, so they don't dry out as quickly.

title: Hawks Sign Top Choice
description: Rumeal Robinson, the Atlanta Hawks' No. 1 draft choice from the University of Michigan, yesterday signed a four-year contract. Terms of the agreement were not announced.

title: Morris Gets a Chance
description: Joe Morris, the former Giants running back, worked out for the Washington Redskins yesterday, but the team said there were no plans to sign the veteran free agent. A team spokesman said Morris was among several players who are brought in each Tuesday to be evaluated in case active players are injured later in the season.(AP)

title: Francis Hogan Jr., 77, A Former Underwriter
description: Francis Leo Hogan Jr., a retired underwriter with the John Hancock Insurance Company, died on Sunday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 77 years old and lived in the Riverdale section.

title: Reviews/Music;   Trying To Reflect The World
description: Was it optimism or simply arrogance that separates the music of our great-grandfathers from ours today? Recent composers indulge in helpless mourning, practice self-hypnotism, float back and forth on the tides of chance or else invent computers that write music of their own.

title: Ralston to Close Pennsylvania Plant
description: The Ralston Purina Company said it will close its pet-food plant in Mechanicsburg, Pa., in late November or early December The plant, which was built in 1970, employs about 160 people.

title: U.S. Becomes TV Studio For World
description: People keep saying the United States is into a recession, and the dollar is down, and we can't manufacture automobiles anymore.

title: Martin Driver Guilty
description: A Town of Fenton Court jury in Port Crane, N.Y., yesterday found a Detroit bar owner guilty of driving with a blood-alcohol content above the legal limit for intoxication in the Christmas Day crash that killed the former Yankee manager Billy Martin.

title: Chronicle
description: Angered by the failure of his publisher to advertise ''A Native's Return,'' the third and final volume of his memoirs, WILLIAM L. SHIRER has taken out advertisements himself in book reviews. His book, published last January by Little, Brown, was well-received by critics.

title: Carlyle Getting Part Of Ford Aerospace
description: A disgruntled suitor in the recent auction for the Ford Aerospace Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy BDM International Inc., one of Ford Aerospace's biggest money makers.

title: Between-Lines Disaster
description: The Persian Gulf crisis has already directly affected the lives of well over a million people -refugees, hostages, military personnel, residents of occupied Kuwait. Many hundreds of millions more are or will be indirectly affected even if it doesn't come to open war.

title: Baghdad Fails to Allow Visit of U.N. Relief Chief
description: With shortages of food and medicine beginning to pose a serious problem for tens of thousands of people trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, Iraq has stalled on a request that it allow a visit to Baghdad by the United Nations representative named to lead the relief effort.

title: John W. DeWire, 74, A Nuclear Physicist And Professor, Dies
description: Dr. John W. DeWire, a high-energy physicist who was a longtime member of the Cornell University faculty, died on Monday at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Ithaca. His family said he died of leukemia.

title: Saudi, in Moscow, Says Soviet Troops Would Be Welcome
description: Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister ended a three-day visit here today with diplomatic relations restored between his country and the Soviet Union after a half-century breach.

title: Medicine and Soothing Talk In the Houses of the Dying
description: On a recent day Maureen Nakimera, a social worker from an AIDS support group, visited several clients in their homes in the countryside. Her aims, she said, were ''to see how things are going, what their needs are, and if the family is O.K.''

title: Russia Gets Call By Solzhenitsyn For Slavic State
description: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the exiled master of Russian literature, broke his silence in his homeland today with a call for a separate Slavic state and a scathing indictment of Soviet history, including the ''noisy'' reforms of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: U.S. Action On Airbus Aid
description: The United States today set a deadline of Sept. 30 for the European Community to work out reductions in subsidies to the Airbus Industrie aerospace consortium or face a complaint filed with a world trade body.

title: Top State Department Aide Is in Liberia to Meet Rebels
description: A ranking State Department official flew today to the battle-torn capital of Liberia, where he met one of the two feuding rebel leaders.

title: Confronting the Cruel Reality Of Africa's AIDS Epidemic
description: ''It all started as a rumor,'' Dr. Sam I. Okware, a senior health official, said of hazy reports in 1982 that a new affliction was causing Ugandans to waste away. ''Then we found we were dealing with a disease.''

title: Curb on Textile Imports Is Passed by the House
description: The House of Representatives today passed by 271 to 149 a bill already approved in the Senate to restrict imports of apparel and shoes. But the vote was short of the two-thirds majority needed to override a promised Presidential veto.

title: Eastern Pact With Agency Assures Pension Payments
description: Eastern Airlines cleared a critical hurdle yesterday in its attempt to reorganize under bankruptcy laws by reaching an agreement to have the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, a Federal agency that oversees pension plans, take over the payment of the retirement benefits of Eastern employees.

title: Massachusetts to Lay Off Mental Health Workers
description: Because of Massachusetts' deepening fiscal crisis, 517 workers at schools for the mentally retarded are being laid off in an effort to cut $24 million from the state budget.

title: Grandmother, Still Silent, Is Freed After Week in Jail
description: A Superior Court judge reversed himself today and released a 77-year-old woman from prison, conceding that her eight days behind bars failed to force her to disclose the whereabouts of her daughter and granddaughters.

title: Fund for New Plays Announces Grants
description: The Fund for New American Plays announced $492,550 in grants yesterday for nine plays that will have their premieres in eight theaters this season. The fund, a joint project of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and the American Express Company, in cooperation with the President's Committee on the Arts and the Humanities, has awarded $1,213,050 in the last 4 years to 26 regional theaters for 29 plays. These are the recipients of this year's awards: Circle Repertory Theater, New York, for ''Babylon Gardens'' by Timothy Mason: $32,000 for the theater, $10,000 for the playwright.

title: Try Pork Chops as End-of-Summer Fare
description: SEPTEMBER marks the end of summer; school has resumed and the days are getting shorter. Yet this is the ideal time, especially in the Northeast, to enjoy the plenty of the garden. Corn, tomatoes and zucchini are at their best, and these vegetables are less expensive now than at any other time of year.

title: Panel, Ending Long Inquiry, Urges Legislation on Ethics
description: Winding up one of the most far-ranging inquiries into governmental ethics in New York's history, a state commission called on the Governor and legislative leaders yesterday ''to put government ethics at the top of the legislative agenda.''

title: Defining Souter, Some;   Undogmatic Middle-of-the-Road Nominee Is Surprise for Liberals and Conservatives
description: In his three days before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Judge David H. Souter defined himself as an undogmatic, middle-of-the-road Supreme Court nominee by what he said and what he chose not to say.

title: Successor to Chief Picked at Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, David O. Maxwell, will retire Jan. 31 and that James A. Johnson, currently vice chairman, will take his place.

title: 10 Computers Introduced By Amdahl
description: The Amdahl Corporation today introduced 10 new mainframe computers, even though the machines will not be ready to ship for more than a year. The announcement follows similar ones made by several competitors in recent weeks.

title: Measure Urges Newspapers To Rely More on Recycling
description: Calling used newspapers the nation's ''No. 1 solid waste problem,'' a Pennsylvania Congressman introduced legislation today to provide economic incentives for recycling newsprint.

title: People
description: * Fern Hope Cohen has joined D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, as a senior vice president and associate creative director. Mary Ellen Pirozzoli has joined as vice president and executive producer.

title: Animals and Human Rights
description: To The Living Section:

title: Review/Television;   To Praise or Challenge Castro's Cuba
description: How, you may wonder, did the coupling of documentaries at 8 tonight on Channel 13, under the title, ''Castro's Cuba: Two Views,'' come about? There is some argument as to the details, but it appears to have happened more or less as follows.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 11 about Chiquita Brands International misstated the percentage of Chiquita stock controlled by Carl H. Lindner's American Financial Corporation. It is about 61 percent, not 63 percent.

title: The Illogic of Saudi Arms Sales
description: LEAD: In response to the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, the Bush Administration announced two huge arms deals with Saudi Arabia. Clearly, however, these sales were not part of a comprehensive and balanced reappraisal of U.S. policy but an attempt to seize the circumstances to expedite controversial arms sales.

title: Alienation From Government Grows, Poll Finds
description: Americans express even greater alienation toward their government and politics today than they did three years ago, and virtually all of the increase has been among people from families earning less than $50,000 a year, a new study of public opinion shows.

title: New Public Service Ads From Backer Spielvogel
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates, New York has created two public service announcements to encourage people to vote, just in time for November elections. The ads, which will be released on network television next week, use news footage from around the world. One depicts a rapid-fire series of missiles, fighter planes and guns, and uses the tagline ''Of all the weapons in the world, in the last 40 years, none has more power than this one.'' The final frame shows a woman in a babushka placing a ballot in a box.

title: Police Chief Wants to Add More Civilians
description: In his effort to remold the New York City Police Department, Commissioner Lee P. Brown hopes to hire hundreds of civilian workers, not only to free uniformed officers from desk jobs and to save money, but also to bring the department's technical abilities up to date, senior city officials say.

title: Jays Move Into Tie for First With Red Sox
description: Even by their own admission, the Toronto Blue Jays did not seem to believe their long summer would bring them here. But now, with just 13 games to play, they have been thrust back into first place.''

title: Western Europe Urges Air Embargo Against Iraq
description: Moving toward closer coordination of their military policies, nine Western European nations urged the United Nations Security Council today to extend the trade embargo against Baghdad to include aircraft entering and leaving Iraq and Kuwait.

title: KEY RATES
Books of The Times;   On the Survival of the Not-So-Fit Risk Takers
description: Why the Reckless Survive

title: Alfred Kouzel Dies; Film Cartoonist, 67
description: Alfred Kouzel, a film cartoonist who won a 1961 Academy Award for adapting, illustrating and producing ''Munro,'' based on a Jules Feiffer story about a youngster mistakenly drafted into the Army, died on Sept. 6 at a hospital in Trostberg, West Germany, where he was undergoing treatment for cancer. He was 67 years old and lived in Atlantic Beach, L.I. He died of chest cancer and heart disease, a family spokesman said. Mr. Kouzel earned honors at many film festivals for various aspects of animated cartoon making. He worked for most leading studios and his own company, Ariel Productions, with Eli Bauer, and on television specials, including ''The Muppet Babies'' with Jim Henson.

title:
Real Estate;

New Towers Push Toward Ohio River
description: LEAD: A $150 MILLION twin-tower office complex to be built over the next five years along Third Street here is the latest in a wave of development that is pushing the commercial district south toward the Ohio River.

title: KEATING INDICTED IN SAVINGS FRAUD AND GOES TO JAIL
description: Charles H. Keating Jr., who has been widely portrayed as a symbol of the misconduct and reckless investment style that devastated the savings and loan industry, was indicted on criminal fraud charges today and led to jail after he was unable to post the $5 million bail.

title: Rostislav Nebolsine, 90, A Civil Engineer, Dies
description: Rostislav Nebolsine, a civil engineer and a leader in the White Russian community on the East Coast, died on Sunday at his home in Bridgehampton, L.I. He was 90 years old. He died of a heart attack, a grandson, Paul Klebnikov, said.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;

Los Angeles
description: LEAD: EL PARIAN is a home away from home for natives of Jalisco, the west central Mexican state, who are drawn in droves by the restaurant's keynote dish, birria, a spicy broth flavored with savory chunks of goat meat.

title: New York Developers Feel a Chill
description: There is little doubt that the deep slump in demand for offices and high-priced apartments has caught New York City real estate developers off guard, but different developers have been stung in different ways. While many are struggling with too much space and too few tenants, not all face the gargantuan financial pressures looming over Donald J. Trump.

title: Moody's Reviews Ford Motor Debt
description: The ratings on about $40 billion in debt issued by the Ford Motor Company, Ford Motor Credit Company and their guaranteed subsidiaries arebeing reviewed with negative implications, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Home Products Corp. and Microgenesys Inc. have agreed to develop jointly Microgenesys's anti-AIDS product Vaxsyn HIV-1. The product is currently being tested.

title: Blackstone Widens Link With Europe
description: Reflecting Europe's increased importance in the mergers business, the Blackstone Group is forming an alliance with the investment banking unit of Banque Indosuez, a leading financial institution in France, the groups said yesterday.

title: Clerk at Broker Pleads Guilty
description: A senior billing clerk for L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court in Newark to charges of conspiracy and income tax evasion charges.

title: Porsche Alters Course
description: As had long been rumored, Porsche yesterday announced that it would end its Indy-car racing program at the end of this season. The West German automaker has built engines to compete in the Championship Auto Racing Teams Indy-car circuit and the Indianapolis 500 for three years and has one victory and 29 top-10 finishes in 44 races.

title: Stivender Memorial
description: There will be a free concert at the Metropolitan Opera in memory of the opera's chorus master, David Stivender, on Friday at 6 P.M. The Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and Chorus will perform, with the soprano Carol Vaness, the tenor Jerry Hadley and the baritone Thomas Hampson as soloists, under the direction of James Levine. Mr. Stivender died of congestive heart failure on Feb. 9 at the age of 56.

title: Trade Deficit Climbs to $9.33 Billion
description: The nation's trade deficit jumped in July to $9.33 billion, the second-highest monthly level this year, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. And the rising cost of imported oil suggests that for the rest of this year the deficit might remain stuck at $8 billion to $9 billion a month.

title: Cubs Rout Smiley; Pirates Stay in First
description: Depending on whether the glass is half full or half empty, Monday was either a day for the Pirates to rest or a time for them to think.

title: U.S. Cancels S.& L. Auction
description: Federal savings and loan bailout officials have canceled the much-promoted international satellite auction of million-dollar properties inherited from bankrupt savings and loan associations.

title: Hong Kong Journal;   And Speaking of the World's Wistful Causes . . .
description: Up five flights of chipped cement stairs, in a small living room with only one fan to stir the heavy afternoon heat, a group of old Chinese men and women sit around a table stacked with Japanese yen, each bundle of money carefully wrapped in string or cheap paper ribbon.

title: The Pop Life
description: Political Explicitness

title: LAYOFF PROVISIONS BUOY AUTO UNION
description: The subject was unemployment, but the mood of auto workers employed by the General Motors Corporation was anything but bleak.

title: Youth Charged in Suspect's Killing Is Released
description: Four days after he stabbed and killed a man who he apparently believed had mugged his mother, Victor Lopez returned to his South Bronx street yesterday as his neighbors expressed outrage that the young man, out on $2,500 bail, had been charged with manslaughter.

title: ACCUSATIONS BEGIN IN BUDGET TALKS
description: Democrats and Republicans spent the day today blaming each other for a budget deadlock that has come down to a fight over which party's policies are fairer and have a better chance of averting a serious decline in the economy.

title: Oliver Butterworth, Children's Writer, 75
description: Oliver Butterworth, an author of children's books and a professor of English at Hartford College for Women for 43 years, died on Monday at his home in West Hartford, Conn. He was 75 years old. He died of melanoma, a family spokesman said. His popular allegorical books include ''The Enormous Egg'' (1956), ''The Trouble With Jenny's Ear'' (1960) and ''The Narrow Passage'' (1973). He once wrote that his novels for children sprang from ''a deeply rooted American skepticism of social institutions and a corresponding tendency to believe in the independent untaught individual.''

title: Home Loan Bank Interest Rates Set
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board yesterday set the interest rate on $931 million in debentures consisting of one-year and three-year maturities through its regular dealer selling group.

title: PRETORIA PLANNING A KIDNAPPING TRIAL OF WINNIE MANDELA
description: Winnie Mandela, the wife of the African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, is to be charged with kidnapping and assault in connection with the abduction in late 1988 of four youths, a prosecutor announced today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: In Budget Move, Pentagon Plans Closings and Cuts for 150 Sites
description: In its latest effort to scale back the military, the Defense Department announced today that it was closing down or cutting back operations at 150 military bases and installations around the world.

title: Mission Resource In Talks on Sale
description: Mission Resource Partners said it was negotiating the possible sale of substantially all of its remaining assets to an independent oil and gas company, which it did not name. It said the deal could result in the dissolution of Mission.

title: Roland F. Simons, 85, Health-Care Executive
description: Roland F. Simons, a retired health-care industry executive, died on Saturday at the Naples Community Hospital in Florida. He was 85 years old and lived in Naples.

title: Long Takeover Battle for UAL Raises Doubts Over Sale
description: A growing number of people following the takeover battle at the UAL Corporation are concluding that the parent of United Airlines will not be sold.

title: John B. Creegan, Lawyer, 80
description: John B. Creegan, a retired New York lawyer, died on Sunday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Stocks Plunge in Manila
description: Share prices in Manila sank today to 40-month lows after a bomb exploded on the first day of talks on the future of United States military bases in the Philippines, brokers said. Manila's composite index slid 10.18 points to close at 615.39, its lowest since recording 610.59 on May 29, 1987. Depreciation of the Philippine peso to an all-time low of 26 to the dollar, from 15, and violent street protests on Monday by students opposed to the bases weighed down the market at the opening, analysts said.

title: Next Inc. Returns to Center Stage
description: Steven P. Jobs returned to the stage at this city's symphony hall today, hoping to rekindle the sense of anticipation his computer company, Next Inc., had when it introduced its first product in the same place two years ago.

title: Citicorp Rates Up at Auction
description: At Citicorp's final weekly commercial paper auction yesterday, interest rates were up slightly for the second consecutive week.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Agent Is Convicted in Iran-Contra Affair
description: Thomas G. Clines, a former intelligence official who became an international arms dealer, was convicted today of four income tax charges stemming from his role in shipping weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels in the Iran-contra affair.

title: U.S. Softening on Subsidies
description: Softening its position in global trade talks, the Bush Administration said today that it was prepared to allow some farm subsidies in a new accord to liberalize international trade.

title: Bernard Peter May; Christian Brother, 85
description: Brother Bernard Peter May, a member of the De La Salle Christian Brothers for almost 70 years, died on Monday at the Riverview Medical Center in Red Bank, N.J. He was 85 years old and had lived at De La Salle Hall in Lincroft, N.J., since he retired in 1981.

title: Some Things Never Change, And Honey Lovers Are Grateful
description: THIS evening many Jews will dip slices of apple or pieces of hallah into honey, symbolic of hopes for a sweet new year, as Rosh ha-Shanah begins at sundown.

title: Accounts
description: * Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester, to J. Walter Thompson, New York, for a worldwide introduction of its new Kodak Photo CD systems. Billings are reportedly between $20 million and $30 million. The agency handles other Kodak accounts.

title: About Couch Potatoes
description: To The Living Section:

title: 2 GROUPS OPPOSE SOUTER AT HEARING
description: The leaders of two major abortion rights groups urged the Senate Judiciary Committee today to reject the nomination of David H. Souter for the Supreme Court, but several Senators told them that Judge Souter was probably the least hostile nominee they could expect from the Bush Administration.

title: U.S. Says It Is Ready to Cut Philippine Force
description: The United States Government is prepared to reduce its military forces in the Philippines, an American official said today as talks on American bases opened.

title: Security Council's Military Panel Reviews Naval Efforts to Enforce Trade Embargo
description: The military arm of the United Nations Security Council met informally today to review naval efforts to enforce the Council's trade embargo against Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait.

title: Stocks Swing Widely; Dow Closes Up 3.96
description: Stock prices fluctuated wildly yesterday in slow volume as investors, traders and speculators watched for bargains but mostly watched the clock for the time to go home.

title: Pirelli Is Rejected
description: Continental A.G. of West Germany said its supervisory board voted to reject a proposal from Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy to merge the two companies' tire operations under Pirelli's control. Instead, Continental will draft its own proposal to present to Pirelli, a Continental spokesman, Dieter von Herz, said. A spokesman for Pirelli said the company had no immediate comment.

title: Others Have Said as Much as Dugan But 'on Background,' Not on Record
description: In the final analysis, the problem wasn't really what Gen. Michael J. Dugan said that hurt him so much.

title: Excerpts From Solzhenitsyn's Article on Soviets
description: Following are excerpts from an article, ''How to Revitalize Russia,'' by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, published today in Komsomolskaya Pravda, as translated by The New York Times:

title: We Need a Corps of Inner-City Youth Workers;   Baby Hit Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Put a Little Dragonfly in Your Life Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Racial Harmony a Key for Atlanta
description: Atlanta's successful bid to stage the 1996 Olympics represents a triumph of old-fashioned politics, modern technology and a desire to hold a hassle-free summer Games for the first time in 20 years. When they could have easily let sentiment or other factors influence their voting yesterday in Tokyo, members of the International Olympic Committee instead rewarded a city whose representatives went to great lengths to assure them comfort, safety and convenience.

title: Don't Get Robbed
description: What's almost - well, not really - as bad as having a teen-ager stick a knife to your wife's throat and scamper with her purse is working with friendly assistant bank managers to reconstruct your life and finances.

title: Limited U.S. Saving Seen in Altering 1988 Bailout Deals
description: A study released today by regulators supervising the bailout of the savings and loan industry shows that the Government would save only $2 billion to $3 billion if it tried to recoup some costs on the 96 expensive sales of failing institutions made at the end of 1988.

title: Brazil to Close Shaft Suited for Nuclear Test
description: President Fernando Collor de Mello flew to the Amazon jungle today to order the closing of a deep shaft that Government officials conceded this week could be used for nuclear tests.

title: Herbert Spiegelberg, Philosophy Teacher, 86
description: Herbert Spiegelberg, professor emeritus of philosophy at Washington University in St. Louis, died Sept. 6 at his home in St. Louis. He was 86 years old. A university spokesman said he died of leukemia.

title: Salvador Peace Talks End in Bitterness
description: Six days of talks between the Salvadoran Government and leftist rebels ended here today with both sides saying there was almost no chance of a cease-fire before elections next March.

title: Collusion Interest Charge May Add to Owner Costs
description: Arbitrators' awards of $113 million for lost players' salaries in baseball's ongoing collusion case could jump by nearly 40 percent, to the $156 million area, if the arbitrators grant the union's request for interest.

title: CBS Top Ratings On Opening Night
description: CBS, which has finished in last place in the A. C. Nielsen ratings for three straight years, scored a major surprise in the first night of the new television season. (The accompanying ratings chart reflects the final week of the summer season.) CBS dominated the Monday ratings and achieved a significant victory over NBC in a confrontation between two of the season's new programs. In the 8 P.M. time period, CBS's new comedy ''Uncle Buck'' easily defeated NBC's new comedy ''Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' the most eagerly anticipated new program of the season, with a 14.1 rating to a 12.7. (Each rating point represents 931,000 homes.) ''Uncle Buck'' may have been helped by CBS's new-season promotion with K Mart stores, but ''Fresh Prince'' was far below the rating NBC expected.

title: Indiana Housing Agency Prices $96 Million Offering
description: A $96 million tax-exempt bond issue of mortgage revenue bonds for single-family homes from the Indiana Housing Finance Authority was tentatively priced yesterday through a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Ysebaert's Top Priority Is to Impress Devils
description: A forward with the credentials of Paul Ysebaert will have no trouble making the roster of an average team in the National Hockey League, but the Devils may no longer be an average team.

title: Commerce Dept. Settlement Offers Census Relief for New York;   Ineffectual Counting
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: Filming began yesterday on ''The Dark Wind,'' based on a novel by TONY HILLERMAN, but ROBERT REDFORD's production team is still in the middle of a controversy between officials of the Hopi Tribe and religious tribal leaders of one village. The tribal government on Friday approved filming on the reservation near Phoenix.

title: Underground Ideas
description: A New Yorker who takes a trip on the London Underground or the Paris Metro comes away with the thought, ''Why can't we do this?''

title: A Bar to Women as Cantors Is Lifted
description: When Cantor Marla Rosenfeld Barugel approaches the pulpit of her congregation tonight in Rumson, N.J., to lead the Rosh ha-Shanah service, there will be an extra spring to her step and lilt to her voice.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: A FRIEND writes:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Campaign Helps Sleeper Become a Hit
description: PARAMOUNT'S ''Ghost,'' a sleeper released just before the rush of big-budget summer films, has proved to be the clear winner of the season's box office sweepstakes, suggesting how valuable a highly targeted advertising campaign can be in promoting a movie.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've never felt more elated in my entire life. I felt like an exclamation point has just been laid down in the life of our city.''

title: Review/Film;   A Cold-Eyed Look at the Mob's Inner Workings
description: Some guys grow up wanting to design computer games, fly space missions or play for the New York Knicks. Henry Hill always wanted to be a gangster. Like Martin Scorsese, who, from any early age, wanted to make movies, Henry Hill realized his grand ambition.

title: Iran, Holding Key, Hints at Hostage Release
description: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait may have indirectly improved the chances of freeing American hostages long held in Lebanon, Administration officials said today.

title: Giants Set Back Reds, 5-3
description: Will Clark hit two home runs and Kevin Mitchell hit another today as the San Francisco Giants beat Cincinnati, 5-3, to slow the Reds' playoff drive.

title: 'Double Bunking' in Prisons Will Go On Through January
description: A New York State panel voted today to let the prison system continue to put inmates in bunk beds until Jan. 31.

title: Lectures on Dance
description: Ushio Amagatsu, the director of the Butoh dance troupe Sankai Juku, will discuss his work at City Center, 131 West 55th Street, tomorrow at 5:30 P.M. in a lecture series presented by the theater. The season's other speaker will be Judith Jamison, the director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, on Nov. 28 at 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $10. Reservations: 581-7907.

title: The Case of the Central Park Jogger
description: April 19, 1989 - A woman jogging on the 102d Street Transverse in Central Park is attacked by a gang of youths at about 10 P.M. The 28-year-old victim is beaten and left in a coma and near death from brain damage and loss of blood.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 23 about appliance makers referred incorrectly to the stacked washer-dryer business of the White-Westinghouse group of White Consolidated Industries. Although the group has made stacked washers and dryers for many years, they have been small-load models; only this year did it introduce full-load models.

title: Consumer Prices Jump By 0.8%
description: Spurred by the disruption in Persian Gulf oil supplies, the Consumer Price Index jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent in August, the biggest rise since the exceptional cold of January, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Washington
description: WHEN Mark Furstenberg sent a questionnaire to a random sampling of 900 Washingtonians this year, 70 percent of them said they wanted good bread, 30 percent wanted better fruits and vegetables and 20 percent wanted simple take-out food.

title: In the Wilderness And Truly Paradise
description: PLUNK dab in the center of this once prosperous railroad town along a remote stretch of highway here in northwestern Minnesota is a cozy retreat (not much to look at from outside) where day in and day out the coffee is hot and the home-cooking honest.

title: Birthplace of Games Shocked and Angered
description: Greeks reacted with shock and anger today to the vote by the International Olympic Committee to award the 1996 Golden Olympics to Atlanta.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING

title: Class Action Is Requested By Manville
description: The trust fund set up two years ago by the Manville Corporation to compensate asbestos victims asked a Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday to treat all of the personal-injury lawsuits filed against it as a single class action.

title: Does 'Yogurt' On the Label Make It So?
description: YOGURT has been called everything from the fountain of youth to the world's first junk health food. There's a kernel of truth in both descriptions, their accuracy depending on how far a variety of yogurt has strayed from its origins.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;

Congress, Ariz.
description: LEAD: RATTLESNAKES, scorpions and cactus spines are just some of the occupational hazards at Cahill Desert Foods during its annual harvest of prickly pear cactus near this small town northwest of Phoenix.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: David Opont's Burn Injuries Are Permanent, Doctor Says
description: David Opont is healing well but has permanent and serious injuries from being critically burned on March 7, a doctor testified yesterday in Family Court in Brooklyn.

title: Now Atlanta Gets Down to Brass Tacks
description: With the designation of Atlanta as the site of the 1996 Summer Olympics, the boosterism and promotion of the Atlanta Organizing Committee, which led the effort to land the Games, will now give way to the quasipublic Metropolitan Atlanta Olympic Games Authority, which will be the operating authority to raise funds and oversee construction for the Games.

title: Racial Harm Is Found in School 'Tracking'
description: Black and Hispanic students are falling behind in math and science partly because they are more likely than other students to be put into classes for those with lower abilities, according to a Rand Corporation study released yesterday.

title: Teaching Doesn't Buy the Campus Computers
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Officials Satisfied With Soviets' Gulf Role
description: Ten days after the summit meeting in Helsinki, Bush Administration officials say they are satisfied with Soviet cooperation in isolating Iraq.

title: Books of The Times;   New Words and Views On Roots of the Bible
description: The Book of J

title: John C. Staton, Executive, 89
description: John C. Staton, a retired Coca-Cola executive who designed the company's first cooler and developed its first fountain dispenser, died Sunday at his home in Atlanta at the age of 89.

title: Pirates Walk Edge, but Survive Cubs' Rally
description: If there was ever a moment that could have symbolized the futility of what has become the Race Nobody Wants to Win, this was it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: KEY RATES
Canada Calls Off Plane Search
description: The search for a Peruvian airliner that disappeared off Newfoundland Sept. 11 has been called off, Canadian search and rescue officials said today. None of the 16 people aboard the Boeing 727 are believed to have survived what apparently was a crash into the Atlantic, said the rescue coordination center. The aircraft was 186 miles off Newfoundland when it vanished after the pilot reported a fuel emergency.

title: Bulgarians View Recent Past With Anger;   Socialist Support Wanes
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Floors in Garages

title: Canadian Developer To Cut Stake in U.S.
description: Olympia & York, one of North America's largest and also most secretive developers, is seeking to sell an interest in its American holdings. The move by the Toronto-based giant was seen on Wall Street as a way for the company to hedge its position in troubled American real estate markets and to raise cash for its huge but unfinished Canary Wharf development in London.

title: Parent & Child
description: THE Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has affected many families in ways other than having to pay more for gasoline. Psychologists and psychiatrists are beginning to see changes in children's play and artwork, which are usually good reflections of their unspoken hopes and fears. Most children first show their concerns through changes in their behavior. Their words come later.

title: 50 Runners to Compete In Long Island Biathlon
description: A field of 50 runners is expected for the Long Island event of the 1990 Kingsbury Summer Biathlon Series on Sept. 30.

title: Chase's Share Price Is Lowest in 12 Years
description: The share price of the Chase Manhattan Corportion closed at a 12-year low yesterday, and interest rates on its long-term debt rose - a result of the banking company's weak earnings and unconfirmed rumors of its difficulties in borrowing money, analysts said.

title: 400 Westerners Arrive In London on Iraqi Jet
description: An Iraqi airliner carrying more than 400 Western women and children, mainly Americans fleeing Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, arrived in London this evening.

title: David C. Anchin, Accountant, 86
description: David C. Anchin, a retired managing partner of Anchin, Block & Anchin, a New York accounting firm, died on Tuesday at the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio. He was 86 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.

title: Editorial Notebook;   Magic Numbers in Government
description: New York politicians are at war over a number - 5,000 new police officers for New York City. Each politician offers powerful arguments for or against the 5,000. But all are engaged in the venerable and honorable game of setting the ''magic number.''

title: Bills Are Bickering In Mid-Season Form
description: Until they were bodyslammed and pinned by the Miami Dolphins, 30-7, on Sunday, the Buffalo Bills had the distinction of holding on to at least a piece of first place in the American Conference East for 33 straight weeks.

title: Poland's President to Step Down, Clearing Way for Free Elections
description: President Wojciech Jaruzelski notified Parliament today that, as expected, he would step down shortly, paving the way for general elections to choose his successor.

title: Ed Sadowski, Basketball Star, 73
description: Ed Sadowski, who led Seton Hall to its only undefeated season, in 1940, then became a standout in the early years of the National Basketball Association, died of cancer on Tuesday at his home in Wall, N.J. He was 73 years old.

title: TV License In Rare Shift
description: The owners of WSNS-TV in Chicago lost a lengthy license renewal battle today when the Federal Communications Commission, in a rare move, said a competing applicant was more deserving to run the station.

title: An Uneasy Alliance Is Born For Mitsubishi and Daimler
description: Mitsubishi and Daimler-Benz said today that they were exploring several joint ventures, including making cars in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, producing computer chips, jet airplanes, high-speed trains and refrigerators.

title: IRT Station Repairs May Be Accelerated
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that structural engineers would inspect the crumbling ceiling of the Nevins Street IRT subway station in downtown Brooklyn today and recommend whether an 18-month repair program should begin sooner than planned.

title: Boyd Named to Post
description: Mike Boyd, an assistant coach at Michigan since 1979, yesterday was named as Cleveland State's new basketball coach, replacing Kevin Mackey, who was dismissed two months ago following his arrest on drunken driving and cocaine abuse charges.

title: BRIEFS
description: * ABB Asea Brown Boveri, the Swiss-Swedish engineering group, said it had given final approval to a $600 million employee share ownership plan.

title: Vietnamese Pay a High-Level Visit to China
description: A Vietnamese Deputy Prime Minister arrived today to attend the Asian Games beginning Saturday in the highest-level official visit here by a Vietnamese since Beijing and Hanoi fought a brief border war in 1979. Both sides said they hoped for a normalization of relations.

title: Pan Am to Eliminate 2,500 Jobs
description: Pan American World Airways Inc. said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,500 jobs, or 8.6 percent of its work force, by next month. The layoffs, which include managers and other employees, are the most visible sign yet of the weakening condition of the nation's airline industry.

title: John Miller Dickey, Architect, 79, Is Dead
description: John Miller Dickey, an architect who restored historic buildings in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, died yesterday at his home in Westtown, Pa. He was 79 years old. He died of liver cancer, his family said. Mr. Dickey began his restoration work in the late 1960's, after he and a partner, William Price Jr., based in Media, Pa., had designed many buildings for the Pennsylvania educational system.

title: Iraqi Tankers' Loading Oil in Gulf May Signal Iranian Help in Breaking Embargo
description: Three Iraqi tankers have recently docked and taken on oil at an Iraqi pipeline terminal in the Persian Gulf, American officials said today, a move that may signal new efforts by President Saddam Hussein to export oil and to enlist Iran into breaking the global trade embargo against his Government.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SHEILA RAUCH KENNEDY and JOSEPH P. KENNEDY 2D filed for divorce Tuesday, the same day he won a primary election in Massachusets. Mr. Kennedy, a Democrat, is seeking a third term representing the Eighth Congressional district, which includes parts of Boston and its surrounding suburbs.

title: In His Own Words: A Silber Sampler
description: ON IMMIGRANTS

title: Savings Bailout Chief Asks for $100 Billion
description: The head of the Federal bailout of the savings and loan industry asked Congress today for $100 billion to $110 billion for the new fiscal year, which begins next month, to continue the rescue program.

title: Dow Falls 13.86 in Another Lackluster Day
description: Wall Street suffered through another day of the blahs yesterday, with stocks down only slightly despite several fairly strong declines.

title: New York Defends Use Of Hotels for Homeless
description: New York City officials yesterday defended their decision to violate a court order prohibiting the use of welfare hotels for homeless families beyond July 31 and said they were not sure when they would be able to comply with the order.

title: Death and Democracy in Guatemala
description: Tens of thousands of Guatemalan civilians have died violently in recent decades, with few of their killers brought to account. Now the suspicious death of an American could spur overdue Government action. The Bush Administration deserves credit for pressing the case.

title: Red Sox Stumble Again And Fall a Game Behind
description: If Tony Pena was trying to motivate the Red Sox by calling them ''quitters'' after a loss Tuesday night, the immediate results were not promising.

title: Federal Computer Contract Ran Millions Over Estimate
description: A $7 million computer contract let by the Agriculture Department instead cost almost $62 million because its instructions to the system's designer were vague, according to testimony before Congress on Tuesday.

title: McKeon Role Unclear
description: The head of the San Diego Padres' new ownership group has scheduled a meeting tomorrow with General Manager Jack McKeon to discuss the club's future direction and McKeon's role in it.

title: Europe Subsidy Plan Fails
description: The European Community's strategy for world trade talks was thrown into disarray today when its commissioners refused to back a plan for cuts in farm support programs.

title: Bank Scandal In Mexico
description: Ten people, including three high-ranking bank officials, have been arrested in connection with a multimillion-dollar fraud at a Mexican bank, the Government newspaper, El Nacional, reported today.

title: Helen Finn Ruder, Psychotherapist, 64
description: Helen Finn Ruder, a specialist in child psychotherapy in Westchester County, died on Sunday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived in Larchmont.

title: Loss Reported by Circle K
description: The Circle K Corporation said today that it lost $10.8 million in the quarter ended July 31, compared with a profit of $7.6 million, or 13 cents a share, in the same quarter last year.

title: Optimism On Latin Debt
description: Traders in debt issued by third world countries expect the loans of Latin American nations to rise in value on the debt market next year, a magazine survey said.

title: Study Links Emotions to Second Heart Attacks
description: A new study of survivors of heart attacks suggests that emotions play an important role in predicting, and possibly even preventing, a second attack. But the researchers found that the emotions at play differ in men and women.

title: A Mistrial Is Declared As Sundown Nears
description: A Westchester County court judge declared a mistrial today after jurors told him in a note that they were hopelessly deadlocked and concerned that continuing deliberations would prevent some of them from observing the Jewish new year.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Gangs, Crime, Smut, Violence
description: ''Probably in no city in the civilized world is life so fearfully insecure,'' wrote Isabella Lucy Bird, an English visitor to New York in the early 1850's. ''The practice of carrying concealed arms, in the shape of stilettoes for attack, and swordsticks for defense, if illegal, is perfectly common . . . and terrible outrages and murderous assaults are matters of such nightly occurrence as to be thought hardly worthy of notice.''

title: Time Warner Combining Book and Magazine Groups
description: Time Warner Inc. yesterday announced the creation of Time Warner Publishing Inc. to oversee all of the company's book and magazine publishing activities.

title:
Currents;

Good Ideas Can Last For Years
description: LEAD: WHEN Chapman Market opened in in Los Angeles in 1929, the Spanish-Moorish complex designed by Stiles O. Clements was a novelty. The shopping plaza had parking space in its interior courtyard. It is now called the city's first mini-mall.

title:
Currents;

Designs That Could Be More
description: LEAD: FOR each chair, table and lamp produced every year, many more inventive designs never make it to the manufacturing process. The New York Design Center has mounted an exhibit of 50 designs it believes could be produced.

title: Chrysler Expects Market Share Gain
description: The head of the Chrysler Motors division, Ben Bidwell, said he expects the company's market share to rise to 10.5 percent in the fourth quarter from the 8.9 percent level so far this year. In displaying its lineup of new cars, Chrysler said its Shadow and Sundance America models would be the lowest priced air bag-equipped 1991 models in the United States. A two-door lift-back model is tentatively priced at $7,699. The prices are more than $1,000 less than Chrysler's lowest-priced 1990 Shadow and Sundance models.

title: Calendar: Fall Tours, Classes And Shows
description: Village Views, Urban Center Galleries of the Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street; (212) 935-3960.

title:
Currents;

From the Prairie To Urban Villa
description: LEAD: SOME architects look on designing houses as an opportunity to experiment. Others prefer to stay with familiar forms and time-tested solutions, like the group of Chicago architects whose work is on view there in ''Chicago Villa.''

title: Among Hummel Fans, Details Mean So Much
description: Jeanette Ferrante got her first one in 1975 as a 15th anniversary present from her mother. It was the ''For Father'' figurine, perhaps not the wisest possible choice, but who can understand why mothers do what they do?

title: Furniture as Sculpture
description: A chair that looks like a spinal column, a three-layered mirror and a sofa with an attached chaise are three of the 12 offbeat objects on view through Oct. 6 at Art et Industrie, the SoHo gallery at 106 Spring Street (Mercer Street).

title: Accounts
description: * ARTnews, New York, an art magazine, to Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, New York. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Talking Deals;   Delicate Balance In Eastern Pact
description: THE agreement expected to assure backing for Eastern Airlines' pension plan was put together in months of careful negotiations, with a Government agency putting great pressure on Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., while seeking to avoid pushing the carrier into bankruptcy.

title: Experts Call for U.S. to Expand Drug Treatment; Bush Aides Are Receptive
description: Drug treatment programs in the United States have been neglected, eroding steadily for more than a decade, and should be greatly expanded, a panel of prominent medical and drug treatment experts reported today after a two-year study.

title: U.N. NEAR ACCORD TO ASSURE CUTOFF OF IRAQI AIR LINKS
description: The five permanent members of the Security Council were reported close to final agreement today on a new resolution imposing an air embargo on all passenger and cargo flights to and from Iraq and occupied Kuwait unless the planes are on an approved humanitarian mission.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EZRA TAFT BENSON, leader of the Mormon Church, underwent surgery for blood clots in the brain yesterday at LDS Hospital in Salt Lake City. He was admitted to the hospital Tuesday for observation.

title: 7 Hours of Talks, No Budget Accord
description: Congressional leaders and Bush Administration officials met for seven hours today in an effort to break the impasse on a deficit-cutting package and to avoid broad automatic spending cuts that will take effect on Oct. 1 if no agreement is reached.

title: Home Building Off 1.7% To Lowest in 8 Years
description: Housing starts fell 1.7 percent in August to the lowest level since the last recession eight years ago, the Government said today.

title: Puerto Rico Journal;   A Drive To Make Spanish No. 1 Voice
description: Some legislators in this United States commonwealth of 3.6 million people are seeking to demote the English language and enshrine Spanish as the official tongue of Puerto Rico.

title: Apple Plans System Delay
description: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that it would delay by as much as six months the release of its new Macintosh System 7.0 operating system software. This spring the Cupertino, Calif., computer maker told software developers that it expected to release the program by the end of the year.

title: New York Census Missed 254,534 Dwellings
description: New York City officials said yesterday that they had found 254,534 housing units that were not counted by the Census Bureau. They said their finding bolstered their claim that almost one million New Yorkers were not counted.

title: Software Offer From Xerox
description: The Xerox Corporation said today that it would offer its office automation computer software for use on computers made by other manufacturers.

title: Ohio Cult Leader's Son Guilty in 4 Killings
description: The teen-age son of a religious cult leader has been convicted of helping his parents kill a man and his three children. The 19-year-old defendant, Damon Lundgren, could be sentenced to death.

title: Teaneck Inquiry Under Criticism By Police Chiefs
description: In a rare public split with the leaders of New Jersey's criminal-justice system, the state's police chiefs have urged Gov. Jim Florio to remove Attorney General Robert J. Del Tufo from the state's new inquiry into the fatal shooting of a black teen-ager by a white police officer here last April.

title: McGee's .335 Bothers N.L. Pursuers
description: Obviously, the specter of Willie McGee is too much for Lenny Dykstra and Dave Magadan. Eddie Murray, however, is a different story.

title: Review/Rock;   For a Grateful Dead Party, Bring Your Own Patience
description: Enjoying the Grateful Dead, which pulled into Madison Square Garden on Friday for the first of five sold-out shows, demands faith. One is either part of the City of Tie-Dye or in the suburbs. From the outside, the adulation and close scrutiny the band gets from its audience seems intentionally blindered, since most of the musical elements used as selling points by the band's fans can be found in a much better form elsewhere.

title: AMMAN ASKS FUNDS TO HELP IN CRISIS
description: The Jordanian Government made a strong public plea for international financial aid today, warning that unless it is compensated for enforcing the international embargo against Iraq, the nation's economy may collapse.

title: Decision on Florida Due
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is expected to announce its penalties against the University of Florida on Thursday, ending a two-year investigation into the football and basketball programs at the school.

title: Israel Said to Fault U.S. Arms Sales
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens of Israel was quoted today as expressing disappointment with Washington's initial response to Israeli concerns about a planned $20 billion American arms sale to Saudi Arabia.

title: What Should Parents Worry About?
description: LEAD: Parents who worry that their children are going to be kidnapped or die from cancer are probably wasting energy that might be better directed elsewhere, according to two doctors who conducted a survey of parents to find out their greatest fears for their children.

title: A New Image For Doughboy
description: The Pillsbury Company has revamped the image of its pudgy Doughboy, the animated character that has appeared in the company's ads for 25 years.

title: Scientists Say an Acne Drug Can Prevent a Type of Cancer
description: After nearly 20 years of tantalizing hints that vitamins or other food substances might prevent cancer, researchers say they have finally proved that this strategy works. By giving people a form of a vitamin, they prevented one type of cancer.

title: John Steinle, Lawyer And a Consultant, 73
description: John Gerard Steinle, a lawyer, hospital administrator and health-care consultant, died on Sunday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. He was 73 years old and lived in Fort Lee.

title: I.R.A. RAID WOUNDS AN EX-BRITISH AIDE
description: A former Governor of Gibraltar who authorized a security operation in which three Irish Republican Army guerrillas were killed was shot and seriously wounded at his home on Tuesday night. The I.R.A. claimed responsibility today for the attack.

title: Stations Oppose a Streamlined PBS
description: As if to underscore the sizable changes taking place in American public television, the Public Broadcasting Service will begin its new season on Sunday night with an 11-hour documentary on the Civil War that will be shown, in mini-series style, over five consecutive nights. It would be an exaggeration to say that a civil war of sorts is also taking place within public television, but several of the most powerful public television stations are leading an insurgency against some of those changes.

title: Dr. Arnold P. Friedman, 81, Dies; Authority on Migraine Headaches
description: Dr. Arnold P. Friedman, an international authority on migraine headaches, died on Monday at the El Dorado Hospital in Tucson, Ariz. He was 81 years old and lived in Tucson.

title: Giants' Collins Sidelined For 4 Weeks With Injury
description: The Giants lost two players today: Mark Collins for four weeks with a sprained right ankle and Dave Meggett for probably one day because he is unhappy with his contract and did not show up for work.

title: A Third of the News Staff at The Post Quits
description: Roughly a third of The New York Post's news staff resigned before 5 P.M. yesterday, the deadline established by the paper's owner for receiving a severance bonus of eight weeks' pay.

title: Review/Dance;   An Absent Grande Dame Enraptures the French
description: Martha Graham was recently asked if she regarded her dance works as specifically American. ''They are American because I am nothing but an American,'' she replied.

title: Unplugging A Diverse Bit Of Cable TV
description: In a claustrophobic mid-Manhattan production studio cluttered with videocassette recorders perched on rickety metal shelves, Jim Chladek tried to explain how a cable-television show featuring a pair of $2-a-minute phone-in psychics served ''the communities.''

title: Businessland Cuts Staff 10%
description: Businessland Inc., the nation's biggest computer retailer, said today that it was cutting its worldwide staff by 10 percent and shrinking operations in an effort to turn the ailing company around.

title: Speeches Supporting Souter Begin As Soon as Senate Hearings End
description: Minutes after the Senate Judiciary Committee ended its hearings today on the nomination of Judge David H. Souter to the Supreme Court, several senators took to the Senate floor to announce that they would vote to confirm him.

title: Archdiocese Orders Play to Vacate Church
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has demanded that an Off Off Broadway theater company in Manhattan terminate performances of a play being presented in a former parochial school the company leases from the archdiocese. The archdiocese says the play has language that is against the church's principles and is being performed in violation of terms in the lease between the church and the theater.

title: New Discount Frontier: Home
description: THEY live for Loehmann's; a hangtag quickens their pulse. This fall, New York's more ferocious bargain hunters have a new frontier: the home.

title: Rainout Forces Mets To Compress Rotation
description: Bud Harrelson, who is running out of fingers when trying to count how many pitchers to squeeze into how many starts in the next five days, doesn't like doubleheaders.

title: Games Asians Play
description: Six thousand muscular young people, 3,000 foreign journalists and an estimated 700,000 ''watchers'' - Chinese assigned to make sure no unsuitable demonstrations take place - are gathering for next week's Asian Games.

title: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN: Electoral Powder Keg;   In Messages of Dissatisfaction by Voters, Politicians Sense Danger of an Explosion
description: Voters sent an unmistakable message of dissatisfaction to their political leaders Tuesday in two quite different states, Massachusetts and Oklahoma, as a widespread mood of discontent with government and politics began to boil over at the ballot box.

title: Criticism of U.S. Gulf Policy Growing Louder in Congress
description: Congressional criticism of the Bush Administration's policies in the Persian Gulf, nonexistent in the first days after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, then muted, is growing louder on both sides of the aisle as lawmakers openly attack the President on several major points.

title: The Politics of Slash and Burn
description: ''Sick.'' ''Traitors.'' ''Bizarre.'' ''Self-serving.'' ''Shallow.'' ''Corrupt.'' ''Pathetic.'' ''Shame.'' The group that urged political candidates to use these epithets has since regretted suggesting the word ''traitors,'' in response to inquiries from the press. But the others were allowed to stand; they appear in a glossary that a conservative Republican group recently mailed to Republican state legislative candidates.

title: Why H.U.D. Ran From Grace
description: Of all the reports produced in the last decade, one stands alone in its potential to make the Government more effective and efficient.

title: East Germany's Economy Far Sicker Than Expected
description: With the union of the two Germanys just weeks away, East Germany's economy lies in shambles and Western companies have balked at investing in its outdated industries.

title: Court Prohibits Sex Bias In Choosing Trial Juries
description: Prosecutors may not bar women from trial juries because of their sex, a New York appeals court ruled Tuesday in overturning a criminal conviction in a burglary case in the Bronx.

title: With Wicker, Don't Put Off Repairs
description: TEDIOUS is the word David Alford uses to describe the process of repairing and restoring wicker furniture. But Mr. Alford, who started D & H Wicker Repair in 1987 with Harold Peters, also relishes the challenge of turning worn, dried-out wicker into useful, attractive and often valuable furniture that will last for years if properly cared for.

title: Princeton Club Told To Admit Women
description: A judge has ordered an all-male eating club at Princeton University to admit women, a ruling that could end an 11-year-old sex discrimination case.

title: Bail Hearing For Keating
description: A judge agreed today to consider reducing the $5 million bail he required of Charles H. Keating Jr. on Tuesday after Mr. Keating was indicted on criminal fraud charges related to the collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.

title: Jim Jarmusch's First Feature at Archives
description: Aloysious Christopher Parker (Chris Parker), 16 years old and as skinny as a bean, calls himself Allie in the signatures he occasionally spray-paints on the walls of buildings in downtown Manhattan. Allie is not a serious graffiti artist. Mostly he just drifts around, allowing things to happen.

title: Persian Gulf Conflict Makes Argentina and Britain Allies
description: Argentina will send two warships and about 450 military personnel to join the United States-led forces against Iraq, Foreign Minister Domingo Cavallo said today.

title: Debating Cigarette Ad Curbs
description: THE recent weakening in Congress of a bill that would have severely restricted cigarette advertising is not the end of the issue, backers and opponents of the measure say.

title: Soviets Open An Exchange
description: About 200 Soviet businessmen began trading today at the first commodities exchange to open in Moscow since the Bolshevik Revolution.

title: Bulgarians View Recent Past With Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * All News Channel, New York, a venture of Viacom Satellite and Conus Communications, named Matthew A. Riklin executive vice president.

title: House Told Bank Insurer Needs Action
description: A senior official of the General Accounting Office said today that Congress should do more to shore up the Government fund that insures bank deposits than simply remove the ceiling on premiums that banks pay into the fund.

title: STUNNING PRIMARY IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: The people of Massachusetts launched a political revolt Tuesday, giving smashing victories to Dr. John R. Silber as the Democratic candidate for governor and William F. Weld as the Republican contender.

title: I.M.F. Sees Growth for U.S. in 1991
description: Despite oil price increases stemming from the Middle East crisis, the United States will avoid a recession next year and experience even faster growth than in 1990, the International Monetary Fund said today.

title: Review/Television;   Hero's Fight For Truth, Justice And Ratings
description: Every television season needs its manufactured hype, and this year's top honors go to the showdown between NBC's ''Cosby Show'' and Fox's ''Simpsons'' on Thursdays at 8 P.M. With all the huffing and puffing, little attention has been paid to the fact that CBS will be countering at 8 with a new series called ''The Flash,'' based on characters created years ago for D.C. Comics.

title: Macy Plans To Buy Back 'Junk Bonds'
description: R. H. Macy & Company, the giant retailer, is planning to purchase a large chunk of its ''junk bonds'' to cut its $600 million in annual interest payments. The company has some $4.7 billion in long-term debt, and another $1 billion in short-term borrowings that fluctuate seasonally.

title: Dinkins Talks Of Crime Fear And of Race
description: Reflecting with rare pointedness on the charged issues of crime and fear in New York City, Mayor David N. Dinkins has suggested that some of the recent concern over violence was prompted by well-publicized incidents and attacks outside the poor minority neighborhoods where crime is endemic.

title: Puccini's Inheritance Part of a Murky Tale That's, Well, Operatic
description: When Giacomo Puccini died in a Brussels clinic in 1924, he left a fortune estimated at more than $100 million at today's value. His estate would grow further over the years through substantial royalties from ''La Boheme,'' ''Tosca,'' ''Madama Butterfly'' and other operas.

title:
Currents;

Last Nail Is Always
description: LEAD: THE last nail hammered into a new or renovated house should be special, because it marks the end of an arduous process. To celebrate the occasion, Ellen Halloran, a New York City designer, suggests using her sterling silver nails.

title: Bridge
description: There are times when it is safe for a defender to neglect an obvious play because it is clear that the declarer will not be able to take advantage of it.

title: If a Queens Block Could Talk, Would It Say, 'I Have People'?
description: The tenants of the Buckingham, a 130-unit apartment building in Sunnyside, Queens, were counted by the Census Bureau, were not counted, or were counted and forgotten.

title: Turks, on West's Side, Regain Voice
description: Although the Persian Gulf crisis is adding to this country's already considerable burdens, it has also handed Turks an unexpected gift of reborn confidence. Turkey's troubles are plain enough. It stands to lose billions of dollars a year in trade and investment because of the embargo against Iraq, and prices in the last few weeks have skyrocketed for basics like gasoline and bread. From senior officials to store clerks, Turks say they dread being dragged into an unwanted war in neighboring Arab lands that once were part of the Ottoman Empire.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Staggering to Finish, Reds Lose Once More
description: Cincinnati lost tonight for the fourth time in six games as Houston's Mark Portugal gave up just two runs in seven and two-thirds innings in a 5-2 victory over the Reds.

title: Teaching Doesn't Buy the Campus Computers;   Raise the Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Agents Said to Issue Fake Parking Tickets
description: A former investigator for the city's Department of Transportation asserted yesterday that 20 percent of the 12 million parking tickets issued each year in New York City are fake.

title: The Second-Best Way to Save Gas
description: There's a potent prescription that at a single stroke would slash America's dependence on foreign oil, trim the trade deficit, roll back smog and avert global warming. It's to mandate that auto manufacturers produce more fuel-efficient cars. The Senate is considering a bill by Senator Richard Bryan of Nevada to raise the fuel efficiency of new cars 20 percent by 1995 and 40 percent by the year 2001. That's not the best way of improving fuel efficiency, but it's a lot better than doing nothing.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the choice of Atlanta for the 1996 Olympic Games misstated the date of the Democratic National Convention there. It was 1988.

title: Metro Matters;   City as Landlord: Homeless Force Policy Turnabout
description: ''If you build it, they will come,'' a prophesy widely attributed to the disembodied voice in the film ''Field of Dreams,'' was actually said first by Edward I. Koch.

title: Harbor Development Opposed by Nassau
description: The top official in this Nassau County town said today that he and the rest of the town board opposed development of two parcels of land on the shore of Oyster Bay Harbor, and favored acquiring the land for public use.

title: Bush Seems to Toughen His Approach to War
description: President Bush said today that he was ''prepared to take additional steps'' if diplomacy failed to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis peacefully.

title: Commonwealth Nations Sound Alarm on Oil Impact
description: Heads of government and finance ministers from the Commonwealth nations, meeting at an annual conference, expressed alarm today over the impact of sharply increased oil prices on the economies of poor countries.

title: Big Shift In Phone Regulation
description: The Federal Communications Commission today gave the nation's eight big providers of local telephone service greater freedom to raise or lower the prices they charge long-distance carriers for completing interstate calls. The move signals a fundamental shift in the economic philosophy of American regulation.

title: Judge Dismisses Chevron Lawsuit
description: A Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit by the Chevron Corporation that charged that the Pennzoil Company had illegally purchased nearly 9 percent of Chevron's stock, a Pennzoil lawyer said.

title: Fund Yields Stay Mixed
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, underlining the lack of clear direction that has enveloped the market for nearly two months.

title: Gulf Troops Get $110 More Pay
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney ordered $110 a month in hazardous duty pay today for more than 150,000 American troops and sailors now in the Persian Gulf region, the Pentagon said.

title: F.B.I. to Promote 11 Hispanic Agents in Bias Case
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has ordered the immediate promotion of 11 veteran Hispanic agents who joined in a landmark discrimination lawsuit against the bureau.

title: AIDS Advocates Report Quilt Vandalized
description: The handmade quilt that was put together as a memorial to people who have died of AIDS was vandalized while on display here last week, and organizers said today that it would be restored.

title: French Article Says Saudi Radar Can Track U.S. Stealth Fighters
description: A French news magazine has reported that Saudi antiaircraft radar units are able to track United States fighter-bombers that were designed to be virtually invisible to radar.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Food and Drug Administration told toothpaste and mouthwash manufacturers that they must show that their ingredients are safe and effective if they want to claim on labels that their products prevent plaque. If safety cannot be substantiated with scientific data, makers will have to remove claims from the labels.

title: Prominent Field in Fifth Ave. Mile
description: The 10th running of the Mercedes Mile down Fifth Avenue on Saturday is shaping up as the Fifth Avenue Medical Mile, a race with one of the greatest fields of milers ever assembled from among the lame and the halt.

title: Top Film Makers Finding Freedom in TV
description: Steven Spielberg has directed or produced some of the most popular and profitable movies in history. In recent months, though, much of his energy has gone into a new venture called ''Tiny Toon Adventures,'' a syndicated television cartoon series that went on the air this week.

title: Shrunken Lots, Full-Size Houses
description: LEAD: A SINGLE-FAMILY home in the suburbs has commonly meant at least a quarter acre of land with enough lawn for a swing set or badminton net. But as the price of land reaches a million dollars an acre in parts of California and nearly as much in some areas of the Northeast, builders are squeezing as much house on as little land as possible.

title: Safe Use for Tobacco: Staining Raw Pine
description: LEAD: For many years pine paneling and shutters - some of them not so old or so genuine - have found their way here from England. Some restoration problems that arise are puzzling; when, for example, one section of a shutter turns out to look totally different from the others in the same set and finally you realize that this must have have been a replacement, possibly many years younger.

title: Bernard Silber, 90, Figure in '57 Hearing
description: Bernard Silber, a former Western Union employee who was convicted of contempt of Congress charges, a conviction that was later reversed by the United States Supreme Court, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Oakland, Calif. He was 90 years old and moved from Manhattan to Oakland in 1987.

title: Personal Health
description: Medical innovations, from contact lenses to bone marrow transplants, that replace or restore body parts and functions generally win wide applause as miraculous solutions to life-limiting or life-threatening problems.

title: Thomas Raleigh, 63, A Senior Executive At Price Waterhouse
description: Thomas L. Raleigh Jr., a former co-chairman of operations and deputy senior partner of Price Waterhouse-U.S., died Sunday at the New England Medical Center in Boston. He was 63 years old.

title: 5 Arrested Outside 2 Boycotted Stores in Brooklyn
description: Five protesters were arrested yesterday, two days after an appeals court ruled that the Police Department must enforce a 50-foot barrier between demonstrators and two Korean-owned grocery stores in Brooklyn.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Newspaper Faults Columnist for Remarks on Jews
description: An angry debate between opinion-page columnists took an unusual turn yesterday when The New York Post attacked Patrick J. Buchanan in an editorial next to his column. The Post said that ''when it comes to Jews as a group,'' Mr. Buchanan ''betrays an all-too-familiar hostility.''

title: Amid Sea of Difficulties, India's Prime Minister Welcomes a Small Victory
description: As his Indian Air Force jet climbed into a hazy morning sky over the Bay of Bengal, Prime Minister V. P. Singh was relishing a moment of triumph.

title: American Stores Weighs Acme Sale
description: The American Stores Company, the nation's largest grocery and drugstore retailer, said it was exploring the sale of its Acme Markets Inc. unit, which operates 275 supermarkets in the Northeast and had sales of $3.3 billion last year. The company said proceeds from a sale would be used to reduce debt and to invest in technology, remodeling and new store programs.

title: Olympia & York Selling Stake in U.S. Holdings
description: Olympia & York, one of North America's largest and most successful developers, is seeking to sell an interest in most of its American holdings in what Wall Street executives described as an effort to raise cash for other projects, including its huge Canary Wharf development in London.

title: Collecting the Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Retirement At Northrop
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that Thomas V. Jones, its longtime chairman, had retired and had been succeeded by Kent Kresa, the president and chief executive.

title: Greenspan Cools Hope Of Rate Cut
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said today that while the Persian Gulf confrontation had ''introduced new and substantial risks'' to the economy, there was still no clear evidence of actual or imminent recession that would force a cut in interest rates now.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities celebrated its 25th anniversary Tuesday night with a preview of ''The Civil War.'' The endowment was one of the financial backers of the 11-hour documentary, to be broadcast beginning Sunday on the Public Broadcasting System.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on the Company News page of Business Day in some editions yesterday about the trust fund set up by the Manville Corporation to compensate asbestos victims misidentified the party that asked the court to make a single class action out of all lawsuits naming Manville. It was the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust, not the corporation.

title: Close to Home
description: THEY'RE back, the wives who spent the summer in the country with their children and the husbands who left town on Friday afternoons and returned on the Monday morning train. I can hear the elevator door clanging and the children asking their eternal questions, and when I go to sleep it is with the knowledge that once more I am living in a hive. The bike boys with the Chinese takeout are buzzing the front door; the sound of toilets flushing and showers rushing troubles the pipes.

title: Suicide Solution
description: It was two days before Christmas when Jay Vance blew the bottom of his face off with a shotgun still slippery with his best friend's blood. He went second. Ray Belknap went first. Ray died and Jay lived, and people said that when you looked at Jay's face afterward it was hard to tell which of them got the worst of the deal. ''He just had no luck,'' Ray's mother would later say of her son to a writer from Rolling Stone, which was a considerable understatement.

title: Jackson Rejoins Eagles After a Lost Battle
description: Keith Jackson, the tight end from Oklahoma who made the Pro Bowl in his first two seasons in the National Football League, ended a 50-day holdout yesterday and returned to the Philadelphia Eagles under the same four-year, $2.1 million contract he had been trying to renegotiate.

title:
Currents;

Good Taste And How It Changes
description: LEAD: ONE generation's version of stripped-down design can look like another's decorative excess. Similarly, one period's garish testaments to popular culture can seem later to be a well-considered lesson in taste. Such axioms are readily apparent in ''20th-Century Ornament,'' by Jonathan M. Woodham (Rizzoli International

title: CHRONICLE
description: JANET HOLMES A COURT, whose husband, Robert Holmes a Court, an international financier and Australia's largest landowner, died on Sept. 3, is now the richest woman in Australia, says Australian Business magazine. In its issue out today, it estimated her worth at $623 million.

title: Tennis Court Surface, Not Racquet Size, Dictates Style of Play
description: To the Editor:

title: Minnie's Last Hurrah (Well, Maybe)
