Strawflower, globe thistle, Cut on long stems and arrange statice and silver dollar. in a bowl without water. Fruited branches Cut and arrange without water. such as bayberry. Ornamental grasses Cut and hang upside down for a week.

title: Gain in Disaster Response Seen Since Hugo
description: The Government was not as well prepared to deal with a major disaster when a hurricane struck the Caribbean and southeastern United States a year ago as it is now, a Federal emergency official said Thursday.

title: Big Apple in 1909
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film Festival;   A Cannes Winner From the U.S.S.R.
description: In the Far Eastern Soviet city of Suchan, as depicted in Vitaly Kanevski's austere and haunting ''Freeze-Die-Come to Life,'' an unexpected story unfolds. The loosening of constraints upon the imaginations of Soviet film makers has meant the collapse of countless stereotypes regarding Soviet life, and those governing depictions of life in the gulag have been among the first to go.

title: Monopoly Status Led Cable TV to Gouge
description: To the Editor:

title:
How Best to Use 5,000 More Police;

Put the Cops Back On the Beat
description: LEAD: Is 5,000 more cops a ''magic number'' picked out of the air?

title: CHRONICLE
description: The 1991 Jefferson Lecturer in the humanities is GERTRUDE HIMMELFARB, professor emeritus of history at the graduate school of the City University of New York. Established by the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Jefferson Lecture recognizes distinguished achievement. Professor Himmelfarb, the author of many books on Victorian England, is the 20th lecturer and will collect $10,000 for the honor when she speaks in Washington on May 1, 1991.

title: Yearlong Leak of Radioactivity Is Reported
description: Radioactive water may have leaked for nearly a year from a plant at the Hanford nuclear reservation before being discovered, the Federal project's manager has disclosed.

title: Keep Developers Out of Our Water Sources
description: To the Editor:

title: Football and Politics Square Off at Michigan State
description: When George Perles coaches Michigan State against Notre Dame here Saturday, one of the 76,000 fans attending the Spartans' home opener will be John DiBiaggio, the university's president. He has been a regular spectator for his six years on the job and does not plan to change that habit.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about discount sources for home furnishings in Lower Manhattan misstated the telephone number for Pearl River Emporium. The number is (212) 431-4770.

title: Carolyn Haft Weds
description: Carolyn Anne Haft, a daughter of Robert S. Haft and Pamela W. Haft, both of New York, was married yesterday to Jeff McAdam Muller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mervin E. Muller of Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. Ellen Johnson-Fay, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at St. Clement's Estate in Portland, Conn. Mrs. Muller, 24 years old, and her husband, 25, are 1988 graduates of Wesleyan University.

title: Review/Piano;   A Soviet Teen-Ager Makes His American Debut
description: To paraphrase T. S. Eliot, I have been to hear the latest Russian transmit Chopin through his fingertips. This time the transmitter in question is named Yevgeny Kissin, an 18-year-old pianist from Moscow who made his American debut on Thursday evening as soloist in Chopin's Concerto No. 1 in E minor with the New York Philharmonic. It is easy to become a little blase about the endless flood of transoceanic geniuses, most of whom arrive bearing a stamp of approval from one or more international competitions and fanfares from major record companies. It was impossible, however, to sustain anything like a detached or suspicious attitude during this remarkably gifted musician's debut.

title: Dead Soldier Identified
description: The Army today identified the American soldier killed Thursday in a vehicle accident in Saudi Arabia as Specialist Robert Allan Noonan, 21 years old. He was a Cincinnati native and an anti-armor weapons specialist in Company D, 1st Battalion, 505th Parachute Infantry Regiment of the 82d Airborne Division. He was killed, and two other soldiers suffered minor injuries, in an off-road accident.

title: Stephen F. Kolzak TV Executive, 37
description: Stephen F. Kolzak, former senior vice president of casting and talent at Columbia Pictures Television, died on Wednesday at Sherman Oaks (Calif.) Community Hospital. He was 37 years old and lived in Los Angeles. His family said he had died of AIDS. Mr. Kolzak, who was born in Hartford and was a graduate of Harvard, was previously manager of West Coast casting for NBC and vice president of casting for Embassy Television.

title: Bicycle Called a Danger
description: Federal safety officials are being urged by Consumers Union to recall a bicycle because, the group says, its brakes are unsafe.

title: U.S.-Soviet Differences Are Said to Threaten Arms-Cut Pact
description: A senior American official said today that serious differences with the Soviet Union must be ironed out in the coming weeks if a conventional arms-reduction treaty is to be ready for signing at a 35-member meeting scheduled for Nov. 19 in Paris.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Urges Souter's Defeat, Citing Earlier Statements on Race
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the nation's oldest and largest civil rights organization, urged the Senate today to reject the nomination of Judge David H. Souter to the Supreme Court.

title: Japanese Gain In Beer Output
description: Japan became the world's fourth-largest beer brewer last year, surpassing Britain, the Kirin Brewery Company, Japan's biggest, said on Thursday.

title: Padres Drop McKeon As General Manager
description: Jack McKeon was dismissed as general manager by the San Diego Padres last night, ending a decadelong stay.

title: Suspect in 10 Sexual Murders Is Portrayed as Unremorseful
description: A man accused of being a serial murderer was easily provoked to kill and felt little remorse for his victims, according to his confessions, which were released today.

title: In Jordan, Saddam Hussein Is 'King'
description: First, the masked men on the roof burned Israel's Star of David flag, and the crowd cheered. Then it was the turn of the Stars and Stripes, and the crowd cheered louder. Finally, it was the turn of the Soviet Union's hammer and sickle banner, and the cheers rolled on.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GILBERT CATES, a producer and director who was responsible for last year's Academy Awards program, has been named dean of the new School of Theater, Film and Television at the University of California at Los Angeles. But Mr. Cates, who directed ''I Never Sang for My Father,'' among other films, and was a two-term president of the Directors Guild of America, is not leaving Hollywood permanently for U.C.L.A. His agreement allows him to pursue outside work, including producing next year's Academy Awards.

title: New Bush Tone on Capital Gains Hints at a Budget Compromise
description: As Congressional and Administration budget negotiators wrestled with an impasse over cutting the capital gains tax rate, President Bush pointedly avoided criticizing a suggestion by the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, that the tax cut be severed from the budget package.

title: Joseph Schwartzman , Pediatrician, 84
description: Dr. Joseph Schwartzman, professor emeritus of pediatrics at New York Medical College, died on Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 84 years old.

title: Traffic Alert
description: George Washington Bridge: New Jersey-bound traffic will be disrupted through 6 A.M. Monday. Tie-ups are also expected on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: CHASE MANHATTAN TO CUT 5,000 JOBS AND TRIM DIVIDEND
description: In a telling new sign of the problems afflicting the nation's banks, the Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $1 billion charge against earnings and reduce its work force by 5,000 employees. The nation's second-largest bank also took the unusual and humbling step of cutting its stock dividend by more than 50 percent as part of a drive to rebuild its financial strength.

title: Hilton Planning Share Buyback
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 21 (Reuters) - The Hilton Hotels Corporation said it plans to buy back up to six million of its common shares from time to time in the open market or through negotiated purchases. Six million shares represents about 12.5 percent of Hilton's 48.1 million shares outstanding.

title: Irving N. Hinnau, Executive, 66
description: Irving N. Hinnau, a retired executive of the International Business Machines Corporation, died on Tuesday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 66 years old. His family said he died of melanoma. Mr. Hinnau graduated from the University of Cincinnati and held a master's degree in business administration from Columbia. He served in World War II and the Korean War as an Air Force first lieutenant. He joined I.B.M. in 1949 and was director of Asia-Pacific area marketing before retiring as a vice president of I.B.M. World Trade in 1976. He then bought the Greenwich Hardware Company and ran its Greenwich store until 1985.

title: Miss Barrios Wed To John C. O'Neill
description: Lauren Claire Barrios, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Digby W. Barrios of Ridgefield, Conn., was married yesterday to John Colin O'Neill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger W. O'Neill of Cedar Grove, N.J. The Rev. Canon Charles W. Stubbs officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EDWARD DWIGHT is to be the sculptor for a memorial to the black soldiers of the American Revolution. The memorial, for which Congress has given a two-acre site on the Mall in Washington, is being designed by a team of architects, headed by MARSHALL E. PURNELL. The project was conceived by MAURICE A. BARBOZA, a former lobbyist who created the Black Revolutionary War Patriots Foundation. He must raise $4 million, the cost of the memorial, by Oct. 27, 1991, or the foundation will forfeit the land.

title: Can Heads Be Counted in a Dynamic City?
description: When New York City officials said the Census Bureau had failed to count hundreds of thousands of housing units in the five boroughs - and, they implied, the people living in them - they were challenging more than the Federal agency's arithmetic.

title: KEY RATES
Books of The Times;   How Two Ballerinas See The Trees and the Forest
description: Holding On to the Air

title: 2 Shot and a Robber Is Slain
description: Customers of a social club in Brooklyn pounced on one of two men who tried to rob them on Thursday night, and in the struggle the robber was stabbed to death, the police said yesterday. The two men had interrupted a card game in a private room at the Red Spot Social Club at 538 Nostrand Avenue in the Flatbush section shortly after 10 P.M., the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Wednesday about grants made by the Fund for New American Plays incompletely listed the authors of ''Mule Bone,'' which is to be presented by Lincoln Center Theater. They are Langston Hughes and Zora Neale Hurston.

title: Zuckerman Talks Reported With Sony on Coliseum Site
description: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the New York developer, is negotiating with the Sony Corporation to form a venture that might develop the Coliseum site on Columbus Circle in Manhattan, several real estate executives said this week.

title: Harry Palevsky, 71, An A-Bomb Developer
description: Harry Palevsky, one of the early researchers in nuclear physics who helped to develop the atomic bomb, died Monday at Community Memorial Hospital in Ventura, Calif. He was 71 years old and lived in Ojai, Calif.

title: Mandela, in a Conciliatory Mood, Agrees to Meet With Zulu Leader
description: Prospects for an end to violence in black townships grew today when Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader, made a surprisingly warm overture to Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the leader of the Zulu-based organization vying with the congress for influence.

title: Philadelphia Stalls Bankruptcy
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode announced a series of steps today to stall the city's bankruptcy until Dec. 1.

title: ExaminingThe N.F.L.Conscience
description: As soon as Dan Hampton plops onto a trainer's table after a Chicago Bears game, he lights a cigar and yells, ''Gimme a double with cheese.'' But the 6-foot-5-inch, 275-pound defensive tackle is not ordering a burger. He's ordering two ice bags and two Ace bandages for his knees, which have had arthroscopic surgery 10 times, five on each knee.

title: Police Investigating Bias In Vandalism Linked to Lee Film
description: The police said yesterday that the department's anti-bias unit was investigating vandalism against property owned by a white man who had rented a building to a Spike Lee film production, but the man denied that the incident was racially motivated.

title: Harley-Davidson
description: Harley-Davidson Inc. said it had laid off 180 of the 1,800 employees at its Holiday Rambler Corporation recreational vehicle subsidiary in response to continued softness in the market and consumer uncertainty brought about by the Persian Gulf crisis. The company also said it had discontinued Holiday Rambler's Aviator Van Conversions operations here and closed its Woodland, Calif., Utilimaster commercial vehicle manufacturing plant. Harley's stock slipped 50 cents today, to $20.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Explosives and Guns Are Found In Trunks on the Upper East Side
description: Two steamer trunks containing automatic weapons and explosives were discovered last night in the hallway of an apartment building on the Upper East Side, and the police said that officers later found more explosives inside an apartment there.

title: Arthur L. Amundsen, A.S.P.C.A. Official, 85
description: Arthur L. Amundsen, former director of operations for the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, died on Thursday at a friend's home, where he was staying as part of the Good Samaritan Hospice Program in Bay Shore, L.I. He was 85 years old and lived in Valley Stream, L.I.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-6

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bayer A.G., Leverkusen, West Germany, said it had received permission from all necessary regulatory agencies to acquire the polysar rubber division of Nova Corp., Calgary, Alberta, a petrochemicals company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about legislation to provide incentives for recycling newspapers misstated the amount of recycled newsprint used by The Asbury Park (N.J.) Press and The Star Ledger in Newark. The Press uses recycled paper for about 33 percent of its production and The Star Ledger uses it for about 18 percent, said spokesmen for the newspapers. Incorrect data from a survey provided by the legislation's sponsor had said the newspapers printed 100 percent of their newspapers on recycled newsprint.

title: Surgery for Salvador
description: The cold war is over, but El Salvador lies trapped in a twilight zone where nothing seems to change. Peace talks between Government and guerrillas are deadlocked. Insurgents say they won't lay down their arms until agreement is reached on purging notorious violators of human rights from the army and security forces.

title: William G. Andrews, Executive, 83
description: Willliam G. Andrews, a former vice president of Grand Union Food Stores, died on Saturday at his home in Winter Haven, Fla., where he had lived since he retired in 1971. He was 83 years old.

title: Austrians Seeking Czech Plane Deal
description: An Austrian trading company said it was negotiating to buy Soviet airliners from Czechoslavakia's state airline. ''If the deal comes off, we would be the first people in Western Europe to buy Eastern planes,'' said Herwig Winkler, the manager of Aircom Luftfahrthandels.

title: Loan for Shanghai VW
description: Hit hard by China's austerity measures, Shanghai Volkswagen has signed an agreement with the Chinese Bank of Industry and Commerce to borrow $27 million to complete its 1990 production plan, the Shanghai newspaper Liberation Daily reported on Thursday. Shanghai Volkswagen, a joint venture of the Shanghai Automobile and Tractor Industries Corporation and Volkswagen A.G. of West Germany, can produce 60,000 cars annually but is licensed by the Government to make only 15,000 this year.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Disputes Over Fees
description: Dealing with overcharges by lawyers and accountants can be daunting. But consumers are speaking out to professional societies and, in some instances, provoking change.

title: Giants Undecided
description: When the Giants play the Miami Dolphins tomorrow for the first time since 1972, Mark Collins will be on injured reserve. So who will be the starters at cornerback: Reyna Thompson, Everson Walls or Perry Williams?

title: Jackie Moran, Actor, 67
description: John E. (Jackie) Moran, who was a child actor in films in the 1930's, died on Thursday. He was 67 years old.

title: 'Air America' Movie Doesn't Say U.S. Fought for Drugs in Laos
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music;   Tribal Life Evoked in 'Potawatomi'
description: When the University of Wisconsin at Parkside commissioned Otto Luening in 1979 to write music for its 10th anniversary, the Milwaukee native responded with ''Potawatomi Legends,'' a piece with both personal and local connections. At the end of his 1980 autobiography, ''The Odyssey of an American Composer'' (Scribner's), Mr. Luening wrote, ''The premiere is scheduled to be near the port where my great-grandfather Neukirch debarked in 1839; the Potawatomi tribe still camped near his log cabin at the time.''

title: 300,000 Lose Water Supply In New Jersey
description: About 300,000 people in Jersey City, Hoboken, and Lyndhurst were left without water for three and a half hours yesterday when an aqueduct ruptured.

title: Police Criticized in San Diego Killings
description: Five years after a serial killer, or killers, began attacking prostitutes and other young women here, the San Diego police are still searching for suspects and a special task force has begun investigating the investigation itself.

title: Mortgage Rates Rise
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.16 percent this week, up from 10.13 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.30 percent, up from 8.26 percent last week.

title: Fare Advice to Air Travelers: In Case of Discount Sale, Leap
description: The airline industry is once again planning fare increases that are expected to be followed by restricted, short-term discounts to lure leisure travelers.

title: Patents;   Clarifying Questions on Technology
description: A broad piece of patent legislation dealing with advances in technology moved closer to approval this week. The bill is intended to clarify such questions as where a patent should be issued for inventions in outer space or who owes a royalty on offspring of patented animals.

title: Surrogate Is Denied Custody
description: A Superior Court judge today awarded temporary custody of a baby to a couple who hired a woman to be a surrogate mother and were then sued by her for custody.

title: Polly Peck Backs Chief
description: The directors of Polly Peck International P.L.C. said today that the board ''deplores the recent attacks on the chairman'' of the conglomerate, who has been questioned by Government investigators.

title: Henry Lax, Physician, 95
description: Henry Lax, an internist and a cardiologist, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95 years old and died of a stroke, his son Peter said.

title: Crude Oil Prices Rise Sharply
description: Crude oil prices climbed sharply yesterday, following big jumps for both heating oil and gasoline.

title: Review/Film Festival;   On Oppression of Women in China
description: The most dazzling element in ''Ju Dou'' is the everyday work of its characters. In a Chinese village in 1920, a beautiful young woman named Ju Dou is married off to a belligerent older man who owns a factory where fabric is dyed. Though this weighty film is about the sins of the fathers, the oppression of women and passion challenging tradition, cheerful-looking banners of ruby, sapphire and topaz-colored cloth are hung to dry in the open air. They fly in the background as perpetual suggestions of the beauty that exists here only in stolen, illicit moments.

title: What of the Other Lost Spoils of Hitler's War?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pirates Edge Ahead
description: Zane Smith pitched a five-hitter and Sid Bream broke a scoreless tie with a one-out double in the seventh inning tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates past the St. Louis Cardinals, 1-0.

title: When Chips Are Down, A Surprising Bunt Isn't
description: Tim Teufel's idea, as things turned out, had no direct impact on the winning or losing of a game. It had everything to do with the state of mind the Mets have created for themselves, a line of thought that became a little harder to eliminate this afternoon, after their fifth consecutive defeat, and the sixth in seven games, in what is left of a race for first place.

title:
How Best to Use 5,000 More Police;

Patrols Are Better Than Arrests
description: LEAD: New Yorkers may soon pay for 5,000 more police officers to fight crime. What they may get is 5,000 more officers making arrests.

title: F.D.I.C. Sues Neil Bush And Others at Silverado
description: Federal regulators today sued Neil M. Bush, the President's son, and other directors, officers and lawyers of a defunct Denver savings and loan association, saying their ''gross negligence'' had led to a collapse that could cost taxpayers more than $1 billion.

title: Post-Communist Blues
description: Poland's trenchant writer Adam Michnik now says, ''We have a strange feeling that we are losing.'' It is an important message from Eastern Europe, somewhat overlooked in the preoccupation with the Persian Gulf crisis, which also hurts Eastern economies.

title: Richard E. Goodman, Ad Executive, 62
description: Richard E. Goodman, an advertising executive, died on Tuesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 62 years old and lived in Chatham Township, N.J.

title: About New York;   Key to Survival Lies in Spirit Of Teen-Agers
description: ''You're talking about kids who are eating and sleeping death,'' said Carol A. Beck, principal of Thomas Jefferson High School in the East New York section of Brooklyn. ''The stories that are news stories to you are friends and family to them.''

title: Indians Drop Blue Jays Into a Tie
description: Sandy Alomar's bases-empty home run in the top of the 13th inning gave the Cleveland Indians a 2-1 victory over Toronto tonight, dropping the Blue Jays back into a first-place tie in the American League East.

title: Sundstrand Tie To Milton Roy
description: The Sundstrand Corporation, an aerospace contractor, and the Milton Roy Company, an industrial equipment maker, signed a merger agreement that they expect to be put into effect about the end of the year. Under the agreement, Milton Roy shareholders will receive $28 cash for each outstanding share of the St. Petersburg company's common stock, for a total of $128 million. Milton Roy's shares jumped $3.75 today, to $26.75, on the New York Stock Exchange, where the 16.3 percent gain was the best of the day. Sundstrand fell 62.5 cents, to $23.25.

title: Alfonso Cata, 53, A Dancer, Teacher And Ballet Director
description: Alfonso Cata, artistic director of the Ballet du Nord in Roubaix, France, died on Sept. 15 at the Hospital of Tourcoing, near Roubaix. He was 53 years old.

title: Florida Executes Convict for Killing Store Owner
description: A 61-year-old inmate was executed in Florida's electric chair this morning for killing the owner of a lingerie shop in Jacksonville six years ago.

title: Syracuse Is Putting Its Fate in Graves's Hands
description: Marvin Graves, the nifty Syracuse quarterback who practiced with the team last year as a freshman but was ineligible to play, has been upgraded by his coach, Bill MacPherson.

title: Judge Refuses To Cut Bail For Keating
description: A judge refused today to lower the $5 million bail he had set for Charles H. Keating Jr., forcing the former savings and loan executive, who insists he is now virtually penniless, to remain locked up in a county jail.

title: Hell No More
description: One of the breakfast shows used television magic the other day to reunite an Army mother in Saudi Arabia for a few minutes with her husband and small son back home in North Carolina.

title: Profit? Loss? A Primer for Soviets
description: Nikolai V. Panteleyev has the unenviable task of creating an accounting profession in a nation unfamiliar with profits and losses, let alone concepts like intangible assets, good will or fair value. He likens the job to teaching people to ''learn Chinese overnight.''

title: INSIDE
description: Regulators Sue Neil Bush

title: The Mayor Visits the Red Apple, Finally
description: He waited far too long and sent one mixed signal after another. But after eight months of procrastination, Mayor David Dinkins marched right into two boycotted Korean grocery stores yesterday -leaving no doubt that when he wants to be the healer and conciliator that so many New Yorkers had hoped for, he knows how to play that role.

title: Minoso Is Out
description: Minnie Minoso has struck out in his bid to become the first major league baseball player to appear in six decades. Commissioner Fay Vincent directed the Chicago White Sox not to activate the 68-year-old Minoso in the final days of the season, the team said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about talks between two black organizations in South Africa misidentified the capital of Natal province. It is Pietermaritzburg, not Durban.

title: Robert B. Spence, 89, Psychology Professor
description: Robert Beckett Spence, a professor emeritus of psychology at Teachers College at Columbia University, died on Wednesday at his home in a retirement community in Newtown, Pa. He was 89 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JAMES B. HUNT JR., a former Governor of North Carolina, had a run-in with a cow last weekend. The cow won.

title: Bush to Revise Proposal to Sell Arms to Saudis
description: Bowing to Congressional pressure, the White House today modified its plans to sell $21 billion in arms to Saudi Arabia and said it would present the package to Congress in stages, with the largest part deferred until next year.

title: Wilfred Wilson, Lawyer, 68
description: Wilfred Wilson, a lawyer and retired senior vice president of a national teachers' pension fund, died on Aug. 26 at Sydney City Hospital in Sydney, Nova Scotia. He was 68 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: Shock for a Celtic
description: Dee Brown of the Boston Celtics said he was held at gunpoint yesterday by several Wellesley, Mass., police officers who thought he was a bank-robbery suspect.

title: Domino's Pizza In Marriott Pact
description: Domino's Pizza will be on the menu at schools around the nation under an agreement the pizza delivery company signed with the Marriott Corporation. A subsidiary of Marriott, based in Bethesda, Md., manages school lunch programs at more than 200 United States school districts, serving 120 million meals a year.

title: Religion Notes
description: Yom Kippur Plea One week from today is Yom Kippur, the Day of Attonement , on which Jews traditionally undertake a voluntary fast by refraining for 25 hours from all food and drink. As in past years, a national organization, Mazon, is trying to harness this sacrifice for a good cause. The organization is asking that American Jews ''help to end the involuntary fast of millions'' by contributing to Mazon the amount of money they would have spent on food had they not fasted on Yom Kippur.

title: Spurs to Drop Wingate
description: San Antonio Spurs officials said yesterday that the guard David Wingate would not be back with the team after his indictment on rape charges in Maryland.

title: 32 Month-Term in Pentagon Bribery Case
description: William M. Galvin, a leading figure in the sweeping military procurement scandal that came to light in 1988, was sentenced to 32 months in prison today for bribing two senior Pentagon officials to influence the awarding of lucrative contracts.

title: Guam to Appeal Striking Down of Abortion Curbs
description: The government of the Pacific island of Guam said today that it would appeal a Federal court decision striking down a law that prohibits abortion in nearly all circumstances.

title: Lake Shikotsu Journal;   Japan Into the Woods: Are Golf Courses Nature?
description: Some of the out-of-town visitors who come here to crowd the rocky shores of one of Japan's last unspoiled lakes came up with what they thought was a splendid idea a few years ago -creating an elaborate sanctuary for swans and other rare species of water fowl from around the world.

title: The Wrong Way to Clean House
description: Oklahomans voted 2 to 1 on Tuesday to put a 12-year limit on state legislators' terms. California and Colorado have similar proposals on their November ballots; opinion polls in both states indicate overwhelming public support, and national polls show the same. Has the time arrived?

title: Tibet After Martial Law: Whispers of Protest
description: Five months after martial law was lifted here, a sullen calm has returned to the narrow lanes of this holy city. But Chinese marksmen are still perched on the roofs of buildings overlooking the central square, and many Tibetans suspect that their guns have not been silenced for long.

title: Alaska G.O.P. Nominee Abandons the Ticket
description: The Alaska Republican Party has been thrown into disarray by the defection of its nominee for lieutenant governor to a third-party ticket led by former Gov. Walter J. Hickel.

title: Lebanese Chief Signs a New Power-Sharing Law
description: President Elias Hrawi signed into law today a package of constitutional amendments setting forth a new political order for power sharing between Muslims and Christians in an attempt to end 15 years of civil war.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the faculty strike at Temple University misstated a faculty union offer. The union did not propose reducing the salaries of new faculty members.

title: Brokers Play Down New Threat
description: Securities industry executives said yesterday that J. P. Morgan & Company's newly granted ability to underwrite stocks was not much of a near-term threat. But, they said, it could lead to fundamental changes in their industry and bring new riskiness into the nation's banking system if other banks get similar authority. And Wall Street plans to take these concerns to Washington.

title: Mets' Collapse Deepens With 5th Loss in Row
description: The Mets steepened their headlong rush toward oblivion today when they managed only four hits, lost to the Chicago Cubs by 4-3, and ran their losing streak to five games with only 12 to play in a collapsing pennant race.

title: Donald Cawley, Ex-Police Head, Is Dead at 61
description: Donald F. Cawley, who was called an ''innovator'' and ''an enormously able professional'' when he was appointed as the 30th Commissioner of the New York City Police Department in 1973, died yesterday at his home in Massapequa, L.I.

title: Life-Cycle Studies: Imperfect Science
description: Scientists are struggling to devise a way to help consumers, regulators and others choose among competing products, like those made from paper or plastic, based on their environmental impact. But researchers say that despite a spate of studies that make such comparisons, a valid method is not likely to be found for years.

title: Your Money;   Shielding Children After Remarriage
description: When people who have children get a divorce and remarry, special care needs to be taken in financial and estate planning - particularly if the new spouse also has children from a previous marriage.

title: Court Rules Abortion Opponent Won Illinois Legislative Primary
description: The Illinois Supreme Court today declared State Representative Penny Pullen winner of a hotly contested legislative contest that was seen as a test of the importance of the abortion issue with voters.

title: Film Festival/Two Portraits: One of Romance in France, One of Crime in New York;   A 1934 Work Is Half The Legacy Of Jean Vigo
description: The highlight of the current New York Film Festival could well turn out to be the single performance today at 5 P.M. of Jean Vigo's 1934 ''L'Atalante.''

title: Yankees Oblige Red Sox in a Time of Need
description: Their ugly little season has been reduced to that of spoilers, but the Yankees can't even seem to do that right. Instead, they are The Cure. Earlier this week, they helped push the Toronto Blue Jays into first place in the American League East. Last night at the Stadium, they patched up the cracks in the sinking ship known as the Boston Red Sox.

title: Film Festival/Two Portraits: One of Romance in France, One of Crime in New York;   Drug Lord Reigns Supreme Amid Urban Decadence
description: When confronted by three muggers in a deserted subway car, Frank White (Christopher Walken) stares at them coldly, adjusts his belt so that the gun at his waist is clearly visible, casually tosses a large wad of cash in their direction and suggests that they look him up at the Plaza Hotel if they're ever interested in a better line of work. That's nerve. In the middle of a policeman's funeral, with scores of assembled officers paying their respects to a colleague felled by Frank White and his henchmen, Frank pulls up in a stretch limousine and finishes off a particular cop he's sorry to have missed the first time around. That's nerve, too.

title: Serbs Endanger Displaced Hungarians
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberian Rebel Leader Declares a Cease-Fire
description: Charles Taylor, the leader of Liberia's main rebel group, today announced a unilateral cease-fire and said he hoped that all warring parties would comply, according to a news report.

title: Administration Offers Plan To Limit Northwest Logging
description: After spending three months trying to come up with a way to save both owls and logging jobs in the Pacific Northwest, the Bush Administration acknowledged today that ''no perfect solution exists.'' It proposed a series of measures, harshly criticized by both sides of the issue, that are given little chance of passing Congress.

title: DINKINS SUPPORTS SHUNNED GROCERS
description: Taking sides in one of the most divisive disputes of his administration eight months after it began, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday went to two Korean-owned groceries in Brooklyn that have been the object of a bitter black-led boycott and bought about $10 worth of produce.

title:
How Best to Use 5,000 More Police;

The Finest Can Be Even Finer
description: LEAD: Five thousand. By this time, it would be hard to find a New Yorker who doesn't know what that number means.

title: After a Few Steps Tpward a New Life, an Untimely End
description: With his long hair and beard and old woolen coats, Thomas Ebbers looked like so many of the homeless men who roam New York City's streets and subways. But friends said he was special, a former recluse struggling not only to put his own life back together but to help other homeless people do the same. He was emerging from his shell.

title: Keep Developers Out of Our Water Sources;   System Needs Study
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1990
description: Companies

title: Electrolux Seeks Sale of Subsidiary
description: Electrolux A.B., the Swedish appliance maker, said it wanted to sell its commercial services business unit. which had revenue in 1989 of 3.9 billion kronor, the equivalent of about $675 million. Electrolux said the unit employs 30,000 people in environmental cleaning and janitorial services.

title: 'M. Butterfly' Tour Starting
description: Stuart Ostrow and David Geffen, co-producers of ''M. Butterfly,'' have resolved their differences over the national tour of the show, which is to begin performances today in Boston as scheduled, with Mr. Ostrow directing, Mr. Ostrow announced yesterday. John Breglio, a partner in Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison in New York, had applied for a preliminary injunction on Mr. Geffen's behalf to keep the show from opening. Mr. Geffen alleged that he had been denied joint approval rights over the tour and had not been told of Mr. Ostrow's decision to direct the tour himself. Details of the agreement were not revealed.

title: Agassi a Winnner But Chang Beaten
description: On a day of few surprises on the red clay court of Prater Stadium, the United States and Austria stood even at one match each after the first-day singles in the Davis Cup semifinals.

title: U.S. PANEL INDICTS 5 MORE LAWMAKERS
description: A Federal grand jury indicted five more legislators today on charges involving bribery and drugs, bringing to 10 the number of lawmakers implicated in a Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry of vote-buying in the South Carolina Statehouse.

title: Defenders and Detractors View Banks' New Powers
description: Bank regulators and Bush Administration officials said today that the Federal Reserve's decision to further relax restrictions that had prevented commercial banks from trading corporate securities would probably not lead to the speculative stock trading and underwriting problems that caused the ban to be written into the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933.

title: Ceausescu's Son Convicted And Sentenced to 20 Years
description: Nicu Ceausescu, the youngest son of the former Romanian dictator, was convicted by a military tribunal today of ''instigation to murder'' and sentenced to 20 years in prison.

title: George D. Bjurman, Retired Financial Manager, 84
description: George D. Bjurman, a retired investment portfolio manager, died Monday at the Medical Center of the University of California at Los Angeles. He was 84 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Review/Dance;   Cunningham Is an 'Event' in Lyons
description: In the huge festival devoted to American dance that is being staged here this month by the fourth International Dance Biennial, Merce Cunningham is king.

title: Bridge
description: A common bidding dilemma afflicts the player who has a five-card major suit and a weak balanced hand when his partner has opened one no-trump. To pass or not to pass, that is the question.

title: Lease Is Signed In Washington For Trade Center
description: Plans for the construction of an International Cultural and Trade Center on Pennsylvania Avenue appeared to be back on track today with the signing of a 30-year master lease agreement by the General Services Administration.

title: Woman Says Police Officers Bullied and Threatened Her
description: A book editor who had demanded that a group of New York City police officers stop taunting her taxi driver said yesterday that she was yanked from the cab, handcuffed and taken to a midtown jail cell, where officers held her incommunicado for nearly five hours and subjected her to a torrent of threats, lewd insults and anti-Semitic slurs.

title: Thomas McGrath, 74, A Poet and Teacher
description: Thomas McGrath, a poet who was widely published in the last four decades, died on Thursday at the Abbott-Northwestern Hospital in Minneapolis. He was 74 years old and lived in Minneapolis.

title: Pro Football;   Eagles Take Ryan Under Wing
description: ''Hey, Keith!'' Jerome Brown yelled across the Philadelphia Eagles' locker room to Keith Jackson. Jackson was being swamped last Thursday by reporters and cameramen on his first day back from a 50-day, two-game contract holdout.

title: Unfair Picture Of Ivy League
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Woman's Journey in the World of Law
description: LEAD: THE year was 1929, and Florence F. Forgotson, fresh out of New York University Law School, was looking for a job. The first prospective employer she went to see told her that he could not hire a female lawyer because his secretary of 26 years would resent it.

title: Music Groups Count on Galas to Offset Aid Cuts
description: LEAD: ALL across the state this season, patrons of arts organizations will be donning tuxedos and evening gowns and attending gala fund-raising events more often than before, as organizations attempt to compensate for cuts in corporate and individual gifts and in grants from the New Jersey State Council on the

title: A Scruffy Thingness
description: LIMBO RIVER

title: Campus Life: Chico State;   Campus Searches Of Bags for Alcohol Are Discontinued
description: Searches for alcohol in the bags and backpacks of dormitory residents in the wake of a tougher anti-drinking policy at California State University at Chico were stopped last weekend. The student government charged that the practice violated students' rights.

title: Metal Alloy Tapes Suit the Task Of Capturing the Range of CD's
description: Belated recognition has come to metal tape cassettes. These are tapes coated with particles of metal alloy instead of the usual metal oxide particles. Such tapes languished on the market for more than a decade, but now their advantage is being appreciated.

title: Taking Care of Doorbell Problems
description: DOORBELL problems are usually easy to fix. And because they operate on very low voltage (usually fewer than 18 volts), their components are safe to handle even when connected.

title: At Sea With McPhee
description: LOOKING FOR A SHIP.

title: Sheryl A. Porter Is Married
description: Sheryl A. Porter, the daughter of Gene Porter Jr. of Cincinnati and the late Elizabeth A. Porter, was married yesterday to Steven M. Durham, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Durham of McAdenville, N.C., by the Rev. Steven L. Mowery at Crossnore Presbyterian Church in Crossnore, N.C. The bride is an assistant vice president of Glenmede Trust Company and her husband is a vice president of Goldman, Sachs & Company, both in Philadelphia.

title: Music Festivals
description: To the Editor: Regarding the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival (Q & A, July 29): Your readers should know of an interesting tour company called Festival Tours in Santa Monica, Calif., 213-395-2486. This small operator offers to take you behind-the-scenes of musical festivals such as New Orleans. I took the excursion to England's and Scotland's folk scene: it included Fairport Convention Reunion and the Edinburgh Festival (and Fringe). But, it also took us to the premiere of the film ''Local Hero'' in the fishing village of Pennan. This is only one example of their attempt to let us know the real people and musicians. Doing a ''crossover arm swing'' at a local dance with a sheep-farmer's wife makes you appreciate the country in country dance!

title: Hermes Pan, Dancer, 79, Is Dead; Choreographer of Astaire Classics
description: Hermes Pan, the Academy Award-winning choreographer who, with Fred Astaire, created some of the most elegant, spirited and amusing dances in film history, died on Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 79 years old.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES/IN SHORT: FICTION
description: RELIABLE LIGHT: STORIES. By Meredith Steinbach. (Rutgers University, $18.95.) Meredith Steinbach has won both a Pushcart Prize and an O. Henry award for short fiction, and it's easy to see why. At her best, she gives us what we want from stories; root emotion recognized through someone else's consciousness. The best story of the seven in this, her first collection, is the novella ''To Be Sung On the Water.'' With great delicacy, Ms. Steinbach moves us into a family -- the family as it was and is and is to be, the family in all its ramifications, the family as destiny. The main character is Rose, a gifted young painter who is also a wife, mother, sister, the daughter of a beauty who has missed her great chance for happiness, a granddaughter and the lover of a married man. Rose's life has been interrupted by the death of her grandfather and a trip home for his funeral. Ms. Steinbach moves easily backward and forward in time, from the adult Rose consoling her widowed, unexpectedly diminished grandmother, to the small Rosie who nestles against her for comfort. Ms. Steinbach touchingly details what is left of the child in the adult, and what the adult eventually comes to realize from what the child has seen. The shortest piece in the book, ''On Star Street,'' is a brilliant little portrait of an old woman in a nursing home, the syntax of her life dribbling away. Ms. Steinbach is particularly gifted at using quiet, typically plaing her characters in rural settings against which emotional clangor stands out as clearly as the bright colors of the yellow slicker and red boots in the rainy city of her story ''A Preponderance of the Small,'' a moving tale in which a young widow has to face a second experience with death.

title: All About/Investing in Agriculture;   Wall Street's Latest Diversification Strategy: Down on the Farm
description: With opulent office towers desperate for tenants and several big-city developers choking on debt, some major investors are heading for the country. Wall Street is discovering the heartland, where reliable returns often flow from the open fields.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 9 about the Adirondacks misstated room rates for the Point resort on Upper Saranac Lake. The rates range from $525 to $675 for two people sharing a room, not $525 to $675 each.

title: Around the Dial, And Around The World
description: World beat is the most fashionable label of the moment in the American music business, attached to everything from concert series to record labels. This sudden passion for non-American music is a departure for an industry in which the word international used to signify one of three places - London, Sydney or Tokyo. Perhaps cross-cultural curiosity is the fallout of recent political events, or maybe global hip is simply this year's model. For whatever reason, the industry is tuning into the world, and this enthusiasm is energizing one of the most criticized and cliche-worn products of the business: music television.

title: Molly Merthan and Andrew Cornell Are Married
description: Mary Elizabeth Merthan and Andrew Hewlett Cornell were married yesterday at the Solebury, Pa., home of the bridegroom's mother , Mrs. Mortimer Ryon. The Rev. William H. Wood 3d, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Gracious Living From the Gilded Age
description: The first thing that needs to be said about the Grand Hotel, the sprawling monument to Greek Revival architecture that dominates a bluff on Mackinac Island, Mich., is that it is everything modern luxury hotels are not. Most modern hotels are of steel and glass and concrete; the Grand, one of America's great summer hotels, was built from whitewashed Michigan pine. Modern hotels have lobbies with soaring atriums and fountains; the Grand's lobby more resembles a sitting room in a private home. And while the trend today is to build hotels with extensive sports facilities, the Grand's offerings - a midsized swimming pool, a short nine-hole golf course and four clay tennis courts - are quite modest.

title: Marcel F. Grilli, 83, Music Critic in Japan
description: Marcel F. Grilli, an American music critic and prominent figure in cultural exchanges between Japan and the United States, died in Tokyo on Thursday. He was 83 years old.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Sept. 8

title: Beth Abrams To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald W. Abrams of Louisville, Ky., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter, Elizabeth Sue Abrams, and Robert Edward Mitchell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Mitchell of West Hartford, Conn.

title: Question Of the Week;   Have Elite Yacht Races Become Too Dangerous?
description: Competitive sailing - eight months of deprivation, strong winds, storms, high waves and icebergs - is perilous but not too dangerous. It is the classic competition of man against the elements. Completing the 27,000-mile race is a meaningful conquest and an understandable acceptance of risk. Every participant will be a winner.

title: No One Is Sure of Souter, So There's Hope of Harmony
description: Before David H. Souter's Supreme Court confirmation hearing began, when there was only the paper record and the bare biographical facts to go on, the New Hampshire country judge with the tumbledown house and the unmowed lawn looked like a throwback to an earlier age. So he proved to be, but not quite in the way that skeptics had predicted.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. What would you recommend to clean dirty aluminum siding? If cleaning results are unsatisfactory, can the siding be painted?

title: College Football: South;   Georgia Overcomes Alabama
description: John Kasay's 40-yard field goal with 1 minute 31 seconds remaining today lifted Georgia to a 17-16 victory over Alabama, extending the Crimson Tide's longest losing streak in 34 years to five games.

title: Pays Basque
description: To the Editor: The article on the Basque region of Spain was of particular interest to me. Last year you published a letter from a man who toured this area and wrote to report his enthusiasm. That letter prompted me to contact the tour company, Backroads International, and to take the July 20-Aug. 4 tour.

title: Suffolk May Ban Cigarette Machines
description: LEAD: THE Suffolk County Legislature is weighing a bill to ban people younger than 18 from buying cigarettes at vending machines.

title: BUSINESS DIARY/September 16-21
description: THE ECONOMY

title: DOCTOR, TALK TO ME
description: Reading Anatole Broyard's article ''Doctor, Talk to Me'' (Aug. 26), I wondered if my old pal knew that in his search for the perfect doctor he had become the perfect patient, the patient who understands himself. I envisioned 100,000 doctors reading the article along with me and then phoning colleagues to say they must read it, too - here was the wittiest statement they're ever likely to see of what the seriously ill patient thinks and wants. I thought, too, it might easily become a classic text in medical-school curriculums.

title: Barbara Lettieri Weds Alexander Matturri Jr.
description: Barbara A. Lettieri, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Lettieri of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday to Alexander J. Matturri Jr., the son of Judge and Mrs. Alexander J. Matturri of Allenhurst, N.J. Msgr. William P. Devine performed the ceremony at the St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Why the Body Is Disgusting
description: SIN AND FEAR

title: Correction
description: A photograph on the Headliners page last Sunday carried an incorrect caption. The photograph showed former President Ronald Reagan and Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, meeting in Gdansk, Poland.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   Recent Sales
description: Chester, Conn. $594,000

title: Mealtime, Dealtime
description: For as long as the world has known expense accounts, business and fine eating have gone together like bib and tucker. The tradition continues, despite a contagious obsession with fitness and despite the recession in several major industries. Granted, money managers in Boston prefer to take lunch at their desks and many old boys in various cities repair to their private clubs. But the status restaurant remains the primary locus for striking deals with meals. Most often, but not necessarily, the power meal is lunch.

title: Postings: 'Village' Waterfront;   Show and Tell
description: Gritty but richly historic, the Greenwich Village waterfront will be the subject of a month-long exhibition that opens Wednesday at the Urban Center gallery in the former Villard Houses, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street. The centerpiece of the show will be a 20-foot-long scale model of the waterfront, with photographs, portraits, paintings, maps and text on the walls.

title: The Conscience of the Campus
description: UNIVERSITIES AND THE FUTURE OF AMERICA

title: De Klerk Hopes to Show Bush the Change Is Real
description: A political cartoon earlier this year depicted President F. W. de Klerk as a solitary surfer precariously balanced on the crest of a breaking wave. Although his hobby is golf, not surfing, Mr. de Klerk was flattered, telling some subordinates that that was how he felt trying to navigate the dismantling of apartheid to a stable finish.

title: Soothing Sand And Adobe Of Mazatlan
description: From the air Mazatlan is an urban sprawl on the edge of a wide, green, coastal plain - dotted by isolated hills and bordered by the sea. Far to the east, the Sierra Madre range disappears into an almost constant cloud bank. To really get the feel of the place, though, come on the fast, overnight train from Nogales on the Arizona border. An hour or so before arrival in Mazatlan the train breaks out of a jungle of palms and banana trees onto a low cliff overlooking the sun-soaked Pacific. The tracks parallel the shore along miles of empty beaches, then the first big hotels flash past, and the train roars into town.

title: Trial and Tribulation
description: November 1986. I learn this morning that a colleague has died. Suicide, the newspaper reported. Although I never met him, my sadness at his passing is no less acute than had we been good friends, for George Laszlo and I endured the same misfortune, and nothing binds men together like shared pain. George F. Laszlo was a general practitioner in the town of Woodbury, L.I. He was 72 years old at the time his wife, Maritza, discovered his lifeless body in their house. It had been 48 years since he graduated from medical school in Budapest. Then came the war and the Hungarian Revolution. From 1960 until the day he killed himself, he practiced medicine on Long Island.

title: Draw!
description: AND DIE IN THE WEST

title: Wishbone Smothers Returning Coach
description: For the second time in four seasons, a former Army offensive coordinator returned to West Point and was haunted by the wishbone offense he helped implement under the Cadets' head coach, Jim Young.

title: Sports of the Times;   Lockout Legacy: N.L. Playoff Mix-Up
description: As the pennant races streak and stumble to their conclusion, the baseball labor lockout that delayed opening day a week in April is all but forgotten. But the legacy of that lockout soon will be as conspicuous as it will be controversial: squeezing and stretching the National League Championship Series.

title: Carol O'Rourke Is Married
description: Carol Ann O'Rourke, a daughter of Domenic S. Gautieri of Warwick, R.I., and Lucy M. Gautieri of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Bruce Alan Colbath, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl M. Colbath of Piscataway, N.J. The Rev. Fred Schultz officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in East Hampton, L.I. The bride is a vice president of marketing for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York. Her first marriage ended in divorce, as did the bridegroom's. Mr. Colbath is an associate at the law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges in New York.

description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance;   Javanese Cultural Riches Revealed
description: Two forms of Indonesian dance, Bedhaya and Golek Menak, were featured on Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the second program offered as part of the series called ''Court Art of Java From the Kraton of Jogjakarta.'' Both were quite different. And neither resembled Wayang Wong, the dance form that had been presented on the opening night of this series by dancers and musicians from the palace (kraton) of Jogjakarta. As a result, the performance was a revelation.

title: College Football: Local Colleges;   Wagner Is Beaten
description: Greg Harris scored two touchdowns in eight minutes of the third quarter yesterday as Wagner registered 16 consecutive points to defeat previously undefeated Montclair State, 22-13, at Irvington, N.J.

title: Melissa Zelen to Marry David Neier
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Zelen of Princeton, N.J., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter Melissa Zelen and David Neier, the son of Mrs. and Mrs. Aryeh Neier of New York.

title: Redistribute the Burden for the Bailout
description: Asking ordinary taxpayers to cover the costs of a financial debacle they neither caused nor benefited from was bad enough. But now, the Resolution Trust Corporation - the agency set up by the Government to dispose of the assets of the failed savings and loan institutions - is compounding the misery. It is lavishing the taxpayers' money on wealthy depositors and awarding sweetheart deals to buyers of the insolvent savings and loan institutions and their foreclosed assets.

title: Mealtime, Dealtime
description: For as long as the world has known expense accounts, business and fine eating have gone together like bib and tucker. The tradition continues, despite a contagious obsession with fitness and despite the recession in several major industries. Granted, money managers in Boston prefer to take lunch at their desks and many old boys in various cities repair to their private clubs. But the status restaurant remains the primary locus for striking deals with meals. Most often, but not necessarily, the power meal is lunch.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: CITIES and the people who live in them did not find much to cheer about in the preliminary figures released recently by the United States Bureau of the Census. Around the nation, New York, Chicago, Philadelphia and nearly every other big city lost a lot of their population. Detroit fell below a million, about half what it was in the 1950's.

title: Eagerness Pays Off for Jets' Nichols
description: When Gerald Nichols was a seventh-round draft choice out of Florida State in the strike-shortened 1987 National Football League season, he started 5 of the 13 games he played in for the Jets. But his starts went down from there, two in 1988 and none in 1989, although he played in all 16 games each of those seasons.

title: An Illness Is Giving Up Its Secrets
description: LEAD: APART from the scattered but persistent coughing and slightly quickened breathing, the cystic fibrosis patients asking Dr. Jack Gorvoy about new treatments seemed healthy. Seated at a long table in a hospital conference room, they focused on technical advances like new drugs and lung transplants that may improve their lives and extend the median life span of cystic fibrosis patients beyond 30.

title: Sports of the Times;   'Young Kid' Gets A Red Sox Tryout
description: ''Who?'' Mike Greenwell asked in the middle of a crowded clubhouse. ''You mean the young kid who pitched a few weeks ago?''

title: Tending to the Poets
description: A few university presses have long traditions of publishing poetry. But in the last couple of decades the number of those issuing new work by poets, and translations of poetry from other languages, has grown rapidly. University presses are now among the foremost publishers of poetry in this country. Here is a small sampling from many scores of volumes issued in the past year:

title: Wall Street;   Playing the Bankruptcy 'Endgame'
description: Some people love inefficient markets, those murky bazaars where most investors have no idea what a particular security is worth and where their uncertainty produces vast differences between what buyers will pay and what sellers will demand. Back in the barbaric 80's, the people who called themselves risk arbitragers made money trading in takeover stocks, hoping to have guessed correctly (or, in a few unseemly cases, to have been accurately informed) about how the deals would turn out.

title: Review/Theater;   Biblical Tale as a Parable of Marriage
description: Before there was Eve there was Lilith. In his new play, ''Lilith'' (at the Home for Contemporary Theater and Art), Allan Havis has placed Adam's legendary first wife at the center of a parable about marriage. Springing Lilith loose in our age, the play is as devious as it is diabolical.

title: SELLING SOFTWARE THE HARD WAY
description: The announcement carried by both the Dow Jones and Reuters wires shortly after 8 o'clock on Thursday morning, July 12, was mysteriously brief. ''Based on analysis of preliminary numbers. . .'' the company statement read in part, ''it appears that revenues will be significantly less than the revenues of last year's comparable quarter and, consequently, earnings may also be lower.'' No further explanation was offered.

title: DOCTOR, TALK TO ME
description: Broyard is not asking for the impossible. He is asking only that his doctor recognize that his illness is not something apart from the person. In short, he is asking his doctor to take a moment to help him find ways to cope with his situation - to provide information, to encourage him to ask questions. It requires spending time. Even doctors who are not good conversationalists should be able to recognize this crucial part of medical practice

title: Tracey Roberts to Wed Paul Haigney
description: The engagement of Tracey Elizabeth Roberts to Paul Joseph Sean Haigney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Haigney of Larchmont, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Joanne Van Wart Roberts of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and John A. Roberts Jr. of New York. A November wedding is planned.

description: CLASSICAL

title: Correction
description: A caption with the Stamps column on Sept. 9 about an auction of rare philatelic items misidentified the illustration. It showed an artist's model for a proposed commemoration of the centennial of the birth of the Canadian statesman Sir George Etienne Cartier. It was not a stamp, and it did not commemorate the French explorer Jacques Cartier.

title: Baseball;   Yankees Defeat Red Sox
description: Two teams with opposite aims spent what seemed like a week at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

title: Small Towns Have Big Problems, Too
description: CHARLES J. DUFFY is the executive director of the Council of Small Towns, an organization formed in the late 1970's to lobby for the interests of rural and suburban municipalities in Connecticut.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Mel Torme Reminisces
description: Mel Torme's show at Michael's Pub on Sept. 12 had good intentions. Mr. Torme, who plays the club every year, varies his programs; this year for his engagement (through Oct. 6), he has decided to celebrate the memory of the band leader and drummer Buddy Rich by taking a big band with him to play selections he recorded with Mr. Rich, among others.

title: After >Loss at Polls, Young Savors Role in Winning the Games
description: About a year and a half ago, when he was still Mayor of Atlanta and considering an attempt to be Georgia's first black Governor, Andrew Young sat in his office and sketched out for a visitor a script of his reaching for a political brass ring and the city's quest for the 1996 Summer Olympics.

description: RIVER OF TRAPS

title: New Tack in Assault on Yosemite Commercialism
description: One hundred years after its founding, this spectacular natural landmark in the Sierras has become the battleground in the environmentalists' war to scale back commercial activities in the nation's parks.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
Northeast Notebook: Pittsburgh;

Canadians Buy 60% of Project
description: LEAD: A financing commitment has been received by the developers of Treesdale, a residential-recreational-commercial complex to be built about 20 miles north of this city's downtown in Pine and Adams Townships.

title: Peru Rebels Kill Ex-Minister And Son in Ambush in Lima
description: Leftist rebels killed a former Labor Minister and one of his sons today and then blew up their bodies with a stick of dynamite, the police said.

title: Cambodian Refugees Think of Home With Hope and Dread
description: Cambodia may be sliding toward peace, but the prospect is more than a little daunting to the thousands of Cambodians who have spent the last 11 years in refugee camps like this one along the Thai-Cambodian border.

CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Of Men and Their Mowing Machines
description: LEAD: MY husband, Cliff, and our neighbor, Ron, are enemies. The problem is Ron does not know that he is the enemy.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sarah Burchfield Wed in Princeton
description: Sarah Elizabeth Burchfield, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Burchfield of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to John Gibson Carey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Carey 3d of Morristown, N.J., and Throckmorton, Tex. The Rev. Patrick Connor performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the chapel of St. Joseph's Seminary.

title: Group of Seven Presses to Keep Interest Rates Up
description: Economic policy makers from the United States and its main industrial allies agreed today that the best response to the oil-price shock would be to keep a lid on inflation and refrain from making hasty interest-rate cuts.

title: BRITAIN'S IRREPRESSIBLE PUBLIC MAN
description: THE TIME OF MY LIFE

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: When nothing seems to be happening, keep your eye on the bishops - with their great range, a move that appears to be merely a minor adjustment can be cataclysmic.

title: A Treasure Trove Just Keeps Growing
description: WANT to peruse 1969 issues of The Berkeley Barb? Need to study 19th-century Puerto Rican documents or an 18th-century work on Chinese insects? Perhaps you are interested in the notes of the naturalist Edwin Way Teale or the sketches of the children's book illustrator Richard Scarry.

title: Racial Slur by Japanese Aide Rekindles Anger
description: A new Japanese Cabinet minister has compared prostitutes in Japan to black Americans who move into white neighborhoods and ''ruin the atmosphere.''

title: Special Today:
description: Business World/Magazine Part 2

title: Question Of the Week;   Have Elite Yacht Races Become Too Dangerous?
description: The basic challenge of man against the sea is much as it has always been. The risks have always been known. I have tremendous respect for all who dare to challenge oceans, but I don't know what new dangers one need fear.

title: Horse Racing;   Quick Mischief Wins Ruffian
description: Quick Mischief, the fastest filly in the field but an unknown quantity at the distance, benefited from a sloppy track and the absence of Gorgeous to score a three-length victory yesterday in the $240,800 Ruffian Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: Planes Seized in Drug Inquiry
description: Federal agents have seized four DC-3 cargo planes here, saying they were bound for duty with a Colombian drug operation. United States Attorney John E. Fryatt said the planes were seized Thursday as part of an investigation of purchases of aircraft by the Medellin drug cartel. Pilots with Air Colombia of Bogota, which had bought the planes, arrived in Oshkosh to take them to Colombia, said J. E. Snyder, an agent of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration in Milwaukee. The pilots were questioned and released, he said.

title: At 100, Carnegie Is Still the Place to Get To
description: As Carnegie Hall prepares to open its centennial season Wednesday night, there may be no better moment to toast not only the health of the dowager queen of American concert halls but the durable values she typifies. Carnegie was designed according to an ancient and honorable esthetic that increasingly shows signs of returning to fashion: it is primarily a place to listen to specific kinds of music (classical is the inexact but useful word) in a civilized atmosphere. By design and in practice a hall best suited for symphony orchestras, it survives and thrives as a rebuke to the all-purpose auditoriums that sprang up all across America a generation ago and that still disfigure the musical landscape.

title: Wall Street;   In Hard Times, Stay the Course in Equities
description: There is a substantial penalty for ill-timed panic in the stock market, warns Mark Stumpp, the director of research for PDI Strategies, a unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

title: The Fine Art of Lending Art
description: LEAD: FOR the next three months, there will be an empty space on a wall in the atrium where Adele and Herbert J. Klapper usually display the art in their South Shore Nassau home.

title: Small Fortunes Vanishing in Kuwait
description: In the cool of the nearly completed three-story concrete house that has been paid for with money earned in 27 years of teaching in Kuwait, Mohammed Hassan Abdul Baki was still exhausted from his six-day drive across the desert to escape and the sunstroke he experienced at the crowded Jordanian border post.

title: Tbilisi Theater Troupe Plans American Debut
description: The Shakespeare Theater at the Folger here is to present the Film Actors' Studio Theater of Tbilisi, U.S.S.R., in its North American premiere this fall. The Georgian troupe will perform Moliere's ''Don Juan'' and ''Bakula's Pig,'' a traditional Georgian story.

title: Elizabeth Cahill, A Banker, Weds
description: Elizabeth Ann Cahill was married yesterday to David Stanley Ruksznis at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. George Almeda officiated. Mrs. Ruksznis, 31 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Cahill of Vero Beach, Fla. A graduate of Wheaton College, she is an associate at the Bank of Boston. Her father, a management consultant, retired as a marketing vice president of the Xerox Corporation in Stamford, Conn.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   An 18th-Century Estate Along the East River
description: The Abigail Adams Smith Museum, 421 East 61st Street in Manhattan, has virtually no relation to its name. It does not commemorate the life of the daughter of President John Adams, nor is it a museum about the colonial era. Truth be told, Mrs. Smith never lived there.

title: MINING THE SILVER LININGS
description: NOTHING SUCCEEDS LIKE failure - at least in the case of the Failure Group, an accident-investigation and -prevention company based in Menlo Park, Calif. On Aug. 17, just as a bear market was accelerating amid growing concern about Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, the company went public. ''A fitting day for the Failure Group,'' says Roger L. McCarthy, the company's chairman. Shares were offered at $13 and climbed as high as 16 1/4 in one week.

title: Drivers
description: To the Editor: I read with interest the article about driving in Portugal. I believe that the cavalier attitude of Portuguese drivers owes much to that country's love of bull fighting. The adrenalin rush after avoiding an oncoming truck while passing on a curve is likely similar to what a forcado gets while attempting to catch a rushing bull by its horns.

title: Penn Station Users Deserve Clean Station
description: How I would love to talk to Russell Olwell [''At Penn Station, Commuters See the Ugly Truth,'' Sept. 9] 10 years down the line. Perhaps by then he will be working for a living and paying taxes and will look at the beggars in Penn Station in a different light. Perhaps by then he will have come to realize that we get what we work for, and work we must, and that those who use Penn Station and pay the high price of riding the L.I.R.R. deserve at the very least a clean and unthreatening station. Perhaps by then he will not be ''uncomfortable'' or criticize the police for doing their job, but will wonder why the young man in the men's room did not get a job instead of using a ''comedy routine'' to beg. Indeed, the lesson he did learn was ''superficial'' - the lesson he has yet to learn is to grow up and face reality.

title: Bad Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbia Offers Laurels to a Band of Poets
description: Columbia University last week held a dinner to honor 18 poets, all graduates or faculty members of the university, in an effort to increase recognition of their work and their ties to Columbia.

title: As Child-Care Challenges Grow, a Plea to Loving Families
description: LEAD: WITH a surge in the need for foster care in the last two years -some experts say it has doubled - local agencies are struggling to help children affected by crack addiction and AIDS, as well as by what many see as an increase in physical and sexual abuse.

title: Two Passionate Collectors Share Their Love of History
description: When Leon Levy and Shelby White began bidding for antiquities at a New York auction in 1975, they were in awe of them. ''Realizing it was possible to own an ancient bust came as a shock,'' said Mr. Levy, a New York financier. ''I could raise my hand and in minutes own something that was 2,000 years old.''

title: Rugby's Thrill: Mud and Bruises For Gentlemen
description: HIS freckled skin flushed under the late summer sun, Vinny Ryan of Limerick, Ireland, shouted encouragement to his team. ''Fine kick, McRoyne! Luvly ball, Paddy!''

title: Muslims Patrol Hempstead Project
description: LIKENING themselves to Wild West posses, groups of frustrated residents in crime-ridden housing projects are turning to private patrols for protection.

title: Mr. Entertainment Is Still Playing Vegas
description: So many rhinestones, so little time. That is the burden of the visitor who steps from the dazzling Las Vegas sun into the equally dazzling spaces of the Liberace Museum in the Liberace Shopping Plaza on Tropicana Avenue and Spencer Street.

title: PREGNANT, ADDICTED - AND GUILTY?
description: Treatment facilities are available to only 4 percent of the nation's addicts and most programs exclude pregnant women like Lynn Bremer and Kim Hardy. Thousands of addicted mothers-to-be are turned away from help and turned in for prosecution under statutes prohibiting child abuse, drug distribution to minors and involuntary manslaughter. Driven underground for fear that their newborns will be placed in foster homes, they may forgo even the minimal prenatal care available and often give birth to their babies at home.

title: CD's Cut Down to Size
description: Not all good things come in small enough packages. By now even the casual CD purchaser must suspect what collectors have long known, that for all of the wondrous compactness made possible by digital audio technology, the standard hard-plastic container may be the most cumbersome and unlovable packaging since turn-of-the-century bathing suits. Still, many have hesitated to adopt the radical solution Will Crutchfield outlined in these pages three years ago, jettisoning the ''jewel boxes'' and storing the disks between pages of the accompanying booklets in cardboard filing drawers.

title: New Mexico Restoring Its Old Adobe Churches
description: With each winter, more historic adobe churches built by Hispanic settlers 100 or even 200 years ago begin to crumble.

title: With the Mostest
description: Just let Saddam Hussein try to check into a Helmsley hotel. Overcome with indignation, Leona Helmsley last week let fly at the Iraqi president in a full page ad in The New York Times, scolding him for holding people against their will while referring to them as guests. ''I know something about how to treat guests,'' the Helmsley Hotels president assured Mr. Hussein. ''The people held in your grasp are not guests. They are hostages.'' Mrs. Helmsley told a Newsday reporter that the ad was a show of ''patriotism.'' She also ordered the top of the Empire State Building lit in red, white and blue each night ''until all our boys come home.''

title: Schooling at Home: Parents and Officials Clash Over Control
description: WHEN people ask them about being educated at home by their parents, Michelle Addorisio and Samantha Hough say, they usually have to straighten out a few misconceptions. ''First I tell them that yes, we do have a social life, and yes, it is legal,'' said Miss Hough, 15 years old, whose home in Clinton also serves as a classroom for her four younger siblings.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: JAMES F. BISHOP;

Matching an Executive to a Company
description: LEAD: IN 1965, James F. Bishop was in his native Chicago, working as a civilian special agent with the Defense Department's Office of Naval Intelligence. He got a phone call from Burke & O'Brien Associates, a New York-based executive search consulting firm, asking if he would be interested in joining it.

LONG ISLAND SOUND;

You're Only An Only Child One Time

When we played ''Monopoly,'' if he landed on ''Boardwalk'' and I owned ''Park Place,'' he would deliberately not buy it so that I could.

WESTCHESTER Q&A;: FRANCIS T. DONOHUE;

Juggling a Civilian Job and the Reserves

title: Plan to Curb Lampreys in Vermont to Begin
description: A program to control sea lampreys in Lake Champlain with chemicals will begin Sunday as scheduled, a Federal district judge here ruled today.

title: Pony Up $95 Million? Sure, for a Baseball Team
description: Judging by the numbers, winning one of the two National League baseball expansion franchises that will start playing in 1993 would not seem terribly attractive. The league is demanding an entrance fee of $95 million from each new team, up dramatically from the $7 million the American League charged for franchises in Seattle and Toronto during baseball's last expansion in 1977. The additional start-up costs will run at least another $25 million. It will be years before the new teams turn an operating profit.

title: In the Democracy Of Nicaragua, Control Control Is Still From the Top
