title: More Scanner Buffs Eavesdropping on New York's Troubles
description: Since Joe Braganza began listening to a police-band radio in his free time, he has wondered what moves his fellow New Yorkers to commit the acts of brutality that he hears police officers describe every night.

title: Landmarks of Kuala Lumpur
description: For hundreds of years Malaysia, the southernmost tip of mainland Asia, was an important crossroads for the great civilizations of China and India. A quirk of geography - the country's strategic position just north of the Equator, between the Indian Ocean and the South China Sea - made it a historic meeting place for traders and travelers from West and East.

title: Tender Outrage and Tough Sympathy
description: STORIES BY CONTEMPORARY IRISH WOMEN. Edited by Daniel J. Casey and Linda M. Casey. (Syracuse University, Cloth, $32.95; Paper, $14.95.) ''Are there Irish women writers the like of Yeats and Joyce? Is there a developing feminist tradition in Ireland worthy of serious critical attention?'' Such interesting questions, posed by Daniel J. Casey and Linda M. Casey in their introduction to ''Stories by Contemporary Irish Women,'' cannot be answered by these 17 works alone. But the Caseys' impressive collection makes a sterling case for the need to include several female writers in the highest echelon of Irish fiction. Edna O'Brien's story ''A Scandalous Woman,'' set in County Clare and deeply rooted in conventional Irish values, is a masterpiece of ironic fiction. In it, the narrator poignantly tells the story of a beautiful childhood friend who loses her spunk and sanity after a forced marriage to a man who impregnated her during an adventuresome girlhood dalliance. Equally eloquent is Mary Lavin's ''Lilacs,'' which explores the conflicts of a traditional Irish family that prospers by - but agonizes over - selling manure for a living. In addition to such established writers, the Caseys include several new voices of distinction. Ita Daly's ''Aimez-Vous Colette?'' is an achingly sad story told by a fusty spinster, a romantic soul at heart, who has sacrificed the love of a good man to save her silly pride. In ''Five Notes After a Visit,'' Anne Devlin, a writer born in Northern Ireland, pitches her lovers - one Roman Catholic, the other Protestant - from their exile in London into their native Belfast, where political tensions and outright threats fray the couple's nerves and finally unravel their reunion. The Troubles are evoked even more explicitly in Maura Treacy's story ''A Minor Incident,'' a horrifying account of senseless violence in the North. Not surprisingly, there's a sorrowful tone to this entire collection, born of these writers' tender outrage and tough sympathy for their haunted homeland and its inhabitants. As Ms. O'Brien expresses it, ''Ours indeed was a land of shame, a land of murder and a land of strange sacrificial women.''

Even in Success, Foster Care Involves a 'Continuum of Loss'

''It takes a special woman to have 67 children in five years,'' proclaims another. And, ''Foster kids are tough to take, but they're even tougher to give up.

As a result, a model network that was to have been a showcase for Networld's 30,000 visitors was partly knocked out.

Mahwah Journal;

All I knew was that this damp and shady place was where my aunt lived somewhere in the state of New York, a place as different and distant from the known world of west Texas as I could possibly imagine.

Occupying a Home As It Awaits a Buyer

Cracking the Tax Whip on C.E.O.'s

For some, that means peeking over their shoulders more frequently to see if their jobs are secure. The disposable diaper, which during the 1970's and 80's became as indispensable to working parents as ''Sesame Street'' and strained carrots, is suddenly the environmental bad boy of the 90's. With the resurgence of the ecology movement and the attendant rise of environmentally correct ''green'' consumer products, change-and-chuck diapers are under attack by a loose confederation of ecologists, politicians and health-care advocates.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES/IN SHORT: FICTION
description: EVA THE FUGITIVE. By Rosamel del Valle. Translated by Anna Balakian. (University of California, Cloth, $22.50; Paper, $7.95) Written in 1930 and first published posthumously in 1970, this Chilean novel is a fascinating early example of the effects of Surrealism on Latin American letters. ''Eva the Fugitive'' followed Andre Breton's ''Nadja'' by only two years, and in the delirious, multidirectional prose of Rosamel del Valle's novel there are clear echoes of Breton's artistic revolution-in-progress, a feverishly lyrical determinedly antiliterary expedition into the darkness of unreason and dream. Like Breton's title character, Eva is mad, and she more than fits Breton's definition of beauty (it must be ''convulsive''); she exercises a powerful erotic fascination on the narrator, not least because she shares her own doubts about whether she exists anywhere except in fantasy. As they walk together through a Santiago amusement park, fragments of overheard conversations season the narrative with a hint of everyday realities in which Eva's hallucinatory existence must be contained. Yet she is not truly of this world. ''Eva's freedom,'' we are told,''maintains no connection with any other.'' Constantly associated with oneiric images of blood and water, desperate Eva eventually comes to embody the narrator's own despair, which is said to resemble ''a forest peopled with everything except life.'' It may seem idle, at this remove in time, to complain of life, yet it may be that Eva is too exquisitely fey to be convincing. Anna Balakian, the eloquent translator of this whirling prose, points out in her introduction that in its flight from common sense, Surrealist narrative often defaults to standard Gothic structures of phantasms and demonic possession. Rosamel del Valle's Eva, with her edenic name and fatal madness, is perhaps only a familiar dislocation of the Eternal Feminine, another link between the Surrealists and their excitable Romantic forbears.

title: Anne H. Rodgers and Daniel P. Rice Are Married
description: Anne Helen Rodgers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Rodgers of New York, was married yesterday to Daniel Phillips Rice, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Rice of New Orleans. Msgr. George Bardes officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Miss Ritter Weds Michael Aylward
description: Deborah Bradford Ritter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Underwood Ritter of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married there yesterday to Michael Fayerweather Aylward, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Aylward of New Lebanon, N.Y. The Rev. Stephen J. White officiated at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: Stop Grandstanding And Use Shoreham
description: How many oil shocks do we need to realize that our reliance on this finite energy source is faulty? Nor is it in our interest to rely on a supply of natural gas from Canada. Of course, we could annex Canada as Saddam Hussein has annexed Kuwait but that would not be nice.

title: At I.B.M., a Long Tradition in Training
description: DAVID GUEST, a senior lecturer in industrial relations in the London School of Economics, has long studied International Business Machines from afar. He recently found that the vast computer maker looks different from inside.

title: Question Of the Week;   Have Elite Yacht Races Become Too Dangerous?
description: Suppose elite yacht races have suddenly become a woefully perilous undertaking. Who cares? If Marie Antoinette had complained that because of the sudden loss of her head, she could no longer smell the flowers in her pretend-milkmaid's garden, what do you think the citoyens would have said?

title:
FILM;

Richard Sylbert Works His Magic by Design
description: LEAD: There couldn't be much common ground among the worlds of Dick Tracy, Sherman McCoy, J. J. Gittis and the American Communist John Reed. In fact, the sole exception might well be that the cinematic environments of the central figures of ''Dick Tracy,'' ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' ''Chinatown'' and ''Reds'' were created by the Oscar-winning production designer Richard

title:
Northeast Notebook: Washington;

13-Story Tower Rising on Spec
description: LEAD: One of the few speculative office construction projects expected to start in the nation's capital this year is moving forward as a French-Japanese venture.

title: Mutual Funds;   Cleaning Up on the Ground Floor
description: If Donna Dempsey Calder were to crack open a Chinese fortune cookie, the message would probably read, ''Get in on the ground floor.'' That's how she managed her career, and how, as manager of the $55 million Oppenheimer Discovery Fund, she picks her stocks.

title: About Long Island;   A Teacher With AIDS Returns to School
description: THE first day of school, the 46-year-old heart of Thomas J. Bradley beat as fast as a kindergartener's waiting at the school-bus stop with a camera-toting parent.

title: Tina Dee Eberle Is Married
description: Tina Dee Eberle, an actress, and Marc Alan Salonsky, the executive chef of the Petrossian Paris Restaurant in New York, were married yesterday at Studio 25 in Manhattan. Rabbi Joel Goor officiated. The bride, a graduate of Missouri Southern State College and the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, is the granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Eberle of Joplin, Mo. Mr. Salonsky, a graduate of the Verenne cooking school in Paris, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Chestney of New York.

title: Tamera Colletti Is Married
description: Tamera Ann Colletti and Kevin John Leichter were married yesterday at All Souls Unitarian Church in New York by the Rev. Frank Hall. Mrs. Leichter is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Colletti of Westport, Conn. The bridegroom is a son of Susan L. Leichter of Westhampton Beach, L.I., and Dr. Stuart Leichter of New York. The bride, a graduate of Skidmore College, is an account management executive at Widmann & Company, an advertising and promotions concern in New York. The bridegroom, a law clerk at the United States District Court for the District of Maine in Bangor, is a Skidmore graduate with a master's in anthropology from Columbia University and a law degree from Boston University.

title: 8 Arrested in Boycott of Brooklyn Store
description: One day after Mayor David N. Dinkins called for a peaceful resolution of the eight-month boycott of two Korean-owned stores in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, scores of shoppers returned to the stores, but eight protesters were arrested for violating the court order that mandated they stay at least 50 feet from them.

title: Campus Life: Yale;   Course in Korean Draws 80 Students On Its First Day
description: After eight years of student lobbying, Yale College has begun offering a course in Korean language study, and the response has been overwhelming.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

I Like My Caterer and I Don't Feel Guilty
description: LEAD: PEOPLE who are philosophically oriented usually have questions that they continuously try to answer. Generally these questions are never answered to their satisfaction. Yet, they spend a great deal of time in a state of perpetual conflict because their inquisitive minds are unable to rest without definitive answers.

title: No End of Lessons on Iraq
description: Two enormous miscalculations lie at the root of the Persian Gulf crisis. The most glaring was Saddam Hussein's rash assumption that the world would do little or nothing if Iraq devoured Kuwait. But his dirty deed owed something to the world's limp response to Iraq's previous use of poison gas, its grim human rights record and its voracious appetite for mass-killing weaponry.

title: Orchestrating The Birthday Bash
description: In planning the Carnegie Hall centennial, those organizing the season-long celebration found themselves practicing a peculiar brand of musical politics, emphasizing international and historical sweep yet keeping the event very American and very up-to-date. Page 25.

title: No Ands and Buts, But Plenty of Ifs
description: IF MR. MARKHAM had not found the second page of a love letter, if Mrs. Markham had not been so accommodating, if Alistair, the interior decorator, had not taught Sylvie, the maid, all about geese - if there had not been all these ifs - there would not be a ''Move Over Mrs. Markham.''

title: Margot Huber Weds Russell Heckler
description: Margot Morehouse Huber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce B. Huber of Locust, N.J., was married yesterday in Navesink, N.J., to Russell Stine Heckler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard E. Heckler of Hatfield, Pa. The Rev. Harry R. Sorensen officiated at All Saints' Memorial Episcopal Church in the Highlands of Navesink. Mrs. Heckler is an associate editor at Sports Illustrated in New York. She is a graduate of the Taft School and the University of Vermont with a master's degree in sports administration from Teachers College at Columbia University. Her father is the president of Huber-Hogan Associates, financial and insurance consultants in Red Bank, N.J. Her mother, Marti Huber, is a broker with Weichert Realtors in Rumson, N.J.

title: Diane Jean-George Marries
description: Diane Jean-George and Demetrios Condeelis were married yesterday at Christ United Methodist Church in New York by the Rev. Stephen P. Bauman. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar George of Wilmington, Del. She graduated from John Jay College and is an actress. The bridegroom is a son of Adalais Condeelis of New York and the late Athanasios Condeelis. A graduate of George Washington University, he is a clerk in the legal records department of the New York law firm of Chadbourne & Parke. His two previous marriages ended in divorce.

title: Controlling Litigation Costs with a Neutral Third Party
description: On the wall of his Hartford law office, William Champlin keeps a chart that faintly resembles a giant scorecard. The ''players'' are more than 100 companies, manufacturers of products ranging from elevators to floor wax. They are also defendants in a lawsuit growing out of a devastating 1986 fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan, P.R., and the chart allocates their contributions to a hypothetical settlement.

title: Philippine Talks on U.S. Bases End Without Pact
description: Talks on the American military bases in the Philippines concluded Friday, with no agreement by the two countries on the terms of a reduced American military presence on two large bases.

title:
RECORDINGS;
The Art of Transcription Sheds New Light on Old Work
description: Mahler's richly colored orchestration is so much a part of ''Das Lied von der Erde,'' that tampering with it would seem a sacrilege. Yet Mahler himself left a piano-voice version of the score, as he did for many of his other vocal works with orchestral settings.

title: Yale Research on Genetic Testing Supports Use of DNA Fingerprints
description: A new study of the genetic tests used to identify criminal suspects has found no basis for concern that the same DNA pattern is much more likely to turn up twice among members of the same ethnic group.

title: Martin White Wed To Phoebe Zerwick
description: Phoebe Zerwick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. B. Zerwick of New York, was married yesterday at her family's summer home in Hudson, N.Y., to Martin Brent White, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack White of Winston-Salem, N.C. Acting Justice Shirley Fingerhood of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Lemieux's Status
description: He has has not seen action in any of the Pittsburgh Penguins' exhibition games this month and he is continuing to have back spasms, so the word now is that Mario Lemieux could miss the team's opener on Oct. 5.

title: Rivoli
description: To the Editor: It puzzles me that neither Olivier Bernier's extensive article on the Baroque splendors of Turin nor the Piedmont essay by Beth Archer Brombert (Travel, July 29) mentions the Castello di Rivoli, that superb edifice in Turin's suburb, ''the 18th-century dream of a Piedmontese Versailles.''

title: At the News, Both Sides Prepare for a Seige
description: With resolution last week of the most recent face-off between The New York Post and its unions, attention has returned to a struggle that will influence the city's newspaper landscape for years to come: the labor battle at The Daily News.

title: Broad Oil Spill Law Is Signed in California
description: Gov. George Deukmejian signed a sweeping oil spill bill today that taxes oil 25 cents a barrel, creates an official with broad powers to oversee oil safety and regulates tankers in California waters.

title: Tribal Labels
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater;   'My Father, My Son,' Homage to a Family Relationship
description: Filial affection and devotion may be admirable qualities, but they are not in themselves ingredients that make engaging theater.

title: Lisa Bradley Weds
description: Lisa June Bradley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Bradley of Milltown, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Patrick Robertson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Robertson of Parlin, N.J. The Rev. David Beckerdite performed the ceremony at St. Paul's United Church of Christ in Milltown. The bride is a clinical dietitian at the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. Her husband is a computer operations analyst at the Home Life Insurance Company in Piscataway, N.J.

title: Anne K. Albright, Lawyer, to Wed
description: The engagement of Anne Korbel Albright to Geoffrey Roland Watson, a son of Elizabeth Robinson Watson of New York and Vals-les-Bains, France, and Edward J. Watson of Bar Harbor, Me., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Madeleine Korbel Albright and Joseph Medill Patterson Albright, both of Washington. A November wedding is planned.

title: Beverly Y. Lindh to Marry in January
description: Beverly Yost Lindh, an assistant treasurer of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and David John Little, a senior associate at Barclay's Bank, both in New York, plan to marry in January. Miss Lindh is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David E. P. Lindh of Dallas. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. John R. Little of New York.

title: AIDS Exhibition Pleads Its Case
description: UNVEILED at the Paris Salon of 1819, Theodore Gericault's ''Raft of the Medusa'' was met with mixed reactions, and though it attracted thousands of spectators, the picture brought the artist neither critical nor financial success. He died five years later, at the age of 33, having been wracked alternately with despair and the desire to produce still more ambitious works. It is said that on at least one occasion he dismissed the 18-by-24-foot canvas (now in the Louvre) with: ''Bah! A vignette!''

title: Question Of the Week;   Have Elite Yacht Races Become Too Dangerous?
description: There are dangers in many sports and activities in which men and women strive to excel. Sailing competitively around the world is risky but not too dangerous. Climbing the world's highest mountains is not too dangerous because the achievement is meaningful and civilized. Boxing is too dangerous, because its real object is violence and the achievement is meaningless and uncivilized. That is the difference between dangerous and too dangerous.

title: Rhine Gold Weaves a Spell at the Metropolitan
description: When the Metropolitan Opera opens its 108th year tomorrow night, the ''great golden curtains,'' as the opera announcer Milton Cross used to describe them to radio audiences, will be new. For many spectators the opera curtain becomes an object of focus only at the moment it rises on an imaginary world. But this particular curtain, for all its silky fresh radiance, already possesses its own history, first as the culmination of an architectural form that originated at the Festspielhaus in Bayreuth in 1876 and also as an object crafted by traditional means both in New York and, not inappropriately, in the Rhine Valley.

title: GOD SPEAKS THROUGH HIS WOMEN
description: THE BOOK OF J

title: From Mythology, Welded Metal Masks
description: DEITIES from ancient European and Asian mythologies, regenerated as contemporary welded metal masks, are among the images on exhibit in ''Icons and Archetypes'' at Nardin Fine Arts here. Suzanne Benton, an internationally known, award-winning artist, also is represented by a group of free-standing floor sculptures and a series of monoprints.

title: Correction
description: A Posting on Sept. 16 about the Day School on the Upper East Side misidentified the architectural firm that is designing the school's expansion into a town house on 89th Street. It is Paul Segal Associates of Manhattan. Arthur C. Jackson designed the town house in 1913.

title: As Problems Fester, Voters Send Pink Slips
description: In growing numbers, Americans say they are fed up with politicians. They look around and see schools that don't teach, streets that aren't safe, doctors they can't afford. Then they look to Washington, or Sacramento or Albany or City Hall, and they see bickering and feuding and deadlock.

title: Social Events
description: A Shipboard Party

title: And Now, Can Bob Crandall Have It All?
description: His lean, wiry body encased in camouflage fatigues, a bandanna around his forehead and a toy plastic rifle in hand, Robert L. Crandall burst onto the huge video screen. In his film debut at the 1987 meeting in Fort Worth, the American Airlines chief appeared as Crando, the terror of the competition, the unstoppable killing machine of the airline wars.

title: In the Region: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Farmingdale $145,500

title: NEW YORK WANTS CLEANEST AIR ACT
description: New York City officials, faced with continuing violations of Federal smog and carbon monoxide standards, are pressing for adoption of the strongest anti-pollution measures Congress is considering as it tries to agree on amendments to the Clean Air Act.

title: Technology;   Making a Model, And Doing It Fast
description: Over the past two years, design engineers who have created the specifications for complicated parts on their computer screens have begun to use lasers to build plastic models of those parts in just a few hours. Scores of companies have used such prototypes to get a quick read on how the new designs will function, whether they can be manufactured efficiently, and whether consumers like them.

title: The Case - and Verdict - Against Judge Souter
description: LEAD: Judge David H. Souter has put the country in an untenable position. He is asking the American people to support his nomination to the Supreme Court without assurances that he will protect our rights once on that court. What's at stake is not mere theoretical principle. The lives, health and livelihoods of millions of women and their families hang in the balance.

title: Ireland for, Yes, the Food
description: The people of Ireland regard the changes on the national table with the kind of self-satisfied wonder normally reserved for rainbows.

title: Constance Harriman Wed to W. Edward Whitfield
description: Constance Bastine Harriman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Howland Harriman of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to W. Edward Whitfield, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward O. Whitfield of Hopkinsville, Ky. The Rev. John Harper officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church on Lafayette Square in Washington. Mrs. Whitfield, 41 years old, graduated from Stanford University and received a law degree from the University of California at Los Angeles. She is an assistant secretary in the Department of the Interior in Washington. Mr. Whitfield, 46, received B.A. and J.D. degrees from the University of Kentucky. He is a vice president of CSX Transportation in Jacksonville, Fla. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bride's.

title: Soccer Merger Debated
description: The two conferences of the American Professional Soccer League have been meeting here this weekend to determine which of their teams would become members of a revamped league next season.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES/IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

The Mills Were Alive
description: LEAD:

title: Apartheid's Last Vicious Gasps
description: AGE OF IRON

title: Tennis;   U.S. Beats Austria in Doubles
description: Rick Leach and Jim Pugh today gave Andre Agassi a chance to be a Davis Cup hero on Sunday.

title: Dana Bullwinkel Marries
description: Dana Jean Bullwinkel, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George A. Bullwinkel of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Kent Larcom Campbell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kent Campbell of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, by the Rev. Jonathan B. Appleyard, an Episcopal priest, at the Bowdoin Chapel in Brunswick, Me. The bride and her husband are 1985 graduates of Bowdoin College. She received a master's degree in counseling from Harvard University and is the assistant director of career planning for Boston University Law School. He is a sales representative for Aetna Life and Casualty in Concord, N.H.

title:
RESTAURANTS: DALLAS;

Mealtime, Dealtime
description: LEAD: For as long as the world has known expense accounts, business and fine eating have gone together like bib and tucker. The tradition continues, despite a contagious obsession with fitness and despite the recession in several major industries. Granted, money managers in Boston prefer to take lunch at their desks and many old boys in various cities repair to their private clubs.

title: New Reatta Is Not Quite Special
description: The special cars are few and far between. And back in '88, when Buick introduced its Reatta coupe, I was enthused.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Money Has Always Played a Role in the Art World
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombia Abductions Signal Escalation of Drug War
description: Next month, Francisco Santos Calderon was to travel to Kansas to address the Inter-American Press Association on press freedom in Colombia.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES/IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Shhh! Kids and Scholars at Work
description: Margaret Hetley, the head librarian at the Hunts Point branch of the New York Public Library in the South Bronx, is having a typical afternoon. It's quiet, subdued - a couple of men in leather jackets killing time, reading magazines at a corner table; a woman in a nurse's uniform perusing the library's community service guide; a young mother with an infant in a stroller browsing in the neatly kept stacks - until about 3:30 P.M., when the local schoolkids begin filing in.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: Hundreds of Americans who took part in the world championships that ended in Geneva a week ago have brought back three lasting impressions.

title: Environment Problems: Home Rule Is Hurting Search for Solutions
description: THE question is no longer whether to improve the quality of our environment. The question is how to get the biggest bang for the buck we must spend on it.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: If the connection between the National Football League and the Doges of Renaissance Venice seems tenuous, read on.

title: Practical Traveler;   Newsletters For Singles, Golfers and Others
description: In the desktop publishing era, travel newsletters multiply like junk mail. But while computers create a more presentable publication than a mimeograph, technology is no guarantor of quality, and many newsletters do not last a year, let alone support their creators.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Shell money was a significant means of exchange among many aboriginal cultures. Native Americans used beads made from the shell of the quahog clam to barter for goods and this wampum spread far inland. African slave traders made use of the cowrie shells to purchase slaves and other goods.

title: Ex-Tenant Is Sought in Bomb Case
description: A police and F.B.I. task force on terrorism was looking yesterday for a young woman who had been evicted from an Upper East Side apartment building where two steamer trunks of pipe bombs and automatic weapons were found on Friday night.

title: Carla Stanmyre, Executive, Weds
description: Carla E. Stanmyre, the daughter of Frederick W. Stanmyre of Dallas and Hong Kong and Karen P. Stanmyre of Harrison, N.Y., was married last evening to William H. Groner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Groner of Pompano Beach, Fla. Rabbi Burt Siegel and the Rev. Louis L. Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Jesuit Bend Journal;   Keeping Obstinate River In Line
description: It was too wet even for egrets. After the storm blew in from the Gulf of Mexico, they disappeared.

title: Review/Fashion;   Turning a Fresh Eye on the 60's, Updated for the 90's
description: Short skirts, skinny pants, long blazers and sleeveless shifts. Those were the strongest trends at the Fashion Coterie, last week's trade fair where adventurous retailers scouted out fresh new talent. Many of those new designers are looking to the past for inspiration, updating the fashions of the 1960's for the 90's generation by, say, combining blazers with bicycle shorts and making minidresses in stretch fabrics.

title: College Football;   Hatajik's Passing Routs Lions
description: Behind a strong performance by Todd Hatajik, who threw for 224 yards and four touchdowns, Bucknell defeated Columbia, 41-16, today and kept the Lions without victory in their first two games of the season. The Bison improved to 2-1. Hatajik's excellent performance, in which he completed 18 of 21 passes, powered the Bison past a Columbia defense that was consistently unable to stop Bucknell.

title: Baseball;   For a Day, Darling Goes Against Wind and Odds
description: There was too much on Ron Darling's mind early this afternoon for him to consider that he might have been going to a mound as a starting pitcher for the final time as a Met.

title: Mama Rose in 'Gypsy' Needs Sharp
description: It is often advanced as a rule of life that if you take care of the little things, the big things will take care of themselves. But that's a rule of the theater, too, isn't it?

title: The Violent Debate Over Tribal Sovereignty
description: The standoff between some 20 heavily armed Mohawks and the Canadian Army has become the rallying point for many Indians across Canada and the United States who claim vast tracts of government land and who want to establish complete sovereignty over areas they control.

title: Mealtime, Dealtime
description: For as long as the world has known expense accounts, business and fine eating have gone together like bib and tucker. The tradition continues, despite a contagious obsession with fitness and despite the recession in several major industries. Granted, money managers in Boston prefer to take lunch at their desks and many old boys in various cities repair to their private clubs. But the status restaurant remains the primary locus for striking deals with meals. Most often, but not necessarily, the power meal is lunch.

title: Currency;   Big Trouble for the Pound
description: The British pound dropped sharply last week, hit hard by disappointment over the dimming prospects of a quick entry into the European Monetary System. Joining the system would make the pound, notoriously volatile, more stable and therefore more attractive to investors. Karl Otto Pohl, president of the German Bundesbank, knocked the pound down first on Wednesday when he indicated that Britain's inflation rate was too far above the European average to permit the pound to be tied to the Deutsche mark. And on Friday, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said the country's inflation rate, heading toward 10 percent, was still too high for immediate entry. The two blows took the pound down more than seven cents against the dollar between Wednesday and Friday's close.

title: Rent-A-Government
description: Anyone who doubts the urgency of upcoming Congressional negotiations to clean up Federal campaign financing might drop by Vice President Dan Quayle's house in Washington this afternoon. A select group of wealthy Republican Party contributors, lured by the promise of cozy dinners and ''closed door'' meetings with key Government officials, will be there for a private reception - opening a two-day fund-raising program on behalf of Republican candidates for the Senate.

title: Long-Quiet Player Pianos Tinkle Again
description: SEATED at the piano, the woman sways in time to the music, as the old tune ''A Pretty Girl Is Like a Melody'' echoes through the room. Dressed in lace, with long dangling rhinestone earrings, she appears to be a creature of another era, a flapper, playing her heart out.

title: Drivers
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''In Portugal, Wheels of Misfortune'' (Travel, July 22): I am European and have been acquainted with the United States for over 30 years. Repeatedly I have heard Americans criticize European drivers: none of us French, German, Italian and, now, Portuguese are rational or careful drivers.

title: Campus Life: Georgetown;   Taking a Break From Lawbooks To Help Others
description: Georgetown University Law Center students pushed aside textbooks and case studies last week to tour the national monuments with homeless children, repair an emergency housing shelter and make 600 peanut-butter-and-jelly sandwiches for a soup kitchen.

title: Running the Gulf Coalition Is Tricky Business
description: It would be hard to find another international military operation in which the raising and distribution of money has played so central a role as it has in the Persian Gulf crisis. Watching American officials traveling the globe in recent weeks collecting pledges of more than $20 billion to support the anti-Iraq coalition makes one wonder whether the United States has military allies in this affair or only limited financial partners.

title:
Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;

Rum and Brown Sugar Put the Sizzle of Reggae Into Chicken
description: LEAD: The rum and brown sugar give the Jamaican edge to this chicken dish, which takes on a lovely brown color.

title: Focus: Restrictive Growth;   A California Town Finds Mixed Results
description: Under the shade of giant cypress and elm trees near this Southern California town's main shopping arcade, workers are busy transforming a neo-Spanish convent into 10 tiny ''satellite'' offices that are expected to be ready next month .

title: Miss Smith Wed To Clifford Voges
description: The First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Kendall Simmons Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. C. Bowen Smith of Greenwich, and Clifford Lowell Voges, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Voges of Greenwich.

title: 'Ha Ha Ha Poor Jack'
description: THE CRIERS AND HAWKERS OF LONDON

title: Stop Grandstanding and Use Shoreham
description: If Saddam Hussein could have placed his own man in this country to increase: electrical costs, use of OPEC oil, our trade deficit and pollution from fossil fuels, he couldn't have picked a better man than what our own Governor, Mario M. Cuomo, has done for Long Island.

title: Review/Music;   A Piano Duo From Canada
description: Renee Morisset and Victor Bouchard, a husband-wife piano duo from Quebec, brought many virtues to their Monday evening performance at Merkin Concert Hall, although it was not immediately apparent that this would be the case.

title: New York City's Kinder Face
description: For New York's ailing public schools, help is on the way in the form of thousands of volunteers willing to tutor students. The New York City School Volunteers Program begins another year this week.

title: Review/Film Festival;   Murders Most Foul In France's 'Dr. Petiot'
description: In May 1946, Dr. Marcel Petiot died on the guillotine in a prison outside Paris. He had been convicted of the murder of 26 of the more than 60 people he had been accused of killing during the German occupation of France in World War II.

title: Israel Has a Unique Deal for U.S. Aid
description: Sometime before Oct. 30, the Treasury will write a check to Israel for $1.2 billion. The money, almost half of the $3 billion in economic and military aid that the United States gives Israel every year, will be quietly deposited in the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and immediately start earning interest at about 8 percent.

title: College Football;   Penn State Routs Rutgers
description: Penn State is a bit like an older brother to Rutgers when it comes to college football. The Scarlet Knights show up to play the big boys once a year and Penn State beats them up and sends them home.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   Bristol's Land-Taking Angers Harwinton
description: Owning property overlooking a lush Connecticut wetland populated with egrets, or a stately reservoir surrounded by forest, may turn out to be less than idyllic as the state keeps developing.

title: Man Is Held in Slayings on Appalachian Trail
description: A 38-year-old man has been charged in the slayings of two young hikers on the Appalachian Trial. He was arrested wearing the boots and backpack of one victim.

title: Sampras Style Recalls Gonzalez
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: INSURERS REDUCING MALPRACTICE FEES FOR DOCTORS IN U.S.
description: After rising sharply for more than a decade, medical malpractice insurance premiums are now declining in many states around the country.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a picture last Sunday in Men's Fashions of the Times, part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about retail stores, was printed in reverse. The caption was correct - Ira Neimark, chairman and chief executive of Bergdorf Goodman, was at the left in the photograph as published, and Stephen A. Schwarzman, president and chief executive of the Blackstone Group, was at the right.

title: Thinking About Spring: Anemones
description: HOW about a daisy for spring? Though most of the spring-blooming bulbs have a typical flower shape, there is one that has daisy flowers: Anemone blanda.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AUSTRALIAN THEATER

title: The 110-Hour Week For Interns
description: In response to ''Why Must an Intern Work 110-Hour Week?'' by Jennifer Kane (Opinion page, Aug. 26):

title: A Resident Company For Westport Playhouse
description: FOR about five years, a modest, enterprising professional theater company has been gaining a foothold as Fairfield County's Off Broadway counterpart. But there has been a hitch. In pursuit of offbeat plays, audiences have had to venture off the beaten path, to a recycled school in Fairfield.

title: College Football;   Notre Dame Needs Another Rally
description: It was a four-letter word used so often today in the Notre Dame locker room you would have thought it obscene.

title: Local History Catches Up To the Video Generation
description: IN Greenwich, the hottest video is ''A Place in the Heart.'' Produced by the town, the video commemorates Greenwich's 350th anniversary, celebrated this year.

title: Public Issue Forum Grows Up on TV
description: LEAD: NOT so long ago, Steve Adubato Jr., then producer and host of a local cable television public affairs program, was delighted to have snared an interview with the consumer advocate Ralph Nader.

title:
ART;

Opposing Tacks by Two Portraitists
description: LEAD: IN TWO exhibitions now at the Port Washington Public Library, portraits by Joan Powers and Ellen Lourie offer opposing interpretations of the human subject.

title: A German Divide Fades, But 2 Towns Still Feel It
description: It is once again a pleasant 30-minute drive from Bad Harzburg to Wernigerode through a classic German landscape of wooded mountains and half-timbered villages. The two towns share a common heritage: people used to speak the same dialect and were reared on the same legends of the Brocken, the nearby mountain where witches dance on Walpurgis Night.

title: Elvis: The Cousin
description: THE BOY WHO WOULD BE KING. By Earl Greenwood and Kathleen Tracy. (Dutton, $19.95.) For some Americans, Elvis Presley remains an obsession. For others, he has turned into a joke. The authors of ''The Boy Who Would Be King'' offer a different view, depicting a profoundly insecure child who grew up tormented by poverty and emotional abuse. With its thoughtful, honest commentary, this biography hits readers with the force of truth - at least as Earl Greenwood, Elvis's cousin, close friend and press agent, sees it. With the help of Kathleen Tracy, a freelance writer, he chronicles the singer's childhood in Tupelo, Miss., and his youth in Memphis. Many elements of Elvis's life would suit a Gothic novel: a twin brother born dead, whom Elvis invokes as a protector; a father jailed so often the sheriff ordered the Presleys to leave Tupelo; an alcoholic mother who manipulated her son's sense of guilt so well he felt he had betrayed her simply by asking another female for a date. As an adult, Elvis added more unsavory characters to his circle, selecting a manager who controlled him through intimidation. Twenty-five years of mounting frustration and rage, the authors suggest, created a cynic who mistrusted everyone, especially the ever-changing roster of women he bedded regularly. Plenty of details here match the standard gossip about Elvis's later years. But others - his first entry in a talent contest, his joyful discovery of gospel music outside a black church - reveal the man's spirit and inspire sympathy for a life dominated by feelings of unworthiness. The authors lend fluid writing to the story, even if their foreshadowing is heavy-handed and their arguments occasionally repetitious. Thanks to Mr. Greenwood's closeness to his subject, he and Ms. Tracy help readers care about a fellow human being many other writers have reduced to a cartoon.

title: Susanne Denk Has a Wedding
description: Susanne Romy Thelen Denk and Alan John Romney y de Cardenas were married yesterday at Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Thomas C. Blessin, a Roman Catholic priest. Mrs. Romney is the daughter of Ruth E. Schreyer Denk of New York and the late Horst G. Denk. The bridegroom is a son of Piedad M. de Cardenas of New York and Dr. Harry Romney of Majorca, Spain.

title: Bus Garage To Incinerator: An Itinerary For Russians
description: THE day's agenda - visiting a bus garage and sewer treatment plant in Yonkers and a garbage incinerator in Peekskill - would not have thrilled most visitors to Westchester County. But for a delegation of 14 mayors from the Soviet Union who were spending two weeks in the United States, it was close to perfect.

title: A.T.& T. Dance Tour Grants
description: The A.T.& T. Dance Tour program has awarded grants totaling $100,000 for touring to the Paul Taylor Dance Company, the Trisha Brown Company and the Urban Bush Women.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   How Should the Yanks Rebuild the Team?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: INSIDE
description: Poland Bracing for Election

title: 3 in Family Charged in Big Cocaine Seizure
description: In the first arrests in the state's largest cocaine seizure, a family has pleaded not guilty to Federal charges of conspiracy to import cocaine.

title: Superpianist Of the Golden Age
description: About five years ago Danacord issued a six-disk LP album of all the known Ignaz Friedman recordings. Now, a new Pearl set duplicates that material except for the Beethoven ''Kreutzer'' Sonata in which Friedman played with Bronislaw Huberman (''The Complete Solo Recordings 1923-1936,'' Pearl CD IP 2000, four disks). Friedman (1882-1948) was one of the superpianists of the Golden Age and is becoming a cult figure among young pianists who are beginning to be interested in Romantic performance traditions. Start with the Mazurkas. Nobody - nobody - played them better, not Rubinstein, not Horowitz.

description: The idea was to personalize the campaign as much as possible, and if that meant borrowing a pair of swim trunks to splash around a lake in Bulgaria with Ivan Slavkov, so be it.

description: FALL FESTIVALS

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21

title: Free Concerts Mark Beginning of Season
description: FREE concerts abound this week at the Hartt School of Music, at the University of Hartford, in West Hartford. On Tuesday evening at 8 -after a long absence - the ''Basically Baroque'' series returns to the campus calendar. The opening concert is totally Bach, including several Sinfonias and solo Cantatas sung and played by five Hartt alumni, Nancy LaMarch, Kevin Anderson, Mark Stanton and Bruce Henley, with other student and faculty artists.

title: OILING THE SKIDS UNDER THE ECONOMY
description: When President Saddam Hussein made his grab for Middle Eastern hegemony, the world's stock markets tumbled. Traders remembered the oil droughts of the 1970's, when skyrocketing petroleum prices caused economic dislocations around the globe. With the prospect of a recurrence, Wall Street turned to its economic pundits, whose skills are never so much in demand as when the future seems most unpredictable.

title: U.S. Gave Iraq Little Reason Not to Mount Kuwait Assault
description: In the two weeks before Iraq's seizure of Kuwait, the Bush Administration on the advice of Arab leaders gave President Saddam Hussein little reason to fear a forceful American response if his troops invaded the country.

title: Plea for Balance In Open Coverage
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bottom Line: Perception;   Budget Deal Might Not Do Much at First, But Economists Agree It's Worth Making
description: At a news conference with out-of-town reporters last week, President Bush said an agreement with Congress to reduce the Federal deficit was ''the best antidote to further economic slowdown.''

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Where the Elderly Do More Than Play Connect-the-Dots
description: LEAD: My friend Winnnie Petrocelli grabbed my hand the other day and said softly, ''In all my 87 years, I've never had this much fun with my mind.''

title: Style Makers;   Di Willis, Wedding Dress Designer
description: No woman should pay a lot of money for a dress she can only wear once - even a wedding dress, says Di Willis. And for the last four years, Ms. Willis has been producing glamorous wedding dresses for women who want to wear them again - to a club, a romantic restaurant or to somebody else's wedding.

title: Eurocheques
description: To the Editor: With reference to Betsy Wade's article ''Getting Cash Abroad'' (Travel, July 15), I would like to mention a credit arrangement popular in Europe called Eurocheques. I am surprised no U.S. bank or U.S. subsidiary of a European bank offers this service.

title: At Larchmont Station, Angry Out-of-Towners
description: LEAD: WHEN the Town of Mamaroneck began repaving and relining its commuter parking lot next to the Larchmont train station, temporarily decreasing the number of spaces, it came up with a simple solution to avoid inconveniencing town residents. It denied parking to anyone without a town parking sticker. The out-of-town commuters are restricted to all-day metered spaceson a first-come-first-served basis.

title: Catherine M. Colavecchio Is Married
description: Catherine Mary Colavecchio was married yesterday to Richard Norman Foster at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. John Hartnett officiated, assisted by the Rev. Nancy W. Hanna. Mrs. Foster is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Colavecchio of Greenwich, Conn. The bridegroom is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William H. Foster of Chagrin Falls, Ohio.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES/IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

description: Jane's addiction, a flamboyant Los Angeles hard-rock band, loves attention. But they may have received more than anticipated when their lead singer, Perry Farrell, submitted the proposed cover for the band's third album to Warner Brothers last spring. Mr. Farrell himself had designed it - an elaborate collage with three papier-mache figures, one male and two female, each anatomically correct.

title: Corrections
description: Congressional vote tally last Sunday misstated votes taken in the House on Sept. 12 on two measures.

title: D.C.'s War on Drugs, Why Bennett Is Losing
description: New York City may have more addicts, Los Angeles more gangs and Miami more big-time traffickers, but no other city, it seems, has been as ravaged by drugs as the nation's capital.

title: Year Later, St. Croix Is Coming Back, And Trying to Bring Tourists With It
description: A year ago this week, Isabelle M. Pence boarded a plane on St. Croix as she and hundreds of others fled in a scene of frenzy that she likens to the evacuation of Saigon. Carrying what little they could salvage, they left frightened and hungry from an island lost to a hurricane that hit like a wrecker's ball.

title: Memo to Banks: Deep-Six The Dividends
description: ''Every banker knows that if he has to prove that he is worthy of credit, however good may be his arguments, in fact his credit is gone.''

LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Village Fair, a Tradition Going Down the Drain
description: LEAD: QUESTION. When is a community fair not a commercial crafts festival? When did the locals yield to the pros, the hokey to the sophisticated, the village to village chic?

title: Elizabeth Reid Is Wed to David Potts
description: Elizabeth Brooks Reid, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Reid of New Canaan, Conn., and Hawley, Pa., was married yesterday to David A. Potts, a son of Dr. and Mrs. D. Gordon Potts of Toronto, Ontario. District Court Judge William N. Sanquilly of Pike County, Pa., officiated in the ceremony at the Blooming Grove Club in Hawley.

description: Dr. Cara Chandler Wilson and Dr. Joseph E. B. Burchenal, senior residents in internal medicine at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, were married yesterday in Waynesboro, Va. The Revs. J. Whitner Kennedy and T. Guthrie Speers officiated at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Question Of the Week;   Have Elite Yacht Races Become Too Dangerous?
description: Let them race, but don't expect me to be waiting for them to return. I've got a pennant race to worry about and another Super Bowl for the Giants.

description: A ROOM with a view may not be the first criterion one looks for when dining out, but it is unquestionably a bonus.

description: To the Editor:

title: If Scientists Were Calling the Shots . . .
description: As president of Sony U.S.A., and the first American to sit on the board of directors of a major Japanese corporation, I have had my share of interviews. They usually start with a routine question: ''Where did you go to college?'' ''Grinnell College in Grinnell, Iowa.'' ''And where did you get your M.B.A.?''

title: Speaking Out
description: Since he left the Soviet Union in 1974, Aleksandr Solzhenitzen has been living in a kind of double exile. Isolated in his home in the hinterlands of Vermont, he as shown a repugnance for Western society, with its ''TV stupor'' and ''intolerable music,'' that is almost as intense as his hatred of Communism. Neither is he very impressed by glasnost. Last week in an article in Komsomolskaya Pravda,the newspaper of the Communist Youth League, he called for the creation of a separate Slavic nation out of Russia, the Ukraine and Byelorussia. The Nobel laureate wrote, ''What has five or six years of perestroika brought us but a halfhearted reshuffling of the party Central Committee and an ugly fake election system with only one goal: for the Communist Party not to lose power?''

title: By Robin Hardy
description: LEAD: ''Guinness is good for you!'' is the slogan of a brewery that has made its cool, dark, creamy brew into what James Joyce, the great Irish writer, called ''the wine of Ireland.'' To see it served in pubs all over the Emerald Isle is to watch a ceremony that borders on the religious.

title: Fashion;   New Urbanity for Denim and Chambray
description: This fall, chambray and denim fabrics, rugged staples of men's wear, are lighter and more urbane-looking, Denim work shirts by Joseph Abboud are in faded and dark indigo, stone-washed for a soft hand. ''We're stressing versatility - the same shirts with a tie and tweed jacket and with jeans,'' Mr. Abboud said.

title: China's Great Dissident
description: In his Shanghai writing days, Lu Xun, never a Marxist but ever a rebel by instinct, radicalized a whole generation of young intellectuals and students and even won the admiration of Mao Zedong, under whose orders Lu Xun Academy of Literature and the Arts was established in Yanan in commemoration of his death in 1936.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Thoughts That Grow From Acorns
description: LEAD: MY neighbor complains a lot about falling acorns. In fact, not a day goes by that he doesn't walk across his driveway to ours to talk about them. The man is obsessed with acorns - almost possessed by them. But I notice that it only started when he bought his new car. He says that no matter how briefly he may park his shiny black car in his driveway, it's sure to be bombed by acorns.

title: How Lean Production Can Change the World
description: LEAD: In the spring of 1950, a young Japanese engineer named Eiji Toyoda set out on a three-month pilgrimage to Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant in Detroit. The enterprise his family had founded, the Toyota Motor Company, had just suffered through a disastrous collapse in sales and a lengthy strike, and Toyoda knew the company needed help.

title: Big Cocaine Cache Seized in Pennsylvania
description: A Canadian man was held on drug charges today after officials seized a DC-3 cargo plane that apparently ran low on fuel before landing with nearly 3,000 pounds of cocaine, the authorities said.

title: The Scam Goes On
description: DR. ENRICO S. MANGO, A LONG ISLAND ORTHOPEDIC surgeon, was growing suspicious of his stockbrokers at Wellshire Securities, a low-budget brokerage house based in New York City. During the spring of 1989, he had bought penny stocks - shares of companies too small to be listed on a stock exchange - recommended by a Wellshire broker and lost money on them. But that July, Dr. Mango bought again: 20,000 shares of Ventura, a fledgling leasing company based in Needham, Mass., at $2.50 a share.

UNIVERSITY PRESSES;

Revolution Afoot
description: LEAD:

description: THE ENGLISH TOWN

title: After Hurricane Hugo, A Double Repair Task
description: A year after Hurricane Hugo devastated the Virgin Islands, residents are struggling to rebuild not just buildings, but also the vacation site's reputation, which was damaged by lawlessness and looting that followed the storm.

title:
DINING OUT;

An Unlikely Place to Find Eclectic Food
description: LEAD: SOMETIMES one gets tips on restaurants that are to be found in the most unlikely places. Take Paparazzi, for example. Unless you got lost looking for the locker room after a game of tennis at the Tiger Racquet and Health Club, you would never stumble across this agreeable little spot by chance.

title: DOCTOR, TALK TO ME
description: When I first skimmed Broyard's article, I was angered and too tired to keep reading. Must physicians always be panned for their shortcomings - lack of feeling, and now even the lack of Oriental rugs in their offices?

title: READ THEIR LIPS
description: COULD IT BE A STRAW IN THE WIND? W. Michael Blumenthal was clean-shaven when he was Secretary of the Treasury in the 70's. But in 1989, while C.E.O. of the Unisys Corporation, he caused something of a stir by sprouting a mustache. ''I just decided to grow one,'' Blumenthal, now a limited partner in the investment banking house of Lazard Freres & Company, recalls. ''My wife said, 'Gee, honey, it would look nice.' I grew it because I liked it, and I still have it because I like it.''

title: Jane Orloff Is Married
description: Jane Orloff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Orloff of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Lionel Kaliff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Kaliff of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Church of All Souls in New York. The bride graduated from George Washington University, as did her husband. She is a vice president of the investment banking firm Lehman Brothers. Her husband received a master's degree in finance from New York University and is a vice president of Moody's Investors Service, the bond-rating concern, in New York.

title: Outdoors;   The Hunt Can Beat a Trophy
description: There is a growing body of North American writing in which fishing or hunting, or both, is a launching pad for sensitive and evocative explorations into man's relationship with the natural world.

title: Michael Della Femina Is Wed to Laurie Fullerton
description: Laurie Jeanne Fullerton, a movie director's assistant, and Michael Della Femina, an actor and movie producer, both in Los Angeles, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Pompeii Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Tarcisio Bagatin performed the ceremony.

title: Games Offering China a Chance To Polish Image
description: With parachutists, panda balloons, 11,000 pigeons and 20,000 young Chinese dancers and martial arts experts, China opened the 11th Asian Games today as a mini-Olympics intended to win back international respect and domestic support lost during the military crackdown last year.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES/IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A. PHILIP RANDOLPH, PIONEER OF THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT. By Paula F. Pfeffer. (Louisiana State University, $29.95.) The visionary A. Philip Randolph (1889-1979) helped shape this nation. Before him there was no African-American labor leader. He organized this country's first black union, the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, and sat as the first black member on the inhospitable American Federation of Labor's executive council. A front-rank civil rights leader, he conceived of two marches on Washington. The political establishment so detested the idea of the first one, set for 1941, that no one needed to take to the streets; President Franklin D. Roosevelt acceded to Randolph's demands that the Government issue orders for fair housing practices. Randolph was also part of of the effort that led to the abolishment of segregation in the armed forces. The sadly neglected Pullman porter who helped create the civil rights movement in the 50's, E.D. Nixon, was a Randolph protege. Randolph abhorred racial separatism; he also explained that pro-black does not mean antiwhite. He was an atheist, a Socialist and an unwavering anti-Communist; he was also an authoritarian leader whose multiple commitments spread him thin. In her detailed and insightful biography, ''A. Philip Randolph, Pioneer of the Civil Rights Movement,'' Paula F. Pfeffer proclaims twio goals: to show how Randolph laid the groundwork for the modern civil rights movement and to describe the difficulties experienced by a black leader who, though lacking in resources, believed that rich white allies can be as harmful (especially to black psyches) as helpful to the cause. Throughout, Msd. Pfeffer, who teaches history at Mundelein College. In Chicago, discusses the impact of Randolph's tenets and achievements.

title: Students Need Better Campus Security

description: ''He looks exactly like my husband,'' one woman said. ''He looks like my brother,'' another said, so startled at the resemblance that she did a double take.

description: Q. What would you recommend to clean dirty aluminum siding? If cleaning results are unsatisfactory, can the siding be painted?

title: Lifestyle;   The Yarmulke Is Now a Fashion Item
description: Yarmulkes are not just yarmulkes anymore. The traditional skullcaps worn by Jewish men during study and prayer are turning up in designer versions on boys age 10 and under, and not just in velvet and gold thread. Handpainted leather yarmulkes have images of Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles, Bart Simpson, Bert and Ernie of ''Sesame Street'' fame, as well as logos of baseball and football teams.

title: Lisa Vail Bush Is Married To Steven Marc Hankin
description: Lisa Vail Bush, a daughter of Dr. Martin H. Bush of New York and Elinor Seward Hall of Syracuse, was married yesterday to Steven Marc Hankin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Hankin of Baltimore. H. Erle Schafer, Circuit Court Clerk of Anne Arundel County, Md., officiated at the William Paca House in Annapolis, Md.

Fallon of Winchester, Mass. The Rev. William C. Metzdorf officiated at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church.

description: April Fools: An Insider's Account of the Rise and Collapse of Drexel Burnham

title: A Resident Troupe for Westport Playhouse
description: FOR about five years, a modest, enterprising professional theater company has been gaining a foothold as Fairfield County's Off Broadway counterpart. But there has been a hitch. In pursuit of offbeat plays, audiences have had to venture off the beaten path, to a recycled school in Fairfield.

title:
DINING OUT;

Romantic Setting in a Peekskill Factory
description: LEAD: SITUATED in a reclaimed old factory building, Zephs' has much accidental charm. The rear window view offers illuminated ruins of even older factories - dramatic empty windows in looming brick walls - softened by vines and other volunteer greenery, a pure Romantic vision. Inside, decor has not quite reached completion; but the dining room is bright and comfortable, classical music or jazz fills the space unobtrusively and service is friendly, helpful and nicely paced.

title: Iraq Grants More Visas to U.S. Networks Than Newspapers
description: With the Persian Gulf crisis entering its eighth week, most major American newspapers have been struggling unsuccessfully to obtain visas to provide daily news coverage from Iraq.

title: Has Dole Found a Way Out of the Budget Impasse?
description: Congressional budget negotiators, taking a break from their formal deliberations until Sunday evening, spent today trying to decide whether Senator Bob Dole of Kansas had found a way out of the current impasse with his proposal to sever capital gains tax cuts from a deficit reduction package.

title:
ART;

A Probing Look Beyond the Surface
description: LEAD: At one time or another, every painter comes to feel that the work's surface poses issues that must be addressed. Does the image lay on top, go behind, push at the edges or jump off? Is it held and contained, or does it pierce the surface?

title: Question Of the Week;   Have Elite Yacht Races Become Too Dangerous?
description: Technology and equipment have improved over the years to help minimize the dangers associated with yacht racing. Granted, we are dealing with elements that can be quite severe, but with weather faxes, satellite navigation, Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacons, better safety equipment, and superior yacht construction materials, the dangers are minimized although never eliminated.

title: Campus Life: Bard;   Students Hope To Be Published In New Magazine
description: Creative-writing students here are harboring new hopes of being published now that Bard College has taken over the literary magazine Conjunctions.

title: Tracking Down Foucault's Pendulum
description: I knew it was in a church. Or rather, that the museum where it is housed had formerly been a church. And so, that afternoon, after a friend and I had lunch in an excellent little restaurant in Place des Victoires, we set off on foot toward the Rue St.-Martin and the Conservatoire National des Arts et Metiers.

title: The Correct Setting
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Bochco's Cops Say It With Music
description: ''What's the reason for doing another cop show?'' Steven Bochco asks himself, stretching back on the couch in his elegant Spanish hacienda of an office on the lot of 20th Century Fox studios. ''There is none.''

title: Susan W. Shapiro, 47, Lawyer in New Jersey
description: Susan W. Shapiro, a lawyer and former law secretary to an appellate judge of the New Jersey Superior Court, died on Friday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 47 years old and lived in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: Diane Crosson, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Diane Marie Crosson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Crosson of Bloomfield, Conn., and Quonochontaug, R.I., was married yesterday to Mark Tresham McEnroe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. McEnroe of New York and Cove Neck, L.I. The Rev. Joseph Byrns, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Watch Hill (R.I.) Chapel.

title: Watching That Diet? It's a Piece of Cake
description: THE 1990's may rank as the decade of eating right in addition to eating well. Even fast-food chains have hopped aboard the healthy-food bandwagon. Nevertheless, dining out is still a land mine of fats, frustration, calories and cholesterol.

title: When Mothers And Infants Are Addicts
description: A WOMAN from White Plains was nearing the time to deliver her child when doctors monitoring her condition at the Westchester County Medical Center here noticed a sudden drop in the fetal heart rate and performed an emergency Caesarean section.

title: For Some Heroes, Life Is Just Too Much
description: We all know what Benjamin Braddock, in Mike Nichols's ''Graduate,'' did when it was suggested to him that he might find his professional future in plastics: he barely blinked. When processing a proposition like that one, disbelief was the only sensible reaction. Twenty-three years later, Mr. Nichols's screen heroes and heroines remain as dumbfounded as ever, in understandable response to the duplicity, wrongheadedness and just plain idiocy that rages around them. Stupefaction, in the face of life's little conundrums and absurdities, can indeed be the best revenge.

title: Rock's Individualists: Good, Bad and Ugly
description: It would be hard to find two uglier voices in pop music than the ones owned by Neil Young and Bob Dylan. They wail and whine as if their vocals were produced somewhere behind an irritated adenoid. There's little traditional pop pleasure here. But the two rock icons, roughly 25 years into their careers, create something just as important: recognition. They're still ugly, and people know it.

title: Modern Judaica in Riverdale, Science Fiction in Pound Ridge
description: FOR every jeans commercial, television should show a slice of life in an old-age home, just to lend perspective. The Hebrew Home for the Aged seems a superior example, if only for being a complex of well-tended apartment buildings on 19 acres overlooking the Hudson River from Riverdale.

title: Track and Field;   Plumer Wins Mile In Course Record
description: Proving that she runs a better race than she predicts, PattiSue Plumer, a 28-year-old lawyer from Palo Alto, Calif., surged from behind on a rainswept Fifth Avenue course yesterday to win the 10th Mercedes Mile. In the process, she broke a four-year-old course record and won a $35,000 car from the sponsors.

title: 178 Evacuees, on Last Flight From Iraq, Arrive in London
description: An Iraqi Airways jet carrying Western women and children from Iraq and occupied Kuwait arrived today in London, the last in a series of United States-chartered ''freedom flights.''

title: Linda Frankenbach Wed To Hendrik J. Kranenburg
description: Linda Alice Frankenbach, the daughter of the late Henry G. Frankenbach and the late Dorothy Todd Frankenbach, was married yesterday to Hendrik Johannes Kranenburg 3d, the son of Johanna F. Kranenburg of San Diego and the late Mr. Kranenburg Jr. The Rev. Stephen Quinlan officiated at the Presbyterian Church in Bridgehampton, L.I.

title: When a Man and His Art Become One
description: STROLLING from one bargain table to the next, suburban shoppers at a recent sidewalk sale were diverted by a pewter-colored, life-size statue of a man on the edge of the curb. Some instinctively reached out to feel the rough metallic texture of its suit.

title: Nina Timpson Weds Lawrence Hilbert
description: Cornelia Vallon Timpson, a watercolorist and former head teacher at the Park Avenue Christian Church Day School in New York, was married yesterday to Lawrence Patrick Hilbert, the director of racquet sports at the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. James King officiated at St. James Episcopal Church in Prouts Neck, Me., assisted by the bridegroom's brother, the Rev. Michael P. Hilbert, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Irene Dunne: No Oscar, Just Love
description: She was my father's favorite movie star, and my grandfather's too. Talking with my best friend, he said, ''Irene Dunne, you know, was my all-time favorite.''

title: The American Who Is Lobbying the World
description: As the Bush Administration strives to tighten the noose of United Nations sanctions around Saddam Hussein's neck, the man adjusting the rope has been doing his job with an appeal to high moral values and the lessons of history. For Thomas R. Pickering, America's representative to the United Nations, the world is engaged in the struggle it forgot to wage in the 1930's as it seeks to push Iraq's army out of occupied Kuwait.

title: Unity Approaches, and East Germany Is Looming Smaller
description: IT has become common to speak of German unity in somber and elevated tones, as befits an event of such indisputable historic dimensions. But it is also instructive to note that the actual moment of unity, Oct. 3, was selected not for any historic or symbolic significance, but as a result of the most rollicking variety of political maneuvering.

title: What Britain Sowed, Iraq and U.S. Now Reap
description: To the Editor:

title: School Football;   Scheier Spurs Edgemont
description: Before the football season, Brian Connolly, the coach of Edgemont High School in Scarsdale in Westchester, said his team would go only as far as Adam Scheier took it.

description: Alexandra Sachs Shaw and Brooke Winfred Ablon were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. George Zabriskie performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John Covington.

description: Wendy Stevens believes ''trucks are beautiful creatures.'' She is also quite taken with suits of armor, the perforated metal in phone booths and the stainless steel in subway cars.

description: BODIES OF WATER

title: At UConn Baby Lab, Researchers Seek Messages Amid the Tears
description: LEAD: GWEN E. GUSTAFSON'S research subjects are often unpredictable, sometimes confounding. Slated to meet at a laboratory for some clinical observations, they kick their feet, cry uncontrollably, even fall asleep on the floor. After all, they're only babies. Dr. Gustafson, a psychology professor at the University of Connecticut, in Storrs, has been studying infant development for 15 years, so she is used to fussing and feistiness.

description: CROSSBLOODS

title: Zimbabwe Drops Plan For One-Party Statute
description: In a move seen as a political setback for President Robert Mugabe, the country's governing party decided today to drop its campaign to legalize one-party rule, Mr. Mugabe had made a single-party state a linchpin of his plans for Zimbabwe, formerly the British colony of Rhodesia.

title: Hers;   Remembering Jane
description: In The Opening scene of ''The Webster Street War,'' a videotape made in Fort Wayne, Ind., documenting a typical procedure day at the local women's clinic, two women cautiously emerge from a parked car, their eyes trained on the small crowd of ''sidewalk counselors'' waiting for them. The older woman offers a protective arm to her vulnerable young companion - presumably her daughter - as the hostile group moves in their direction. Four clinic volunteers follow immediately but their progress is impeded by their bulky cargo: a four-sided plywood box, with no top or bottom, hinged on one side and with carrying handles on the others.

title: Corrections
description: A map on July 22 with an article about Pueblo pottery in New Mexico placed the Laguna Pueblo incorrectly. A reader has written to point out that it is north, not south, of Interstate 40.

title: Looking Homeward
description: The reunification of Germany won't bring the Hohenzollerns back to power, but Prince Louis Ferdinand of Prussia, for one, is resting easier. The 82-year-old heir to the throne last held by Kaiser Wilhem II during World War I said that when the Berlin wall was breached, he ''had the feeling that a new life was starting.'' After reunification becomes official next month, the Prince plans to begin arranging to return the coffin of his ancestor, Frederick the Great, to Sans Souci, the Potsdam palace that was formerly the family seat. East German leaders invited the Prince to return Frederick's remains to the tomb from which they were removed as the Soviet Army advanced on Potsdam near the end of World War II, but he declined. ''I just couldn't imagine Frederick being buried under a regime of terror and suppression,'' he said.

title: Virginia Is for Stories
description: ERIC CLAPTON'S LOVER

title: THE REGION: Excerpts;   An Ethics Panel Ends Its Work, And It's Angry
description: After working for 40 months and questioning nearly 1,000 witnesses, the New York State Commission on Government Integrity issued its final report on Tuesday. In a strongly worded letter to Governor Mario M. Cuomo accompanying it, the panel, known as the Feerick Commission, said leaders of both major parties had failed New Yorkers by not insisting on ethics reforms, and asked him to press for changes. Here are excerpts from the letter: The campaign finance law of the state is a disgrace and embarrassment; incumbents are favored unfairly by the state election law; the laws governing access to the primary ballot are completely at odds with the democratic principle of open elections; judges are elected in a manner that weakens the independence of the judiciary; personnel practices are tainted with politics; municipal officials are given little guidance in handling conflicts of interest, and untold millions of taxpayer dollars are wasted as a result of flawed contracting procedures.

description: PUNDITS, POETS, AND WITS

description: How can you even ask a question like that when there are so many more important things to worry about? How about the breakneck pace of modern polo matches? Now, there's a problem!

On the streets of Brooklyn and Queens he is still most commonly thought of not as a political neophyte, not as a maverick underdog, but as a French artist.

Bersani of Syracuse. The Rev. Vincent Walsh, assisted by the Rev. Frederick Heberle, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Valley Roman Catholic Church in Sheffield, Mass.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: LATE ON THE NIGHT OF JUNE 30, THOUSANDS of East Germans milled about the entrance of a bank on Alexanderplatz in East Berlin. When midnight struck, a bank manager swung open the doors and the crowd surged forward, racing inside to exchange their East German currency for West German marks. The four-decade-long economic division of Germany had ended, and it seemed only appropriate that the first dramatic moment of unification should occur at a branch office of Deutsche Bank, a leading symbol of

title: The Battle of the Columnists: Telling Leaders How to Think
description: In the earliest days of the Reagan Revolution, conservative activists frequently showed their disdain for the technocratic, bipartisan politics they believed prevailed in Washington by proclaiming ''Ideas matter!'' The ideological furor now roiling the conservative movement is reminding politicians and the press that idea-mongers matter too.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Keep up with planting. Keep mowing as long as the grass is growing, but start raking leaves if they are beginning to drop as the grass must be clear to sustain root and top growth. Finish dividing perennials, especially those that bloom in early spring. Last call to take the house plants indoors, if they have not been moved inside. Start cleaning tools that will not be used.

title: In the Gulf, the Danger of a Diplomatic Solution . . .
description: If Saddam Hussein were to withdraw from Kuwait tomorrow, the world would rejoice. An end to the Iraqi aggression would be universally regarded as a triumph for the United Nations and for President Bush and the broad coalition he has so skillfully assembled to oppose Sadam Hussein.
