title: DOCTOR, TALK TO ME
description: I don't think religion or taste in office decor, which Broyard mentions, is a good basis for choosing a physician. Rather, one should consider checking a physician's plants. A doctor attentive to the needs of his flora will probably be sensitive to the needs of his patients.

title: Amelia P. Burns, Executive, Weds
description: Amelia Petitti Burns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Petitti of Lavallette, N.J., was married yesterday to James Anthony Quaremba, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Anthony G. Quaremba of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Anthony Gulley officiated at Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Albany.

title: Mealtime, Dealtime
description: For as long as the world has known expense accounts, business and fine eating have gone together like bib and tucker. The tradition continues, despite a contagious obsession with fitness and despite the recession in several major industries. Granted, money managers in Boston prefer to take lunch at their desks and many old boys in various cities repair to their private clubs. But the status restaurant remains the primary locus for striking deals with meals. Most often, but not necessarily, the power meal is lunch. Herewith a sampling of international business eateries by New York Times correspondents and frequent contributors to this magazine.

title: Kelli Ann Hunter Marries Theodore Krebsbach
description: Kelli Ann Hunter and Theodore Anthony Krebsbach were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph in Garden City, L.I., by the Rev. Richard F. Delaney.

title: World Markets;   Prospecting for the Market Bottom
description: Barton Biggs, chief global strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, is tired of advising clients to stay away from the world's stock markets. ''It is not an inspiring message and repeating it gets endlessly boring,'' he said.

title: Review/Dance;   4 Elements Are Theme For Chen
description: The four works that the Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company performed last Sunday night at St. Mark's Church derived from the Buddhist belief that the physical world is made up of water, earth, fire and wind. Each dance depicted a mighty elemental power. Yet the evening lacked excitement.

title: Campus Life: Williams;   Students Arrested In a Crackdown On Rowdy Parties
description: The start of fall semester at Williams College has in recent years led to an increase in residents' calls to the local police complaining about noise and property damage caused by students partying in off-campus housing. This year, students returning to campus discovered that Williamstown had had enough.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES/IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE CHRIST CHILD GOES TO COURT. By Wayne R. Swanson. (Temple University, $27.95.) The separation of church and state is an idea that is accepted by most American. Controversy arises, however, when the boundaries of the separation are asserted in a particular situation. Wayne Swanson, a professor of government at at connecticut College, has written a case study of one such situation. In 1980, the American Civil Liberties Union sued the city of Pawtucket, R.I., for erecting a Nativity scene with public funds. The Supreme Court, in the 1984 case of Lynch v. Donnelly, overruled the lower courts and, in a 5-4 decisin, held that the creche was not an establishment of religion prohibited by the First Amendment. The court reasoned that the context of the display had the basically secular purposes of promoting the spirit of the holiday season and attracting shoppers to the downtown stores, rather than demonstrating government support of religion. The author does a good job of presenting the issues that the courts faced in the decisions set forth at each judicial level. He also traces the history of Supremem Court cases concerning separation of church and state, and includes some background on the Federal judicial system. All this, will be useful to the reader with no grounding in the issues involved, but the book lacks the depth and perspective to add any insight into this controversy. The relationship between religion and government has stirred sufficient passions on both sides to cause fundamental fissures in Americna life today. The scope of Mr. Swanson's book is too limited to give his readers an understanding of how deeply rooted attitudes and beliefs make this issue, for many, a moral crusade rather than a legal argument.

title: Anne S. Balas Is Married
description: Anne S. Balas, the daughter of Mrs. William Balas of Sebastopol, Calif., and the late Mr. Balas, was married yesterday to James A DeNaut, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. DeNaut of Flossmoor, Ill., by the Rev. Richard Jeske at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in New York. Mrs. DeNaut, a University of Southern California graduate, and her husband, a Northwestern University graduate, both received M.B.A. degrees from Harvard University. She is an associate at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. The bridegroom, who also has a master's from the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, is an associate at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York.

title: Portland, Ore.
description: When Portland opened the doors to its performing arts complex three years ago, a tightrope walker headlined the dedication. The choice was apt. In this city of 432,000 development has followed a carefully plotted course, executed with flair, hoopla and, often, whimsy. Funds for large-scale projects have at times been precarious, but that has made each completion more exciting.

title: Is There a Cheaper Way To Attack Rising Crime?
description: Should firefighters wield guns as well as hoses, and garbage collectors carry nightsticks along with trash? Should private security patrols get city subsidies, and serious criminals be tried in special courts? Should the police stop and frisk dozens in sweeps, challenging civil liberties laws?

Mrs. Tiedemann is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Masamichi Imura of Chiba, Japan. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tiedemann 2d of New York and East Hampton.

description: The family of Robert Wallace Jr., who was convicted in 1988 of killing a man outside a Manhattan bar with a karate kick, prays daily for his release from prison.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   Southwestern Samples (Choice of 2 Arizonas)
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some restaurants that offer a variety of American foods.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;

For Paris, It's the Flea Market
description: LEAD: It is 80 years since Ragane, a ragpicker out of Balzac, tucked his wares under his coat, snuggled up against the rope that was the entrance to the Marche aux Puces just over the Paris city line in St.-Ouen, and fell asleep. In those days before the two world wars, even the king of Parisian rag pickers couldn't count on one of his cronies to wake him at 5 A.M.

title: Our War the Way It Was
description: Its theme - the clash of countrymen, of brothers - resounds through world myth. The battles were terrible, the casualties beyond imagining. Its heroes live more vividly in national and regional memory than the Founders themselves. The root cause stirred profound beliefs, and the nation continues to struggle with the consequences. What wonder that the Civil War has never lost its hold on the American imagination or that it should attract the imagination of Ken Burns, who with his ambitious television series, ''The Civil War,'' takes his place as the most accomplished documentary maker of his generation.

title: Food;   A Jewish Yen For Chinese
description: Crossing culinary cultures may be the the hottest food trend of the moment, what with Southwest-Asian-Italian-Cajun combinations on menus from coast to coast. For me, however, such ethnic mixes are old stuff. My cross-culinary experiences began in Brooklyn in the late 1930's and early 40's, when my mother would try to duplicate the dishes we favored in local Chinese restaurants.

title: Baseball: Notebook;   Boyd and Tudor Are 2 Pitchers Earning Their '90 Salaries
description: Last winter Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd was a free agent, but he was a risk because he spent four months on the disabled list last season and he had put in more time on the disabled list (332 days) in the previous three seasons than he had on the active roster (214 days).

title: Marie Errico Wed To John A. Bicks
description: Marie Elizabeth Errico and John Alexander Bicks were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary's of the Lake in Skaneateles, N.Y., by the Most Rev. Thomas J. Bicks of New York.

title: Power Lines And Health Risks
description: The July 29 article ''Power Lines Stir Concern on Health Risk'' reported on activities in Essex, Ocean and Monmouth Counties by residents protesting the lines. The article contained unattributed reports and unwarranted conclusions.

title: Behind Bars, Keeping Mother and Child Together
description: Elizabeth Mercado gazed pensively at her six- and-a-half-month-old daughter, Glori Lou, who was reaching eagerly toward the bright animal mobiles over her crib. ''Sometimes, I feel sad,'' the 26-year-old mother said. ''They are babies, but they feel everything we feel. Sometimes, I feel she can recognize these rails.''

title: Change of Heart
description: The Boston Celtics' rookie gaurd, Dee Brown, says he is canceling plans to buy a home in Wellsley, Mass., after he was held at gunpoint on Friday by Wellesley police officers who thought he was a bank robbery suspect.

title: Review/Music;   Spanish Pieces for Guitar
description: Jose Salazar, a guitarist from New Mexico, played a program at Weill Recital Hall last Sunday evening that was more typical of a turn-of-the-century Spanish salon concert than of a modern recital. His aims, one gathered, was to point up his educational pedigree and to pay tribute to his teachers and the tradition they represented.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Are you ready for the coming ''imaging environment''? That's the gold-tinged horizon that pundits in the photography industry are anticipating, a land where conventional silver-halide films and electronic pixels co-exist in happy harmony.

description: Reading ''When Gum Balls Cost a Penny'' [Westchester Opinion, Sept. 2] brought a smile, chuckle and a flood of happy memories.

The Is Seasonal Beauty in Native Grasses

description: Q. What would you recommend to clean dirty aluminum siding? If cleaning results are unsatisfactory, can the siding be painted?

title: New & Noteworthy
description: VAMPIRES, BURIAL, AND DEATH: Folklore and Reality, by Paul Barber. (Yale University, $9.95.) From the days of Dracula to those of Anne Rice, people have been fascinated by legends about the living dead. In 1988 one reviewer said that in seeking to explain scientifically how the vampire myth began, Paul Barber has produced a ''learned, energetic, creepily absorbing study - definitely not for children.''

title: U.S. Diplomats Return in Force to Nicaragua
description: On the southern edge of Managua, workers are readying an office building for a tenant that is determined to change the neighborhood.

title: No (Painless) Cure for the Budget Deficit
description: The United States has a huge structural budget deficit and there is no painless way to undo it. The pain could have been less if the difficult choices had been made at a more favorable time, when economic growth was more robust. That chance was missed. But doing nothing will not eliminate the pain. It will merely postpone and compound the economic and financial costs.

title: Baseball;   Mets End Slide at 5; Trail by Only 2 1/2
description: The Mets rose up from the ruins of their divisional race today, manhandled the Chicago Cubs, 11-5, and even gained a game on the first-place Pittsburgh Pirates. But they had no illusions about the mean mathematics. After losing five straight games before this one, they stood two and a half games out with only 11 left to play.

title: Sandra Maria Pinnavaia Is Married
description: Sandra Marie Pinnavaia was married yesterday to Guy Moszkowski. The Rev. Sandra Haines officiated at the Tagart Chapel of the McDonogh School in Owings Mills, Md.

title: Banning Cigarette Sales In Vending Machines
description: Hooray for East Brunswick (''Ban on Cigarette Vending Machines Encounters Opposition,'' Aug. 5). There are many reasons why we should end or control cigarette sales by machines:

title: The Courts Are Again Asked to Redefine Family
description: A woman with two sons and no more husband finds someone who cherishes her and goes through a wedding ceremony. They live together for 12 years, mingle their finances, buy a house together and raise the boys in it. Then her mate falls ill with cancer, deteriorates slowly despite her nursing and prayers, and dies in her arms. The question now before a court: Were they a family? The answer, for the moment, is no, not in the eyes of the law if, as in Sandra Rovira's case, the mate she found was a woman. Nor in the eyes of A.T.& T., which employed Ms. Rovira's partner, Marjorie Forlini, and which Ms. Rovira sued this month, charging that it discriminated against her by refusing to pay the death benefits it would have paid a surviving spouse.

title: Critics Notebook;   Beckett Remembered, In His Own Words
description: Samuel Beckett was celebrated with his words rather than with personal memories in a tribute to the late playwright on Monday night at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center. The capacity audience - which included the author's nephew Edward Beckett and American friends - shared the celebratory mood. To emphasize the words, excerpts from plays and prose were shorn of all environmental and design elements, except for those glimpses of past performances on film.

title: LOWERING THE TRADE DEFICIT BY DEGREES
description: WITH CORPORATE AMERICA draws fire from critics at home and abroad for its manifest inefficiencies and lack of competitive verve, the American-style business education, corporate America's guiding light, has more cachet than ever. All across the nation, growing numbers of foreign students are enrolling in business schools.

title: Trapped by a Stuffed Bear
description: A. A. MILNE.

title: DOCTOR, TALK TO ME
description: Physicians find themselves bound by the intellectual discipline of science, which is to understand and manipulate the natural history of a disease under various management strategies. The individuality of a particular patient never enters the picture, because scientific reasoning is about something common to individuals, prostatic cancer in this case, not something unique to them, their experience of illness.

title: 'Berkeley in the 60's' Brings Back the Future
description: LEAD: As an adolescent in San Francisco in the 1960's, the independent film maker Mark Kitchell was ''more hip than radical,'' he said recently. Yet he followed the actions of the student movement across the bay with intense interest. ''They had a heavy impact on me,'' he said. ''They formed my world view and sense of politics.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Gt. Barrington, Mass.;

Renovation For '05 Theater
description: LEAD: Southern Berkshire County's only movie theater, the Mahaiwe, whose fate was uncertain for two years, has a more assured future now that the owner is renovating it while continuing to present films and live performances.

title: Hale House Fights City Hall on Babies' Care
description: Hale House, a narrow brownstone on 122d Street in Harlem that has been home to 800 unwanted babies since 1969, is the city's shrine to good works. Clara Hale, who began rescuing children off the streets in 1941, has long been a secular saint.

title:
The Executive Life;

Just You Wait, 'Enry 'Iggins ...
description: LEAD: ''UNNNNNNNN,'' hums John Colomius, a senior account executive at a New York computer graphics company, loudly. ''Maa-maaaa,'' he adds. Then, louder still, ''WHOOOOOOSH!'' Standing next to a grand piano in the living room of an apartment in Manhattan's Upper West Side, Mr. Colomius has been making baby-like talk for the last 45 minutes.

title: Log Cabin Luxury

title: Evening Hours;   Doing Good By Having A Good Time
description: About 450 New Yorkers, including Jean MacArthur in her first public appearance after a two-year illness, filled the Plaza ballroom Monday to honor Milton Petrie for his generosity to victims of crime. The evening raised more than $400,000 for the National Victim Center founded by Alexander von Auersperg and his sister Ala Isham. Two of the victims Mr. Petrie helped, Marla Hanson and Steven McDonald, gave moving tributes.

title: Boris Yeltsin Taking Power
description: One day last month, Boris N. Yeltsin barreled into a meeting with managers of a mine in Vorkuta, an Arctic coal city. The weak smiles and wary eyes announced that the guest had been preceded by his reputation: populist demagogue, Communist Party defector, nemesis of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and, not least unsettling to this gathering, hero to legions of restive coal miners. This man had been a candidate member of the Politburo when that meant something, and had been driven from the ruling heights with all the ritual humiliation the party could muster. Now here he was reborn, by a miracle of democracy, as the President of the Russian republic.

title: Residential Remodeling Making Gains
description: David and Toni small have just spent $50,000 to improve their home in Lake Hopatcong, N.J. The updated kitchen has new oak cabinets, a new floor of Mexican tiles, new pale yellow countertops and new appliances. The terrace and stone steps leading from the house to the shore of the lake have been regrouted and the 10-room house is wearing a fresh coat of paint.

title:
TO START WITH ...;

BIG SHOTS WITHIN EARSHOT
description: LEAD: Since the advent of the Sony Walkman a decade ago, we have grown all too familiar with the unwanted sound of music - or self-improvement seminars - leaking from the earphones of nearby strangers in trains and planes and elevators. Now comes an even more intrusive personal-electronics device: the portable cellular phone.

title: Ms. Leffert Plans October Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert D. Leffert of Chestnut Hill, Mass., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter, Lisa Rae Leffert, and Lee H. Schwamm, a son of Ellen Schwamm Brodkey and Jay Marc Schwamm, both of New York.

title: John Pirie Wed To Jane Shotwell
description: Jane Shotwell, a daughter of Tamara Dudley Shotwell of Manchester, Mass., and Edward Carle Shotwell 3d of Wenham, Mass., was married yesterday to John Taylor Pirie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Pirie of Hamilton, Mass. The Rev. Barbara P. Hendren officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Beverly Farms, Mass.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Mendham Township
description: LEAD: The allure of Mendham Township lies as much in what is not there as in what is. Sidewalks and street lights are rare, crime is almost nonexistent and, except for a post office and a restaurant, no commercial structures have elbowed their way onto its landscape.

title: Beach Residents Imperiled
description: LEAD: FOR 10 years, John Hamilton, an economics professor at Suffolk County Community College, has spent his summers at his cottage at West Meadow Beach in Stony Brook.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Now It's Gone. That's the Last Straw!
description: LEAD: ONE by one they're slipping away, those old friends I used to visit for hours on end. First it was the New York crowd, Altman's and then Bonwit's. But losing a more recent chum, Bloomingdale's in Stamford, is the last straw!

title: Talking: Fuel Co-ops;   Shopping Around for Savings
description: Fuel cooperatives are getting new attention these days as a result of the Persian Gulf crisis. But they are not necessarily for everyone.

title: The Child Is Father to the Mad
description: SPIDER

title: 'Our Daughter Needs a Complete Cure'
description: THE HEALER

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

Office Complex Planned for Trade Center
description: LEAD: After nearly a year of negotiations and delays - and despite the sluggish commercial market - plans are moving ahead on a 1.7-million-square-foot office complex for BASF Corporation, the chemical conglomerate, at the International Trade Center in Mount Olive.

title: Traffic Alert
description: George Washington Bridge:

title: SOME BOAT PEOPLE WILL BE RETURNED
description: Vietnam, Britain and the United Nations refugee commission have reached an agreement on the repatriation of Vietnamese boat people from camps in Hong Kong.

title: Speaking Up
description: New York State Republician leaders were seething last week when their sacrificial lamb in the gubernatorial race, Pierre A. Rinfret, began to put up an embarassing commotion on his way to the slaughter. Party leaders had expected Mr. Rinfret, an economist and political unknown, to bear their standard in quiet dignity while Gov. Mario M. Cuomo waltzed into a third term. But that went out the window last week when Mr. Rinfret threatened to quit campaigning if the party did not come up with more funds and, when no money appeared, accused top G.O.P. office holders of ''trying to sabotage my candidacy.'' The state Republican leader, J. Patrick Barrett, said he looked askance on the intraparty attacks, but added, ''I guess that was his way of asking for help.''

title: Hospital Agrees to Start AIDS Program
description: LEAD: SOME days Enrique, a 38-year-old man with AIDS, is too weak to fix himself something to eat. His housemates, Elmer, 56, and Lillie, 19, who also have AIDS, bring him a bowl of cereal or a sandwich.

title: Atlanta Seeks to Deliver City It Sold to Olympics
description: The bid for the Olympic Games was one part Rhett and Scarlett and one part the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., both marketed with the entrepreneurial zeal that has been Atlanta's most consistent thread since its founding as a lonely railroad junction in 1842.

title: Keith Williams Weds Margit Edwards
description: Margit Edwards, a drama student at Hunter College, and Keith David Williams, an actor known as Keith David, were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Corona, Queens. The Rev. Alex Chambers and the Rev. Louis F. Ferrara officiated.

title: When TV Talk Is Intrusive
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On Language;   Those Defining Moments
description: The Iraqi Invasion of Kuwait,'' testified Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, ''is one of the defining moments of a new era. . . .'' Lest anyone miss the import of the phrase, he came back to it a moment later: ''we must respond to the defining moments of this new era. . . .''

title: Man Killed and Powder Is Poured on Body
description: One man was shot and killed and another seriously wounded yesterday in upper Manhattan by men who forced their way inside an apartment in Washington Heights, the police said.

title: State Looking at Pay Phone Charges
description: SIX pay telephones line the rear wall of the lobby of the Hudson County Administration Building in Jersey City. All six are owned by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company. All are identical and contain the same dialing instruction cards.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Discovering, A Bit Late, Security In Religious Identity
description: LEAD: ON my 15th birthday, my mother asked me to speak with her privately for a moment. We went to my bedroom. She looked uneasy. I felt that something was terribly wrong and anticipated that my parents had decided to cut their cord of matrimony. But I was wrong. I was about to learn what might have been their most weighty secret.

title: Excerpts From Iraqi Document on Meeting With U.S. Envoy
description: On July 25, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq summoned the United States Ambassador to Baghdad, April Glaspie, to his office in the last high-level contact between the two Governments before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Here are excerpts from a document described by Iraqi Government officials as a transcript of the meeting, which also included the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz. A copy was provided to The New York Times by ABC News, which translated it from the Arabic. The State Department has declined to comment on its accuracy.

title: Tech Notes;   Pardon Me, Your Heroin's Showing
description: Travelers may someday find themselves and their luggage being gently vacuumed by airline personnel before flying, or by border guards before they cross national boundaries. No, it's not part of an international campaign for spiffiness. It's the latest in drug and explosives detection technology from Barringer Instruments Inc. of Morristown, N.J. In Barringer's system, molecules attached to dust particles collected by the vacuuming are vaporized by heat. They are then ionized - that is, electrically charged by a quick bath in low-level radiation - and set adrift in an electric field. Each type of ion moves at a characteristic pace. The results are matched to computer profiles of plastic explosives, cocaine, heroin and so on. The $65,000 system, which passed its first test with the United States Customs Service,also handles samples gathered remotely by vacuum cleaners equipped with disposable credit-card sized filters.

title: Lemon Juice as Punishment
description: A former day-care teacher has been charged with tying up children and forcing them to drink lemon juice as a disciplinary measure, the police said. Jennie L. Williams, 24 years old, of Gloversville faces one misdemeanor count of endangering the welfare of a child for reportedly restraining two students on April 1, and making them drink the sour juice, the Gloversville Senior Investigator, Robert Spedding, said Friday. Police began investigating Ms. Williams in May when one of her former aides at the Gloversville Y.W.C.A.'s Bebee Taylor Daycare Center told a local couple that their 3-year-old son was being abused by unorthodox disciplinary measures.

title: New York Streamlines an Essential Link: 911
description: They sit in cubicles, glued to outdated computer screens, gleaning information from often frantic callers. With a constant mantra of ''911, may I help you,'' the 70 operators of the Police Department's 911 telephone emergency system are an essential link between New Yorkers and the police, the Fire Department and the Emergency Medical Service.

title: Theresa A. Elvidge Is Wed To J. M. Bistrong in Maine
description: Theresa Ann Elvidge, a social worker at the Spaulding Rehabilitation Hospital in Boston, was married yesterday at the Sea Coast Mission in Bar Harbor, Me., to Jeffery Matthew Bistrong, a loan officer at the Bank of Boston. John Drake, superintendent of the mission, officiated.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Why was Barbara Greenwald so happy? Because a few days hence she had an appointment with a popular new hairstylist who books 10 weeks in advance.

title: Assignment: 90 Days on the Polish Front
description: THERE I SAT ON THE morning of Jan. 5 in a Polonez sedan headed south from Warsaw. At the age of 63, retired from RCA, I had offered my services as a volunteer consultant to businesses in foreign countries. Now I found myself about to meet with the management of my first client, Polkolor, a company I was expected to help restructure over the next three months.

title: Postings: Avenue B Luxury;   A Rehab Does It
description: A glut of market-rate rental apartments has sent even long-time owners throughout the city scrambling for tenants. But a couple of newcomers to the development scene managed to lease all 16 apartments in an East Village tenement they renovated only three weeks after completion, in part by bringing a touch of luxury to Avenue B. Doron and Karen Resheff, a husband-and-wife team who are 28 and 30 years old, respectively, put microwave ovens and washer-dryer units in all the studio and one-bedroom apartments they created in the building 190-192 Avenue B, at 12th Street. The eight 465-square-foot studios rent for $890 a month and the eight, 624-square-foot one-bedroom apartments for $1,050 a month.

title: Landfill Deadline Could Push Towns To Regional Efforts
description: LEAD: WHEN State Environmental Conservation Commissioner Thomas C. Jorling proposed a strategy this month showing how the 13 towns and two cities on Long Island could comply with a state law to close municipal landfills by Dec. 18, he urged a new level of cooperation among local officials to solve their solid-waste problems.

title: Campus Life: Harvard;   Athletes Invoke Muse To Fight a Stereotype
description: ''Most people have misconceptions about us jocks, with our tiny brains and our sweaty socks,'' proclaimed halfback Mike Agrillo, pacing before the statue of John Harvard in the college's Yard last weekend.

title: Travel Advisory
description: To Cut Waiting, Airport Checks Abroad Planned

title: Perspectives: Land-Use Review;   New Charter Procedure Gets Its First Test
description: Five years ago Peter Schorr made a tactical mistake at a New York City Board of Estimate hearing. Assured by a clerk that the board would adjourn before it reached his request to demap a paper street in the College Point section of Queens, he left the chamber prematurely.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 16 about pottery in Thailand misstated the price of a 12-inch Benjadol plate. It is about $14, not $140.

title: Syrian Chief Is Said to Urge Iran Not to Violate Embargo
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met today with his Iranian counterpart, President Hashemi Rafsanjani, and reportedly tried to persuade him not to send food and medicine to Iraq in violation of the United Nations embargo.

title: Review/Dance;   Riley Troupe In Sketches And Shocks
description: Words spoke louder than actions on Monday night when Deborah Riley Dance Projects appeared at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. Five of the six works presented by this troupe from Washington included spoken texts.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They think that because they haven't had anything for 40 years they can demand it all now. They want to have everything in one day if possible. You just want to say to them, you can't be lazy and stand around here, you have to build up your country and not rely on the West so much.''

title: Lilco and Cuomo Correctly Identified
description: Three cheers! We hear from the silent minority, the Long Island businessman [''Oil Pendulum Is Swinging Too Far Toward Higher Costs,'' Sept. 9] .

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES/IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;

Boy of Steel, Man of Mets: A Tale of Two Baseball Cities
description: LEAD: As a boy growing up in Pittsburgh in the 1940's, my pal Herby Caplan and I would each take six salami sandwiches to sustain us through glorious Sunday doubleheaders of Pirate baseball at old Forbes Field. The excitement was so great we barely noticed that the Pirates were regularly a last-place team.

title: The New Saladin?
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Property: Grand Central Terminal;   A New Look at a 1910 Proposal for Using Air Rights
description: Directly over the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal - sanctum sanctorum of historic preservation in New York - an office tower has been proposed that would rise 22 stories and might contain 1 million square feet of space.

title: Jane Lugaric Weds
description: Jane M. Lugaric, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Lugaric of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Kurt G. Burkhard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Burkhard of Greenbrae, Calif. The Rev. John M. Morley performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Montclair. The bride graduated from Wells College and is the West Coast account manager of Pro/Health, a medical communications concern in San Francisco. Her husband, a graduate of the University of California at Berkeley, is an associate vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco.

title: Wine;   Once Around the Bloc
description: The wine bars in the lovely Old Town in Prague are far more notable for their beer. It doesn't matter, because Czechoslovak beer is great. But for a while, during a recent visit, it seemed as if the city's charms were not going to include anything vinous.

title: In the Gulf, the Danger of a Diplomatic Solution . . .;   . . . And the Horrors of a Desert War
description: President Bush has not only embarked on his own voyage into the Persian Gulf, that Bermuda Triangle of Presidencies. Unlike his two immediate predecessors, he has dragged more than a hundred thousand of our troops with him. And as the President struggles at home, our troops have been learning to cope with a sun that can melt electrical wiring, sand so fine that few filters can keep it out of gear boxes and a growing ennui that seeps through even the most careful monitoring of our press corps.

title: Irma J. Kanter, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Irma Jean Kanter and Warren Jay Nimetz, lawyers in New York, plan to marry in November. Miss Kanter is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Kanter of Clifton, N.J. Mr. Nimetz is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Nimetz of Forest Hills, Queens.

title:
RESTAURANTS: PARIS;

Mealtime, Dealtime
description: LEAD: For as long as the world has known expense accounts, business and fine eating have gone together like bib and tucker. The tradition continues, despite a contagious obsession with fitness and despite the recession in several major industries. Granted, money managers in Boston prefer to take lunch at their desks and many old boys in various cities repair to their private clubs.

title: Jazz-Malone Accord
description: The Utah Jazz are close to a contract that will keep the forward, Karl Malone, for another eight years, the team president, Frank Layden, told an audience gathered to honor Malone at Louisiana Tech on Friday night, where Malone's college jersey, No. 32, was retired. . . The Cleveland Cavaliers on Friday matched an offer sheet to keep Steve Kerr with the team. Kerr was the National Basketball Association's best 3-point shooter last season with a long-range shooting percentage of .507. The 6-3 guard was a restricted free agent, and the Minnesota Timberwolves had made him a contract offer. Terms of the contract were not disclosed, but Kerr reportedly is to receive $1.65 million over three years. . . . The Milwaukee Bucks guard, Alvin Robertson, must attend a program on spousal abuse and perform 50 hours of community service in a pre-trial agreement in connection with a misdemeanor assault charge brought against him by his wife after an Aug. 13 incident in San Antonio.(AP)

title: Why So Little Training for American Judges?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Israelis, Appeal of Occupied Territories Grows
description: Thousands of Israelis who might not ordinarily choose to be settlers are moving to the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, driven by the housing shortage in Israel brought on by a wave of Soviet immigrants.

title: Men's Style;   The Flip Side of Jackets
description: Some things are best kept under wraps. But the sumptuous, handsomely patterned fabrics lining men's clothes this fall clearly aren't among them. In a season when what a man wears beneath his suit can say as much about him as the suit itself, linings are more than just insulation. How else to explain the proliferation of crests, crowns, elks, hunting scenes and other upper-crust insignia on the flip side of everything from suits to coats to collars?

title: Poland's Elections Threaten to Jeopardize Change
description: Poland, tired but exhilarated after 14 months of a Solidarity Government, is bracing for a presidential election campaign that threatens to divide the nation and jeopardize economic and political change.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: Savoring the Mellow Delicacy of Leeks
description: A BUNCH of leeks brings the cook close to the farm. The vegetable is sold whole, the white bulb merging gradually into the green, which ends in long trailing leaves. Rootlets cluster from the bulbs. Inside and out, this member of the onion family comes caked with the rich black soil that nourished it.

title: U.S. Said to Weigh Multi-Front Attack To Divert Iraq Force
description: Contingency plans drafted by top Army and Marine Corps officers call for a multi-front ground attack against Iraq to prevent the massing of elite Iraqi troops to guard against a possible American invasion of Kuwait, The Washington Post reported in its Sunday editions.

title: Baseball;   Wildness Leads to Loss for Pirates
description: Stan Belinda lost his control, Jim Leyland lost his patience but Ken Hill somehow didn't lose a game in which the bases-loaded walk was the chief offensive weapon.

title: Miss Morash Wed To Adam Cohen
description: Kate E. Morash, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Morash of Lexington, Mass., was married yesterday in Nantucket, Mass., to Adam Z. Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman R. Cohen of Upper Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Edward B. Anderson officiated at the Unitarian Universalist Church.

title: College Football;   Pitt Helped by Blocked Kick
description: One of college football's most uncommon scoring plays, a return of a blocked conversion kick attempt for 2 points, helped Pitt to come from behind in the fourth quarter today and tie Syracuse, 20-20, at the Carrier Dome.

description: INTER/VIEW

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Foraging For Secret Treasure: Wild Raspberries
description: LEAD: NOTHING brings the foraging instinct to the surface like wild raspberries. Bright orange in the early stages of ripening they are designed to catch the eye even from passing automobiles. Cars are regularly pulled onto the shoulders of certain Westchester highways while their drivers strip berries into empty coffee mugs or whatever else is at hand.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Son's Suicide, A Father's Promise
description: LEAD: ''DEAR Dad,'' wrote the son of the author Roger Kahn. ''After 22-plus years in the amusement park the roller coaster isn't fun anymore. I'm going to get off the ride.''

description: In an address to the American people, King Hussein of Jordan pleaded tonight for understanding of his country's increasingly difficult position in the Persian Gulf crisis but repeated his call for the removal of all American troops from the Middle East.

UNIVERSITY PRESSES;

'She Is a Man'
description: LEAD:

title: Taking on the World From 125th Street
description: Kinshasha Conwill has been at the Studio Museum in Harlem 10 years now and its executive director since 1988. In that time she has become increasingly visible, and her museum has become an ever more important forum, at a time when interest in black artists continues to grow. The changes in the museum reflect the personality and dynamism of the 39-year-old director, who has been working to expand and expose it while securing the identity it has been building throughout its 23 years.

title: Apartheid's Last Vicious Gasps
description: ''When some men suffer unjustly . . . it is the fate of those who witness their suffering to suffer the shame of it.'' This observation by the Magistrate in J. M. Coutzee's ''Waiting for the Barbarians'' (1982) could easily stand as an epigraph to ''Age of Iron,'' his superb new novel, which lays bare the effects of apartheid on the psyches of both the oppressor and the oppressed.

title: Carl Hahn's East German Homecoming
description: Wednesday will be one of the biggest days in Carl Hahn's life.

title: Treasured Family Is the Secret Wealth Of 'The Rothschilds'
description: Five hundred and five performances on Broadway in 1970 and 1971 and a vivid ''chamber'' revival in 1990: the Rothschilds are lucky. That is undeniable. Anyone will confirm it. Their name lives as a virtual guarantee of good quality. Is that why a considerable public is still interested in them? Is it because now, as always, people revel in success stories or, as some put it, the Frankfurt ghetto of the 19th century prefigures the modern ''Dallas''? We must forgive them their misguided humor. Obviously, for the Jewish family we come to know in this very Jewish play, the danger is not corruption of morals and traditions by money, but rather isolation, oppression and death. For them, evil lies not within the family, but outside it. Their story is not of a clan's decline, but of its flowering, in the context of a great adventure in war-torn Europe.

title: College Football: East;   Louisville's Field Goals Top W. Virginia
description: Klaus Wilmsmeyer kicked three field goals today to lead Louisville to a 9-7 victory over West Virginia.

title: Pays Basque
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Susan Heller Anderson's ''Two Faces of the Pays Basque'' (Travel, Aug. 12), but I cannot understand why a writer takes liberties with town names. For example, she writes of a town known as St. Jean-de-Luz. Then later the name becomes St. Jean. Why? The name is still St. Jean-de-Luz. As a Frenchman practically raised in the Pays Basque, I cannot accept shortening names of towns. They were called whatever name for centuries. There are two St. Jeans and about 30 St. Jeans-of-something or other.

title: Works in Progress;   Desert Wrap
description: ''We started testing the tank covers when the Iraqi crisis began in the gulf,'' Efraim Forem says. ''We're testing them for the Israeli Defense Forces. They wanted to know if they'd stand up to the gases.''

title: Chilean Communists in Turmoil About the Future
description: The Chilean Communist Party, an entrenched part of the political scene since 1922 and traditionally one of the most loyal to Moscow, is going through internal turmoil with ousters, mass resignations and public name calling.

title: India Sending Army After Unrest in North
description: The Indian Army today was asked to take control of the northern Indian town of Kurukshetra, where mobs of students burned Government offices and attacked officials after a student burned himself to death to protest the Government's job-quota policies.

title:
ART;

Works That Unite 2 Elements

John Fitzgerald performed the ceremony at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Centerport, L.I.

description: When the Islanders ended training camp last year by turning a goaltending trio into a duo, it was Jeff Hackett who received a hearty thank you, a bus ticket to Springfield and the predictable dollop of advice concerning what his fate might be if he just worked hard, trained right, and grew up.

title: What a Museum Owes Its Public
description: The Israel Museum is not officially a national museum, since it receives only 15 percent of its budget from the Government, but it has been from its inception an institution of symbolic weight in this country. Strategically situated between the Knesset, or Israeli Parliament, and Hebrew University, the museum was by its very location a statement of priorities on behalf of the politicians and patrons who oversaw the initial stages of its construction 25 years ago, when strong arguments could have been mounted against spending or soliciting money for anything not directly related to defense.

title: PREGNANT, ADDICTED - AND GUILTY?
description: If we are to arrest men for abusing their wives, and parents for mistreating and neglecting their children, where do we draw the line (''Pregnant, Addicted - And Guilty?'' by Jan Hoffman, Aug. 19)? Who is to decide whether drug-addicted mothers who are doing harm to their babies should not be subject to the same kinds of child-protection laws? Whose life and individual rights are to be considered more important?

title: YUGOSLAVIA FINDS ANOTHER STRUGGLE
description: As democracy continues its slow, sometimes unsteady march across Yugoslavia, it poses a question that for more than 40 years lay buried under Communist rule: How can this agglomeration of nations, religions and languages continue as a single country?

title: Japan Deports 258 Chinese Who Entered as Boat People
description: Japan today deported 258 Chinese who had entered the country posing as Vietnamese refugees, officials said. That brought to 1,520 the number returned involuntarily to China in the last year.

title: Miss Watters Weds Peter Grubstein
description: Valeska Anne Watters and Peter Sulzberger Herzog Grubstein were married yesterday at St. Bernard's Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J., by the Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin. Mrs. Grubstein is the daughter of Mrs. Henry Weeks Trimble Jr. and Wellington Morse Watters, both of New York. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Grubstein of Bernardsville.

description: An anonymous, racist note that a Yale University dean condemned as ''the stuff of Hitler'' has angered students and professors and prompted an investigation at the Yale Law School.

NEW JERSEY OPINION;

A Friendship Reborn: My Piano And I
description: LEAD: A BIG chunk of my past pulled up in a small van recently and moved into my house. It's an unlikely story, but I once again own the piano I gave away 29 years ago.

title: College Football: Midwest;   Michigan Rushes Past U.C.L.A.
description: Jon Vaughn, the nation's rushing leader, ran for 288 yards and 3 touchdowns today as Michigan trampled U.C.L.A., 38-15.

description: After seven smooth weeks of handling the Persian Gulf crisis, the White House is fumbling several critical gulf issues on Capitol Hill and finds itself grappling with internal tensions that strain its vaunted air of collegiality.

title: Louis Calta, 77, Dies;Reported on Theater
description: Louis Calta, a former reporter in the drama department of The New York Times, died yesterday at Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 77 years old.

title: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: One Germany - Second in a series.;   As Marriage Nears, Germans in the Wealthy West Fear a Cost in Billions
description: For most Germans, the burning questions of unification center on money. From Chancellor Helmut Kohl down to Otto Normalverbraucher - the average German consumer - they are wondering what will it cost, who is going to pay for it and how?

title: Bridge
description: A tournament that could claim to be both the world's strongest and the world's smallest was played last week in Zandvoort, the Netherlands, sponsored by Europe's largest options exchange, the EOE Optiebeurs of Amsterdam. There were only 16 pairs, but almost all of them were of world class.

title: Finance Chiefs Back Money Rein
description: Most of the world's industrial and developing nations decided this weekend not to try to shield consumers from higher energy prices, endorsing a strategy of tight monetary policies that increases the risk of a recession.

title: Yankees Add to Red Sox Woes
description: On their way out the door, the Boston Red Sox stumbled badly again. In the last three weeks, they have lost a division lead, lost their best pitcher and, it sometimes has seemed, lost all of their bluster and confidence. They somehow even figured out how to make the Yankees look good.

title: Ford and G.M. Closing Plants
description: The Ford Motor Company will close three plants this week and the General Motors Corporation will shut down a Chevrolet Caprice plant for two weeks because of slow sales, the auto makers said Friday.

title: Commuters Agonize as Road Repairs Spread
description: It is 2 P.M. on the Cross-Bronx Expressway, and for thousands of cars inching toward the George Washington Bridge, the air is heavy with exhaust. Half a mile ahead, where the highway and the Henry Hudson Parkway feed into the bridge's seven westbound lanes, traffic is stopped.

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED IN HIKER SLAYINGS
description: A 38-year-old man has been charged in the slayings of two young hikers on a section of the Appalachian Trail in central Pennsylvania.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Bhutto's Opponent Says She Is the Crucial Issue
description: Pakistan's caretaker Prime Minister, Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, says the national elections on Oct. 24 will be won or lost not on issues of Government policy but on a single political question: was the dismissal of Benazir Bhutto justified?

title: Warring Cambodian Factions Accept Proposal by Sihanouk
description: Leaders of three Cambodian guerrilla factions agreed today to a compromise proposal offered by Prince Norodom Sihanouk in efforts to resume talks that could end the nation's long civil war.

title: Free Magazines for the Gulf Troops
description: Magazine publishers, rallying to provide reading matter to American troops in the Middle East, have volunteered to donate more than 19,000 magazines a month to the United States Air Force for its desert operation.

title: Cardinal Is Denounced In Rally at St. Patrick's
description: Two hundred chanting demonstrators rallied outside St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning to denounce John Cardinal O'Connor for his stands against homosexuality and abortion, but they did not disrupt the Mass inside, where he was the celebrant.

title: Test Case for Obscenity Standards Begins Today in an Ohio Courtroom
description: The passions ignited here last spring over an exhibition of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe will be revisited in a Cincinnati courtroom Monday when for the first time in this country a museum and its director will stand trial on criminal charges over work it displayed.

title: After Silence, Japan's Army Pushes for Armed Gulf Role
description: After four decades of silence, Japan's military has openly split with some of the country's political leaders in a bitter debate over whether and how Japan should contribute forces to the Persian Gulf in what may become the military's first excursion abroad since World War II.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the dates that major economic indicators are scheduled to be released this week.

title: Chronicle
description: To coincide with the 40th anniversary of her accession to the throne in 1952, QUEEN ELIZABETH will star in a BBC documentary on her job as head of state of the United Kingdom and her constitutional role in the 15 Commonwealth nations. Filming will begin next month, when President FRANCESCO COSSIGA of Italy makes a state visit to London.

title: Eagles Finally Win a Game
description: Randall Cunningham threw for two touchdowns and Andrew Toney ran for 103 yards today as the Philadelphia Eagles beat the Los Angeles Rams, 27-21, for their first victory of the season.

title: Books of The Times;   After 2 Decades of Silence, a Novel on Alcoholism
description: Sams in a Dry Season

title: The Accelerating Schedule Of Hardcover Production
description: FOR years, publishers have occasionally rushed ''instant'' paperback books into print to cash in on interest stimulated by the daily headlines. Now, however, they are increasingly speeding up the deadlines for hardcover books. Driven by financial and competitive pressures and aided by growing technical sophistication, more and more publishers are trimming the average yearlong interim from completed manuscript to finished book to as little as three or four months.

title: Rift on Software Arouses Concerns
description: Like an earthquake that rattles windows and breaks china but leaves the roof intact, the decision last week by the International Business Machines Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation to pursue separate paths in developing software has filled many people in the computer industry with anxiety about the next tremor.

title: Spectacular, but No Surprise
description: Even though the playing field has been the same - 300 feet by 160 - since 1912, more has become common in college football: more scoring, more passing, more new records. Because the players are larger and faster, better conditioned and better coached, they do more.

title: Jets Confront Bills With New Outlook
description: The last time the Jets played the Buffalo Bills it was two days before Christmas and the 21,148 diehard fans who showed up last December in Giants Stadium made up the smallest home crowd for a nonreplacement game since Dec. 14, 1963, when the team still played in the Polo Grounds.

title: Pirates Get a Breather
description: Suspense has been and long will be an integral part of every pennant race. It was missing here today. Some of the fans at Three Rivers Stadium may have been anxious in the late innings, but it was probably because they were worried about getting home in time to watch the Steelers against the Raiders.

title: Withdrawals Set a Record
description: Customers withdrew $15.1 billion more than they deposited from the nation's savings and loan associations in April, the Government said Friday. The amount was a record.

title: Reviews/Music;   Javanese Shadow Puppets
description: Wayang kulit, the Indonesian shadow-puppet play that the court performers from the sultan's palace in Jogjakarta presented on Friday night and Saturday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is an often earthily popular art that translates uncomfortably to an American context.

title: When Decline Hurts
description: Massachusetts voters turned angrily against incumbents in primaries last week, and many other states report a mood of hostility toward politicians. Why? The experts talk of high state taxes, corruption, cynicism. But a far more profound phenomenon may underlie the discontent.

title: Accounts
description: * Meineke Discount Muffler Shops Inc., Charlotte, N.C., a unit of GFN Ltd., London, to Partners & Shevack, New York. Media buying and planning will continue to be handled by Corinthian Communications, New York. The account was previously handled by Garrison Productions in Charlotte. Meineke will spend $26 million on its entire advertising effort.

title: Art School, Still Needy, Is Thanking Its Champion
description: When he first visited the fledgling New York Studio School 25 years ago, the eminent art historian Meyer Schapiro was ''very moved'' at the sight of students doing carpentry, wiring and painting to turn their seedy premises into a working space.

title: In Shift, Fed Puts Emphasis on Inflation
description: After 15 months of gradually lowering interest rates to avoid a recession, the Federal Reserve has shifted strategy and is trying to freeze rates at their present levels, having concluded that inflation is now the greatest threat to the American economy.

title: Swiss Limit Nuclear Power
description: Swiss citizens have voted to forbid the construction of nuclear power plants for the rest of the century but not to abandon nuclear power altogether.

title: Mandatory Auto Insurance Really Raises Rates;   Supplemental Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Has Created Model Health System
description: To the Editor:

title: Warmup Unit For Calves
description: A hockey player, Chris Smith, who once hurt his knee during play has developed a device for stretching the calf muscles before and after exercise. He designed ProStretch, a plastic foot rocker that is made to condition the leg muscles so as to avoid injury.

title: William Randolph Hearst 3d Is Wed To Margaret Crawford in California
description: The marriage of Margaret Kerr Crawford to William Randolph Hearst 3d took place yesterday at the Ventana Inn in Big Sur, Calif. The Rev. Angus Dun Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Hearst is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bartholomew Crawford of New York. A graduate of the National Cathedral School in Washington and Smith College, the bride is the chairwoman of the AIDS Home Care and Hospice Project of the Junior League of San Francisco. Her father is a senior producer of the ''CBS Evening News'' in New York. She is a granddaughter of the late Kenneth Gale Crawford, Newsweek's Washington columnist from 1961 to 1970.

title: Review/Dance;   The Lyons Opera Ballet Tangles With Zappa
description: Ballets to music by the rock star Frank Zappa? Anything is possible. The Lyons Opera Ballet has just made that point at the International Dance Biennial here by inviting three Americans - Lucinda Childs, Karole Armitage and Ralph Lemon - to choreograph to their countryman's highly undanceable music.

title: De Klerk Arrives in the U.S. for Talks With Bush
description: President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa, citing the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. as an inspiration for the changes he has begun in his own country, arrived in Washington today for talks with President Bush.

title: NATO STRUGGLING TO REDEFINE ITSELF
description: Having concentrated entirely on deterring Soviet aggression over the past 40 years, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is now struggling to find a new role for itself after the collapse of Communism and the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

title: Bombs Found On Store Roof In Brooklyn
description: Nineteen gasoline bombs were discovered during the weekend on the roof of the Family Red Apple, one of two Korean-owned grocery stores that have been the target of an eight-month boycott, the police said yesterday.

title: Reviews/Music;   Billy Idol Moves On, But the Fans Hold Back
description: Billy Idol came up with one of the winning rock formulas of the early 1980's: a drum-machine dance beat plus rock guitar chords plus baritone crooning derived from Jim Morrison and David Bowie. With his bleached-blond hair and his lips perpetually curled in a sneer, he quickly became a staple of MTV, singing arrogant, slightly ominous songs like ''White Wedding'' and ''Rebel Yell.'' But tonight at Brendan Byrne Arena here, both the formula and Mr. Idol himself sounded enervated as he failed to stir up much enthusiasm for songs from his new album, ''Charmed Life'' (Chrysalis).

title: Correction
description: A front-page article Friday about foster care misstated the title of the Federal law that was meant to help troubled families stay together. The law was the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980, not the Juvenile Justice and Deliquency Prevention Act.

title: Sharon Ostow, Publisher, Is Married
description: Sharon E. Ostow, the founder and publisher of The Northeast Equine Journal in Keene, N.H., was married yesterday in New York to James A. Rousmaniere Jr., the editor and president of The Keene Sentinel. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman officiated at the Water Club.

title: INSIDE
description: A Matter of Marks

title: Khrushchev Memoir Tells of Castro Plea For Attack on U.S.
description: Fidel Castro urged the Soviet Union to attack the United States in 1962 because he feared an American invasion of Cuba during the Cuban missile crisis, Nikita S. Khrushchev said in portions of his memoirs published today.

title: Bears Win on a 52-Yard Kick
description: The Chicago Bears and the Minnesota Vikings knocked each other silly today at Soldier Field, with the Bears usually getting the first and the last licks. Minnesota finally caught up in big hits and on the scoreboard, tying the score at 16-16 with 1 minute 5 seconds left.

title: Cricket Is Foreign to Most Americans
description: ON Sundays during the summer and early fall, Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx is a sea of white. Hundreds play the slips, bowl to the wicket and swing for sixes in the crisp uniform of the signature sport of the British Commonwealth - cricket.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Blending Movements And Words
description: Robert Frost once defined poetry as that literary quality that tends to get lost in translation. On Saturday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, much theatrical poetry got lost because there was not enough translation.

title: U.S. Energy Options (and Habits)
description: From the day Ronald Reagan arrived in Washington until just before Saddam Hussein's troops reached Kuwait City, energy policy was a fringe issue in the United States. Now, the deployment of American troops in the Persian Gulf has left many policy makers wondering whether the United States has options other than force to assure an adequate suppply of energy.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Rowers Summoned To Beat the Clock
description: LEAD: WITH the fall comes rowing's popular head races. The Challenge of the Hudson, an all-day regatta in Verplanck, N.Y., and the Head-of-the-Charles Regatta in Cambridge, Mass., will attract hundreds of thousands of spectators and thousands of rowers racing against the clock.

title: El Salvador Chief Lobbying to Stop U.S. Aid Cuts
description: President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador begins an intensive three-day lobbying campaign on Capitol Hill on Monday in an effort to thwart legislation that would cut United States military aid to his country by 50 percent next year.

title: Lord Swann, 70, Former Chief of BBC And Educator, Dies
description: Lord Swann, the governor and chairman of the British Broadcasting Corporation from 1973 to 1980, died on Saturday, the BBC said. He was 70 years old.

title: Excerpts From Statement by Iraqi President Warning of the Effects of War
description: Following are excerpts from the statement issued today by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in the name of the Revolutionary Command Council. Parts of the text were translated from a dispatch by the Iraqi News Agency and a broadcast by the Iraqi radio. The British Broadcasting Corporation provided other portions in English.

title: Last Planned Refugee Flight From Iraq Arrives in the U.S.
description: A jet carrying 112 people from Iraqi-occupied Kuwait arrived in the United States today after a flight from Baghdad via London.

title: With Its Huge Banks Weakening, Japan Cuts Lending to the World
description: At Japan's powerful banks, which in recent years have served as financiers to the world, profits are tumbling and a global investment spree is slowing.

title: Gooden And Bats Click For Mets
description: With Dwight Gooden pitching and Darryl Strawberry hitting, and with all their flags otherwise flying in the winds of Wrigley Field, the Mets did what they could do today to stay in hot pursuit as they turned into the final full week of their pennant race.

title: Ballot Becomes a Burden in California
description: Like millions of California voters, Cyrus Chartres will not only vote for a new governor in November but will also decide whether he wants to create an elected environmental ''advocate'' for the state, limit the terms of state lawmakers, buy unlogged forests and allow the state to put out contracts for prison labor, just to mention a few of the choices on the ballot.

title: New Creative Director For Young & Rubicam
description: After barely a year in the top creative spot at the New York office of Hal Riney & Partners, Helayne Spivak is leaving to become the executive creative director of the New York office of Young & Rubicam.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Tuba City Journal;   Returning, Hollywood Lights Up The Desert
description: It is not unusual for Hollywood or Madison Avenue to use the multicolored desert of the Navajo reservation for commercials, but only the older people remember when film companies came to town, usually to shoot a western.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Struggles In History And Myth
description: Deep beneath the Cathedral of St. John the Divine is a striking new space for dance. Its potential was revealed on Friday night when the Forces of Nature Dance Company presented ''Coming Forth by Day'' in the cathedral's Theater of the Crypt. The event was the company's third annual benefit and the first dance performance in this theater, which had previously been used only for dramatic productions since it opened in June.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: SWIMMING;

Shattered Dream
description: LEAD: IT was, while it lasted, a dream job, a well-paid position coaching a financially secure national team of dedicated athletes who showed such rapid improvement they seemed on the verge of winning their nation's first major international medals in their sport.

title: Foyt Seriously Injured
description: A. J. Foyt, who has won more Indy-car races than any other driver, was in satisfactory condition today after a crash in the Texaco-Havoline 200. Foyt broke his left knee and heel and dislocated his right foot.

title: Breech Sets Mark As Bengals Roll
description: Jim Breech got the Cincinnati Bengals' sluggish offense going today and it never stopped.

title: Business Scene;   Inventory Data Can Be Deceptive
description: THE sluggish American economy is in danger of sliding into a recession. Few Americans dispute that; yet they are being told by economists to take comfort. The national economy will muddle through, as long as companies maintain small stockpiles of unsold goods. The problem with this thesis is that when sales plunge recessions can be born anyway, no matter how small the stockpiles.

title: Rallying Blue Jays Take 1-Game Lead
description: The Toronto Blue Jays moved back into first place in the American League East today, rallying for a 4-4 tie in the ninth inning and beating the Cleveland Indians, 5-4, in the 10th on Mookie Wilson's single.

title: U.S. Spent $21.5 Billion in 1989 To Support Families of Teen-Agers
description: The Federal Government spent more than $21.5 billion last year on welfare programs for families started by teen-agers, said a report released today.

title: Question Box
description: Shutouts in a Row

title: Elsie A. Crum, a Lawyer, Is Married To Roger Coy, a Banker, in New York
description: Elsie Alberta Crum, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Crum of Brooklyn, was married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University to Roger Ellington Coy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lopez Livingston Coy of Coral Springs, Fla. Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu of Cape Town, the Anglican Primate of Southern Africa, officiated.

title: 2 Debtors' Role in Silverado's Fall
description: They were the highest of the highfliers, pillars of Denver's business and social communities, with dreams of reshaping the city's skyline and suburban shopping habits.

title: Kendall W. Goodwyn; Magazine Editor, 79
description: Kendall W. Goodwyn, retired managing editor of Popular Science magazine, died on Sept. 15 at the Rosary Hill Nursing Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Cutty Sark Is Updating Its Image
description: CUTTY SARK, once one of the most popular brands of Scotch, is trying to make a comeback with a $45 million advertising campaign intended to update its image.

title: Proposals for a U.S. Energy Policy: Some Possible, Most Not
description: From the day Ronald Reagan arrived in Washington until the day before Saddam Hussein's troops reached Kuwait City, energy policy was a fringe issue in the United States. Now, the deployment of American troops in the Persian Gulf to assure a steady flow of oil has left many policy makers wondering whether the United States has options other than force to insure an adequate supply of energy.

title: New Air Force Chief Is Chosen
description: President Bush on Friday nominated Gen. Merrill McPeak to replace the Air Force Chief of Staff dismissed for discussing American military strategy in the Middle East, officials said. General McPeak, 54 years old, has been commander of Pacific Air Forces since July 1988. If confirmed by the Senate, General McPeak would succeed Gen. Michael Dugan, who was dismissed Sept. 17.

title: Cranston Says He Will Vote Against Souter Confirmation
description: Senator Alan Cranston of California, the second-ranking member of the Senate Democratic leadership, said today that he would vote against confirming Judge David H. Souter, President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court.

title: Review/Film Festival;   Capturing the Moral Code of an African Village
description: ''I violated tradition by not killing Saga,'' a man says of his own brother, an adulterer whose punishment by death fell to his sibling. ''My conscience bothers me.'' His aged mother tries to soothe him to sleep, saying, ''That is the way of the world.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cholestech Corp., Hayward, Calif., appointed Dr. Eric McAllister vice president of clinical affairs and Dr. Robert A. Baughman director of preclinical development.

title: Peddlers Irk Stores In Harlem
description: On a recent afternoon, vendors lined several blocks of West 125th Street practically elbow to elbow, standing by tables or crouching by blankets displaying their goods, which ranged from imitation Louis Vuitton bags to tapes of Malcolm X speeches.

title: Chronicle
description: CLARA HALE, who began rescuing children off the streets in 1941 and whose Hale House in Harlem has been the home to 800 unwanted babies, was hospitalized over the weekend and is expected to be released today. She was admitted on Friday to Lenox Hill Hospital complaining of chest pains. After tests, the attending doctor has given her ''a clean bill of health,'' said Jesse Devore, the spokesman for Hale House, which Mrs. Hale founded.

title: Le Pen, Isolated in France, Opposes Gulf Involvement
description: The flags of France and its regions flapped noisily and the music was rousing as the far-right leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen, boomed out his nationalistic message today to about 15,000 supporters from atop a blue pyramid-turned-podium.

title: Miss Rapp Weds Joseph M. Lodato
description: Linnette Claire Sessan Rapp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lennart Rapp of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Joseph Michael Lodato, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ross Lodato of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Leo P. Gorman officiated at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside.

title: Dole Hints at Revising Rates for Income Tax
description: With the deadline for reaching a deficit-cutting budget agreement a week away, Senator Bob Dole gave the first public hint that Republican opposition to tinkering with income tax rates could be cracking.

title: Ruling Adds to Uncertainty On Newspaper Sales Taxes
description: In a ruling that adds uncertainty to the question of taxing newspaper and magazine sales, the Iowa Supreme Court unexpectedly upheld a state law last week that taxes the sale of magazines but exempts that of newspapers.

title: The Value of Pigs And Other Insights At Mead Film Festival
description: In the short documentary film ''Outrageous Taxi Stories,'' a New York cabby named John looks into the camera and speaks of power. ''You know,'' he says, ''you're driving down Park Avenue on a Sunday afternoon, and there are all these people with their doormen whistling at you, and you're just cruising down Park Avenue not picking up any of them. That's power.''

title: Outdoors: A 35-Year Flirtation Blossoms
description: ALTHOUGH I began saltwater fly fishing more than 35 years ago, it wasn't until this summer that I became deeply hooked by the sport.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Panel Examines L.I. Law Firm Of D'Amato Kin
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn is looking into allegations of influence-peddling on military contracts by the Long Island law firm of the brother of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, investigators said yesterday.

title: Metro Matters;   New York City On the Rocks? Don't Bet on It
description: A looming recession, coupled with soaring energy prices, presage the loss of nearly 100,000 jobs in the first year of the new decade and will keep the number of employed New Yorkers from expanding at all in the next 10 years.

title: Accusations On Neil Bush
description: Federal regulators have brought conflict-of-interest accusations against Neil Bush as a director of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver on three matters:

title: Straight Talk on Pakistan
description: Pakistan's democracy is in peril. Its demise threatens relations with Washington, already strained by Islamabad's pursuit of nuclear weapons. A half-billion dollars in U.S. aid is at stake. Under such circumstances, the highest obligation of American diplomacy is to speak plainly. The grim example of Iraq demonstrates how failure to convey diplomatic concerns bluntly might encourage disastrous miscalculations.

title: A Quick Fix: One-Man Patrol Cars
description: Eventually, expanding the 26,000-member New York City police force will help contain crime. But recruitment and training take time. And even increasing the size of the force won't make a dramatic difference unless officers are deployed more efficiently. Too many are busy at desk jobs, or rushing to emergencies that the Fire Department could handle - or riding in two-officer patrol cars when, in some cases, one officer would do.

title: Pavarotti and Others To Sing at Tucker Gala
description: Jerry Hadley, Marilyn Horne, Elena Obraztsova, Luciano Pavarotti, Samuel Ramey and Carol Vaness will head the program at the 1990 Richard Tucker Music Foundation gala on Nov. 11 at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Trinidad's Once-Civil Society Frays Along Racial Lines
description: When he eased his way to the dais with the aid of a sculpted wooden cane to open an international conference this week, a smile briefly played upon the face of Prime Minister Arthur N. R. Robinson as he bathed in expressions of sympathy and admiration.

title: The 80's Party Is Over . . .
description: LEAD: America had a party in the 1980's, and we - the ''twentysomething generation'' -weren't invited. While high-flying S.& L. robber barons were making millions with other people's money, while men of bad conscience were constructing investment houses of paper, we were making our way through college and graduate school, taking out loans to finance our educations.

title: Taiwan to Import Sugar
description: Taiwan will import sugar for the first time because of falling domestic production and a rise in consumption, the state-owned Taiwan Sugar Corporation said last week. Taiwan, traditionally a sugar exporter, will import up to 50,000 metric tons, a company spokesman said. He declined to give a schedule. The island will consume 500,000 tons of sugar in 1990, up from 480,000 tons in 1989, he said.

title: Will Changes in Schools Improve Reading and Math Scores?
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Serious About the U.N.
description: In a wondrous sea change, the United Nations has silenced most of its detractors. A body once scorned as a dithering talk-shop has now mobilized impressively to punish Iraq's aggressions in the Persian Gulf. Elsewhere, from Afghanistan to Namibia, from Cambodia to Central America, the U.N. has also offered a glimpse of President Bush's hopes for a new world order to resolve conflicts by multilateral diplomacy and collective security.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: On the Sidewalks, Business Is Booming
description: Steven Frost makes his living on the street, selling toy spiders that jump when you squeeze a rubber ball. They are $3 each, two for $5.

title: Gooden Gives Mets a Show
description: The sight does not yet rank near the checkpoint that Met teams of the past once sought, the dirt upon Tom Seaver's right knee as evidence that his form was sound and their franchise was safe for a day.

title: Market Place;   When a Big Bull Is Forced to Sell
description: IT is an old Wall Street story, the kind grizzled veterans tell to rookies. Now, in the case of the stock of a Kentucky insurance company, the story has come to life.

title: Mandatory Auto Insurance Really Raises Rates;   On Policyholder's Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Victoria Bennett, Film Maker, Wed
description: Victoria Elizabeth Bennett, a daughter of Mrs. Herbert H. Miller Jr. of Rowayton, Conn., and the late Robert A. Bennett, was married yesterday to David Matthew Fite, a son of Constance Alderson Fite of New York and the late Warner Fite 2d. The Rev. Edward R. Danks performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Noroton, Conn.

title: Mandatory Auto Insurance Really Raises Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Opera;   In 'Moses und Aron,' a Debate With the Self
description: Arnold Schoenberg's ''Moses und Aron'' is one of opera's legendary monsters, so rarely seen on the stage that its fearsome nature tends to be exaggerated. Not that the fears are entirely imaginary. First sketched out in the early 1920's as an oratorio, ''Moses'' could hardly be more theatrically static. Its 12-tone musical idiom contributes further to a sense of monumental stasis. The drama revolves around a theological debate between the title characters that is unmatched in opera history for didactic intent.

title: Reviews/Television;   Vanessa Redgrave In Williams's 'Orpheus'
description: Sir Peter Hall first directed his version of Tennessee Williams's ''Orpheus Descending'' starring Vanessa Redgrave for the London stage. Then, still with Miss Redgrave, it moved to Broadway. Now that New York production has been adapted for television by Sir Peter, using a location in Jacksonville, Fla., to simulate the nasty small-minded Two River County in Mississippi in 1948. The remarkably effective film may be seen at 8 tonight on TNT on cable television.

title: U.N., as Well, Is Entering the Post-Cold-War Era
description: The first gathering of the United Nations General Assembly in the post-cold-war era moves into its most active phase this week as heads of government and foreign ministers from virtually every country arrive here for two weeks of speeches and meetings that could help to define an emerging new world order.

title: Shanghai Breezes
description: On a foggy morning about a dozen years ago, passengers on a flying jalopy were told that Beijing was socked in and the pilot had been diverted to Shanghai. We landed at a deserted airfield; no planes were expected at Shanghai that morning, and nobody on the ground quite knew what to do with a planeload of transients. Hungry and disconsolate, we sat in a barren waiting room, a handful of Westerners stranded in a Communist wasteland.

title: Success Looms for Maker Of Civil War Film Series
description: Ken Burns, the film maker whose epic documentary, ''The Civil War'' has been called a television masterpiece and the best American film of the year, is ''very guarded'' about how success may change his life.

title: Chronicle
description: CLAUDE POMPIDOU and 80 friends flew into New York on Friday for the weekend. The widow of a former French president, Mrs. Pompidou was beating the drums for her foundation, which aids elderly and disabled people in France.

title: 15th-Century Portrait Is Stolen From Museum
description: A 15th-century painting was stolen from the Correr Museum in St. Mark's Square on Friday, and art experts quickly demanded more guards and better security systems The painting, Lazzaro Bastiani's 20-by-16-inch portrait of the Venetian doge Fran-cesco Foscari, was removed from its frame in the second-floor gallery of the city-run museum during regular museum hours.

title: Dole Hints at Willingness to Alter Income Tax Rate in a Budget Deal
description: In the first public hint that Republican opposition to income tax rate increases may be cracking, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas said today that budget negotiators were looking at ways to raise taxes for wealthy Americans that would ''pierce the so-called bubble.''

title: The Breakfast Of a Champion Fan
