description: A new translation of the Bible that uses contemporary language and eliminates many male-centered terms and all the archaic thees and thous was officially introduced yesterday for use in the nation's major Protestant churches.

title: Accounts
description: * Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, New York, resigned as agency of record for the Genesee Brewing Company, a beer maker in Rochester. They have handled the account since 1987. The agency said a decrease in spending on advertising to $3 million from $12 million in three years made the company a less attractive client.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In Paris, the actor ALAIN DELON has revealed himself as a buyer of Modigliani's ''La Belle Epiciere,'' for which he paid a record $11.5 million for last March. But to finance his half of the painting, which he bought with FRANCIS BOUYGUES, a construction tycoon, he will put up 32 paintings from his own art collection to be auctioned in Paris on Nov. 25.

title: Pirates Scrabble, Then Win
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates would be a natural for ''Sesame Street.'' Bert and Ernie could use the Pirates to teach the show's young viewers about the letter B. The Pirates have Bobby Bonilla and Barry Bonds, and they also have Backman, Bell, Bream, Belliard, Belinda, Bair and Bilardello.

title: Judge Fines USX $4.1 Million in Conspiracy Case
description: A Federal District judge here levied the maximum possible fine on the USX Corporation today and gave prison terms to two top union officials who had been found guilty of conspiring with the company to obtain lucrative pensions in exchange for granting concessions in labor negotiations.

title: In Opposing Souter, Bradley Raises Issue Of Abortion in Race
description: Senator Bill Bradley, by declaring he opposes the nomination of Judge David H. Souter to the United States Supreme Court, has drawn fire from his Republican opponent and brought the abortion issue into the Senate campaign here.

title: Pact Is Extended
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company agreed this week to a one-year extension of its franchise to provide electricity to Chicago customers. Edison's old contract will expire on Dec. 31, but a string of power failures have raised questions about the utility's reliability as it has been trying to negotiate its first new franchise with Chicago in 42 years.

title: Pop Radio Shares Decline by 33.9%
description: Shares of the Pop Radio Corporation lost 33.9 percent of their value in over-the-counter trading today after the Heritage Media Corporation disclosed that it might not complete its $20.50-a-share offer for the New York-based customized music service. Pop Radio's stock fell $5.125, to $10.

title: White Sox Get Sanders
description: Deion Sanders, the Atlanta Falcons' defensive back who was released by the Yankees on Monday, was claimed on waivers yesterday by the Chicago White Sox. He has until Tuesday to accept or reject the waiver claim. If he rejects it, he is a free agent and can talk to all teams.

title: Boston Edison Names New Chief Executive
description: The Boston Edison Company, the city's electric utility, named its president yesterday to be its next chief executive.

title: Ben Gradus Film Producer, 72
description: Ben Gradus, a film producer who worked closely with Harry S. Truman to produce 26 half-hour programs recalling major events in the President's life, died Tuesday at Greater Northern Weschester Hospital in Mt. Kisco, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Postal Service Felt Wary of Bus Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Seeks 25% Reduction In 10-Year Plan
description: Squeezed between ambitious plans to build schools, modernize hospitals and improve highways and the fiscal constraints of a faltering economy, Mayor David N. Dinkins has called for a 25 percent cut in the 10-year capital spending plan now being drawn up.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Modernizing Traditions

title: De Klerk's Trip Lifts His People's Hopes
description: President F. W. de Klerk's trip to the United States this week has encouraged South African whites to believe that his policies may be breaking their country out of the international isolation that came about as a result of apartheid.

title: Review/Television;   From Many Nations, a Single Force
description: ''Blue Helmets: The Story of United Nations Peacekeeping,'' a 90-minute documentary tonight at 9 on Channel 13, was made before the current show of force in the Persian Gulf, but it demonstrates how untypical the latest United Nations effort is. In the past, the multi-national contingents that have found themselves in trouble spots like Cyprus and Lebanon were not supposed to be taking sides.

title: U.S. Urged to Revitalize Work on Nuclear Fusion
description: A Federal panel urged the Government yesterday to revitalize its languishing effort to harness nuclear fusion, saying the budget of the chief fusion research program should double over the next six years.

title: Capturing New York Anew From a Camera's Perspective
description: IN photographic terms, New York City is a contrary utopia where glamour rubs shoulders with desolation, sophistication does battle with artlessness and the cliched coexists with the outrageous. For the peripatetic connoisseur, the city's visible charms rest not so much with its postcard-quality vistas and landmarks as with its unexpected combinations of vast public grandeur and small, often overlooked private spaces.

title: MCA 4Acquisition
description: Talks about a possible acquisition of MCA Inc. by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan were postponed until later next week or the week after, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday. The talks had been scheduled to start on Sunday. No reason was given for the postponement. MCA's stock slipped $2.25 yesterday, to $59.

title: Medjugorje Journal;   Do 4 Behold the Virgin? Bishop Is Not a Believer
description: The Vatican has warned that church-sponsored pilgrimages to this mountain village are banned, but that has not stopped Roman Catholic pilgrims from crowding into Medjugorje, where the Virgin Mary is said to have been appearing daily to four young people for the last decade.

title: Burmese Said to Harass Embassies
description: The Burmese Government is harassing foreign diplomats by sending soldiers into the compounds of Western embassies and by rounding up the missions' Burmese employees for interrogation, a diplomat said today.

title: Evacuation of Brazilians Set
description: The United Nations today authorized Brazil to evacuate 256 Brazilians in Iraq on a special flight of an Iraqi commercial plane, Brazil's Foreign Ministry said. After the United Nations Security Council authorized an air blockade of Iraq on Tuesday, prohibiting planes from entering or leaving Iraq without special permission, a U.N. commission authorized Brazil to contract the Boeing 747. The group could return home this weekend, provided that 82 more visas are issued, a ministry spokesman said.

title: Argentine Privatizations
description: The Government of Argentina plans to sell the state-owned gas, electric and water companies and the Buenos Aires subway system, President Carlos Saul Menem said today.

title: Chaplain's Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amdura Corp., Denver, said a bankruptcy court had approved the sale of certain assets of its subsidiary, the Amdura National Distributing Co., to the United Hardware Distributing Co., Plymouth, Minn. The purchase price will depend on asset values as of the date of closing.

title: Deposit Fund Condition Is Worsening
description: The condition of the fund that insures deposits at banks appeared to be worsening, as regulators today revised their estimates of its losses for the year by 50 percent, to more than $3 billion.

title: New York Sets Stricter Rules On Emissions
description: New York State yesterday adopted new pollution rules for cars and light trucks that put it on a par with California, which has the tightest standards in the nation.

title: Stocks Fall As Oil Sale Impact Fades
description: President Bush's plan to sell a token five million barrels, or less than a day's supply, from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve sent oil prices lower and stock prices higher yesterday -but only briefly. Oil prices quickly soared and stocks plunged.

title: What Students Think About Condom Plan
description: The teen-age girls, clustered on a sidewalk yesterday outside Martin Luther King Jr. High School in Manhattan, wore almost identical gold earrings, giggled in unison over a soap opera star passing by and agreed that the school system's proposal to distribute condoms was a prudent move.

title: Review/Dance;   In Boots And Jeans, The French Dos-a-Dos
description: The women came in their ''Gunsmoke'' dresses, hair piled high, and the men wore jeans with the cowboy boots that are all the rage in France.

title: Archibald A. Talmage, Executive, 86
description: Archibald A. Talmage, vice president of the Electric Bond and Share Company, a New York holding company that is now Ebasco Services Inc., died on Tuesday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in West Cornwall, Conn.

title: Unisys to Halt Common Stock Dividend
description: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that it would suspend its quarterly dividend on its common shares. The dividend on the company's preferred shares would remain intact.

title: Our Towns;   Board Won't Buy A Pig in a Co-op, Even if He's Cute
description: After a long day in customer relations, Nick DiGiaimo is happy to get home to his quiet suburban street. When he walks into his co-op apartment, the first thing he does is go upstairs to the bedroom and feed the pig. ''Hello, Fideau,'' he said, opening the cage, and the pig raced by, bounded downstairs and went right for the supper dish in the dining room.

title: National Gains on Capital Gains
description: After weeks of bickering about cutting the capital gains tax, and with Monday's deadline looming, budget negotiators appear within reach of a compromise. And not just any compromise. This may be one case in which political posturing is about to produce an economic pot of gold.

title: Rockets Obtain Smith
description: The Houston Rockets obtained the 6-foot-3-inch guard Kenny Smith from the Atlanta Hawks yesterday in a trade involving three other players. Also going to Houston was Roy Marble, the forward who was suspended for 30 games last season for drug abuse. The Hawks acquired John Lucas, a 36-year-old guard, and Tim McCormick, a forward who missed most of last season because of two knee operations. (AP)

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the price of crude oil misstated the Monday closing price of the New York Mercantile Exchange's contract for November delivery. It was $38.25 a barrel, a record that was then broken by Wednesday's closing price of $38.67.

title: For Want of Recognition, Chief Justice Is Ousted
description: The chief justice of Washington State, a widely respected judge who has drawn little controversy in his six years in the post, was thrown off the bench last week by voters who chose instead a 39-year-old lawyer who has never been an elected judge and who did not campaign.

title: Charles R. Kaufman, Lawyer, 81
description: Charles R. Kaufman, a founder of the Chicago law firm Vedder, Price, Kaufman & Kramholz, died Wednesday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 81 years old and lived in Winnetka, Ill.

title: Thomas B. Greenslade, Teacher, 80
description: Thomas B. Greenslade, a science teacher in the New York City public schools for more than 30 years, died on Tuesday at Riverside Hospital in Columbus, Ohio. He was 80 years old and lived in Gambier, Oh.

title: Tribes to Hear Proposal to Revamp Indian Bureau
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. has called American Indian tribal leaders from around the country for a meeting on Friday that he says will point a course toward greater self-determination for the tribes.

title: Cockroaches Dumped in Court
description: A woman has pleaded no contest to a contempt citation for dumping thousands of cockroaches in a courtroom to protest conditions at her rented house. The woman, Maria Terwen, 67 years old, entered the plea Tuesday in Morgan County Court but was not fined. Ms. Terwen dumped the roaches on the Magistrate Margaret Gordon's desk at a hearing on a complaint by Ms. Terwen's landlord, who said she owed $5,400 in rent. Ms. Terwen, who has 17 dogs and cats, said there were so many roaches in the house she must skim roaches from her cats' milk bowl. Court officials halted the rent case after the hearing.

title: Union Pacific Unit To Buy Gas Sites
description: Union Pacific Resources, a unit of the Union Pacific Corporation, said it had reached an agreement with the Oryx Energy Company to buy producing natural gas properties in two fields for a total price of about $109 million. The properties are in East Texas and southern Wyoming.

title: Oil Prices Up Despite Bush Move
description: Oil prices plowed stubbornly ahead yesterday despite President Bush's effort to tame them by announcing a test withdrawal from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: Benefit on Staten Island
description: A musical benefit for the St. George Civic Association, featuring six local musicians, is to be held at 4 P.M. on Sunday at Veterans Memorial Hall, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, in Livingston, S.I. The performers are to be Leslie Sixfin Merwin, a pianist; Lois Lamb, Ann Trinita Sohm and Jacqueline Shotigian, singers, and Joseph Fischetti and Ira Bishop, clarinetists. On the program are works by Chopin, Schumann, Mozart and Puccini. Tickets are $7. Information: (718) 448-2500.

title: Grogan Seems Unlikely to Face Jets
description: The prospect of Steve Grogan's making his 20th career start against the Jets on Sunday grew slimmer today when the status of the 37-year-old New England Patriots quarterback was downgraded from probable to questionable because of a neck injury that kept him out of last Sunday's game.

title: Boy Shot and Killed in the Bronx
description: A 13-year-old boy was shot and killed in a Bronx apartment yesterday morning when a gun being handed around among friends fired, apparently by accident, the police said.

title: New Jersey Court Bars Tax Plan Referendums
description: The State Supreme Court decided today that nonbinding referendums on Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax plan cannot appear on election ballots in five counties.

title: Across the Land, Americans Express Wide Support for Reunited Germany
description: For a number of Americans who have been involved with German issues over many years, the formal establishment of a single German state on Oct. 3 is perceived largely as a good thing, although among them are some who acknowledge occasional twinges of unease.

title: Part of Door From United Jet Is Retrieved From the Pacific
description: Part of the cargo door that blew off a United Airlines jumbo jet last year, bringing death to nine passengers, has been retrieved by a tiny Navy submarine from the Pacific Ocean floor at a depth of almost three miles, the Government said yesterday.

title: Plug In To Moscow
description: Assorted hints have come from Moscow that the Soviets are willing to supply intelligence about Iraq. This could be of critical importance. Long and intimate involvement with the Iraqi military and police establishments, from the top well on down, gave Moscow information unavailable anywhere else.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Senate Takes Up Pact Cutting Role in Berlin
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee took up the treaty today that will end the rights and responsibilities the United States acquired 45 years ago in Germany and Berlin as a victorious power in World War II.

title: Patents;   Tire Pressure Gauge Is Mounted in Hubcap
description: James Jard, a commercial real estate broker in Virginia Beach, Va., has patented a tire pressure gauge mounted into automobile hubcaps.

title: After Early Drop, Dow Closes Up 25
description: Fed by a broad selloff in Tokyo and unfounded war rumors, prices plunged on the New York Stock Exchange early yesterday but quickly recovered to close with a solid gain. The Dow Jones industrial average moved ahead 25 points in heavy trading, to 2,452.48, with bank and insurance stocks showing strong increases.

title: Pirates Increase Pressure With Victory Over Cards
description: Scoreboard watching at Busch Stadium is a timely thing this time of year. Out-of-town updates are flashed on the electronic board in rotation, a different bunch every 4.8 seconds.

title: KEY RATES
Underwriting Fees Decline Sharply
description: The squeeze on Wall Street profits grew tighter in the last quarter, as fees for underwritings of securities fell by more than half, to their lowest levels in six years, and corporate America began to pull back from raising money in the capital markets.

title: Drug Tests for Fuhr
description: Grant Fuhr of the Edmonton Oilers, who was suspended for a year by the National Hockey League on Thursday for cocaine use, has agreed to submit to random drug tests, a team spokesman said yesterday.

title: C.I.A. Fears Iraq Could Deploy Biological Arms by Early 1991
description: Iraq has developed biological weapons that will be able to deliver significant quantities of the deadly agents on the battlefield by early next year, according to American intelligence reports.

title: Grenade Attack in Djibouti
description: Assailants tossed three grenades into a crowded cafe, killing the 9-year-old son of a French soldier and injuring 17 other people, officials said today. No one claimed responsibility for the attack Thursday night in Djibouti, a small country on the Red Sea that is used as a staging area for French forces sent to the Persian Gulf region.

title: Goodbye, Channel J - and Good Riddance
description: LEAD: To hear it on late-night cable television, New York is about to enter the iron night of silence, when all freedom of speech is lost and citizens cower in fear under tyrranical government censorship. On Monday we will lose Channel J, and a few self-interested programmers are trying again to bend the First Amendment.

title: 16 Sentenced to Life for Killing Aquino
description: A Philippine court sentenced a general and 15 other soldiers to life imprisonment today for the slaying seven years ago of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the nation's opposition leader, whose widow, Corazon, is now President.

title: Congress Resists El Salvador's Chief on Aid Cuts
description: President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador impressed several members of Congress during his four-day lobbying visit to Washington this week, but he did not succeed in altering Congressional sentiment on cutting military aid to his country.

title: City Hall No Longer City's
description: The city of East St. Louis, which is bankrupt, has had to give up its City Hall to a man who won a lawsuit against the city.

title: Brooktree Wins on Patent
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said today that a jury had ordered it to pay $25.6 million in damages stemming from an earlier finding that the company had infringed patents held by the Brooktree Corporation and that it intended to appeal the award.

title: Political Memo;   Bush Sure-Footed on Trail of Money
description: He hits the road, sometimes he presses the flesh, but President Bush doesn't really campaign, not in the classic sense. Not like Ronald Reagan or Hubert H. Humphrey or Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: Review/Film Festival;   In a Satire, Many Are Killed but Few Stay Dead
description: ''What does a real artist do when he sees blood?'' asks a menacing, middle-aged murderer after he has stabbed two almost-innocent bystanders in a college men's room. ''He uses it,'' the killer says as he dips his hand into a pool of bright red goo and starts writing on the wall. He would seem truly lethal, but the two corpses on the floor are definitely fidgeting. One of the dead men raises his head and calmly observes, ''This school is full of wackos.''

title: Your Money;   Ways to Trim Tax Liabilities
description: Savvy taxpayers will use the last three months of the year to pare their tax liabilities, while strengthening their personal finances. And there are a number of ways to do this, regardless of uncertainty over what Congress may do on the tax front.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Behind Student Attitudes, Legacy of Divided Germany
description: Between this impoverished rural town of 5,000 inhabitants and prosperous Reinfeld, where 7,200 West Germans live, there lies about 15 miles and a frontier that will be formally erased when Germany reunites on Wednesday.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball DENVER (NBA) - Agreed to terms with T. R. Dunn, guard, on a one-year contract.

title: Rome Says Goodbye to Moravia With a Quiet but Loving Tribute
description: Rome bade a dry-eyed farewell today to its celebrated native son Alberto Moravia, who remained faithful to his city in life, even if his writings did not always treat it like a lady.

title: Polls Still Show Weicker Ahead In Connecticut
description: With 39 days left in Connecticut's gubernatorial race, Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Greenwich, a Republican campaigning as an independent candidate, still holds a large lead over his Democratic and Republican rivals, according to two statewide polls released yesterday.

title: Japan and North Korea Set Talks on Ties
description: After 45 years of hostility, Japan and North Korea agreed today to open talks to establish diplomatic relations ''as soon as possible.'' The Japanese, in return, promised financial compensation for their occupation of the Korean peninsula in the early decades of this century.

title: Quarterbacks in Spotlight When B.Y.U. Meets Oregon
description: Rarely has there been such anticipation for a college sporting event in Oregon. When undefeated Brigham Young meets the University of Oregon today before an expected overflow crowd at 41,678-seat Autzen Stadium in Eugene, the excitement will be as much about the opposing quarterbacks as about the Ducks' chances for an upset.

title: C. P. Turner, 83; Devised Alternative For School Diploma
description: Cornelius P. Turner, who supervised development of the high school equivalency credential, died Wednesday at Alexandria Hospital in Alexandria, Va. He was 83 years old and lived in Alexandria.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Down by 2%
description: The prices that farmers receive for raw products declined by 2 percent from August to September, but the overall commodity index was still 3.5 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: About New York;   First Problem Is Homelessness; 2d Is Denial
description: ''It's not good for you to be depressed at such a time,'' said the shy young woman, 20 years old and pregnant with her second child.

title: Editorial Notebook;   America's Last Robot?
description: Cincinnati Milacron, the last major American maker of heavy robots, is selling its business to a Swiss company. That will leave most of the U.S. robot market in the hands of foreigners. Does it matter that yet another high-tech, American-grown industry is now dominated by foreigners, mostly Japan?

title: President Of Emerson Radio Quits
description: Stephen L. Lane announced yesterday that he would resign immediately as the president and chief executive of the Emerson Radio Corporation in an effort to spare the company further adverse publicity over his financial affairs.

title: Meeting the Artists
description: The eighth season of Lincoln Center's Off Stage Series, in which guest artists meet with the audience for an hour of informal converstion followed by a light supper reception, will begin on Oct. 11. Leonard Slatkin, the music director of the Saint Louis Symphony Orchestra, is to be the first guest. Others are to be the author and monologuist Spalding Gray, Oct. 18; the composer and lyricist Stephen Sondheim, Nov. 7, and the performance artist Karen Finley, Dec. 12. The events take place from 6 to 7:30 P.M. at the Juilliard School's Paul Recital Hall, 144 West 66th Street. Subscriptions are $45; single tickets are $13. Information: 877-6770.

title: Ellis Found Guilty
description: Dale Ellis of the SuperSonics was convicted by a Seattle District Court jury yesterday of drunken driving and reckless driving.

title: Oil Prices Fall, Then Recoup
description: Crude oil prices dropped sharply in the early afternoon yesterday only to stage a late rally and close little changed in light futures trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: UAL Shares Jump On Davis's Offer
description: The UAL Corporation's stock price jumped $6.625 today, to $97.25, on the New York Stock Exchange after the investor Marvin Davis offered late Thursday to join an employee buyout of the company, which runs United Airlines.

title: Evolution in Europe: One Germany;   New Germany or Not, in the East It's Same Old Teachers, Same Old Books
description: When Communist rule was toppled last year, and the old order swept away, one of the most abrupt changes in this town of modest villas and vineyards centered on the small building where Elisabeth Aust's children attend elementary school.

title: Britain Clears 5 Oil Concerns
description: The British Office of Fair Trading cleared five oil companies today of fixing gasoline pump prices in the face of rising oil prices that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last month. The office's director general, Gordon Borrie, said the industry's reaction to events in the Persian Gulf followed a ''pattern one would expect in a competitive market.''

title: Denise Carty-Bennia, Law Professor, 43
description: Denise Carty-Bennia, a lawyer and visiting professor at the City University of New York Law School at Queens College, died on Sept. 11 at her home in Detroit. She was 43 years old.

title: U.S. JUDGE UPHOLDS RAP GROUP'S SHOW
description: A Federal district judge today forbade the Westerly Town Council to interfere in a concert by the rap music group 2 Live Crew.

title: 'Junk Bond' Prices Drop Further
description: The record-setting decline of ''junk bonds'' in August was a short-lived distinction: In September, prices of junk issues plunged even further, to new lows, amid concerns about the economy and the Middle East.

title: Disaster Zone Is Urged After Soviet Nuclear Blast
description: The Soviet republic of Kazakhstan asked the central Government today to declare an ecological disaster zone around the city of Ust-Kamenogorsk, saying that an explosion at a nuclear fuel plant there had spewed ''extremely harmful'' gas across inhabited areas.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about California's consideration of stricter anti-pollution measures misidentified the road shown. It was the San Diego Freeway.

title: Hudson River Park Plan Draws Critics
description: As the Hudson River spills past 59th Street and down to the Battery, it is separated from the city by a series of industrial complexes devoted to garbage and electrical power, surrounded by fences festooned with barbed tape and no-trespassing signs.

title: Illinois Court Rejects Forced Marrow Tests Of Potential Donors
description: The Illinois Supreme Court ruled today that 3-year-old twins cannot be forced to be tested as potential donors of bone marrow to their half-brother, who has leukemia.

title: Review/Music;   A Festive Start for Solti's Final Season
description: The advent of autumn is season-opening time all over the world, but the musical season is starting more auspiciously than usual this year in Chicago. The Lyric Opera is already under way, with a controversial but striking production of Gluck's ''Alceste'' by Robert Wilson and a well-received account of Tchaikovsky's ''Eugene Onegin.'' And on Thursday night the Chicago Symphony season began with a special glamour, complete with searchlights piercing a balmy Indian-summer sky and Chicago's leading citizens purring with pride.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Ethics Committee is Urged to Clear 2 of 5 in Savings Inquiry
description: The special counsel to the Senate Ethics Committee has recommended that the panel clear two of the five Senators under investigation for their links to the savings and loan debacle, Congressional officials said today.

title: War May Be at Hand, but Bedouins Find Their Desert Peaceful
description: The American troops here swill gallons of water and barely move under the camouflage netting that shelters them from the harsh Saudi sun. Many a soldier has compared this place to hell.

title: Jordan Militants Urging Iraq To Use 'Chemicals' on U.S.
description: Muslim militants urged President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today to turn his chemical weapons on United States troops in the Persian Gulf region.

title: Honeywell Backs Spinoff of Unit
description: Honeywell Inc said its board had approved the spinoff of its military and marine systems business, tests instruments division and signal analysis center into an independent company to be named Alliant Techsystems Inc. Alliant Techsystems started operations today, Honeywell said. Honeywell said its shareholders of record on Oct. 9 would get one share of Alliant Techsystems for every four shares of Honeywell stock. About 9.3 million shares of Alliant Techsystems will be distributed to Honeywell shareholders. Honeywell's stock closed today at $78.75, down $1.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Trial Is Delayed in Sexual Assault Case
description: NEWARK, Sept. 28 -

title: INSIDE
description: Old Foes Aim to Open Ties

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Tuesday about Korean-Americans seeking political power in New York misstated the role of a group, Korean-Americans for Social Concerns, in a rally at City Hall. It did not help organize the rally.

title: Review/Opera;   New Don in Title Role of the Met's 'Giovanni'
description: It would be easy to go overboard about Thomas Hampson's performance in ''Don Giovanni'' on Thursday evening. Let us be cautious and merely say that the young American, taking the title role for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera, sent one home thinking of hallowed names from the past: Cesare Siepi, George London - even, briefly, Ezio Pinza. Unless the rigors of the busy new season have already begun to soften the critical brain, no Don Giovanni in recent decades has brought to the part a more convincing blend of vocal authority, athletic grace and psychological depth. Mr. Hampson is surely fated to be the Don Giovanni of his generation.

title: Plan Limiting Northwest Logging Is Adopted
description: The Forest Service today adopted a plan that would save the northern spotted owl but result in greater reductions in logging than the White House recommended last week.

title: Ex-Aide to Pierce Rebuffs Questions in Inquiry on Housing Agency
description: The former top aide to Samuel R. Pierce Jr. has refused to answer questions from Congressional investigators about allegations of political favoritism and mismanagement during Mr. Pierce's tenure as Housing Secretary in Ronald Reagan's Administration.

title: Washington Students Gain in Protest
description: The 13-year-old University of the District of Columbia has long been a troubled institution, but it took a student takeover of two university buildings two days ago to get the city government to begin to grapple with its problems.

title: U.S. Gives Details on Oil Auction
description: The Energy Department today announced the details for the auction of five million barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve next month.

title: Lawrence O'Brien, Democrat, Dies at 73
description: Lawrence F. O'Brien Jr., the Democratic Party strategist who organized the successful senatorial and Presidential campaigns of John F. Kennedy, died yesterday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 73 years old. His family said he died from complications of cancer.

title: Jury Hears Passionate Arguments As Obscenity Trial Opens in Ohio
description: In opening arguments today that sometimes turned passionate, lawyers in the Mapplethorpe obscenity trial outlined their approaches to the nation's first criminal trial of an art museum over the content of an exhibition.

title: Red Sox Retrieve Victory From Blue Jays
description: LEAD: In a division where it seems all but impossible to win, perhaps it was only fitting that the Boston Red Sox built a one-game lead over the Toronto Blue Jays tonight by using a most improbable hero in their 7-6 victory.

title: Store Chain Goes Public in Canada
description: The North West Company, which started life as a single fur trading post in 1668 on the shore of Hudson Bay, went public today after 322 years in business. The company is listing its shares on the Toronto and Winnipeg stock exchanges.

title: Mortgage Rates Mixed
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.22 percent this week, up from 10.16 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the highest rate since Aug. 31. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.28 percent, down from 8.30 percent last week.

title: John B. Goodman, Executive, 78
description: John B. Goodman, retired executive vice president for the Downtown Lower Manhattan Association, a civic group, died on Tuesday at his home in Bellingham, Wash. He was 78 years old and had lived in Darien, Conn., for many years before moving to Bellingham.

title: Review/Theater;   Gay Couple Adopts A Baby
description: ''Big, Fat and Ugly With a Mustache,'' a new play by Christopher Widney at the Perry Street Theater, has all the right ingredients for a television movie of the week with an option for a series.

title: Help the Children, Here and Abroad
description: LEAD: Tomorrow, leaders from more than 70 nations will convene at the United Nations to participate in a World Summit for Children. The meeting will reflect a growing world wide commitment to the rights of children everywhere.

title: Barge Owner Investigated In Oil Spill
description: State and Federal law-enforcement officials have begun a criminal investigation of the owner of a barge that sank and spilled as much as 50,000 gallons of oil in the Kill van Kull on Thursday.

title: 'Civil War' Seems to Have Set a Record
description: Obliterating the long-held notion that public television appeals only to those interested in predators, pageants and pundrity, ''The Civil War'' ended on Thursday night as apparently the most popular noncommercial series ever broadcast. The documentary, which was shown over five nights, had an average rating of 9 and was seen by 13 percent of the people watching television, according to the A. C. Nielsen Company.

title: Don't Coerce Quebec With Trade Exclusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Revamping; Will Spin Off Pet Inc.
description: The Whitman Corporation, a troubled conglomerate, announced a long-awaited revamping today but surprised analysts by including the spinoff of its profitable food division, Pet Inc., its biggest unit.

title: Low-Demand Subway Service Being Cut
description: The New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that it would curtail late-night and weekend service on nine subway lines beginning tomorrow to cut costs, a move that drew strong opposition from consumer advocacy groups.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q&A column of Science Times on Sept. 18 about the Rockwell scale of hardness misstated the system. The higher the number, the harder the material.

title: Beliefs
description: ''Sing lustily and with a good courage. Beware of singing as if you were half dead, or half asleep; but lift up your voice with strength.''

title: Midway Air Is Cutting Staff
description: In another sign of hard times in the nation's airline industry, Midway Airlines Inc. said today that it was cutting its staff by 10 percent, putting about 500 people out of work.

title: We Have to Pay Attention to Teacher Training
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Port Buoyed By Cold War's End
description: The arguments against a New York home port have always been weak. Now, given the realities of the post-cold-war world and the difficulties of our community, they're even weaker.

title: Washington Talk;   Governing By Veto: Who Is In Control?
description: As Congress begins its final push on major bills before adjourning for the fall elections, a sword hangs over the process.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about legislation to permit a referendum on Puerto Rico's political status misidentified the commonwealth's delegate to the United States House of Representatives. He is Jaime B. Fuster. Ron de Lugo is the Virgin Islands delegate.

title: Prices of Securities Rise on Budget Hopes
description: Prices of Treasury securities continued to advance yesterday, largely on the belief that the Bush Administration and the Congress will hammer out a budget agreement this weekend.

title: Something Draweth Nigh
description: New York after a long absence:

title: Whiteners: New Ways To Brighten A Smile
description: Americans are spending more and more money these days on cosmetic whiteners that they hope will brighten their teeth and improve their smiles.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: An Odd Sort Of Underdog
description: From the beginning, Pierre A. Rinfret's blustery and combative persona was well suited to his underdog campaign strategy against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. As an underfinanced and unknown challenger, Mr. Rinfret knew he would need the ''free media'' to bolster his name recognition, and a little outrageousness goes a long way in winning headlines.

title: Economic Memo;   Quiet Moves at Bank Talks: A Reshaping of East Europe
description: The Middle East crisis dominated the speeches and news conferences at the annual meeting this week of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. But away from the newsmakers, in hotel rooms outfitted with conference tables, Eastern Europe's emerging free market economies were quietly being shaped.

title: Those Hisses on the Launching Pad
description: The flight of the space shuttle Columbia has been canceled for the fourth time after another leak from its hydrogen fuel system was detected, and NASA's round-the-clock study team has still not pinpointed the source.

title: Iraq Seen Looting Kuwait of Identity
description: Having physically denuded Kuwait in nearly two months of military rule, looting computers, amusement-park rides and even street lamps and school blackboards, Iraq has embarked on a systematic effort to strip the nation of its very identity, exiled Kuwaitis and other recent refugees say.

title: Fran Smith, Theater Director, 69
description: Fran Smith, director of the Westbury (L.I.) Players, an amateur theater group, for 17 years, died on Wednesday at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. She was 69 years old and lived in Westbury.

title: Cuomo Plans a Weekend Trip to Poland
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has been known to fly to California for the day, is planning a trip to Poland - for a long weekend.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Who wants to vote for Medicare cuts? Who wants to vote for Social Security cuts? Who wants to vote for a gasoline tax?'' - Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi. [12:1.]

title: Iran Resents U.S. Base-Building in Gulf
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about New York City's 10-year capital plan misstated Mayor David N. Dinkins's position on the possibility of cutbacks in spending.

title: Summit at the U.N.: The World's Children
description: A promise to increase assistance to children in poor countries was made by the World Bank and other agencies as world leaders prepared for a United Nations summit meeting on the plight of children.

title: Adkins Leads Yanks Past Brewers
description: Steve Adkins held Milwaukee hitless for six innings to earn his first major league victory and Jesse Barfield and Randy Velarde hit home runs last night as the Yankees beat the Brewers, 7-2.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN V. KRUTILLA and ALLEN V. KNEESE, economists working in resource and environmental economics, won the Volvo Environment Prize for their work at Resources for the Future, a nonprofit Washington organization for research in environmental quality. The two men have sought to identify and quantify the consequences of water, noise and solid-waste pollution, and to develop plans to manage such pollution. They will receive their awards, $125,000 each, in November at the University of Goteborg, Sweden.

title: Brooklyn Man Convicted in Officer's Killing
description: A Brooklyn man was convicted of murder yesterday for throwing a New York City police officer to his death from the roof of a McDonald's restaurant in Times Square during a robbery.

title: Subtle Changes in Piano Man's World
description: Like most other entertainers, Ronny Whyte, the singer and pianist who has been an enduring presence in the night life of New York City for nearly three decades, has his store of anecdotes.

title: How Long Do Smoke Detectors Last?
description: Federal officials estimate that up to 85 percent of all dwellings in the United States have smoke detectors, but that as many as a third of them may not work.

title: As Gulf Crisis Solidifies the World Order, Cuba Feels Left Out
description: The exuberance of Soviet and American officials about the new world order being established after the cold war is not universally embraced at the United Nations.

title: From an Old Iraqi Battlefield, Warnings of New Bloodshed
description: On a journey to Fao, the obliterated landscape resembles nothing so much as a nightmarish vision of hell. It was here that 173,000 Iraqis and Iranians died in their recent war.

title: Airbus Awarded Swissair Contract
description: The Swiss national airline, Swissair, chose the European aircraft maker Airbus Industrie over the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to provide 26 new airliners in an order worth at least 2.3 billion Swiss francs (about $1.8 billion). The airline, which took options on an additional 26 aircraft, said it would buy seven 133-seat Airbus A320's and 19 170-seat A321's. The type of engine to power the aircraft will be decided later.

title: Texas Way of Electing Judges Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court in New Orleans ruled overwhelmingly yesterday that the 1965 Voting Rights Act did not apply to the election of state judges.

title: After a 51-Year Break, Albania Seeks Diplomatic Ties With U.S.
description: The leadership of Albania, one of the last hard-line Communist Governments, has concluded a series of talks with the United States to establish diplomatic relations after a break of 51 years, Albania's chief delegate to the United Nations said today.

title: Government in Beirut Imposes Siege on Aoun
description: The pro-Syrian Government of President Elias Hrawi today imposed a siege around areas controlled by Gen. Michel Aoun to force the defiant general to relinquish power in Christian East Beirut.

title: Canada Clears Way For Johnson in Games
description: The Canadian Olympic Association lifted its ban on Ben Johnson yesterday, removing the last barrier to the sprinter's return to Olympic competition in Barcelona, Spain, in 1992.

title: COMBAT RESERVES MAY GET CALLED UP
description: Officials in the Defense Department and in Congress are debating whether to call up combat reserve units to join the nearly 27,000 reservists already summoned to perform military support roles in the United States and in the Persian Gulf region.

title: McIlvaine and Padres Talk About General Manager Job
description: Joe McIlvaine, the Mets' vice president for baseball operations, has talked with the San Diego Padres about their general manager's job and would accept the job if it is offered, baseball executives said yesterday.

title: Thomas A. Flinn, Professor, 65
description: Dr. Thomas A. Flinn, a professor of political science at Cleveland State University for 20 years, died Wednesday at Lakeside Hospital of University Hospitals in Cleveland. He was 65 years old and lived in Cleveland.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   7- and 15-Month CD's
description: To attract certificate-of-deposit money during the heavy renewal periods of April and October, some banks are heavily promoting their odd-term certificates, like 7 or 15 months, along with the standard maturities of 6, 12, 24, 30 and 60 months. The premise is that the longer the maturity, the greater the interest earned. But longer is not always better; is it worth it to tie up your money for a few extra dollars? One way to compare certificates of deposit is to figure the average monthly return without regard to maturity. Below are some examples based on a $10,000 certificate of deposit using national averages of the yields banks are advertising. $ Maturity Yield Average Total Interest Monthly Return Earned 6 months 7.69% $63.00 $378.01 7 months 7.80% $65.00 $390.00 12 months 7.84% $65.35 $784.14 15 months 8.00% $66.67 $1,000.00

title: When Pain Is Still A Pleasure
description: Lawrence Taylor's hamstring was a major sports issue during the week. Would that now celebrated tendon, stretched at the end of last Sunday's game, be suitable for action for this Sunday's game, and allow its fearsome proprietor, the Giants linebacker, to once again chase and corner a quarterback like a cat a rat?

title: More Police, Eventually
description: Even if Mayor David N. Dinkins agrees next week, as expected, to hire thousands of new police officers for New York City, the process of recruiting and training them is so complex that the last of them would probably not be ready for duty on the streets for two years, with luck.

title: Off-Duty Officer Is Slashed
description: A police officer on his way to work in midtown Manhattan was slashed across the throat last night by a man wielding a broken bottle, the police said. The officer, Lawrence McDonnell, 26 years old, was in serious but stable condition at Bellevue Hospital Center, said a police spokesman. The officer was attacked after exchanging words with a group of 14 men at Eighth Avenue and West 38th Street at 9:40 P.M.

title: Books of The Times;   Giving a Nod to Kafka, As a Jew Faces Calamity
description: Hourglass

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELLEN BURSTYN will pick up an award from the Guttman Breast Diagnostic Institute on Monday on behalf of Actors' Equity Association, which co-sponsors a mobile mammography screening program in the Broadway theater district. The award, for individuals or organizations that help raise public consciousness about breast cancer, is given in connection with National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, beginning Oct. 1.

title: Photo: Beatriz Rodriquez as The Chosen One in Vaslav Nijinsky's ''Sacre du Printemps.'' (Jean Marc Charles Rapho for The New York Times) Contrite Paris Hails Nijinsky's 'Sacre'
description: As if making amends for past insult and injury, French audiences and critics have warmly, indeed almost reverently, welcomed home Vaslav Nijinsky's radical choreography of ''Le Sacre du Printemps'' 77 years after it came close to provoking a riot here.

title: Giants Put Allegre on Injured Reserve
description: The Giants today placed their place-kicker, Raul Allegre, on injured reserve with a strained right groin muscle and signed the veteran Matt Bahr as his replacement for Sunday's game here against the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Review/Music;   Tolling Bells and Dreamy Scoring of a Curtain Raiser
description: A centerpiece of Carnegie Hall's centenary celebration is its commissioning project, which will yield 13 new orchestral, chamber and vocal works this season. Andre Previn led the Los Angeles Philharmonic in the first of them, Steven Stucky's ''Angelus,'' on Thursday evening.

title: Liberia Cease-Fire Collapses As Battle Erupts in Monrovia
description: Liberia's shaky cease-fire collapsed today when Government troops and rebels battled for several hours in this capital city.

title: Mutual Fund Buyers In a Flight to Safety
description: With many investors apparently growing more worried about financial stability, mutual fund companies are seeing a flight to safety and quality, fund managers said yesterday.

title: BAT Industries
description: BAT Industries P.L.C., the British tobacco and financial services conglomerate, said its Canadian affiliate Imasco Ltd. of Canada would buy the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rochester for $150 million. Imasco's Canada Trust unit is making the purchase. First Federal has $5.6 billion in assets and 65 offices throughout New York State. BAT holds a 40 percent stake in Imasco, a Canadian tobacco and financial services concern.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Choosing a Wood Stove
description: Rising fuel costs and concern over the future of oil supplies from the Middle East have aroused renewed interest in wood stoves.

title: Corrections
description: A brief front-page summary yesterday about New York State's decision to toughen pollution rules for cars and trucks misstated New York's ranking as a market for cars.

title: Time to Retire an Indian Place-Name Hoax;   Debt to Caughnawagas
description: To the Editor:

title: Carl F. Ewig, Executive, 85
description: Carl F. Ewig, a retired steamship company executive, died on Saturday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Review/Film Festival;   Nature's Splendor and Aphorisms in Godard's Latest
description: ''Nouvelle Vague,'' a phrase that evokes the renaissance of the French cinema in the 1960's, is a good title rather badly used for Jean-Luc Godard's featherweight new film.

title: Doctor Fees Found Higher in U.S. Than in Canada
description: Doctors in the United States charge more than twice as much as doctors in Canada for the same work, a study says, adding that this helps explain why this country's health care costs are dramatically higher than Canada's.

title: 500,000 Bicycles for Cubans
description: Cuba will build 500,000 bicycles to help curb effects of a fuel shortage caused by a cutback in oil imports from the Soviet Union, the official Cuban press agency Prensa Latina said today. The dispatch, monitored in Mexico City, said the first units would go on the market next year. The agency quoted the newspaper Rebel Youth as saying Cuba would build five factories to make bicycle parts. It said Cuba might also buy bicycles from China.

title: Senators Block Bill to Regulate Cable TV Prices
description: Legislation to regulate cable television prices was set back and probably killed today when objections by three Senators forced supporters of the bill to withdraw it from consideration on the Senate floor.

title: Two Soviet Giants, in Dissent
description: It is a salutary measure of Soviet openness that Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn can finally speak directly to a Soviet audience during its great national debate. Remarkably, his first full statement on the Gorbachev era appears as a special supplement in a journal for young Communists. Yet nowhere in his 16,000-word essay does Mr. Solzhenitsyn mention Mikhail Gorbachev's name. Nor does the great exile praise the reforms that enabled him to join in the debate.

title: Leading Indicators In Big Fall
description: The Government index designed to predict turns in the economy dropped 1.2 percent in August, the biggest fall since just after the 1987 stock market crash, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Japan-Europe Car Pact
description: European Community officials said off the record today that the community and Japan were close to a deal under which Japanese car producers would be allowed to increase market share in Europe to almost double by 1999, when all quotas would be scrapped. The pact, which will set the pace at which the 12-nation bloc liberalizes its partly protected car market, will be an informal arrangement, the officials said. ''There are still some questions of detail to resolve but the core of the arrangement is agreed,'' one official said.

title: Surgery for Molitor
description: Paul Molitor, the Milwaukee Brewers infielder, underwent successful shoulder and forearm surgery yesterday at Sinai Samaritan Medical Center in Milwaukee, team officials said. Molitor had arthroscopic surgery performed on his right shoulder to relieve an impingement. The 34-year-old Molitor, who finished the season with a .285 batting average in 103 games, also had a torn muscle in his right forearm sutured. (AP)

title: House Votes Trading Curb
description: The House of Representatives gave final Congressional approval today to market-regulation legislation written in response to the stock market collapse in October 1987.

title: George R. Ince Jr., Banker, 81
description: George R. Ince Jr., a first vice president of Bankers Trust Company in Manhattan for more than 40 years, died on Thursday at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 81 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: John Ducas, 70, Dies; A Publicity Consultant
description: John J. Ducas, a communications consultant with the Chase Manhattan Bank who in the 1950's and 60's was a principal adviser in the public relations program for the nation's first intercontinental ballistic missiles, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Ducas, 70 years old, died of a heart attack, said his son, Paul.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-7

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID SHILLING, one of Britain's maddest hatters, whose confections, often startling, are worn by stylish women at the Royal Ascot race meeting, is going on a United Nations mission to Ecuador in October to advise the Government there on strengthening its hat-making industry.

title: Police to Meet in Montana To Study Coin Shop Killings
description: Law-enforcement officers from several states and Canada are seeking to question a man accused of killing two people in a Billings coin shop, saying he may be a suspect in similar crimes.

title: Can Choosing Form of Care Become Neglect?
description: When Juliet Cheng was called in to Newington Children's Hospital in July, she thought it was for a final consultation about the health of her 7-year-old daughter, who suffers from severe juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, before they returned to China for medical treatment there.

title: Managua Journal;   Uniting the Germanys, in a Latin American Setting
description: If there is an important political upheaval in the world, you can probably find out about it by checking the stack of work in Georg Boomgaarden's in-basket.

title: Eleanor C. French Service
description: A memorial service for Eleanor Clark French, a former New York City Commissioner to the United Nations and New York State Democratic Party official, will be held at 6 P.M. Thursday in the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall.

title: World Bank and Other Agencies Pledge an Increase in Aid to Poor Children
description: As more than 70 world leaders prepared to meet here on the plight of children, development agencies and banks have been promising to increase assistance to children in poor countries, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada said today.

title: Tax Compromises Open Way To Pact in Budget Talks
description: White House officials agreed in private budget negotiations tonight to a higher income tax on wealthy Americans in return for a lower capital gains tax, officials from both parties said.

title: S.E.C. Nominee Is Confirmed
description: The Senate confirmed Richard Y. Roberts, the former chief of staff of Senator Richard C. Shelby, Democrat of Alabama, today to fill the vacancy on the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Auction of Ford Artworks Planned
description: Art and antiques from the collection of Henry Ford 2d, valued at more than $50 million, are to be auctioned in November at Sotheby's in Manhattan, states an internal memorandum circulated this week at Christie's.

title: Time to Retire an Indian Place-Name Hoax
description: To the Editor:

title: Alvin Broido, 85, Dies; Educator in New York
description: Alvin Broido, a teacher and principal in the New York City public school system for about 45 years, died on Thursday at Scripps Memorial Hospital in Encinitas, Calif. He was 85 years old and had lived in Rancho La Costa, Calif., since retiring in 1970.

title: Tabler's 3-Run Homer Keeps Met Hopes Alive
description: Darryl Strawberry, bundled up against the chill and all but nailed to the bench by his ailing back, smiled gently and extended his hand. Pat Tabler, the din outside the dugout roaring at full gale, made his way to the end of the bench, grasped the hand and smiled back.

title: In Shift, Rinfret Agrees to Debate Cuomo and 2 Other Candidates
description: Reversing his position, Pierre A. Rinfret agreed yesterday to participate in two televised debates with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and two other candidates for governor.

title: Patents;   New Device To Measure Audiences
description: In search of a more accurate way to measure television and radio audiences, a small company in Chicago has patented a pocket-sized device that silently monitors and logs the programs a person listens to.

title: Patents;   New Type of Pince-Nez For Use by Athletes
description: Pince-nez for athletes? Walter D. Somerville, an inventor in Carmel, Calif., has patented a new version of the antiquarian eyeglasses that are attached by pinching the frame to the bridge of the nose.

title: Padres Set BackReds, 2-1
description: Bruce Hurst pitched a four-hitter and Benito Santiago doubled home a ninth-inning run tonight as the San Diego Padres beat Cincinnati, 2-1, to keep the Reds from clinching a tie for the National League West title.

title: Helping Older Women Enter the Job Market
description: To the Editor:

title: LaFontaine Skips Trip
description: The Islanders confirmed yesterday that Pat LaFontaine, the club's leading scorer for the last three seasons, did not accompany the team to California for the completion of its exhibition schedule.

title: I.R.A. Plants Bomb in London
description: The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility today for planting a bomb made of plastic explosive at a London conference on terrorism. The I.R.A., which is fighting to oust Britain from Northern Ireland, said in a statement in Dublin that the incident showed its ability to ''strike at will.'' The four-pound Semtex device, which would have devastated the hall, was discovered and defused only minutes before the conference opened on Thursday.

title: Small Business in Peril From Street Peddlers
description: To the Editor:

title: Search for Survivors of Sinking
description: A Coast Guard airplane resumed searching today for possible survivors of a vessel whose partially sunken hull was spotted 500 miles southeast of Nova Scotia. The identity of the vessel and the conditions under which it sank remained unknown, said Petty Officer Lionel Bryant, a Coast Guard spokesman. A Canadian plane had sighted the hull on Thursday and also saw white, blue and brown boxes in the water, which are commonly used by fishing boats to hold their catch, he said.

title: SACKING OF KUWAIT IS PRESSURING U.S.
description: President Bush's national security adviser said today that the ''systematic destruction'' of Kuwait under Iraqi occupation was shortening the time that the United States can wait for economic sanctions to drive President Saddam Hussein's army out of the Persian Gulf sheikdom.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Parking: Alternate-side rules will be suspended today for Yom Kippur.

title: Delegates From World Are Doing The Town
description: The vanguard of the largest gathering of foreign dignitaries ever to meet in New York converged on midtown Manhattan yesterday and, like so many tourists, fanned out to sample the city's dazzling cornucopia of sights, culture, food, celebrities and chaos.

title: Oil Problem Termed 'Manageable'
description: The International Energy Agency said today that while the global oil-supply situation ''is not comfortable,'' it is ''manageable'' enough that there is no need to call on the agency's 21 members to tap their strategic petroleum reserves. But the agency did say its members should be ready to draw on reserves quickly in an emergency.

title: Bridge
description: Beginners are advised, when playing no-trump, to develop the longest combined suit. As they advance in the game they discover that there are many exceptions, and one of them is demonstrated by the diagramed deal.

title: Review/Television;   Love, Treason and Blackmail in Wartime Britain
description: ''Masterpiece Theater'' on public television will begin its 20th season tomorrow - at 9 P.M. on Channel 13 and at 10 P.M. on Channel 49 - with a production that, given its stellar list of credits, fails to fully live up to its promise.

title: Help for Forgetful Bank-Card Holders
description: CHEMICAL BANK doesn't want its customers to take their money and run, not without their automated teller card and receipt. So now, said Ken Herz, a Chemical Bank spokesman, the bank is testing a change in the way cash is dispensed from its 359 New York City money machines.

title: Managing;   Corporate Donations Under Attack
description: From Philip Morris to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, some of America's biggest companies are being attacked by special-interest groups for donating money to causes the critics simply don't like. As a result, companies are growing more frightened of controversy and are reassessing their donations, turning philanthropy into a image-boosting tool instead.

title: It's on That Avenue Called 42d Street
description: SHAKESPEARE wrote that all the world's a stage and all the men and women merely players. He might have added that most of the players want to be stars.

title: What Ike Would Do in the Gulf
description: LEAD: Late last month, Iraqi soldiers seized our 24-year-old son in Kuwait. He had gone there three days before the Aug. 2 invasion after repeated reassurances from the State Department that nothing untoward was going to happen. The soldiers took him first to Baghdad, then to a military installation as part of Iraq's ''human shield.

title: Review/Film Festival;   A Strange Triangle and Its Aftermath
description: Jacques Doillon's ''Vengeance d'une Femme'' (''A Woman's Revenge'') is described as being ''based loosely'' on Dostoyevsky's novella ''The Eternal Husband,'' which is said to be a classic.

title: Why Cars Need the Surge of Speed
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Jones Is Married
description: Susan J. Jones and John J. McKeon were married at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N.J., yesterday by the Rev. Dr. David St. George. Mrs. McKeon is a daughter of Carolyn W. Jones of Convent Station, N.J., and Harry H. Jones of Califon, N.J. She is a sales manager for the New Jersey Bell Yellow Pages in Somerset, N.J. Mr. McKeon a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. McKeon of Short Hills, is the managing partner of Emerald Associates, a money management firm in Millburn, N.J.

title: Lessons of Watergate
description: Among the casualties strewn in the wake of Watergate is the Presidential claim of uncontrolled discretion to withhold ''confidential'' information from the courts, raised to its highest pitch by Richard M. Nixon.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;   Recent Sales
description: Bedford, N.Y. $830,000

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: THE REV. ALOYSIUS P. KELLEY;

Jesuit Education for the 'Whole Person'
description: LEAD: SINCE the Rev. Aloysius P. Kelley, S.J., became Fairfield University's president in 1979, the landscape of the more than 200-acre, parklike campus has witnessed major development. Ten new complexes have been erected, including three sets of town-houses for use as dormitories, a faculty office building, an arts center with a 750-seat theater and a chapel scheduled to open in

title: What Would We Do Without Evil?
description: A GOOD BABY

title: Give Credit To Antley
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: For Thai Politician, a Break From Retirement
description: Now 79 years old, Kukrit Pramoj, one of the most revered figures in Thai political and intellectual life, has embarked on what he agrees is a kind of mad second childhood.

title: My Child, On Flight 103
description: Today is the first anniversary of the worst day of my life. On Dec. 21, 1988, my only child, Theodora (we called her Theo), was on her way home from London, where she had spent a semester studying drama. Theo never reached home. She was murdered by Palestinian terrorists: 269 people died with her. Theo was on Pan Am Flight 103, which exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland. What was she like, my Theo? Spunk and a sense of humor, that was my daughter. Long dark hair, sparkling dark eyes, a wide smile, that was my daughter. Witty, flamboyant, quick-tempered, tough to be around at times, that was my daughter. She was full of fire and adventure and joy. The last time I heard from Theo was Dec. 19, 1988. She said, ''I miss you and I love you.'' I couldn't wait to see her. Then came the panicky phone call from a friend. I turned on the television. In that one instant life broke. At Kennedy, all I did was scream.

title: A Very Fit and Proper 'Me and My Girl'
description: THERE'S a spate of ''Me and My Girls'' going around in the New York metropolitan area. Why, the show has taken on epidemic proportions in professional theaters, in semiprofessional theaters, in community theaters, in dinner theaters.

title: Ms. Lynch Is Wed To R. J. Makin Jr.
description: Madelaine Chauncey Lynch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Lynch Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday in Bridgehampton, L.I., to Richard John Makin Jr., the son of Mrs. Makin of Gloucester, Mass., and the late Mr. Makin. The Rev. Ronald G. Abrams and the Rev. Charles P. Scott officiated at St. Ann's Episcopal Church.

title: Court Denies Grandparents Visitation Rights
description: Grandparents do not have a legal right to visit a grandchild over the objection of the child's parents in ordinary circumstances, an appellate court has ruled in a Long Island case.

title: What Punishment Will Fit the Crime?
description: Last April, Michael R. Milken agreed to plead guilty to six felony counts, including conspiracy, securities law violations and tax fraud. These charges stemmed from his activities as head of the ''junk bond'' division of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The maximum prison sentence that Mr. Milken faces is 28 years.

title: Technology;   The Lure of Small Satellites
description: INCREASED demand from the telecommunications industry, the military and meterologists is fueling a rebirth of the small satellite. Less costly and quicker from drawing board to orbit than large satellites, ''lightsats'' are scheduled to be launched in record numbers over the next ten years.

title:
THE LITERARY EYE;

Swallowing
description: LEAD: The American people have swallowed a lot in the last four years. A lot of swallowing has been done. We have swallowed electric bugs, laundered money, quite a handsome amount of grain moving about in mysterious ways, a war more shameful than can be imagined, much else. There are even some people who believe that the

title: Lake Champlain
description: To the Editor: In reply to your article ''Champlain's Hideaway Islands'' (Travel, Aug. 5), I wish to add one additional suggestion to an otherwise very inclusive account of what to do on the islands. As a flatlander who vacations regularly on North Hero, we discovered the Northumbrian Pipers' Convention a few years ago and have made it a must on our Vermont vacation ever since. Held in the North Hero Village Hall the week before Labor Day, this workshop and concert attracts pipers from around the world. What begins on Sunday evening as a piping concert often ends after midnight as the audience clears the chairs and spontaneously begins dancing!

title: Kathleen Ballou, Banker, Engaged
description: October wedding plans for Kathleen Mary Ballou and Kevin Slattery McCarthy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard McCarthy of Longmeadow, Mass., have been announced by her mother, Mrs. Robert A. Ballou of Sea Girt, N.J.

title: Campus Life: Connecticut;   Summer Reading Includes Parents And Faculty, Too
description: Students, faculty and alumni all came back to Connecticut College last weekend to discuss a summer reading assignment. President Claire Gaudiani, who initiated the program, wrote in a letter to alumni and parents this summer, ''the college has achieved another first.''

title: Death Row
description: In October 1983, four days before he was to be executed in the electric chair at the Florida state prison at Starke, something took place that enraged Shabaka Sundiata Waglini more than any single event during his nearly 10 years on death row. They came into his cell and measured him for his burial suit. The bloodlessly finicky, mechanical tailoring procedure upset him violently.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

'Are You The Last in Line?' 'No, You Are!'
description: LEAD: SETTING lifetime goals often includes major events like going to college, getting married, raising a family and finding a satisfying career. Getting through each day on the way to these goals often requires performing a variety of routine tasks, rituals that can become irritating.

title: What's Inside A CD Player? More Pleasure
description: Among the millions of people now owning a CD player, many have only a fuzzy notion of how it works. With the old LP turntables, it was a lot easier to understand the basic principle of operation. You could practically tell by looking at it. The interaction of needle and groove seemed self-evident. By contrast, the digital transformation of sound into numbers and back again is much harder to imagine. Of course, it is hardly necessary to understand the theory of a CD player to appreciate the sound. You don't have to be a cook to enjoy a souffle. Still, knowing something about the anatomy of a CD player definitely adds to the pleasure of owning one.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Recycling Efforts Require More Than Hoopla
description: LEAD: EDUCATION is all about change, new knowledge, new perspectives and new behaviors. That should be the goal of all educational efforts, including recycling education.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title:
College Football;

McGwire Fills a Tall Order
description: LEAD: If Dan McGwire was more known for being the kid brother of the Oakland A's home run hitter than the quarterback of San Diego State University, he has since established his own identity, even in defeat. Brigham Young University's 62-34 victory over San Diego State, and Ty Detmer's brilliant statistics, did nothing to diminish McGwire's performance last Saturday in Provo,

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Miss Archibald Is Wed To Stanton Williams
description: Jennifer Gibson Archibald, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas N. Archibald of Pittsfield, Me., was married yesterday to Stanton North Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles N. Williams of Berlin, Conn. The Rev. Ted Hoskins performed the ceremony at the Union Congregational Church on Isle au Haut, Me.

title: Iraqi Document: A Correction
description: Because of an editing error, excerpts last Sunday from a document described by the Iraqi Government as a transcript of a meeting between President Saddam Hussein and the United States Ambassador to Iraq misattributed some remarks. The following remarks should have been attributed to President Hussein, not to Ambassador April C. Glaspie:

title: Out of the Melting Pot - Into?
description: To the Editor:

title: On Language;   Microwave of the Future
description: Jimmy, the most noteworthy item about electronic communication today is the fixation on viewer-avoiding transitions. This thought hit me upon receipt of a few items of the latest dialect from Lexicographic Irregular T. Brokaw of New York and Riyadh, after a brief sojourn in Montana.

title: Connecticut River Valley Provides Concert's Theme
description: ''HARTFORD, Northhampton and Saybrook'' is the umbrella title that covers a touring concert of music written, published or performed in the Connecticut River Valley before 1825. The brain child of Neely Bruce and his American Music-Theater Group, the program ''features pieces selected to demonstrate the variety of the material and the geographical spread of music throughout the entire river valley during this period,'' he said.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have several hardwood floors that are badly scratched in several places. There are black marks where a heavy piece of furniture was moved. Is there any way I can restore the finish in these areas?

title: Will Landlords Desert Their Buildings Again?
description: For much of the 1970's, landlords abandoned thousands of apartment buildings each year in New York City's poorest neighborhoods, producing a real-estate and social disaster of major proportions. More than 200,000 apartments were lost,and the burned-out shells that marred huge swaths of the South Bronx, Harlem and central Brooklyn became potent symbols of urban despair.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have several hardwood floors that are badly scratched in several places. There are black marks where a heavy piece of furniture was moved. Is there any way I can restore the finish in these areas?

title: Passaic Official Indicted in Voter-Registry Fraud
description: Assemblyman Cyril Yannarelli, Democrat of Passaic, has been indicted on charges that he, the Paterson Council President, Vera Ames, and six paid workers falsified as many as 5,000 voter-registration forms.

title: Ms. Gitlin Plans March Wedding
description: The engagement of Tina Gitlin to Steven Price, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Price of New York has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Joel S. Gitlin of New York. A March wedding is planned.

title: Why Limit Indexing to Capital Gains?
description: As a compromise in the tortuous budget negotiations, the Bush Administration has sensibly suggested the indexing of capital gains, so that we don't pay taxes on gains that are attributable solely to inflation. Indexing of capital gains probably will stimulate investment, at least moderately. But why stop there?

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Selective Pickers

title: In Harlem, Children Reflect the Ravages U.N. Seeks to Ease
description: Only a short distance from the polished glass towers of the United Nations, where 71 world leaders have converged this weekend for the first global summit on children, the very symptoms and conditions the leaders would eliminate still fester, in places like central Harlem, where the infant mortality rate is the same as Malaysia's.

title:
MUSIC;

Station Enjoying A Change
description: LEAD: WHEN Neely D. Crowley, general manager of radio station WSLT, and Jack Moore, the station's program director, agreed to change its format from ''adult contemporary'' to classical, they did so on a hunch, without formal surveys or market research studies.

title: Dump Quayle in '92? Despite Calls for Change, Probably Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Among the Crocodiles
description: From the paved road leading into Kakadu National Park the landscape is not terribly remarkable. As my mother, who lives in Memphis, Tenn., observed leaving Darwin, the capital of Australia's Top End and 75 miles from the park's entrance: ''It looks a lot like Arkansas to me.'' (All Tennesseans maintain the provincial belief that Arkansas is a dull state.) But as we neared the park things slowly began to change. What looked like a low-slung dachshund scurrying into a sewer grate was actually a giant lizard, the raucous bird on the telephone wire was a kookaburra and salmon-colored sand-castlelike sculptures as tall as basketball players began to dot the fields. We had entered the land of giant anthills known as the Kakadu.

title: Flying Blind in the Kremlin
description: Privatization. It's a simple enough idea. Let Soviet citizens, rather than the state, own the factories and farms. That way they'll have a stake in working hard. And that way the Soviets can finally break the chains of centralized control and race toward capitalism.

title: U.S. Explores New Strategies to Limit Weapons of Mass Destruction
description: Iraq's emergence as a regional superpower, bristling with missiles and chemical arms and close to producing nuclear ones, is prodding the Bush Administration to consider new strategies to stem the worldwide spread of mass-destruction weapons, according to Government officials.

title: How the Spin Doctors Operate
description: ROAD SHOW

title: Maura Kehoe Is Wed to David Collins
description: Maura Ann Kehoe and David Charles Collins were married yesterday at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club at Centre Island, L.I., by the Rev. Eric Markman, a Presbyterian minister. Mrs. Collins is the daughter of Kathleen McManus Kehoe of Glen Cove, L.I., and John P. Kehoe of New York. Mr. Collins is a son of Elizabeth Booth of Littleton, Colo., and Timothy Collins of Reno.

title: Why I Left America, And Why I Am Returning
description: I am often asked why I want to return to the U.S. This question never fails to bowl me over, and I find it impossible to answer. I feel it is an improper question. Most people who ask are not really interested in that question. What they want to know is what will I do if they allow me to return.

title: Should Jews Criticize Israel?
description: THE FUTURE OF THE JEWS

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;

Foreclosure Facing an 1,850-Unit Project
description: LEAD: The developers of an 1,850-unit condominium development on the Hudson River in Yonkers are trying to work out financial problems and deal with a pending bank foreclosure.

title: New Federal Law Encourages Fire Safety in Hotels
description: The fire safety of American hotels is taking a big step forward. This month brought the enactment of a law that will eventually require that 90 percent of civilians traveling on Federal Government business in the United States and its territories stay in hotels with sprinklers and smoke alarms if the Government is to pay the hotel bill. While the law does not mandate the installation of sprinklers, Federal employees are estimated to be worth $1.6 billion a year to the hotel industry, a big incentive.

title: Monterey
description: From its window on the Pacific 100 miles south of San Francisco, the Monterey Peninsula has been welcoming newcomers for almost four centuries: first came the explorer Sebastian Vizcaino, who sailed into Monterey Bay in 1602 and claimed all he could survey for Spain. More than a century and a half later came columns of dark-robed Catholic padres seeking souls on behalf of Rome. Then came successive waves of Spanish and Mexican colonials, New England whalers, Yankee traders, Italian immigrant fishermen, cowboys, farmers, merchants and others who helped create the modern state of California.
