title: Jeanne Jennings to Marry M. E. Hendrickson 3d
description: Jean Jennings of Huntington, L.I., has announced January wedding plans for her daughter, Jeanne Elizabeth Jennings, and M. Edmund Hendrickson 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Manville F. Hendrickson of Rye, N.Y.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Those Wild Spring Days of 1970, When We Were Young
description: LEAD: TWENTY-YEAR high school reunion bells are ringing. I'm trying to distinguish if the bells are sonorous funereal bells calling in middle age, festive carnival bells to celebrate having made it so far, or little bells in the back of my head reminding me of what I still want to accomplish.

title: Kuwaitis Say U.S. Doubts Embargo Will Get Iraq Out
description: Senior Kuwaiti officials say they believe the Bush Administration has concluded that it can no longer rely on the embargo of Iraq to force the Iraqi army out of the Persian Gulf sheikdom.

title: Moynihan's Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Nina Yonkman, Model, Is Wed
description: Nina Ver Meulen Yonkman and Harry Payne Tower were married yesterday at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Robert S. Hundley.

title: Day Devoted to Alzheimer's Disease
description: LEAD: EVERYONE from elementary schoolchildren to seasoned health-care professionals will have a chance to learn more about Alzheimer's disease Tuesday, when the White Plains Hospital Center's Senior Services Program sponsors ''Alzheimer's Awareness Day'' at various sites communitywide.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CHAMBER SYMPHONIES

title: Dr. Double-Face and His Descendents
description: LEAD:

title: Bringing a Touch Of Latin Sunniness To Amsterdam
description: It's American night at the Holland Festival. That means hot dogs and Heineken, red and white marshmallows and Dutch doughnuts made of heavy cake and dripping in sticky syrup. It means the highly refined Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra has temporarily exchanged the near-perfect sonics of its wondrous hall, the Concertgebouw, for the antiseptic sound of a convention center, where an audience of 4,600 can be accommodated on folding chairs, with plenty of room left for television cameras to capture Riccardo Chailly's enthusiastic, aerobic conducting from every angle or to pan close up to the delighted, cheering crowd. And it means, for the first time in the orchestra's history, an all-Gershwin program.

title: In Cities, Who Is The Real Mugger?
description: Bernhard Hugo Goetz has become a folk hero. Respectable citizens have identified with his shooting of four teen-agers who ''harassed'' him on the subway and asked him for $5. In so dealing with these potential ''muggers,'' Mr. Goetz personified and aroused the pervasive fears, anger and sense of personal powerlessness of a large segment of the public faced with rising urban crime. The outrage over lawlessness in our cities has masked the lawless act of an individual. But this incident cannot be understood in isolation.

title: Bush Is in New York for the U.N. Conference and a Flurry of Gulf Diplomacy
description: Blending humanitarian concerns with military ones, President Bush arrived in New York yesterday to attend an international summit meeting on children and to engage in three days of aerobic diplomacy designed to send President Saddam Hussein of Iraq a signal that the world's patience is running out.

title: In the Region: New Jersey;   JUMP Program Aids Low-Cost Rentals By RACHELLE GARBARINE
description: Even during the construction boom of the mid-80's, new rental projects in the state were rare. Now two New Jersey developers and one from Manhattan are building rental housing under a state program meant to produce urban units for low-income families.

title: Candidates Stressing Dramatic Differences
description: LEAD: THE Republican Congressional candidate in the Third District, Thomas Scott, says the only thing he has in common with his Democratic opponent, Rosa L. DeLauro, is that they were both born in New Haven.

title: Voters Choose The Best TV Sets
description: The count is in for 1990. Nine hundred and thirteen video dealers voted for what they considered the best products of the year in the annual poll by Audio/Video International, a leading trade journal.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ENRICO CARUSO: My Father and My Family. By Enrico Caruso Jr. and Andrew Farkas. (Amadeus Press, $39.95.) Enrico Caruso Jr. was 17 and his brother, Rudolfo, was 23 when their father, the renowned operatic tenor, died in 1921. In 1983, at 79, Enrico Caruso Jr. began an extraordinary project. He recorded his memories of his father, which formed the basis of a highly readable biography, ''Enrico Caruso,'' written with Andrew Farkas, a professor of library science at the University of North Florida and the editor of ''Lawrence Tibbett: Singing Actor.'' The fascinating personal life of the flamboyant, earnest elder Caruso resembled soap more than grand opera, though the authors tell the drama with the polite dispassion of a watcher from the stage wings. Caruso spent money lavishly on homes, hotel suites, clothes, jewelry and women. The opera singer Ada Giachetti, who abandoned her husband and infant to live with Caruso, was the mother of Rudolfo and Enrico Jr. In 1908, she bolted with the family chauffeur. In 1912, Rina Giachetti, sister to Ada and also a famous singer, became Caruso's mistress. Her tenure ended abruptly in 1918 when he unexpectedly married an American, Dorothy Park Benjamin. The Carusos had a daughter, Gloria, who inherited the bulk of her father's estate. Although the sons never really knew a mother and never dared contradict or assert themselves with their father, they seem to have adored him. Enrico Caruso Jr., who died in 1987, has served his father well with musical details of the singer's life throughout the text, accompanied by some 200 family photographs, including wonderful caricatures, some in color, by the Great Caruso. The authors have also provided a discography of all the Caruso recordings, dates and places of the tenor's performances of operas and recitals, and bibliographies of earlier biographies. Enrico Caruso Jr. finally earned, posthumously, his own sustained ''Bravo.''

title: Just 85 Shopping Days Left Until Christmas
description: IT began in May. Late May - Memorial Day to be exact - but May nonetheless. It was then that I saw my first Christmas ad, the first of the very, very many we will be inundated with between now and Dec. 24.

title: Hampstead Hangouts
description: In Hampstead on a given afternoon, the world sits down to coffee. Polish and Russian, German and French, Hebrew, Arabic, Spanish, and all the Englishes of the world - American, Australian, South African, Indian - blend in the fervor of love or debate.

title: From TV to Antietam, Musings on the Civil War
description: It is little more than a long depression in the ground now, weathered smooth and benign by time, like the rest of Antietam Battlefield, America's deadliest killing ground.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Mow if the new lawn is at least three inches tall. Keep up with planting, particularly container-grown perennials and shrubs; wait until leaves fall to transplant large trees. Start planting hardy bulbs. Start raking if the leaves are beginning to fall. Pick and dry herbs, grasses and strawflowers for winter bouquets. Pot up seedlings and move them into the coldframe; it is late in the year to plant young newly-rooted plants in the garden.

title: A Whiff Of Deflation In the Air
description: Around the world, something very close to a debt panic has begun. After years of expansion, credit now appears to be contracting. The great fear, as Nancy Reagan might say, is that borrowers will ''just say no'' when it comes time to repay.

title: World's Leaders Gather at U.N. for Summit Meeting on Children
description: More than 70 world leaders will meet here on Sunday to adopt an ambitious set of goals to improve life for poor children throughout the world.

title: Data Bank/September 30, 1990
Don't Call Us Selfish
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SPORTSCASTERS
description: Perhaps Bud Collins, on-air at Wimbledon, said it best, ''Let's just watch.''

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Who Is the Best Coach In Pro Football?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BECOMING GERSHONA

title: WILDMON'S WAR ON THE ARTS
description: Despite the attempt to characterize the N.E.A. controversy as a struggle between artistic freedom and censorship, the real issue is whether art should be publicly subsidized and, if so, with what restrictions as to content. No one is seriously contending that works of art should be censored, but rather than certain works should not be funded at public expense.

title: Jerusalem, Baghdad
description: Iraq's occupation of Kuwait not only menaces Saudi Arabia and the oil producing emirates but also is likely to change the power balance dramatically in the Arab Middle East. It will do so by posing a serious challenge to Egypt's ascendancy, threatening the rival Baathist regime in Syria and turning Jordan into an Iraqi protectorate.

title: Baseball;   Pirates Sprinting to Finish
description: Like a world-class runner who kicks hard and fast as he sprints to the finish line, the Pittsburgh Pirates are ending the division race impressively.

title: Nuns and Priests Offer Ways of Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: About Cars;   Will Saturn Weather Geo's Storm?
description: It will be interesting to see what happens when General Motors finally gives birth to its new baby, the Saturn. Will buyers flock to ooh and ahh. To coo, perhaps to buy?

title: Tot-Rock: A Mini-Boom in Pop Music
description: It was the screams, finally, that signaled the change. The sound of the audience at a New Kids on the Block concert - a sustained soprano wail - wouldn't have been heard a decade ago, when pop was the province of teenagers and their elders. Screaming girls have accompanied pop phenomena at least since Frank Sinatra wowed the bobby-soxers, but teen-age hysteria tends to be about half an octave and some decibels lower than the response to the New Kids. That piercing shriek, like an agonized herd of hydraulic brakes, is the sound of pop's latest marketing breakthrough - the power to draw pre-teens, grade schoolers and pre-schoolers, with their resigned parents in tow.

title: The Role Slides Play in Judging Art
description: SOONER or later, most contemporary artists confront the need to photograph their work. Slides have become a fact of life in juried exhibitions, and artists hoping for shows in distant cities have little choice but to send photographs.

title: WILDMON'S WAR ON THE ARTS
description: As a longtime member of New York City's gay and arts communities, I find Wildmon, with his newsletter propagandizing and down-home, good-guy act, to be obnoxious and more than a little fascistic. It is no less appalling to me, however, that avant-garde artists and the curators who show their work have the audacity to expect funding and support from a Government and populace that their art seems to depise.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: The lowly cent has taken quite a beating in the past few years. Some merchants and others are calling for the end of the least valuable coin. Even Congress has been asked to look into the possibility of minting a new dollar coin and to stop minting the cent.

title: U.S. Urges Nicaragua to Forgive Legal Claim
description: With hundreds of millions of dollars of American aid hanging in the balance, the Bush Administration has begun exerting sharp new pressure on President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro to abandon a judgment of as much as $17 billion that Nicaragua won against the United States at the International Court of Justice during the contra war.

title: Single Parents Find Help With Sharing Homes
description: THREE years ago, a financially comfortable 80-year-old widow was finding it hard to manage her house in Bergen County, where she had lived for many years. She opted to share her home with a single father who had custody of his son and daughter on weekends. In exchange, he agreed to help her with the maintenance.

title: Visions of Home;   As Welfare Hotels Return, Children Recall What Life Inside Was Once Like
description: Every Wednesday I have to go to the Barber Shop and have Vincent shape my hair. He does absolutely nothing but talk and swiggles me around in that chair and hurts my neck with that whiskbroom. Sometimes I sklonk him in the kneecap. Vincent says that if I am not careful I am not going to have a hair on my head by the time I'm 7 for Lord's sake.

title: Miss Bliss and William Marshall 3d Are Married in Chestertown, Md.
description: Georgina Bassett Bliss, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hooker Bliss of Worton, Md., was married yesterday to William Richmond Marshall 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Swan Marshall 3d of Harbour Island, the Bahamas. The Rev. Gregory S. Straub performed the Episcopal ceremony at Emmanuel Church in Chestertown, Md.

title: Ted & Mary & Archie & Fido
description: I see that a lot of people are going bisexual this year. This seems to be different from going homosexual, which was last year, in that the homosexuals weren't going, actually. Usually they were coming out, whereas the bisexuals like to talk about it, as people do about their travels. They don't talk, actually; they confess.

title: CRIME
description: There's a type of mystery that begs to be called the Big Boys' Adventure Book. The central character, who is always male and often middle-aged, has made a pretty penny at some respectable profession like teaching or dentistry, but he craves more excitement in his life. If he's lucky, some mad-dog killer will stray onto his suburban patch, and before you can say ''Cancel that 2 o'clock root canal, nurse,'' he's oiled his service revolver and is tearing off in his BMW after truth, justice and kicks. It obviously takes a special storytelling gift to lend credibility to this sort of fantasy, plus a certain boyish esprit to make it fun.

title: The Loneliness of Divorce
description: THEY walked into the room one by one. A quick glance at those already there, a hesitant smile at eyes that connected, and each person quickly took a seat at the T-shape conference table. Fourteen women and one man gathered as unknown colleagues venturing into unknown territory.

title: Elizabeth Paradise Married
description: Elizabeth Janeway Paradise and John Matthew Sweeney were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Sacred Heart in Richmond, Va., by the Rev. Thomas Miller. Mrs. Sweeney, an advertising copywriter with the Martin Agency in Richmond, is the daughter of Joan Paradise of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Robert Paradise of Greenwich, Conn. She graduated from the University of North Carolina, where Mr. Sweeney received a master's degree in educational media and is an associate professor of journalism. Mr. Sweeney, a son of Mrs. William Sweeney of Washington and the late Mr. Sweeney, graduated from Northwestern University.

title: The Third World War
description: Very few have noticed, or have had the courage to admit, that World War III has already happened. It ended this year - with the free world soundly defeated.

title: Arafat's Aide, On Talks
description: The Palestinians want lasting peace and security for themselves and the Israelis because no one can build his own future on the ruins of another's. The key to a settlement lies in talks between the Palestinians and Israelis.

title: Katherine Lewis Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Katherine Rush Lewis to Adam Weinstein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry Weinstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. Alfred B. Lewis and Mary E. Lewis, both of New York. The couple plan to marry in October. Miss Lewis, 27 years old, graduated from the Brearley School and Haverford College. She and her fiance, a Yale University alumnus, both received M.B.A. degrees from Harvard University. She is a consultant at Bain & Company, a management consultants in Boston.

title: Few Old Millionaires
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Bash the Bottom Line
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Texasville' Isn't Deja Vu All Over Again
description: The dictionary defines it as ''a literary work continuing the course of a narrative begun in a preceding one,'' but Hollywood sees it differently. A sequel, most likely, means more of the same. These days a successful film is no sooner off the drawing board than someone is ready to add a ''II'' to its title and send the same characters jumping, a bit more wearily, through the same hoops. When the retreads rule, the honest sequels become rarities, for better or worse.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Should The Yanks Rebuild The Team?
description: The Yankee management must nurture Kelly, Maas, Leyritz and Azocar and develop future star players from its farm system. Veterans such as Mattingly, Sax and Espinoza must serve as a solid foundation and example for younger players. Quality pitchers should be sought from current major league rosters and, by all means, the able and stable Stump Merrill should be retained as field manager.

title: Too Many People Believe Myths of Aging
description: While I realize that Barbara Klaus's article ''Are You Out to Lunch on Your Birthday?'' [Sept. 9] was meant to be humorous, at the core of the article are the aging myths unfortunately believed by many younger people - and some older ones for whom it's a big source of anxiety.

title: Presenting Folk Art's Greatest Hits
description: Five years ago Jean Lipman, the doyenne of folk-art collectors, began discussing the decline in quality of the art with Robert Bishop, the director of New York's Museum of American Folk Art. Their talks resulted in ''Five-Star Folk Art,'' a museum show and book that present some of the genre's most memorable portraits, weather vanes, quilts, furniture and trade figures. The exhibition, which opened earlier this month at the museum, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, continues through Dec. 2.

title: Los Angeles Journal;   Counter-Trend: Rights of the Unhip
description: Of all of life's cruel jokes, perhaps none is harsher here in the West Coast capital of trendiness than to be judged in front of one's peers as being hopelessly uncool. It's enough to make a dude rip off his acid green framed sunglasses, jump into his shocking pink nylon running shorts and go file a lawsuit.

title: New Season: Audacious, Varied and Vital
description: WHAT are the consequences of the austere economic outlook and the precarious state of the arts for the new season? Conservative? Perhaps compromised and curtailed theater fare? Not so. Consider the audaciousness, variety, vitality - and sheer bounty - of the theater season just begun in Connecticut's regional playhouses. A survey of the repertories of the state's professional companies affirms the freeing power of the playwright's art. If it is to reflect reality, it is also reflecting upon it, making statements of defiance and transcendence.

title: On Unity's Eve, Subdued Mood Replaces Euphoria
description: On the eve of German unity, large crowds have been drawn to a major exhibition in West Berlin devoted to Otto von Bismarck, the original architect of German unity.

title: INSIDE
description: Reflection for Germans

title: Tell Me About It, Lucky
description: LADY BOSS.

title: Soviets Hint at a Role In U.N. Military Action
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, has indicated that if the United Nations Security Council authorizes a military force to act in the Persian Gulf crisis, Soviet troops might take part.

title:
WATERGATE;

A Soliloquy
description: LEAD:

title: College Football;   West Virginia Upsets Pitt
description: Greg Jones threw for two touchdowns and Mike Beasley ran for 135 of his 197 yards and a touchdown in the first half as West Virginia, held to 17 points in its previous two games, exploded for 547 yards to upset its rival Pitt, 38-24, today.

title: ROMANIA'S LOST CHILDREN
description: We wish to express our most grateful thanks to your generous readers whose moral support and financial contribution will be of great help in the continuation of our work in Romania (''Romania's Lost Children,'' a photo essay by James Nachtwey, with text by Kathleen Hunt). Unfortunately, we cannot answer all the mail we received following the mention in your columns of our fund for Romanian children. But to each of you, and in the names of those unfortunate children: Merci beaucoup and Multu mesc soarte mult.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are ready to defend our country, but we want to be supported and respected for what we're doing.''

title: Australia Wants Asia to Come A-Waltzing
description: For years, this outpost of Europe behaved like a standoffish neighbor to the Asian community it lived in. Instead of cultivating ties with the community, it relied on its own natural wealth and its political, economic and cultural links to Europe.

title: College Football: Local;   A Backup Passer Rolls for Hofstra
description: Tim Lynch, who replaced the ailing Rhory Moss at quarterback, threw four touchdown passes yesterday as undefeated Hofstra crushed Buffalo, 44-0, at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, L.I.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Pro Football;   Eason Not Bitter in Return
description: With the Jets traveling to New England to face the Patriots in Foxboro Stadium today, the obvious questions arose for Tony Eason during the week. Would the Jets' backup quarterback be going up ahead of time and was he eager to get into the game against his former teammates?

title: Linda Ianieri Wed To W. J. Mosconi
description: St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Linda Helen Ianieri and William John Mosconi. The Rev. Damien O'Connell performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Rock;   Heavy Metal From an Era Before Poses
description: Masters of Reality are a streamlined blast from the past - specifically, from the cusp of the 1960's and 70's, the era of Cream and early Led Zeppelin and Black Sabbath, when blues-rock was turning into heavy metal, but before bands learned how to pose.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: SCARSDALE HIGH SCHOOL;

A Heads-Up Sports Program Tosses Aside an Egghead Image
description: LEAD: MORE brains than brawn: that has been a popular image of Scarsdale High School, an institution with a reputation for scholastic excellence in a community perennially described as affluent and academically oriented. Ask someone unfamiliar with the realities of the local scene to name a top sports high school and chances are Scarsdale would not be mentioned.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 23, 1990
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 43 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $5.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 2 5 SILENT PARTNER, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Bantam, $5.95.) The psychologist-detective Alex Delaware investigates an apparent suicide. 3 * 10 CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $5.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan fights Colombian drug lords. 4 9 THE PILLARS OF THE EARTH, by Ken Follett. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Murder, arson and lust surround the building of a 12th-century cathedral. 5 3 COUNTERATTACK, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Jove, $5.50.) Volume Three of ''The Corps'' follows the Marines from Pearl Harbor to Guadalcanal. 6 3 THE OLD SILENT, by Martha Grimes. (Dell, $5.95.) Scotland Yard's Richard Jury probes a triple-murder case in the West Country. 7 18 THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Ivy, $5.95.) The tensions and bonds shared by Chinese-American women and their immigrant mothers. 8 2 SOME CAN WHISTLE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $5.95.) A middle-aged writer meets the daughter he has never seen. 9 3 MODERN WOMEN, by Ruth Harris. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) The lives of three newcomers to New York are greatly changed by a selfish man. 10 * 2 EARTH SONG, by Catherine Coulter. (Onyx, $4.95.) A 13th-century Cornwall woman runs away from home to avoid a marriage. 11 7 THE ENDEARMENT, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Jove, $4.95.) A mail-order bride from Boston finds true love on the Minnesota frontier. 12 3 THE CAT WHO TALKED TO GHOSTS, by Lilian Jackson Braun. (Jove, $3.95.) A reporter and his two Siamese cats look into a mysterious death. 13 1 ULTIMATE PRIZES, by Susan Howatch. (Fawcett, $5.95.) The midlife crisis of an English archdeacon. 14 * 3 THE RENEGADES OF PERN, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $5.95.) Strife on the once-paradisiacal planet of Pern. 15 2 THE EYES OF THE BEHOLDERS, by A. C. Crispin. (Pocket, $4.50.) ''Star Trek'' 's Enterprise investigates the disappearance of several spaceships on a newly opened trade route. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 44 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 2 * 6 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict over the past decade. 3 361 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 4 4 I WANT TO GROW HAIR, I WANT TO GROW UP, I WANT TO GO TO BOISE, by Erma Bombeck. (Harper Paperbacks, $5.50.) Fifteen stories of children surviving cancer. 5 16 WHEN RABBIT HOWLS, by the Troops for Truddi Chase. (Jove, $4.95.) A woman voices the 92 personalities that live within her. 6 * 16 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $9.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 7 2 THE ROAD FROM COORAIN, by Jill Ker Conway. (Vintage, $8.95.) The historian and former president of Smith College recalls her childhood on an Australian sheep farm. 8 13 IT'S ALWAYS SOMETHING, by Gilda Radner. (Avon, $4.95.) The late comedian's memoir. 9 7 THE BRIDESMAIDS, by Judith Balaban Quine. (Pocket, $5.95.) The lives of Grace Kelly and the six attendants at her marriage to Prince Rainier. 10 110 LOVE, MEDICINE, AND MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 11 * 3 AMONG SCHOOLCHILDREN, by Tracy Kidder. (Avon, $9.95.) A year in the life of a fifth-grade teacher in Holyoke, Mass. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 107 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/HarperCollins, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people. 2 31 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $7.95.) The 1990 edition. 3 20 THE T-FACTOR FAT GRAM COUNTER, by Jamie Pope-Cordle and Martin Katahn. (Norton, $2.50.) How to reduce fat in one's diet. 4 3 WHAT TO EXPECT WHEN YOU'RE EXPECTING, by Arlene Eisenberg, Heidi E. Murkoff and Sandee E. Hathaway. (Workman, $8.95.) Counsel for parents-to-be. 5 1 TOXIC PARENTS, by Susan Forward with Craig Buck. (Bantam, $5.95.) Ways by which you can improve your relationship with your parents.

title: Elizabeth S. Gillan Is Wed
description: Elizabeth Stuart Gillan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Wilson Gillan of Wilbraham, Mass., was married yesterday at the First Church of Christ Congregational in Springfield, Mass., to Peter Joseph Caulo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Caulo of Centerville, Mass. The Rev. Thomas C. Carlton and the Rev. Barnabas Keck, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Mrs. Caulo, 27 years old, graduated from Pine Manor College and the University of Massachusetts. She is the advertising traffic manager for Adweek magazine in New York. Mr. Caulo, 28, a graduate of Merrimack College, is a vice president at Lehman Brothers.

title: London's Literary Village
description: Hampstead is a village of dreams gazing down loftily on the City of London from its hillside perch, about three miles away to the northeast. For two centuries the pretty streets, hidden courtyards and tree-lined groves have provided a haven for writers, artists and scholars.

title: Awkward but Immortal
description: THEODORE DREISER

title: Question Of the Week;   How Should The Yanks Rebuild The Team?
description: Above all, the Yankees should resist the temptation to make Maas the designated hitter. It ruins young players by taking them out of half of the game. Both Mattingly and Maas should work out in left and Azocar in right. Barfield should relearn how to go the other way. Then work out a rotation between the four for positions in the field and designated hitter. The catching corps should take up yoga or anything to avoid the injuries that have plagued Yankee catchers since Munson. And can Nokes catch? If so, why doesn't he?

title: College Football;   For Once, Irish Win Easily
description: There was no need for narrow escapes and last-minute heroics by the Fighting Irish this afternoon in their game against Purdue.

title: Miracles at a Price
description: THE BABY DOCTORS

title: Rio de Janeiro's Rich Trove of Gems
description: Smart shoppers in Brazil know that the best buys come in small packages. When one thinks of Rio de Janeiro, flamboyantly colored, itsy-bitsy bikinis, or fio dentals - dental floss - as they are called, come to mind. But Brazil is also the source for dazzlingly colored emeralds, aquamarines, amethysts, topazes and tourmalines. Sixty-five percent of the world's gem production takes place in Brazil, according to Richard Ojalvo, vice president of Amsterdam Sauer, a major jewelry retailer with more than 40 shops in Brazil, New York and St. Thomas. Brazil has an unusual variety of colored gems as well as the advantage - for the manufacturers - of inexpensive labor.

title: Catholic Education
description: A free spirit is important, leaders of Catholic colleges and universities have argued, to insure academic freedom and to avoid jeopardizing government financing. For the last several years, however, they have feared a Vatican crackdown. Last week, many of them were relieved when Archbishop Pio Laghi, a former papal ambassador to the United States who is now head of the Vatican's Congregation for Catholic Education, presented a document upholding independence for the schools. The Apostolic Constitution on Catholic Universities said that it was important that the institutions maintain a religious character and fidelity to Catholic teachings, but it did not adopt provisions in earlier drafts that seemed to give Vatican officials and local bishops more control over the schools.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Military Museum 'Guards' the Harbor
description: The British were coming - someday. But they never made it to Fort Hamilton.

title: Ignorant Drug Policy
description: The United States' war on drugs has led to the attempted ouster of Panama's leader, the virtual kidnapping of a Honduran, new efforts to burn crops in Bolivia and a proposed Congressional resolution accusing Mexican officials of accepting bribes. A short time ago, similar actions were directed at Pakistan, Colombia, Peru, Turkey and Thailand.

title: Julie McDonald Weds Peter Gilbertson
description: Julie McDonald, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. McDonald of Canandaigua, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Peter Andrews Gilbertson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis E. Gilbertson of Rumson, N.J.

title: Traffic Alert
description: World Summit for Children:

title: Lifestyle;   Signs Do the Talking: No Sitting, No Menus, No!
description: New Yorkers, considered to be an extremely vocal lot, are increasingly getting their messages across without saying a word. They just let their signs do the talking.

title: Perspectives: East Side Housing;   Zoning's Potent Impact on Development
description: A new apartment house that may be the last of its kind on a wide cross street on the Upper East Side is on the point of coming on the rental market. It is called the Lucerne - at 350 East 79th Street, on the southwest corner of First Avenue - and its design points up one of the dilemmas of East Side zoning: How to limit the height of new buildings without creatinng still another blow to housing production.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: P. D. Q. BACH

title: Anne C. Thacher and Kenneth B. Tate Jr. Marry
description: Anne Creveling Thacher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter S. Thacher of Stonington, Conn., and Washington, was married yesterday to Kenneth Burrell Tate Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Burrell Tate of Stonington. E. Sims Casey, a justice of the peace, officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: TOP GERMAN COURT REJECTS VOTE RULE
description: West Germany's highest court today struck down the election rules prepared for the first all-German vote in December, saying that they posed unfair obstacles to small political groups.

title: Legislators Agree to Condemn Jay Property
description: A NEW chapter in the long history of the Jay property opened last week when the Board of Legislators voted to condemn the 23-acre site, which adjoins the county-owned Marshlands Conservancy in Rye and has been the focus of a decadelong dispute over development.

title: The Allure of the Raj
description: THE SUN IN THE MORNING

title: Postings: Florida Sites;   Sidewalk Sales Pitch
description: Sidewalk vendors have an uncanny ability to discern New Yorkers' needs - witness the sunglass stands that miraculously become umbrella stands at the first drop of rain. So with all the recent talk about people wanting to flee this area for friendlier climes, it was no real surprise to find a sidewalk vendor hawking land in Florida.

title: The People vs. Pollution
description: NO SAFE PLACE

title: All About/Corporate Jets;   The Ultimate Status Symbol Still Sells
description: People who sell corporate jets can talk a transcontinental streak about the security, convenience and flexibility their products afford. What they don't need to say is that these particular corporate assets are 600 mile-per-hour odes to success - faster than airliners, with interiors that make first class seem like steerage.

title: P.L.O. Embarks on Biggest Gamble in Many Years by Moving Closer to Iraq
description: As the Persian Gulf crisis drives ever-deeper schisms through Arab ranks, the Palestine Liberation Organization and its chairman, Yasir Arafat, have embarked on a political gamble with stakes as high as any the organization has faced in many years of crisis.

title: Commercial Property: 57th Street;   A New Glitter Added to a Premier Retail Boulevard
description: While much around it seems to be moribund, 57th Street is showing signs of vitality, with several significant projects nearing completion or under way. The Japanese are prominent, with other players coming from London, Paris, Munich and - perhaps - Redmond, Wash.

title: For a Bonsai Artist, Pleasure and Profit
description: LEAD: BRIARCLIFF MANOR

title: Currency;   Another Big Jump for Gold Prices
Joi Katz Plans to Wed Peter Baum This Fall
description: November wedding plans for Joi Lisa Katz and Peter David Baum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner G. Baum of White Plains, have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Katz of the Port Liberte section of Jersey City.

title: Airport Security After a Tragedy
description: Re: ''Lockerbie Aftermath: Split Among Families, Aug. 12.''

title: Howard Beach, U.S.A.
description: Although Mayor Koch's intentions in visiting Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church were laudable, the anger with which he was met by its Howard Beach parishioners was totally understandable. The people there figure they're not very different from those in any other all-white neighborhood and thus should not be singled out for deviating from the national norm.

title: Washington Holds the Key
description: While the situation in the occupied territories continues to deteriorate, neither the Palestinians nor the Israelis can or will make the first genuine move toward reconciliation. Only strong action from Washington can end the violence.

title:
ENVIRONMENT;

A Welfare Mother's Trouble
description: LEAD: The public seems to forget that when we welfare mothers got married and planned our lives, we, just like you, expected our marriages to last. To all you people who were lucky enough to have your marriages last and who have ''lived happily ever after,'' I am very glad you made it.

title: Operatic Winds Blowing Every Which Way
description: Never, in the history of any art form, does all creative activity appear to be heading in the same direction at once. That easy truism is vividly illustrated by the confused state of operatic staging and design today. It is as if two warriors were mounted on the same horse facing in opposite directions, both waving swords and crying ''Charge!'' The horse goes its own way, following some mysterious urge known only to its genes. Opera survives, somehow.

title: Motorist Aids Cyclist in Distress
description: I write in response to the Aug. 19 article [''A Car Transforms a Good Samaritan''] from the bicyclist who fell in Montauk and received no assistance from motorists who drove by. I am sorry for her, and for others who are not helped when they're in need.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Feeding the Birds: It's a Jungle Out There
description: LEAD: A THOUGHTFUL friend once gave us one of those cute, clear plastic, press-on-the-window bird feeders. You fill it with seed, stick it on a window and watch birds nibble inches from your nose. In theory, that's how it's supposed to work.

title: Margaret Schiffenhaus Wed to Ernest DiPietro
description: Margaret Ann Schiffenhaus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence C. Schiffenhaus of Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church to Ernest William DiPietro, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph DiPietro of San Diego. The Rev. William J. Dowd officiated.

title: Year Later, Dinkins's Friends in the Unions Are Facing Their Contracts' End
description: Most of New York City's municipal unions were marching at David N. Dinkins's side a year ago, campaigning for his election as Mayor. But with two contracts to expire at midnight tonight, the unions now face him across the table in hard bargaining for raises at a time when the city says it cannot afford them.

title: U. of Bridgeport Gets Tentative Agreement
description: One of three striking unions at the University of Bridgeport has reached a tentative agreement with the school after a monthlong strike, but two other unions remain deadlocked.

title: Postings: 7 on Wednesday;   Managing Rentals
description: New York City landlords and managers of small rental properties who feel in need of a business refresher or primer can enroll in a seven-session course at the Cornell University Cooperative Extension, 280 Broadway, at Chambers Street. The two-hour sessions, beginning at 6 P.M. on each of the next seven Wednesdays, will cover the following topics:

title: Kimberly Betz Married To David M. Woodman
description: Kimberly A. Betz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Betz of New Caanan, Conn., was married there yesterday to David M. Woodman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Woodman of Laurel Hollow, L.I. The Rev. James J. Benson officiated at the United Methodist Church. Mrs. Woodman, 27 years old, is the assistant to the president, and her husband, 31, is the president of the Woodman Construction Company and Punchlist Inc. in New York. She is a graduate of Dickinson College. Her father is a director of United States marketing and services for the International Business Machines Corporation in Southbury, Conn. The bridegroom's father is a senior vice president of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York.

title: Ms. Weaver Plans October Wedding
description: Dr. Jeanne M. Weaver of Birmingham, Ala., has announced October wedding plans for her daughter Julia Anna Weaver and William N. Bernstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Bernstein of East Rockaway, L.I.

title: No Headline
description: Philip H. Geier Jr. has become a kind of corporate psychiatrist treating a case of schizophrenia at the Interpublic Group of Companies, the largest and oldest advertising conglomerate in the United States. And at least for the present the treatment seems to be working beautifully.

title: Campus Life: Oklahoma;   State Regents Propose 'No Pass No Play' Plan
description: A proposed ''no pass no play'' rule governing sports and other extracurricular activities for Oklahoma college students is causing an uproar on campuses and becoming an issue for political campaigns. If approved, state education officials say, Oklahoma could be the first to have such a rule on a statewide college basis.

title: Spectaculars That Go Beyond Spectacle
description: Dances can take people's breath away. That includes the breath of spectators and performers alike. When movement is allied with elaborate stage designs and atmospheric music, dances may be astonishing spectacles. The best of such attractions eventually do more than dazzle.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have several hardwood floors that are badly scratched in several places. There are black marks where a heavy piece of furniture was moved. Is there any way I can restore the finish in these areas?

title: Romantic Views Recall the Berkshires
description: THERE are occasions when revisionism cannot be told from regionalism, and ''Arcadia Revisited'' is one of them. An export from the Berkshire Museum in, Pittsfield, Mass., to the New Britain Museum of American Art, this is a show of about 50 landscapes painted in the Berkshires between the early 1830's and the late 1890's. It was organized by the Massachusetts museum's curator of education, Maureen Hickey. The catalogue, however, is a joint effort by Mrs. Hickey and William T. Oedel, a professor of art history at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, and their stated aim is to show the Berkshire region as the mecca it was for landscapists famous and obscure.

title: George L. Hubbell Jr., Lawyer, 96

title: Beneath Faded Glamour, a Real Maestro

He and the music he conducts are impressed all over that 1941 classic, even though Disney's heirs misguidedly re-recorded the soundtrack digitally a few years ago.

description: LEAD: To celebrate the Labor Day weekend, Richard Vega, the owner of the Catalpa Deli and Grocery in Ridgewood, Queens, gave a block party. ''I've only been here a year, but I know all my customers by name,'' said the 27-year-old Mr. Vega, who was an internal auditor on Wall Street before buying the store on Catalpa Avenue at 60th

title: What It Means To Turn 50
description: When I was in my 30's, a 50-year-old friend told me that you don't know anything until you are 50. I reach 50, and what does he tell me? ''You really don't know anything until you are 60.''

title: Wall Street;   Stubbing a Toe on Primerica
description: The markets are clearly of two minds about the Primerica Corporation, the financial conglomerate that owns Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, the Commercial Credit Company and the A. L. Williams insurance operation.

title: The Song of High Watt

title: Review/Film Festival;   A Modernist Approach to Biography
description: Biography, once considered a direct and factual form, long ago gave way to interpretive psychobiography. Several films to be shown today at the New York Film Festival take that modernist approach, still archaically called avant-garde, and apply it to lives as different as those of Andy Warhol and an Indian classical musician named Siddheshwari Devi. As these collages of images and voice-overs swirl across the screen, each becomes a collaboration among the subject, the film maker and the viewer, creating biographies whose forms mirror the lives they chronicles.

title: Hot Wheels
description: We were college chums. few students on campus could afford a car, never mind a sports car, but this friend was an exception. A member of a wealthy Pennsylvania family, he had developed a taste for fine automobiles, and sophomore year he showed up with a new Triumph TR 250 roadster in British racing green. The Triumph's canvas roof folded down on sunny days, and we would chase the open road, the wind drowning our laughter as we tried to outdo each other at the wheel.

title: Tech Notes;   Images of an Atom From an Electron Microscope
description: With conventional electron microscopes, the material under study is illuminated with a broad beam of electrons. The electrons strike the object, are scattered, detected and then converted into an image. Because the electrons are scattered, image resolution is too poor to see individual atoms. Now, a team of researchers at the Oak Ridge National Laboratories in Tennessee has developed a microscope based on what they call Z-contrast imaging. This new technique uses a finely focused electron beam to scan an object. Because the beam is narrow, the image is easier to detect than ones made with a conventional electron microscope. The new system can resolve an image small enough to obtain a clear image of an atom.

title: Paper Reports 6 Officers May Be Tied to Slaying
description: Detectives looking into the slayings of 43 women here are investigating up to six current and former police officers who may be linked to one of the slayings and the disappearance of a prostitute, according to a newspaper report.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: ALBERT ANOUNA;

Where the Business Is Reproduction
description: LEAD: FROM the outside, it looks like one of hundreds of businesses housed in the small office buildings that line busy Route 22 in Union County. Inside, though, that impression immediately changes. Biogenetics, a sperm bank, is believed to be one of two in the New York metropolitan area and the only one in New Jersey.

title: School Football;   A New Moore at Hempstead
description: If you ask Charles Moore how often he gets to see his older brother play professional football, he would look at you and say, ''He does his thing and I do mine.''

title: Haiti, Easing Uncertainty, Plans Elections Dec. 16
description: After months of political uncertainty deepened by the recent return from exile of two widely feared figures of the deposed Duvalier dictatorship, Haitian electoral officials have announced plans to hold national elections in December.

title: A Blueprint For U.S. Forces
description: The new Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, has hardly settled in his seat and already the civilian and uniformed sachems of the military tribe are leaping about him with their hair on fire, urging immediate decisions. He should refuse - until he has made his most important choice.

title: Review/Rock;   The Power Of the Waif
description: The Sundays' show at the Ritz on Wednesday cruised along nicely until it hit a reef of coyness, then sank. The band, from England, has been successful on the college circuit, offering airy, elongated tunes that conjure up paradisaical images. Major or ambiguous harmonies support pretty melodies sung by Harriet Wheeler, and the whole world seems fine. And sensual: Ms. Wheeler, who has ivory high notes, works a wispy, waiflike quality into the music that comes off as emotional and intelligent.

title: Truth of Reputation?
description: In seeking to suppress the Vietnam documents [the Pentagon Papers] , the Government asserted that their continued publication in The New York Times would ''cause irreparable injury to the defense interests'' of the U.S. If this assertion were true, the case against publication would have been strong indeed. The protection of military security constitutes an entirely proper limitation on the freedom of the press and on the ''people's right to know.''

description: BRICK used for decoration - it is called facing or veneer brick - is thinner than ordinary brick, yet requires the same skill and time to apply.

Mrs. Pauza is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Sabo of Short Hills, N.J. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William V. Pauza of Hershey, Pa.

title: His Mrs.'s Voice
description: Should courts divide between two what God has given to one? In one of the more notable recent tests of the premise that a husband or wife who aids in a spouse's rise to fame is entitled to a share in the value thereof, a New York court last week rejected a claim by Peter Elkus, former husband of the opera star Frederica von Stade. The two met as aspiring music students; she went on to become an internationally acclaimed mezzo-soprano, he went on to become her photographer, adviser and voice teacher. When their 17-year marriage ended, Mr. Elkus claimed that his wife's fame was marital property that he was entitled to share. Her lawyer argued, and the judge apparently agreed, that marital property does not include one spouse's ''God-given talent or recognition.'' Mr. Elkus's lawyer said he would appeal.

title: Tutu Addresses 3,000 In New Rochelle Forum
description: LEAD: ARCHBISHOP Desmond M. Tutu, speaking last week at the College of New Rochelle, expressed cautious support for President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa, saying the president deserves ''considerable credit for courage.''

ENVIRONMENT;

Indians' Odd Foes

After a bitter contest, Congress awarded the Indians 185,000 acres that the environmentalists had wished, instead, to have included in an enlarged Grand Canyon National Park.

description: Leslie Ann Okinaka, an associate at the Richmond law firm of Hunton & Williams, and Dr. Paul Edward Juan, a pediatrics intern at the Medical College of Virginia in Richmond, plan to marry in November.

Stock funds followed suit, with the average fund losing 15.5 percent for the quarter ended Sept. 27, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc..

I couldn't explain to them that I saw Snow White and the Cowardly Lion and the alligators every morning. That there were no fantasies in California that I had not seen in New York.

D'Amato should file away the paragraph describing his Senate-floor performance, tearing up the catalogue of the Serrano exhibit. Such demagogic buffoonery may be appropriate for a minister from Tupelo, Miss., but it is surely out of place from a Senator who represents a state so heavily invested in the arts - emotionally, philosophically, spiritually and economically - as New York.

Mrs. Barr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Everts of Lancaster, Pa., graduated from Villanova University and received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. She is a vice president at the United States Trust Company of New York. Mr. Barr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. A. Barr of Omaha, received B.A. and J.D. degrees from the University of Nebraska and a master's in tax law from New York University. He is the director of tax planning at the Kyocera Corporation, an electronics concern in New York.

description: The Pipino in the title of Sam Henry Kass's ''Lusting After Pipino's Wife'' at Primary Stages is an immigrant dishwasher who speaks no English and who has made love to his wife every single night of their marriage. Pipino's wife and the mother of his dozen or so children has never known another man and is so accommodating to Pipino's every whim that she doesn't even object to his fooling around with a waitress on the side.

But in Chicago the answer is as likely as not to be Comiskey Park, the home of the White Sox, a park that is actually four years older than Wrigley, and in many ways possesses much more of the character of this great city.

description: The afternoon and arguably the season having been wasted, the Mets exited the dugout and stole one final glance at the scoreboard, desperate for a late change in the lopsided score from St. Louis.

title: Lit Wit
description: HISTORICAL FICTIONS: Essays. By Hugh Kenner. (North Point, $24.95.) In these book reviews and short essays, Hugh Kenner is like the albatross in Baudelaire's poem: his giant wings prevent him from walking. His mind hefts too much bulk for these cramped forms, and why shouldn't it? A professor of English at Johns Hopkins University, the author of 24 books, personal friend to Ezra Pound and Samuel Beckett, Mr. Kenner has written many of the greatest works on modernism, and if his ideas on everything from literary preservation technologies to the new Oxford English Dictionary unfold well beyond the edges of a newspaper column or a magazine page, all I can say is, more power to him. What is remarkable is that given the pressure of such expansive knowledge, Mr. Kenner still manages to write apt, amusing prose. Of dull literary biographies he snipes: ''From gossip the book-writer sucks a goo called information, to cement edifices of assertion with.'' Of leisure in literature he boldly declares: ''Fiction was always about people on vacation - people in free-fall. Don Quixote was not punching a time clock.'' Of Wallace Stevens he almost coos: ''Not-quite-Milton, a sort of Origami Milton, the paper phoenix fluttering in the wizard's hand.'' Mr. Kenner is an old-fashioned critic, the kind who sprinkles his brilliant microscopic readings with personal anecdote (''Sam [Beckett] could be exasperatingly denying''), the kind whose stylistic imitations are, indeed, the sincerest form of flattery (Tom Wolfe is ''the nonchalant master of the neon-piped sentence''), the kind who, to the certain dismay of his academic colleagues, blithely ignores the past two decades of critical theory (as well as much of anything having to do with minorities and women). No matter - go somewhere else for theory. Stick with Mr. Kenner's ''Historical Fictions'' when you want to remember that literature is not only the best intellectual exercise around, it is also supposed to be fun.

description: Melissa Lawson Margetts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Thomas Margetts 3d of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard George Jaeger, a son of Patricia Jaeger of Garden City, L.I., and George F. Jaeger of Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. David P. Hegg, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

description: I am by no means unrealistic, even though I am an optimist. I knew that no single act, or even a combination of acts, could bury the past easily. But I do believe that great goals are reached through patience and perseverance. Each step helps. This process culminated in November 1977 with my sacred mission to Jerusalem.

title: Patricia Hodge Steps Off the Page
description: When British Television and film directors are looking for style and poise with a strong sexual undercurrent, they tend to send for Patricia Hodge. She played the fiction-writing mistress in the BBC's version of Fay Weldon's ''Life and Loves of a She-Devil''; the languid, classy, dog-toting Monica in ''Hotel du Lac,'' and the deceptive, enigmatic Emma in the film of Harold Pinter's ''Betrayal.'' Something of a Pinter specialist, she now plays a 1940's divorcee enmeshed in lies and treachery in his dramatization of Elizabeth Bowen's novel ''The Heat of the Day,'' a Granada TV production that received strong critical praise when it was broadcast in England last year and which is to air tonight at 9 on PBS's Masterpiece Theater.

Northeast Notebook: Washington;

description: Fred Holland guided viewers through a strange private realm in ''What I Like About Us.'' The haunting dance that he presented on Thursday evening at the Ohio Theater was based on a case study of twin sisters who never spoke to each other. Instead, they developed their own secret gestural language.

description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some restaurants that offer special chicken dishes.

title: Sports of the Times;   Mets Turn Off the Television Set
description: This time there was no sense in Bud Harrelson's trying to exercise X-ray vision through the media swarm so he could watch the Pirates and the Cardinals on the tube, the way he did Friday night when there was still a realistic hope. He had heard the score, and he knew the score. ''My family is here,'' Harrelson said, ''and we'll go have something to eat.''

title: Data Update
Environment Bankruptcy
description: The Superfund is a fiasco, and the debate over the terms of its renewal after its expiration Oct. 1 reveals the bankruptcy of the environmental movement.

description: THE recession has paid its first dividend to Long Island diners. Restaurant Zanghi in Glen Cove has lowered its prices and changed its name, menu and outlook. These changes have not adversely affected the restaurant. Nicola's measures up and retains Restaurant Zanghi's longtime top rating.

title: Social Events

title: Gathers Suits Are Restricted
description: A court has thrown out parts of negligence lawsuits filed in the death of Hank Gathers, ruling that Gathers's aunt and brothers cannot sue for emotional distress inflicted when the college player collapsed on a basketball court and later died. California's Civil Code requires plaintiffs in such cases to be heirs or parents.

title: I Don't Want to Be in That Number When the 'Saints' Go Marching In
description: As a former semi-flower child, fervent peace marcher and honorable hippie of the 60's, I find it mildly amusing, at best, to observe the various Presidential hopefuls as they jockey for position. And as they each proceed to package themselves and become dangerous parodies of one another, it is there that my amusement ends.

title: Baseball;   Clemens Returns to Spark Red Sox
description: The crescendo rose from every nook and cranny in which Boston Red Sox fans were crammed into Fenway Park today.

title: From the Ashes, Church Is Rebuilt
description: LEAD: ON June 5, 1986, the sanctuary of Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale was destroyed by a fire investigators believed to be arson-related, although no suspect was ever found. Almost immediately fund-raising began so the church could be rebuilt. Next Sunday, the fruits of those labors will be evident when the new sanctuary - constructed on the site of the old - will be dedicated.

title: Arts Groups Hope to Work Around Aid Cuts
description: LEAD: WHEN Carolyn Clark recently filed into the New Jersey State Museum auditorium here, she carried her pocket calculator.

title: A Triathlete at Age 60: Defying the Expected
description: WHEN she is just taking it easy, Ethel Autorino bikes 50 miles a week, runs 30 miles and swims another 7. But when Ms. Autorino, who is 60 years old, trains for a major competition, it is another story altogether. Then the numbers soar.

title: Victoria Thaler Marries Toby Cabot
description: Victoria Louise Jane Thaler, the daughter of Mrs. Vincent G. O'Gorman of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Dr. Richard W. Thaler, was married yesterday to Chilton Lyons Cabot, a son of Lynne O. Cabot of Dedham, Mass., and Chilton S. Cabot of Quincy, Mass. The Rev. Spencer M. Rice performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston.

title: Review/Opera;   The Public and Private In 'Rigoletto' at the Met

title: With or Without Art, Performance Perseveres
description: The problem with jazz documentaries is that they rarely get the right balance beween art and music. THELONIOUS MONK; STRAIGHT, NO CHASER (1990, Warner, $89.95), to be released Oct. 17, goes easy on the art. Unfortunately, the commentary is rudimentary, and there's virtually no explanation about Monk's importance. But the footage of Monk is extraordinary. We see him at the Village Vanguard in the company of his friend the Baroness Nica de Koenigswarter, whom he gently pokes of; traveling in Europe with a big band, and at a Columbia Records recording session.

title: Sakharov's Answer
description: Mikhail P. Malyarov (First Deputy Prosecutor General) -When you began a few years ago to engage in what you call public activity, we could not possibly ignore it and we paid close attention. We assumed that you would express your opinion as a Soviet citizen about certain shortcomings and errors, without attacking the Soviet social and political system. Lately your activity and statements have assumed an even more harmful and anti-Soviet character. You denounced the Socialist system in our country, calling it a system of maximum nonfreedom, a system that is undemocratic, closed, deprived of economic initiative, and falling to pieces.

title: Gant Is Among the Select Players Eligible for Arbitration

description: The day began with a thudding. Jolts waked me. It was six in the morning. We were Jews in Vienna in 1938. Everything in our lives, including our beds, stood on a cliff.

title: A New Role for Mother Hale

Now, she and the institution she established, Hale House, are embroiled in a dispute with city and state agencies over a change in state foster care policy. It's in the interest of both sides to reach a compromise, so that a valued institution can continue to serve the city's children.

description: Perusin' the news, as I have been for a while, I was surprised to find myself dissected, directed and interjected.

title: Suzanna Benson Weds
description: Suzanna May Benson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy K. Benson of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Kevin Michael Rumon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Rumon of Delmont, Pa. The Rev. Joseph H. Gilmore officiated at the South Presbyterian Church. Mrs. Rumon, 27 years old, graduated from Skidmore College and is a consultant to the South Central Connecticut Water Authority in New Haven. The bridegroom, 29, received bachelor's and master's degrees from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. He is a manager at Textron Lycoming, which makes turbine engines in Stratford, Conn.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Faithful Few at Remnant Of Howard Beach Case
description: For the last month, a black woman from the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and a small group of white men and women from Howard Beach, Queens, have faithfully appeared at an otherwise sparsely attended trial in a Queens court.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Should The Yanks Rebuild The Team?
description: The Yanks should rebuild by acquiring Rickey Henderson, Winfield, McGee, Bonilla, Whitson, Rijo, Drabek and Tewksbury. They had all of these guys; obviously, their services were superfluous to the dynasty of disaster in the Bronx.

title: Food;   Wunderbar!
description: Though my mother claimed she was born to cooking the way a sultan is born to wives, she did, in fact, very little of it. To be fair, my mother worked, so when she stepped off the train and sped home in her tiny Ford Anglia at night, she was more than kaput. Yet on Saturday afternoons, unwound and melancholy, she'd put on her high-heeled slippers and get creative in the kitchen.

title: Man of Letters
description: In Hollywood, where Archibald Leach became Cary Grant, the ''X'' rating last week had its name changed to ''NC-17.'' The change, announced by Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, came amid a rising chorus of complaints that the trade association's rating system was outdated and unfair. Filmmakers complained that because the X designation had come to be strongly identified with pornographic films and many theaters would not exhibit them, producers were effectively barred from making serious films containing material that might earn the dreaded X. The change came just a day before the director of ''Harry and June,'' a new big-budget film from Universal Pictures, had intended to challenge the rating system, and the X it gave his movie, at a hearing in New York.

title: Man Thrown From Window Of Apartment in the Bronx
description: A 33-year-old man, his hands bound behind him, was thrown from a sixth-floor window of an apartment building in the Bronx Friday night, the police said.

title: Far Beyond the Fringe
description: In April 1961, the fourth man of a comedy revue seemed quiet and less anarchic than his fellow performers. He and his cohorts - Jonathan Miller, Peter Cook and Dudley Moore - had created a new satirical revue called ''Beyond the Fringe,'' and they were doing a run-through of the show in a theater bar in London for a prospective producer. Afterward, the impresario sighed and said he wasn't at all sure it would work. In any case, ''The fair-haired one will have to go.''

title: We Must Change Our Lives

title: If the Written Word Is Really Dying, Who Is Patronizing The 'Superstores?'
description: It has become de rigueur to predict the demise of the American reading public. In his book ''The Closing of the American Mind,'' which, ironically, became a best seller, Allan Bloom wrote that ''our students have lost the practice and taste for reading.'' In a just published book called ''The Death of Literature,'' Alvin Kernan of Princeton University declares that reading books ''is ceasing to be the primary way of knowing something in our society.''

title:
The Executive Life;

title: Criticizing Sentencing Rules, U.S. Judge Resigns
description: Federal District Judge J. Lawrence Irving, who has presided over a series of highly publicized cases in San Diego, has announced that he is resigning because he believes Federal sentencing guidelines are too harsh.

title: Plastic Gnomes in Washington
description: Conscious though I am that the American political structure is as different from the British political structure as chalk from cheese, the Watergate inquiry terrifies me when I watch it on my TV here in London. It confirms all my suspicions that there are too many men in the world, and that this is not a good thing.

title: Exotic Birds Flock to Bridgeport
description: LEAD: A GROWING colony of monk parakeets, rarely spotted so far north, is making lots of noise in Bridgeport. Bird experts say they are not sure just how the parakeets settled in the city's affluent Black Rock section, but the brilliantly colored green-and-yellow birds are causing conflict between bird-watching tourists and local residents, who say they wish the squawking birds would shut up and fly back to Buenos Aires.

title: Block That Vietnam Myth
description: By the end of 1968, most of the top echelon of the Johnson Administration had concluded that the war was unwinnable. When Lyndon B. Johnson declined to run for a new term, he left the problem of extrication to his successor.

title:
VIETNAM;

The Demise Of South Vietnam
description: LEAD: Was the defeat of South Vietnam inevitable? Ultimately, yes, under the conditions that prevailed - specifically, total violation of the Paris agreement by Hanoi; United States impotence and the negative conduct of those nations that were to assure success of the agreements. But emphatically not from a lack of courage and heart by the long-suffering Vietnamese soldier.

title: Concert Will Feature 3 Prokofiev Premieres
description: The American premieres of three works by Sergei Prokofiev will be presented by the Riverside Symphony in its opening concert of the season on Oct. 11 at Alice Tully Hall. The concert, which commemorates the centennial of Prokofiev's birth and the ensemble's 10th season, will feature the composer's Andante (Op. 29), Chant Symphonique (Op. 57) and Suite from ''Le Pas d'Acier'' (Op. 41). Prokofiev was born on April 23, 1891.

title: Streetscapes: The Dorilton;   A Blowzy 1902 Broadway Belle
description: In its day it was considered the architectural equivalent of a fist fight, but critics' tempers have cooled off on the subject of the 1902 Dorilton apartment house at the northeast corner of 71st and Broadway. Over the years large hunks of its blowzy decoration have been removed, leaving it more curiosity than contretemps.

title: On the Reef, a Changing Island
description: ''You won't recognize the place,'' our Australian friend said when I told him we were going back to Lady Elliot Island. ''It might be too civilized for you now.'' My husband and I had been there in 1981, when it was the well-kept secret of a handful of Queenslanders. Lady Elliot, the most southern of the more than 700 coral islands that comprise the 12,000-mile-long Great Barrier Reef, had been open to tourism since 1969, when a landing strip was pounded right down its middle (it's the only island on the reef to have one). But it was tourism of an exceedingly primitive nature.

title: Insensitivity
description: To the Editor: From what I saw and heard on a visit to Rome, Venice and Florence, American tourists are more admirable than tourists from other countries. However, there were moments when I wished that some Americans would have stifled it. Some of their comments were not only derogatory to the country, the culture and the people, they were also quite self-revelatory. For instance: ''My hotel room has a terrible view. I'm going to have it changed. All I am looking at is just a dumb, dirty, old wall.'' (This lady must have been talking when our guide explained as we approached the hotel that the wall was built by Emperor Aurelian (A.D. 270-275).

title: Why Schools Belong in Offices
description: The preliminary census results remind us once again that America is not an agrarian society. Probably less than a quarter of the population lives in rural areas, and even fewer toil in the amber fields of grain. Why is it, then, that the American educational system continues to be based on an agricultural model? A respite during the summer and short school days made sense when children were needed at home during harvest and chore times, but currently it is competitiveness that counts, not cows.

title: Style Makers;   Charles Nicholas, Hair Dresser
description: Charles Nicholas opened a hair salon recently for the person who does not like going to the hair dresser. It's not just for women: 40 percent of his clients are men, and of these, 50 percent have their hair colored.

title: Kathleen Dougherty Weds
description: Kathleen Mary Dougherty, a registered nurse at the White Plains Medical Center, and Michael William Troiano, an assistant treasurer at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. John Kauta officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Dougherty of North Salem, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Roger P. Troiano of Huntington, L.I. The bride, 26, and Mr. Troiano, 25, are graduates of Fairfield University.

title:
Focus: Massachusetts;

Low-Cost Houses Thrive in Soft Market
description: LEAD: In the slow residential real estate market of the Northeast, where prices are falling and construction financing is tight, Massachusetts builders with a history of successful projects are finding that it pays to put up less costly entry-level homes - condominiums and single-family dwellings priced from $97,000 to $150,000 and affordable by people earning from $35,000 to $60,000.

title: No Headline
description: As an active and concerned cyclist, I commend Assemblymen Cimino and Mecca for advocating helmets for bicyclists. This effort is long overdue in a state like ours, which has heavy traffic and too many careless and ignorant automobile and truck operators, who pay no attention to the fact that bicyclists have equal right to public road access.

title: Campus Life: Kenyon College;   Obscenity Clause To Prompt Journal To Refuse Grant
description: The Kenyon Review, one of the nation's leading campus literary journals, will refuse a $7,500 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts because of an obscenity clause that is a condition of acceptance.

title: Hard-Headed Detente
description: The debate over detente has become so charged with emotion that substance gives way to semantics.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a caption about bilingual music on Sept. 2 rendered the name of a bandleader incorrectly. He is Valerio Longoria.

title: Hong Kong Unsure of Value of Refugee Pact
description: When a new accord on the return of Vietnamese boat people from Hong Kong's crowded detention camps was announced last weekend, Government officials here hailed it a breakthrough. But in the past few days, officials have admitted no one is certain if the program will have any effect at all.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have several hardwood floors that are badly scratched in several places. There are black marks where a heavy piece of furniture was moved. Is there any way I can restore the finish in these areas?

description: To the Editor:

title: Ministry For Gays Is Revived
description: After a rocky start, an Episcopal ministry for gay men and lesbians is resuming here with a new director, a renewed church welcome to spiritually isolated homosexuals, and a quieter approach to the sensitive issue of blessing gay and lesbian relationships.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SAMS IN A DRY SEASON. By Ivan Gold. (Seymour Lawrence/Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Jason Sams, the blocked novelist and creative-writing professor whose story is told in ''Sams in a Dry Season,'' counsels himself to ''beware romans a clef.'' Ivan Gold himself has clearly not followed this advice. A writer who has not published fiction since the 1960's, when he produced a short-story collection, ''Nickel Miseries,'' and a novel, ''Sick Friends,'' also about Sams, Mr. Gold has devoted his new novel to the travails of a hero who seems remarkably like himself. And although Mr. Gold doesn't state so directly, numerous allusions point to the same cause for both men's long silence: alcoholism that nearly destroyed career, health and marriage. Not surprisingly, this painful narrative, which concentrates on a brief period in 1976, reads more like autobiography than fiction -Mr. Gold even switches abruptly from third-person to first-person narration in the final passages - and the book has both the merits and difficulties of a personal account. Mr. Gold's insights lend immediacy to Sams' suffering, and his portrayal of the man's self-delusions allow the reader to share an alcoholic's viewpoint in nearly unparalleled fashion. We see vividly how the humiliations to which Sams subjects himself, ranging from missed student conferences to cleaning out a friend's supply of ale, create a private hell whose misery inevitably leads to more abuse. Yet few human lives have the thematic tautness of a novel, and the one chronicled here sometimes sprawls all over, with forays into past events and relationships that are never fully explained. The excess is also stylistic - seen in pages of unpunctuated, stream-of-consciousness prose, undoubtedly illustrative of drunken ruminations but extremely hard to follow. It is easy to wish, too, for more attention to detail. Mr. Gold never reveals how the down-on-his-luck Sams manages to support his family when, sans job, he finally joins Alcoholics Anonymous. But some beautifully realized portraits, particularly of Sams' parents, Orthodox Jews trying to eke out a living on New York's deteriorating Lower East Side, show Mr. Gold's talent. His return is welcome.

title: New Housing Outlook For New York Is Gloomy
description: Production of new housing in New York City rode a strong economy to a 14-year high last year, but the good news for a housing-starved city will probably not last long. Developers say that with inventories of market-rate housing high and buyers scarce, the city's private home-building sector will soon be as quiet as a vacant apartment.

title: Sports People;   Charger Speaks Out
description: He suffered a concussion, facial fractures and other injuries that will require surgery and an estimated 10 weeks of rehabilitation, but Joe Phillips, the San Diego Charger nose guard who received the injuries in a confrontation with three men early Wednesday morning, wants the world to know that he wasn't in a fight. In his first public statement since the incident, Phillips said he was the victim of an unprovoked assault. ''It was completely unprovoked,'' he said in a statement released through the Chargers.

title: Morristown Show Is Lure for Collectors
description: CRAFT collecting can be habit forming. Just ask inveterate collectors; they will be easy to spot among the nearly 15,000 visitors who are expected to turn out for the Morristown Craftmarket next weekend.

title: Pernicious Thinking
description: It is not that there is no truth in many of the things that people say and believe about the Russians; it is rather that what they say and believe involves a great deal of exaggeration and oversimplification. And this is serious, because there are times when exaggeration and oversimplification, being harder than falsehood to spot, can be fully as pernicious.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

If It's Fall, Can the Clothes Be Far Behind?
description: LEAD: THE semiannual ritual of getting out or putting away the summer or winter clothes has been known to cause night sweats and hives. I am able to approach this task only by viewing it as alternative service to purgatory.

This play-within-a-play, about the first theatrical performance in 18th-century Australia, requires that the actors play not only actors but also opposite sexes, as well as British convicts and officers.
