title: Works in Progress;   The Scary 64
description: Analysis of a pap smear, the early-detection test for cervical cancer, is still performed manually. A smear may comprise 100,000 or more cells, as few as half a dozen of which, in an afflicted woman, may be abnormal; the analysis is conducted by a technician - a cytotechnologist - with a microscope, who may examine 100 slides a day. And though perhaps 98 percent of samples are benign, the rate of false negative reports - that is, samples with precancerous cells that have been overlooked - is up to 30 percent in some labs.

title: Lisa Beth Nachtigall, Intern, to Marry
description: Dr. Lisa Beth Nachtigall, an intern at New York Hospital-Bellevue Medical Center, and Robert Charles Flaumenhaft, a student at the New York University School of Medicine, plan to marry in April.

title: Ms. Locke Plans A Fall Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Locke of New York and Waccabuc, N.Y., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter, Katie Locke, and Oren Rod Aviv, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Aviv of New York.

title: Susan K. Ziegler Marries Albert Saltiel in New Jersey
description: Susan K. Ziegler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Ziegler of Chatham, N.J., was married there yesterday to Albert Saltiel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alberto Saltiel of Oakbrook, Ill. The Rev. James Mahoney performed the ceremony at the Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church.

title: Mercury 'Living Presence' Comes to Life Again
description: For many record collectors, restorations of favorite recordings from the past constitute one of the most valuable benefits of the compact disk. While the emphasis in most such cases is on preserving exceptional performances, the Mercury ''Living Presence'' reissues, just released by Philips after more than two years of painstaking preparation, will be every bit as interesting to audiophiles as to music-lovers, even though some of the recordings are more than 30 years old.

title: Campus Life: Colorado;   After Coors Gift, Arena Renaming Angers Students
description: Student groups that receive money from the student government at the University of Colorado will no longer be allowed to accept support for fund-raisers and other activities from the Coors Brewing Company, student legislators decided last week.

title:
THE LITERARY EYE;

A Guide to Civil Disobedience
description: LEAD: In perpetrating a revolution, there are two requirements: someone or something to revolt against and someone to actually show up and do the revolting. Dress is usually casual, but if either faction fails to attend the whole enterprise is likely to come off badly. In the Chinese Revolution of 1650, neither party showed up and the deposit on the hall was forfeited.

title: Greece
description: To the Editor: Americans should know what is happening in Greece. My family spent $10,000 to stay five weeks in a house by the sea, and we couldn't even flush the toilet. A strike made electricity (and, as a consequence, water) a scarce commodity. It is a shame that the Government could not guarantee its citizens and visitors a basic necessity.

title: An Endurance Test For Horse and Rider
description: LEAD: SIXTEEN years ago, Cheryl and Stagg Newman received doctoral degrees from Cornell University and, freed from the rigors of academic life, they started looking for a hobby they could share.

title: Kelly S. O'Connor Wed in Bermuda
description: Kelly Suzanne O'Connor, the fashion editor of Town & Country magazine, and Gerard Pasciucco, an associate in the investment banking division of Morgan Stanley & Company, both in New York, were married yesterday at Christ Church in Warwick, Bermuda. The Rev. Frederick J. Marshall performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: If You Want to Know How Dinkins Is Doing, Just Ask Ed Koch

In his new life as a print and broadcast commentator, Mr. Koch so regularly takes aim at the Mayor that some wonder whether he is really pontificating or merely vindicating his own legacy.

title: WILDMON'S WAR ON THE ARTS
description: It seems Wildmon's son, Tim, reports that his father likes to relax at home by watching nature shows on PBS. The nature specials are featuring more and more mating footage because it genuinely fascinates us. Does the good reverend change the channel at graphic scenes depicting the wooing of a female Australian fruit bat by her visibly tumescent mate, or does he remain riveted in his comfy armchair?

title: Los Angeles County Deputies Accused of Brutality
description: Last February, William Leonard was stopped by police officers who apparently thought he was armed, was ordered to place his hands behind his head and, as he tried to kneel, was killed by 33 bullets fired into almost every part of his body. His 18-year-old daughter watched.

description: The reality of the bottom line often creeps into Frank Viola's professional conversations, an understanding that there is very little consolation in his business. Near the end of a 19-victory season, Viola looks at the three most recent bottom lines and does not like what he sees.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE EAGLE AND THE RAVEN. By James A. Michener. (State House Press, Box 15247, Austin, Tex. 78761; $19.95.) Waste not, want not. It's generally good advice, especially in this era of social and environmental responsibility. And it can usually be applied to writers, since most are pack rats when it comes to their own prose. Consequently, when one of James A. Michener's former assistants, who had recently established a small Texas publishing house, approached her one-time boss and asked permission to publish a chapter he'd written seven years earlier for his novel ''Texas,'' he leaped at the chance. ''Yes!'' he reports in the lengthy and somewhat self-promotional introduction to ''The Eagle and the Raven.'' ''I spent a lot of time on that chapter, but nobody else felt it should be included in the book, and for good reason. It was written outside the normal story-telling pattern. . . . I hated to cut it, but had to.'' And so Mr. Michener presumably reached into a dark corner of his file cabinet and came up with this rather slight text, a comparison of the American politician and frontiersman Sam Houston and the Mexican general (and oft-time president) Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna, the man responsible for the massacre at the Alamo - history with a bit of fiction thrown in for good measure. This is an odd sort of book. First, there is that introduction, in which Mr. Michener, now in his 80's, recaps his distinguished career. Then there are the alternating chapters detailing and contrasting the lives of Houston and Santa Anna. It's difficult to imagine who the audience for a book like this might be, other than die-hard aficionados of Mr. Michener or Texas history. But even they might be disappointed, given that the writing is rather flat, its tone not unlike that of a high school textbook.

title: Reagan and Iran-Contra
description: The disappointment that accompanied the release of President Reagan's Iran-contra testimony is unwarranted. If there were no revelations, no smoking guns, no sudden confessions, that's because we have known since the hearings ended in the summer of 1987 all that is knowable about the affair. What was known was disturbing and ugly enough. What was unknowable could be inferred with a little common sense and imagination.

description: To the Editor: Many Americans lease new French automobiles under special terms available to foreigners. However, the unique color scheme required for the lessee's license plates creates a novel security problem.

The Rev. Thomas Genis officiated at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Washington. description: An assistant football coach at Hofstra University was shot to death early yesterday outside a restaurant near the school by a man in what appeared to be a bungled robbery attempt, the police said.

Recently, while doing research, I was going through old newspapers and found the puzzle in a Sunday New York Times dated March 22, 1942. As an avid crossword puzzler, I made a copy of it and set about solving it.

Mr. Leigh, 26, is a son of Henry A. Leigh 3d of Old Greenwich, Conn., and the late Joan A. Leigh. title: My Baseball Years
description: In one of his essays, George Orwell writes that though he was not very good at the game, he had a long hopeless love affair with cricket until he was 16. My relations with baseball were similar. Between the ages of 9 and 13, I must have put in a 40-hour week during the snowless months over at the neighborhood playfield - softball, hardball and stickball pick-up games - while simultaneously holding down a full-time job as a pupil at the local grammar school; as I remember it, news of two of the most cataclysmic public events of my childhood - the death of President Roosevelt and the bombing of Hiroshima - reached me while I was out ''playing ball.'' My performance was erratic; O.K. for those easy-going pick-up games, but lacking the calm and the expertise that the naturals displayed in stiff competition. My taste, and my talent, such as it was, was for the flashy whiz-bang catch rather than the towering fly ball; running and leaping I loved, all the do-or-die stuff -somehow I lost confidence waiting and waiting for the ball lofted right at me to come down. I could never make the high school team, yet I remember that in one of the two years I vainly (in both senses of the word) tried out, I did a good-enough imitation of a baseball player's style to be able to fool (or amuse) the coach right down to the day he cut the last of the dreamers from the squad and gave out the uniforms.

title: A New York Firm Sets the Style In Chicago
description: Chicago hasn't seen so presumptuous an architectural invasion from New York since Richard Morris Hunt and Stanford White swept into town to drop their Beaux-Arts extravaganzas into the World's Fair of 1893. But what else to call the now ubiquitous presence of the New York architectural firm Kohn Pedersen Fox in Chicago? Since completing the stone and glass skyscraper at 333 Wacker Drive in 1983, KPF, as the firm is widely known, has designed three other towers that have risen in Chicago, including two that are among the city's tallest. Its architecture has become nearly as conspicuous on the skyline here as that of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the vast architectural firm whose name is as much a part of Chicago lore as Mayor Daley's.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, excerpts last Sunday from a document described by the Iraqi Government as a transcript of a meeting between President Saddam Hussein and the United States Ambassador to Iraq misattributed some remarks. A corrected version of the passage appears today on page 21.

title: The Beholder's Eye
description: Scientists still debate the definition of life, so who is to say what art is? In a case that has seized the attention of the art world, the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati and its director, Dennis Barrie, went on trial last week on charges of pandering obscenity and illegal use of a minor. At issue were seven photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe that were part of a retrospective of the artist's work at the museum last spring. Leading museums around the country have displayed the same works as art but the Cincinnati prosecutors said they violated local standards of obscenity in a city that has banned peep shows, adult book stores, X-rated videos and Hustler magazine. If so, Mr. Barrie could get a year in jail and a $2,000 fine - unless it develops that Cincinnati's enforcement of its standards violates constitutional guarantees.

title: Sports People;   Islander Dispute
description: The general manager of the Islanders, Bill Torrey, confirmed yesterday that the absence of the team's star center, Pat LaFontaine, from the final week of training camp was linked to a contract dispute. Torrey, who joined the Islanders in California yesterday for an exhibition game against Los Angeles, said he had not yet been able to meet with LaFontaine but has had numerous discussions with the player's agent, Don Meehan.

title: So Young!
description: RABBIT AT REST

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Ear Transformed

title:
COUNTERPOINT;

Housing the Homeless
description: LEAD: As the debate rages over emergency shelter for New York City's homeless, the essential issue - affordable housing - is, as usual, being ignored.

title: Dress Code Unites Parents and Students
description: LEAD: ON the first day of the school year, most of the children in a Hempstead elementary school wore the same clothes. It was the first step toward a dress code, the only one in effect in a Long Island public school.

title: Editorial Notebook;   The Last Jewish Farmer
description: ''Come meet the last Jewish farmer in Lithuania!'' says Emanuelis Zingeris, a restless young scholar and member of Parliament, at the door of the Vilnius Photography Gallery. He strides over to greet 78-year-old Joshua Matzkin, a genial man with a red nose, bushy eyebrows, two gold teeth and a tight gray beret.

title: Scientists Seek One-Shot Children's Vaccine
description: The United Nations Children's Fund and the World Health Organization are calling on world leaders to support an intensified effort to produce a single children's vaccine that could in one shot eradicate diseases that kill nearly eight million children each year and cause some 900 million cases of severe illness.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last week about Volkswagen A.G. referred incorrectly to a sensor used on an experimental car that can park itself electronically. It is ultrasonic, not supersonic.

title: Mary Jarratt Marries William Dunn
description: Mary Claiborne Jarratt, a food and pharmaceutical marketing consultant, and William Wyly Dunn, chairman of the International Business Law Firm, both in Washington, were married there yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church at Lafayette Square. The Rev. Dr. John C. Harper performed the ceremony.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: These days no one thinks twice about getting film processed. We shoot it, we take it to a lab around the corner, we get prints back in a day or two. The simplicity of the system and the near omnipresence of processing facilities undoubtedly have helped fuel the boom in 35-millimeter picture taking.

title: Q and A
description: Broker's Fees

title: Lawyers in Celesteville? Babar Is in Court
description: When Babar returns from the Old Lady's house in the town to the great forest, he brings with him many city things, including a dapper green suit, a derby hat and a red roadster. But there is one part of grown-up life he does not bring back with him. He does not bring any lawsuits.

title: Rural Areas Hurt by Landfill Law
description: The enactment of the Long Island landfill law [''Long Island Flounders in Closing Landfills,'' Aug. 29] was because of concern that toxins from garbage were poisoning drinking water. The law indiscriminately affects rural areas that are not in the deep-recharge area and do not have toxins leaking from their garbage sites. The Suffolk County Department of Health findings show no concern for public health and no significant groundwater threat. Attention must be paid to these reports that will save taxpayers money on closing and landfilling liners that are not necessary.

title: Rutgers, Confronts A Crossroads
description: ACROSS from Old Queens here, workers are completing a $9.6 million renovation of Winants Hall, a stately 100-year-old building, in preparation for its dedication in November as a new administrative center. With the building refurbished inside and out and with the lawn freshly sodded, Winants is yet another example of Rutgers's decade-long drive to transform itself from a tired state university into a first-class institution of higher education and research.

title: Useless 'Japan-Bashing'
description: There are several possible things to do when you don't know what else to do about a problem: You can rant and rave, kick a door, look for a Communist or - the latest fad - jump on Japan.

title: Ms. Falk to Wed In December
description: Mrs. William J. McDonough of Chicago has announced the engagement of her daughter Melanie Borden Falk to Roderick Ian Vere Nicoll, a son of Mrs. Douglas Vere Nicoll of Charlottesville, Va., and the late Dr. Vere Nicoll. A December wedding is planned.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Should The Yanks Rebuild The Team?
description: Pay whatever price is needed for a power hitter. Strawberry would be great, but there are others out there. On the mound, the Yankees need to look hard and pay a lot for another starting pitcher.

title: Review/Music;   Manhattan Symphony on a Forgotten Man
description: For anyone who attended Thursday evening's concert by the Manhattan Symphony and took in the current program of the New York Philharmonic either before or after, a skewed sense of deja vu was inevitable. The Philharmonic is leading off with two works of Barber, including ''Medea's Dance of Vengeance.'' The Manhattan School of Music ensemble, in its first concert of the season in John C. Borden Auditorium, began with a third work of Barber, the ''School for Scandal'' Overture, and a ''Medead'' by another Pennsylvania composer of the so-called lost generation, Vittorio Giannini.

title: Formulating Impeachment
description: The impeachment process under way poses novel and unusually difficult challenges to lawyers, to men in government, indeed to all of us. We write upon an almost clean slate. Little law or political precedent is available to guide the hard decisions. Yet, regardless of the outcome, the value of the proceeding will depend on whether the process is so conducted that the country perceives it as a fair and legitimate measure for restoring integrity to government.

title: Television's Independents: Working on a Slippery Slope
description: Critics and viewers have embraced NBC's new Monday night situation comedy, ''Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' about a streetwise teen-age rap artist from Philadelphia transplanted to a wealthy section of Los Angeles. But the show is notable for another reason as well - one that is giving the shakes to independent television producers, and might give pause to viewers, too.

title: Design;   COMING OF AGE
description: Last year, it was the new kid on the block. This year, the International Antique Dealers Show is seen as the first indicator of the direction that the art market will take. Although only in its second year, the show has fast eclipsed all the other American antiques events with its seriousness and its outstanding quality of offerings.

title: Voltaire and the Jews
description: To the Editor:

title:
VOICES OF A NEW GENERATION;

Growing Up in the Shadow of AIDS
description: LEAD: I was 12 years old when AIDS was first identified, and my entire generation came of age under its shadow. It existed during our first kisses, first dates and first relationships, bringing to an end a decade or two of sexual freedom. AIDS put my generation in a position closer to that of our parents than our older siblings and forced us to become responsible for our actions before we really wanted to.

title: Witness From the Prosecution
description: ROUGH JUSTICE

title: English, Not Spanish
description: Mine is a Spanish-speaking household. Instilling in my children a sense of ethnic identity is my role; it is not the role of the school system. The public schools have the responsibility to teach skills needed in public life - among them the use of the English language. I differ with educators who advocate bilingual education programs whose goal is to preserve the Spanish language and culture among children of Hispanic families.

title: It May Be War, But It's Not In Video Stores
description: ''FOR THIS ONE I WANTED TO CARVE THE territory finely,'' said Ken Burns, producer of ''The Civil War,'' the acclaimed documentary aired on PBS last week. Mr. Burns was discussing the video release of his latest work on two separate sets of cassettes - one from PBS Video (for schools, libraries and other institutions) and the other from Time-Life Video (for home viewers) - and why that came about when many documentary makers have enough trouble managing one video release.

title: Pro Football;   Dallas to Test Giants' Defense
description: Two weeks ago, when the temperature on the Astroturf field at Texas Stadium reached 122 degrees, the Giants routed the Dallas Cowboys, 28-7. On Sunday, they will meet again at Giants Stadium, and the Giants figure to dominate again.

title: Beauty;   LIVING WITH LABELS
description: ''wiggle.'' kind of a cute, giddy little word, evocative of all sorts of endearing, warm and fuzzy traits. It's also the color of a lipstick (pink, actually) and one of a slew of uber-cosmetics labels from Ultima II. ''Wiggle'' as a name doesn't say much about the actual color - or the product - but who cares? (Nobody ever really knew what those deceptively explicit color titles, like ''Hibiscus'' and ''Think Pink,'' meant anyway.) It's all very misleading as far as products go, and yet. . . . There is something about these punchy names that sells.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the avant-garde misstates the schedule for the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It begins Tuesday and runs for 10 weeks, not 5.

title: Learning to Live When Life Is a Welsher
description: Midway through ''Falsettoland,'' the stirring musical by William Finn at the Lucille Lortel Theater, a beleaguered housewife named Trina sings of the difficulty of ''holding to the ground, as the ground keeps shifting.''

title: Autumn Game With a Touch of Tuscany
description: THE late Alfredo Viazzi had for years a trio of successful restaurants in Greenwich Village, the best of which was Trattoria da Alfredo, where he served Tuscan food. In the early 70's, when to most New Yorkers Italian cooking still meant eggplant parmigiana and spaghetti with red clam sauce, his food was a revelation.

title: Artillery Duels Violate Liberian Truce
description: Rebel armored units fought a fierce artillery and rocket duel today with Government troops trapped inside the executive mansion and the main army barracks here in the capital.

title: Esther Cohen to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Cohen of Brooklyn, have announced January wedding plans for their daughter Esther Deena Cohen and Chaim Shlomo Kahn, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Nachman Kahn of Oak Park, Mich. Miss Cohen, 22 years old, graduated from the State University Health Science Center in Brooklyn and is serving her affiliation in occupational therapy at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. Mr. Kahn, 25, expects to graduate from the University of Maryland in January. He is also an advanced scholar at the Ner Israel Rabbinical College in Baltimore.

title: The Troubles of South Asia Take Over on Campus
description: Struggling to exist on meager budgets while fighting perennial battles to stay open through bouts of political turmoil and violence, the universities of South Asia are in trouble.

title: Amid Socratic Groves, a Place For Thinkers and Dreamers
description: In a museum world that grows more giddy by the hour, an example of quite another sort is being set by the Art Museum here, which reopened early this year after a four years' closure for expansion and renovation.

title: Pop, Pre-Pop and Rivers
description: To the Editor:

title: They've All Got Automobiles
description: I came up to the big league 58 years ago this fall in Brooklyn, and if you ask me if I'm discouraged by the state of the world these days, I'd have to say I am disappointed by a few things.

title: 200 Years Of Sexism Rampant
description: Maybe women should use 1976 to challenge the American dream, not celebrate it. After all, 1776 was the year women's powerlessness was first enshrined in the Constitution.

title: WILDMON'S WAR ON THE ARTS
description: I'm tired of hearing people complain about their hard-earned tax dollars going to smut.

title: On the Hudson, a Fleet Of Sculls Will Race
description: LEAD: On Saturday, Riverfront Green Park in Peekskill will be the scene of what Mayor Richard E. Jackson Jr. predicts will be ''the beginning of a new tradition in the city'' - the first annual Challenge of the Hudson rowing regatta.

title: Annex, Expel
description: Will Israel opt for Jewishness and survival or democracy and national suicide?

title: Youth Program's Mixed Day: $100,000 Won, $250,000 Lost
description: A Cambridge, Mass., youth training program hailed as a model for the nation got a dose of good news and a jolt of bad news on the same day last week.

title: Group Seeks to Prevent Nuclear Space Probe
description: An environmental group asked a Federal judge on Friday to stop next week's scheduled launching of the space shuttle Discovery with the nuclear-powered Ulysses probe in its cargo bay.

title: 1776 and All That
description: REDCOATS AND REBELS

title: Jazz Guitarists for the Not So Progressive
description: In most American pop and jazz criticism, orthodoxy is a dirty word, used to smear the virtue of a backsliding musician who ignores the party line. The party line, derived from a European Romantic ideology that places the artist in opposition to repressive bourgeois babbitts, states that progress and value are synonymous. Which does nothing for American music - often designed to appeal to a lot of people, including babbitts out on a Saturday night. That isn't to deny the radical impulse. But any American esthetic that can't make sense of Duke Ellington as well as Elliott Sharp, of the Jungle Brothers and Hank Mobley, doesn't have much going for it.

title: A Holiday Quiets India After a Week of Rioting
description: After a week of disturbances marked by the self-immolation of young Indians protesting the extension of an affirmative action plan for the poor, the cities and towns of north India were largely quiet today as people prepared for a major Hindu holiday.

title: Halpin's Budget: The Costs of Service Cuts
description: LEAD: WITH his new budget, Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin is emerging as a major proponent of stopping property-tax increases, but possibly at a significant political cost.

title: Australia's Sunshine State
description: Like most Queenslanders, I'm prepared to admit that there are few city sights more stunning than Sydney viewed from one of the harbor ferries or from the windows of the Opera House restaurant; and I'll even concede that Melbourne (Bleak City, as we denizens of the Sunshine State call it), with its wide boulevards, elegant architecture, cafe society and sidewalk restaurants, has an Edwardian graciousness and Parisian ambiance that Brisbane rivals only in a few neighborhood pockets of terrace houses close to its subtropical heart.

title: Official Says Soviet Blast Affected 120,000
description: An explosion at a nuclear fuel processing plant in the Soviet republic of Kazakhstan this month may have contaminated 120,000 people, a local environmental official said today.

title: Study Revives Debate on Shoreham
description: LEAD: A STUDY released by the Long Island Power Authority last week found that converting the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station to natural-gas fuel would be sensible and economically beneficial. The study paves the way for the authority trustees to decide by early next year whether to proceed with such a project.

title: More Grandparents Helping Their Families With Child Care
description: LEAD: THREE mornings a week, Gloria Kirkwood travels 17 miles to care for her 3-year-old granddaughter, Casey Ackermann, in Westfield. Arriving around 8 o'clock, Mrs. Kirkwood stays until 7:30 P.M., when both her daughter and son-in-law return from work. By 8 P.M., Mrs. Kirkwood is back in her home in Somerset

title: Baseball;   Are A's a Dynasty In the Making?
description: From deep behind the closed doors, there was only the muffled sound of joy and the sharp aroma of champagne. At the end of the night, after they had won still another American League West championship, the Oakland Athletics convened in the privacy of a laundry room - among washing machines, dirty uniforms and old boxes - and doused themselves in celebration.

title: Troops in Gulf Talk of War, And of Vietnam and Respect
description: The uniformed men and women the United States has deployed in the desert of Saudi Arabia may have only vague notions of why they are here, but they seem to have few doubts that it is the right thing to do.

title: Gregory Ruffa Wed to Lisa Gallagher
description: At St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Milton, Mass., Lisa Marie Gallagher was married yesterday to Gregory James Ruffa. Msgr. Thomas Finnegan and the Rev. John Mahoney performed the ceremony. The bride, 29 years old, will keep her name. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Gallagher of Milton. A graduate of Boston College with a master's degree in journalism from Northwestern University, she is an assistant account executive at the New York advertising agency of Backer Spielvogel Bates. Ms. Gallagher's father is a retired vice president of the Bank of Boston. Her mother, Marie Gallagher, is a special-needs teacher in the Boston school system.

title: Reds Close In On Title
description: The Cincinnati Reds won their first division title in 11 years this afternoon when they clinched the National League West championship during a rain delay as they trailed the San Diego Padres, 3-1.

title: Cool Water
description: They were the kind of couple you know have been through deco, retro, Armani, Mizrahi, Nautilus, weight training, rap, punk and fusion, who have postmodern furniture in the living room, lava lamps by the bed and a photograph of James Dean over the toilet. She had hair like Elvis; he had hair like hers. She turned to him in the Korean grocery and said:

title: Oregon Upsets B.Y.U.
description: Oregon intercepted five Ty Detmer passes, three by Daryle Smith, and sacked the Brigham Young quarterback five times as the Ducks beat Brigham Young, 32-16, today.

title: Mr. Nixon's Feelings
description: When Democrat caucuses in Congress threaten to cut off funds if a settlement is not reached by a certain date, they are deliberately encouraging Hanoi's representatives at the peace negotiations to hold off agreement on any kind of a settlement until after that date. I can understand the frustration which is so rampant in Congressional circles because of Hanoi's backing and filling on provisions for arranging a cease-fire. I can also understand the unhappiness caused by the renewed bombing of North Vietnam on orders of President Nixon. The frustration on Capitol Hill cannot begin to equal the frustration in the White House. And it does Mr. Nixon's critics no credit to run around suggesting that President Nixon is gleefully bombing North Vietnam out of a spirit of hatred or revenge.

title: Jean L. Kirk Is Married To William R. Toupin
description: Jean Lois Kirk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Kirk Jr. of Rumson, N.J., and Jupiter, Fla., was married yesterday to William R. Toupin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland G. Toupin of Margate, Fla. The Rev. Synesio Lyra Jr. performed the ceremony at the Coral Ridge Presbyterian Church in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Postings: Advice From Experts;   How to Care for a Brownstone
description: Built-up roofs. Limestone pointing. The dread specter of parapet failure. Who would recognize those terms of the New York housing scene but the brownstone restorer, whose weekends are spent in such close communion with the foibles of old row houses?

title: Sports People;   Tensions Mount
description: Things got pretty tense this season between the Padres' best hitter, Tony Gywnn, and some of his San Diego teammates. They accused him of being a selfish player more interested in improving his statistics than in helping the team. Since Gwynn left the team two weeks ago with a broken finger, feelings against him seem to have gotten worse. Now he's being accused of deserting the team and commenting on his critics.

title: Margaret Salisbury Marries Thomas W. Burdick
description: Margaret Walker Salisbury, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gifford R. Salisbury of Buffalo, was married yesterday to Thomas Walton Burdick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walton E. Burdick of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Birth Of a Style
description: A new page demanded a new editorial art, and The New York Times, which had rejected traditional, captioned editorial cartoons decades before the Op-Ed page was conceived, sought an unconventional illustration style as the page's visual signature. The solution was a hybrid form, neither captioned cartoon nor literal illustration - rather an art that used metaphor, allegory, literary allusion and personal iconography, not to slavishly illustrate but to complement a text.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;

Bringing Braille Into the Computer Age
description: LEAD: Some blind people say that one of the biggest barriers between them and the sighted world is a written language unsuited for the high-technology age. If Braille, the method of reading and writing with raised dots, were modernized, they say, it would be easier for them to do mathematics and work on computers.

title: WILDMON'S WAR ON THE ARTS
description: Bruce Selcraig's article ''Reverend Wildmon's War on the Arts'' (Sept. 2) brings up a moral issue of far greater significance than whether or not the National Endowment for the Arts should offer grants to artists whose work might offend the proprieties of some, or even many, Americans. If Government grants were to be awarded only to those projects that reflect the values of most Americans, how could we justify the enormous sums (far greater than any given to artists) granted to agencies and individuals for the research and development of weapons, poisons and other chemicals intended for the destruction of humans and the planet?

title: Review/Rock;   A Nostalgic Mix of Tex-Mex Styles
description: Popular music respects no borders, and Tex-Mex rock is proud of its dual nationality, mixing up Mexican polkas, Texas blues, rhythm-and-blues and rock and roll. The Texas Tornados, who opened a two-night stand at the Lone Star Roadhouse on Thursday night, bring together four of the most important figures in music from the United States side of the border.

title: Street-Fighting Woman
description: The F.B.I. told us that violent crimes rose again last year and that forcible rape took the biggest jump of all, a whopping 11 percent. It is not unrelated that at the age of 38 I have solemnly embarked on a dedicated program of self-defense instruction.

title: College Football;   Overmatched Yale Routed by UConn
description: Connecticut's biggest concern coming into today's contest against intrastate rival Yale was Darin Kehler, the all-Ivy quarterback and offensive star of the Eli wishbone attack.

title: The Inn Is Old, but the Menu Is Not
description: LIKE the buggy whip, the village of Ivoryton's raison d'etre disappeared long ago. Once the center of a thriving industry in piano keyboards, in an era when the keys were made of elephant tusks, Ivoryton derived its name from its major industry, and some of the imposing houses along the main street belonged to merchants in the ivory trade.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: MADISON;

Town Tries to Foster Lower-Cost Housing
description: LEAD: AS a single parent and schoolteacher, Polly Dee LeClaire said, she can barely afford to continue living in Madison, the town that her illustrious forefather, Phineas T. Meigs, helped to found. Although family friends helped her find an apartment with a reasonable rent, ''I have no prospect of making a down payment on a house here,'' she said.

title: Get Moving on AIDS
description: The time has come for the Government to underwrite a nationwide effort to produce an effective vaccine against HTLV III, the virus that causes AIDS. Though a frightening new disease, AIDS is no longer so novel that such an effort would be premature.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

For a Memorial To the Holocaust, A Night's Memories
description: LEAD: A PLAN is taking shape to build a memorial in Westchester to the victims of the Holocaust. A monument such as this, no matter what physical form it may take, will, as a concentration camp survivor put it, document the past and serve as a commitment to the memory of those who have perished.

title: William Stewart Weds Amy Geer
description: Montrey Amy Geer, an investment banking consultant, and William Hadden Stewart, the editor of Eastern Europe Times, a daily business and financial newsletter, both in Washington, were married yesterday at St. James's Episcopal Church in Monkton, Md., by the Rev. Heyward H. Macdonald.

title: Miss Cox Marries Philip Clippinger
description: Jenner Girard Cox, the daughter of Mrs. John E. Avery of Princeton, N.J., and D. Michael Cox of New York, was married yesterday to Philip Edward Clippinger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Clippinger of Princeton. The Rev. Wallace Alston performed the ceremony at Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton.

title: Q and A
description: Parisian Fashion Shows
